Re: Vocabulary

Post by katherinegibson » Thu Sep 04, 2025 9:00 am

RENDER -- to prove or give (Oxford Languages). In regard to the first letter and after reading the syllabus, I believe this word is meant for students to realize that they will render their own knowledge and become vulnerable to learning more. It will allow us to admit that we don't know everything, and we must be open to learning and accepting new aspects about ourselves.

IMPLICIT -- implied though not plainly expressed (Oxford Languages). To relate it back to the first letter, I think that "Implicit" is for students to realize that there are implicit instructions that's incorporated in this course. It involves the idea that learning isn't what is lectured or instructed to us, but we must find ways to reflect and become engaged with what is said to us.

EXPLICIT -- stated clearly and in detail, leaving no room for confusion (Oxford Languages). Based on the first letter, this must relate to the fact that there will be some instruction that students are meant to find explicit. We have a portion of clear guidelines that we must fulfill to have success in this class.

COGNITIVE FORM -- the process of knowledge being developed in the brain (Oxford Languages). Predicated on the first letter, this word is meant to enrapture that students must view this class as cognitive form, not just recalling a basic definition of these vocabulary words.

KNOWLEDGE -- awareness or familiarity gained by experience of a fact or situation (Oxford Languages). After reading the first letter, I conquer that this word is for students to accept that knowledge will always be increasing/expanding. With reading each other's vocabulary posts, we gain new insights and learn a little bit more with each one.

KNOW -- to be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information (Oxford Languages). I think this word is used to have students realize they will need to recognize that awareness and involvement is necessary to genuinely have "knowledge" on something. So, as said before, we will need to engage with these words and actually make an effort to reflect based on the context of the letters and our own thinking style.

INWARD -- directed or processing toward the inside, coming from the outside (Oxford Languages). The first letter makes me believe that this means students should be self-reflecting during this course in order to gain the most out of it. It requires learning external knowledge (such as the google searches) but also makes us understand ourselves more as we navigate which definition is best and how it relates to the letter given to us. This will showcase how our thinking works -- which in turn makes us know more about ourselves.

UNFOLD -- reveal or disclose (thoughts or information) (Oxford Languages). This word relates to students as it is the descriptive word for how our learning will run its course. It will slowly unfold throughout the semester. As new ideas and perspectives are given to us, we unfold new knowledge.

COMPREHENSIBLE -- able to be understood; intelligible (Oxford Languages). What was interesting is that this word only has one definition in the Oxford Languages Dictionary. This proves to me that this word has a very universal understanding of what it is. But it relates to the letter and syllabus because I take it as a sign that students will find that acquiring new knowledge is more comprehensible when we make an effort to actually connect new ideas, observe, and simply listen to what others have to say.

Re: Vocabulary

Post by katherinegibson » Mon Sep 08, 2025 3:36 pm

AWKWARD – not smooth or graceful (Oxford Languages). I think in relation to the letter, this describes how learning may go throughout this course. As said in class, this class is not “linear”, and so we’re expected to make mistakes and have awkward moments, but that just means we (Students) are adjusting.

ROLE – the function assumed, or part played by a person or thing in a particular situation (Oxford Languages). I think this means that every student is going to have to figure out their role in this class. Because we bring different perspectives and diversity, each of us have our own role in these letters in giving our perceived thoughts.

EXPECTATION – a belief that someone will or should achieve something (Oxford Languages). I believe this can relate to how the class will run. Students have expectations of themselves that they are trying to perform and produce, but that’s not what the professor is explicitly looking for. As said in class, we aren’t supposed to worry about the “grade” and the “A” is what most students strive for in every class. So, this word gives students a new meaning of what is actually expected of us and how we will contribute to this learning curve between ourselves and other classmates.

NEGOTIATE – obtain or bring about discussion (Oxford Languages). People will have different ideas that they post and it all adds to the discussion.

SHARE – a part or portion of a larger amount which is divided among a number of people, or to which a number of people contribute” (Oxford Languages). Each student in this class is going to share some type of confusion or concern and that’s part of the learning journey the professor has set up for us.

UNDERSTANDING – the power of abstract thought; intellect (Oxford Languages). With each “letter” that we receive, we will all gain new intellect that will affect how we learn and think.

CONCEPT – an abstract idea; a general notion (Oxford Languages). Throughout these letters, we will learn new concepts that will add to our learning. We will start branching out to forming new ideas and concepts that we most likely wouldn’t have thought of before.

WORD – a single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing, used with others (or sometimes alone) to form a sentence… (Oxford Languages). To create discussions and provide our own thinking, we need words. Words are how we communicate in the classroom, and it enables humans to share ideas and knowledge.

ASSEMBLAGE – the action of gathering or fitting things together (Oxford Languages). As we go through this course, our ideas and perspectives will start to click, and we learn how to successfully navigate this class.

IDEA – a thought or suggestion as to a possible course of action (Oxford Languages). Students communicating their thoughts and understanding will lead to students forming new ideas on different aspects of learning.

MEANINGFUL – having a serious, important, or useful quality or purpose (Oxford Languages). These discussions and posts will become meaningful, as each post has a purpose and that is to lead to collaboration and the exchange of understanding across various subjects.

Re: Vocabulary

Post by katherinegibson » Tue Sep 09, 2025 2:09 pm

STRUCTURE – the arrangement of and relations between the parts or elements of something complex (Oxford Languages).

SYNTAX – the arrangement of words and phrases to create well-formed snetences in a language (Oxford Languages). We use syntax to be able to portray different ideas and form new conversations.

SYMBOL– a thing that represents or stands for something else, especially a material object representing something abstract (Oxford Languages).

IMAGE – a representation of the external form of a person or thing in art (Oxford Languages). Exchanging ideas and statements allows students to create new images in their head.

REPRESENT – be entitled or appointed to act or speak for (someone), especially in an official capacity (Oxford Languages).

PERSONIFY – attribute a personal nature or human characteristics to (something nonhuman) (Oxford Languages).

INCARNATE – embody or represent (a deity or spirit) in human form (Oxford Languages).

EMBODY – be an expression of or give a tangible or visible form to (an idea, quality, or feeling) (Oxford Languages).

MANIFEST – will (something) into being by the exercise of mental powers or through force of belief (Oxford Languages).

Re: Vocabulary

Post by katherinegibson » Wed Sep 10, 2025 1:43 pm

COHESIVE– tending to unify, harmonize, or be consistent (thefreedictionary.com). Being cohesive allows for better performance on tasks and a better sense of belonging among groups of people.

GROUP– a number of people or things that are located close together or are considered or classed together (Oxford Languages). It involves having forming relationships and people coming together.

SOCIETY– the aggregate of people living together in a more or less ordered community (Oxford Languages). The larger the society, the more likely it will be that groups start to operate and form identities

CULTURE– the customs, arts, social institutions, and achievements of a particular nation, people, or other social group (Oxford Languages). As this class continues, the culture will change. We will develop new cultural habits, such as creating meaning, reading others' thoughts, and actually registering the new information we learn.

CONJURE– implore (someone) to do something (Oxford Languages). With the words we use to exchange new ideas and perspectives, we are able to bring it into a discussion. That implores us to learn something new.

TEXT– a written work chosen or assigned as a subject of study (Oxford Languages). The text we write is the backbone of the discussion that transforms our interpretations.

TRANSPARENT – easy to perceive or detect (Oxford Languages). Students have an obligation to be transparent with their thoughts and be vulnerable to letting others see how we think, which adds authenticity.

SUSTAINABLE– able to be maintained at a certain rate or level (Oxford Languages). The class vocabulary posts must be consistent so the practices continue. It seems that, after previous classes, the way we’re learning will carry forward into future classes.

GENERATIVE– relating to or capable of product or reproduction (Oxford Languages). The work students are doing is going to spark new discussions, and it is going to expand our knowledge. The fishbowl acts as a community that will generate growth for everyone.

Re: Vocabulary

Post by katherinegibson » Sat Sep 13, 2025 10:15 pm

PRACTICE– the actual application or use of an idea, belief, or method, as opposed to theories relating to it (Oxford Languages). Students are committed to practice the action of google searching and forming new ideas when reading other posts.

SORT – a category of things or people having some common feature; a type (Oxford Languages).

SIFT– examine (something) thoroughly so as to isolate that which is most important or useful (Oxford Languages). It is easy for us to filter out ideas that don’t resonate with us but that will only hinder the learning process.

SELECT– carefully choose as being the best or most suitable (Oxford Languages). We, as students, are using our best judgement to select the definition that fits the best though our google searches.

SUBSTITUTE – use or add in place of (Oxford Languages).

LISTEN – give one’s attention to a sound (Oxford Languages). Students have enough humbleness about them to hear out other perspectives.

ELEMENT– a part or aspect of something abstract especially one that is essential or characteristic (Oxford Languages). Each word used is an element to form the definition each student chose to display.

WHOLE– all of; entire (Oxford Languages)

STRUCTURE– the arrangement of and relations between the parts or elements of something complex (Oxford Languages). Students are creating sentences that showcase a purpose. Because students think differently; reading these definitions enable the majority of the other students to see how someone else thinks.

Post by vanessajayala » Thu Sep 11, 2025 10:42 pm

In the Wisdom Library, the textual world "encompasses the foundational texts underpinning Buddhist rituals."

In the Textual world of the bible, "its composition and intertextuality are what make it a representation of reality."

In the text world theory is "a cognitive linguistic model of human discourse processing."

Three different websites I visited all gave different but similar meanings. The textual world refers to the imagined universe created within written text, where characters, settings, events, and ideas exist independently from the real world. Authors build a textual world to convey meaning, explore themes, and create emotional responses. It becomes vivid and believable, inviting readers to interact in unique ways. The textual world serves as a bridge between the author's intentions and the reader's understanding.

Re: Vocabulary

post by EamonMcLaughlin » Thu Sep 11, 2025 5:46 pm

Vocab 1

Render: To cause or to become. EX: The sinkhole rendered the road useless.

Implicit: Implied, rather than expressly stated. You must infer what is wanted.

Explicit: Fully and clearly expressed or demonstrated. Being told directly what is wanted.

Cognitive Form: The act or process of knowing, perceiving. How you understand things.

Knowledge: everything you know to be true with the information you have.

Know: What you understand to be the truth with a degree of certainty.

Inward: What is towards the center or inside of something.

Unfold: to make something no longer folded or to watch a reveal of something.

Comprehensible: Making something understandable for people to easily get.

Re: Vocabulary

post by EamonMcLaughlin » Thu Sep 11, 2025 6:03 pm

Vocab 2

Awkward: A feeling of embarrassment often in social situations.

Role: A small part by a person in a greater group.

Expectation: What you believe something should be in the future.

Negotiate: Talking with another person to find a middle ground that you both can agree on.

Share: Giving an idea or physical object to someone so they can also experience it.

Understanding: The ability to comprehend why a person says or does something. It could also mean being able to comprehend complex topics.

Concept: An idea of something formed by mentally combining all its characteristics

Word: A single thing spoken or written and multiple can create a sentence. The basic building block for every sentence.

Assemble: To put together or gather in a place

Idea: A thought that comes to a person

Meaningful: Putting a good amount of effort into what you are doing so others will see that you have tried.

Re: Vocabulary

post by EamonMcLaughlin » Thu Sep 11, 2025 6:16 pm

Vocab 3

Structure: Any type of building or an organization of things to form a group or plan.

Syntax: An arrangement of rules of patterns that form a sentence.

Symbol: Something used to represent a person, place, thing, or idea.

Image: A physical representation of a person, place, or thing.

Represent: To show others another's values with your actions and words.

Personify: To embody or represent an idea or person.

Incarnate: to embody something in physical form.

Embody: to give a concrete form to an idea or belief

Manifest: A record of people on a mode of transportation or a belief that you will obtain something.

Re: Vocabulary

post by EamonMcLaughlin » Thu Sep 11, 2025 6:30 pm

Vocab 4

Cohesive: Things that stick together and don’t come apart. It can be physical or mental.

Group: Any collections of people or things.

Society: An organized group of people that share things in common such as beliefs and morals.

Culture: A quality in a person that is shared and promoted by a group of people.

Conjure: To call something into existence from nothing.

Text: Any form of writing that people can read such as books, scrolls, or messages on a phone.

Transparent: Something that is see through or a person who is trying to be as honest as possible.

Sustainable: Something that is able to be maintained with minimal effort.

Generative: Something that is able to create new things.

Awkward: Something or someone that is clumsy, lacks grace, is difficult to handle or use, or causes embarrassment in social situations.

Role: The function assumed or part played by a person or thing in a particular situation.

Expectation: A strong belief that something will happen or be the case in the future.

Negotiate: To obtain or bring about something by discussion.

Share: A part or portion of a larger amount which is divided among a number of people, or to which a number of people contribute to.

Understanding: The ability to understand something and or comprehend it.

Concept: An abstract idea; a general notion. Something conceived in the mind like a thought.

Word: A single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing, used with others, or sometimes alone, to form a sentence.

Assemblage: A collection or gathering of things or people.

Idea: A thought or suggestion as to a possible course of action.

Meaningful: Something that has meaning, depth, purpose and importance.

Subject: Assignment 1: Sharing Reflections on our Names

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. My antecedents are from Punjab in India/Pakistan and the Sikh greeting is Sat Sri Akaal, which means Truth is Eternal. And Namaste, the predominantly Indian greeting, acknowledges the spirit in you. I like the short American version: Hi there!

At birth we are given a name which has a historical, cultural and contextual meaning. This word, one’s name, is a symbol and has an image attached. We personify the name and we are its manifestation, or indeed, we are not. We are the incarnation or embodiment of a person or idea.

We enter the world with a syntax. Please read your postings in the fishbowl in that light. Please see Ridouane Cailloce’s posting below as an example. 

So what structure do you represent? To address such a complex question, it is best to start at your beginning. Hence the first assignment.

Assignment 1

Post by Ridouane Cailloce » Sun Sep 07, 2025 11:09 pm

The name Ridouane is not very common, right ?

I discovered while looking for some information about it that the name Ridouane has a lot of derivatives (Radhwan, Redouane, Redwan, etc.).

In addition, the name Ridouane comes from the Arabic name ridwãn, which means satisfaction, pleasure, and approval at the same time.

Even though this name isn't used that much throughout the world, its Arabic roots show that I have a meaningful name !

Indeed, as mentioned previously, this names could refer to pleasure but it also refers to an angel called Ridwan, who's in charge of keeping one of the seven heaven's gates.

As a reference in the islamic religion, this names embodies spiritual and positive connotations, as well as divine flavor and a life pleasing of God.

Therefore, I always wondered why did my parents gave me this name in particular ? Why Ridouane specifically and why not another name ?

So, according to my parents, due to the fact that my mother is French and my dad is Algerian, they both wanted to give me a religious name.

In facts, I am a muslim, and so my parents are, so they decided to look for a muslim name obviously, but an orignal one.

At first they were questioning about Nasser, but my mother thought Ridouane would be better, due to its meaning.

They wanted me to be unique, orignal, to have a strong and beautiful personality. So my parents agreed on calling me Ridouane, with that orthography especially, to make it more rare, and original.

So that's my name, Ridouane, a name that conveys a strong message based on religious beliefs, and I am very proud of my name, I would never change it for any other names.

Re: Vocabulary

post by LukeJerman » Sun Sep 07, 2025 3:59 pm

Render means to create or become something. When I think of rendering the first thing that comes to mind is a computer rendering. Render has a lot of definitions but I like to think of it as causing or developing something.

Implicit means implied or connected closely with something. If something is implicit it doesn't need to be said. If two ideas are implicit they are very closely tied together.

Explicit is the opposite of implicit. It's something that is clearly defined. Simple terms that leave no room for interpretation.

Cognitive is the process of your mind. Thinks applies to anything you learn, study, or think about. When I hear this word I think of cognitive thinking which refers to how the brain processes information.

Form is shaping something. When you form something you change its identity into what you want it to be.

Knowledge is the things that you understand. If you have knowledge on a topic you know the ins and outs of it.

Know are the things you are aware of.

Inward is going towards the middle. Looking inward is looking deep into something.

Unfold means to open or reveal something. If you unfold a situation you are looking deep into it to see what happened.

Comprehensible is something that is easy to understand. If you comprehend something you understand it fully.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/3/2025 15:49:57
Subject: Syllabus for MGT 448: International and Cultural Dimensions of Business
------------------------------------------------------------
UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION

FALL, 2025

Sanjiv S. Dugal, Ph.D.

314 Ballantine

Human Resource Management

Address: sanjivdugal@uri.edu

Office Hours: MW: 1-2 pm

MGT 448

INTERNATIONAL AND CULTURAL DIMENSIONS OF BUSINESS

PREFACE

“As we globalize, we increasingly have to interact, manage, negotiate, and compromise with people from different cultures. Working with people whose values and beliefs, as well as languages and customs, differ from your own can lead to costly misunderstandings. Experience tells us, often painfully, that one’s behavior, actions, and decisions are not separate from one’s values and beliefs. All social behavior is embedded in a particular context and is connected to other deeply held values and beliefs. This means that the stakes are high for mismanaging cultural differences.” (Lisa Hoecklin, 'Managing Cultural Differences: Strategies for Competitive Advantage,' The Economist Intelligence Unit Series, Addison-Wesley, 1995)

I. INTRODUCTION 

How do you navigate and negotiate a situation that is foreign and strange? A situation where the Other's language, customs, and culture (values and. beliefs) are unknown, and you have no predetermined script nor map on the ground. Under these circumstances, what skills are necessary to collaborate successfully on projects together?

II. PROBING DIFFERENCES

"In a global marketplace, many leading international business scholars are arguing that sustainable competitive advantages are increasingly changing from ‘harder ’ efficiency sources to ‘softer ’ effectiveness sources, such as managing differences in values and beliefs. Our differences provide a reflective lens to see where we're positioned concerning each other." (Hoecklin).

In the course, we are comparing broad value differences between America and Japan, America and China, and America and India. Values, according to Geert Hofstede’s definition, are ‘a broad tendency to prefer a particular state of affairs over others.’ The course identifies four dimensions of value differences across cultures, viz., Power Distance, Uncertainty Avoidance, Individualism/Collectivism, and Masculinity/Femininity. 

Managing differences among ourselves gives the course not only an identity but also its competitive advantage. The course fulfills the logical sequence of: 

Awareness (of differences among ourselves), 

Knowledge (of those differences), and 

Communication (of those differences). 

These three traits, viz., awareness, knowledge, and communication, underlie the development of cross-cultural skills (Geert Hofstede). Empirical evidence suggests that creating sustainable advantages when interacting with people from different cultures, at home and abroad, will require the following skills:

a. an ability to express

b. flexibility in thought and action

c. sharing and disclosing one’s position in a situation

d. abstracting from the particulars of an interaction

During the semester, we are developing these capabilities on a digital platform called The Fishbowl.

III. METHODOLOGIES: PARTICIPANT OBSERVATION, INTERPRETIVISM, SYMBOLIC INTERACTIONISM

The course utilizes research methods such as Participant Observation, Interpretivism, Social Reflexivity, and Symbolic Interactionism for addressing Cultural questions such as:

How do you experience the Other’s culture?

That is, how do you experience the Other’s deeply held values and beliefs?

What do you see?

How do you feel?

What did you do?

IV. TEXT

1. Letters in the Fishbowl: The Fishbowl is a social network of writing/viewing/experiencing. The Fishbowl is something knowable only through specific fishbowl practices and contingencies that occur during the semester.You will receive around 100 letters explicitly written to you for safe-keeping and re-reading, because the text in the letters represents a potential effect that is realized in the reading process. 

Reading is therefore your focal point, for it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend both on the text and on the exercise of your basic human faculties.

2. ‘Exploring Culture, Exercises, Stories and Synthetic Cultures,’ by Gert van Hofstede, Paul B. Pedersen, and Geert Hofstede. Intercultural Press, Boston, London, 2002.

Real-life exercises and stories, all accompanied by debriefings, make this book ideally suited for self-study. Specific activities and exercises are steps towards awareness and knowledge of differences. We will practice intercultural communication skills, and playfully experience what it feels and means to be a ‘foreigner.’

3. Films: Kinky Boots, Japanese Story, Moonrise Kingdom, Outsourced, Iron & Silk.

We deconstruct and decode text and images to discern the underlying cultural assumptions and structures that are at play.

V. GRADE DISTRIBUTION

1. Regularity and Quality of Participation in the Fishbowl: 50%

There will be ongoing assignments that will help you develop a knowledge and understanding of the four dimensions of culture-related values, namely, identity (individualism/collectivism), gender (masculinity/femininity), power distance, and uncertainty avoidance. These interactive assignments are 50% of your grade.

2. Attending to Meaning in Social Space: 30%

We attend to meaning by sharing, responding, and listening to each other. Working in the Fishbowl is an interactive practice of shared words, symbols, images, and felt-experiences. Your process will be assessed by the importance you place on 'attending to meaning.' 

“When operating in a global economy, if you want your philosophies, objectives, products, and services to be not only understood but also believed by employees, customers, and partners in different cultures, you must attend to what these things mean to the people in each culture.” (Hoecklin, p.3)

3. Final: A Self-Reflexive Process 20%

In the final analysis, you’re exploring differences in meanings that existed when working together on a particular idea. Your final paper (3 pages, double–spaced and constructed individually) presents your fishbowl experience as a coherent idea. You're obliged to become self-reflexive, suspend preconceptions, and reflect upon the culture of a fishbowl at the University of Rhode Island.

VI. SELF-ASSESSMENT IN THE FISHBOWL

Learning is about actively combining enriching experiences with academic rigor and creative opportunities. Interaction during the semester requires the courage to push back against the boundaries of past experiences and explore the possibilities available to you. In MGT448, you experience the excitement of discovering what you are capable of achieving, far more than you ever felt or thought possible. The following elements are essential for this experience:

* Knowledge

* Concept

* Skill

* Attitude

* Action

The student is able to make accurate self-assessments at any point during the semester based upon the following criteria:

BEGINNING (B) 

You have basic knowledge and skills. 

DEVELOPING (D)

You are making conceptual connections. 

ACHIEVING (A)

You have acquired knowledge and skills, and are making conceptual connections, thereby developing new learning.

EXCELLING (E)

You are applying knowledge and skills beyond grade-level expectations and demonstrating self-initiated action in unfamiliar situations. You are self-motivated and an independent learner.

Faster and better learning through realization is a large part of the assessment logic.

VII. CONCLUSION: FISHBOWL LEARNER PROFILE

The Fishbowl aims to develop globally minded participants who recognize their common purpose and shared responsibility in creating a culture of learning. 

As fellow participants in a fishbowl, we strive To Be the following:

1. Inquirers 

We nurture our curiosity, developing skills for inquiry and research.

2. Knowledgeable 

We develop and use conceptual understanding, exploring knowledge across a range of disciplines. We engage with issues and ideas that have local and global significance.

3. Thinkers 

We use critical and creative thinking skills to analyze and take responsible action on complex issues. We exercise initiative in making reasoned, ethical decisions.

4. Communicators 

We express ourselves with confidence and creativity in many ways. We collaborate actively, listening carefully to the perspectives of other individuals and groups.

5. Principled 

We act with integrity and honesty, guided by a strong sense of fairness and justice, and with respect for the dignity and rights of others. We take responsibility for our actions and their consequences.

6. Open-minded 

We critically appreciate our own culture and personal history, as well as the values and traditions of others. We seek and evaluate a range of points of view, and we are willing to grow from the experience.

7. Caring 

We show empathy, compassion, and respect. We are committed to service, and we strive to make a positive difference in the lives of others and in the world around us.

8. Risk-takers 

We approach uncertainty with forethought and determination, working independently and cooperatively to explore new ideas and innovative strategies. We are resourceful and resilient in the face of challenges and change.

9. Balanced 

We understand the importance of balancing different aspects of our lives, including intellectual, physical, and emotional, to achieve well-being for ourselves and others. We recognize our interdependence with other people.

10. Reflective 

We thoughtfully consider the world and our ideas and experience. We work to understand our strengths and weaknesses to support our learning and personal development.

WELCOME TO MGT 448

Hi Everyone,

Welcome to the Fall 2025 semester! I’m excited to begin this journey with you and wish you all the best for a rewarding semester ahead.

In this course, we’ll experiment with how we communicate and reflect—building habits that make learning more engaging and meaningful.

With AI becoming such a big part of our world, our focus will be on making complex ideas clearer and more usable—turning what’s hidden or implicit into something we can truly understand. In other words, our work together will be about unfolding knowledge in ways that help us see and know more deeply.

At the heart of the course is a simple question: how do we keep remaking ourselves—through culture, discipline, technology, and now AI? Instead of dwelling on abstract theory, we’ll explore practices of self-formation and survival in today’s global, technological world.

Rendering the implicit explicit will be the cognitive form for the course.

Please see Lauren Marsella’s reflection below. Her experience and way of being, I hope, will help set the stage for the semester.

Felt experiences

Post by Laurenmarsella » Thu May 01, 2025 6:09 pm

At the beginning of the semester, I was unsure about how to use the Fishbowl and what it meant to me but over time, I understood the concepts from the letters every week. It took me awhile to figure out how to post, how to reply, and what was due, but I listened, I watched others, I observed carefully each letter, and I reflected on every one. I learned so much from this course, and through the fishbowl. It taught me how to interpret vocabulary from a multiplexed lens, and to not always view everything as black and white. I was able to gain your perspective on your letters, and able to gain other people’s perspectives based on their responses. I enjoyed learning from others, and taking that knowledge and applying it through my own experience. Seeking wisdom from others and helping each other in that way is so significant, and is a crucial part of growth. I feel this semester I took with me a lot, and will carry this knowledge and awareness with me for the rest of my life. This is not only a fishbowl, it is a community. A community to learn, adapt, evolve, and change. Change how we view the world, change our mindset on how we can make a difference. I always want to be a life long learner and this class has taught me in doing so. To never stop reading, and reading, and writing. To make reading and writing a life long habit and hobby. I have a strong passion for both, and want to continue growing from this experience. This class has taught me the most, in a very special and different way. It taught me how to never give up even when I didn’t understand or couldn’t comprehend a word, phrase, or paragraph. Searching and googling to strengthen our vocabulary and expand our knowledge has been something I deeply enjoyed doing. I thank you for this class, and for this opportunity, as this class is meaningful and important for all students to take. You learn how to be a good listener, a good researcher, a good observer, and a good writer. The fishbowl is a world of its own, one that is beautiful and sacred to this course. Thank you very much.

Sincerely,

Lauren Marsella

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/2/2025 22:30:07
Subject: Syllabus for MGT345: Business and Society
------------------------------------------------------------
University of Rhode Island

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS

FALL, 2025

BUSINESS AND SOCIETY

MGT 345

SANJIV S. DUGAL

sanjivdugal@uri.edu

314 Ballantine Hall

OFFICE HOURS: MW 1-2 pm

“MGT 345 is about becoming who you are. Upon completing the course, you are not arriving at any fixed destination, nor will you find some permanent room with a view. But you will see and experience for yourselves that whenever you reach for the highest, you become who you are.” (Toni Morrison)

WELCOME TO MGT 345

 

I. INTRODUCTION: MASS MEDIA AND SCHOLARLY PRACTICE

Major social changes reshape how we experience time and space (Manuel Castells, 2010). Today, the biggest changes are happening in communication technologies, which are creating new social spaces and ways of interacting. Communication technology includes traditional tools like telephones and office hours, as well as digital innovations like AI platforms, email, social media, mobile apps, and video conferencing.

Using these technologies thoughtfully can support meaningful intellectual work. In this context, the course highlights how mass media and scholarly practice intersect.

II. BUILDING A SOCIETY: A NETWORK OF VISUAL REALITY

The question we are confronting in the course: what is your ‘way of seeing’ the world? What is the visual reality of your social space and network? A ‘way of seeing’ is the key manifestation of ‘the network society’ according to Manuel Castells. 

Participants in MGT 345 develop and experience two interrelated concepts during the semester: A Network Society and a Visual Reality. We will be creating a network of perceptual spaces characterized by the sharing of “thought images” among ourselves. Our networks reflect distinctive realities that are “individuations” and outside any regulation. That is to say, we will be developing unique social relations (forms of relatedness) that are manifestations of our networks of text and thought images. The result is a visual reality —a ‘way of seeing’ and ‘being’ in the world — that is unique to us, the participants. 

III. COURSE DICTUM: DESCRIBE THINGS

In the course, you work as a phenomenologist whose dictum is: Describe Things! The things that you describe denote any ordinary thing, object, or event as it presents itself to your experience, rather than as it may or may not be in reality. To ‘describe’ is to strip away distractions, habits, cliches of thought, presumptions, and received ideas, to return attention to what is called ‘things in themselves.’ To capture them exactly as they appear, rather than as you think they are supposed to be. Like blind-tasting! In the course, you ‘set aside’ or ‘bracket out’ theorizing and moralizing about what the thing is, so that you are left only with the intense and immediate experience of the phenomenon. 

The result is a great liberation. It frees you to talk about your experience as a serious topic of investigation. The course provides participants with a formal means of accessing their human experience. 

In other words, we’re concerned with concrete felt-experiences and individual aesthetic responses. We discuss our own lives while remaining methodical and rigorous. Our rigor is concerned with describing phenomena. Saying the music concert or the homework assignment was great is not enough. You must remain committed to telling the experience. Traditionally, we begin learning from theories in textbooks. In this course, you’re going straight for life as you experienced it at the moment. For instance, what does it mean to be in this very moment as you read this letter? Anticipation, or Intimidation, perhaps? What is it for this thing ‘anticipation’ or ‘intimidation’ to exist, To Be? Until we ask such fundamental questions, we will not make any progress in understanding the experience of these words. Our method is to disregard intellectual clutter and pay attention to ‘things,’ letting them reveal themselves.

IV. COURSE METHOD: ETHNOGRAPHIC ACTION RESEARCH

Ethnographic Action Research (EAR) is a form of participatory action research. The ethnographic approach, combined with action research, aims to build upon notions of immersion, long-term engagement, and holistic understanding of local contexts. The course combines three approaches: participatory techniques, ethnography, and action learning. (1) Participatory techniques are used to help participants understand complex issues in an inclusive and participatory manner. (2) Ethnography has traditionally been used to understand different cultures in detail, rejecting preconceived ideas and categories in favor of locally emergent ones. (3) Action learning enables us to apply what we learn from research, then research those actions, and adjust and adapt accordingly.

A foundational concept of Ethnographic Action Research is ‘communicative ecologies.’ A communicative ecology comprises communicative assemblages and refers to the complex systems of communication, media, and information flows within a community or a network of individuals. Whenever we start to notice how we communicate around particular themes or how we accomplish specific tasks, we begin to appreciate which channels and flows are used and why, how this relates to other possible uses, and therefore, what and where the opportunities and barriers to a development initiative lie.

V. “IS THERE A TEXT IN THIS CLASS?” 

You will receive around 100 letters or so during the semester. What happens to you as readers of these letters, and what does their text make you feel and do, brings into the world something that hitherto did not exist. This can be qualified as virtual reality. 

Reading the letters in a particular way is the focal point of the course because it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend on both the text and on the exercise of your human faculties (senses, wits, reason, intelligence). In other words, the letter’s text represents a potential effect that is realized in the reading process. This happens whenever you, as a reader, assemble the meaning of the letter in a process of ‘re-creative dialectics.’ 

To get the participation going, there are necessary prerequisites. These prerequisites are outlined in the letters through a wide range of specific instructions. By the end of the course, you can see how you generate and occupy ideas, abstractions, and words; how you move about, and how you conduct yourself in perceptual space.

The Instructor uses the following seminal Texts as references in MGT 345:

References:

1. Manuel Castells, 2010, The Rise Of The Network Society, Vol 1-3, Wiley-Blackwell

2. Margaret Dikovitskaya, 2005, Visual Culture, M.I.T. Press

3. David Harvey, 1990, The Condition of Postmodernity, Blackwell

4. Nicholas Mirzoeff, 2016, How To See The World, Basic Books

5. Mike Chang and Nigel Thrift, Eds, 2000, Thinking Space, Routledge

6. Zygmunt Bauman, 2003, Liquid Love, Polity

7. Anthony Giddens, 1986, The Constitution of Society, California University Press

8. Antonio Negri, 2008, The Porcelain Workshop: For a New Grammar of Politics, Semiotext(e)

9. Bruno Latour, 2007, Reassembling the Social, Oxford

10. Muriel Combes, 2013, Gilbert Simondon and the Philosophy of the Transindividual, The MIT Press.

11. Wolfgang Iser, 2006, How to do theory, Blackwell Publishing, MA, USA; Oxford, UK; Victoria, Australia

12. Michel de Certeau, 1988, The Practice of Everyday Life, Univ. of California Press

VI. PRACTICE AND PROCESS

When undertaking any developmental initiative, it is, ultimately, our sustained practices and processes that determine success. To accomplish that, you’re expected to respond under the following Topic heads regularly:

1. Short Notes: Taking and Making Notes from Google Searches, Wikipedia, and AI. 

2. Vocabulary: Defining Concepts and Thought-images from Dictionaries

3. Deep Learning: Peeling layers of Meaning and Deconstructing words 

4. Assignments: Interwoven in the above three activities

The method that is practiced in MGT345 begins with the simple act of paying attention to a word with care and respect. Word practices are found in many traditions worldwide. It is having awareness that arises by non-judgmentally paying attention, on purpose, to the present moment. Such awareness is a combination of receptivity, like listening, alertness, and attentive presence. That is, letting everything else take a backseat or letting it go entirely.

The course requires a different way of thinking —a thinking that ‘knowing’ reminds you, awakens you, brings you to yourself, and transforms you. Besides claiming to transform the way you think about doing business in society, the course promises to change how you feel about yourself within a context. There is no traced-out path that will lead you; you must constantly invent your path. But to invent it, you have to be free, responsible, and without excuse, for every hope lies within you. In the end, we have no other interest than this: to reconnect with normal lived experience. 

In MGT 345, you are developing skills to convince viewers, readers, and your audience of the advantages of your semantic and action-orienting powers. 

Your success, under the circumstances, has the following two characteristics: 

First, multiple channels of communication that helped you frame issues; 

second, credibility that is enhanced by your sustained practices and processes. 

VII, LEARNING GOALS

You will be immersed in the society and culture of a small, tightly knit community, which we refer to as the Fishbowl.

Here you are learning and understanding by living ‘a life of practice.’

You are developing word structures, word images, and felt experiences that are significant to anyone seeking to contextualize, navigate, and transform increasingly complex cultures, societies, and networks. Your life of practice in the fishbowl illuminates how to nurture creative practices from the initial spark to the finished outcome. From your in-depth accounts in the fishbowl, you will discover methods for yourselves that will help you achieve the following learning goals:

* Frame critical questions through an iterative process

* Apply hands-on, embodied learning from text and images

* Enhance seeing through closer looking

* Meet uncertainty with flexibility

* Evaluate and articulate the significance of your work

VIII. GRADE DISTRIBUTION: ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATION OF ‘A LIFE OF PRACTICE’

1. A Society of Transnational Organizations: 40%

Empirical research (Bartlett and Ghoshal) identifies four characteristics of successful transnational organizations, viz., 

Integrated Networking Structures, 

Complex Adaptive Systems, 

Dynamic Decision-Making, and 

Unique Innovative Capabilities. 

Each characteristic is developed and experienced by participants in 10 interactive and iterative steps.

2. Deconstructing Letters and Deep Learning: 30%

You are developing slower and more essential cognitive processes, such as critical thinking, reflection, and empathy, all of which are integral to deep reading. 

When do you read and post? What do you read and post? Why do you read and post? What you read and post changes how you think. The quality and quantity of your reading and posting are not only an index of the quality of your thought, but it is the best-known path to developing whole new paths.

Through analogies, drawing inferences, and forming independent judgments, you will be deconstructing texts and generating subjective experiences.

3. Final Reflection: Visual Reality and Network Society: 20%

The act of taking on the perspective and feelings of another is a form of communication that occurs in solitude and depicts an intimate emotional dimension within the fishbowl experience. Your Final is a reflection on your visual reality and network society, completed by “looking at yourself looking at yourself.” Three pages, double-spaced.

4. Individuation: 10% 

At the end of the day, after it is all said and done, your grade is determined by two things: level of engagement and creation of value. How often, how much, and to what end did you develop and individuate yourself? Individuation, or the way you distinguish yourself from others, is always in a relationship, and it is a process. Individuation enables awareness, action, and evaluation.

Date: 4/30/2025 1:44:11
Subject: implementing Bauman-Latour's mindset
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

We are at the end of the semester, and Apr.30 is the last day of classes. You may continue with your postings until the final assignment, which is due on May 1st at 6.30 pm. After that, the fishbowl will be closed for evaluation.

Please complete your student evaluation by April 30 if you haven’t already. It will be helpful to me if you leave comments regarding your experience in the fishbowl. Thank you.

I wish to leave you with some suggested implementation strategies for those who have a Bauman-Latour mindset, which you experienced in the fishbowl.

Best Mindset for a Liquid, Networked World

* Flexibility over rigidity

Always be ready to pivot. Treat plans like drafts, not monuments.

* Relationship over isolation

Success flows through connections with people, technologies, and ecosystems.

* Co-creation over top-down control

Customers, workers, and partners expect to shape outcomes with you, not just receive instructions.

* Systems thinking over linear thinking

Every action ripples outward. Manage the whole web, not just your corner.

* Tech partnership over tech mastery

Don’t just "use" tech — collaborate with it. Let it shape your strategy.

* Adaptation over perfection

In a constantly changing world, it's better to be fast and adaptive than slow and "perfect.”

 

*Fragility awareness over stability assumptions

Always ask: “What fragile system am I depending on?” Prepare backup plans early.

* Lifelong learning over set expertise

Expertise ages fast. Stay a student — curious, experimental, humble.

Mantra for the Modern World:

"Navigate the tides. Tend the web. Stay in motion."

Let's bring this mindset down to daily action: Here’s how a business (big or small) could live Bauman + Latour's mindset every single day:

Daily Action Plan for a Liquid, Networked Business

1. Morning Quick-Check Meeting (15 minutes)

Purpose: Sense the environment, not just manage tasks.

Questions to ask:

What changed yesterday (markets, tech, customer behavior)?

Are there new connections we need to build or repair?

What systems seem fragile today?

What's emerging that we can adapt to early?

Mindset: Always scanning for change, not assuming stability.

2. Weekly Ecosystem Map Update

Purpose: Visualize your business network, not just your internal team.

Tasks:

Map your key partners, suppliers, customers, technologies.

Note the strength of each relationship: strong, weak, vulnerable.

Ask: “Where are we too dependent?” “Where are new opportunities appearing?”

Mindset: You are only as strong as your network health.

3. Tech Watch Ritual (1 hour/week)

Purpose: Stay partnered with tech, not blindsided by it.

Tasks:

Assign someone (even part-time) to track emerging tech that could disrupt or empower your business.

Tiny reports: one-page summaries, fast discussions.

Actively ask: "Could this be a co-creator, not just a tool?"

Mindset: Tech is part of your team, not your toolbox.

4. Customer Co-Creation Checkpoints

Purpose: Involve your customers in shaping offerings — don't just sell to them.

Tasks:

Run small surveys, beta tests, and feedback loops constantly.

Invite customers into early-stage idea formation (“Would you want this?”).

Mindset: Customers aren't passive — they co-create your future.

5. Monthly Fragility Audit

Purpose: Prepare for shocks before they hit.

Tasks:

List all critical dependencies (single suppliers, platforms, power-users).

Ask: “If this fails, what's our Plan B?”

Build tiny "resilience projects" (ex: backup suppliers, tech redundancies).

Mindset: Always assume systems can fail, and be ready.

6. Quarterly Strategy Reframe

Purpose: Refresh your big-picture direction intentionally.

Tasks:

Revisit assumptions about markets, tech, and culture.

Reset goals based on current reality, not old forecasts.

Embrace strategic improvisation: stay bold, but loose.

Mindset: A good plan today beats a perfect plan tomorrow.

Bottom Line: Businesses that thrive now act like agile sailors navigating shifting waters, not like builders of castles waiting for the perfect day.

A few concrete tools or apps fit this agile, networked leadership style. (Things like mapping tools, trend trackers, or fragility auditors) 

If you use the right lightweight tools, small teams can outperform big ones in a liquid, networked world.

Best Tools for Small Teams Navigating Bauman + Latour’s World

1. For Daily Change Scanning and Quick Meetings

Tool: Slack + a 15-min "change channel"

Set up a #shifts-and-changes channel.

Team members post short notes about anything shifting: markets, tech, customers.

Keep it informal — the goal is constant low-pressure awareness.

* Why Slack?

Fast, casual, and builds a daily habit of scanning without heavy meetings.

2. For Ecosystem Mapping

Tool: Miro (or Whimsical for simpler diagrams)

Create living maps of your business networks: customers, suppliers, partners, tech tools.

Use color codes: strong ties, weak ties, risky dependencies.

* Why Miro?

Visualizes complexity simply — helps you see your network health at a glance.

3. For Weekly Tech Watch

Tool: Feedly (plus a shared Google Doc)

Set up topic feeds: “emerging tech,” “market trends,” “future of work,” etc.

Each week, one person shares 2–3 key finds in a shared doc.

* Why Feedly?

Super easy way to track fast-moving fields without drowning in news.

4. For Customer Co-Creation

Tool: Typeform (or Google Forms for free)

Quick, beautiful surveys to test ideas, get feedback, or invite customers into product discussions.

Make it part of customer rhythm: “We build with you, not for you.”

* Why Typeform?

Friendly, mobile-ready surveys feel less corporate, more conversational.

5. For Monthly Fragility Audits

Tool: Notion (or Trello if you prefer kanban style)

Set up a simple board:

Columns = [Critical Systems] ➔ [Current Health] ➔ [Risks] ➔ [Backup Plans].

Update it monthly, and assign owners for each risk.

* Why Notion?

Highly customizable and lightweight — fits a small team's style without feeling bloated.

6. For Quarterly Strategy Refresh

Tool: FigJam (part of Figma)

Host a 1-hour casual online workshop.

Put your current goals in bubbles.

Ask “Does this still fit today’s world?” and adjust your life.

* Why FigJam?

Super interactive — perfect for thinking visually without heavy “PowerPoint fatigue.”

Key Rule for Small Teams: Use tools that make you lighter, faster, and more connected — never tools that weigh you down.

Best wishes for completing the semester.

Sanjiv

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 4/24/2025 15:46:52
Subject: from imitation to transformation
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

In every case, copying involves repetition. But in this act of repetition, something else happens. Difference manifests itself in repetition and marks a transformation that occurs within repetition. Please see Adam Mizia’s reflection below.

Marcus Boon's In Praise of Copying, 2010 (please Google) challenges the conventional dichotomy between "original" and "copy," proposing that copying is not merely derivative but a fundamental aspect of human existence and creativity. Boon argues that copying is intrinsic to learning, cultural development, and even the universe's functioning at a molecular level. He suggests that the distinction between original and copy is rooted in Western metaphysics, particularly Platonic ideals, and reinforced by modern intellectual property laws.​

Gabriel Tarde's theory of imitation (please Google) posits that individuals learn and adapt behaviors through observing and copying others, especially those with higher status or closer proximity. He also believed this imitation is a universal phenomenon, not just in social behavior, but in all areas of life, including physical processes. Tarde's theory suggests that imitation drives social change, cultural evolution, and even crime, as individuals adapt and modify imitated behaviors. 

Sanjiv

REPEAT, COPY, TRANSFORM, ORIGINAL

from the fishbowl...

Re: Felt Experiences

post by adammizia » Thu Apr 24, 2025 9:05 am

Felt Experience: Learning Patience Through Vocabulary and Google Searches for the Fishbowl

In the beginning, I treated vocabulary work and Google searches like tasks on a checklist—just something to get through before getting to what I thought was the "real work." But as I spent more time with each word, I realized that slowing down actually changed the way I learned. One word would spark curiosity about another, and soon I was doing more than just looking up definitions—I was exploring deeper meaning. Tracing words to their origins or seeing how different people use them started to feel rewarding in its own quiet way. I came to understand that learning isn’t always fast, and that the process itself teaches you something. In this case, patience didn’t just improve how I researched; it made me feel more connected to the ideas we were exploring in class, even if I wasn’t always speaking up in the fishbowl.

Re: Felt Experiences

post by kiaramadrid » Wed Apr 23, 2025 8:08 pm

As I think back on this experience, I realize it’s hard to put into words everything I felt. There were times when I felt both involved in the conversation and removed from it, watching myself react and sometimes feeling uncomfortable. What stood out wasn’t just what was said, but how it was framed—the way the conversation shaped how we connected or disagreed. Some things were clear, while others were hidden, affecting how we learned from each other.

As we tried to understand everything, I saw that our views depended on who was speaking and their perspective. I started wondering if we were uncovering something real or just making up our own ideas. Still, the process allowed space for new possibilities. Imagination didn’t come all at once, but slowly, challenging what I thought was true. Maybe that’s the main takeaway: meaning is always changing, and understanding, like identity, is something we’re always figuring out.

Final Assignment

Empirical Research suggests that successful online businesses, global and transnational, exhibit the following common characteristics:

1. An Integrated networking structure

2. Dynamic decision-making

3. Adaptive coordination mechanism

4. Unique innovation capabilities

Please deconstruct each of the above characteristics. You are creating an understanding of each characteristic. You are constructing knowledge content and a knowing based upon your felt experiences. Please keep it simple. I am examining your thought process and constructions of dichotomies, structures, experiences, and dimensions.

Template

Step 1. Write the characteristic under investigation, for example: Integrated networking structure

Step 2. Create a word pool by taking each word from the dictionary and the thesaurus—fifteen words or so.

Step 3. Create a dichotomy from the word pool by selecting two disparate elements, two uncorrelated words.

Step 4. Expand the dichotomy words and create a word pool from the dictionary and the thesaurus to construct a meaningful sentence—a universal, generalized, pithy axiom. 

Step 5. Step back and see where you've progressed from step 1. Don’t be afraid to create new meaning. You are on a trajectory of creativity.

Step 6. Do a felt experience that ‘fits' the sentence you created in step 4. The sentence is the form, and the felt experience is the content. Whole and the Particular.

The felt experience is a description of an incident from your life, or an interpretation of a scene from the movies, or a felt experience in the fishbowl.

Step 7. Conclude on a dimension. Select two words from the above, and create a dimension.

Good luck! I think you will be terrific, and I look forward to seeing the outcome on May 1st at 6:30 p.m. Until then, back to the letters in the fishbowl.

Words are concepts and categories, images and symbols; we create more words whenever we reconfigure them anew, without limits.

Words get us in trouble and can get us out of trouble.

Words provide solutions, and they also create problems.

In digital space, it is indeed about words, and as Rilke put it in his famous poem Archaic Torso of Apollo (please Google), we must change our lives, for there is no place to hide!

What does Rilke mean by this call for arms?

Date: 4/10/2025 12:50:54
Subject: make formulation possible
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

We have been exploring topics together and separately in a social network we call the fishbowl. What we offer to the outside viewer is an emerging digital space with its own culture, ups and downs, twists and turns. At the end of the semester, we are raising the multidimensional question of what it means to participate in online culture and its capacity to create a public sphere.

We are participating through text postings regarding vocabulary, google searches, felt experiences, and assignments. Essentially, for our purposes, we define our digital culture as comprising modes of communication and information exchange that displace, redefine, and reshape knowledge into new forms, formats, and methods for acquiring and transmitting such knowledge.

We are making possible, for ourselves and others, the formulation of information and its subsequent transformation into knowledge in a manner in which it produces the categories and concepts for ordering, organizing, and transmitting our understanding.

“So once again, before we get too carried away, she asked, what exactly are we doing?” 

We spend our time thinking about words and concepts, their meanings, and the ways they shape some of our perceptions and inform our ideas about ourselves and the world around us. Please see Isabella Ventura's postings below.

Sanjiv

Re: Vocabulary: Isabella Ventura

post by isabellaventura » Wed Apr 09, 2025 2:25 pm

reflections and other matters during vexatious times

Develop:To gradually grow or improve something over time through effort, learning, or experience, often turning a simple idea into something more complex or useful.

Culture:The shared beliefs, behaviors, traditions, languages, and values of a group of people that shape how they see the world and live together.

Content:The ideas, information, or creative material included in something like a book, website, video, or lesson that gives it meaning and purpose.

Artifact:A physical object made or used by people in the past that helps us understand their culture, daily life, or history.

Remix:To take existing content—like music, words, or images—and change or combine it in creative ways to make something new and original.

Reimagine:To look at something familiar in a completely new way, often by changing its meaning, form, or purpose with creativity and insight.

Create:To bring something new into existence by using imagination, skill, or effort, whether it’s a physical object, idea, or work of art.

Image:A visual or mental picture that represents a person, idea, object, or feeling, often used to communicate or express something deeper.

Inspire:To spark motivation, creativity, or a strong feeling in someone that encourages them to act, make, or think in a new or meaningful way.

Tradition:A practice, belief, or custom passed down from one generation to the next that helps maintain cultural identity and connection.

Produce:To make or bring something into existence, often through planning and effort, like creating a product, work of art, or result.

Aesthetic:Related to beauty, style, or the way something looks or feels, especially in art or design; often tied to personal or cultural tastes.

LLM (Large Language Model):An advanced type of artificial intelligence trained on large collections of text to understand, process, and generate language in a way that mimics human conversation and writing.

Manifestation:The visible or tangible result of something that was previously just an idea, feeling, or possibility; the act of making something real.

Fragment:A small, incomplete piece that has broken off from a whole, often used to describe a bit of text, memory, or object.

Corpus:A large and organized collection of texts or language samples used for research, especially in linguistics or AI training.

Reshape:To change the form, structure, or purpose of something in a way that makes it new or better suited for a different use or meaning.

Ethnography:A detailed, close-up study of people and their culture through observation, participation, and description, often used in anthropology and social research.

Skill:The ability to do something well, usually developed through practice, learning, and experience over time.

Possibility:Something that could happen, exist, or be true—even if it hasn’t yet; a chance for something new or unexpected.

Identify:To recognize or name someone or something based on certain qualities or characteristics that make it unique or known.

Variation:A difference or change in form, appearance, or meaning that occurs within a group of things that are otherwise similar.

Collaborate:To work together with others to reach a shared goal, often by combining strengths, ideas, and efforts.

Engage:To actively take part in something, showing interest, focus, and effort; also means to connect meaningfully with people or ideas.

Experience:The knowledge, feelings, or skills gained by being involved in or going through something personally.

Uncover:To find or reveal something that was hidden, unknown, or overlooked—often leading to new understanding or awareness.

Deep:Extending far beneath the surface, either physically or emotionally; often used to describe intense, thoughtful, or layered ideas.

Pattern:A repeated design, structure, or behavior that helps us see order, rhythm, or relationships in things.

Serve:To provide help, support, or a specific function for others; to fulfill a purpose or role within a larger system.

Collaborator:A person who works closely with others on a shared goal or project, often contributing ideas, time, or creativity.

Partner:Someone you work or team up with in a project, relationship, or business, sharing responsibility and commitment.

Draft:The first or rough version of something, like writing or a design, that will be revised and improved later.

Refine:To make something better or clearer by polishing details, improving structure, or removing unnecessary parts.

Insight:A deep or accurate understanding of a situation, person, or idea that helps reveal something important or meaningful.

Observe:To watch or notice carefully, often with the goal of learning, understanding, or recording what’s happening.

Interpret:To explain or find meaning in something, especially when it isn’t immediately clear, like a message, image, or event.

Framework:A structured way of thinking about or organizing something that helps explain how it works or fits together.

Lens:A way of viewing or thinking about something that shapes how we interpret or understand it, like a perspective or filter.

Frame:To shape or structure something—like a question, argument, or situation—in a specific way to focus attention or meaning.

Protagonist:The main character in a story or situation, often the one who drives the action or experiences the most change.

Structure:The organized way parts of something are arranged or built, giving it form, strength, and clarity.

Dimension:A distinct aspect, level, or feature of something that helps describe or understand it more completely.

Dichotomy:A clear division between two opposite ideas or groups that are often thought to be very different or in conflict with each other.

Read:To look at written or printed words and understand their meaning; also used to describe analyzing or interpreting something thoughtfully.

cultural interaction: finishing the assignment (3)

Apposite:Highly relevant, fitting, or appropriate in a specific situation—especially when something matches the tone, topic, or context exactly.

System:An organized set of parts or processes that work together as a whole, often following rules or patterns to achieve a function or purpose.

Classification:The process of sorting or organizing things into categories based on shared characteristics or rules to better understand or manage them.

Embedded:Firmly placed or deeply integrated within something else, whether physically (like an object) or conceptually (like an idea within a system).

Symbolic:Representing something beyond its literal meaning, often using images, words, or actions to express ideas, emotions, or abstract concepts.

Template:A guide, model, or pre-designed format used as a starting point to shape or structure something new while maintaining consistency.

Uncover:To reveal or discover something that was hidden, unknown, or not obvious, often leading to new understanding or insight.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 4/9/2025 0:28:30
Subject: cultural interaction: finishing the assignment (3)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

By now, you have seen the films once, read and written about Hofstede’s dimensions, and even interpreted the movies through Hofstede’s lens.

Stay with me.

Think of a dimension as two words, one at the end of a straight line.

We are free to create our dimensions and to slide along them. Please Google how Hofstede came up with his dimensions.

Please see Andrew Montan and Rebecca Jenkins's postings below.

 

Create a dimension.

Identify Clear, Opposing Concepts:

Begin by defining the two extreme poles of your dimension. For example, in the dimension of individualism versus collectivism, you might define:

Individualism: A focus on individual rights, autonomy, personal goals, and independence.

Collectivism: Emphasis on group goals, interdependence, community, and shared values.

Start with oppositions, such as singular/multiple, dependent/independent, introverted/extrovert, depth/breadth, etc.

You are selecting an ‘apposite' for each word. You are creating apposites. 

You are looking at the relation between two words in your perception and applying them in three different cultural contexts: American, Indian, and Chinese.

We’re big on relationality, a nuance of the word relationship. Please Google Relationalism.

The appropriate opposite (apposite) is the foundation of good structure. 

We are structuralists. Please google Ferdinand de Saussure. 

A structuralist analyzes cultural phenomena and social practices by uncovering the structures that govern them. They believe that these structures shape meaning, behavior, and cultural products.

However, to understand other cultures by uncovering their structures, we must first be able to see our structures—not in the abstract and knowledge sense (we believe in democracy) but in our lived experiences, interactions, choices, and decisions, which we take for granted every day.

"So how do we do that," she asked, “see oneself!"

To ‘see’ one’s structures is to be self-aware within an environment, like in the fishbowl. Please see Rebecca Jenkins and Andrew Montan.

To be self-aware, we must distance ourselves from a situation and raise appropriate questions. AI already has the answers; it is the raising of relevant questions that concern us. 

We are looking for the right questions in a culturally constructed world where others' behavior and understanding of the world come from their embeddedness in a cultural system.

The task before us, according to Pierre Bourdieu (please Google), is "to uncover the most profoundly buried structures of the various social worlds which constitute the social universe, as well as the mechanisms which tend to ensure their reproduction or their transformation.” This universe is peculiar according to Bourdieu in that its structures lead, as it were, a “double life.” They exist twice: in the “objectivity of the first order” constituted by what you see, read and hear, and in the “objectivity of the second order,” in the form of 'systems of classification,' the mental schemata that function as 'symbolic templates,’ like our use of Hofstede’s six dimensions.

Here’s a key line from each film that illustrates one of Hofstede’s cultural dimensions:

1. Power Distance (PDI)

Film: Iron and Silk

Objectivity of the first order: "In China, when the teacher tells you to do something, you do it.”

The objectivity of the second order reflects China’s high power distance, where authority is respected and obedience is expected.

2. Individualism vs. Collectivism (IDV)

Film: Outsourced

First order: "You need to learn about India. Try to understand how we work together.”

Second order: highlights India’s collectivist culture, where collaboration and social harmony matter more than individual ambition.

3. Masculinity vs. Femininity (MAS)

Film: Moonrise Kingdom

First order: "I love you, but you don’t know what you’re talking about." (Suzy to Sam)

Second order: The film leans toward a feminine culture, valuing relationships and emotions over ambition or aggression.

4. Uncertainty Avoidance (UAI)

Film: Outsourced

First order: "Everything is different here, and that's the point." (Todd)

Second order: This shows Todd’s American low uncertainty avoidance, where adaptation and flexibility are embraced rather than fearing the unknown.

5. Long-Term vs. Short-Term Orientation (LTO)

Film: Iron and Silk

First order: "Patience. You cannot master this in one day." (Martial arts teacher)

Second order: China’s long-term orientation values perseverance and gradual mastery over immediate results.

6. Indulgence vs. Restraint (IVR)

Film: Moonrise Kingdom

First order: "We're in love. We just want to be together. What's wrong with that?" (Sam)

Second order: This reflects a high-indulgence culture, where personal happiness and emotional freedom are prioritized over social norms.

Finally, to complete your assignment for the three movies, consider any three Hofstede dimensions and use them as a template for each movie. It is recommended you create your dimensions as described above. 

Next, select a sentence from each movie as your "objectivity of the first order," and then interpret that sentence in terms of the dimension (the second order) you have chosen.

Your layout will look like the above presentation.

In all, you will have generated three pairs of knowing across three cultural contexts and three dimensions.

It’s a game of design. Sorting, sifting, selecting, and substituting words.

Sanjiv

My Role in the Fishbowl:

As a digital participant in this fishbowl, I observe the films Moonrise Kingdom (USA), Outsourced (India), and Iron & Silk (China) to absorb different values and storytelling structures, then reimagine them through my own cultural lens. I follow Charlie and Lola's path in Kinky Boots as I navigate unknown ground while redefining meaning, reshaping context, and expressing my findings through words.

Ethnographic Approach:

Through ethnographic skills, I detect variations between cultural values and norms and traditions. I think about how my background affects my perception of Suzy and Sam's rebellion in Moonrise Kingdom, Todd's cultural adjustment in Outsourced, and Mark's disciplined transformation in Iron & Silk. I create new content by analyzing their actions, gazes, and language through both symbolic and cultural frames.

Cultural Framing:

I examine the three films through American individualism and emotional expression and Indian community and adaptation and Chinese discipline and tradition lenses for comparative reflection. I notice that the three main characters transform personally after stepping into new environments to transform their worldview which parallels my experience as a digital fieldworker exploring new theoretical landscapes.

Creative Output:

Each scene, character arc, or cultural clash becomes a fragment I rework. The analysis helps me to remix meaning, reimagine motivations and achieve a deeper aesthetic understanding. Through each film, I gain insight and contribute cultural artifacts that inform a richer, more diverse digital storytelling space.

Conclusion:

I work with content, engage with culture, and function as a co-creator of meaning in this reflective process. The analysis of Goffman's frame analysis and cultural dimensions helps me understand how identity, tradition, and transformation appear across different worlds while showing how they reshape me.

Ethnographer:

I can personally relate to the idea of ethnography through my experiences in this class and with the fishbowl. In the fishbowl, we don’t simply observe what people are posting about the topics from the outside, instead, we immerse ourselves in this community by generating our own knowledge and understanding, which we can compare and expand by observing the posts of others in this community. In the fishbowl, we are all looking at each other through this figurative glass and our understanding of knowledge is deepened by being fully engrossed in this community instead of just researching and observing as an outsider. We are all ethnographers in the fishbowl community.
