Assignment 1. Interacting Cultures: Hofstede's Dimensions

EditDeleteReportWarnInformationQuote

Post by Klaranelander » Sat Apr 05, 2025 10:43 am

I really enjoyed watching the three movies and especially when keeping cultural differences and Hofstede’s dimensions in mind. There are clear differences between cultures, and since I’m originally from Sweden it was interesting to contrast my cultural values to American culture as well.

While watching the movies it made me realize how important culture is to the way we think, interact, and interpret the world. All of our values are based on our beliefs and what we perceive to be the right thing to do. Hofstede’s Cultural Dimensions helped provide a structured way to organize my observations and truly understand how different societies prioritize different things. The reflection below explores how each film symbolically portrays cultural norms and how they both align and contract with my personal beliefs.

Moonrise Kingdom - American Culture

Beginning with Moonrise Kingdom, it highlighted many different aspects of American culture and especially focused on individualism, rebellion, and emotional expression. Sam and Suzy, two 12-year-old children, serve as symbols of rebels, breaking free from the norms, questioning authority, and seeking freedom and independence.

Power Distance: The adults (parents, scout leader, police officer) try to uphold authority, but they constantly fight the children who question their power. The film features a low power distance culture where there is no clear hierarchy and the kids constantly push the boundaries. In Sweden, we’re taught to always respect authority and adults, but similarly, in the movie, I also feel comfortable questioning it when I disagree.

Individualism vs. Collectivism: The film strongly focuses on individualism, where Sam and Suzy clearly value their personal desires and independence over family and community expectations. This can also be seen by Sam’s foster parents rejecting him and Suzy’s parents not understanding her. I believe this is very typical of American culture, characterized by individual success over anything. However, in the end, community collaboration is finally valued. The other Khaki scouts decide to help Sam and Suzy, Captain Sharp adopts Sam, and Suzy’s parents are becoming a bit more open-minded. The Swedish culture is very similar when it comes to valuing independence and self-expression. However, our culture has a stronger sense of social responsibility, and I believe we care more about the welfare of others.

Masculinity vs. Femininity: Emotional expression, creativity, and nurturing relationships speaks for a more feminine culture. I strongly identify with these values, Sweden is one of the countries with the most feminine cultures, and to me quality of life and wellbeing is extremely important.

Uncertainty Avoidance: Sam and Suzy embrace uncertainty and risk in multiple ways. This can be seen when they run away in the wilderness on their own with no clear plan. I tend to prefer structure and planning, so their openness to uncertainty felt risky, but also inspiring to me.

Long-term vs. Short-term: Sam and Suzy have a short-term focus. They take it day by day with no clear plan for the future. I believe my culture has a more long-term focus. Even though innovation, short-term plans, and emotional actions are okay, there is always a long-term plan.

Indulgence vs. Restraint: Sweden scores very high in indulgence, and I’m used to a culture that values leisure, fun, and enjoying life. The adults in the movie depict the exact opposite of this, but the kids are challenging this, pursuing life with values more similar to an indulgent culture.

Outsourced - Indian Culture

Outsourced explored culture values in a completely different way by letting us follow the American call center manager Todd Anderson through his experience in India. The movie shows how embedded our cultural values are, but also how openness to learning about others can introduce a whole new world.

Power Distance: India has a clear hierarchy where elders are respected and employees defer to authority. This contradicts both the American and Swedish culture, where things are more egalitarian.

Individualism vs. Collectivism: India has a strong focus on collectivism. They focus on family and social harmony, which can be seen through arranged marriages and living with extended family. Initially Todd had a hard time understanding these values, and for me this communal perspective was also eye-opening.

Masculinity vs. Femininity: The movie depicted a good balance between hard work and care for relationships. I really agree with these values. Todd on the other hand had more of a masculine and American mindset, solely focusing on crunching numbers and conducting business.

Uncertainty Avoidance: The Indian culture introduced the concept of “jugaad”, referring to creative problem-solving. This can be seen in the call center when the employees come up with creative ways to understand the American products. Todd, depicting American culture, struggles with the lack of structure and so did I. Even though Sweden has low uncertainty avoidance, the jugaad mindset was a little too chaotic for me.

Long-term vs. Short-term: Long-term orientation is key in India. Tradition and duty are deeply rooted in the culture and there isn’t much room for personal choice. In my culture we also value tradition, but we tend to focus as much on the present and personal choice.

Indulgence vs. Restraint: Public behavior is highly restrained. Physical affection and personal desires are moderated, and Todd struggles with this a lot. Similarly, I’m also used to more open emotional expressions.

Iron & Silk - Chinese Culture

Lastly, Iron & Silk depicts Chinese culture, showing strong values of discipline, collective identity, and respect. As a huge fan of Kung Fu Mark believed he would fit perfectly into the Chinese culture while moving there for a year to live and teach English.

Power Distance: Teachers and authority figures are deeply respected, and questioning them is rare. Mark struggled with this initially, and similarly, in Sweden, the hierarchy is more relaxed.

Individualism vs. Collectivism: Harmony and social responsibility is strongly valued. Actions reflect on the community and not just the individual. I greatly value independence, so the Chinese perspective pushed me to think differently.

Masculinity vs. Femininity: Achievement and the mastery of skills is highly respected, but so is relationship building. I agree with the focus on personal growth, but public humility is much more strongly emphasized than in my culture.

Uncertainty Avoidance: Structure and tradition are core values, and rules around education, social behavior, and relationships are formal and explicit. I’m more used to open dialogue and flexibility.

Long-term vs. Short-term: Patience, perseverance, and respect for the past are strongly present. I found this admirable and respectable, but my own thinking is usually a bit more present-focused.

Indulgence vs. Restraint: Behavior strictly follows social norms and personal desires are undermined collective values. These types of restraints contrast my daily experiences and cultural values a lot.

Analyzing these three films through Hofstede's framework didn't only teach me about different cultures but also gave me a much deeper insight into my own cultural identity. Learning about the Indian and Chinese cultures it made me realize how much I value independence, emotional openness, and the balance between structure and freedom. At the same time, I became aware of how cultures like India and China emphasize respect, tradition, and group cohesion. Those are values I now appreciate more. After watching the movies, it also made me realize the big difference in how Americans and Swedes value success. In all three movies, the American values of chasing money, having a "successful" career, and always working were very evident. In Sweden, and for me, success is defined as finding a balance between well-being, work, and quality of life. Always chasing to maximize and achieve a new career milestone isn't always the top priority. While I do value some of the masculine cultural values, I still have a much more feminine view of life.

Subject: constructing ownership of words

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

Please see Klara Nelander’s posting below. It is a constellation of signifiers, carefully selected and translated into a communicable form.

Her words are the medium through which the world of her posting is disclosed. 

It is only by her ‘saying' that this world makes an appearance. 

It is the fundamental way beings come into presence for human understanding. Please Google Heidegger and The Nature of Language.

When you undertake the deconstructive process, you take ownership of your words by disclosing your selection. You take ownership because each word you select is not so much a concept as a “relation”: a relation between you and that word. 

Constructing a New Complex Sentence:

Framed by perspective and shaped by consequence, reality ripples through the depths of subconscious knowing, where impulse and cognition intertwine to forge the truths we live by.

Several points to consider:

For Heidegger, language is not secondary to thought or reality; instead, it is the language of your posting through which the world of the fishbowl is meaningfully revealed. 

Please see the posting below as an example. 

Heidegger critiques the traditional view that language merely represents an already-existing world. Instead, he argues that language is the house of Being, meaning that through language, the world is disclosed to us in a way that allows us to relate meaningfully. In the fishbowl, we’ve been relating meaningfully to each other from the opening event of posting vocabulary. In this sense, “saying” or posting in the fishbowl is not just speaking words—it is an act of revealing, a way of bringing forth the fishbowl as an intelligible space where things can appear to us as what they are. 

Without your deconstructive process, the world of the fishbowl would not "appear" meaningfully; it would remain an undifferentiated flux without structure or significance. 

Sanjiv

feed back on your fishbowl postings

For as long as I can remember, I have always had trouble grasping information given to me in school settings for the most part. As the teacher would give lessons and speak, her words never stuck into my brain. They hover over me, just out of grasp, like I'm using my bare hands to attempt to gather the information. While I sit there looking at the page, the letters and figures blending into something unintelligible, I watch other students nod, make notes, and respond to questions with ease. It was always so frustrating to me, knowing others had such a simple time while I was holding onto dear life to grasp the concepts thrown at us. It wasn't the lack of trying, because I did that was no question. I repeatedly read the same sentence, hoping it would make sense. However, it doesn't. It feels like my brain is constantly slipping behind while attempting to stay up while navigating through the challenges. The class has already progressed by the time I finally get the first section, and I feel as though I'm just standing there while everyone else is running forward. A knot of frustration tightens in my chest. I don't want to seek support once more. "Just pay attention" or "do better" are not things I want to hear. I'm making an effort. As a result, I pretend to take notes while sitting silently in the hopes that no one will realize how lost I truly am. I could get it later. It might simply click. But at the moment, I feel as though I'm clutching a puzzle with pieces missing, and no matter how hard I try, I'll never be able to complete the picture.

ACTOR-NETWORK THEORY, CINEMATIC EXPERIENCE, AND DERRIDEAN DECONSTRUCTION IN VISUAL CULTURE: EVOLVING NETWORKS

S. Dugal1, J. Booth1, K. Nelander1, P. Deslauriers1, M. Conti1, K. Khalfayan1, A. Montan1, S. Conquest1, M. DaGraca1, C. Flint1, K. Irons1, E. Provost1, D. Kane1, S. Maloof1, B. Luzzi1, I. Luksch1, K. Pinell1, A. Sullivan1, R. Ritacco1, K. Regan1, C. Sylva1, B. Velasquez1, D. Wallace1, S. Blanchard1, R. Davidson1, A. Mukherjee1, D. Daly1, R. Fry1, W. Grant1, K. Madrid1, A. Mastin1, V. Zullo1, S. Boffi1, M. Maxim1, R. Singh2, A. Mizia1, S. Singh3, R. Singh4, J. Quatchak1, M. Corbett1, E. Perdomo1, A. Dodson1, A. Griffin1

1 University of Rhode Island (UNITED STATES)

2 Sommelier India (INDIA)

3 Sommelier India (UNITED STATES)

4 RLDesign Studio (INDIA)

I. Introduction

Our study uses three key frameworks: Actor-Network Theory (Latour), deconstruction (Derrida), and visual culture studies. By viewing responses from 135 online participants, we examine how cinematic experience is shaped through digital platforms, meme culture, and audience participation, which challenge traditional film boundaries. Digital platforms complicate traditional cinematic boundaries, transforming cinema into an evolving network of signification.

1. Actor-Network Theory and Cinematic Experiences

Experiences arise through cameras, editing software, projection technologies, online streaming, and viewer interactions.

2. Derridean Deconstruction and Textual Fluidity of Film

Constructing cinematic experiences through intertextual references, personal histories, and cultural contexts.

3. Visual Culture and the Network of Signification

II. Purpose

We aim to provide an analytical lens for understanding the interaction between cinematic texts, visual imagery, cultural meanings, and spectator participation. We aim to highlight how film extends beyond traditional theatrical viewings into online spaces, where participants engage with cinematic content in new ways.

III. Method

We are viewing online spaces where participants engage actively with text from the film Kinky Boots.

1. Textual Selection and Structure Formation: select a key sentence from a film snapshot in Kinky Boots as a foundational structure for interpretation.

2. Word Pool Development: focus on significant words (concepts, word images) from above, expanding their meaning through dictionaries, thesauruses, and online searches to explore nuances and semantic shifts.

3. Engage with Word Pool: immerse in the evolving lexicon, create active knowledge, and explore film as an intertextual construct.

4. Interpretative Reconstruction: Using the word pool, generate new statements—concise aphorisms or axioms—distinct from the original sentence.

5. Experiential Reflection: contextualize the interpretations above by infusing personal experiences and cinematic references.

IV. Findings and Discussion

Our study shows that visual culture functions as a decentralized and interactive network. Key themes from participants’ responses include:

1. Shared Influence on Film Engagement – Algorithms, online communities, and streaming platforms shape how viewers watch and interpret films.

2. Flexible Meanings – Films have multiple interpretations, aligning with Derrida’s idea that meaning is never fixed.

Interactive Visual Culture – Film snapshots circulate online, extending cinema beyond theaters into digital conversations.

3. Collective perception - Images function within a dynamic network of signification, where their meanings are not intrinsic but emerge through intertextual relationships, cultural codes, and socio-historical contexts that shape and are shaped by collective perception.

V. Conclusion

Our research underscores the intricate networks that shape cinematic experiences. In our final paper, we will present Insights from participants who affirm that film is not a static text but a dynamic, networked event influenced by human and non-human actors. Future research could expand on these findings by incorporating real-time data analytics to examine viewer engagement with digital film platforms more comprehensively.

Keywords: Actor Network Theory, digital platform, cinematic experience, Derridean deconstruction, visual culture, spectator participation, network of signification

Step 1: Start with a Complex Sentence

“Understanding arises when we connect deeply with the unseen forces shaping experience.”

Step 2: Break Down Key Elements

Choose keywords:

Understanding

Arises

Connect

Deeply

Unseen

Forces

Shaping

Experience

Step 3: Gather Around 15 Related Words or Images from These

Let’s expand based on definitions, connotations, and imagery:

Understanding – comprehension, insight, grasp, clarity, perception

Arises – emerges, manifests, surfaces, unfolds, springs

Connect – link, bond, bridge, merge, relate

Unseen – hidden, veiled, obscure, implicit, invisible

Forces – energy, pressure, influence, drive, motion

Shaping – forming, molding, crafting, patterning, structuring

Experience – encounter, perception, memory, sensation, awareness

(We now have more than 15 words.)

Step 4: Select a Few Words and Break Them Down Further

Let’s choose: Insight, Invisible, Drive

Insight: Inner, Light, Vision, Penetration, Realization

Invisible: Absence, Masked, Hidden, Unknown, Ether

Drive: Impulse, Urge, Motion, Hunger, Direction

Step 5: Continue Further

Let’s dive deeper into Realization, Ether, and Hunger

Realization: Truth, Recognition, Awakening, Alignment, Fulfillment

Ether: Space, Vibration, Medium, Silence, Immaterial

Hunger: Desire, Lack, Yearning, Pull, Craving

Step 6: Watch for the Axiom

Now, as these words swirl and interact, something begins to crystallize.

Axiom:

“What is unseen moves us, and we name it only in the moment of recognition.”

This feels felt. It emerges naturally from the spiral — from invisible forces to realization to hunger — all pointing toward a core truth: we are moved by what we don’t yet see, and only through experience do we name it.

The fishbowl is a living text

Post by Klaranelander » Thu Feb 20, 2025 1:10 pm

"The more languages one knows, the harder it is to find a truth in what a word truly means."

I had never thought about the way languages have shaped me as a person until I read about this week's concept of deconstruction by Derrida. Just as we reinterpret words every time we hear them, learning a new word in another language reshapes our understanding of its meaning. Every time I go through my vocabulary, I instinctively translate the word into Swedish and German. Often, I realize that I would have described the word very differently in another language compared to what feels natural in English. It’s as if meaning itself is fluid, never fixed, only shifting depending on the structures of the language I’m using. This makes me wonder, if words can never fully capture a singular truth, how much of what I perceive as reality is shaped by the languages I speak?

Post by Klaranelander » Wed Feb 26, 2025 12:20 pm

Finding a true purpose can sometimes be hard without having people cheering you on.

In my writing class last year I wrote a paper on how social media and immediate validation have shaped today's society. Many teenagers today feel the need to post and document everything they do in order for them to feel a true purpose of doing it. Inner motivation is lacking in many young adults, and the need for an audience to confirm, support, and encourage is only growing bigger. Looking back, I realize how many times I've fallen into the trap of seeking approval before taking action. It happens easily, especially when we get stuck in endless scrolling on social media. That assignment taught me the importance of self-discipline. By looking for inner motivation, clarity emerges, and the need for an audience fades away.

symbolic interactionism

Post by Klaranelander » Thu Feb 27, 2025 1:15 pm

Objects carry meaning beyond their function, many times sending a message before words even are spoken.

Watching Kinky Boots made me realize how much of a deeper meaning shoes have than just the basic function of helping with walking. Shoes, and fashion in general, serve as symbols and a way of expressing who we are. To Lola, shoes are everything. The process of designing, creating, and picking the right material for her boots is an essential part of who she is. The way we dress sends a message to the world, before even saying a word, we have already communicated a lot by the way we look. This insight made me think about how professors always tell us to dress nicely when going to an interview. A nice pair of shoes, a nice blouse, or a nice suit, sends a message. It sets the tone of a conversation before it's even started. Watching the movie really made me understand this.

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

The Kinky Boots exercise is at the heart of the abstract for EDULEARN25. This letter provides feedback on what I have ascertained thus far regarding the exercise. Please know that we are creating this exercise together, like an orchestra. New concepts and new understandings emerge as we journey together. I am not more intelligent than you, I am only a participant observer. And so we are to each other. "We were never about intelligence!" she declared.

You have to watch Kinky Boots in person because you are engaging not only the text spoken, but also registering fleeting images from the film. 

We define the cinematic experience by immersing ourselves in the characters' lives and focusing on five snapshots from Kinky Boots. Please see Kiara Madrid’s posting below.

I have attached the film again.

Each snapshot you select is represented by a structure of words, i.e., by your selected sentence.

Your selected sentence is the opening sentence, the structure from which each of us in the fishbowl jumps off the cliff into the unknown.

“Cliffs of the heart," she said. "That commences a journey, leading to the conference Edulearn25," I replied.

As each individual selects a structure, after sorting and sifting images in Kinky Boots, we develop a word pool as a whole in the fishbowl that becomes a flexible and growing boundary of words and pictures regarding the film.

When we do the exercise, we immerse ourselves in and engage with the text and images in the word pool, our domain of action and knowledge creation.

How do you do that?

Pull out three or four words from your opening sentence. The more complex the sentence structure, the greater is the chance of coming up with something meaningful for the exercise. Please bear this in mind.

Use the dictionary, thesaurus, and Google searches when necessary, and collect words similar to the key word(s). Here you are looking for nuance, perhaps a shift in stance. So if you have five similar words for each keyword, then for three keywords, you will have created a word pool of fifteen words or so. 

These fifteen words or so is the domain you are working in.

Narrow it down to three or four words that are different from each other. This is important to keep in mind.

Take these three/four words and look up thesaurus for substitute words.

Before long, your new structure will begin to emerge, surface and take form.

Your new sentence is a pithy statement. An axiom, an aphorism. It has nothing to do with your opening structure.

Next is your felt experience, an example from your past experience. You are reflecting on it here, using memory and your interpretation of the incident. You are using examples from Kinky Boots, the fishbowl, and your personal life.

The last couple of letters and your work in the fishbowl have given me an outline for writing the abstract to submit to EDULEARN25 (please Google). I feel good about it, and I hope you do, too.

Sanjiv

3. “A factory is its people. It’s not about the bricks; it’s the people in it.”

4. “You change the world when you change your mind.”

5. “Pursue the truth.”

• Sentence 1: warn, Charlie, Northampton, terrible, habit, doing, opposite, people, want

• Sentence 2: look, heel, young, man, sex, in

• Sentence 3: factory, people, not, about, bricks, in

• Sentence 4: change, world, when, mind

• Sentence 5: pursue, truth

2. “Focus on the heel, young man; allure resides there.”

3. “A factory’s essence lies in its people, not the building materials.”

4. “Altering your perspective can transform the world.”

5. “Seek out the truth.”

1. “Charlie, I must inform you, I tend to act contrary to others’ expectations.”

• This reminds me of times when I followed my own path despite external pressures, leading to personal growth and self-discovery.

2. “Focus on the heel, young man; allure resides there.”

• It highlights how minor details can create a significant impact, much like how small changes in my work or appearance can make a difference.

3. “A factory’s essence lies in its people, not the building materials.”

• This emphasizes the importance of teamwork and community, reminding me of moments when strong collaboration led to success.

4. “Altering your perspective can transform the world.”

• It suggests that a shift in mindset can open new doors, something I’ve experienced when overcoming challenges with a fresh approach.

5. “Seek out the truth.”

• This encourages honesty and integrity, values that I strive to uphold in both personal and professional aspects of life.

Date: 3/5/2025 22:32:44
Subject: developing the Abstract (1)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

I write to you today to explore the connections between Actor-Network Theory (ANT), Jacques Derrida’s deconstruction of text, the cinematic experience of watching Kinky Boots, and the visual culture of the fishbowl. These seemingly disparate concepts share a deep and intricate relationship, shaping how we perceive identity, agency, and representation.

Actor-Network Theory and the Web of Relations

Actor-Network Theory (ANT), developed by scholars like Bruno Latour, challenges the idea of stable entities by emphasizing the network of relationships between human and non-human actors. ANT argues that meaning and agency do not reside in individual subjects but emerge from the interactions within a network. When we consider Kinky Boots, the transformation of Charlie Price and Lola (Simon) is not an isolated journey but one shaped by relationships—between tradition and innovation, personal history and societal expectations, and even the materiality of boots themselves. The factory, the workers, the boots, and the markets are all part of the network that reshapes Charlie’s and Lola’s lives.

Derrida’s Deconstruction: Unraveling Fixed Identities

Derrida’s deconstruction teaches us that text—and by extension, identity—is never fixed but always in a state of flux. The binary oppositions that structure meaning (male/female, success/failure, tradition/progress) are not stable but depend on context and intertextual play. In Kinky Boots, Lola disrupts normative ideas of masculinity and femininity, embodying Derrida’s notion that meaning is always deferred and contingent. Charlie, too, undergoes a deconstructive process as he questions his inherited role as a traditional businessman and instead embraces reinvention.

Cinematic Experience and Empathy

When watching Kinky Boots, we are not just passive spectators; we are enmeshed in the film’s emotional and visual textures. Cinematic storytelling employs framing, lighting, music, and performance to draw us into Charlie and Lola’s struggles, encouraging empathy. The film positions us to witness their vulnerabilities and triumphs, much like how ANT insists that actors—whether human or non-human—gain significance through their relationships and networks. Our engagement with the film, then, is itself a performative act of meaning-making.

The Fishbowl: A Visual Metaphor for Cultural Observation

The concept of the fishbowl in visual culture refers to both surveillance and spectacle. It represents the act of being observed and the constraints that shape identity when placed under scrutiny. Lola’s navigation of public and private identities—drag queen and son, performer and laborer—reflects the pressures of being seen through different gazes. Likewise, Charlie struggles with how his employees, family, and investors perceive him. The fishbowl effect is a crucial lens through which we can understand the characters’ performative identities and their relationship with society.

Conclusion: Networks of Meaning

By linking ANT, deconstruction, cinematic empathy, and the visual culture of the fishbowl, we see how identity and meaning are always in flux. Just as Lola and Charlie find agency through relationships, so too must we recognize that meaning—whether in texts, films, or social roles—is co-constructed. Our task, then, is not merely to consume narratives but to critically engage with the networks that shape them.

I invite you to reflect on these ideas and consider how they apply to your own experiences of identity, storytelling, and visual culture.

Sanjiv

PERCEIVE, IDENTITY, AGENCY, REPRESENTATION

Derrida's Deconstruction

Cinematic experience

Visual Culture

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. Please see Harvey Meaghan’s completed assignment on Kinky Boots below

We are watching ourselves in a fishbowl, watching Kinky Boots.

We are watching disparate sub-cultures communicating and collaborating successfully.

We are watching symbolic (word) structures intersecting.

We are watching different realities, stories, and narratives unfolding simultaneously in a fishbowl.

Actor-Network Theory (ANT) in Ethnography provides a way to study the relationships between humans, technologies, and material objects within a given social setting. ANT is particularly useful for techno-social ethnographies, such as when viewing Kinky Boots and Strictly Ballroom and ourselves in a fishbowl, because it helps trace how different actors (both human and non-human) shape each other within networks.

Practicing ethnography involves immersing yourself in a community or cultural setting to observe, interact, and understand actors’ behaviors, beliefs, and social dynamics. 

Sanjiv

Your opening structure will determine what will follow, so carefully select it.

Key lessons: Opening structure is important. Don’t stop your word pool in the first round. Take selected words from the structure further, and then do it again and again. Until you come up with a completely new idea and sentence. It may have little to do with the starting structure.

Att/1 from 2/25 Letter subject: Assignment: Looking and Being 

Assignment: Kinky Boots

When viewing Kinky Boots, we are learning to understand what we see/look/read, before we write and post. Please view Kinky Boots as a journey through nets of meaning.

Step 1.

Select 5 sentences spoken in Kinky Boots by the actors.

Step 2.

Define words and construct word pools for each sentence.

Step 3.

Re-structure each sentence in Step 1 by using your word pool.

Step4.

Do a felt experience about your fishbowl/Kinky Boots/personal experience for each of the 5 re-structured sentences

Follow the KISS principle.

The upshot: We are meaning-spinning participants. Whatever we experience, we take in and interpret as meaningful---or else, we do not experience it at all. Meaningless things are chaos to the human mind; they fall outside of what it can absorb. Berger proposes that looking can be used to see between the meaningful and meaningless, that the gaze can be purposefully directed at the yet unnamed and held like this to catch meaning as it is born.

We might consider this assignment and its framing for the EDULEARN conference—just a thought about ‘reading' and ‘writing' in the age of AI.

Subject: Kinky Boots: Transnational Business and Actor Network Theory
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

Kinky Boots is a real-life story of interacting with a foreign culture without fear or prejudice.

It’s an excellent metaphor for understanding what a global business is about. 

The ‘actors' in Kinky Boots are a social network where each entity displays the characteristics of a transnational corporation according to Bartlett and Ghoshal's research. Please Google. Their central argument is that significant businesses can no longer afford to base their strategy on a single focus. To cope with the complex international environment, companies must have an equally complex and multi-faceted business strategy. Firms operating worldwide must pursue what the authors call a transnational corporation. This organization has the following characteristics:

Integrated Networking Structure, 

Dynamic Decision-Making, 

Adaptive Coordination Mechanisms, 

Unique Innovation Capabilities. 

Please Google Actor Network Theory and Bruno Latour. We are viewing the story of Kinky Boots from the perspective of Actor Network Theory (ANT). We also identify each of the four characteristics above in the actors' actions and words. First, we will define these four characteristics by deconstructing words and rewriting sentences. Sorting, sifting, selecting, substituting, and developing meaning. 

I trust I am not overloading. You must watch Kinky Boots and take down sentences. The basic premise of the course is learning by writing sentences. But before we can write them we must read them. Reading comes first. Whenever we engage with words in this way, we develop an understanding of the Self and things become meaningful..

Please review the text in Kinky Boots, keeping ANT and the four characteristics of a transnational business in mind.

Sanjiv

Date: 3/2/2025 14:23:15
Subject: Assignment: Society of the Spectacle
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are doing well.

The fishbowl is, among other notions, a Society of the Spectacle. Please Google Guy Debord.

Guy Debord’s concept of the spectacle, outlined in his 1967 work The Society of the Spectacle, refers to a social condition where images, media, and commodification dominate everyday life, shaping how people perceive reality and interact with one another. According to Debord, modern society has shifted from direct human relationships and authentic experiences to a world where representations—especially those produced by mass media and capitalism—mediate everything. The spectacle is not merely a collection of images but a worldview that prioritizes appearance over reality, passive consumption over active participation, and distraction over genuine engagement.

Debord’s analysis is even more relevant now than in the 1960s. Consider the following:

	• Social Media & Digital Culture: Platforms like Instagram, TikTok, and Twitter encourage people to construct idealized versions of themselves, prioritizing image over authenticity.

	• 24/7 News & Information Overload: Media narratives are often driven by sensationalism rather than substance, shaping public opinion in a way that prioritizes spectacle over truth.

	• Corporate & Political Spectacles: Political campaigns, celebrity activism, and corporate branding rely on spectacle-driven engagement rather than substantive policy or genuine transformation.

	• AI & Virtual Realities: The rise of AI-generated content, deepfakes, and immersive digital experiences (e.g., the metaverse) creates even greater detachment from tangible reality.

Debord’s critique invites participants in the fishbowl to question how much of their reality is mediated by images, branding, and constructed narratives—and whether we can reclaim a more authentic, participatory existence in an increasingly spectacle-driven world.

Assignment: Do you see examples of the spectacle in your own experiences, outside the fishbowl and inside? Please share two examples.

To help with your examples, consider the key aspects of the Spectacle:

	• Alienation: Individuals are distanced from authentic social interactions, instead engaging with representations of reality curated by media, advertising, and entertainment industries.

	• Commodity Fetishism: Everything, including human relationships, is commodified, turning lived experiences into consumer products.

	• Passive Consumption: People become spectators rather than active participants in their own lives, consuming prepackaged experiences rather than creating their own.

	• Pseudo-Events & Manipulation: Political, economic, and cultural events are staged more for their media impact than for any intrinsic value.

Sanjiv

NOTION, SOCIETY, SPECTACLE, REPRESENTATION, AUTHENTIC, APPEARNCE, REALITY, PASSIVE, ACTIVE, ENGAGEMENT

Step 1: Five Quotes from Kinky Boots

Step 3: Reworded Sentences

"Shifting your perspective can transform everything around you."

"Confidence and identity make something truly special."

"You are your truest self when you feel at ease being who you are."

"The impact we leave is shaped by how we connect with others."

Step 4: Felt Experience

"Seek realness and follow what's honest."

When I started college, I had to figure out what really mattered to me. Balancing school, work, and life got easier when I focused on what felt right instead of worrying about outside pressure.

"Shifting your perspective can transform everything around you."

Managing a job and school at the same time was tough at first, but once I saw it as a chance to grow instead of just a struggle, things changed. Now, as I get ready to graduate, I can see how much I've learned.

"Confidence and identity make something truly special."

Lola owned who she was, and that made all the difference. I've learned that when I trust myself—whether it's making decisions or handling challenges—things turn out better.

"You are your truest self when you feel at ease being who you are."

The more I focused on my own goals instead of outside expectations, the more things started to click. I've realized that staying true to myself is what makes everything feel more meaningful.

"The impact we leave is shaped by how we connect with others."

Charlie and Lola's success came from the people around them, and I've seen the same in my life. Friends, classmates, and coworkers have helped shape who I am. Looking back, I'm proud of how I've adapted, and I know I didn't do it alone.

Date: 2/17/2025 19:58:29
Subject: Google Searches: Taking and Making Notes
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. We will go online from now on. Your attendance will automatically be recorded in the fishbowl. 

Class time will be office hours by appointment on Monday mornings and Wednesday afternoons. Please let me know the night before.

Your excellent contributions of Google Searches (taking and making notes) and your vocabulary draw the boundary of the fishbowl’s ‘discourse’ (please Google ‘discourse analysis’). 

The difference between taking notes and making notes lies in their purpose, approach, and level of engagement.

Taking notes is purely objective and is something we all concur with. Making notes is subjective. Tone, mood, pace, dramatic gesture, and the like are subjective.

Taking Notes

Definition: Recording information from a lecture, book, or source as it is presented.

Approach: Passive; focuses on capturing key points without much modification.

Example: Writing down bullet points from a professor’s lecture or copying information from a textbook.

Purpose: To have a record of information for later review.

Making Notes

Definition: Actively processing and restructuring information in your own words.

Approach: Active; involves summarizing, organizing, and personalizing the content.

Example: Creating mind maps, summaries, or flashcards to understand better and recall information.

Purpose: To enhance understanding, retention, and critical thinking.

Key Difference

Taking notes is about recording information.

Making notes is about understanding and structuring information in a meaningful way.

Making notes rather than taking them is better for effective learning, as it helps in deeper comprehension and recall. 

Sanjiv

TAKE, MAKE, NOTES, RESONATE, LEVEL, ENGAGEMENT, DEEP, COMPREHENSION, DRAW, BOUNDARY, DISCOURSE, ANALYSIS

"You have to change your life."

"There is no place to hide." — Rilke

This quote comes from Rainer Maria Rilke’s poem Archaic Torso of Apollo, which describes a broken but powerful statue that still seems full of life. The final line "You must change your life." feels like a direct challenge, as if the statue itself is forcing the reader to reflect and take action. The idea is that true beauty and truth leave no room for pretense and you have to face them and let them transform you.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 11, 2025 5:42 pm

Rilke’s The Panther - Rilke

Rainer Maria Rilke’s poem "The Panther" is about captivity and how it slowly drains the life out of something once wild and strong. He wrote it in 1902 after visiting a Paris zoo, where he saw a panther endlessly pacing in its cage. The poem describes how the panther's world has shrunk to just the bars around it, making everything else feel distant and unreachable. Even when it briefly sees something beyond the cage, the moment fades just as quickly, showing how confinement kills not just freedom but even the ability to imagine it.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 11, 2025 5:43 pm

Cubism

Cubism was an art movement started by Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque in the early 1900s. Instead of showing objects from a single angle, Cubist artists broke them into geometric shapes and showed multiple viewpoints at once. This gave their paintings a fragmented and abstract look.

The movement had two phases. Analytical Cubism (1907–1912) used complex shapes and muted colors to deconstruct objects. Later, Synthetic Cubism (1912–1919) introduced brighter colors, simpler shapes, and collage techniques. Cubism changed the way people thought about art, influencing design, architecture, and later styles like Futurism and Abstract Art.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 11, 2025 5:44 pm

Social Constructivism

Social Constructivism is a theory that says people learn by interacting with others and through their culture, not just by figuring things out alone.

Lev Vygotsky, a key thinker behind this idea, believed that our knowledge is shaped by our social experiences.

Instead of just absorbing information, this theory suggests that learning happens when people share ideas, ask questions, and challenge what they know. It has influenced education by making learning more interactive, encouraging collaboration, and focusing on problem-solving rather than memorization.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 3:17 pm

Perceptual space refers to how our brains interpret and organize sensory information like sight, sound, and smell. It helps us recognize patterns, make comparisons, and understand relationships between different events. Two key aspects of perceptual space are dimensionality and intrinsic geometry, which influence how we perceive the world around us.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 3:18 pm

Other: The word "other" has multiple meanings depending on the context. It can refer to something different or opposite, something additional, or even a reference to a past event. For example, "the other day" meaning a few days ago.

As an adjective, it typically means something distinct from what was previously mentioned or implied.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 3:20 pm

Rigid Mental Structures: In psychology, rigid mental structures refer to inflexible ways of thinking that make it difficult to adjust to new perspectives or adapt to change. This kind of mental rigidity can lead to stubbornness, resistance to new ideas, and an inability to modify existing beliefs or behaviors.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 3:23 pm

Text World: Text world theory is a cognitive approach to understanding how people create meaning from language. It explains how we mentally construct representations of written or spoken text as we process information.

Textual World: A textual world refers to the mental image or conceptual space a person creates when processing language, whether from a book, a speech, or a conversation. This idea is central to text world theory, which examines how our minds build these representations as we engage with language.

This theory, developed by Paul Werth in the 1980s, is used in education to help students engage more deeply with literature by analyzing how they interpret and visualize texts.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 3:25 pm

The True Life by Alain Badiou: Alain Badiou’s The True Life is a short but powerful book that challenges young people to rethink what it means to live authentically. He argues that chasing money and power leads to a "false life," while a true life is about creating something meaningful beyond societal expectations. Drawing on philosophy, he encourages readers to resist conformity and embrace truth, love, art, and political action as ways to live more genuinely.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 3:34 pm

Through the Looking-Glass by Lewis Carroll: Lewis Carroll expands on Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland with a more intricate and symbolic story about growing up and making sense of an unpredictable world. When Alice steps through a mirror, she finds herself in a place where everything is reversed and logic works in unexpected ways. The story follows Alice as she navigates a chessboard world, encountering characters like the Red Queen, Tweedledum and Tweedledee, and the talking flowers. The book plays with logic, language, and the concept of time, making it both whimsical and thought-provoking.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 3:40 pm

Knowledge Workers: Knowledge workers are professionals whose main asset is their expertise in thinking. This includes roles like scientists, engineers, architects, doctors, lawyers, and academics. The term was first introduced by Peter Drucker in 1959, emphasizing how intellectual skills drive innovation and economic progress.

The Knowledge Economy: The knowledge economy is a system where economic growth depends more on knowledge, information, and innovation than on physical labor or material production. In today’s world, industries rely on research, technology, and specialized expertise to create value, making knowledge a key driver of success.

Pierre Bourdieu and Cultural Capital: French sociologist Pierre Bourdieu introduced the concept of cultural capital, which refers to non-financial assets like education, skills, tastes, and social behaviors that help people navigate society. Cultural capital often comes from one’s upbringing and can influence success in areas like school, work, and social interactions. It’s essentially the kind of knowledge and refinement that gives someone an advantage beyond just money.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 4:15 pm

Peter Sloterdijk: A German philosopher and cultural theorist recognized for his unconventional ideas about human existence and society. He teaches philosophy and media theory at the University of Art and Design Karlsruhe and gained public recognition as a co-host of Das Philosophische Quartett, a German philosophical television program that aired from 2002 to 2012. Sloterdijk challenges the traditional divide between concepts like mind and body, nature and culture, or subject and object. He argues that these distinctions are artificial and that everything exists in a state of mutual influence. His philosophy explores the ways humans, animals, technology, and the environment are deeply connected. He calls for a new framework that accounts for these interwoven relationships, moving beyond outdated ways of understanding existence.

His philosophy is often associated with posthumanism.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 4:31 pm

Immaterial Labor and Maurizio Lazzarato

Maurizio Lazzarato’s theory of immaterial labor explains how modern work has moved away from physical production to focus on knowledge, communication, and emotional engagement. This shift is especially visible in industries such as media, design, advertising, and technology, where economic value is created through intellectual and social contributions rather than manufacturing. Many of these jobs involve unpaid or undervalued work, such as social media users generating content that companies monetize. Immaterial labor also blurs the line between work and personal life, as workers are often expected to maintain an online presence, engage with professional networks, and be constantly available. While this type of work offers flexibility, it also introduces new forms of exploitation, where companies benefit from labor without providing job security or traditional compensation.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 4:32 pm

Commonwealth by Michael Hardt and Antonio Negri

In Commonwealth, Michael Hardt and Antonio Negri critique how modern political and economic systems prioritize protecting private property over the well-being of society as a whole. They introduce the concept of "the common," which advocates for collective resources and shared governance instead of individual wealth accumulation. The book challenges traditional capitalist structures and presents "altermodernity," an idea that encourages moving beyond existing political systems to create alternative models based on cooperation and inclusivity. Hardt and Negri argue that rethinking ownership and governance is necessary for building a more equitable and sustainable society.

Post by kelseykhalfayan » Tue Feb 04, 2025 4:34 pm

Luce Irigaray

Luce Irigaray is a Belgian-born French philosopher and psychoanalyst who has made significant contributions to feminist theory and the study of language. She argues that Western philosophy has historically defined women in relation to men rather than as independent individuals. Her work critiques "phallocentrism," or the dominance of male perspectives in philosophy, culture, and language, which she believes has excluded women’s voices and experiences. Irigaray calls for a transformation in the way language and identity are structured, advocating for the development of a feminine subjectivity that allows women to express themselves on their own terms rather than through male-defined norms.

Jackson Pollock

Jackson Pollock transformed modern art with his radical approach to painting, pioneering techniques like drip painting and action painting. Rather than using a brush in a controlled manner, he would pour, splash, and layer paint onto a canvas, creating highly expressive, energetic compositions.

Dynamic, Expressive, Layered

These parallels highlight how both Pollock's artistic approach and the fishbowl method emphasize active engagement, personal expression, and the development of complex, layered understandings.

1. Dynamic: Pollock's method involved energetic movements, pouring and dripping paint onto canvases laid on the floor, creating lively and spontaneous compositions. Similarly, the fishbowl discussion has been dynamic, with participants actively engaging and contributing diverse perspectives.

2. Expressive: Pollock's art is renowned for its emotional intensity and personal expression, achieved through his unique application of paint. In the fishbowl, individuals openly share their thoughts and feelings, fostering an environment rich in personal expression and authenticity.

3. Layered: Pollock's paintings are characterized by complex layers of paint, resulting in intricate and multifaceted artworks. The fishbowl discussions mirror this complexity, as multiple viewpoints and ideas overlap, creating a rich tapestry of dialogue that deepens understanding.

Date: 2/11/2025 2:32:17
Subject: social construction of reality (4)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

Strictly Ballroom shows us, in the example posted by Kaitlyn Irons below, that the worlds we live in are extensions of ourselves and the forms of life through which we experience and engage. It is an example of how we use language to construct meaning. Words, at face value, are clear and precise. They depict an image, idea, and agreed meaning. But is the process of constructing meaning this simple? Language in the form of written and social text is never self-evident. External contexts and points of reference always mediate meanings and actions. To grasp and understand even the most straightforward meanings, we draw on all kinds of implicit knowledge and engage in complex acts of social construction and interpretation that are tentative, paradoxical, and always in danger of breaking down.

A general social-constructivist view is that whatever the characteristics of the “objective” world, they are always known and experienced subjectively. We play an active role in constructing, making, and enacting our realities.

Whether we know it or not, we have the potential to make and transform ourselves and our world through individual and collective enactments that can “realize” new images, ideas, and worldviews. 

The fishbowl, as an approach to understanding social reality and as an approach to change, belongs to the social constructionist school of thought. It is underpinned by the idea that our awareness and knowledge have an unfolding transformative potential and the images and ideas we hold of ourselves and our world fundamentally impact how our realities unfold.

While this may be true in principle, the deep structure of power relations we witness in Strictly Ballroom is shaped by deeply ingrained assumptions and discourses, where particular groups and individuals have much greater power than others to shape the infrastructure of what one can do. 

Sanjiv

EXTERNAL, CONTEXT, MEDIATE, IMPLICIT, KNOWLEDGE, CONSTRUCT, MAKE, ENACT, POTENTIAL, REALIZE

from the fishbowl...

Strictly Ballroom

Scott: "Look, a beginner has no right to approach an Open Amateur."

Fran: "Yeah, well an Open Amateur has no right to dance non-Federation steps, but you did, didn't you?"

Scott: "But that's different."

Fran: "How is it different? You're just like the rest of them! You think you're different, but you're not, because you're just, you're just really scared! You're really scared to give someone new a go, because you think, you know, they might just be better than you are! Well, you're just pathetic, and you're gutless. You're a gutless wonder! Vivir con miedo, es como vivir a medias!"

This exchange highlights how social constructs (e.g., the rules of the dance federation) dictate behavior, limiting individual growth. Fran challenges Scott to confront his fears, calling out his attachment to conformity and encouraging him to embrace a different path. Social Constructivism emphasizes the importance of breaking free from these norms in order to learn and grow authentically.

THE DEPTH

		OF AN EXAMINED RELATIONSHIP 

		

		IS MATCHED

		BY THE EXPANSE

		OF UNDERSTANDING AND FEELING:

Management Passion in the New Millennium

Presentation 

by matt & sanjiv, 

of matt & sanjiv, 

for matt & sanjiv.

 	 

 	Copyright, Letters To Matt, @dugal, 1999

Prologue

Midway, this way of life we’re bound upon

I woke to find myself in a dark wood,

Where the right road was wholly lost and gone.

Aye me, how hard to speak of it,

The rude and rough and stubborn forest,

The mere breath of memory stirs the old fear in the blood.

But when, at last, I stood beneath a steep hillside,

Which closed the valley’s wandering maze,

Whose dread had pierced me to the heart root deep.

Then I looked up and saw the morning rays

Mantle its shoulder from that planet bright

Which guides men’s feet aright

On all their ways.

		(from “Divina Commedia” by Dante Alighieri)

	

		 IN THE FISH-BOWL

Creating this fish-bowl is a performative act. It is a gesture for the continuation of a story... we’re writing as we go along… we do not know where it will lead, nor where it will end…but we know this for sure, it exists in our heads.

		

This is the story of two characters, matt and sanjiv, and the narrative unfolds in new england, at a small university near the ocean…where they’re swimming in a mental fish-bowl, combining Western sensibilities with Eastern ideas…in tryst with purpose, but shunning all direction, except an inner pressure to radicalize. One Viking, the other Sikh, they progress from liberating ego structures, through deeply bled wounds onto downward spirals of hatred and feelings of isolation, and then returning with renewed joy of understanding, forgiveness, and anticipation. Bringing a surging heritage (of bravery in battle) in their bloods, their forays range from existential arguments, to sudden affectionate détentes, and finally onto other arguments. Their relationship mirrors the profound changes in their lifestyles, in their conceptions of work, and of themselves. Determined to move away from conventional categories (of the division between self and other, of the representation of individuality, of established academic standards) in order to reflect a vision of themselves that transcends these boundaries in a new way. The two characters have an odd volatile nature to their wooing…their interactions end suddenly, and generally with puzzled amusement. They improvise, fabricate, and talk about dimensions and chemistry between people… at times their minds almost meet on the same page, until one makes a tiny faux pas that the other sees as shattering…they’re able to maintain this fragility by improvising from moment to moment. That is, they allow themselves to let their personalities and moods influence their performance but not alter the words or circumstances of the scene they enact in their minds…they really have very different ways of thinking, but are able to pass the ball back and forth easily, making for spontaneous fun.

So how do they do this in the fish-bowl? Like their characters, matt and sanjiv can’t agree. “The more I do it,” sanjiv said, “ the more I realize the character is me.” For matt, “it’s a matter of stripping down my defense mechanisms to being that vulnerable again.” Sanjiv countered: “I think for me it’s more building on top of me. I think.”

This interaction ended suddenly, as many interactions between matt and sanjiv, with puzzled bemusement.

Creating a Concept: the Fish-bowl

Instead of the idea of a relationship (like, teacher/student), attached to a real place (like, College of Business at URI), we created the idea of a place, attached to real people, namely, matt-and-sanjiv-in-a-fish-bowl. In this imaginary place, the Fish-bowl, with extraordinary patience and power, through words, we agreed to project awareness and unity of self as the principle theme. 

The Fish-bowl is a meeting place of the mind; it is a metaphysical place. There is no hiding here for matt-sanjiv because they’re simultaneously, observers and observed. 	

It cannot be assumed that the Fish-bowl is a determined, ordered system intelligible to the outsider who can discover the natural laws that govern matt-sanjiv, or that the role of reason is the power guiding matt-sanjiv.

Rationally and empirically, the Fish-bowl has no significance. It can only be seen in terms of the impact that the matt-sanjiv experience will make on its existence.

			

		2.20.99

My Dear Siddharatha,

During our period of estrangement, our inward journey was around doubts as to “who I am” and, “what I stand for,” i.e. who is the authentic self? Am I this, or, am I that? 

Through thought alone, one transcends a situation (of this/that), and thus we transcended our 

situation, comprising of hurt and feelings of insult, by conceiving the fish-bowl. However, to act upon thought, (beginning with the memo allocating matt’s assistantship to sanjiv), is a contingent act… to survive, to live, to be represented. Our contingent act was a gesture demarcating matt-sanjiv representation. Gesture demarcates, and so we conceive of ourselves…

 			a contingent act

 			to exist.

of ideas

Our Intent: to Play a Unique Role

Our intent is to play a unique role in education: to gain intellect not through verbal discourse per se but through presentation of thought and action; not through involvement with people in an outside world but in a Way Within or an Inward Way that presents world as inner landscape, and so carry out in practice our theme of awareness and unity of self.

Fear of Expressing Feelings

We do not always express Feelings because they’re often Confused, and even Frightening. However, to deny Feelings is to make false, restricted work. To be inauthentic and fake.

In the fish bowl we’re learning to touch Feelings. We touch through expression, i.e. expressing conceptions and perceptions of things, including each other. Particularly, differences like viking/sikh, west/east, physical/ mental, student/teacher,love/hate, and other such dimensions. 

We touch Feelings under public gaze. We have a need to go public with every thing that we say or do.

We’re developing a need to write.

Management Principle 1: Conceiving Ambiguity, Creating Possibility

Ambiguous space is nonhierarchical, horizontal. Its nodes intersect in random, unregulated networks in which any node can interconnect with any other node. We create a new form of rhizomatic knowledge by mixing metaphors. Rhizome is a complex metaphor that contrasts with rooted, 

traditional metaphors, such as, teacher/student. In the fish-bowl, matt-and-sanjiv celebrate their nomadic and schizophrenic qualities. 

We’re motivated to do this because to conceive of ambiguity is to create possibility, and the stronger the ambiguity, the greater is our creativity, and the more powerful our felt-experience.

In the fish-bowl, we’ve created an ambiguious relationship between ourselves: 

we’ve fulfilled all formal requirements (papers, etc.), yet we’re inconclusive about them (grades, etc.); 

we’re not involved in each others research, yet our interaction is research; 

matt is paid fifteen hours/week to assist sanjiv, yet it is sanjiv who assists matt.

The ambiguity in our relationship creates possibility because it allows us to be anything we want. This freedom makes us examine each other in ways we hadn’t been able to see before.

				

Management Principle 2: Creating Myth

The “fish-bowl” is an example of creating a myth. Myth is created inter-subjectively between matt and sanjiv.

“Myth (of matt-sanjiv-in-a-fish-bowl) is a system of communication, it is a message. It is a mode of signification, a form. We assign to this form historical limits, conditions of use, and reintroduce community into it: we must nevertheless first describe it as a form.” (roland barthes)

We use our imagination to describe our form of myth.

The matt-sanjiv form is diasporic ambiguity.

The college of business at URI is percieving and experiencing it.

	Management Principle 3: Create Myth/Intersubjectivity/Intertextuality

Intersubjectivity helps matt-sanjiv to see that most human experience and action goes on between the self and others.

Myth creates Inter-subjectivity; and Inter-subjectivity creates Myth. However, in the fish-bowl the notion of Intertextuality replaces that of Intersubjectivity. “Every text is constructed as a mosaic of other texts, every text is an absorbtion and transformation of other texts” (julia kristeva). Through their intersubjectivity and intertextuality, around the texts of T.E. Lawrence (Lawrence of Arabia), Rainer Rilke (German poet), and Thomas Becket (Archbishop of Canterbury), among others, matt-sanjiv create the myth of the fish-bowl.

Management Principle 4: Experiencing Learning

In the fish-bowl the problem of Being takes precedence over that of Knowing (when acquiring a Ph.D. or anything else). 

“Being cannot be made a subject of objective enquiry; it is revealed to the individual by reflecting on his own unique concrete existence in time and space. Existence is basic: it is the fact of the individual’s presence and participation in a changing and potentially dangerous world. Each self-aware individual understands his own existence in terms of his experience of himself and of his situation. The self of which he is aware is a thinking being which has beliefs, hopes, fears, desires, the need to find a purpose, and a will that can determine his actions.” (sartre)

In the fish-bowl we distinguish between authentic/fake on the basis of our endeavor to transcend a particular dimension or form. 

This endeavor is the matt-sanjiv form of Authenticity.

We are free to choose our reality.

Our Method: the Interplay between Verbalized-Thought and Felt-Experience

In the fish-bowl, the interplay between our two distinct identities brought complexity and depth to our respective worlds. We interpreted text (and each-other), as we saw (perceived) and felt (experienced) it. Even as we respect another’s text, we brought our subjectivity to bear upon it. We infused the text with our individual being; not the other way round. The text did not infuse us. 

In other words, we used words as expressions of sensed-thought (felt-experience) rather than as verbalized-thought in promoting the idea of unity above the inner divisions between us. Our interpreted text reveals us and reflects on us.

Example of Verbalized-thought:

“That evening, I found that I had to untangle two different reactions, writing a description of the conversation and, carefully separated, an expression of my feelings as a member of another culture. Each person is calibrated by experience, almost like a measuring instrument for difference, so discomfort is informative and offers a starting point for new understanding. Indeed, what I had seen and heard would not have pushed me to reflection and generalization were it not for the urgency produced by the sense of difference.”

(Mary Catherine Bateson, Peripheral Visions, page 17)

Example of Felt-experience:

In the fish-bowl we found

we had to untangle two processes:

description of the script (between us), 

and carefully separated, 

expression of (our) feelings.

WORDS DESCRIBE, STEP BACK, FEELINGS EXPRESS

We experience difference through the expression of feelings.

Discomfort from difference is Information;

Information is a starting point for new Understanding.

		

EXPERIENCE DIFFERENCE THRU EXPRESSION

	(My) experence, 

Makes (me)

different (from you).

difference (from you)

Makes (me) 

experience (you).

 DIFFERENCE CREATES SOMETHING NEW

The urgency 

produced by our sense of difference

Forces us to 

Reflect and Transcend the situation.

From the above method, what we learned about ourselves and for the practice of management were the following:

Construct a text/written script

express feelings

expressing feelings makes for difference 

sense of difference produces urgency

 			urgency requires us to reflect, and to transcend

			the written text…

Date: 2/9/2025 14:14:07
Subject: social constructivism (3)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

In Strictly Ballroom, I relate to Scott Hastings, and this was the role I played in the College and the University. And so, the Fishbowl was born among much bloodshed and devastation. Please see the attached document: "The Depth Of An Examined Relationship Is Matched By The Expanse of Understanding and Feeling: Management Passion In The New Millennium” By Matt & Sanjiv.

Now, I play the role of Scott’s father, Doug Hastings, but I will always love Tina Sparkle, and I believe Liz is a good egg and deserves to win, and I think everyone else in the film is out of it and doesn’t get it. And sometimes, it feels that they will prevail. 

In Strictly Ballroom (1992), social constructivism is evident in how the protagonists, particularly Scott Hastings and Fran, construct their realities based on their social interactions, cultural expectations, and personal agency within the rigid world of competitive ballroom dancing.

Scott Hastings: Breaking Free from Tradition

Scott begins the film deeply embedded in the social reality of the ballroom dancing world, where strict rules and traditional dance steps define success. His worldview is shaped by the Australian Dance Federation’s rigid expectations, his mother's obsession with winning, and the broader dance community’s belief that deviation from the norm leads to failure. However, as Scott interacts with Fran and her family, he gradually reconstructs his reality, realizing that self-expression and personal authenticity matter more than conformity. This shift directly challenges the socially constructed "truth" of the dance world.

Fran: Transforming from Outsider to Confident Dancer

Fran starts as an overlooked and ridiculed beginner at the bottom of the dance hierarchy. The constructivist lens shows how her initial reality is shaped by the social norms that define her as unworthy. However, as she asserts herself, learns to dance with Scott, and embraces her Spanish heritage, she reconstructs her self-image. Her father and grandmother introduce her to a different reality—one where dance is about passion, not rigid steps—further enabling her transformation.

Social Constructivism and the Dance Community

The ballroom dance community represents an example of a socially constructed reality that enforces norms through language, tradition, and power structures. Barry Fife, the head of the federation, embodies this construct, manipulating history to maintain control. However, Scott and Fran’s rebellion and their final triumphant dance dismantle these constructs, proving that reality is not fixed but socially negotiated.

Ultimately, Strictly Ballroom illustrates how reality is constructed through social interactions, power dynamics, and individual agency, aligning with social constructivist ideas. Scott and Fran redefine success and identity by challenging and reshaping the norms imposed on them.

Please see Carina Sylva’s work on the assignment on social constructivism. I thought she did what was expected and did it very well. She pulled out a phrase and interpreted it in terms of social constructivism, raising our awareness of reality, agency, and role play when we watch the film unfold.

Sanjiv

REALITY, AGENCY, ROLE, EXPECTATION, PLAY

Assignment #3- Social constructivism

Social constructivism- a theory of knowledge and learning that places a strong emphasis on how social interactions, cultural settings, and group projects influence how people perceive the world.

Phrases from Strictly Ballroom:

Scott-

“Maybe I'm just sick of dancing somebody else's steps all the time."

Scott becomes frustrated when he tries to follow conventional moves that are prescribed by superiors like Barry Fife and his dancing instructor, Les. The process of building knowledge and identity outside of the established conventions is reflected in his ambition to develop his own style.

Fran-

“If you kept it simpler and danced from the heart..."

Scott's belief that winning is everything is challenged by Fran, who argues that knowledge about dancing and success is constructed via authenticity and personal expression.

Shirley-

“I mean, we never imagined... that he would do such a thing in front of... Federation President Barry Fife."

Particularly in competitive settings like ballroom dancing, Shirley's worry about Scott's departure from socially acceptable standard.

Les-

“People who have passed on those steps... know more about dancing than you do!"

Les makes known how crucial it is to follow the standard ballroom dancing routines, demonstrating the powerful effect of experts and societal norms in forming an individual's identity.

Barry-

“Well, of course, you can dance any steps you like. That doesn't mean you'll... win."

Barry's commanding demeanor shows how success and failure are determined by social validation.

Subject: subjectivity of the other

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

Please see Matthew Claps’ posting below.

'To recognize the existence of another subjectivity implies recognizing that it belongs to, and constitutes, a world of its own, which cannot be substituted for mine; that the subjectivity of the other is irreducible to my subjectivity.'

Luce Irigaray, in Sharing the World (p.1), writes, 'The self comprises all that belongs to a world of one’s own: the way in which the subject relates to itself, to the other, to the world, but also to the cultural environment in which this subject lives, an environment which takes part in our subjectivity and is too often confused with identity itself.'

According to Irigary (please Google), 'The world that we can share is always and still to be elaborated by us and between us starting from the perception and affirmation of what and who we are as humans here and now.’..

'Tell me how you think and feel,' she asked.

Unread post by matthewclaps » Sun Feb 02, 2025 3:05 pm

In my communications class, I decided to use the concept of perceptual space for my presentation. I set up three scenarios: one simulating a professional conference setting, another resembling a casual coffee chat, and a third that felt like a formal interview. As I practiced my speech in each space, I noticed how my tone and body language changed. In the conference setting, I felt authoritative and confident; in the coffee chat, I was more relaxed and friendly; and in the formal interview, I focused on being articulate and persuasive. By the end of the exercise, I realized how different environments can influence communication styles and effectiveness.

Subject: our common wealth
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

The ‘common’ is a crucial concept (word, image, symbol, metaphor) to understand the ethos of the fishbowl. We consider the ‘common’ as a form of shared wealth that includes not only natural resources (like air, water, and land) but also social and cultural resources (such as knowledge, communication, and affective labor).

In the fishbowl, we highlight the role of immaterial labor (intellectual, communicative, and affective) in the production of the social. This form of labor (please Google “immaterial labor” and Maurizio Lazzarato ) creates knowledge, relationships, and networks that we share and post in the fishbowl’s ‘common’ space. Please see Mike Conti’s post on anthropo-technics below.

We are a diverse and networked collective of singular individuals who can self-organize and manage their ‘common’ outside of hierarchical control. We are the “multitude." 

We advocate new mental structures that enable self-management of shared resources. Please Google Commonwealth by Michael Hardt and Antonio Negri.

In essence, the fishbowl rethinks the way to prioritize collective care and maintain one’s autonomy.

Sanjiv

1/31/25

When I first started learning to cook, I was terrible. I burned pancakes and undercooked pasta and set off the smoke alarm more times than I’d like to admit. But something about it fascinated me—how simple ingredients could be transformed into something completely new. So I practiced. I watched my parents, read recipes, and experimented in the kitchen. At first, I was just following instructions, but over time, I started to transcend the recipes, adjusting flavors intuitively. Cooking became more than just a skill—it was a way to express creativity and bring people together. Looking back, I realize I wasn’t just learning to cook; I was shaping myself, building patience, precision, and confidence. It was my own form of anthropo-technics, a daily practice that slowly transformed me.

Date: 1/31/2025 23:11:55
Subject: Life of Practice: Peter Sloterdijk
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

There is something quite profound that is taking on increasing significance in the present day, according to Peter Sloterdijk: 

the human as a practicing being, one that creates itself through exercises and thereby transcends itself. 

Those of us who engage expressly in practice embody the mode of existence most clearly of farmers, workers, warriors, writers, students, yogis, rhetoricians, musicians, technicians, competitive sports, and carpenters. 

By sharing our practices and peak performances in the fishbowl, we offer a panorama of postings necessary to be and remain human beings.

By anthropo-technics, Peter Sloterdijk (please Google) means a labor that is self-shaping and cultivates a repeated practice or set of habits as a way to transform or transfigure the human condition. It is not about completing deadlines for assignments but setting up learning practices, leading "a life of practice."

Please see Brandon Velasquez’ practice below.

“Forging ahead in vigilance," she said.

Sanjiv

PRACTICE, TRANSCEND, TRANSFORM, TRANSFIGURE, HUMAN, CONDITION
