Date: 10/2/2024 13:34:28
Subject: abstracting the fishbowl
------------------------------------------------------------
OPENING STATEMENT

A. TEACHING PHILOSOPHY AND PROCESS

My feet are firmly planted in the Undergraduate classroom experience. Teaching is my vocation. I am a teacher, first and last. 

I joined the teaching profession in 1971 as a Lecturer in Economics at Delhi University. 

In 1974, I pursued a career in the Indian Civil Service, only to return to teaching in 1980 as a doctoral candidate at UMass, Amherst. Since then, I’ve never left the classroom or missed a semester. 

I. Creating a Fishbowl

My classroom is an online platform, a digital Fishbowl, where participants focus on their habits and actions surrounding reading each other’s selected word images, symbols, and constructed sentence structures rather than reading content in particular Textbooks. We are focused on our reading practice and reading process in a digital world. 

The Fishbowl idea was born of a new analysis for organizing student work, in which value becomes the cognitive and ‘immaterial’ product of creative action and thus escapes the laws of objective valuations. 

In the Fishbowl, we explore the implications of the claim that “we learn to love…not primarily by acquiring information about what we should love but rather through practices that form the habit of how we love.” 

The Fishbowl fosters a “reflective practice” where students become skilled interpreters of the situations they have to deal with. It enables skills of framing and reframing so that we can all learn to see the same problem in different ways, remain open and flexible with multiple meanings, generate new insights, and become comfortable with the paradox that the same situation can mean many things simultaneously. It encourages students to become reflective, creative, and expansive.

A reflective student knows how implicit images, ideas, theories, frames, metaphors, and ideas guide and shape his or her practice and how they can be used to create new possibilities. Please see a Demo co-authored by three students. (The Materials Dossier in Interfolio has 560 pdf files of students’ work in the Fishbowl.)

II. Demonstration: reading process and engaging with words

Ten Steps

We begin “reading” with an opening sentence structure in groups of three. Our reading practice and process are visible to all in the Fishbowl. 

The group agrees that the opening sentence structure serves as a platform from which three individuals venture on a journey, together and apart, of interactive and interfacing search-making, generating subjectivities and inter-subjectivities. 

Step 2, participants gather a pool of synonyms and metonyms from the above sentence structure and agree to stay within that domain of words.

Step 3, participants individually restructure the opening structure, staying within the domain of words gathered in Step 2. 

Step 4, each participant writes a felt experience from their past that “fits” their re-structured sentence.

Step 5, each participant assigns a perceptual category to each other’s felt experiences, including themselves. This generates nine words.

Step 6, the participants jointly create a dichotomy from the nine words in Step 5.

Step 7, participants jointly construct a sentence structure from the dichotomy.

Step 8, participants write their experience on the structure in Step 7.

Step 9, participants share their perceptual categories of each other’s experiences described in Step 8.

Step 10, participants reflect upon their insights and realizations.

Demo in Ten Steps

Step I: Opening Structure

“Metaphors only have an impact when they “ring true,” “hit a chord,” and “resonate” around fundamental insights.”

Step 2: Word Pool

Metaphor - analogy, image, symbol, pattern, picture

Impact - burden, impression, influence, meaning, repercussion 

Ring true - sound right, seem legitimate, have a ring to it

Catch on - ascertain, confirm, determine, divine, verify, disseminate, promote, assert

Resonate - echo, reverberate, vibrate, oscillate

Fundamental - central, constitutional, crucial, elemental, essential, principal

Insight - acumen, intuition, judgment, observation, understanding, vision, wisdom

Steps 3/4: Individual Restructures and Felt- experiences

1. “Images only have an influence on people when they seem legitimate and echo around a central vision.”

There are a lot of ideas out there that a lot of people seem to not be able to grasp because they do not resonate with them. You have to be able to relate an idea to someone to make it work for them. I look at the example of sports and how it can have a great influence on the lives of people. It can impact lives in so many different ways, but there are some people that the idea of sports does not resonate with them. It is just all based on what people like. Sports is not something that all people can relate to, but those who can relate to it, like myself, it has a profound impact.

2. “Analogies have the greatest amount of meaning when they grab attention of the public, seem legit, and oscillate around an essential vision.”

Examples and analogies create more meaning to people than any other way to communicate to people. I believe if you can grab attention of the public, have correct information, and create a visual, then people will understand better. Example based information grabs more attention to the people and allows them to generate a meaning that will help them create their own meaning. Legit information always generates comfort in people’s eyes and this helps people conclude their decision that analogies create the greatest amount of meaning. In my personal experiences, in math class I would have a better understanding of the material if I was given an example or an analogy that relates to me. If I couldn’t relate it to me, then I wouldn’t have a great understanding of the information being taught.

3. “Pictures can only be influencing if they are compelling and reverberate essential substance.”

The initial structure makes use of words from the semantic field of music. In my opinion especially music is an art where metaphors and analogies are frequently used. I listen to a lot of American Rap music or Old School Hip Hop. Metaphors are not only used but also an indicator of quality in hiphop/rap songs. The more compelling the punchline the more respect is shown to the artist. Metaphors are very powerful. They can strengthen an insult but also underline a positive phrase.

Impact/Material/Powerful

Profound/Greatest/Positive

Step 6: Dichotomy

Impact/Indicator

Step 7: Creating a structure from the dichotomy

“A good indicator of how well someone gets a topic is by seeing the impact it has on them.”

Step 8: Participants’ Experiences on the new structure

1. This is something I see a lot in classes. If I do not fully grasp the subject or care for it that much, then it does not leave a long, resounding impact on me. But then there are the classes that I fully grasp and care about. Those are the ones that leave an impact on me. Those are the ones that I realize that I can take with me in the future. I can use those lessons every day to better myself. Whether it be bettering myself in the working world or my own life, those classes impact me.

2. The impact is important to tell if someone is a good indicator. If the effect is good then it shows that the indicator is good and shows that it is trustworthy. An indicator is something that shows information about something. In my life, a measuring tape is a good indicator to measure with because the impact that is displayed is correct. I trust a tape measurer to measure things, which makes me rely on this good indicator. This allows people to get the topic since the indicator has an impact of the truth. This impact is important because indicators are useful in everyone’s daily life.

3. Everything has impact on us. The impact can be seen as a consequence of our understanding of something. School grades are a very transparent indicator of impact. The grades reflect how well someone engages with content that is broad toward him/her. Sometimes it is not a good indicator though. In school I have witnessed a lot of unfair grading in my life. People who put much effort into a project were not rewarded for it. And people who tried to manipulate the grading system got away with it. What I think at some point is that we may study for good grades but we learn for life. And that is something one cannot manipulate.

Lessons/Correct/Witness 

Care/Measure/Unfair

Step 10: Realization and Insight

1. Considering this is the last algorithm we have done together, it has gone very smoothly. We have gotten better at them each time, and our felt experiences have become more personalized each time. Our group has become very cohesive and done great work together. We interpret things differently since we come from different places, but even though we are different, we work very well together. I think that is what is essential about all of this. You need other people to work together to get the best work. If you have people who are all the same, you will get the same ideas, and nothing original or unique will come of it.

2. This is the fifth algorithm we have done in the Fishbowl. I have noticed that our experiences are different since we are other people. Interestingly, people can all think of various things all coming from the same sentence. Our felt experiences are coming along great, much better than the first one we did when we started. I also have noticed from doing this algorithm is that our group works together really well. We had good synergy when we first started working together, but now I think we work well together.

3. What I realized within the whole process of doing the steps is that everything is a matter of perspective. Communities just like our fishbowl are networks where these perspectives converge. The felt experiences in all algorithms we have done in teamwork are stories derived from the same structure. It’s just a different angle every individual looks at the structure. That is what learning is about for me.

Conclusions by the Participants

Creativity is the behavior that animates the innovative process. We started by selecting a structure of words, a syntax, or a sentence to enter the unknown. From this starting point, we took one step (one word) forth into the unknown, checked this word out in all its manifestations through self-reflection, and then stepped back and “looked” at what we got and then we selected a course of action (which is to substitute the word). When repeated, this sequence is a proven method [3] for navigating an uncertain world.

Please see the Video around here.: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KF3yPG7Yj0c&t=31s 

The video shows participants’ research-making as a discursive practice based on critical thinking and dialogue. The Demo in Ten Steps above is an example of “research-making” as a signifying practice that generates, mediates, and produces social meaning, especially in the context of networking and social media.

 

“In today’s highly transparent world, where everything is published, shared, and therefore commented, it is challenging to focus on relevant matters and evaluate them critically. It has become an even more important skill to switch perspectives when looking at things in general. I have a friend who believes almost everything that comes on TV. It can be crazy news stories or even commercials. He takes everything that is said on TV for granted. If Reese’s Puffs are referred as the best Peanut Butter Chocolate cereals, they are the best. He would buy them the next time he is grocery shopping. From my opinion, this is questionable. We should rather use our human mind to evaluate anything that we are confronted with.” (Participant)

III. Premise: Accumulating Attention when Engaging with Words

We increasingly live in an “attention economy” rather than an “information economy.” By the 2000s, so much information was being generated worldwide that only a tiny fraction (0.5% in 2015) of the digital data generated was being analyzed.

The attention economy refers to strategies to capture our attention and maintain profitability. Attention is a currency; like our time, energy, and money, we choose how to spend it. Davenport and Beck (2001) first define the "economics of attention" as an approach to knowledge management that treats human attention as a scarce commodity and applies economic theory to solve various management problems.

In the Fishbowl, we focus on practices that help participants resist transactional approaches to reading. We discuss strategies encouraging readers to prepare for and engage in communion around a text. By framing text as an ongoing conversation, we develop openness and generosity habits that form the individuals and the Fishbowl.

In other words, attentive reading processes in the digital age of AI require a redefined reading process, which includes reflections on the act of reading, communal reading, and discussion strategies devoted to knowledge creation.

Reflecting on one’s reading process:

* What do your reading habits in the fishbowl tell you and others about what you are doing and why?

* How do you relate emotionally to ideas, language, characters, and stories evoked in the fishbowl?

* How can you grow in genuine appreciation for the texts you read in the fishbowl?

* What aspects of the fishbowl helped you to develop ethical practices in other areas of your life?

IV. Assessment and Evaluation

My teaching suggests new economic logic and strategies governed through accumulating attention. 

Students create original and valuable content to succeed in the attention economy, use social media effectively, and leverage influencer marketing. 

Measuring success in the attention economy requires defining success metrics and using the right tools to measure them.

My assessment emphasizes the finite resource of engagement (with words) and its importance in our personal lives, culture, and economy.

The following are Measurable, Observable, and Performed by the student:

* Knowledge

* Concept

* Skill

* Attitude

* Action

BEGINNING (B grade) 

You have basic knowledge and skills. The student charters the vocabulary. 

DEVELOPING (B+)

You are making conceptual connections. Search as research. 

ACHIEVING (A-)

You have acquired knowledge and skills, made conceptual connections, and developed new learning. Original thought.

EXCELLING (A)

You apply knowledge and skills beyond grade-level expectations and demonstrate self-initiated action in unfamiliar situations. You are self-motivated and an independent learner.

B. RESEARCH ENGAGEMENT, STRATEGIES, AND ACTIVITY IN A DIGITAL FISHBOWL

The Fishbowl is a digital research site for undergraduate students. We are a community of researchers investigating business societies and international cultures. Our research activity, engagement, and strategies are centered on learning and innovation among ourselves in the Fishbowl. For myself, research as engagement and research strategies shifted in the 1990s. It was no longer Publish or Perish, but Demo or Die! Along with the likes of Linda Smircich and Marta Callas, David Boje, Heather Hopfl, and Gareth Morgan, my strategies for social research have evolved.

In the Fishbowl, we construe ourselves as an interdisciplinary research lab working to invent the future of augmented reality, social networks, behavioral science, ecology, performance, interactive systems, marginalized perception, social justice, collective intelligence, long-term interaction, algorithms, gender studies, culture, decision-making, misinformation, artificial intelligence, art, design, human-machine interaction, teaching-learning, architecture, space. 

Please see the genesis and prototype of the Fishbowl in the paper, “The Depth of an Examined Relationship is Matched by an Expanse of Understanding and Feeling: Management Passion in the New Millennium,” Presentation by matt & sanjiv, of matt & sanjiv, for matt & sanjiv. Copyright Letters to Matt, @dugal,1999.

Students in the Fishbowl have been demonstrating and presenting at the iated.org/inted and iated.org/edulearn conferences since 2000. These standing conferences are international and accredited; our submissions are peer-reviewed and blind. The IATED Academy, website: iated.org, emphasizes the same research goals and objectives as the Fishbowl.

The research undertaken by undergraduates is about their creative process when working hands-on with text (words) and metaphor (images). As students, we are immersed in a culture of “critical making,” in which text and image combine to envision and create essential objects, experiences, and meanings. Our value extends far beyond the Fishbowl. Our research is significant to anyone seeking to contextualize, navigate, and transform increasingly complex cultures, structures, and networks. My Materials dossier with Interfolio, with over 400 PDFs, bears testimony. 

The Fishbowl nurtures creative practice, from initial spark to finished outcome. In our in-depth accounts, you will discover methods and tools that generate your own “critical-making,” helping you to:

* Frame critical questions through an iterative process

* Apply hands-on embodied approaches to your problems

* Enhance your seeing through closer looking

* Meet uncertainty with flexibility

* Evaluate and articulate the significance of your own work

* Generate ethical responses to global issues

Our exchange in letters and postings in the Fishbowl gradually become small conceptual “work groups” of shared reflection and common knowledge.

Globalization has led to a shared digital world without boundaries or escape. We are bound to this universe, exposed to its control and misconduct. In this circumstance, we must learn the art of self-rule and create enduring models of social interaction among ourselves as singular individuals. Forms that are self-governing, egalitarian, and autonomous. 

According to Antonio Negri, such forms between singular beings are imaginable and possible only because we share and participate in the “common.”

By “common, “ we mean the results of the social output, like in the Fishbowl, such as knowledge, text, codes, information, affect, subjectivity, and intersubjective spaces. In other words, the vocabulary necessary for social interaction. This definition shifts focus to interaction, care, and cohabitation practices in a shared world, promoting the beneficial and limiting the detrimental forms of the “common.” 

So much of our world is shared and open to all, and it is developed through active participation, expression, creativity, and communication.

The Fishbowl is a semester-long project about the “common” we develop during the semester. This shared “common” cuts diagonally across false, arbitrary alternatives and opens a new language, vocabulary, and grammar instead. During the semester, participants work on vocabulary and construct structures that correspond to this notion of the “common.” The “common” that affects us in the Fishbowl is expressed by understanding concepts and creating new categories.

C. COMMUNITY SERVICE: SOCIAL PRACTICE AND RESPONSIBILITY

My contributions to Community Service is not a given set of performances but a social practice, as you see develop among my students in their documentaries and YouTube videos.

I served on the Undergraduate Research Committee at the University and represented the College of Business’ undergraduate research. 

My service activity is to archive footprints in digital space where students express their learning outcomes on YouTube. 

I have built a YouTube community based on memory, image, and experience—an intersubjective space among undergraduate alumni, forever changing and growing across generations. Please review my videos in the light of social networking and media subcultures.

Digital literacy is one of the central problems of participatory cultures. Along with my students, I endeavor to contribute to a participatory culture in the college. This requires dealing with specificity and scale, presenting epistemological and methodological challenges.

Prologue

Midway, this way of life we’re bound upon

I woke to find myself in a dark wood,

Where the right road was wholly lost and gone.

Aye me, how hard to speak of it,

The rude and rough and stubborn forest,

The mere breath of memory stirs the old fear in the blood.

		 IN THE FISH-BOWL

Creating this fish-bowl is a performative act. It is a gesture for the continuation of a story... we’re writing as we go along… we do not know where it will lead, nor where it will end…but we know this for sure, it exists in our heads.

		

This is the story of two characters, matt and sanjiv, and the narrative unfolds in new england, at a small university near the ocean…where they’re swimming in a mental fish-bowl, combining Western sensibilities with Eastern ideas…in tryst with purpose, but shunning all direction, except an inner pressure to radicalize. One Viking, the other Sikh, they progress from liberating ego structures, through deeply bled wounds onto downward spirals of hatred and feelings of isolation, and then returning with renewed joy of understanding, forgiveness, and anticipation. Bringing a surging heritage (of bravery in battle) in their bloods, their forays range from existential arguments, to sudden affectionate détentes, and finally onto other arguments. Their relationship mirrors the profound changes in their lifestyles, in their conceptions of work, and of themselves. Determined to move away from conventional categories (of the division between self and other, of the representation of individuality, of established academic standards) in order to reflect a vision of themselves that transcends these boundaries in a new way. The two characters have an odd volatile nature to their wooing…their interactions end suddenly, and generally with puzzled amusement. They improvise, fabricate, and talk about dimensions and chemistry between people… at times their minds almost meet on the same page, until one makes a tiny faux pas that the other sees as shattering…they’re able to maintain this fragility by improvising from moment to moment. That is, they allow themselves to let their personalities and moods influence their performance but not alter the words or circumstances of the scene they enact in their minds…they really have very different ways of thinking, but are able to pass the ball back and forth easily, making for spontaneous fun.

So how do they do this in the fish-bowl? Like their characters, matt and sanjiv can’t agree. “The more I do it,” sanjiv said, “ the more I realize the character is me.” For matt, “it’s a matter of stripping down my defense mechanisms to being that vulnerable again.” Sanjiv countered: “I think for me it’s more building on top of me. I think.”

This interaction ended suddenly, as many interactions between matt and sanjiv, with puzzled bemusement.

Creating a Concept: the Fish-bowl

Instead of the idea of a relationship (like, teacher/student), attached to a real place (like, College of Business at URI), we created the idea of a place, attached to real people, namely, matt-and-sanjiv-in-a-fish-bowl. In this imaginary place, the Fish-bowl, with extraordinary patience and power, through words, we agreed to project awareness and unity of self as the principle theme. 

The Fish-bowl is a meeting place of the mind; it is a metaphysical place. There is no hiding here for matt-sanjiv because they’re simultaneously, observers and observed. 	

It cannot be assumed that the Fish-bowl is a determined, ordered system intelligible to the outsider who can discover the natural laws that govern matt-sanjiv, or that the role of reason is the power guiding matt-sanjiv.

Rationally and empirically, the Fish-bowl has no significance. It can only be seen in terms of the impact that the matt-sanjiv experience will make on its existence.

Our Intent: to Play a Unique Role

Our intent is to play a unique role in education: to gain intellect not through verbal discourse per se but through presentation of thought and action; not through involvement with people in an outside world but in a Way Within or an Inward Way that presents world as inner landscape, and so carry out in practice our theme of awareness and unity of self.

Fear of Expressing Feelings

We do not always express Feelings because they’re often Confused, and even Frightening. However, to deny Feelings is to make false, restricted work. To be inauthentic and fake.

In the fish bowl we’re learning to touch Feelings. We touch through expression, i.e. expressing conceptions and perceptions of things, including each other. Particularly, differences like viking/sikh, west/east, physical/ mental, student/teacher,love/hate, and other such dimensions. 

We touch Feelings under public gaze. We have a need to go public with every thing that we say or do.

We’re developing a need to write.

Management Principle 1: Conceiving Ambiguity, Creating Possibility

Ambiguous space is nonhierarchical, horizontal. Its nodes intersect in random, unregulated networks in which any node can interconnect with any other node. We create a new form of rhizomatic knowledge by mixing metaphors. Rhizome is a complex metaphor that contrasts with rooted, 

traditional metaphors, such as, teacher/student. In the fish-bowl, matt-and-sanjiv celebrate their nomadic and schizophrenic qualities. 

We’re motivated to do this because to conceive of ambiguity is to create possibility, and the stronger the ambiguity, the greater is our creativity, and the more powerful our felt-experience.

In the fish-bowl, we’ve created an ambiguious relationship between ourselves: 

we’ve fulfilled all formal requirements (papers, etc.), yet we’re inconclusive about them (grades, etc.); 

we’re not involved in each others research, yet our interaction is research; 

matt is paid fifteen hours/week to assist sanjiv, yet it is sanjiv who assists matt.

The ambiguity in our relationship creates possibility because it allows us to be anything we want. This freedom makes us examine each other in ways we hadn’t been able to see before.

				

Management Principle 2: Creating Myth

The “fish-bowl” is an example of creating a myth. Myth is created inter-subjectively between matt and sanjiv.

“Myth (of matt-sanjiv-in-a-fish-bowl) is a system of communication, it is a message. It is a mode of signification, a form. We assign to this form historical limits, conditions of use, and reintroduce community into it: we must nevertheless first describe it as a form.” (roland barthes)

We use our imagination to describe our form of myth.

The matt-sanjiv form is diasporic ambiguity.

The college of business at URI is percieving and experiencing it.

	Management Principle 3: Create Myth/Intersubjectivity/Intertextuality

Intersubjectivity helps matt-sanjiv to see that most human experience and action goes on between the self and others.

Myth creates Inter-subjectivity; and Inter-subjectivity creates Myth. However, in the fish-bowl the notion of Intertextuality replaces that of Intersubjectivity. “Every text is constructed as a mosaic of other texts, every text is an absorbtion and transformation of other texts” (julia kristeva). Through their intersubjectivity and intertextuality, around the texts of T.E. Lawrence (Lawrence of Arabia), Rainer Rilke (German poet), and Thomas Becket (Archbishop of Canterbury), among others, matt-sanjiv create the myth of the fish-bowl.

Management Principle 4: Experiencing Learning

In the fish-bowl the problem of Being takes precedence over that of Knowing (when acquiring a Ph.D. or anything else). 

“Being cannot be made a subject of objective enquiry; it is revealed to the individual by reflecting on his own unique concrete existence in time and space. Existence is basic: it is the fact of the individual’s presence and participation in a changing and potentially dangerous world. Each self-aware individual understands his own existence in terms of his experience of himself and of his situation. The self of which he is aware is a thinking being which has beliefs, hopes, fears, desires, the need to find a purpose, and a will that can determine his actions.” (sartre)

	Real and Unreal:

We are free to choose between authentic and fake as a form of existence. Freedom distinguishes between “authentic” and “inauthentic” forms of existence. 

In the fish-bowl we distinguish between authentic/fake on the basis of our endeavor to transcend a particular dimension or form. 

This endeavor is the matt-sanjiv form of Authenticity.

We are free to choose our reality.

Our Method: the Interplay between Verbalized-Thought and Felt-Experience

In the fish-bowl, the interplay between our two distinct identities brought complexity and depth to our respective worlds. We interpreted text (and each-other), as we saw (perceived) and felt (experienced) it. Even as we respect another’s text, we brought our subjectivity to bear upon it. We infused the text with our individual being; not the other way round. The text did not infuse us. 

In other words, we used words as expressions of sensed-thought (felt-experience) rather than as verbalized-thought in promoting the idea of unity above the inner divisions between us. Our interpreted text reveals us and reflects on us.

Example of Verbalized-thought:

“That evening, I found that I had to untangle two different reactions, writing a description of the conversation and, carefully separated, an expression of my feelings as a member of another culture. Each person is calibrated by experience, almost like a measuring instrument for difference, so discomfort is informative and offers a starting point for new understanding. Indeed, what I had seen and heard would not have pushed me to reflection and generalization were it not for the urgency produced by the sense of difference.”

(Mary Catherine Bateson, Peripheral Visions, page 17)

Example of Felt-experience:

In the fish-bowl we found

we had to untangle two processes:

description of the script (between us), 

and carefully separated, 

expression of (our) feelings.

WORDS DESCRIBE, STEP BACK, FEELINGS EXPRESS

We experience difference through the expression of feelings.

Discomfort from difference is Information;

Information is a starting point for new Understanding.

		

EXPERIENCE DIFFERENCE THRU EXPRESSION

	(My) experence, 

Makes (me)

different (from you).

difference (from you)

Makes (me) 

experience (you).

 DIFFERENCE CREATES SOMETHING NEW

The urgency 

produced by our sense of difference

Forces us to 

Reflect and Transcend the situation.

From the above method, what we learned about ourselves and for the practice of management were the following:

Construct a text/written script

express feelings

expressing feelings makes for difference 

sense of difference produces urgency

 			urgency requires us to reflect, and to transcend

			the written text…

Principle activity: create a sense of difference to achieve unity above inner divisions.

It’ All In Our Heads

						Thank you

								Bye…for 

now.

Epilogue

Our revels now are ended,

These are actors, as I foretold you,

We’re all spirits, and are melted into air.

And like the baseless fabric of this vision,

The cloud capp’d towers, the gorgeous palaces,

The solemn temples, the great globe itself.

Yea all which it inherit shall dissolve,

And like this insubstantial pageant faded,

Leave not a rack behind.

We are such stuff, as dreams are made of,

And our little life is rounded,

With a sleep.

(from “The Tempest” by William Shakespeare)

Mattering & Luce Irigaray

"Mattering consists of feeling valued and adding value to ourselves and others. By feeling valued, we mean being appreciated, respected, and recognized. By adding value, we mean making a contribution and a difference in the world." (Psychology Today")

"Irigaray emphasizes that an ethical love relationship must be creative independent of procreation and that both men and women need to have a place for themselves (be embodied individuals) that is open to, but not subsumable by, the other." (Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy)

While the idea of mattering and the philosophy of feminist Luce Irigaray might seem unrelated, they are highly connected. Mattering deals with feeling like you mean something to those around you. It is the belief that your actions and presence make a difference to the existence of others. This is a broader concept than Luce Irigaray's explanations. She divided this up into men and women and how their relationship with one another depended on how they viewed each other. To coexist, they each needed to make their place in the world. In the Fishbowl, a similar view comes to life. Each user must create their original work and believe it matters. Much like Luce believed, each user must understand the value of work that is not their own.

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

"Mattering” (please Google) is feeling valued and important in our relationships, work, and life. It's a core human need that's important for well-being. 

Whenever we respond in the fishbowl, we do not precisely respond to the other. In this regard we are independent and autonomous. 

Instead, we respond by sharing our selections, substitutions and generating felt experiences.

We are valued because our sharing is being viewed by an audience, i.e., the fishbowl. This is the premise of the fishbowl.

"It’s like becoming global,” she rightly exclaimed.

Talking business, according to Luce Irigaray (please Google): “We cannot share the world as it already is, except for the natural world. The world that we can share is always and still to be elaborated by us and between us, starting from the perception and affirmation of what and who we are as humans here and now.”

Post by johnheyder » Tue Sep 24, 2024 11:22 am

Deep reading refers to a focused and immersive approach to reading that emphasizes comprehension, critical thinking, and engagement with the text. Unlike surface reading which may involve skimming for information or quick understanding, deep reading involves attention to detail, critical thinking, emotional engagement, sustained focus and a contextual understanding of the text. Deep reading fosters a deeper appreciation for literature and complex ideas, enhancing retention and enjoyment.

 post by johnheyder » Thu Sep 26, 2024 10:34 am

A textual world is the fictional or conceptual universe created within a text that encompasses its characters, settings, events, and themes. This world is constructed through the narrative and language of the text, allowing readers to immerse themselves in its specific context and meaning of the story that is being told.

Subject: Method: sorting, sifting, selecting, substituting
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

Please see Ariana’s Google Search below and her “selection" on social ontology. 

Step 1: Selection. You begin with a word, a structure, a DNA.

Ariana's selection of words represents Social Ontology. It is her starting point.

Our purpose is to take and make notes. 

Our purpose is to generate a knowing through subjective feelings and 

to create knowledge by framing and structuring words.

So what do I do next, she asked. What are the steps for success?

You simplify for clarity, I replied.

Step 2: make a word pool of alternative words (15 or so) from the dictionary that defines Social Ontology.

Throw your net far and wide, and bring the catch in. Metaphor.

You’re doing the fundamental activity of sorting, sifting, selecting, and substituting.

We started with blocks as infants!

Step 3: re-structure the original text in step 1. Substitute words from your word pool, i.e., your arsenal of resources, and simplify the definition for easy understanding.

How do I simplify something and increase understanding?

By letting go of clutter, I replied.

Step 4: Felt Experience. You can use your experience from the fishbowl, the films, and personal to explain your restructuring in step 3.

Sanjiv

social ontology- Social ontology is the philosophical study of how social entities like institutions, norms, and collective beliefs exist and function in society. It examines how these entities are created and sustained through shared human agreements and interactions.

Date: 9/24/2024 13:51:11
Subject: uncovering hidden structures
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? I hope you are well.

Selecting a word, phrase, or sentence from a host of other words is a complex decision with irreversible consequences.

I'd like you to please keep in mind (aware) about this fact. 

Our ‘selections' go on to form ‘structures' that are invisible for the most part. According to Pierre Bourdieu (please Google), decision-makers task is “to uncover the most profoundly buried structures of the various social worlds which constitute the social universe, as well as the mechanisms which tend to ensure their reproduction or their transformation.”

Whenever you restructure a sentence, you reveal a hidden structure. Please see Cassidy Kleinwaks’ work below.

To see what is unseen must, of necessity, effect a "double reading." To effect a double reading in the fishbowl is to understand the fishbowl as a bi-dimensional system of relations of meanings between participants and other outside groups.

Please take a look at this YouTube video, 7mts on double reading?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8v1_-YXtpfU

In the fishbowl, we are following a similar process.

Sanjiv

Deconstruction

 post by cassidykleinwaks » Mon Sep 23, 2024 3:21 pm

Original: "His research-based artistry can be characterized as a complete inhabitation of digital logic. It abandons the desire to find connections between links in favor of what art historian David Joselit (please google) has described as 'aggregation,' the selection and configuration of relatively autonomous elements that signify different values or epistemologies".

ARTISTRY, INHABIT, CONNECTION, AGGREGATION, SELECTION, CONFIGURATION, SIGNIFY, EPISTEMOLOGY

Artistry: creative skill, ability

Inhabit: To occupy a space

Connection: The association between two independent elements

Aggregation: The clustered formation of items

Selection: To choose the most suitable of elements

Configuration: The arrangement of elements in a specific form or combination

Signify: to be a sign of, to signal, or to denote

Epistemology: The theory of knowledge with a distinction between belief from opinion.

Reworked: His creative proficiency, rooted in research and inquiry embodies a deep engagement with computational logic. Rather than trying to find similarities within links, it embraces 'aggregation,' as showcased by art historian David Joselit. This approach involves the act of choosing and sorting or categorizing individual elements with diverse and independent meanings.

Date: 9/12/2024 15:49:18
Subject: word, image, symbol, metaphor
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well and ready for the semester. We are off to a good start. By the end of the week, we should have got the nuts and bolts out of the way.

Most of you have completed the assignment about the meaning of your name. In this exercise, we learn that imagery, symbols, and metaphors are all literary devices that contribute to the meaning of a word by enhancing the reader's experience. Please see George Younes’ posting below.

Doing the assignment is one thing, but you wish to identify the underlying concepts and phenomena in your words...

So we may say the name George has an image that refers to something concrete in the objective world. And symbol takes that image and gives it a deeper meaning. Words are symbols in themselves. The word stands for what it means but is not itself that thing or idea. 

Metaphors are implied analogies that imaginatively identify one object with another and ascribe to the first, one or more qualities of the second.

Sanjiv

Post by georgeyounes » Wed Sep 11, 2024 5:04 pm

Lookup the meaning of my name (the image/symbol/metaphor that it is):

-When looking at the etymology of the name "George" I learned that it is of Greek origin, and it means "farmer". It comes from the Greek name "Georgios" which is derived from the Greek word "Georgos" which means "farmer, tiller"

Why my parents named me George:

-My parents named me George after my grandfather on my mom's side. I unfortunately never got the chance to meet him myself as he passed a few years before I was born. My mom told me that she and my father wanted to name me after him to continue the legacy of his name. It was meant to pay homage to him and to have him continue to live life through me and see it through my eyes. They felt as though I would carry his spirit of joy and kindness as he had endless love for his family and all the patients that he treated throughout his life as he was a doctor. When he walked into a room, he brought pure joy and healing to any broken, hurt or sick person before even beginning to treat them medically. They also believed I would be a great father and be as dedicated and passionate about my profession as he was. My father also wanted to name me George as he strongly believed in the spirit and the virtues of Saint George, his courage, conviction, dedication, resilience, and truth.

Whether I live up to the meaning/image of the name that my parents provided me:

-I'm not exactly sure I live up to the Greek origins of my name, as a farmer. As for my parents' reasoning for naming me George, I can say that I am trying to fill those shoes, whether it's with regard to being named after my grandfather or after Saint George. While I am no doctor, I can say that I try my best to love and care for those closest to me like my friends and family, especially when they're feeling down. I'd also hope that I can be as great of a father as he was and I can already feel as though I will have a similar dedication and passion towards my profession, whatever that may be. I can also resonate and relate to Saint George, especially the story of Saint George and the Dragon as I often try to put others before myself while also helping those in need.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/6/2024 21:11:40
Subject: Syllabus for MGT 448: International and Cultural Dimensions of Business
------------------------------------------------------------
UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION

FALL, 2024

Sanjiv S. Dugal, Ph.D.

314 Ballantine

Human Resource Management

Address: sanjivdugal@uri.edu

Office Hours: MW: 12-1 pm

MGT 448

INTERNATIONAL AND CULTURAL DIMENSIONS OF BUSINESS

PREFACE

“As we globalize, we increasingly have to interact, manage, negotiate and compromise with people from different cultures. Working with people whose values and beliefs, not to mention languages and customs are different from your own can make for costly misunderstandings. Experience tells us, often painfully, that one’s behavior, actions and decisions are not separate from one’s values and beliefs. All social behavior is embedded in a particular context and is connected to other deeply held values and beliefs. This means that the stakes are high for mismanaging cultural differences.” (Lisa Hoecklin, 'Managing Cultural Differences: Strategies for Competitive Advantage,' The Economist Intelligence Unit Series, Addison-Wesley, 1995)

I. INTRODUCTION 

How do you navigate and negotiate a situation that is foreign and strange? A situation where the Other's language, customs, and culture are unknown, and you have no predetermined script nor map on the ground. Under these circumstances, what skills are necessary to successfully collaborate on projects together?

II. PROBING DIFFERENCES

"In a global marketplace, many leading international business scholars are arguing that sustainable competitive advantages are increasingly changing from ‘harder ’ efficiency sources to ‘softer ’ effectiveness sources, such as managing differences in values and beliefs. Our differences provide a reflective lens to see where we're positioned with regards to each other." (Hoecklin).

In the course, we are comparing broad value differences across America-Japan, America-China, and America-India. Values, according to Geert Hofstede’s definition, are ‘a broad tendency to prefer certain state of affairs over others.’ The course identifies four dimensions of value differences across cultures, viz., Power Distance, Uncertainty Avoidance, Individualism/Collectivism and Masculinity/Femininity. 

Managing differences among ourselves gives the course not only an identity but also its competitive advantage. The course fulfills the logical sequence of 

Awareness (of differences among ourselves), 

Knowledge (of those differences), and 

Communication (of those differences). 

These three traits, viz., awareness, knowledge and communication underlie the development of cross-cultural skills (Geert Hofstede). Empirical evidence suggests that creating sustainable advantages when interacting with people from different cultures, at home and abroad, will require the following skills:

a. an ability to express

b. flexibility in thought and action

c. sharing and disclosing one’s position in a situation

d. abstracting from the particulars of an interaction

We are developing these capabilities on a digital platform, we call The Fishbowl.

III. METHODOLOGIES: PARTICIPANT OBSERVATION, INTERPRETIVISM, SYMBOLIC INTERACTIONISM

The course utilizes research methods such as Participant Observation, Interpretivism, Social Reflexivity, and Symbolic Interactionism for addressing Cultural questions such as:

How do you experience the Other’s culture?

That is, how do you experience the Other’s deeply held values and beliefs?

What do you see?

How do you feel?

What did you do?

IV. TEXT

1. Letters in the Fishbowl: The Fishbowl is a social network of writing/viewing/experiencing. The Fishbowl is something knowable only in specific fishbowl practices and contingencies during the course of the semester.You will receive around 100 letters written specifically to you for safe-keeping and re-reading, because the text in the letters represents a potential effect that is realized in the reading process. 

Reading is therefore your focal point, for it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend both on the text and on the exercise of your basic human faculties.

2. ‘Exploring Culture, Exercises, Stories and Synthetic Cultures,’ by Gert van Hofstede, Paul B. Pedersen, Geert Hofstede. Intercultural Press, Boston, London, 2002.

Real-life exercises and stories, all with debriefings, make much of this book ideally suited for self-study. Specific activities and exercises are steps towards awareness and knowledge of differences. We will practice intercultural communication skills, and playfully experience what it feels and means to be a ‘foreigner.’

3. Films: Kinky Boots, Japanese Story, Moonrise Kingdom, Outsourced, Iron & Silk.

We deconstruct films to discern underlying cultural assumptions and structures that are playing out.

V. GRADE DISTRIBUTION

1. Regularity and Quality of Participation in the Fishbowl: 50%

There will be ongoing assignments that will help you create a knowing and knowledge content around four dimensions of culture-related values, viz., identity (individualism/collectivism); gender (masculinity/femininity); power distance; and, uncertainty avoidance. These interactive assignments are 50% of your grade.

2. Attending to Meaning in Social Space: 30%

We 'attend to meaning' by sharing, responding and listening to each other. Working in the Fishbowl is an interactive practice of shared words, symbols, images and felt-experiences. Your process will be assessed by the importance you place on 'attending to meaning.' 

“When operating in a global economy, if you want your philosophies, objectives, products and services to be not only understood but also believed by employees, customers and partners in different cultures, you must attend to what these things mean to the people in each culture.” (Hoecklin, p.3)

3. Final: A Self-Reflexive Process 20%

In the final analysis, you’re exploring differences in meanings that existed when working together on a particular idea. Your final paper (3 pages, double–spaced and constructed individually) presents your fishbowl experience as a coherent idea. You're obliged to become self-reflexive, suspend preconceptions, and reflect upon the culture of a ‘fishbowl ‘at the University of Rhode Island.

VI. SELF-ASSESSMENT IN THE FISHBOWL

Learning is about actively combining enriching experiences with academic rigor and creative opportunities. Interaction during the semester requires courage to push back boundaries of past experiences and explore the possibilities available to you. In MGT448, you experience the excitement of discovering what you are capable of achieving, far more than you ever felt or thought possible. The following elements are essential for this experience:

* Knowledge

* Concept

* Skill

* Attitude

* Action

The student is able to make accurate self-assessments at any point during the semester based upon the following criteria:

BEGINNING (B) 

You have basic knowledge and skills. 

DEVELOPING (D)

You are making conceptual connections. 

ACHIEVING (A)

You have acquired knowledge and skills and making conceptual connections, and thereby developing new learning.

EXCELLING (E)

You are applying knowledge and skills beyond grade-level expectations and demonstrate self-initiated action in unfamiliar situations. You are self-motivated and an independent learner.

Faster and better learning through realization is a large part of the assessment logic.

VII. CONCLUSION: FISHBOWL LEARNER PROFILE

The aim of the Fishbowl is to develop global-minded participants who recognize their common purpose and shared responsibility when creating a culture of learning. 

As fellow participants in a fishbowl, we strive To Be the following:

1. Inquirers 

We nurture our curiosity, developing skills for inquiry and research.

2. Knowledgeable 

We develop and use conceptual understanding, exploring knowledge across a range of disciplines. We engage with issues and ideas that have local and global significance.

3. Thinkers 

We use critical and creative thinking skills to analyze and take responsible action on complex issues. We exercise initiative in making reasoned, ethical decisions.

4. Communicators 

We express ourselves with confidence and creatively in many ways. We collaborate actively, listening carefully to the perspectives of other individuals and groups.

5. Principled 

We act with integrity and honesty with a strong sense of fairness and justice, and with respect for the dignity and rights of others. We take responsibility for our actions and their consequences.

6. Open-minded 

We critically appreciate our own culture and personal history, as well as the values and traditions of others. We seek and evaluate a range of points of view, and we are willing to grow from the experience.

7. Caring 

We show empathy, compassion and respect. We have a commitment to service, and we act to make a positive difference in the lives of others and in the world around us.

8. Risk-takers 

We approach uncertainty with forethought and determination; we work independently and cooperatively to explore new ideas and innovative strategies. We are resourceful and resilient in the face of challenges and change.

9. Balanced 

We understand the importance of balancing different aspects of our lives, intellectual, physical, and emotional, to achieve well-being for ourselves and others. We recognize our interdependence with other people.

10. Reflective 

We thoughtfully consider the world and our own ideas and experience. We work to understand our strengths and weaknesses in order to support our learning and personal development.

WELCOME TO MGT 448

ADDENDUM 2: FIVE OBJECTIVES STATED BY UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND:

1. Acquiring skills in working with others as a member of a team.

2. Developing creative capacities (writing, inventing, designing, performing).

3. Developing skill in expressing oneself in writing.

4. Learning how to critically evaluate ideas, arguments, and points of view.

5. Acquiring an interest in learning more by asking questions and seeking answers.

Success requires that you keep pace with the work, understand course concepts, and study effectively. The Academic Enhancement Center (www.uri.edu/aec) is a great place to do this. At the AEC you can work alone or in groups, and tutors and professional learning specialists are available to help you to learn, manage your time and work, and study well. They’re open Monday through Thursday from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. and Fridays until 1 p.m. All services are free (the coffee is free as well!), and no appointment is needed. You can call them for complete information at 874-2367, or just stop by the center on the fourth floor of Roosevelt Hall.

Date: 5/8/2024 14:39:18
Subject: They didn't bring me a letter today ...
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

Congratulations on completing MGT345 and MGT448. You were indeed a great class! 

Of 185 participants, 46 received straight As, and 40 received A-minuses. Your caring attention undoubtedly fueled my continuing curiosity and desire to learn; I listened with genuine interest to your ideas, vocabulary, Google searches, and deconstructions. Your processes of remembering, reflection, and choices were critical to my thinking about your learning. Your fishbowl was a profoundly pluralistic and self-conscious approach to experiences and relationships. 

Thank you.

Central to your work in the fishbowl was disciplined subjectivity. This had several aspects. It meant you were not striving for spurious objectivity but instead bringing your subjective response into consciousness to be part of the available data. To balance that, you displayed a degree of detachment regarding events in your personal life. No one can do this thoroughly, and the processes of disciplined subjectivity and purposeful empathy are not yet fully understood.

You must consider participation in shared performances like the fishbowl over competency of any kind and move toward considering the possibilities of communication across disparate codes. Regardless of our differences in learning, we must look at our exchanges as joint constructions. Because everyone is oblivious to certain kinds of detail, it allows you to develop a contextual structure into which later learning will fit.

Why the films? By watching the communication between the protagonists, you were paying attention to the epigenesis of conversational interaction.

Finally, the lesson of whatever I have learned from your fishbowl is that looking carefully at anything informs looking at everything. Our task is to learn again to see things whole by respecting and treasuring their “minute particulars.” The best hope for our species lies in learning new patterns of attention to each other and the biosphere, which grow out of curiosity and respect and allow for wonder and learning.

As farewell, I have three poems below from different points of time: 

1. The Beginning 

2. The Ending 

3. The Farewell

Thank you for being part of the fishbowl and making it a meaningful experience.

As you step away, I hope to catch you on the rebound!

With my very best wishes,

Sanjiv

1. The Beginning: 

Where The Mind Is Without Fear by Rabindranath Tagore

Where the mind is without fear and the head is held high

Where knowledge is free

Where the world has not been broken up into fragments

By narrow domestic walls

Where words come out from the depth of truth

Where tireless striving stretches its arms toward perfection

Where the clear stream of reason has not lost its way

Into the dreary desert sand of dead habit

Where the mind is led forward by thee

Into ever-widening thought and action

Into that heaven of freedom, my Father, let my country awake.

							 

2. The Ending: 

They didn’t bring me a letter today…by Anna Akhmatova

They didn’t bring me a letter today:

He forgot to write, or he went away;

Spring is like a trill of silver laughter,

Boats are rocking in the bay.

They didn’t bring me a letter today…

3. The Farewell: 

Ithaca by C.P. Cavafy

Date: 4/29/2024 15:06:36
Subject: Research in the Age of AI: we are a consortium
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

I just wanted you to know you have three more days to wrap things up. I’m attaching below abstracts written in the fishbowl by participants every semester up to 2022. Four more abstracts, including yours, have yet to be uploaded.

Your abstract, peer-reviewed and accepted for presentation, is research engagement in your fishbowl with the intent of impacting lives. It is Research in the Age of Artificial Intelligence.

As the abstracts over the years testify, we are a consortium.

You exhibit the principal qualities demanded of knowledge workers today. Empirical observation suggests the following: habitual mobility, the ability to keep pace with highly rapid conversions, adaptability in every enterprise, flexibility in moving from one group of rules to another, aptitude for both banal and omni-lateral linguistic interaction, command of the flow of information, and the ability to navigate among limited possible alternatives. (Paolo Virno & Michael Hardt)

These qualifications result from a socialization process whose center of gravity was outside the classroom. This socialization was punctuated by discontinuous and modular experiences, text interpretations, and sequences of fleeting opportunities.

Today is the last day to do Student Evaluations of the course. Please provide your feedback so we can close the loop. Thank you.

I am working on another letter I will send as I do the evaluations.

Best wishes for your exams and closing up the semester.

Sanjiv

Subject: doing an assignment: image, vocabulary, intuition

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. Please remember that the university is here to help you graduate on time with the highest grade so that you have a leg up.

Your grades will fall within B, B+, A—, and A. In return for your labor in creating knowledge content and a knowing, you will receive my letters and a letter Grade categorizing competency. We are identities in formation, socially constructed. 

In the digital world, we are framed/formed by images and text. You have a picture of me as I of you. I imagine you as a thought leader. Conjuring images requires focus, imagination, and a vocabulary to interpret them. Imagine an underground movement where our fragments of text, letters, and deconstructions are exchanged for a price. Auction them, or better still, a legacy. Once upon a time, there was a mythical place called the fishbowl...and you were there!

"It’s just us," he said. 

(Please connect with Lola’s final song at the end of Kinky Boots.)

You determined your grade from the start. Your intentions and attitude make that possible. The Fishbowl was all about copying, repetition, and tweaking, with feelings splattered throughout the space, like in Jackson Pollock’s paintings. You began with a white canvas/space and filled it with thoughts and feelings. It requires your intuition and being present in the moment.

This semester, we have been reading into each other's words and between the lines. The Fishbowl is about reading at a time when most of us are too rushed to hit Pause. 

But we can’t do anything without reading, I’m afraid. We must slow down and read the message from the mountaintop. Deep and slow reading trains us to focus, imagine, and interpret. Technology, on the other hand, sets us up for medical conditions like Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder while reading slows us down.

About the finale: 

Go easy on yourself. Enjoy the films. All three directors are American. Google them. You are watching their images, assumptions, and frames of reference. They act as different lenses, allowing us to see what we otherwise cannot see. Through the DIrector's lens, you are watching the cultural values of India and China intersect with American values. It is well worth considering from a business and political point of view. 

How does the Other see you? Lack of awareness of perceptual differences leads to misunderstandings and war.

Steps:

First, copy the four definitions of Hofstede’s dimensions and deconstruct them to gain a deeper understanding. This should take an hour or so—not much time, but the subsequent returns to your text are most consequential. 

Please see Zachary Levesque’s posting below.

Second, watch the movies and transcribe the conversations verbatim.

Third, match the four dimensions to the conversation in the three movies.

It’s a textual exercise and one of interpretation.

It requires identifying the context in which the conversation occurred and describing the image. The words don’t tell much in themselves.

You can have four paragraphs, one for each dimension, and compare and contrast the cultural values in the three films in each section. For example, what is the position of the three cultures on the Power Distance dimension? Where are the three cultures on this dimension? What conversation in the films made you interpret their position?

Always follow the kiss principle: Keep It Simple, Stupid. This principle is achieved by opening the dictionary meanings and pushing them to the limit. 

By identifying differences (in the position on each dimension) between the three cultures, you can quickly interpret bizarre behavior: symbols, metaphors, images, gestures, expressions, expectations, and roles. You begin to recognize the cultural matrix of particular patterns of behavior. You come to see their connectedness and to accept their “necessity.” All the frustrations and irritation you experienced in dealing with them become diluted in the sheer pleasure of solving an intellectual puzzle. 

As you will read from the websites, Hofstede’s research has already been done across national cultures. America, India, and China’s positions on Hofstede’s dimensions should not be surprising. Our concern is more with one’s process—looking at myself, looking at myself!

Awareness and understanding of one’s process can affect the outcome. I hope you will always keep that in mind.

Sanjiv

Re: Assignments: FINALE Pt. 1

Post by zacharylevesque » Sat Apr 13, 2024 1:23 am

1. Power Distance: “the extent to which the less powerful members of organizations and institutions (like the family) accept and expect that power is distributed unequally." "refers to the degree of inequality that exists - and is accepted - between people with and without power."

Thesaurus-

Inequality: Disparity, Imbalance, Strife

Power: Charge, Spark, Trigger

Distribute: Administer, Partition, Endow

Deconstruct and example(s): The first dimension of Hofstede can be understood in other ways, such as by referring to the disparity between people with and without spark. The people in a community are typically run by a "president" or "leader" who has the trigger to make the decisions for all. It's like us in the fishbowl with Sanjiv explaining to us what is needed from us in order to earn a specific grade and is also in charge of the "letters" to drive us. The same type of power distance is usually displayed in workplaces. There is always a boss or manager to report to who is in charge of us and who gives orders in hopes of success, and we know that upon typical hiring. It's understood that there is an imbalance of charge, and the majority are on the strife side of things.

2. Individualism versus Collectivism: "extent to which people feel independent, as opposed to being interdependent as members of larger wholes." "refers to the strength of the ties that people have to others within their community."

Thesaurus-

Ties: Link, Bind, Intertwine

Community: Village, Citizenry, Populace

Feel: Sense, Anticipate, Foresee

Deconstruct and example(s): When looking into the first four dimensions of Hofstede, Individualism versus Collectivism is the concept that compares those who are better off doing things independently and those who like interdependency and being with/around others. The anticipation of being linked with citizenry is what collectivism is about, while individualism is more of just doing tasks and whatnot on your own. Introverts are more on the individualistic side of things and don't engage with anyone. We might see people like this on campus who have headphones on or such and foresee that they want to avoid being bothered and then we can see someone raising their hand a lot in class and giving feedback to people. This is someone who does like to be involved within a village and whatnot and is more of a collectivist person. Someone who works in the backroom of a store might have individualism traits more than someone who works in front of a store with all the customers dealing with situations that might come up with being collective.

3. Masculinity versus Femininity: "extent to which the use of force in endorsed socially." "refers to the distribution of roles between men and women."

Thesaurus-

Force: Compel, Dragoon, Oblige

Endorse: Advocate, Patronize, Preach

Role: Function, Duty, Pursuit

Deconstruct and example(s): Masculinity vs. Femininity is the difference between being a man and a woman by providing the roles that each side should fulfill in society. Society advocates how things should be and how dragoon a side should be for their respective tasks that they should complete. A man typically must work and bring in income to a household to help out, while the functions of a woman should be to take care of things like the house. In this day and age, duties for both can be mixed and matched but typically follow a baseline for a home after work (in the times now, both usually work). Moms usually provide meals and clean at home while the men go and work and then come home. This is what is seen in numerous households in all different ways or at least in the olden days. Both will work now, but women usually make dinners and such for families, and men will assist in what they can and clean potentially. It's all based on how the family goes about how following society's "norms" and duties of the idea.

4. Uncertainty Avoidance: "deals with a society's tolerance for uncertainty and ambiguity." "describes how well people can cope with anxiety."

Thesaurus-

Tolerance: Forbearance, Subordination, Docility

Ambiguity: Mystery, Opacity, Vagueness

Cope: Veil, Mantle, Varnish

Deconstruct and example(s): Finally, Uncertainty Avoidance is something we all deal with. It's how we mantle something that makes us feel uneasy. Typically, it poses a mystery to us and has vagueness to it in which makes us not know what's going to occur, and so we find ways to fight this uncertain, nervous feeling. We gradually adopt a type of forbearance to varnish this, whether it be to rewatch something in which we already know what goes on, start fidgeting, or even begin surfing the web to get our minds off the idea. Sometimes, we get it in the classroom and we may leave to go to the bathroom to settle the feeling down and subordinate it or stop focusing and look at something that already happened earlier in the day on our phone. We all deal with is and varnish it in our ow ways in the fishbowl and in classrooms. Fortunately, we all have docility towards it and end up being just fine.

Ethnomethodology leans toward the analysis of social life, with the central focus being to describe how people put ordinary social activities together in an orderly, recognizable way while including core concepts of ethnomethodology. post by saraconquest » Wed Apr 10, 2024, 10:00 am

'critical autonomy':

- The ability of an individual to discover their meaning in a media text. Critical Thinking. A set of skills that allows one to assess their experiences for truthfulness and value rationally. Critical Autonomy

- A "critically autonomous person" can answer questions about a given thing or at least tell you how one would reasonably find those answers; this person would also know what questions to ask. So, the critically autonomous person watching a newscast understands the nuts and bolts of its construction, a variety of contexts for its presentation, and ways of finding out more information to triangulate the source. The critically autonomous person watching a film knows something about film production and film financing, knows something about the genre, and knows something about values embedded in the representation of subjects on the screen.

Denkbild and Walter Benjamin

EditDeleteReportWarnInformationQuote

Post by annienolan » Sun Mar 31, 2024 2:36 pm

"Denkbild" is a German word that translates to "thought image" or "mental image" in English. It refers to the visual representation or picture formed in one's mind while thinking or imagining something. It can also be used in a broader sense to describe the visualization of abstract concepts or ideas.

Walter Benjamin was a German Jewish philosopher and essayist associated with the Frankfurt School. He is best known for his critical and theoretical writings on literature, culture, media, and art, particularly his insights into modernity and the impact of mass reproduction on art.

One of Benjamin's significant concepts is the "thought image" (Denkbild in German), which he discusses in his work "The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction" (1936). In this essay, Benjamin examines how the advent of technologies like photography and film has transformed the nature of art and our experience of it. Benjamin's concept of the thought image raises questions about the nature of authenticity, reproduction, and the impact of technology on our perception of art and culture.

Date: 3/29/2024 13:12:36
Subject: thought image
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

You will agree that we are at a watershed (metaphor, image, symbol, word, concept, thought). Our thought images (please google Denkbild) have symbolic meanings, and we interpret them in the moving screen of our mindscape (mental landscape). Technology has brought the notion of thought images to the forefront.

Please Google Walter Benjamin and Thought Image to grasp the properties of thought images (reproduced below). Whether we know of their ethereal or ephemeral presence, our thought images constitute one’s mindscape.

The thought-image (Walter Benjamin):

* Resembles an aphorism;

* Has “a three-part form consisting of a title, a narrated image, and a related thought” (Kirst 514);

* Corresponds with the Baroque emblem, with pictura (icon in the center), inscriptio (motto at top), and subscriptio (epigram at bottom) (514);

* Creates an interdependency between picture/icon and description/text that simultaneously produces tensions and suggests a totality (514-16);

* Is suggestive or elliptical (resisting truth claims), not exegetical, didactic, or analytical (514-16);

* Lacks any immediate meaning (515) and is instead enigmatic or difficult to grasp (516);

* Implies a secret or hidden meaning, which reveals the discontinuous relation between past and past (517-18);

* Is a departure from the essay form (520);

* Is intertwined with histories of allegory (Sinnbild), where the particular is treated as an example of the general (see Goethe);

* Is not a representation, but rather an act of writing and inscription (Weigel 46);

* Is a “synonym for likeness, resemblance, or similitude” (48);

* Is where “the dialectic of image and thought is unfolded and becomes visible,” or where “the image, understood as dialectic at a standstill, is transformed into writing, that is, set in motion, in such a way as to reveal the origin of the idea and what has gone into its production: what has preceded it, entered into it, disappeared in it, and, simultaneously with the expression of an idea through the image, become, as its reverse side, invisible and invalidated” (48-9, emphasis added);

* Is a “reading[] of images in written form, in which the character of images as writing . . . becomes literally transformed into writing” (50);

* Is not a metaphor representing the relationship between object and concept, but rather a correspondence between the concrete and the general (50-1);

* Is an “imagined image” (53);

* More conceptually, “refuses to give up on the Hegelian ‘labor of the concept’” (Richter 14) and is thus distinct from Marx’s critique of Hegel;

* “Embod[ies] the negative presence of the infinite in the formal aesthetic features of its very finitude” (17);

* “Approaches the world as if it were a text” to be deciphered (18);

* Is that which “cannot be paraphrased” (19);

* Is not a genre, but a medium for “conceptual creation” (18; see also Deleuze and Guattari);

* “Remains suspended in a charged tension between the figural and the literal” (21); and,

* “Elides the binarism of self and other” (35).

Sanjiv

CAVEAT, PROFESSIONALISM, ANECDOTAL

ASSEMBLING DISPARATE ELEMENTS INTO A COHERENT SYSTEM: THE CONCRETIZATION OF TECHNOLOGICAL INVENTION

S. Dugal1, I. Ozuna1, S. Gugliotta1, D. Demers1, C. Guertin1, C. Ritchie1, A. Nolan1, J. Soucier1, G. Gustafson1, S. Rousseau1, S. Sullivan1, H. Yafrate1, G. Ziegler1, S. Glushchenko1, F. Perkins1, J. Collamore1, D. Oliveira1, A. Magen1, Z. Levesque1, A. Tobias1, E. Nash1, D. Nygren1, B. Bethea1, P. Hoan1, N. Hoogasian1, T. Huynh1, S. Singh2, M. Troiano3, R. Singh4, J. Walker1, S. Penkovsky1, L. Leclaire1, E. Kearney1, I. Akomolafe1

Introduction:

Gilbert Simondon defines (1) the concretization of technological invention as assembling disparate elements into a coherent system. Our paper presents the process of ‘concretization’ practiced by 185 participants in a College of Business at the University of Rhode Island who are making ‘inventive’ postings on a digital billboard called the fishbowl.

Our paper presents a method for ‘concretizing technological inventions.’

Technology is defined as ‘applying knowledge for practical purposes.’

Invention is ‘the origination of something worthwhile, like a process or device.’

To concretize is defined as ‘making an idea or concept real; giving specific or definite form to; for instance, the theme park is an attempt to concretize our fantasies.’

Individuating oneself by combining contrasting elements allows for many interpretations, images, and feelings. The collective impact of our technological inventions far exceeds what we initially visualize. The paper emphasizes the human side of concretization, which Simondon calls the unification of “synergy, superabundant functionality, coherence, internal resonance, and formalization” (1).

Purpose:

We aim to ‘share’ our concretization processes. ‘The world that we can ‘share’ is always and still to be elaborated by us and between us, starting from the perception and affirmation of what and who we are as humans here and now’ (2). We aim to share our felt experiences when concretizing our technological inventions, thereby individuating ourselves.

Method:

Individuating the Self by Arranging Contrasting Elements

1. Selecting the opening (sentence) structure initiates using knowledge for practical purposes. It is a self-reflexive process.

2. From the opening structure, identify the essential elements (words), deconstruct them, and assemble disparate and similar words (elements) from a dictionary.

3. Substitute alternative words from the assemblage in #2 to create a new meaning for #1.

4. To concretize is to make sense of disparate elements in an interrelated system. This is achieved by sorting, sifting, selecting, and substituting words representing one’s feelings and experiences, creating new dichotomies and dimensions with a better sense of value.

Findings

1. Our technological inventions brought new properties and complementary functions beyond those initially sought.

2. The assemblage of disparate elements allows for the multiple uses of the elements brought together. Rather than serving a single purpose, every element of the assemblage acquires a plurality of justifications and meanings. The effects are superabundant functionality and far exceed the formalization of the opening structure.

In the full paper, we present two instances of concretization and individuation.

References:

[1] Chabot, Pascal, The Philosophy of Simondon Between Technology and Individuation, Bloomsbury, 2003

[2] Irigaray, Luce, Sharing The World, Continuum, 2008

Keywords: TECHNOLOGICAL INVENTION, CONCRETIZATION, INDIVIDUATION

You will find here a preview of your abstract, once you have filled in the data (title, text, authors) required to do so.

On Mar 10, 2024, at 2:59 PM, Declan Botwinick <dbotwinick@uri.edu> wrote:

Dear Professor Dugal,

As I catch up on some of the letters I missed over this break, I am beginning to understand the implications of the fishbowl and how it operates. I was reviewing the work of Peter Senge, and found the laws of the fifth discipline fascinating.
