Re: Google Searches: The Fifth Discipline

 

The Fifth Discipline is a book published by Peter Senge in 1990. The general concept of the book is exploring a "learning organization." The first four disciplines are Personal Mastery, Mental Models, Building Shared Visions, and Team Learning. The Fifth Discipline is "Systems thinking" or how the prior four disciplines integrate. The objective of this learning organization is to create companies that focus on results that matter to their objectives. Additionally, Senge highlights 11 laws of the fifth discipline (with my commentary on each law below). 

1. Today's problems come from yesterday's "solutions."

 If you present a halfhearted 'band-aid' solution to a problem, it may work for a while until it doesn't, which can lead to snowballed problems. An example of this can be found in the recent manufacturing issues at Boeing, where many of the current issues are rumored to have been through management cutting costs and consolidating their HQ to Chicago. 

2. The harder you push, the harder the system pushes back.

 An object in motion loves to stay in motion, and vice versa. Additionally, nature prefers calm to volatility. Big sweeping moves are likely to be unpopular, whereas the same move but broken up can be accomplished without much notice. 

3. Behavior grows better before it grows worse.

 This one is pretty similar to #1. If you have an issue, and present a solution that works briefly before falling apart, the behavior has indeed grown better before falling back into problematic territory. 

4. The easy way out usually leads back in. 

 A lot of the laws here focus on doing things the right way rather than the easy way. A great example of this is the rise of 'education' software like chegg.com. The easy way out: getting your homework done quickly and without much thought. Back in: when you inevitably fail the exam from not practicing any of the problems that you "solved" 

5. The cure can be worse than the disease. 

 From a literal perspective, this can be true, you see this now with the over prescription of anti-bacterial pharmaceutics which in turn create highly resistant new bacteria. You can see how this would apply in the management realm too. 

6. Faster is slower. 

 Who won that race between the tortoise and the hare again? 

7. Cause and effect are not closely related in time and space 

 When solving a problem related to management, you can't just focus on the immediate causes. If there is something that is underlying or systemic, focus should be brought there first. 

8. Small changes can produce big results... but the areas of highest leverage are often the least obvious. 

 A great example of this occurred to me in sailing. There is a maneuver in sailing called "tacking", it a simple maneuver which results in changing your position, allowing you to sail into the wind. I have done this maneuver probably tens of thousands of times over the past 15 years. This year, I learned a new way of doing it thanks to our new coach, which is highly effective. All the great results I have achieved over the years were in spite of this maneuver being fundamentally incorrect. Sobering, to say the least. 

9. You can have your cake and eat it too- but not all at once

 Winning takes time. Don't sell yourself short before the work is complete. 

10. Dividing an elephant in half doesn't produce two small elephants. 

 If there is an elephant in the room, you may not gain from just simply splitting the work. Instead, the root causes should be identified and rooted out of an organization. 

11. There is no blame. 

 Truly effective managers know that the buck stops with them, even if an underling screws up or if something happens out of the manager's control. There is no benefit to trying to assign blame, and steps should be taken to control the outcomes before they happen 

This is a fascinating look into successful management tactics and the applications of the laws in your own life are plentiful.

Post by samgugliotta » Tue Feb 27, 2024 9:33 pm

Strictly ballroom assignment

Step 1:

Adventure and Security

Step 2:

Adventure: exploration, excitement, discovery, thrill, freedom, growth, growth

Security: certainty, safety, guarantee, comfort, predictability, routine, protection, assurance, familiarity

Step 3:

“The need to constantly feel familiarity prevents one from seeking self-discovery”

Step 4:

After finishing the film “Strictly Ballroom”, I have determined the themes of Adventure and Security fit well with the movie's message, and relate to the main character greatly. Scott Hastings is a male ballroom dancer who challenges the norms of ballroom dancing by creating his style of choreography, amazing fans, and angering the establishment at the same time. Having the drive to pursue his style and break away from the traditional dance norms highlights the spirit of adventure that Scott pushes for throughout the film. His ability to take risks even though they could be career-ruining highlights how important risk-taking can be in anyone's life. On the other hand, the immense pressure to conform to social norms and dance traditionally highlights security that all of us have felt at some point. Pushback from friends, family, and peers affects everyone's lives and this is evident during “Strictly Ballroom”. The message in the film is to go into life with the hope of creating new experiences for yourself, regardless of what others may think. I can relate to this message because pushing to be unique and seek adventure has been a big part of my life. Since I was younger, I always had a love and appreciation for music and sound production. At first, I started as a casual listener and never thought of creating my own work. When I was 15, I was desperate to attempt to make music but felt scrutinized by my friends and peers. I felt that releasing my own music was too personal, and I unfortunately feared the judgment of others. After years of creating songs and never releasing them, I finally realized that following the same path as others was boring and overall unenjoyable. My mother put it best when she said “Life is too short, do what makes you happy”. This is a motto I learned to live by and now I have released multiple songs and enjoyed every step of the way, whether it was difficult or incredible. Feeling comfortable and having security is great in moderation, but stepping outside of your comfort zone allows you to become more fulfilled, and see life with an all-new perspective. Doing what you like and being adventurous regardless of what others think should be the way that every person lives.

Subject: selecting two words and creating a dichotomy

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

How should I make sense of my experience immersed in the Business of Ballroom dancing?

How should I make sense of my experience of living and learning in the College of Business?

You are juxtaposing things, people, metaphors, images, feelings, contexts, perspectives, outcomes, structures.

A dichotomy is the juxtaposing of two words.

By comparing and contrasting the two words, you are generating the relations between them.

That is, you are generating structures of words. Sentences.

We project our sentence structures on a big screen and then compare and contrast them as well.

In this way, through dialog and dialectic, reflection and imagination, I journey to the end and give an account of what is the meaning of Sanjiv in the College of Business. Please see Sam Gugliotta's postings below.

The bottom line. Develop a sentence structure between two words and then deconstruct the structure by infusing your experience from the past. Your process must be organic, fluid, and evolving to a deeper understanding. You are sorting, sifting, selecting, and substituting. You are familiar with the process by now.

Sanjiv

DICHOTOMY, DIALOG, DIALECTIC, IMAGE, IMAGINATION

Karl Weick and Sense-making

Karl Weick is an american organizational theorist and is a university professor at Michigan University. Weick is known throughout the world for his work as a scholar, writing several pieces about organizational behavior such as collective sensemaking under pressure, medical errors, handoffs in extreme events, and continuous change. His largest achievements would be his winning of the 1990 “Best Article of the Year” Award for his influential article “Theory Construction as Disciplined Imagination”, and his 1969 book “The Social Psychology of Organizing” being named one of the best business books ever written. Weick’s theory of Sensemaking is the process in which people give meaning to their collective experiences. To simplify, this means it is the process that allows people to understand difficult or confusing situations. There is some sort of disagreement as there is no clear definition on whether it is an ongoing process or occurs during these rare events. The seven properties of sensemaking include:

Identity and identification

Retrospection provides opportunities for sensemaking

People enact the environments they face in dialogues

Sensemaking is a social activity in that plausible stories are shared, but the audience includes the speaker themselves

Sensemaking is ongoing

People extract cues from the context to help them decide on what info is relevant

People favor plausibility over accuracy

Theory of movement images, Deleuze, and Bergson

Bergson was a philosopher that said the world is always moving, but we see it as separate moments due to our habits and needs. Deleuze decided to test this theory by applying them to film, stating movies can show the constant movement of reality better than other storytelling forms. With the use of perception images, action images, and affection images, movies convey messages the best. Perception images show what we see, action images show what characters do and how events unfold, and affection images highlight the emotions being conveyed. By better understanding the images, we can see the ways the movies affect us and how they reflect constant change in the world.

By observing and analyzing people's interactions, we gain insights into the underlying norms, values, and beliefs that shape their behavior.

Norms, values, and beliefs are generally invisible; underlying structures that are taken for granted we call “culture." 

So, let's consider the business of Strictly Ballroom. When we watch the moving images of social interaction, what insights do we get into the 'underlying norms, values, and beliefs that shape the behavior of the protagonists’? How do we uncover hidden assumptions and taken-for-granted knowledge that people use to navigate their social world? The How can be valuable in understanding the underlying structures and processes that shape social interactions.

HOW do we begin to address such a question? WHERE do we start and WHY?

Step 1. 

Make a dichotomy of two words. This first selection of words will influence the trajectory of the thought movement. You have juxtaposed any of the following expressions: two-word images, two metaphors, two ideas, two symbols, two aspects as the cornerstone of the structure of words you intend to construct.

You have been successfully deconstructing structures thus far, and now you are constructing one and you have complete freedom except one: it must have meaning.

You are giving meaning to what you are seeing and experiencing and you are sharing your views in the fishbowl. After sorting, sifting, selecting, and substituting we zero into two words. We intend to weave a web around these two words.

The act of juxtaposition is a subjective and creative act that is self-reflective and intuitive. This action is the first step, so please be careful and start over when it is not going anywhere meaningful. Remember the practice of life is about making sense, creating meaning, context, and discourse.

Step 2. 

We create a word pool for each of the selected 2 words, and we are free to take the words further to create expanding pools. You are familiar with this step. It is doing your vocabulary. This activity focuses on a word without distraction. It is meditative. It is contemplative.

The word pool is the context, the backdrop, the discourse, and the boundary. You have been creating it since the first day.

Contextual understanding is particularly useful when studying complex social processes or when trying to understand the reasons behind people’s actions.

Step 3. 

From the previous step, we construct an opening sentence: word structure. It is simple, it is pithy, it is an axiom, an aphorism, malleable, flexible, and open to multiple interpretations. 

Castles in the air: We make these things by the choices that we make.

Step 4. Within the context and the structure you have created a space, visualized a circle, and staked your position; your point of view. You did this by expressing felt experiences from your past and infusing them into your analysis and observations of the moving images depicted in Strictly Ballroom.

In conclusion, there is nothing I’ve said here that you are not familiar with. The bottom line is the two contrasting words you select and begin a journey of knowing and knowledge creation that is uniquely yours.

Please see Dylan Demers's field notes and the posting by Ryan Dumont. In the field, your notes are everything, so nurture them assiduously.

Sentence: “When examining how meaning is created and understood, it is useful to understand the role of context.”

Examining - auditing, checking, considering, criticizing, inspecting, pondering, scanning, reviewing

Meaning - definition, content, substance

Created - assembled, completed, constructed, fabricated, finished, made, produced

Understood - accepted, appreciated, implied, inferred, presumed

Context - background, situation, text, conditions

New Sentence: “When inspecting how content is constructed and accepted, it is advantageous to grasp the background of text.”

This resonates with me because it talks about how understanding the entire situation, not just the surface level is very useful to understanding it as a whole. I always would try each different problem and topic the same way, never would switch up how I studied, read problems, or took tests. This made it hard to understand the full context of what my mind was attempting to learn and how it perceived each problem. What I could have done differently is reach out for help to get a different perspective, and understand why we are doing what we are doing so I can fully grasp the situation at hand correctly.

People who just follow the work given and hand it in for the grade aren’t actually learning. When you intend for things to happen, those things will eventually happen.

Re: Google searches: Deconstruction

Post by ryandumont » Thu Feb 08, 2024 3:51 pm

Jacques Derrida was a French philosopher, best known for developing the philosophical approach known as deconstruction. Deconstruction is a method of textual analysis that aims to uncover and destabilize the underlying binary oppositions and hierarchical structures present in language, philosophy, and culture. According to Derrida, these binary oppositions (such as presence/absence, speech/writing, and nature/culture) are not fixed and stable but are instead fluid and interdependent.

Sense Making-Karl E Weick

Karl Edward Weick (born October 31, 1936) is an American organizational theorist who introduced the concepts of "loose coupling", "mindfulness", and "sensemaking" into organizational studies. He is the Rensis Likert Distinguished University Professor at the Ross School of Business at the University of Michigan. Karl E Weick highlights how the `sensemaking′ process shapes organizational structure and behavior. The process is seen as the creation of reality as an ongoing accomplishment that takes form when people make retrospective sense of the situations in which they find themselves. Sensemaking is the process by which people give meaning to their collective experiences. It has been defined as "the ongoing retrospective development of plausible images that rationalize what people are doing"

III. Assignment

Please watch the following two films Strictly Ballroom and Kinky Boots. We are watching the films together as ethnographers. Ethnography is a type of social research that involves examining the behavior of the participants in a given social situation in both films and understanding our interpretation of such behavior.

In Strictly Ballroom you witness how the social order in the business of ballroom dancing (compare with the College of Business) is reproduced and sustained. How innovation is a threat to the established order.

In Kinky Boots you are looking at two cultures with different structures and the skills it takes to connect and thrive as a business.

As you watch the films, take down words spoken (words exchanged) and have meaning for you from your experience. These are field notes in ethnographic research where you are a 'participant observer' (please Google).

Sanjiv

The Fifth Discipline by Peter Senge covers the 5 disciplines of a learning organization, Personal Mastery, Mental Models, Building shared vision, team learning, and finally Systems Thinking which takes the previous four elements and builds upon them. Making a learning culture for yourself and teaching yourself disciplines and habits to better organize your life.

A feedback loop is a process which takes the output and reinserts it back unto itself and continuously does so forever. Think of a microphone and a speaker, if a sound is played into the microphone and the speaker plays it into the microphone again, and again.

The feedback loop in the fishbowl is you sharing the information for us to read, you are reinserting the information we have provided for everyone to intake.

Post by DanielOliveira » Fri Feb 09, 2024 12:15 pm

I am doing great, thank you for asking. I hope you are doing well also.

It seems that cultural capital is the value of the cultural appreciation that is passed down to others. We can be rich in cultural capital by experiencing a broad variety of cultures, and wanting to experience them.

How So? For the fishbowl and our postings being seen as etchings of processes and practices is similar to a community painting, many different stylistic expressions and expertises may be shown, and while individually some may be worse than others that difference is what brings it all together. Not afraid to paint over others' work or add your art because that’s the purpose of the mural, to add your touch.

How So? In dissecting a text we are picking apart each individual word, each phrase and giving meaning and understanding to the text. We pull apart to find the writer's true meaning. Done most commonly with pieces of literature that we care about, we take in every word and analyze and bring together the symphony of text.

The final How So? Is on understanding words better and the new truths that come with the understanding. I believe this example comes for many with a piece of literature held closely to their hearts, for some it may be the bible or the quran, but for others, like me, it could be something profoundly simple in the way of the story but expertly crafted and shaped together to make something unique and interesting. The book that did this for me was “Maniac Magee” a surprisingly short book geared for teenagers that covers the harsh and serious topics like racism, homelessness, and being an orphan but skews them, by not focusing on the child's issues and instead making it an undertone for the story. It is a wonderful book that I endorse wholeheartedly.

Abstract & Final Paper Management System

GENERATING KNOWLEDGE CONTENT AND KNOWING IN THE AGE OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE

S. Dugal1, S. Singh2, M. Troiano3, R. Singh4, E. Sillat1, M. Hanna1, M. Vancouyghen1, N. Gamache1, G. Daddio1, C. Calise1, M. Goeller1, M. Sundwall1, J. Castro1, L. Joseph1, A. Ryder1, J. Morley1, S. Discipline: Education

Type of presentation: VIRTUAL

Introduction: awareness of process:

We are 180 undergraduate students at the University of Rhode Island who are generating knowledge content in a Fishbowl; a digital platform where participants post self-reflections to common texts every week. Our visible reflections create an awareness of the other’s cognitive process. Situated in accounts of one’s “epistemic cognition,” we focus on our aims and processes of knowing. Cognition is ‘the mental action or process of acquiring knowledge and understanding through thought, experience, and the senses.’ Epistemic cognition is ‘awareness of the process of acquiring knowledge.’

“Artificial Intelligence" is a constellation of different technologies working together to enable machines to sense, comprehend, act, and learn with human-like intelligence. The goal of AI is to process large amounts of data and recognize patterns, make decisions, and judge like humans.

Since we experience the Fishbowl and ourselves as continuously changing, we believe the dynamic nature of our ‘being' must be the primary focus for any comprehensive account of acquiring knowledge. We are concerned with dynamic entities, like mental occurrences and the realization of individual values in action. In other words, the actual occasion of experience is central when creating knowledge content and knowing. In our paper, we present and identify processes and shifting relationships as the only real experience in the Fishbowl.

Purpose: to bring forth:

1. To share our process of acquiring knowledge and understanding.

2. To evoke thought-images when reading a text.

Method: a flow of processing information:

1. Metacognitive knowledge is the knowledge individuals develop of their own cognitive processes and their ability to monitor and reflect on them; how you think about your own thinking.

2. Metacognitive control characterizes one’s ability to identify learning needs and adapt behavior based on outcomes.

3. When posting in the Fishbowl, we experiment with “free association” and “reader response theory.” The individual’s response is a series of posts which are carried out to observe emerging outcomes. The participant takes inputs, adds value, and provides output for the viewer. The Fishbowl, as a whole, is a set of postings that interact with each other. Often, output of one is input for the other.

4. Postings are conceptual engagements with subjective feelings in fragments of textual snapshots.

Outcome: life of practice:

We restore significance to the practice of self-reflection. We are contemplative without relinquishing characteristics of action. Our process of acquiring knowledge is a “life of practice” where one develops as a “practicing person” and gets the self “into shape” as the “person-that-can.” It is the evolution of subjectivity, ways of feeling, thinking and communicating and, transcending situations. Within a context, the capability of a "practicing person" is viewed as their constitution, virtue, virtuosity, competence, excellence, or fitness for the job.

In the Fishbowl, we showcase our “life of practice”. In the full paper, we present a ‘triptych of works,' and invite viewers to expand upon them, and share their own practices and processes of reading and writing. Our paper is evidence that epistemic cognition and processing of information is more domain and task-specific rather than reproducing generalizations.

Keywords: Cognition, Epistemic Cognition, Knowledge-content, Processing Information, Experiential Learning, Reflexivity, Thought-image, Artificial Intelligence.

Hi Everyone,

 

How are you? I hope you are well. Sorry about the fishbowl being down. Presently, there is another glitch, and will be fixed soon.

 

I’d like to emphasize the process and practice of deconstruction and deploying our attention.

 

The process of deconstruction in the fishbowl has four integrated steps:

 

1. Select a sentence structure

2. Make a word pool from the thesaurus

3. Create a new sentence structure

4. Match a felt experience from an observation/an interpretation from your past.

 

These can be stated as:

 

1. The Form of Things. An opening structure.

2. Boundary of words for exchange and possibility.

3. Re-structure. Re-formulate. A new composition.

4. Explain with specific examples from the past.

 

In the fishbowl, we are learning how to deploy our attention. How to attend to things; take care of them. Only when we understand participation, collaboration, credibility, and awareness of each other will we be able to control our destiny, according to Howard Rheingold in Net Smart. Please google.

 

We are learning how to exert mental control over our use of always-on communication channels. We are learning to live mindfully in cyberculture.

Post by tiagohuynh » Wed Feb 07, 2024 9:27 pm

AESTHETIC RESPONSE:

1. "We identify our experiences that happened in the past by examining our feelings about them in the present."

2. Word Pool:

Identify: Distinguish, pinpoint, find, locate, recognize, determine, diagnose, investigate, examine, discover, disclose

Experiences: Adventures, times, ordeals, happenings, exploits, actions, escapades, gests, doings, deeds

Happened: Occurred, came, was, did, transpired, befell, passed, happed, came about

Past: History, yesterday, annals, record, flashback, chronicle, long ago, yore

Examining: Reviewing, surveying, scanning, inspecting, analyzing, viewing, scrutinizing, investigating, dissecting, going over, exploring

Feelings: Passions, spirit, sensibilities, sentiment, desire, fondness, warmth

Present: Current, ongoing, recent, immediate, existing, modern, newfangled, contemporary

3. Reconstruct Sentence:

Attempt 1:

We distinguish our exploits that occurred in the annals by investigating our passions about them in the current time.

Attempt 2:

We distinguish our ordeals that occurred in yore by investigating our existing sensibilities about them.

Attempt 3: (Final)

We distinguish our exploits that occurred in history by exploring our current sentiments about them.

Felt Experience:

I believe that our feelings and our perception of past events in our lives can change and warp as we mature and get older. When I was younger, fighting with my brothers was a daily and vicious occurrence. Our arguments would begin at the drop of a hat over the most mundane and insignificant of things. My parents would often describe us as oil and water mixed with gasoline. At the moment, I held so much animosity toward my brothers and every single thing they did vex me beyond belief. It all reached a head when my older brother enlisted in the Marine Corps. Suddenly without him there, all of our fights and issues with one another seemed insignificant and small in the grand scheme. At the time, our arguments would outrage me beyond belief, at the present, I look back with regret over the constant turmoil.

Hi Everyone,

How are you this Monday morning? I hope you are well.

Please see Peter Hoan’s postings below. They are excellent examples of understanding theory. Nicely done. 

Raising it a notch higher: to give evidence of one’s learning through the experience of Doing, one has to describe an instance, incident, or event, in the First person, and answer the question How so?

In other words, give an example from your experience.

Describing an example is the hard part because it takes focused reflection and interpretation with a dollop of imagination. You are looking for circumstances from your life that will test your understanding. Best not to rush it. See it as solving an intellectual game where you can’t hide behind your words. Make this a life-long practice. It is the stuff of leadership.

You are gradually training yourself in the fundamental anthropological skills of “attending to, by observing, registering, and correlating”. You are looking at learning, discovery, and understanding as a pleasurable skill rather than a source of stress. The mantra, the talisman is “How So?"

Sanjiv

Experiential Learning

Post by PeterHoan » Tue Jan 30, 2024 1:43 pm

"Experiential Learning is defined as the process of learning by doing. By engaging in hands-on experiences and reflection" Experiential learning is very important especially in real life situations. By being able to learn by doing gives us experience on what to aspect and allows us to learn from our mistakes early on rather than trying to learn our mistakes down the road. It also emphasizes the importance of reflection as an integral part of this learning approach.

I tend to find myself getting a better understand on things when I am actually doing it myself. I prefer doing hands-on experiences and reflections rather than sitting in a room and taking notes from a powerpoint presentation. Overall, I find myself doing better in class when it comes to experiential learning.

When there is a word that sticks out to me, I find myself taking the time to understand what was said to me and then it either creates some kind of emotions or ideas.

"It has to be pulled out from the roots, and that involves our beginning to think in a new way." What I took away from this phrase was that it addresses a certain issue. It requires a fundamental and complete removal, and this process involves starting to think differently or adopting a new perspective. That sentence resonated with me in a sense where to start thinking differently from everyone else, we have to start facing problems at the core of it instead of the surface. By doing this, it will allow us to fully understand our problems and allows us to start think in new ways. This sentence also resonated with me and how it can help improve personal growth. It suggests that personal growth involves uprooting old ways of thinking and adopting a mindset conducive to positive change.

Date: 2/4/2024 17:08:48
Subject: deconstruction
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

Section I.

Deconstruction is a critical theory and philosophical approach proposed by the French philosopher Jacques Derrida. Please google his name. 

The key argument in deconstruction is that constructing meaning is unreliable as the language that communicates meaning is itself unreliable. Please refer to your postings in the fishbowl.

Derrida posited that it’s impossible to determine fixed, underlying meanings in a text.

The focus on language (words) 

as a means of revealing 

how 

we construct and make a social reality, 

which was witnessed and experienced in the first assignment in the fishbowl.

The focus on language (words) proves to be useful in the age of social media.

By focusing on language in the fishbowl, we can illustrate the complex yet fragile and tentative webs of meaning on which so much of our social practice is based. How So?

Language in the form of written and social text is never self-evident. Meanings (like your names) are always mediated by external contexts and points of reference. Black only acquires significance to the concept and meaning of white. To grasp and understand even the simplest meanings, it seems that we have to draw on all kinds of implicit knowledge and engage in complex acts of social construction and interpretation that are tentative, and always in danger of breaking down. The worlds in which we live, it seems, are truly extensions of ourselves and the forms of life through which we experience and engage them.

Section II.

Step 1. Select a sentence structure:

“Fundamental to our exchange is the way one’s process and practice are structured, I.e., the way they are put together.”

Step 2. From the Thesaurus, copy synonyms for the following words taken from the original sentence structure in Step 1:

fundamental

exchange

way

process

practice

structure

Step 3. From the word pool of about 20-25 words in Step 2, reconstruct the original sentence structure

Step 4. A short paragraph that describes a felt experience from your past and fits the structure in Step 3.

Section III.

Please visit your postings in the fishbowl and realize the knowledge content in section I.

Sanjiv

Re: Google Searches: Aesthetic Response

post by zanefrattarelli » Sun Feb 04, 2024 11:58 am

There has been a struggle to come up with one generally accepted definition for aesthetic response. However, there is some consensus that "the concept involves the registering of affect or pleasure due to the conscious or unconscious influences of aspects of an object." An aesthetic response refers to the reaction that a person has to an object based on their individual perception of the object.

Something that resonates with me is "individual perceptions"

Going through life, we are able to meet so many different people who all have their own sets of values and beliefs. These values and beliefs can lead people to perceive things in different ways. Not just in an "aesthetic" matter but for life in general. It is important to not make judgments about someone based on the way they perceive things because each individual is wired in a different way.

One’s ‘way’ of doing things.

“Getting hold of the difficulty deep down is what is hard. Because it is grasped near the surface it simply remains the difficulty it was. It has to be pulled out from the roots, and that involves our beginning to think in a new way. The change is as decisive as, for example, that from the alchemical to the chemical way of thinking. The new way of thinking is what is so hard to establish. Once the new way of thinking has been established, the old problems vanish; indeed, they become hard to recapture. For they go with our way of expressing ourselves and, if we clothe ourselves in a new form of expression, the old problems are discarded along the old garment.”

Ludwig Wittgenstein, Yermischte Bemerkungen

Subject: Aesthetic Response

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

I am reflecting on what we have done so far…that is, the ‘doing’ of the first assignment (about your name), vocabulary, and Google searches.

From our fragments (postings in the fishbowl) will emerge the outline of a field, a domain, a perspective. We will envision the landscape (metaphor) of our minds.

We learn by reflecting and thinking about our experiences.

We identify our experiences that happened in the past by examining our feelings about them in the present.

We have an arsenal of felt experiences to reflect upon and to learn from those reflections.

By focusing on a word we generate images (visual regions), feelings (emotions), thoughts (ideas), text (language regions), and meaning.

To focus on a word is to meditate on it and contemplate it. 

To be in a conversation (dialog) with the word and investigate (dialectic) the meaning of the word. 

The fishbowl is a dialectic relationship between text, you as the reader, and your interaction with the text. Your posting in the fishbowl is called an Aesthetic Response (please google), because although your posting is brought about by the text (my letter), it brings into play your imaginative and perceptive faculties which make you, adjust and even differentiate your focus, Please see Matthew Cintron’s posting below.

Dialog (conversation with the word), and 

Dialectic (investigate the truth as to its meaning).

We are creative and proactive individuals who critically “make” notes that determine our experiences and outcomes.

We are individuals who exercise their Agency. That is, we act to produce a certain effect or result.

 

I want to congratulate you all. 

Your grades are in the range of A- and A. Well done! 

It was never a matter of right/wrong but whether you did it, or not. We learn by doing!

Sanjiv

1. EMERGE, LANDSCAPE

2. MAKE, EXPERIENCE, OUTCOME, AGENCY

3. AESTHETIC, RESPONSE

4. FOCUS, MEDITATE, CONTEMPLATE, MEANING

5. CONVERSATION, INVESTIGATION, DIALOG, DIALECTIC

Introduction- Matthew Cintron

	 by MatthewCintron » Wed Jan 24, 2024 1:40 pm

Hello, my name is Matthew Cintron and I am a marketing major from Texas. My name stems from Hebrew origins, meaning "Gift of God" or "Gift of Yahweh".

My parents both agreed to name me Matthew because my father is Puerto Rican and my mother wanted me to have a name that could be said in both Spanish and English.

I don't believe I have lived up to my name mostly because I am not religious although my parents are. While I do understand that the meaning can be extended beyond religious context, ideas and concepts based in religion never really connected with me.

MatthewCintron

Joined: Mon Jan 22, 2024 2:10 pm

Re: Introduction- Matthew Cintron

	 by MatthewCintron » Tue Jan 30, 2024 9:50 pm

The word I choose is serenity. Serenity: the state of being calm, peaceful, and untroubled. While I may not literally be physically able to be a "gift from God" (at least not knowingly), I am okay with not feeling a sense of fulfillment associated with my name. To me, a name is simply a label. We all have one to decipher from one another and while many of our names have powerful meanings assigned by our parents, I do not personally see it that way. Because of that, whether or not I live up to the meaning of the name does not matter to me and leaves me a feeling of calmness. My parents also did not stress any particular meaning associated with my name so growing up, there really was not symbolic idea to live up to.

Topic: About Reading in the Fishbowl.

Hi Everyone,

I hope this letter finds you well and the dust settles (metaphor), sooner than later. It was wonderful to see you yesterday. Looking at you looking at me looking at you. We are eyes looking at eyes.

Today I am writing to highlight the incredible opportunity we have to foster a culture of reading within the Fishbowl community. Reading is a powerful tool that not only expands our knowledge but also enhances critical thinking and enriches our understanding of the world around us.

As we navigate the vast and ever-evolving landscape of the fishbowl, the importance of staying informed and continuously learning through reading, cannot be overstated. 

We have a wealth of resources at our fingertips, ranging from insightful articles to thought-provoking postings initiated by ourselves within the fishbowl. Here are a few reasons why embracing reading in the Fishbowl can significantly benefit our academic and professional journey:

1. Diverse Perspectives: Reading exposes us to a multitude of perspectives and ideas. Engaging with different viewpoints within the Fishbowl community broadens understanding and contributes to a more well-rounded education.

2. Current Trends and Insights: The Fishbowl is dynamic, with trends and insights constantly evolving. Regularly reading content will keep you updated on the latest, emerging, innovative practices in the fishbowl.

3, Networking Opportunities: Engaging in exchanges around shared readings can lead to valuable connections and insights.

4. Personal and Professional Growth: Reading is a powerful catalyst for personal and professional growth. Whether you're exploring new subjects, deepening your understanding of familiar topics, or seeking inspiration, the Fishbowl library offers a diverse array of materials to support your growth journey.

5. Encourage a culture of reading within the Fishbowl community by creating a collaborative environment for knowledge-sharing.

6. Elevate your academic experience and enhance your readiness for the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead, by actively engaging with the written content available.

If you have any questions or need assistance in navigating the Fishbowl, don't hesitate to ask. Let's make the Fishbowl a vibrant hub of intellectual curiosity and a source of inspiration to each of us. 

Happy reading, and here's to a semester filled with knowledge and knowing! Please see the Introduction Assignment below.

sincerely,

Sanjiv

Date: 1/21/2024 20:23:03
Subject: Syllabus MGT448: International Dimensions of Business
------------------------------------------------------------
UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION

SPRING 2024

Sanjiv S. Dugal, Ph.D.

314 Ballantine

Human Resource Management

Address: sanjivdugal@uri.edu

Office Hours: MW: 12-1 pm

MGT 448

INTERNATIONAL AND CULTURAL DIMENSIONS OF BUSINESS

PREFACE

“As we globalize, we increasingly have to interact, manage, negotiate and compromise with people from different cultures. Working with people whose values and beliefs, not to mention languages and customs are different from your own can make for costly misunderstandings. Experience tells us, often painfully, that one’s behavior, actions and decisions are not separate from one’s values and beliefs. All social behavior is embedded in a particular context and is connected to other deeply held values and beliefs. This means that the stakes are high for mismanaging cultural differences.” (Lisa Hoecklin, 'Managing Cultural Differences: Strategies for Competitive Advantage,' The Economist Intelligence Unit Series, Addison-Wesley, 1995)

I. INTRODUCTION 

How do you navigate and negotiate a situation that is foreign and strange? A situation where the Other's language, customs, and culture are unknown, and you have no predetermined script nor map on the ground. Under these circumstances, what skills are necessary to successfully collaborate on projects together?

II. PROBING DIFFERENCES

"In a global marketplace, many leading international business scholars are arguing that sustainable competitive advantages are increasingly changing from ‘harder ’ efficiency sources to ‘softer ’ effectiveness sources, such as managing differences in values and beliefs. Our differences provide a reflective lens to see where we're positioned with regards to each other." (Hoecklin).

In the course, we are comparing broad value differences across America-Japan, America-China, and America-India. Values, according to Geert Hofstede’s definition, are ‘a broad tendency to prefer certain state of affairs over others.’ The course identifies four dimensions of value differences across cultures, viz., Power Distance, Uncertainty Avoidance, Individualism/Collectivism and Masculinity/Femininity. 

Managing differences among ourselves gives the course not only an identity but also its competitive advantage. The course fulfills the logical sequence of 

Awareness (of differences among ourselves), 

Knowledge (of those differences), and 

Communication (of those differences). 

These three traits, viz., awareness, knowledge and communication underlie the development of cross-cultural skills (Geert Hofstede). Empirical evidence suggests that creating sustainable advantages when interacting with people from different cultures, at home and abroad, will require the following skills:

a. an ability to express

b. flexibility in thought and action

c. sharing and disclosing one’s position in a situation

d. abstracting from the particulars of an interaction

We are developing these capabilities on a digital platform, we call The Fishbowl.

III. METHODOLOGIES: PARTICIPANT OBSERVATION, INTERPRETIVISM, SYMBOLIC INTERACTIONISM

The course utilizes research methods such as Participant Observation, Interpretivism, Social Reflexivity, and Symbolic Interactionism for addressing Cultural questions such as:

How do you experience the Other’s culture?

That is, how do you experience the Other’s deeply held values and beliefs?

What do you see?

How do you feel?

What did you do?

IV. TEXT

1. Letters in the Fishbowl: The Fishbowl is a social network of writing/viewing/experiencing. The Fishbowl is something knowable only in specific fishbowl practices and contingencies during the course of the semester.You will receive around 100 letters written specifically to you for safe-keeping and re-reading, because the text in the letters represents a potential effect that is realized in the reading process. 

Reading is therefore your focal point, for it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend both on the text and on the exercise of your basic human faculties.

2. ‘Exploring Culture, Exercises, Stories and Synthetic Cultures,’ by Gert van Hofstede, Paul B. Pedersen, Geert Hofstede. Intercultural Press, Boston, London, 2002.

Real-life exercises and stories, all with debriefings, make much of this book ideally suited for self-study. Specific activities and exercises are steps towards awareness and knowledge of differences. We will practice intercultural communication skills, and playfully experience what it feels and means to be a ‘foreigner.’

3. Films: Kinky Boots, Japanese Story, Moonrise Kingdom, Outsourced, Iron & Silk.

We deconstruct films to discern underlying cultural assumptions and structures that are playing out.

V. GRADE DISTRIBUTION

1. Regularity and Quality of Participation in the Fishbowl: 50%

There will be ongoing assignments that will help you create a knowing and knowledge content around four dimensions of culture-related values, viz., identity (individualism/collectivism); gender (masculinity/femininity); power distance; and, uncertainty avoidance. These interactive assignments are 50% of your grade.

2. Attending to Meaning in Social Space: 30%

We 'attend to meaning' by sharing, responding and listening to each other. Working in the Fishbowl is an interactive practice of shared words, symbols, images and felt-experiences. Your process will be assessed by the importance you place on 'attending to meaning.' 

“When operating in a global economy, if you want your philosophies, objectives, products and services to be not only understood but also believed by employees, customers and partners in different cultures, you must attend to what these things mean to the people in each culture.” (Hoecklin, p.3)

3. Final: A Self-Reflexive Process 20%

In the final analysis, you’re exploring differences in meanings that existed when working together on a particular idea. Your final paper (3 pages, double–spaced and constructed individually) presents your fishbowl experience as a coherent idea. You're obliged to become self-reflexive, suspend preconceptions, and reflect upon the culture of a ‘fishbowl ‘at the University of Rhode Island.

VI. SELF-ASSESSMENT IN THE FISHBOWL

Learning is about actively combining enriching experiences with academic rigor and creative opportunities. Interaction during the semester requires courage to push back the boundaries of past experiences and explore the possibilities available to you. In MGT448, you experience the excitement of discovering what you are capable of achieving, far more than you ever felt or thought possible. The following elements are essential for this experience:

* Knowledge

* Concept

* Skill

* Attitude

* Action

The student is able to make accurate self-assessments at any point during the semester based upon the following criteria:

BEGINNING (B) 

You have basic knowledge and skills. 

DEVELOPING (D)

You are making conceptual connections. 

ACHIEVING (A)

You have acquired knowledge and skills and making conceptual connections, and thereby developing new learning.

EXCELLING (E)

You are applying knowledge and skills beyond grade-level expectations and demonstrate self-initiated action in unfamiliar situations. You are self-motivated and an independent learner.

Faster and better learning through realization is a large part of the assessment logic.

VII. CONCLUSION: FISHBOWL LEARNER PROFILE

The aim of the Fishbowl is to develop global-minded participants who recognize their common purpose and shared responsibility when creating a culture of learning. 

As fellow participants in a fishbowl, we strive To Be the following:

1. Inquirers 

We nurture our curiosity, developing skills for inquiry and research.

2. Knowledgeable 

We develop and use conceptual understanding, exploring knowledge across a range of disciplines. We engage with issues and ideas that have local and global significance.

3. Thinkers 

We use critical and creative thinking skills to analyze and take responsible action on complex issues. We exercise initiative in making reasoned, ethical decisions.

4. Communicators 

We express ourselves with confidence and creatively in many ways. We collaborate actively, listening carefully to the perspectives of other individuals and groups.

5. Principled 

We act with integrity and honesty with a strong sense of fairness and justice, and with respect for the dignity and rights of others. We take responsibility for our actions and their consequences.

6. Open-minded 

We critically appreciate our own culture and personal history, as well as the values and traditions of others. We seek and evaluate a range of points of view, and we are willing to grow from the experience.

7. Caring 

We show empathy, compassion and respect. We have a commitment to service, and we act to make a positive difference in the lives of others and in the world around us.

8. Risk-takers 

We approach uncertainty with forethought and determination; we work independently and cooperatively to explore new ideas and innovative strategies. We are resourceful and resilient in the face of challenges and change.

9. Balanced 

We understand the importance of balancing different aspects of our lives, intellectual, physical, and emotional, to achieve well-being for ourselves and others. We recognize our interdependence with other people.

10. Reflective 

We thoughtfully consider the world and our own ideas and experience. We work to understand our strengths and weaknesses in order to support our learning and personal development.

WELCOME TO MGT 448

You can call them for complete information at 874-2367, or just stop by the center on the fourth floor of Roosevelt Hall.

Date: 1/21/2024 20:10:11
Subject: Syllabus: MGT345: Business and Society
------------------------------------------------------------
University of Rhode Island

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS

SPRING 2024

BUSINESS AND SOCIETY

MGT 345

SANJIV S. DUGAL

sanjivdugal@uri.edu

314 Ballantine Hall

OFFICE HOURS: MW 12-1 pm

“MGT 345 is about becoming who you are. Upon completing the course, you are not arriving at any fixed destination nor will you find some permanent room with a view. But you will see and experience for yourselves that whenever you reach for the highest, you become who you are.” 

WELCOME TO MGT 345

I. INTRODUCTION: BUSINESS AND SOCIETY

All major social changes are ultimately characterized by a transformation of space and time in the human experience (Manuel Castells, 2010). The most profound social change is taking place in new communication technologies that are fostering the development of social spaces of visual reality. The Internet is the backbone of this global computer-mediated communication. Please see: https://www.internetsociety.org/internet/

MGT 345: Business and Society is placed within the framework of two fundamental transformations in our daily lives: ‘the fragmentation of societies and the individualization of work.’ 

II. BUILDING A SOCIETY: A NETWORK OF VISUAL REALITY

Participants in MGT 345 develop and experience two interrelated concepts during the semester: A Network Society and a Visual Reality. We will be developing a network of perceptual spaces characterized by the sharing of “thought images” among ourselves. Our networks reflect distinctive realities that are “individuations,” and outside any regulation. That is to say, we will be developing unique social relations (forms of relatedness) that are manifestations of our networks of text and thought images. The result is a visual reality, a ‘way of seeing’ and ‘being’ in the world that is unique to us, the participants. A ‘way of seeing’ is the key manifestation of ‘the network society’ according to Manuel Castells. 

The question we’re confronting in the course: what is our ‘way of seeing’ the world? What is the visual reality of our social space and network society?

III. COURSE DICTUM: DESCRIBE THINGS

In the course, you work like a phenomenologist whose dictum is: Describe Things. The things that you describe denote any ordinary thing, object, or event as it presents itself to your experience, rather than as it may or may not be in reality. To ‘describe’ is to strip away distractions, habits, cliches of thought, presumptions and received ideas, in order to return attention to what is called ‘things in themselves.’ To capture them exactly as they appear, rather than as you think they are supposed to be. Like blind-tasting! In the course, you ‘set aside’ or ‘bracket out’ theorizing and moralizing about what the thing is, so that we are left only with the intense and immediate experience of the phenomenon. 

The result is a great liberation. It frees you to talk about your experience as a serious topic of investigation. The course gives participants a formal mode of access to their human experience. 

In other words, we’re concerning ourselves with concrete felt-experiences and individual aesthetic responses. We talk about our own lives while still being methodical and rigorous. Our rigor has to do with describing phenomena. Saying the music concert or the homework assignment was great is not enough. You have to stay committed to describing the experience. Traditionally, we begin learning from theories in textbooks. In this course, you’re going straight for life as you experienced it at the moment. For instance, what does it mean to be in this very moment as you read this letter? Anticipation, perhaps? What is it for this thing ‘anticipation’ to exist, to Be? Until we ask such fundamental questions, we will not get anywhere in understanding ‘anticipation.’ Our method is to disregard intellectual clutter and pay attention to ‘things’ and let them reveal themselves.

IV. COURSE METHOD: ETHNOGRAPHIC ACTION RESEARCH

Ethnographic Action Research (EAR) is a form of participatory action research. The ethnographic approach combined with action research is to build upon notions of immersion, long-term engagement, and understanding local contexts holistically. The course combines three approaches: participatory techniques, ethnography, and action learning. Participatory techniques are used to help participants understand complex issues in an inclusive and participatory manner. Ethnography has traditionally been used to understand different cultures in detail and rejects preconceived ideas and categories in favor of locally emergent ones. Action learning allows us to turn what we learn from research into actions, then research those actions, and adjust and adapt accordingly.

A foundational concept of Ethnographic Action Research is ‘communicative ecologies.’ A communicative ecology is made up of communicative assemblages and refers to the complex systems of communication, media, and information flows in a community; a network society. Whenever we start to notice HOW we communicate around certain themes, or HOW we accomplish certain tasks, we start to appreciate which channels and flows are used and why, how this relates to other possible uses, and therefore, where are the opportunities and barriers to a development initiative.

V. “IS THERE A TEXT IN THIS CLASS?” 

You will receive around 100 letters during the semester. What happens to you as readers of these letters, and what does their text make you feel and do is bring into the world something that hitherto did not exist. This can be qualified as visual reality. 

Reading the letters in a particular way is the focal point of the course because it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend on both, the text and on the exercise of your human faculties (senses, wits, reason, intelligence). In other words, the letter’s text represents a potential effect that is realized in the reading process. This happens whenever you, as a reader, assemble the meaning of the letter in a process of ‘re-creative dialectics.’ 

To get the participation going, there are necessary prerequisites. These prerequisites are laid out in the letters in a wide range of specific instructions. By the end of the course, you can see how you generate and occupy ideas, abstractions, and words; how you move about, and how you conduct yourself in perceptual space.

The following seminal Texts are used by the Instructor as references in MGT 345:

References:

1. Manuel Castells, 2010, The Rise Of The Network Society, Vol.1-3, Wiley-Blackwell

2. Margaret Dikovitskaya, 2005, Visual Culture, M.I.T. Press

3. David Harvey, 1990, The Condition of Post Modernity, Blackwell

4. Nicholas Mirzoeff, 2016, How To See The World, Basic Books

5. Mike Chang and Nigel Thrift, Eds, 2000, Thinking Space, Routledge

6. Zygmunt Bauman, 2003, Liquid Love, Polity

7. Anthony Giddens, 1986, The Constitution of Society, California University Press

8. Antonio Negri, 2008, The Porcelain Workshop: For a New Grammar of Politics, Semiotext(e)

9. Bruno Latour, 2007, Reassembling the Social, Oxford

10. Muriel Combes, 2013, Gilbert Simondon and the Philosophy of the Transindividual, The MIT Press.

11. Wolfgang Iser, 2006, how to do theory, Blackwell Publishing, MA, USA; Oxford, UK; Victoria, Australia

VI. PRACTICE AND PROCESS

The method that is practiced in MGT345 begins with the simple act of paying attention to a word with care and respect. Word practices are found in many traditions around the globe. It is having awareness that arises by non-judgmentally paying attention, on purpose, to the present moment. Such awareness is a combination of receptivity, like listening, alertness, and attentive presence. That is, letting everything else be in the background or letting it go entirely.

The course requires a different way of thinking; a thinking that ‘knowing,’ reminds you, awakens you, brings you to yourself, and transforms you. Besides claiming to transform the way you think about doing business in society, the course promises to change how you think about yourself. There is no traced-out path that will lead you; you must constantly invent your path. But to invent it, you have to be free, responsible, and without excuse, for every hope lies within you. In the end, we have no other interest than this: to reconnect with normal lived experience. 

VII. ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATION: LIFE OF PRACTICE

In MGT 345, we are developing skills to convince viewers, readers, and our audience of the advantages of one’s semantic and action-orienting powers. 

Our success, under the circumstances, has the following two characteristics: 

first, 

multiple channels of communication that helped us frame issues; 

and second, 

credibility that is enhanced by our sustained practices and processes. 

When undertaking any developmental initiative, it is, ultimately, our sustained practices and processes that determine success.

To address that, you’re expected to regularly respond under the following Topic heads:

1. Notes: Taking and Making from Google Searches 

2. Vocabulary: Concepts and Thought-images

3. Deep Learning and Deconstructing words 

4. Assignments

You will be immersed in the society and culture of a fishbowl.

Here you are learning and understanding by living a life of practice.

Your Being in the Fishbowl and your Mind combine to envision and create essential objects, experiences, and meanings.

You are developing word structures, word images, and felt experiences that are significant to anyone seeking to contextualize, navigate, and transform increasingly complex cultures, societies, and networks. Your life of practice in the fishbowl illuminates how to nurture creative practices from the initial spark to the finished outcome. 

From your in-depth accounts in the fishbowl, your readers and audience will discover methods and tools for themselves that will help them to… 

* Frame critical questions through an iterative process

* Apply hands-on, embodied learning from text and images

* Enhance seeing through closer looking

* Meet uncertainty with flexibility

* Evaluate and articulate the significance of your work

* Generate ethical responses to global needs

VIII. GRADE: DISTRIBUTION

1. A Society of Transnational Organizations 40%

Empirical research (Bartlett and Ghoshal) identifies four characteristics of successful transnational organizations, viz., 

Integrated Networking Structures, 

Complex Adaptive Systems, 

Dynamic Decision-Making, and 

Unique Innovative Capabilities. 

Every characteristic is developed and experienced by participants, in 10 interactive steps.

2. Deconstructing Letters and Deep Learning: 30%

You are developing slower and essential cognitive processes such as critical thinking, reflection, and empathy—-all parts of deep reading. 

When do you read and post, 

How do you read and post, and 

Why do you read and post, 

What you read and post 

changes how you think. 

The quality and quantity of your reading and posting is not only an index of the quality of your thought, it is the best-known path to developing whole new paths.

Through analogies, drawing inferences, and arriving at independent judgments, you are deconstructing text and generating subjective experiences.

3. Final Reflection: Visual Reality and Network Society: 20%

The act of taking on the perspective and feelings of another is communication effected in solitude and depicts an intimate emotional dimension within the course experience. Your final is a reflection on your visual reality and network society by “looking at yourself looking at yourself.” Three pages, double-spaced.

4. Individuation: 10% 

Individuation, or the way you distinguish yourself from others, is always in a relationship and, it is a process. Individuation makes awareness, action, and evaluation possible. 

At the end of the day, after it is all said and done, your grade is determined by two things: level of engagement and creation of value. How often, how much and to what end did you develop and individuate yourself? 

EPILOGUE

Subject: welcome to the fishbowl and registration instructions
------------------------------------------------------------

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well. 

It is time to gear-up (metaphor) for the last lap (metaphor) of the semester. Words are metaphors and they determine how we perceive and experience our worlds. 

Empirical research done by Bartlett and Ghoshal in Harvard/London School of Economics (please google) identified four characteristics of successful transnational organizations, viz.,

Integrated Networking Structure

Complex Adaptive Systems

Dynamic Decision-Making

Unique Innovative Capabilities

Bartlett and Ghoshal maintain that the strength of the multidomestic firm is 'local responsiveness.’ Whereas the global company's strength is seen as ‘efficiency' while the hallmark of an International Multi National Corporations is ‘innovation.’ 

Only the ‘transnational' firm is simultaneously highly innovative, globally efficient and locally responsive.

Please undertake the following steps for each of the four characteristics identified by Bartlett and Ghoshal in order to ENHANCE your understanding, knowledge content and experience:

Step 1. Type the first characteristic: Integrated Networking Structure.

Step 2. Take each word further, (and further again, as necessary) from the dictionary/thesaurus and create a Word-pool of 10 or more words. 

You are sorting, sifting and selecting.

Step 3. From your Word-pool in Step 2, construct a structure that expresses your understanding of the characteristic under development.

Step 4. From your individualized structure in Step 3, do a felt-experience from your fishbowl; self-reflexively. Be specific with examples and instances from the fishbowl. 

Tip for being specific: for every sentence that you write in the first draft of your felt-experience, answer the question: How so? Please be sure to do this in order to prevent trivializing your knowledge content and knowing. This will have ramifications for your grade.

Inflection Point

Step 5. From the four Steps above, select two disparate words/symbols and create a dichotomy.

Step 6. Take the two words in Step 5 further, and further again if necessary, and create a Word-pool.

Step 7. Construct a sentence structure from your Word-pool in Step 6.

Step 8. Do a felt experience from your fishbowl on the structure above; self-reflexively. Be specific with examples and instances. Use the Tip mentioned in Step 4. Doing so is essential to empower your text.

Step 9. A final reflection (one paragraph) on your process when developing 'tacit knowledge’ (please google).

I will be writing subsequently to further elucidate the 9 Steps above. Develop the four exercises in a separate file at first and then post in the fishbowl only on 12/13 (mid-night), the first day of Finals. Please show iterations, edits, deletions and re-writes. You are sharing your thought process and choices made; not a neatly packaged final product. Please keep in mind: 'process is the product.' Please google.

In the fishbowl we embody connectivity. "Connectivity is Destiny." Please see the Ted Talk by Parag Khanna (20mts) and the recent postings by Nate Januario.

"The Spectacle" (9/27)

Post by Nate Januario » Sun Nov 19, 2023 11:45 pm

Debord's magnum opus, "The Society of the Spectacle" ("La société du spectacle"), published in 1967, stands as a cornerstone in political philosophy, social theory, and cultural critique. Within its pages, Debord dissects the concept of the "spectacle," an entity that he contends lies at the heart of advanced capitalism and the consumer-driven society.

The Spectacle:

Let me unfurl the concept of the "spectacle" as a mesmerizing play, where every scene, every act, is a carefully orchestrated dance of images. It is more than a mere visual feast—it is the very heartbeat of modern life, an omnipresent force that casts its spell over the collective consciousness.

Picture the spectacle as woven with the threads of media, advertising, and the relentless pulse of image-driven culture. Each thread, a shimmering illusion, draws us into a labyrinth of narratives, where reality blurs and the tangible gives way to the intangible allure of the visual.

The spectacle is a grand storyteller, a masterful illusionist that shapes perceptions and constructs a curated version of reality. It beckons us to immerse ourselves in its radiant glow, promising a refuge from the complexities of existence. Yet, in its enchanting allure, it conceals a subtle alchemy—an alchemy that transforms genuine experiences into mere reflections, authentic connections into fleeting shadows.

Within this spectacle, the world becomes a grand stage, and we, its unwitting actors, perform roles defined by the images projected upon us. The spectacle weaves narratives that transcend the limitations of time and space, creating a timeless realm where the past, present, and future coalesce into a continuous, mesmerizing performance.

Yet, as the spectacle captivates with these illusions, Debord's critique unfolds—a poignant meditation on the price paid for such enchantment. In the spellbinding dance of images, he hints at the subtle erosion of authenticity, the gradual fading of the real beneath the relentless glare of the simulated.

And so, in the theater of the spectacle, we find ourselves both audience and actor, navigating a world where the lines between reality and illusion blur. Debord's concept becomes a poetic reflection—a call to discern the ephemeral allure from the enduring substance, and to seek, amidst the spectacle's dazzling display, the quiet authenticity that lies beneath the shimmering surface of the modern stage.

"Grammar of the Multitude"

Post by Nate Januario » Sun Nov 19, 2023 11:56 pm

Post-Fordism, with its seismic shifts in labor and production, becomes the backdrop against which Virno's exploration resonates. The multitude, far from a passive entity, emerges as an active grammatical force, rewriting the syntax of resistance amidst the evolving structures of the socio-political landscape.

As we delve into the pages of "Grammar of the Multitude," Virno's prose becomes a brush painting strokes of agency, activism, and empowerment onto the canvas of collective identity. Each chapter unveils a new grammatical rule - a syntactical nuance - revealing the potential for transformative action within the multitude.

In the spirit of Guy Debord's reflections on the spectacle and the shaping of modern society, Virno's work becomes a contemporary sonnet- poetic meditation on the grammar of resistance and the syntax of social movements. The multitude, as an ever-evolving linguistic entity, transcends theoretical abstraction, manifesting as a dynamic force in the lived experiences of those who challenge established norms and reimagine the political landscape.

"Grammar of the Multitude" invites us to read between the lines, to decipher the syntax of solidarity, and to embrace the multitudinous expressions of human agency. It is not merely a philosophical treatise but a living lexicon- an eloquent call to engage with the grammar of resistance inscribed in the collective voices that shape the possibilities of our shared future.

Debord+ Virno:

Virno's work stands as a contemporary companion to Debord- a resonant voice in the ongoing dialogue about the nature of collective action and the transformative potential inherent in the grammar of the multitude. Through this lens, "Grammar of the Multitude" emerges not just as a philosophical treatise but as a call to reimagine the possibilities of human agency in the complex tapestry of the post-Fordist era.

NeverEnding

Post by Nate Januario » Mon Nov 20, 2023 12:03 am

In the magical realm of "The NeverEnding Story," the unfolding narrative becomes a portal, transcending the dusty pages of a magical book. Here, young Bastian Bux, ensconced in the quiet corners of a forgotten bookstore, becomes the storyteller and the audience simultaneously. As he delves into the pages of "The NeverEnding Story," a fantastical odyssey unfolds—a tale of Fantasia, threatened by the inexorable force of "The Nothing."

Within the enchanting contours of this classic fantasy film, we witness the alchemy of storytelling, where words on a page transcend their static existence and come to life in the vivid landscapes of imagination. Bastian's journey mirrors the transformative power of narrative—a testament to the timeless allure of stories that captivate and transport.

In tandem with this cinematic journey, the concept of "performative writing" emerges as a thematic companion—a literary echo that resonates with the interplay between words and actions. Performative writing, much like the enchanted book itself, transcends the traditional confines of text, inviting readers to become participants in a living narrative. It blurs the boundaries between literature and performance, infusing the written word with the immediacy and vitality of a live experience.

The roots of performative language, as explored in the philosophical tapestry, delve into the insights of John L. Austin. In his work "How to Do Things with Words," Austin unveils the concept of performative utterances—statements that not only convey meaning but also enact actions. This profound idea becomes a thread woven into the fabric of performative writing, where the act of reading becomes a dynamic engagement, a performative enactment of the narrative itself.

As Bastian turns each page, he steps into the role of both reader and participant, actively shaping the destiny of Fantasia through the sheer power of his imagination. The movie, much like the performative utterances Austin envisioned, becomes a conduit for action, inviting the audience to not merely witness but actively partake in the unfolding saga.

In the marriage of "The NeverEnding Story" and the concept of performative writing, we encounter a realm where storytelling becomes a living, breathing entity—a continuum that extends beyond the confines of finite pages and fleeting scenes. Through the synergy of cinema and philosophy, we are reminded that stories, whether on the screen or within the pages of a book, possess the magical ability to transcend time, space, and the boundaries between fiction and reality.

The dance of Reflexivity

Post by Nate Januario » Wed Nov 22, 2023 3:35 pm

"Reflexive Methodology" emerges as a guiding compass, a collaborative effort penned by the insightful minds of Mats Alvesson and Kaj Sköldberg. Nestled within the realm of organizational studies and qualitative research methodology, this book stands as a guide for those traversing the nuanced landscapes of social sciences and qualitative inquiry.

At its core, "Reflexive Methodology" is a literary atlas, charting a course for researchers who seek not just to observe but to engage in a dance of critical self-reflection. Alvesson and Sköldberg invite us to embark on a journey beyond the surface of data collection, urging us to navigate the complexities of research with a reflexive lens. Here, the methodology becomes a mirror—an instrument not only for observing the external but also for turning inward, fostering a dynamic dialogue between researcher and research.

Picture the pages of this book as a fertile ground where seeds of insight are sown, and the roots of reflexivity delve deep into the soil of qualitative inquiry. The authors, seasoned navigators of organizational studies, provide a nuanced guide, sharing wisdom garnered from their intellectual odysseys. The reflexive approach, as articulated within these pages, becomes a methodological alchemy—a transformative process that elevates research beyond the mechanical into a realm of thoughtful introspection.

In the dance of reflexivity, researchers are not mere observers; they become active participants in the construction of knowledge. The authors illuminate the intricate choreography between the researcher's positionality and the unfolding narrative of the research itself. This dance extends beyond the confines of data collection, infusing the entire research process with a sense of reflexivity that enriches the depth and authenticity of the scholarly endeavor.

For those navigating the terrain of social sciences, where the understanding of human phenomena demands more than detached observation, "Reflexive Methodology" becomes an indispensable companion. It is a call to embrace the complexity of the research journey, to engage in a dance of self-awareness, and to appreciate the transformative potential that lies within the reflexive embrace of qualitative inquiry.

As scholars turn the pages of Alvesson and Sköldberg's collaborative creation, they enter a realm where methodological reflection becomes a cornerstone of rigorous inquiry. "Reflexive Methodology" is not just a book; it is an intellectual companion that beckons researchers to embark on a reflective odyssey, where the art of inquiry is as much about understanding the self as it is about unraveling the intricacies of the social world.

Nate Januario

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you rest, recuperate and rejuvenate this week.

We are nearing the end of this ‘Dramaturgy’ (please google) which is our fishbowl.

'Dramaturgy is a sociological perspective on identity that employs a theatrical metaphor to explore issues of identity formation and reformation. As such, dramaturgy assumes a place, a moment, and an audience to whom the identity is being presented.'

Please watch the two films attached below: Strictly Ballroom and Beautiful People. They represent two starkly opposite social structures.

1. Strictly Ballroom

Strictly Ballroom mimics the social structure of a “mechanistic” organization (please google) in pursuit of "social inclusion" and "obedience to authority" as the way to act and behave towards each other. It is "militarized capitalism," and “organized time” according to Richard Sennett, in his book, 'The Culture of the New Capitalism' (please google). The price individuals pay for organized time is freedom or individuality. This “iron cage” is both prison and home. It is represented by targets and goals, expectations and achievements that are symbols of success/failure.

The task, of a leader/manager today is to protect and promote creativity of their social group. 

When you fail to do that, you make people “redundant." Like Lola said to Charlie Boy, “you made them redundant, you miserable sod.”

2. Beautiful People

The film Beautiful People depicts the chaos of global organizational spaces. What we realize and understand is that any pursuit of a universal objective meaning is woefully misguided and it is such pursuits that disconnect and prevent us from 'creating meaning and coherence' in our lives. In the film, we see for ourselves, there is no clear system or meaning that can be learnt or taught and implemented with success; and, there are no universal objective truths to be known and there are no longer any facts as such, only interpretations. Emphasizing objectivity (facts and figures) takes the spirit out of the experience of meaning which is inherently subjective, independent and expressive.

Hi Everyone (in 448 only),

I want to REFLECT on the films you are watching this semester from the point of view of “culture.” Keep the films in mind and deconstruct a sentence from each film.

Kinky Boots (across cultures),
