Moonrise Kingdom (American culture), 

Outsourced (Indian culture), 

Iron & Silk (Chinese culture).

II. Culture

It is good to develop a notion of the word “culture" for yourselves. 

What is culture?

1. Culture is a shared system of meanings 

The fishbowl is a shared SYSTEM of meanings, you will agree.

Culture DICTATES what groups of people pay ATTENTION to.

Culture guides how you perceive the world;, how the self is experienced; and, how life itself is organized.

"Patterns of behavior" hold groups of people together or RENDERS them apart.

We have "learned ways" of "constructing meaning" from our experiences.

There has to be a "common way of understanding" events and behavior, and predicting outcomes. For example, waving a hand or squatting on the floor has no clear meaning without the context being understood (see in Outsourced). Furthermore, the INTENDED meaning of a GESTURE need not coincide with the perceived meaning except where cultural identities match. It is only when meanings do coincide that EFFECTIVE communication can happen. Please keep that in mind.

2. Culture is relative

There is no absolute. People in different cultures perceive the world differently and have different ways of doing things as Asha reminds Todd in the film Outsourced.

Todd has the flexibility and agility to turn around and listen (and aske: what did you mean by that?). He found a friend in Asha and Purro. Always helpful to find a person who understands your cultural CONUNDRUM.

3. Culture is learned

It DERIVES from the social environment, not from an individual’s genetic make up.

4. Culture is about groups

It is a COLLECTIVE phenomenon that is about shared values and meanings.

 

As individuals, we carry LAYERS of cultural ‘programming.’ 

Starts with basic values as a child: right/wrong, good/bad, logical/illogical.

Layers are learned or ‘programmed’ in the course of education, in schools and organizations.

These layers are more ways of doing things, or practices, as opposed to fundamental assumptions about how things are.

III. Assignment

Keeping the above notion of culture in mind, please CONJURE SCENARIOS from the films.

You are scrolling and screening the films to experience foreign cultures.

ASSIGNMENT: Through careful observation of text and images in the films (as in real life), please make interpretations (through deconstruction) as to what is going-on in a particular photographic shot (mental) and episode (incident).

We begin to observe oneself making interpretations, by looking at our differences in the fishbowl.

We become self-aware. Differences in cultures makes us self-aware. Please keep that in mind.

Broaden your range of awareness.

Discipline: Education

Type of presentation: VIRTUAL

I. Introduction: awareness of process

We are 180 undergraduate students at the University of Rhode Island who are generating knowledge content in a digital environment, we call the Fishbowl. Situated in accounts of one’s “epistemic cognition,” we focus on our aims and processes of knowing. Cognition is ‘the mental action or process of acquiring knowledge and understanding through thought, experience, and the senses.’ Epistemic cognition is ‘awareness of the process of acquiring knowledge.’

Since we experience the Fishbowl and ourselves as continuously changing, we believe the dynamic nature of our ‘being' must be the primary focus for any comprehensive account of acquiring knowledge. We are concerned with dynamic entities, like mental occurrences and the realization of individual values in action. In other words, the actual occasion of experience is central when creating knowledge content and knowing. In our paper, we present and identify processes and shifting relationships as the only real experience in the Fishbowl.

II. Purpose: to bring forth

1. To share our process of acquiring knowledge and understanding.

2. To evoke thought-images when reading text.

III. Method: a flow of processing information

1. Metacognitive knowledge is the knowledge individuals develop of their own cognitive processes and their ability to monitor and reflect on them; how you think about your own thinking.

2. Metacognitive control characterizes one’s ability to identify learning needs and adapt behavior based on outcomes.

3. When posting in the fishbowl, we experiment with “free association” and “reader response theory.” The individual’s response to a text is a series of posts which are carried out to observe emerging outcomes.. It is one’s group of postings that takes inputs, adds value, and provides output for the viewer. The Fishbowl, as a whole, is a set of postings that interact with each other. Often, output of one is input for the other.

4. Postings are conceptual engagements with subjective feelings in fragments of textual snapshots.

IV.Outcome: life of practice

We restore significance to the practice of self-reflection. Our practice is contemplative without relinquishing characteristics of action. Our process of acquiring knowledge is a “life of practice” where one develops as a “practicing person” and gets the self “into shape” as the “person-that-can.” It is the evolution of subjectivity, ways of feeling, thinking and communicating and, transcending situations. Within a context, the capability of a "practicing person" is viewed as their constitution, virtue, virtuosity, competence, excellence, or fitness. Are you a "practicing person" and the right individual for the job?

As practitioners, we showcase our “life of practice”. The Fishbowl makes an impression of the extent, weight, and variety of forms of the “life of practice.” In the full paper, we present a ‘triptych of works,' and invite viewers to expand upon them, and share their own practices and processes of reading and writing.

Keywords: KNOWLEDGE CONTENT, PROCESS, EXPERIENCE, REFLEXIVITY, THOUGHT-IMAGE, ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE

Subject: deep thinking and thinking spaces

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

For several weeks, we have been swimming in a digital fishbowl. Regarding one's “learning," we raise the question: how does one gain “perspective" about the fishbowl, or about anything else? 

We start by selecting a word, a thought-image, and pose this question; How does one? By focusing on a word, and posing the question, we create a "thinking space" (please google). 

You can raise any question, i.e., select any word you want to meditate and contemplate upon, aka "deep thinking" (Please google).

Three tips to practice deep thinking:

1. Set your best time to think. Many of us spend the best hours of our days in meetings or in execution mode.

2. Find the “room” that works for you. Some of us do our best thinking by sitting down while closing our eyes. 

3. Make your own question library.

Finally, it is about sharing one's thinking spaces, our trajectories of thoughts, our structures of time and space (mental and physical), our points-of-view, forever in formation, always in a state of “becoming" (please google Deleuze) something else. 

Please see Makenna Goeller’s “assemblage" of words below. These may be construed as concepts, symbols, images, dichotomies and dimensions that she is contemplating, in order to understand what happened in Japanese Story. Her posting creates an inter-subjective space among us. We are indeed in a fishbowl.

We perceive and experience the world through each others structures. We can see and experience the Japanese Story through Goeller’s structures or any other structure of our seeking.

Bottom line: we focus onto a word and begin from there, into the unknown.

Letter 10/26

Awareness - knowledge or perception of a situation or fact; concern about and well-informed interest in a particular situation or development; the state or ability to perceive, to feel, or to be conscious of events, objects, or sensory patterns; a concept about knowing, perceiving and being cognizant of events.

Difference - a point or way in which people or things are not the same; the quality or state of being dissimilar or different; to disagree about some things; he difference between two things is often used to explore what the two things do not have in common.

Knowledge - facts, information, and skills acquired by a person through experience or education; the theoretical or practical understanding of a subject; awareness or familiarity gained by experience of a fact or situation; the fact or condition of knowing something with familiarity gained through experience or association; acquaintance or familiarity gained by sight, experience, or report.

Skill - the ability to do something well; the ability to use one's knowledge effectively and readily in execution or performance; a type of work or activity which requires special training and knowledge.

Connect - bring together or into contact so that a real or notional link is established; to join or fasten together usually by something intervening; Social connection can lower anxiety and depression, help us regulate our emotions, lead to higher self-esteem and empathy, and actually improve our immune systems.

Disparate - essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison; markedly distinct in quality or character; containing or made up of fundamentally different and often incongruous.

Construct - an idea or theory containing various conceptual elements, typically one considered to be subjective and not based on empirical evidence; is to make or form by combining or arranging parts or elements.

Structure - the arrangement of and relations between the parts or elements of something complex; construct or arrange according to a plan; give a pattern or organization to; something of many parts that is put together; the way in which it is made, built, or organized.

Inter-subjective - involving or occurring between separate conscious minds; the interchange of thoughts and feelings, both conscious and unconscious, between two persons or “subjects,” as facilitated by empathy; Three traditional kinds of intersubjectivity, that is consensual, regimented and explicit intersubjectivity are differentiated from two alternative kinds, namely argumentative and dialogical intersubjectivity.

Space - a continuous area or expanse which is free, available, or unoccupied; the dimensions of height, depth, and width within which all things exist and move; a limited extent in one, two, or three dimensions.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/26/2023 23:20:20
Subject: Difference: Awareness, Knowledge, Skill
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you?

When you consider Hofstede’s definition of culture as 'collective programming,' then we are considering

’social constructions’ 

'mental structures' 

'mental spaces' and 

'perceptual realities.’

The lynchpin in their understanding is that words are symbols whose meanings are socially constructed. So the meaning of the symbol, the word-image Geisha is different for Sandy and Hiromitsu. 

At the start of Japanese Story, we see Sandy's ante-narrative playing out. She is gender stereotyped by her office mates and now she is asked to be a Geisha Girl to a Japanese Warlord who is boring as cat shit! 

As for Hiromitsu, to be kept waiting, and by a woman chauffeur is a total shock. Hiromitsu experiences Sandy as loud and aggressive and who undermines authority. Far from a Geisha image.

The encounter between the protagonists in Japanese Story may be perceived as an interaction between two disparate mental structures. If Sandy and Hiro can't figure-out how to connect across their mental divides, they will soon be dead in the desert. From the moment Sandy and Hiromitsu met, they were in a downward spiral. What happened?

Sandy and HIromitsu have to construct an inter-subjective space (please google) that lies outside their respective structures. 

It is the space of ‘friendship,' where you can be anything you want.

But how do we get there is the question. Time is running out.

When entering a cross-cultural situation, the logical sequence of steps, according to Hofstede are Awareness, Knowledge and Skills.

1. Awareness that you differ from others in their social behavior and assumptions regarding the roles that we play.

2. Learn to know (knowledge of) these differences.

3. Skills to communicate and express these differences.

In Japanese Story we witness this sequence of steps:

 

1. Sandy and Hiromitsu have zero awareness that there are perceptual differences. Disaster is inevitable. A woman driver threw Hiro off.

2. Sandy and Hiromitsu learn to know (knowledge of) these differences by taking one word, one symbol, at a time. 

The mantra is: turnaround and ask: what did you mean by that?

Once Sandy and Hiromitsu start interacting this way, they are able to get themselves out of the jam.

When interaction covers steps 1 and 2, then friendship develops fast and we feel its power.

Sanjiv

AWARENESS, DIFFERENCE, KNOWLEDGE, SKILL, CONNECT, DISPARATE, CONSTRUCT, STRUCTURE, INTER-SUBJECTIVE, SPACE

The Japanese Story

I found The Japanese Story to be a beautiful film and discussion on how differences in culture can induce stereotypes, yet one can not base their judgements about someone based on their opposing way of life. In the beginning, Sandy makes rude and borderline racist comments when she learns that she will be in charge of the Japanese man, Hiromitsu, who is visiting Australia for business. Yet, as the story progresses, they develop a relationship and learn that they are not as different as they thought. Below I will discuss some quotes and scenarios in the film that I found to be the most impactful.

1. This film included many stark differences in culture that Australian Sandy could not comprehend. For example, it is a Japanese custom to bow when presenting a business card to a new potential partner. Their culture is laid upon a foundation of respect and some of the Australians meeting Hiromitsu learned this custom in preparation of the event, however Sandy did not. Another cultural difference was when Sandy first picks up Hiromitsu from the airport. She is late to picking him up, showing her relaxed culture, and Hiromitsu hands her his suitcase to put in the car herself, as the driver does this for the passenger in Japanese business culture. The suitcase was large and Sandy had some trouble getting it in, while Hiromitsu stood there watching, as that is just what he knows. While I have not had an experience with culture as drastic as this, I can comment on the fact that the Japanese culture is very respectful and operates with poise. I have a couple Japanese professors and I admire how they conduct their classes and speak with certainty and care.

2. "It is very bad to make mistakes, so I must fix them myself."

Hiromitsu says this to Sandy when they are stuck in the desert. He refuses to call for help and insists that he will get them out of this situation. While he eventually does, he puts himself and Sandy at a high risk of death due to his dignity. This is a comment on Japanese culture and how it is considered dishonorable to fail. Hiromitsu does not want anyone to know that he needs help because that could be perceived as weak, while Sandy is eager to call for aid as an Australian.

3. "You can’t send a condolence card to a complete stranger. You don’t know her. You don’t know her culture. You don’t know anything about her. Or her marriage. Nothing!"

After the tragic passing of Hiromitsu, Sandy says this to her mother when she suggests sending a condolence card to his wife. Obviously struck with grief, Sandy yells that that would be highly inappropriate and has learned this through her experiences with Hiromitsu. Sandy has learned that the Japanese culture is more private than that of Australia and knows that this is not a good idea. This is a moment of growth and shows how much Sandy has learned about culture compared to the beginning of the movie. This reminds me of a cultural difference between American and Filipino culture surrounding death. In Filipino culture, it is common for wakes to be filled with decorations and pictures are often taken -- sometimes even of the casket. However, in American culture, the celebration of death is relatively subdued and it would be very weird for someone to take a picture during the wake or funeral.

Alexa Foerder "defining Culture"

Post by alexafoerder » Fri Oct 20, 2023 1:14 pm

Here is how I understand culture in our society.

"culture is the collective programming of the mind which distinguishes the members of one human group from another.”

The five main dimensions are

- identity, power, gender, uncertainty, and time.

- You can think about cultural value dimensions on a scale or a continuum, where one aspect of the value lies on one side of the scale and the other extreme lies at the other end of the scale.

- Hofstede developed this cultural model primarily on the basis of differences in values and beliefs regarding work goals

Vocab

collective: done by people acting as a group

Programming: the process or activity of writing computer programs

Mental: relating or related to the mind.

Construct: an idea or theory containing various conceptual elements, typically one considered to be subjective and not based on empirical evidence

Value: the regard that something is held to deserve; the importance, worth, or usefulness of something

Preference: a greater liking for one alternative over another or others

Subject: improvising and adapting in ambiguous situations
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well this Friday evening.

Participant observation is more than a research methodology; it is a way of being, especially suited to a world of change, where one has to improvise not one but multiple roles. Please see Haley Fornuto’s reflection on Participation Observation and my observations in this letter are about her process of improvisation and adaptation in an ambiguous situation that is threaded with layers of other experiences. 

The quality of improvisation characterizes more and more of our lives online, lived in uncertainty, full of the inklings of alternatives. 

In a rapidly changing and interdependent world, single models of knowledge are less likely to be viable and plans more likely to go awry. The effort to combine multiple models risks runaway mumbo-jumbo, but adhering to a single model brings the whole shebang down.

Adaptation comes out of encounters with novelty that may seem chaotic. In trying to adapt, we may need to deviate from cherished values, behaving in ways we have barely glimpsed, seizing on fragmentary clues. If rejected as an aberration (mumbo jumbo) it may be due to habits of attention and perception (evaluating systems) acting as blinders.

The fishbowl is about ambiguity because ambiguity is the warp (in weaving) of life, not something to be eliminated. In other words, you are learning to do without answers and only fragmentary clues. This opens up the pleasures of recognizing and playing with pattern, finding coherence within complexity, sharing within multiplicity.

Under pressure of the moment, when needing to respond, it is best to be captured by some central point of focus, a word, and then proceed onwards from there... 

Sanjiv

Letter 8- Participant Observation

EditDeleteReportWarnInformationQuote

Unread post by haley_fornuto » Fri Oct 20, 2023 2:57 pm

participant observation: Participant observation is a research method commonly used in social sciences, anthropology, and some branches of sociology. It involves a researcher immersing themselves in a particular social or cultural setting in order to observe and interact with the people or subjects being studied. The researcher becomes a participant in the context they are studying, which allows them to gain an in-depth understanding of the culture, behavior, and social dynamics of the group they are observing.

"When interacting across cultures, we must together be aware of our differences and, from that position, proceed to learn and know about these differences, and all the while, develop skills to correct, connect and communicate across these differences. Awareness, Knowledge, Skills."

Deconstruction:

In my own words, I would describe Participant observation as using your own experiences when recording an observation. In order to adjust to or learn about culture, you must experience it and interact with differences. Overtime, you will begin to understand these differences and adjust your norms accordingly.

 

Felt experience:

Myself and others experience culture differences as we continue through life. One example I could give would be when starting a new job, I am unsure how I am supposed to perform and how I am supposed to interact with all new employees. Overtime, involvement in the new company allows me to connect and communicate correctly with new faces. I become aware of everyone's differences and learn about them. This goes the same for an internship opportunity. The intern engages in casual conversations with employees, attends company events, and builds relationships with staff members. These interactions provide insights into the company culture, employee relationships, and the informal norms that may not be readily apparent. Another example I could give would be when showing up to a party with unfamiliar faces. In this case I also have to give myself time to understand and learn the norms of an unfamiliar group of people.

Kinky Boots:

In kinky boots, I can conclude that the factory workers played a big role in participant observation. As old shoe factory workers, the drag business was not in there known societal norms. By observing and becoming a participant in the shift of the factory, they start to gain an in 'depth understanding of the drag queen culture and industry.

Quote: Lola: " You change the world when you change your mind"

This quote describes lola explaining to the factory workers that in order to understand, they must allow themselves to be involved and give themselves the oppotunity to change there own minds.

10 / 3 / 2023 Letter

"We are at an inflection (metaphor) in our trajectory (metaphor) of learning"

I deconstruct this sentence by beginning with inflection. An inflection is a change, a significant point. In mathematics, we recognize it as the point where a parabola changes from increasing to decreasing, an inflection point. I, then, move to trajectory of learning. We are on a journey of learning and we have been since we were born. We will be lifelong learners, whether we plan to stay in school or not, as we learn new things everyday from other people and the environment around us. The Fishbowl and this class marks a change in our learning journey, so far. We are practicing a different way of learning that involves words and our own thought processes. This change has effected our learning trajectory and will influence how we approach learning from now on. It makes us think more critically and to let go of rigidity, which can impede our learning.

10 / 5 / 2023

"Immaterial and cybernetic labor"

The labor we produce in the Fishbowl is both immaterial and cybernetic. It is immaterial in the way that it is purely our thought processes. While we are posting material writings, the labor put into those writings is purely immaterial. We can not put create physical entity based on the way that we think. How we think, how our minds operate, is invisible to the eye, yet it is our most powerful act of labor. Cybernetics is the study of automatic control and communication functions in both living organisms and mechanical and electronic systems. Our brains and the computers we type on are both cybernetics. Our brains function in amazing ways that we do not even realize. It performs in the same remarkable capacities as a computer. The work we post in the Fishbowl is a result of our immaterial and cybernetic labor.

10 / 8 / 2023 Letter

"How" replaced by "Why"

In the realm of positivist methodology, we are analyzing the question of "How". How does this happen? How did this come to be? How do we change this? However, in the Fishbowl, we are practicing interpretivist methodology and asking "Why". Why does this happen? Why did this come to be? Why do we want to change this? These questions of why make us think more in-depth, rather than just the surface level how which may just describe observable attributes. We can only answer these "why" questions by listening, researching, and communicating. The why questions may take more though, but they answer so much about the human experience.

Felt Experiences in Relation to Moonrise Kingdom

This movie was one that I have wanted to see for awhile, but have not had the chance. The story is very heartwarming and I love how it is told from an adolescent perspective with no embellishment or filter. I also liked how a lot of the film was shot in Rhode Island and I recognized many of the shots! Below I will delve into some spoken sentences in the movie and describe how I relate to them through my own experiences.

1. “You know, you shouldn’t be friends with him."

"Why not?"

"Because he’s crazy."

"Maybe you just don’t know him.”

This conversation between Suzy and one of the scouts that finds her and Sam together reminded me of experiences I have had in the past. Suzy is being ridiculed for being friends with Sam because the other scouts think he is weird. I can remember having friends that people thought were "a little weird" just because they did not fit in to the societal norms or because they were just following how everyone else thought. The scouts have a very hive mindset and one of the boys even tells Sam that he doesn't like him because no one else did. As Suzy says, I do not think it is fair for people to judge people without even knowing them. People are so much more than what they present to the world and once you get to know them, you might realize just how similar you are, even if they are perceived as different.

2. “I wanna go on adventures I think. I don’t want to be stuck in one place.”

After they run away, Sam asks Suzy what she wants to be when she grows up. She doesn't necessarily answer the question, but says that she wants to go on adventures and leave the little island they live on. I relate to Suzy as I also would like to leave the place where I am from, travel the world more, and never be stuck in one place forever. While I love Rhode Island, it can get isolating and boring after living here my entire life. I am excited to live somewhere new after I graduate and I hope it is in a city. I also hope that my future career is possibly with an international company where I can travel while doing the work that I love.

3. “I love you, but you don’t know what you’re talking about.”

While they are sitting and talking on the rock, Suzy tells Sam that she wishes she were an orphan like him and Sam respectfully replies that she has no clue what she is saying. While I am not an orphan, I relate to this conversation because I felt the same way as Sam before. I am half Filipina and one thing I struggled with when I was little was my tan skin compared to my white friends. As I have grown up, I have learned to love it, but when a friend says that they wish they had tan skin, I think about the insecurities that it used to bring me. If a friend says this to me, I still love them, they just do not understand the other weights that come along with being a little different.

4. “I hate you."

"Don’t say hate."

"Why not? I mean it."

"You think you mean it in this moment. You’re trying to hurt me."

"Exactly.”

After Suzy is found with Sam and brought home, her mom is washing her in the bathtub and they have this conversation. Suzy has issues with her parents and her parents consider her to be a troubled child, so it is not out of character for Suzy to say she hates her mom. I have felt just as Suzy does in this moment before. Sometimes we say we hate something or someone when we do not truly "hate" as hate is a very strong word. I am sure there was a time when I was a younger, moody teen that I told someone I loved that I hated them just to get my feelings across. In this personal scenario and in the movie, hate is being used to hurt the person we are talking to. One of my favorites parts about this movie is that it is an unfiltered child's perspective. The way Suzy communicates with her family and Sam is so literal and I like how she admits to her mom that she is just saying she hates her to hurt her. I found many instances in the film where the younger characters say things that I think many adults wish they could say.

5. “What’s your rush?"

"You’ve got your whole life in front of yourself.”

This sentence is spoken after Sam is taken in by the police chief and they are talking at the dinner table. Throughout the film, Sam is very adamant on running off with Suzy and the police chief is telling him to slow down. At just 12 years old, Sam has so much more to experience and learn and should not be tied down to one person or idea just yet. I can relate to this as I have had many people tell me to slow down before. I find that I can sometimes work a lot or move onto the next thing very fast and I forget to slow down. At only 21 years old, I have many years ahead of me to meet new people and develop my career and that is something I tend to forget.

10 / 15 / 2023 Letter

Recognizing Cultural Differences through Participant Observation

When considering cultural differences between myself and my friends, one of the things I think of is cleanliness. I grew up in a household where I was taught to be clean and organized and that has translated into my life as an adult. I make my bed every morning, always ensure my space is organized, and clean up after myself when I cook or shower. My habits were most definitely shaped by my culture growing up. I grew up with a large family so it was essential to clean up after ourselves to make sure no messes piled up. Additionally, my father who was in the military enforced these rules as he learned to be very clean and organized in the Navy. I recognize that I have these cultural differences between friends when they are not so clean or quick to tidy up their messes. I do not blame them for this and I hold no hard feelings because I know that it is due to our upbringings and how our culture conditioned us to act.

Date: 10/19/2023 21:19:59
Subject: defining culture
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well.

Please bear in mind, when you make the slightest of gestures in the fishbowl, I am happy to bump up your grade.

The fishbowl is structured to make it possible for you to get more than Just-a-B.

"Culture” has been defined by Gurus in different ways over the years. In 1871 E. Taylor defined it as a 'complex whole.'

For our purposes, we are going with the definition of Geert Hofstede (please google): "culture is the collective programming of the mind which distinguishes the members of one human group from another.” 

The most widely known research in the attempt to compare cultures in terms of 'broad value differences' is the pioneering work of Hofstede.

Values, according to Hofstede’s definition, are ‘a broad tendency to prefer certain states of affairs over others.’ 

These differences in preferences, or values, have important implications for managers and organizations operating across cultural borders and mental constructs.

Keeping this in mind, please deconstruct three texts from the Japanese Story and infuse your own reflections and experience.

Japanese Story

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1i8tHB8ID0D9-0JAQsNAjnLaxGifSOvPT/view?usp=sharing

COLLECTIVE, PROGRAMMING, MENTAL, CONSTRUCT, VALUE, PREFERENCE

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/8/2023 12:14:23
Subject: thinking about culture
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well and tuned to your learning channel.

In the fishbowl, we are developing a society and a culture that cannot be verified by quantifiable, observable information, nor possible under scientifically controlled conditions. 

This is because we are evoking statements (text and images) regarding human subjectivity, intentionality and meaning which are “passed over in silence” and excluded from the ‘Positivist’s' (please google) domain.

Interpretive interactionism is founded on the study, expression, and interpretation of subjective human experience. 

The interpretive perspective is deliberately nonscientific and nonpositivistic. The search for causal “whys,” causal paths, causal chains, and causal antecedents is detrimental to the study and understanding of directly lived experience.

The “why” question is replaced by the “how” question. That is, how is social and cultural experience, or a sequence of social interaction organized, perceived and constructed by differentially wide-awake, self-reflective, socially constrained, free individuals? How, then, NOT why. 

To address the above question, we will watch the following films, from an interpretive perspective. 

Moonrise Kingdom (American system of values), 

Japanese Story (Australia/Japan), 

Outsourced (India/America) and 

Iron & Silk (China/America).

Culture (please google) as a concept is central in anthropology, encompassing the range of phenomena that are transmitted through social learning in human societies. The immaterial aspects of culture such as principles of social organization, mythology, philosophy, literature (both written and oral) and science comprise the intangible cultural heritage of a society. 

It is the intangible cultural heritage of America that we will look for when watching Wes Anderson’s movie, Moonrise Kingdom.

From the attached film (90mts), please pull our 5 sentences spoken in the film. Please relate and describe a felt-experience from your past or present to each sentence.

Sanjiv

Date: 10/6/2023 2:04:18
Subject: interpretivism
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I want to talk about culture (MGT448) and creativity (MGT345). Before I do so, I want to reiterate that we’re at an inflection on our learning trajectory, but we will never lose sight of Process and Practice. They are both constant companions, whom we observe and interpret all the time. 

Please google Interpretivism.

Interpretivism is based on the assumption that reality (of the fishbowl) is subjective, multiple and socially constructed. That is to say, we can only understand someone's reality through their experience of that reality, which may be different from another person's shaped by one's historical or social perspective.

Interpretive research is a research paradigm that is based on the assumption that social reality (like your fishbowl) is not objective, but is rather shaped by your personal experiences and social contexts.

As Interpretivists, we seek out subjective meanings and interpretations as our main source of knowledge. Positivists (please google) tend to prefer quantitative research methods (such as social surveys), while interpretivists prefer qualitative research methods (such as in-depth interviews). Please see Lauren Joseph’s postings as an example of interpretivism.

Sanjiv

ASSUMPTION, SOCIAL, REALITY, SUBJECTIVE, SOURCE, KNOWLEDGE, INTERPRETATION

9/18 Google Search 2

structuralists - a mode of knowledge of nature and human life that is interested in relationships rather than individual objects

post-structuralists - the belief that individual values are taken from their "milieu" and the common meanings of a group of individuals

phenomenologists - those who study objectivity

Deconstruction:

relationships - the way people are connected through behaviors

milieu - a person's social environment which ultimately reflects how one behaves, dresses, etc.

objectivity - a position with no influence or bias towards a particular side of

bountiful - large quantity

structure - arrangement of something in a particular way, pattern

Reconstruction:

With a focus on society and culture, humans as a whole are influenced by their relationships. Focusing on the behaviors of people and their social environment truly puts forth how society is structured. One's environment influences one's societal norms. There is a natural bias that lies in society. Relationships are interwoven by identities and are what tie together similar and different identities. They are what bring us together. I believe that society continues this way due to how one is brought up or even how school systems have engrained certain ways to behave in life. To look beyond the structure that we all subconsciously live our lives and relationships, there is a possibility to live in a way of objectivity.

Personally, I try and ground myself when I feel as though I let subconscious bias overcome relationships in my life. The practice of objectivity opens up the possibility of a variety of relationships in life rather than just within my personal "milieu." In addition, my life is centered around structure. My personal milieu has constructed my way of thinking and learning. I think that is why I started off confused by the fishbowl. But letting go of structure and looking into the value of words will broaden my ability to learn.

9/18 Storytelling that Moves People

"McKee argues that stories “fulfill a profound human need to grasp the patterns of living—not merely as an intellectual exercise, but within a very personal, emotional experience.”

Deconstruction:

fulfill - bring to completion or reality

pattern - an example for others to follow

intellectual - one with reasoning and understanding objectively to abstract or academic matters

personal - belonging to a particular person

emotional- relating to a person's emotions

Reconstruction:

Director Robert McKee explains how storytelling is how humans can emotionally connect to visualized life experiences. Storytelling, a very visual way to describe a real or imaginary story, is one of the most effective ways humans can emotionally connect. Emotions are what inspires a human's actions and ways of thinking, and storytelling is the connection between merely a story and a personal connection.

In my personal life, I have found that storytelling is how I can see myself in other's shoes. Especially in TV shows or movies, they allow my brain to visualize what the characters are feeling and experiencing. Storytelling is another way to experience.

9/19 Kinky Boots

Social Constructivism - theory of knowledge of biological characteristics such as race, gender, etc. The social constructs in society are the immediate thoughts one thinks when they visualize a certain person or think.

Symbolic Interactionism - viewing society as composed of symbols that people use to establish meaning, develop views about the world, and communicate with one another. For example, a heart means love.

Reflexivity - Someone being able to understand their own feelings. Full consciousness of one's morals and thoughts

Kinky Boots tackles gender norms. There is symbolism in the different shoes that are shown in the movie. The classic black dress shoes that Charlie and his family made, represent the symbolic interactionism of the stereotypical man. The red thigh-high “Kinky boots'' represent the LGBTQ+ community. They defy the social norms when a man wears red boots instead of the typical black dress shoes. I find it interesting how long it took Charlie to have this vision because his life was surrounded by the social construct in the world around him such as his father’s company that he built. It wasn't until Lauren planted the seed of innovation into Charlie's brain that he defied the social construct norms.

In addition, when Charlie puts on the red boots in Milan, Charlie overcomes the social constructivism of a “typical male” wearing women-like boots. I believe that Lola embodies reflexivity, and she is the one to serve as the catalyst that represents one of the anti-social constructive groups in society. She stays true to herself and chooses to continue her drag shows despite it being outside social norms of a man dressing as a woman.

I find this movie inspiring because it emphasizes inclusion. It also represents how businesses need to broaden their market to ALL types of customers. Businesses can especially thrive if they cater to a more niche market, such as drag queens. I think it is a genius marketing tactic and also a heart-warming movie that stresses inclusion and the defying of social constructs.

9/19 The Dance of Alterity

To Be Two:

" For Irigaray, the notion of the individual is twinned with a reconceived notion of difference, or alterity...Yet at the same time, she enriches her discussion with an attempt to bring the elements--earth, fire, water--into philosophical discourse. Even the polarities of heaven and earth come to play in this ambitious and provocative text."

Deconstruction:

reconceived - to create an idea again in a different way

notion - a conception or belief

difference - a point or way something isn't the same

philosophical - the study of fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence

discourse - written or spoken communication or debate

polarities - differences on each end

alterity - the state of being different

Reconstruction:

Irigaray's novel appears to celebrate the nature of differences in our society. Simple natural opposites like natural elements seem to be the examples the author uses to express the differences found in human nature as well. I find this novel topic interesting as it seems to celebrate the differences in our society. Rather than rejecting differences, we should embrace them. This is where alterity comes into play. The "dance of alterity" is always present in or world. This concept can be brought into my own life. Instead of only talking to people I know or similar to my interests or ways of life, I need to expand my social group to others who live life in slightly different ways. It is refreshing when I meet people with different interests/beliefs than me for it allows me to see life in a new light. Living life on one path can be boring. Rather, taking a new path and discovering new lights can be rewarding to the mind and soul.

9/21 Evidence of Learning

"Forms of modern life may differ in quite a few respects – but what unites them all is precisely their fragility, temporariness, vulnerability and inclination to constant change. To ‘be modern’ means to modernize – compulsively, obsessively; not so much just ‘to be’, let alone to keep its identity intact, but forever ‘becoming’, avoiding completion, staying underdefined. Each new structure which replaces the previous one as soon as it is declared old-fashioned and past its use-by date is only another momentary settlement – acknowledged as temporary and ‘until further notice’."

"Starting out with reflecting on how literature functions as a medium of interaction between the context from which it emerges, and a reader who makes the literature concrete, Iser contributed to the development of literary theory by turning literature itself into a mode of reflection."

Deconstruction:

fragility - the quality of being easily broken or damaged

temporariness - state of lasting or being intended to last for a short time

change - to make different

identity - the fact of being who or what a person or thing is

underdefined - inadequately defined

replace - to take the place of

reflection - serious thought or consideration

Reconstruction:

Bauman explains in his novel the fluidity of the modern state. It is a constant state of change because something will always be new and then naturally become old. It is the nature in everything. I can visualize this theory in real life. For example, fashion trends are always changing. A shirt I used to wear last year I would likely never want to wear again. It is an unfortunate but also interesting cycle that everything in life is always changing.

Relating to Wolfgang Iser, he focused on the concept of reflection. The concepts in literature are written but also are subject to reflection within the reader's mind. This reflection can be subject to the readers interpretation and their own beliefs and values.

9/25:

"Mindfulness is the basic human ability to be present, aware of where we are and what we are doing, and not excessively reactive or overwhelmed by what is going on around us"

"Cybercultures: a set of shared attitudes, practices, and goals, associated with the world of computers and the Internet"

Deconstruction:

ability - possession of the means or skill to do something

present - existing or occurring now

aware - having knowledge or perception of a situation or fact

reactive - showing a response to a stimulus

overwhelmed - buried or drowned beneath a huge mass

attitudes - a settled way of thinking or feeling about someone or something typically reflecting one's behavior

practices - the actual application or use of an idea, belief, or method, as opposed to theories relating to it

goals - the object of a person's ambition or effort; an aim or desired result

Reconstruction:

The two concepts of mindfulness and cybercultures I find to be opposites. Unfortunately in the world we live in today, cybercultures share attitudes of being overly reactive. I personally read articles and listen to podcasts that help me practice mindfulness and living in the moment. I think it is something valuable to learn and I think more of society needs to adopt this mindset.

9/28 Immaterial Labor

"The concept of immaterial labor refers to two different aspects of labor. On the one hand, as regards the "informational content" of the commodity, it refers directly to the changes taking place in workers' labor processes in big companies in the industrial and tertiary sectors, where the skills involved in direct labor are increasingly skills involving cybernetics and computer control (and horizontal and vertical communication). On the other hand, as regards the activity that produces the "cultural content" of the commodity, immaterial labor involves a series of activities that are not normally recognized as "work" — in other words, the kinds of activities involved in defining and fixing cultural and artistic standards, fashions, tastes, consumer norms, and, more strategically, public opinion."

Deconstruction:

immaterial - unimportant under the circumstances, irrelevant

commodity - raw material or primary agricultural project that can be bought and sold

processes - series of actions taken in order to achieve a particular end

industrial - relating to industry, very great in amount

skills - ability to use one's knowledge effectively

cultural - relating to the ideas, customs, and social behavior of society

work - to keep in motion of the operation

standards - level of quality or attainment

Reconstruction:

Maurizio Lazzarato's concept is very interesting, especially in today's modern-day age. There's the more typical work of producing certain goods or services in the economy. But then there is also intellectual labor or in today's society: computers. Jobs involving computers is a different form of performing traditional labor and have become a primary focus in many careers nowadays. Now there are majors involving computers and data analytics. Immaterial labor stems beyond just physical labor. It involves more mental skills such as analyzing and problem solving, all key skills that are useful in the economy.

https://www.e-flux.com/legacy/2013/05/2.-Maurizio-Lazzarato-Immaterial-Labor.pdf?b8c429

9/28 Portraying Virtuosity

"Hobbes, who detested the notion of multitude, defined it as shunning political unity, resisting authority, and never entering into lasting agreements. "When they rebel against the state," Hobbes wrote, "the citizens are the multitude against the people." But the multitude isn't just a negative notion, it is a rich concept that allows us to examine new plural experiences and forms of nonrepresentative democracy. Drawing from philosophy of language, political economics, and ethics, Virno shows that being foreign, "not-feeling-at-home-anywhere," is a condition that forces the multitude to place its trust in the intellect. In conclusion, Virno suggests that the metamorphosis of the social systems in the West during the last twenty years is leading to a paradoxical "Communism of the Capital."

"Guy Debord was a rebel, philosopher, and filmmaker. Arch-critic of consumerism and theorist of “the spectacle”. He was one of France’s greatest and most original intellectuals. Today, Debord appears as a prophet of our image-saturated hyper-digital consumer culture. Critically, he highlighted that our descent into a world “mediated by images” corresponds with the production of mass social alienation."

Deconstruction:

authority - the power or right to give orders

notion - conception of or belief about something

plural - denoting more than one

nonrepresentative - not serving as typical

metamorphosis - the process of transformation from an immature form to an adult form

consumer - person who purchases goods and services for personal use

mediated - intervene between people in a dispute in order to bring to agreement

alienation - state of being isolated from a group

Reconstruction:

There is beauty in the mental work that is done. Rather than a commodity, the book "A Grammar of the Multitude" celebrates the different types of work outside the typical physical labor that has dominated our culture for years. I'm coming to understand the connection between the concept of immaterial labor as Guy Debord explains how the world is "mediated by images." It is the works of art and media that truly express individuals and shape our society. And this has become even more relevant in our world surrounded by social media.

"In opposition to most literature on how to conduct good social science research which is either empirically oriented or gives priority to theoretical and philosophical considerations, which tends to make empirical research look odd or irrelevant, this volume on 'Reflexive Methodology' explicitly turns towards a consideration of the perceptual, cognitive, theoretical, linguistic, political and cultural circumstances as backdrop of data interpretation and research design. It showed up to be the most important and informative resource and a source of enlightenment to my lecture on methodology at our institute. I can highly recommend the volume to lecturers and students alike."

Deconstruction:

philosophical - the study of knowledge

theoretical - concerned with an area of study

reflexive - always holding between a term and itself

methodology - system of methods used in a particular area of study or activity

Reconstruction:

Reflexive methodology is a more aware perception of the study. It focuses on the importance of self-reflection in the field of research. Human influence is very apparent when it comes to viewing the world and understanding one's own influence on research and ways of life is key to understanding human nature and concepts in life.

Attention Economy and the Society of the Spectacle

Deconstruction and thoughts on The Society of the Spectacle

The Society of the Spectacle was written in 1967 by author Guy Debord. A description from the foreword of the book describes The Society of the Spectacle as follows, “In this book, Debord describes and critiques the way we live. The power of these ideas lies in their ability to question, identify, and name the common assumptions of the present.” Debord termed the phrase “the spectacle” as a way to look at society as a whole. In the very beginning of the book Debord writes, “In post-industrial societies where mass production and media predominate, life is presented as an immense accumulation of spectacles. Everything that was directly experienced has been replaced with its representation in the form of images.” What this means to me is that in today's society, everything you can think of- events, people, conversations, scenery- can all be depicted into images or a cinematic art. If we look into the spectacle ourselves, we see the world as we ourselves uniquely view it. The image attached to the letter with many people sitting down with glasses on, I assume they are watching a 3D movie at a theater. This is an interesting take on the spectacle because when watching a 3D movie, if you take your glasses off you see one thing, and if you put them on, you see a completely different image. This is also true with our perspective on society. If we take our metaphorical glasses off, we are blind to many things going on around us in society.

Post by michellehanna » Tue Oct 03, 2023 11:47 pm

**Letter 20 - 10/3**

"The focus of procedures and techniques implies an imitation of the quantitative methodology textbooks, and draws attention away from fundamental problems associated with such things as the role of language, interpretation and selectivity in research work, thus underrating the need for reflection" (Reflexive Methodology by Mats Alvesson and Kaj Skoldberg).

Deconstruction

Imitation: the action of using someone or something as a model; a thing intended to simulate or copy something else

Quantitative: relating to, measuring, or measured by the quantity of something rather than its quality

Methodology: a system of methods used in a particular area of study or activity

Attention: Notice taken of someone or something; the action of dealing with or taking special care of someone or something

Fundamental: forming a necessary base or core; a central or primary rule or principle on which something is based

Associated: connected or amalgamated with another company or companies; joined together often in a working relationship

Role: the function assumed or part played by a person or thing in a particular situation

Interpretation: the action of explaining the meaning of something; an explanation or way of explaining

Selectivity: the quality of carefully choosing someone or something as the best or most suitable; the property of affecting some things and not others

Underrating: not rated or valued highly enough

Reflection: serious thought or consideration

Reconstruction

This quote from Alvesson and Skoldberg's book explains that focusing on discrete methods diminishes the sense of ambiguity, curiosity, and thought in the world. The common use of indisputable or incontrovertible information lessens ones understanding of the need to reflect and take moments of serious thought or consideration which is often necessary for life's obstacles.

This quote allows me to reflect on a time in the past where I was extremely reliant on technology and outside knowledge. My second year at URI, in my applied calculus course, I was extremely reliant on the textbook along with the example problems that came with it. These sample problems also had an answer key which included steps on how to solve each of the problem's. I relied on this answer key to reinforce my learning and teach my self the steps needed to reach a specific conclusion. It wasn't until one chapter of the required material did not include any sample problems or answer keys, instead, my teacher created her own example. At first, I began to stress and had no idea how the assignment could be done without any explanation. I began to reflect on past units and apply my previous knowledge on the subject to the material and brainstorm. After much deliberation, I managed to craft a formula that gave me the right answer and worked for me. The next time that our class met, our teacher gave us an answer key that she had created. The answer key had a different formula that seemed more difficult to understand. This relates to the quote from 'Reflexive Methodology' in the sense that procedures repress one's critical thinking abilities. Ambiguity is necessary for creativity, and therefore, learning.

Letter 1

Manuel DeLanda is a Mexican-American writer, artist, and philosopher. Regarding his text, "A New Philosophy of Society", this sentence stood out to me most.

"Since most social entities, from small communities to large nation-states, would disappear altogether if human minds ceased to exist, Delanda proposes a novel approach to social ontology that asserts the autonomy of social entities from the conceptions we have of them".

I find this phrase very fascinating and after further deconstructing it, I agree that without the social interactions and thought process of human beings, regardless of development areas on the globe, taking time to study and decipher the study of nature and properties of the social world, furthering the disconnect and negative effect of the ability to maintain interpersonal relationships and behave appropriately(various social contexts). I teach URI 101 and I do that because I enjoy learning new things from different individuals and it gives myself the opportunity to be in a space to immerse myself into different cultures, ideas, thoughts, and processes.

Letter 2

"They are one person's unique interpretation of an idea and their own thoughts, feelings, and background". This quote is referring to the concept of subjective thinking. When I read this phrase I thought of the concept of a college essay. Everyone is provided a handful of general prompts and is expected to subjective think and stand out to receive a college acceptance. I remember being so nervous writing my essay since I did not want to blend into the sea of applications, which in retrospect is impossible since we all have different unique experiences viewed in different ways. I wrote about a family tradition with the women on my mom's side of the family, if any of them wrote about it, even though it is the sam experience, we would all view it in our own unique ways.

Letter 3

In regards to Derrida and his deconstruction theory, this quote resonates with me, "In particular, the theme of responsibility to the other (for example, God or a beloved person) leads Derrida to leave the idea that responsibility is associated with a behavior publicly and rationally justifiable by general principles". After rereading this sentence, all I could think about was social psychology (a class I am currently enrolled in) and how situations affect how individuals act. There have been studies done, testing the behavior of those publicly vs alone, having an individual endure some sort of pain in front of a friend, partner, group etc and then alone. You are able to see that some individuals will have a larger reaction in front others while some do not. This ties into Derrida since psychology is grounded in ethics and perspective determines what is rationally justifiable or not.

Letter 4

Denkbild

"Thought-images are ...parabolic evocations of something that cannot be said in words. They do not want to stop conceptual thought so much as to shock through their enigmatic form and thereby get thought moving, because thought in its traditional form seems rigid, conventional and outmoded."

The concept of thought images is so powerful, it makes me think of how modernized of a society we have become. I believe I was around 8 or 9 years old when I was truly introduced to technology and the concept that there was this thing called "emojis" that could represent an emotion, thought, feeling, action, or object without having to say it in words. The introduction of gifs also had that same power and now included motion and sometimes a phrase or two. Reflecting as a 21-year-old, this is such a powerful idea that most people did not understand and may still not understand to this day. Words are so influential and taking them away and using thought-images allows for perspective and overall interpretation.

Letter 4 Part 2

Joan Didion "Let Me Tell You What I Mean"

"Do not misread me: I admire objectivity very much indeed, but I fail to see how it can be achieved if the reader does not understand the writer's particular bias. For the writer to pretend that he has none lends the entire venture a mendacity that has never been infected".

We all have automatic and controllable processed within our brain, that is just simply the science of it. With automatic processes, we do endure implicit bias which can very much affect our viewpoint on certain things or concepts in life. When speaking to my students as a URI 101 mentor, I want to be as objective as possible. I have no idea where they are from, what they have experienced along the way, who they know/care about, and how my words evoke a felt experience from them. I have to have limited bias as possible in order to build connection with this diverse group of people and have them trust what is coming out of my mouth. I am well aware that bias is still present since I can look at my roster and picture what my student looks like based on what I know and experience. The important component of this is to stay that bias and learn from the outcome, without it you become stuck in a way.

Letter 7

1. Structuralists study how our minds make meaning through small step-by-step cognitive processes.

Structuralism can be implemented and studied at any point in someone’s life. Whether it be understanding why I use a red pen over a blue pen to write in my planner, or the steps I took to wash dishes. Everyone is unique in their own ways and each cognitive process varies.

2. Post-structuralists believe that power operates everywhere in society and reinforces unjust social disparities.

An example I found when looking into post-structuralists is having educators focus on challenging power structures by developing inclusive discourses. As a URI 101 mentor, over the years I have been trained in inclusive language and diversity in order to create a safe and welcoming environment. For example, simply using “y’all or everyone” instead of “you guys” can make an individual feel more comfortable in class. Also, using “first-year students” instead of “freshmen”, since freshmen has a negative connotation of being on the bottom of the dogpile and not being treated well by older students.

3. Phenomenologists study phenomena (a thing that exists and can be seen, felt, heard, etc) and how we experience them, also known as intentionality.

The concept of phenomenology is quite interesting since as humans there are actions we do subconsciously and some we do with intent. For myself, every morning I grab my toothbrush and toothpaste subconscious with little to no thought to it. However, as of the beginning of this week, I have to take medication for an autoimmune disorder which requires intention on my part to follow the specific instructions of when, how, and with what.

4. Social constructivism is a learning theory according to which human development is socially situated, and knowledge is constructed through interaction with others.

Social constructivism has been prevalent throughout my entire educational career, especially in college. I would say that at least 85% of my courses at URI have incorporated a group project, activity, or editing in some sort of way. This is a collaborative way of learning where we are put in social situations, interacting with individuals from different backgrounds, locations, and overall experiences to work together for a common goal. We learn from each other and use this knowledge to improve our own way of thinking.

5. Symbolic interactionism is viewing society as composed of symbols that people use to establish meaning, develop views about the world, and communicate with one another.

A great example of symbolic interactionism in my daily life would be this course structure. Each letter has symbols for us to deconstruct and decode in order to understand and develop a deeper meaning. This platform, the Fishbowl allows us to share our own unique interpretations for us to communicate with one another and our professor. Each of us can see a word or concept and have a compelled different thought process, which is the beauty of having our own interpretation to share.

6. Reflexivity is the concept of examining one’s own feelings, reactions, and motives and how these influence what they do or think in a situation.

Reflexivity is an important concept for individuals to partake in. I am a constant over-thinker, so much so it would prohibit myself from doing certain things. I decided a little while ago that I should start journaling. Journaling has allowed me to reflect on my own feelings and understand how this influences the people around me and as well as, how I act in a given situation. I now have gotten over irrational fears I have and actively make the effort to journal in order to figure out what is going on inside my brain.

Letter 8

Storytelling is uniting an idea with emotion, expressing how and why life changes.

When the concept of storytelling comes to mind, I think of my childhood. I had (and still do) this large fairy tales book with a crooked spine, passed down to me by my grandmother. It is filled with every original fairy tale that most people know and have heard plenty of time. I find it interesting how the article describes a good story as a display of struggle between expectation and reality in all its nastiness. This made me think of Little Red Riding Hood. Where Red had these expectations of visiting her grandmother only to be faced with the harsh reality that her grandmother was actually the Big Bad Wolf. Fairy tales are good stories, when you first read them you have this expectation of rainbows and butterflies but along the way there is a shock twist that makes you rethink the story.

Letter 10

"To Be Two" by Luce Irigaray

"Irigaray argues that objects of value, such as the sun or God, are typically marked with the masculine gender while less important objects are feminine. Since language and society mutually affect each other, Irigaray believes that language must change along with society".

These phrases resonated with me since their meaning is so powerful. Deconstructing the idea that God is marked with the masculine gender ties into the song by Ariana Grande, "God is a Woman". Ariana Grande challenged the preconceived notion that God is associated with male pronouns, having her fans astonished by the choice. Many religious people, mostly Christians and Catholics, thought that “God is a Woman” was disrespectful towards their beliefs and voiced their opinions on social media. People feel this way since something so powerful as God was suppose to be male since males were viewed as the more powerful and important gender. Also, how Irigaray discusses less important objects as feminine, led to the immediate thought in my mind of how people typically call her cars/boats female names. This stems to how women were viewed and treated as property. I agree with Irigaray idea that this language must change in order to see the results in society. I am glad I was exposed to her work.

Letter 12

Liquid Modernity by Zygmunt Bauman

"To ‘be modern’ means to modernize – compulsively, obsessively; not so much just ‘to be’, let alone to keep its identity intact, but forever ‘becoming’, avoiding completion, staying underdefined."

This phrase immediately made me think of something I learned yesterday in one of my classes. In MKT 470, we did a case study on the store, IKEA. The case study outlined the beginning of the store, all the trial and error along the way, and what it is now. I.K. is the founder of IKEA and he was created heavy, dark furniture since that is what his competitors like Gunnars did always. I.K. took a trip to Milan and learned that in order to differentiate his company from others, he had to improve his product. He learned that furniture could be light, simple, and transported easily, which would appeal to his consumer base. IKEA today still holds those ideals and it fits the needs of their consumers. I.K. modernized his thought process and his overall product line, which ties into liquid modernity.

Wolfgang Iser

"He suggests that we might think of the literary work as having two poles: the 'artistic' pole is the text created by the author, and the 'aesthetic' pole refers to 'the realization accomplished by the reader''.

After re-reading this phrase, the concept of novels and their adaptations came to mind. The author/writer tells a story in their own way with carefully though out words, vivid descriptions, and characters so well-developed it took them maybe months to decide on their name. On the other hand, the reader has their own imagination, picturing what the characters look like, how scenes play out, and the emotional ties to the setting. I remember seeing a dispute regarding one of Colleen Hoover's novels. I have yet to read her books (but is on my list) but loyal readers were disappointed in the casting of the adaptation of the movie. They felt Blake Lively, as great as she is, did not fit the projection in their minds while reading the novel. As filming occurred, people were upset with the choice of other cast members and the outfits worn. The writer is the one collaborating with the film producer and director, making the artistic choices, while the viewer is upset about what aesthetically pleases their mind.

Letter 13

1. Being mindful is apart of the type of mediation, mindfulness. Mindfulness is when an individual focuses on being intensely aware of their own senses and feelings in the moment, without interpretation or judgment. Practicing mindfulness involves breathing methods, guided imagery, and other practices to relax the body and mind and help reduce stress.

"You don’t need to change. Solutions that ask us to change who we are or become something we’re not have failed us over and over again. Mindfulness recognizes and cultivates the best of who we are as human beings."

This phrase truly resonated with myself. In society, people are always looking to change themselves to fit into societal norms in order to present a perfect image to others around them. Growing up in a world where technology was rapidly growing and evolving, most definitely changed my mindset on how I viewed myself. As a ten year old, I did not truly understand what you looked like growing up. I thought that once you went into high school, you instantly looked like a supermodel. At the years old, I broke my teeth twice, just got braces, had a very interesting choice of style, unkempt hair, and was deemed overweight by my gymnastics coaches. Society instilled that all of these characteristics were negative and needed to be changed immediately. Looking back as a 21 year old, I was clearly just a child trying to find my way and was harmed by the unrealistic expectations of social media and that was only the beginning. I wish mindfulness was incorporated more into my educational career since everyone deserves to recognize the best qualities of themselves at any age.

2. Cyber Culture

"In the 1970s, cyberculture was the exclusive domain of a handful of technology experts, including mathematicians, computer scientists, digital enthusiasts, and academics, devoted to exchanging and promoting ideas related to the growing fields of computers and electronics. These early cybercultures sometimes advanced a view of the future guided by the progressive and beneficial hand of technological change".

When I read this phrase, I immediately though of my aunt. In the 1970s, she was a math teacher in the Longwood District on Long Island. She taught with a chalkboard, paper, and pencils. It must be so interesting for her to see the development and overall evolution of technology in the world of teaching as she further in her career. I believe she retired in the early 2000s, which is still a different world from technology we have today. I doubt that most people in the 1970s would have predicted the change in the use of and dependence on technology people experience in modern times.

When I read this phrase, I think of how dependent people have become on technology. Date: 9/30/2023 11:59:53
Subject: writing as doing
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well on this dreary, grey morning.

Thus far, we have understood our process in the fishbowl: Vocabulary; Google Searches; Deconstruction and Felt-experience. And we continue on this journey because it is a Never-Ending Story (please google movie). The fishbowl is the world of Fantasia and we are warriors fighting from being devoured by a malevolent force called “The Nothing.” 

In the fishbowl, our postings are gestures of spontaneous declarations regarding the selection, substitution and infusion of words. We are performing our process of writing and engaging an audience in a visual and perceptual dialog. In the here and now. 

Performative writing (please google) is a method of “writing as doing” where “writing becomes meaningful in the material, dis/continuous act of writing”. Please see Macey Sundwall’s posting below.

"The concept of performative language was first described by the philosopher John L. Austin (please google) who made a distinction between constative language, which describes the world and can be evaluated as true or false, and performative language, which does something in the world. For Austin, performative language included speech acts such as promising, declaring, swearing, betting, and performing a marriage ceremony. For instance, the utterance, “I do”—said under the right circumstances by the right speakers with the right intentions—transforms the utterer from being unmarried to being married."

Performativity is the power of language to effect change in the world: language does not simply describe the world but may instead (or also) function as a form of social action. 

Please see Michelle Hanna’s posting below on performance and virtuosity.

Sanjiv

CONSTATIVE, PERFORMANCE, WRITING, DOING, UTTERANCE, SPEECH, VISUAL, PERCEPTUAL

from the fishbowl...

9/10 Letter

From my understanding of “Denkblid” and Joan Didion’s work, I feel as though Didion was such a successful writer because of her ability to put such descriptive words on paper to allow her audience to feel the emotions in her writing. She achieved this through personal reflection and character development.

I write entirely to find out what I’m thinking, what I’m looking at, what I see and what it means. What I want and what I fear. – Why I Write (essay originally published in the New York Times Book Review in 1976)

Thinking: the process of using one's mind to consider or reason about something.

Meaning: intended to communicate something that is not directly expressed.

Society resonates with Joan Didion because we are all trying to make sense of everything around us. This includes our thoughts, what we see, and the reasons for everything that happens. Thought image in a text we are reading allows us to use our imaginations to make sense of the words and ideas that an author puts together, and allows us to resonate with characters in a story. This provokes emotion and joins us together in a collective journey of understanding ourselves and the world around us.

II. Virtuosity

michellehanna
