**Letter 18 - 9/27**

"Unlike traditional manufacture, say, in which labor produces a commodity, virtuosity is analogous to the performing arts in that it is an end in itself. I think of your work in that light."

Deconstruction

Traditional: existing in or as part of a tradition; produced, done, or used in accordance with tradition

Manufacture: make something on a large scale using machinery

Labor: to make great effort; the amount of physical, mental, and social effort used to produce goods and services in an economy

Commodity: a useful or valuable thing such as water or time; something that is bought and sold

Virtuosity: the quality of being extremely skilled at something

Analogous: comparable in certain respects, typically in a way which makes clearer the nature of things compared

Performing arts: forms of creating activity that are performed in front of an audience

Reconstruction

This quote from the letter compares virtuosity- something you are highly skilled at to performing arts which are comparable in certain respects. Virno highlights that they are especially similar in the sense that they all need an audience or "social cooperation" along with a common way to communicate. They can also both be considered performances because they are forms of creation that are eventually shared with a larger group. This skill is found in themselves and adds value to society.

This relates to the fishbowl in the sense that our work is of considerable virtuosity- we are writing about what stands out to us as an individual, what we can interpret and skillfully make sense of. The fishbowl is also a performance in the sense that we are sharing our thoughts and creations with a larger society- those that are active in the fishbowl.

Although technically not a form of art, explaining how to do something to someone- giving instruction is a kind of virtuosity. My cousin, who is one year younger than me, came to me for advice about applying for colleges. Not because I had been in college for so long and was knowledgable on the subject, because I was not considering I had just started my college career. She came to me because she told me she liked how I explained things to her, she understood what I was saying. In this sense, explaining is a form of virtuosity because that was something I was skilled at. I shared my understanding to my cousin in language that I knew she could easily follow which relates to the performance aspect.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/20/2023 13:42:33
Subject: ante-narrative of the fishbowl
------------------------------------------------------------
THE DEPTH

OF AN EXAMINED RELATIONSHIP

IS MATCHED

BY THE EXPANSE

OF UNDERSTANDING AND FEELING:

Management Passion in the New Millennium

Presentation

by matt & sanjiv,

of matt & sanjiv,

for matt & sanjiv.

Copyright, Letters To Matt, @dugal, 1999

Prologue

Midway, this way of life we’re bound upon

I woke to find myself in a dark wood,

Where the right road was wholly lost and gone.

Aye me, how hard to speak of it,

The rude and rough and stubborn forest,

The mere breath of memory stirs the old fear in the blood.

But when, at last, I stood beneath a steep hillside,

Which closed the valley’s wandering maze,

Whose dread had pierced me to the heart root deep.

Then I looked up and saw the morning rays

Mantle its shoulder from that planet bright

Which guides men’s feet aright

On all their ways.

(from “Divina Commedia” by Dante Alighieri)

IN THE FISH-BOWL

Creating this fish-bowl is a performative act. It is a gesture for the continuation of a story... we’re writing as we go along… we do not know where it will lead, nor where it will end…but we know this for sure, it exists in our heads.

This is the story of two characters, matt and sanjiv, and the narrative unfolds in new england, at a small university near the ocean…where they’re swimming in a mental fish-bowl, combining Western sensibilities with Eastern ideas…in tryst with purpose, but shunning all direction, except an inner pressure to radicalize. One Viking, the other Sikh, they progress from liberating ego structures, through deeply bled wounds onto downward spirals of hatred and feelings of isolation, and then returning with renewed joy of understanding, forgiveness, and anticipation. Bringing a surging heritage (of bravery in battle) in their bloods, their forays range from existential arguments, to sudden affectionate détentes, and finally onto other arguments. Their relationship mirrors the profound changes in their lifestyles, in their conceptions of work, and of themselves. Determined to move away from conventional categories (of the division between self and other, of the representation of individuality, of established academic standards) in order to reflect a vision of themselves that transcends these boundaries in a new way. The two characters have an odd volatile nature to their wooing…their interactions end suddenly, and generally with puzzled amusement. They improvise, fabricate, and talk about dimensions and chemistry between people… at times their minds almost meet on the same page, until one makes a tiny faux pas that the other sees as shattering…they’re able to maintain this fragility by improvising from moment to moment. That is, they allow themselves to let their personalities and moods influence their performance but not alter the words or circumstances of the scene they enact in their minds…they really have very different ways of thinking, but are able to pass the ball back and forth easily, making for spontaneous fun.

So how do they do this in the fish-bowl? Like their characters, matt and sanjiv can’t agree. “The more I do it,” sanjiv said, “ the more I realize the character is me.” For matt, “it’s a matter of stripping down my defense mechanisms to being that vulnerable again.” Sanjiv countered: “I think for me it’s more building on top of me. I think.”

This interaction ended suddenly, as many interactions between matt and sanjiv, with puzzled bemusement.

Creating a Concept: the Fish-bowl

Instead of the idea of a relationship (like, teacher/student), attached to a real place (like, College of Business at URI), we created the idea of a place, attached to real people, namely, matt-and-sanjiv-in-a-fish-bowl. In this imaginary place, the Fish-bowl, with extraordinary patience and power, through words, we agreed to project awareness and unity of self as the principle theme.

The Fish-bowl is a meeting place of the mind; it is a metaphysical place. There is no hiding here for matt-sanjiv because they’re simultaneously, observers and observed.

It cannot be assumed that the Fish-bowl is a determined, ordered system intelligible to the outsider who can discover the natural laws that govern matt-sanjiv, or that the role of reason is the power guiding matt-sanjiv.

Rationally and empirically, the Fish-bowl has no significance. It can only be seen in terms of the impact that the matt-sanjiv experience will make on its existence.

2.20.99

My Dear Siddharatha,

During our period of estrangement, our inward journey was around doubts as to “who I am” and, “what I stand for,” i.e. who is the authentic self? Am I this, or, am I that?

Through thought alone, one transcends a situation (of this/that), and thus we transcended our

situation, comprising of hurt and feelings of insult, by conceiving the fish-bowl. However, to act upon thought, (beginning with the memo allocating matt’s assistantship to sanjiv), is a contingent act… to survive, to live, to be represented. Our contingent act was a gesture demarcating matt-sanjiv representation. Gesture demarcates, and so we conceive of ourselves…

The fish-bowl is

a contingent act

a gesture

to exist.

The betrayal

of ideas

is a death

to being.

To open one’s mind

and one’s mental routine

to the world

is to open one’s heart.

From,

your very dear friend, Hermann Hesse.

Our Intent: to Play a Unique Role

Our intent is to play a unique role in education: to gain intellect not through verbal discourse per se but through presentation of thought and action; not through involvement with people in an outside world but in a Way Within or an Inward Way that presents world as inner landscape, and so carry out in practice our theme of awareness and unity of self.

Fear of Expressing Feelings

We do not always express Feelings because they’re often Confused, and even Frightening. However, to deny Feelings is to make false, restricted work. To be inauthentic and fake.

In the fish bowl we’re learning to touch Feelings. We touch through expression, i.e. expressing conceptions and perceptions of things, including each other. Particularly, differences like viking/sikh, west/east, physical/ mental, student/teacher,love/hate, and other such dimensions.

We touch Feelings under public gaze. We have a need to go public with every thing that we say or do.

We’re developing a need to write.

Management Principle 1: Conceiving Ambiguity, Creating Possibility

Ambiguous space is nonhierarchical, horizontal. Its nodes intersect in random, unregulated networks in which any node can interconnect with any other node. We create a new form of rhizomatic knowledge by mixing metaphors. Rhizome is a complex metaphor that contrasts with rooted,

traditional metaphors, such as, teacher/student. In the fish-bowl, matt-and-sanjiv celebrate their nomadic and schizophrenic qualities.

We’re motivated to do this because to conceive of ambiguity is to create possibility, and the stronger the ambiguity, the greater is our creativity, and the more powerful our felt-experience.

In the fish-bowl, we’ve created an ambiguious relationship between ourselves:

we’ve fulfilled all formal requirements (papers, etc.), yet we’re inconclusive about them (grades, etc.);

we’re not involved in each others research, yet our interaction is research;

matt is paid fifteen hours/week to assist sanjiv, yet it is sanjiv who assists matt.

The ambiguity in our relationship creates possibility because it allows us to be anything we want. This freedom makes us examine each other in ways we hadn’t been able to see before.

Management Principle 2: Creating Myth

The “fish-bowl” is an example of creating a myth. Myth is created inter-subjectively between matt and sanjiv.

“Myth (of matt-sanjiv-in-a-fish-bowl) is a system of communication, it is a message. It is a mode of signification, a form. We assign to this form historical limits, conditions of use, and reintroduce community into it: we must nevertheless first describe it as a form.” (roland barthes)

We use our imagination to describe our form of myth.

The matt-sanjiv form is diasporic ambiguity.

The college of business at URI is percieving and experiencing it.

Management Principle 3: Create Myth/Intersubjectivity/Intertextuality

Intersubjectivity helps matt-sanjiv to see that most human experience and action goes on between the self and others.

Myth creates Inter-subjectivity; and Inter-subjectivity creates Myth. However, in the fish-bowl the notion of Intertextuality replaces that of Intersubjectivity. “Every text is constructed as a mosaic of other texts, every text is an absorbtion and transformation of other texts” (julia kristeva). Through their intersubjectivity and intertextuality, around the texts of T.E. Lawrence (Lawrence of Arabia), Rainer Rilke (German poet), and Thomas Becket (Archbishop of Canterbury), among others, matt-sanjiv create the myth of the fish-bowl.

2.19.99

Dear Matt,

Thank you for expressing feelings so eloquently through the mouth of Mr. Kappus.

You are Mr. Kappus.

When reading our exchange of letters, it is evident that one’s authentic self is indeed problematic in a situation where one can be anything one wants.

We can be friends forever.

Between ourselves: Mr. Kappus, T.E Lawrence, the English, Rilke, Sartre, Hesse, the German, Eriksen, Viking, Siddharatha, Buddha, the Indian, Eakins, the American, Dugal, Sikh, Baudelaire, the French, the West and the East, we’re creating an inter-textuality, an inter-subjectivity, and a shared memory. Indeed, we’re creating our context. We’re laying the foundation.

Through this labyrinthe lies the inward journey of the subjective self.

I find your words,“ Even when overcome by feelings of hate, I still knew that our relationship was a source of great knowledge and understanding” to be most telling of our universal condition, because the central problem is not an abstract one, but one of contingency: what we lack is certainty, confidence, sense of purpose to break paradoxical situations like feelings of hate/ and feelings of great understanding. That is, the more I hate, the more I understand, and the more I understand, the more I hate.

If we had more access to our own past, to memory, to inter-textuality and inter-subjectivity, our sense of purpose would be immensely augmented. Hesse’s Steppenwolf expressed this sense of meaning due to re-possession of the past:

“For moments together my heart stood still between delight and sorrow to find how rich was the gallery of my life, and how thronged the soul of the wretched steppenwolf with high eternal stars and constellations… the kernel of this life of mine was noble. It came of high descent and turned, not on trifles, but on the stars…”(Steppenwolf, Hesse).

From your friend, Sanjiv

Myth/Intersubjectivity/Intertextuality are Inter-connected.

Inter-connectedness is the understanding that relations, connecting and opposing, exist.

Even lies are part of the truth.

To be Inter-connected is To-Be-Aware-of-Other-Realities,

i.e. to be aware of opposing myths, metaphors, dimensions,

and their on-going interactive inter-subjectivities.

“matt-sanjiv-in-the-fish-bowl” are aware of the what, why, whom, and wherefrom concerning their myth.

2.21.99

Dear Lief Erikson theViking,

One’s position within a relationship, like,Viking-Sikh, has to do with intersubjective interpretation, in other words, position is determined by our past (shared memory), our present (interpretation), and, our future (imagination).

The activities representing the past, present, and future, are overlapping in the new millennium to the extent of becoming indistinguishable. We’re experiencing confusion, loss of control, etc. In such a situation, how do I determine my sense of self?

To do so, I reveal a structure, or deconstruct one, or imaginatively construct one…here’s mine: “I was sent to these Arabs as a stranger, unable to think their thoughts or subscribe their beliefs, but charged by duty to lead them forward and to develop to the highest any movement of theirs profitable to England in her war. If I could not assume their character, I could atleast conceal my own, and pass among them without evident friction, neither a discord nor a critic but an unnoticed influence. Since I was their fellow I will not be their apologist or advocate. Today in my old garments, I could play the bystander, obedient to the sensibilities of our theatre…but it is more honest to record that these ideas and actions then passed naturally. What now looks wanton or sadic seemed in the field inevitable or just unimportant routine.” (T.E. Lawrence, Seven Pillars of Wisdom, 1926)

What is our intersubjective interpretation of the above text with regard to us, as Viking-Sikh? Here is a random list of specifics for us to address in the fish-bowl:

locate the fear

build history

zoom in and out

raise the stakes

get specific

explore the underside

Yours truly,

Sardar Bahadur Singh the Sikh

Management Principle 4: Experiencing Learning

In the fish-bowl the problem of Being takes precedence over that of Knowing (when acquiring a Ph.D. or anything else).

“Being cannot be made a subject of objective enquiry; it is revealed to the individual by reflecting on his own unique concrete existence in time and space. Existence is basic: it is the fact of the individual’s presence and participation in a changing and potentially dangerous world. Each self-aware individual understands his own existence in terms of his experience of himself and of his situation. The self of which he is aware is a thinking being which has beliefs, hopes, fears, desires, the need to find a purpose, and a will that can determine his actions.” (sartre)

Real and Unreal:

We are free to choose between authentic and fake as a form of existence. Freedom distinguishes between “authentic” and “inauthentic” forms of existence.

In the fish-bowl we distinguish between authentic/fake on the basis of our endeavor to transcend a particular dimension or form.

This endeavor is the matt-sanjiv form of Authenticity.

We are free to choose our reality.

Management Principle 5: Creating Reality as Representational Space

I can represent something (teacher), if you represent the other (student).

You can only represent something (youth), if I represent the other (mid-life).

in this dimension we are bound

Whenever we articulate other dimensions, other myths, other inter-subjectivites, other realities, other representational spaces, we ipso facto create a temporal and spatial disjunction.

When we articulate the meaning of a new dimension, we experience temporal and spatial disjunction as representational space.

Matt & Sanjiv occupy several dimensions, but their spirits are free.

Viking and Sikh

We’re hooked.

Our Method: the Interplay between Verbalized-Thought and Felt-Experience

In the fish-bowl, the interplay between our two distinct identities brought complexity and depth to our respective worlds. We interpreted text (and each-other), as we saw (perceived) and felt (experienced) it. Even as we respect another’s text, we brought our subjectivity to bear upon it. We infused the text with our individual being; not the other way round. The text did not infuse us.

In other words, we used words as expressions of sensed-thought (felt-experience) rather than as verbalized-thought in promoting the idea of unity above the inner divisions between us. Our interpreted text reveals us and reflects on us.

Example of Verbalized-thought:

“That evening, I found that I had to untangle two different reactions, writing a description of the conversation and, carefully separated, an expression of my feelings as a member of another culture. Each person is calibrated by experience, almost like a measuring instrument for difference, so discomfort is informative and offers a starting point for new understanding. Indeed, what I had seen and heard would not have pushed me to reflection and generalization were it not for the urgency produced by the sense of difference.”

(Mary Catherine Bateson, Peripheral Visions, page 17)

Example of Felt-experience:

Story-telling is a powerful tool. It can help

1) Persuade an audience

2) Build trust

3) Build a connection

4) Emotionally appeal to an audience

5) Help audience understand and retain information

This is a list of beneficial elements that come from story-telling. Story-telling is an engaging way to communicate and intrigue the audience by grabbing their full attention.

Examples of places or professions that storytelling is useful include lecturing to students, sales profession and marketing, fundraising, public speaking, film and television.

To Be Two is the title of a book by Luce Irigaray. Please google.

It took me many years to understand Irigaray's meaning, and

to be able to interpret her in my own way...influenced by an Indian sensibility.

Life is a Dance that begins by selecting Two, and each is Other to the other; Alterity (please google). They co-exist and form and define each other. 

Why alterity? From deconstruction and reconstructing meaning, we will be moving into the creation of dichotomies and dimensions via a circuitous route. We will be selecting two words and thereby constructing structures to enter the unknown. We are staying close to text, in order to become whatever we want. For instance, our fishbowls are paintings to look at because they are telling stories with hidden meanings, layer upon layer of paint (words). You see a range of color, the ordinary and extraordinary and the reach of light. We are painting each other: to become a still life of a magical landscape. We are writing ourselves into existence and we are sailing on our own private dictionary.

9 / 8 / 2023 Letter

Sanjiv's letter on "Epistemic Cognition as an Antidote to Algorithmic Governmentality" sparked my interest in this class and, because of this, I will start by deconstructing the title of that paper. Epistemic Cognition is what we learn through our own personal thoughts and experiences, not what we see other people doing or saying on the internet or in a textbook. This way of learning is how humans developed and it is being lost due to Algorithmic Govermentality. Algorithmic Governmentality is the surrender of our own way of thinking which is overrun by computational technologies and the constant data they feed us. An antidote is something that cancels or counteracts the affects of something else. Sanjiv describes how through this class we will cure this structured way of thinking and learning through our own cognitions. A way of learning that is ignored in today's universities.

I think it is important to consider algorithmic governmentaility and how it affects our daily lives. I often get overwhelmed by the amount of information that is available to me and feel that it can be unhealthy. They say the best learning happens when you are bored, but we do not get those opportunities when we are consumed by the never-ending stimulus of technology and social media.

9 /12 / 2023 Letter

"Sorting, sifting, selecting, and substituting"

We are performing each of these actions in The Fishbowl. We sort through each of the letters and find sentences that confuse us or spark our interest. We reread these sentences within the letter, sifting through the ones that make sense and ones that do not. We select the sentences that we would like to deconstruct, to delve into deeper and find the meaning of. Finally, we substitute words in these sentences with synonyms, therefore, expanding our vocabulary and exercising our brains. We read, look, pick, and switch to make meaning of words.

Post by ceciliacalise » Tue Sep 12, 2023 4:43 pm

"Denkbild"

"The Denkbild is a poetic mode of writing, a brief snapshot-in-prose that stages the interrelation of literary, philosophical, political, and cultural insights."

DECONSTRUCTION:

1. Denkbild: This refers to the subject of the sentence, which is "The Denkbild." A Denkbild is a literary or poetic mode of writing.

2. Poetic mode of writing: This phrase describes what a Denkbild is. It's a style of writing that is artistic and creative, often used in poetry.

3. Brief snapshot-in-prose: This further describes what a Denkbild is. It's a concise portrayal or representation of something, typically written in prose, which is regular written language (not poetry).

4. Stages: This is a verb that means to set up or present. In this context, it's describing what a Denkbild does.

5. Interrelation: This term means the way things are connected or related to each other.

6. Literary, philosophical, political, and cultural insights: These are the kinds of ideas or concepts that a Denkbild portrays. They are insights or perspectives related to literature, philosophy, politics, and culture.

RECONSTRUCTION:

So, in simpler and broader terms, the sentence is saying that a Denkbild is a form of artistic writing that provides a concise, prose-based snapshot of how literary, philosophical, political, and cultural ideas are interconnected or related to each other.

The concept of Denkbild is quite useful as it offers a creative and concise way to capture complex ideas and their interconnections. It allows writers to convey intricate thoughts from various fields like literature, philosophy, politics, and culture in a compact form. This can be valuable for expressing profound insights, fostering intellectual exploration, and encouraging readers to think deeply about the relationships between these diverse areas of knowledge. Denkbilds can serve as powerful tools for both writers and readers to engage with complex concepts in a thought-provoking and artistic manner.

In my real life, I've found that often times my experiences with art are the most complicated to accurately explain to others through language and words alone. I find it difficult to explain the feeling of being at a concert of an artist I love, for example seeing Taylor Swift. After the concert, the only way to provide an accurate description of the experience, was utilizing the concept of a Denkbild. By providing complex and specific sensory details, I'm able to convey a thought-image that others can picture vividly, as if they experienced it themselves. Simply using adjectives is not always enough.

Sensemaking

"If accuracy is nice but not necessary in sensemaking, than what is necessary? The answer is. something that preserves plausibility and coherence, something that is reasonable and memorable, something that embodies past experience and expectations, something which resonates with other people, something that can be constructed retrospectively but also can be used prospectively, something that captures both feeling and thought, something that allows for embellishment to fit current oddities, something that is fun to contrast. In short, what is necessary in sensemaking is a good story."

DECONSTRUCTING:

"Something that preserves plausibility and coherence,"

- This suggests that what's necessary is information or a narrative that makes sense and is believable.

"Something that embodies past experience and expectations,"

- This highlights that it should relate to what people have experienced before and what they expect.

"Something that can be constructed retrospectively but also can be used prospectively,"

- This implies that it should work for understanding past events (looking back) and for guiding future actions (looking forward).

RECONSTRUCTING:

In summary, this passage suggests that accuracy may not be the most important factor in understanding or making sense of something. Instead, what's crucial is a narrative or story that is believable, logical, memorable, relatable, adaptable to different time frames, emotionally and intellectually engaging, flexible for unique situations, and interesting for comparison with other narratives. In essence, a good story is what's needed for effective sensemaking.

In my own experience as a student studying marketing, I absolutely recognize the importance of a "good story" when it comes to sensemaking. I've learned at length how essential it is to convey a "good" story in any form of marketing communications. It is clear that the ideas Weick discusses are applicable in almost every area of life. It holds true in my experience that to really influence or persuade anyone of anything, all these aspects of a good story really are necessary. I have always found myself to be more successful in conveying what I hoped to when ensuring the narrative makes sense and is believable overall; also when real-life experiences are included to create resonance.

Joan Didion

"The dreams and the fears into which Martha Stewart taps are not of “feminine” domesticity but of female power, of the woman who sits down at the table with the men and, still in her apron, walks away with the chips."

DECONSTRUCTING:

FEMININE: of or relating to women, possessing qualities traditionally attributed to women

DREAMS: something longed for, something desired

POWER: ability or capacity to do something, strength or force exerted

RECONSTRUCTING:

More simply, this sentence is saying that Martha Stewart's dreams and fears are not about traditional female roles like housekeeping. Instead, they're about women being powerful and competing with men, even while staying true to their feminine identity, like a woman who can win in a male-dominated game while still wearing her apron.

This quote from the text resonated with me deeply. I think the importance of feminine feminism cannot be understated in today's world, and she provides a perfect example here. I think today, the new wave of feminism often erases real feminity, and instead focuses on a harsher approach. While this is also respectable, of course, I personally believe that empowering women who are indeed feminine, and who do aspire to "feminine" goals, is essential to the movement. Feminine women can be just as strong and empowered as women who are more masculine or less feminine in identity.

Structuralists

Structuralist: A structuralist is someone who follows the principles of structuralism, a school of thought in fields such as linguistics, anthropology, and literary theory, and seeks to understand and analyze complex phenomena by examining the underlying structures or patterns that shape them.

DECONSTRUCTING:

COMPLEX PHENOMENA: Complicated aspects of reality or subjects that structuralists break down into fundamental elements.

PRINCIPLES OF STRUCTURALISM: The core concepts and guidelines that guide structuralist thinking.

FIELDS: Academic disciplines such as linguistics, anthropology, and literary theory where structuralism is applied to gain deeper insights.

RECONSTRUCTING:

So, in simpler terms, a structuralist looks at how different parts or elements within a system relate to each other and how these relationships create meaning or function.

In my own experience, in my junior year of high school, I enrolled in a philosophy course that introduced me to various philosophical concepts and thinkers. One of the topics we explored was "the nature of reality." I remember one particular discussion about the classic philosophical question: "If a tree falls in a forest and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?" This question sparked a lively debate in our class. We analyzed the structural aspects of the question, breaking it down into the components of perception, existence, and reality. I realized how philosophy could be a structured way of examining fundamental questions about the world. It encouraged me to question assumptions and consider different perspectives, which I found to be a valuable skill in both academic and personal life.

Phenomenologists

A phenomenologist is a philosopher who investigates and describes the structures of human consciousness and subjective experience, focusing on how individuals perceive and interpret the world through their lived experiences.

DECONSTRUCTING:

PERCIEVE: To perceive means to become aware of or interpret sensory information from the external world or internal thoughts and feelings.

INTERPRET: Interpretation involves making sense of or assigning meaning to sensory information and experiences, often influenced by personal perspectives, beliefs, and cultural factors.

SUBJECTIVE EXPERIENCE: Subjective experience refers to an individual's personal and unique mental and emotional encounters with the world, which may not necessarily be objective or universally shared.

RECONSTRUCTING:

In simpler terms, a phenomenologist is a philosopher who studies how people think, feel, and experience the world, trying to understand the structures and patterns of our thoughts and perceptions.

A personal experience I think of in relation to phenomenology is one of my favorite family recipes I like to cook a lot when I'm away from home. One particular time I was making this pasta last year, I got a powerful sense of nostalgia. The combination of scents and tastes transported me back to my kitchen when I was younger.

Reflecting on this experience later, I realized that cooking that meal wasn't just about following a recipe; it was about how the sensory experiences of smell, taste, and memory intertwined to create a rich and meaningful moment. Phenomenology helps us understand that even seemingly ordinary experiences can be layered with personal significance and unique perceptions, influenced by our individual consciousness and memories.

Social Constructivism:

Social constructivism is a theory that suggests that many of our ideas, beliefs, and even facts about the world are not inherent or objective truths but are instead shaped by society, culture, and human interactions. It emphasizes that our understanding of reality is influenced by the social context in which we live and that people collectively create and reinforce these shared beliefs and perceptions through communication and shared experiences.

DECONSTRUCTING:

SOCIETY: Society refers to a group of people living together in a community or sharing a common culture, norms, and values.

CULTURE: Culture encompasses the shared customs, beliefs, values, behaviors, and practices of a group of people, often passed down through generations.

HUMAN INTERACTIONS: Human interactions involve communication, relationships, and exchanges between individuals within a social context.

RECONSTRUCTING:

In simpler terms, social constructivism is the idea that our beliefs and knowledge are shaped by the society and culture we live in, rather than being absolute truths.

In my early childhood, I grew up in a culturally diverse neighborhood where many of my friends celebrated Hannukah, while my family celebrated Christmas. One year, I had a conversation with my best friend, who celebrated Hanukkah. We discussed our holiday traditions, and I was fascinated by the differences in our celebrations. It struck me that what I considered "normal" during Christmas and what she considered "normal" during Hanukkah were shaped by our respective cultural backgrounds.

It reinforced the idea that our understanding of reality is influenced by our social context and the collective beliefs and traditions of the people around us. It was a valuable lesson in how social constructivism plays a role in shaping our perspectives and beliefs about the world.

Social constructivism is a learning theory that states individuals are active participants in the creation of their own knowledge.

Symbolic interactionism is a theory that explains how individuals interact with each other. The theory argues that people act as a result of meanings they assign to things, which can differ among different people and can change over time.

Reflexivity is the ability of someone to examine their own emotions, figure out why they feel that way, and realize how their emotions are affecting their actions.

IDENTITY

-the fact of being who or what a person or thing is

FORMATION

-the action of forming or process of being formed

REALIZE

-become fully aware of (something) as a fact; understand clearly

REFLECT

-think deeply or carefully about

ATTEND

CONSEQUENCE

-a result or effect of an action or condition

RESPONSIBILITY

-the state or fact of having a duty to deal with something or of having control over someone

INSTINCT

-an innate, typically fixed pattern of behavior in animals in response to certain stimuli

INTUITION

-the ability to understand something immediately, without the need for conscious reasoning

CONTEXT

DESCRIBE

-give an account in words of (someone or something), including all the relevant characteristics, qualities, or events

Letter 4 - Life of Practice

The Denkbild is the concept of “thought-images” in which it is a form of poetic writing. Providing the reader with a brief “snapshot” of the author’s mind in that exact moment. It helps to provide literary, philosophical, political, and cultural insights.

Joan Didion was an American writer and novelist. Her book entitled “Let me tell you what I mean” addresses a variety of topics from problems with trust in newspapers to why she writes what she does. It provides the reader with an insight into her mind, similarly to what we are doing in the Fishbowl. We are providing the Fishbowl with glimpses into our minds.

Deconstruction & Evoking Felt-Experiences

post by michellehanna » Mon Sep 11, 2023 6:05 pm

**Letter 2 9/8**

“The Denkbild encodes a poetic form of condensed, epigrammatic writing in textual snapshots, flashing up as poignant meditations that typically fasten upon a seemingly peripheral detail or marginal topic, usually without a developed plot or a prescribed narrative agenda, yet charged with theoretical insight.” (Gerard Richter, Thought-Images, Stanford University Press).”

Deconstruction

encodes: convert into a particular form. The process of turning thoughts into communication

condensed: made more compressed or concentrated. Reduced in volume, area, length, or scope; shortened

epigrammatic: expressing oneself using very few words, in a smart, funny manner. Short and clever.

textual snapshots: images of reflection. Ephemeral and ethereal, fleeting and opaque.

-ephermal: lasting for a very short time

-ethereal: extremely delicate and light in a way that seems too perfect for this world

-fleeting: brief, short-lived

-opaque: not transparent, cannot see through

poignant: strongly effective in stirring one's emotions; causing or having a very sharp feeling of sadness

meditations: intervention in a dispute in order to resolve it; conciliation

fasten: to do up securely; to concentrate on someone or something

peripheral: not central or of main importance; lying outside or away from central part. Outer, external

marginal: small or not very important; insignificant

charged: filled with excitement, tension, or emotion

insight: immediate or clear understanding

Reconstruction

The Denkbild is a poetic way of writing in a short yet clever manner in order to evoke a textual snapshot. The image that you see when you think of a specific piece of text. These textual snapshots can usually result in an overwhelming sense of emotion or realization. Although the topic may seem insignificant or small and the narrator may not have a plan, the denkbild is infused with theoretical appreciation and understanding. Denkbild will allow the reader to reflect on important ideas that weren't apparent to them at one point.

Denkbild is about focusing on the aspects of life that may often be overlooked. Taking a deeper look into things and appreciating the value that it brings. Oftentimes this will result in personal value, insight, or realization. A very simple, yet common example of this that has occurred in my own life is waking up in the morning for school, in a new home, right on the water. Although this did not involve reading text, drinking my morning coffee during the first week of school allowed me to appreciate my life and all that I have, even though it was quite simple. Although life can be stressful, calm and simple moments like these allow you to appreciate the good.

michellehanna

Re: Letter 3

post by michellehanna » Mon Sep 11, 2023 10:13 pm

**Letter 3 - 9/10**

"The more advanced the technology is thought to be, the more likely are people to discredit anything that does not come through it. Because of the fallacy of centrality, the better the information system, the less sensitive it is to novel events." (Sense making for Organizations by Karl Weick)

Deconstruction

Discredit: loss or lack of reputation or respect; dishonor, disrepute

Fallacy: a mistaken belief

Fallacy of centrality: assuming you are in a central position, you presume that if something serious were happening, you would know about it. And since you don't know about it, it isn't happening

Information system: an interconnected set of components used to collect, store, process and transmit data and digital information

Novel: of a new and unusual kind; different from anything seen or known before

Reconstruction

As technology continues to advance and demonstrate its capabilities, trust and reliance towards technology grows. This results in doubt around any information that does not come from technology. The fallacy of centrality explains that if something serious were going on, it would be known to the individual. If you have not been exposed to it or have not heard of it, it is not going on or it is not serious enough.

After reading the first few pages of Karl Weick's Sense Making For Organizations, I was instantly intrigued. It explains an everyday occurrence that is often overlooked. The fallacy of centrality. The book starts off describing sense making. Sense making occurs when one believes an event is so unlikely or implausible that they do not report it due to the fear of not being believed. The book goes on to explain the history of battered child syndrome which is a pattern of injuries to a young child with inadequate explanations about the medical history from the parents. In 1946, battered child syndrome was suggested by a pediatric radiologist in an article discussing six cases and including X-ray photos. The radiologist suggested that the accidents may have been due to "intentional ill treatment." By 1953, multiple articles discussing battered child syndrome had been published, but the medical field remained unconcerned. It wasn't until 1961 when people started to recognize the importance. This was because data from a national survey identified 749 cases which led to laws in all fifty states to report suspected cases of BCS. This is an example of the fallacy of centrality. People assumed that because they hadn't heard about it or because there wasn't much information about it, it must not be important or may not be going on at all. As technology improves, people are less sensitive to information that does not come from it. An example of this in our own lives is global warming. Because people aren't seeing specific data from technology and because it isn't being discussed on the news or social media, people believe it must not be happening. This makes me realize the importance of being aware and conscious of all information.

I. Cavafy’s famous poem

Ithaka

BY C. P. CAVAFY

TRANSLATED BY EDMUND KEELEY

As you set out for Ithaka

hope your road is a long one,

full of adventure, full of discovery.

Laistrygonians, Cyclops,

angry Poseidon—don’t be afraid of them:

you’ll never find things like that on your way

as long as you keep your thoughts raised high,

as long as a rare excitement

stirs your spirit and your body.

Laistrygonians, Cyclops,

wild Poseidon—you won’t encounter them

unless you bring them along inside your soul,

unless your soul sets them up in front of you.

Hope your road is a long one.

May there be many summer mornings when,

with what pleasure, what joy,

you enter harbors you’re seeing for the first time;

may you stop at Phoenician trading stations

to buy fine things,

mother of pearl and coral, amber and ebony,

sensual perfume of every kind—

as many sensual perfumes as you can;

and may you visit many Egyptian cities

to learn and go on learning from their scholars.

Keep Ithaka always in your mind.

Arriving there is what you’re destined for.

But don’t hurry the journey at all.

Better if it lasts for years,

so you’re old by the time you reach the island,

wealthy with all you’ve gained on the way,

not expecting Ithaka to make you rich.

Ithaka gave you the marvelous journey.

Without her you wouldn't have set out.

She has nothing left to give you now.

And if you find her poor, Ithaka won’t have fooled you.

Wise as you will have become, so full of experience,

you’ll have understood by then what these Ithakas mean.

C. P. Cavafy, "The City" from C.P. Cavafy: Collected Poems. Translated by Edmund Keeley and Philip Sherrard. Translation Copyright © 1975, 1992 by Edmund Keeley and Philip Sherrard. Reproduced with permission of Princeton University Press.

Source: C.P. Cavafy: Collected Poems (Princeton University Press, 1975)

To understand this, screen and scroll (in your mind) the movies you watched (words spoken and body images) and construct dichotomies and dimensions. There is no right/wrong!

In 448, understanding the notion of dimension is important. 

Picture yourself along a high/low dimension whenever you are interacting with other cultures.

Your position on this dimension is determined by your cultural values (nation, family, etc) and by your personality.

We create dichotomies and dimensions continually. We cook them up. They are imaginary structures. They are our resources and our tools. Often we become inflexible, and then we are stuck under a structure, and success becomes elusive.

Whenever we look at things as dichotomies and dimensions, we are able to understand our differences. It is really about that, isn’t it? Accepting differences.

When you do the final, you are not thinking about such heavy and incomprehensible stuff. 

You are only, sorting, sifting, selecting and substituting. The outcome is Meaning. And you gain Insight. 

We have been doing this since infancy. Please fact check.

Letter Deconstructions

post by michaelferet » Mon Apr 24, 2023 1:33 pm

1/26 “Genesis of a fishbowl”

It is important to not just care about quantity but also quality. These are both vital. Everyday we communicate in different ways. This is both virtual and in person and through using thoughts, words, feelings, and images. The digital space is new to many of us but is where we can all build our knowledge together as a community.

1/28 “Living legend”

We can change the way in which we see the world by adopting different words, metaphors, symbols, and images. This can be done through collaboration within the digital space. The fishbowl is a place where we all do well or do not based on each other so we must be aware of our peers. Anything each of us adds brings more value to the fishbowl and it is up to us how we want to interpret that value.

1/30 “Generating text”

Each and every day we are constantly generating text. We use this text to assign meaning to feelings, images, words, thoughts, and life in general. We collect data to help us with this through our observations and draw conclusions about others based on data.

1/31 “Doing of the Social Meeting Exercise”

By collaborating with each other we are not able to just learn from each other but also develop friendships. By doing the social meeting exercise we will be able to examine how things have much more complex structures than what may be seen. These cannot be explained with traditional methods. In conversation we learn about ourselves as well as others. We are observing ourselves observing the group. This allows us to transform and learn to express ourselves through thoughts, feelings, and images.

2/1 “Social Meeting: Interpretive Interactionism”

According to interpretive interactionism we can only obtain meaningful interpretations of human experience by immersing ourselves into that in which we hope to understand. Looking at the social meeting interaction as digging for gold is a great way to symbolically describe the search for knowledge from within each other. If we look at it like this we will immerse ourselves.

2/2 “Why Deconstruct a Text”

By deconstructing a text we are developing our own voice and taking ownership of that text. Taking the meaning of the text further is a mind-set. Every post is taking ownership of a text and putting one’s own voice on it. This allows us to learn from it and treat it as a “watering hole”. There is much to gain from everyone’s different voices and interpretations. Every action done is never unnoticed and we are constantly witnesses, participants, and scribes.

2/3 “Deploying Attention”

By taking original words further and enhance them we are constructing new structures. These structures are not just of the words. They are also of feelings, values, norms, experiences, interpretations, and understanding. This embellishment of words give us far more knowledge and teaches many new structures. We reveal more and more of ourselves every time that we choose words. The attention we show to certain words reveals more about ourselves.

2/3 “Our Mind-Sets”

The old way of looking at definitions in business is defunct and we must change our mind-sets. We determine our mind-sets and old terms that encourage borders such as” domestic” or “overseas” are leaving the business world. The search for meaning is what makes up our mind-sets and this goes all the way to our thoughts. We can find truth by looking for the connection between all of our positive and negative views. The participation and pursuit of opportunities is important to developing a good mind-set.

I

Subject: Doing the Final in MGT448: International Dimensions of Business
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? It is the end of the semester and we will soon be parting company.

Getting to the point: the doing of the Final for MGT448: International Dimensions of Business. 

I lay out the steps below, which are easy to understand, because you have been doing them and watching others doing them, all semester.

By now you have watched the 3 films, and can access them as required. This is important. I attach them below again. You have been asked to see the films as an ethnographer. Watch the words spoken and the facial expressions; constructing context.

What we have been grappling with all semester is the construction of a culture among ourselves in the fishbowl, where each individual is Singular and represents a piece of their own group/national culture. My letters will continue to address such matters until May 3. 

The time frame for responding to letters and completing the Final in MGT448 is by the end of May 3. You have 10 days and you may complete the final any time during this period. It doesn’t take time in the doing. It takes an immersion.

Doing the Final:

According to Hofstede, the five main dimensions for understanding differences in culture are identity, power, gender, uncertainty, and time. 

STEP 1; 

Google Hofstede’s 5 Dimensions of Culture, and 

define (cut and copy) each dimension.

Post a sentence that describes your understanding of each dimension. 

In other words, for each dimension, you are developing (by deconstructing, editing) a structure of words into one sentence.

Show all iterations to view development.

Your sentence is a definition; it is theory. It is a framework. 

Your sentence is a definition of a dimension of differences (high/low) in values.

STEP 2: 

Identify in words, instances (shots, clips, context, interaction) from the films that express differences in culture from your own on each of Hofstede’s 5 dimensions. Identity, Power, Gender, Uncertainty, and Time.

In other words, you are expressing five dimensions and using each dimension to understand cultural differences in Kinky Boots, India, and Chinese cultures.

The doing of the steps does not take time. You have to have a good handle on the films. An ethnographic text (copying words spoken) is helpful because your resource is the text, i.e., the words spoken in the films by the protagonists. This takes time.

Bottom LIne of the Final: You are describing Hofstede’s 5 Dimensions with examples from your personal felt-experiences and from those in the films.

You have 5 Dimensions and 3 Films. That is 15 short paragraphs. Follow KISS principle. I mean that. 

Good luck! We’re in this together. We are not in competition, we are a fishbowl, and our situation is known and visible. There are no surprises.

Sanjiv

Hi Everyone,

How are you? At this point in the semester most of us are in a mental state of high stress around deadlines, promises, commitments, consequences and generally a feeling of being lost. If you are in such a state, please know, the fishbowl is a radically different way of learning where nobody gets left behind nor left out. Learning happens in complex and devious ways, and there is no end to the fishbowl way of thinking.

Please see Christian Evers postings below.

For greater understanding, I am juxtaposing Evers postings next to the last two paragraphs from our Abstract. 

From the Abstract:

Feeling Human

Soft computing is a set of techniques, including genetic algorithms, fuzzy logic and neural networks, that are tolerant of imprecision, uncertainty, partial truth and approximation. However, while human information processing is easy to explain, human subjective experience is difficult. Working in the fishbowl is easier when its just work, like doing vocabulary; it’s much harder when the person actually cares and shares a felt-experience.

Conclusion

Human expertise depends on unconscious instinct rather than conscious symbol manipulation, and on having a "feel" for the situation, rather than explicit symbolic knowledge (Dreyfus, Hubert). Intuition matters more than data because it allows for spontaneity, impulse, instinct and courage. Ideas lead to a result but ideals result in what makes us human. For instance, in the fishbowl, a cardinal principle is doing right matters more than being right. 

Sanjiv

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 4/19/2023 16:21:02
Subject: Steps for the Final in MGT345: Business and Society
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. I wish you a renewed resolve for completing the semester.

I. 

Your Final in MGT345: Business and Society is an exercise in ‘understanding’ and ‘realizing’ four characteristics attributed to successful trans-national businesses. 

In their book ‘Managing Across Borders,’ Bartlett and Ghoshal (please google) assert that businesses need to organize themselves in a dramatically different way if they are to survive and flourish in the global business arena. 

Business in a Society, as depicted in the films ‘Beautiful People’ and ‘Kinky Boots,’ asserts that a key strategic capability lies in exploiting one’s knowledge through worldwide 'diffusion and adaptation.' 

If we are to cope with a complex environment, we must have an equally complex and multi-faceted business strategy. We must become what Bartlett and Ghoshal call a “transnational corporation.” According to an empirical study conducted by the authors, such an organization has the following four characteristics: 

Integrated Networking Structure

Dynamic Decision-Making

Adaptive Coordination Mechanisms

Unique Innovative Capabilities

Each of these 4 characteristics implies a sophisticated understanding of and ability to manage a business successfully in a culturally diverse society.

For the Final, you are applying 10 steps for each of the characteristics listed above.

The steps are enumerated below. They are specific, pragmatic, easy to follow and do.

You have been doing them all semester.

I call it: sorting, sifting, selecting, substituting

It is important to have finished watching the two films, because you want to go back-and-forth with your text generated in the final. 

Snippets from moving images. 

The flow and flux of life, captured in the moment. 

Working with metaphors, symbols and word-images. 

You are free to begin working on the Final. Yours is a work in progress that ends at the appointed hour.

II.

10 Steps for ‘realizing’ and ‘understanding’ the 4 characteristics of transnational corporations. 

These characteristics are not unlike what you have been doing in the fishbowl:

Step 1. (1 mt) Opening Structure

Start with the first characteristic, in this instance, “An integrated networking structure.” 

Step 2. (15 mts) Word-Pool 

Gather similar words (as many as you see fit) for each of the three words in Step I. 

Use a good dictionary/thesaurus. It is your tool box. Don’t leave home without it! 

In other words, create a word-pool of similar words for each of the selected words.

You can widen your word-pool by taking the words still further. Good policy to follow, for good decisions.

This is chalking the field.

Laying the ground work.

Scoping possibilities.

It is also, lining up the ducks. 

Looking at what you got to play with.

Think of landscape designing as a metaphor.

Step 3. (20 mts) Re-structure

Construct a Single sentence structure from your word-pool. 

This construction shows your vision and path that you intend to follow on your journey of understanding and realization.

Spend thought on this construction: one sentence, arrived at iteratively. 

You are not restricted to the original words in Step 1: integrated, networking, structure. 

Substitute original words (integrated, networking, structure) for better understanding.

How so? 

Simplify the word (by substituting from dictionary), 

simplify the word further (substitute the word again), 

and then simplify yet again (substitute the word yet again) 

is the name of the game. 

The journey, I should say. All metaphors!

 

Edit and re-edit and show your iterations is the best policy to follow for transparency.

Where’s my dictionary, she cried.

Tip from experience: first write out a paragraph encompassing the words in your word pool. 

This is your initial understanding, and then edit and re-edit down to a sentence. 

Using your dictionary through-out. Like an astronomical chart.

Chiseling down to a structure, like a sculptor would do. 

Metaphor again!

Ultimately, it is your own process, your own individuality. We are singular beings.

Step 4. (30 mts) Felt-Experience 

Express a felt-experience that “fits" the sentence structure in Step 3 above. 

It is a short paragraph in the first person. A personal experience, an incident.

What makes its expression difficult is that it has to “fit" Step 3.

The sentence structure in Step 3 is the abstract form, and the felt-experience in Step 4 is the content that fits the form. 

Form and content go together. 

But you created the form first, and then fitted the content. 

Generally it is the other way round. We abstract from experience, which comes before the abstraction.

Cop out: you can use content from the films to “fit" your structures.

The felt-experience is a description of what happened; an incident from your past. 

Start with identifying the feeling that you are describing. 

Put a word to the feeling.

The focus is on the feeling at the time of the experience. This is key to empowering your text.

Step 5. (5mts) Reductionism 

Reduce your felt-experience paragraph to a Dichotomy. 

Please google Reductionism.

Arbitrarily select two words from your felt-experience paragraph.

The two words must be different from each other. No adjectives. 

No correlation between the two words. This is key. Otherwise, the subsequent outcome is trivial, i.e., no insights are possible and any realization is a far cry.

Your goal is to form meaningful relations between disparate elements. 

Creativity and imagination are key skills at this point of time.

Step 6. (25 Mts) Word-Pool 

Make a word-pool starting with the words in the Dichotomy in Step 5.

Step 7. Structure: Same as Step 3 

Construct a sentence structure of words from your word-pool in Step 6 above. 

Easier when you first write out a paragraph and then cut it down to a key sentence.

Step 8. Felt-experience: Same as Step 4

A felt-experience paragraph that ‘fits’ the above sentence structure.

Step 9. Reduce to a Dichotomy: Same as Sep 5

Select two words from Step 8.

Step 10. (30mts) Self-Reflexivity 

What did you ‘realize’ from the above exercise?

Tip to answer such a question: instinctively, construct a dichotomy and follow the process above.

*************

III. 

In Conclusion

What you are doing in these 10 steps is basically constructing two abstract sentence structures and 2 felt-experiences to go with each of them.

You are doing this four times as there are four characteristics. 

You are creating form/content. 

You are distinguishing particular/universal. 

You are differentiating general/specific. 

It is your individual abstract theory/felt-experience.

Finally, always follow the KISS principle. Please see Emily Polkowski’s reflections below for further clarifications.

Sanjiv

REDUCTION, DICHOTOMY, DISPARATE, ELEMENT, CONSTRUCT, RELATION, REALIZE

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 4/18/2023 14:19:40
Subject: exploring differences in culture: doing the final in MGT448 (Part 1)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

For the Final in MGT448:

International Dimensions of Business 

you are 

exploring differences 

in thinking and social action

 

that exist between yourself and people doing business in 3 different cultures:

You are witnessing them on a moving screen of images, contexts, frames, scenes, shots, happenings, interactions, conversations. (please google Movement Image and Deleuze).

You are bringing an ethnomethodological perspective (please google) to your exploration of differences:

Difference Between Yourself

and people in: 

1. Kinky Boots

2. Outsourced

3. Iron and Silk

What is Culture:

Geert Hofstede (please google) defines culture as "the collective programming of the mind which distinguishes the members of one human group from another." 

Hofstede argues that we carry “mental programs” (images and word-structures) which are developed in the family in early childhood and reinforced in schools and organizations, and that these mental programs contain a component of one's culture. 

Mental programs are most clearly expressed in different values (words) that predominate among people from different cultures. 

Cultures are shared systems of symbols and meanings. Culture is symbolically coded and therefore, can be taught from one person to another. 

Your values are expressed whenever you select words to form a symbolic system (please google).

Values are historically selected words. 

Our selections in the fishbowl (after sifting, sorting, and substituting) words says everything about our values.

"Culture consists in patterned was of thinking, feeling and reacting, acquired and transmitted mainly by symbols, constituting the distinctive achievements of human groups, including their embodiments in artifacts; the essential core of culture consists of traditional (i.e. historically derived and selected) ideas and especially their attached values.” (please google Kluckhohn, 1951)

Question 1:

Mental program can be found at the universal, the collective, and individual level. 

Please identify instances (words spoken) in the 3 films, one for each of the three levels of mental programs.

Thank you. More questions will follow. Please watch the films first and copy the words spoken. Please see Des Hatika’s posting below.

Sanjiv

MENTAL, PROGRAM, UNIVERSAL, COLLECTIVE, INDIVIDUAL, VALUES, SYMBOLIC, CODE

c: MGT 345

post by deshatika » Mon Apr 17, 2023 4:47 pm

Active Listening

"Active Listener"- Active listening goes beyond passive hearing, as it involves understanding the meaning and intent behind the words spoken by another person. It requires active participation in the communication process, making it a vital communication skill. Active listening keeps you engaged in a positive manner with your conversation partner, making them feel heard and valued. It forms the basis of successful conversations in any setting, such as work, home, or social interactions. When practicing active listening, you are fully present and immersed in the speaker's words and their underlying significance.

Date: 3/31/2023 14:33:28
Subject: cultivate attitude, position, or posture
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

You can enter the fishbowl anytime in the semester and complete the course. There is no prejudicial assessment. You are assessed on your learning activity and creative action in the fishbowl. 

However, if you are aiming for an A in the course, you have to start with the first letter and move upwards. 

Plus, your work must be posted in the fishbowl because it is a shared space. 

Your work is perceived as a contribution. It is what you are bringing to the table. It is a pot-luck feast (metaphor, symbol, word-image). It is overwhelming! But you eat only as much as you can digest.

"You are not alone with the Instructor! You are not an Elephant sitting on a tiny stool and the fishbowl is not a Circus tent.” “The fishbowl is more akin to a Carnival!” 

“These are all metaphors, symbols, word-images.” 

“We deconstruct each, in order to understand our actions, behaviors and decisions, and reconstruct them to create something new.”

 "I am not afraid," she declared, "because in a Carnival, I can get lost.”

“You’re stalking me again,” I replied.

Four things in the fishbowl: Vocabulary, Google Searches, Deconstructions and Exercises.

The attitude you choose at any moment predetermines the quality and success of your endeavor. 

Cultivate attitude. 

Be purposeful and conscious in choosing the appropriate attitude for each and every occasion. Attitude, like attention, is one of the few things in life that one can control and be responsible for.

It is attitude, position or posture. Roughly translated, it means to behave in a certain way. The words describe a conscious or unconscious physical and mental posture (attitude, position) in relation to other people, surrounding or situations.

Whenever you cultivate the right attitude or position in the fishbowl, you can significantly contribute to the outcome of your posting.

In the fishbowl, we are not so much expressing feelings, but rather ’showing attitudes.’ Attitude is the basic posture that informs any particular exchange between us and conveys specific attitudes toward others.

Please see Phillip Esposito’s attitude, position and posture in his deconstructions below.

Sanjiv

CULTIVATE, ATTITUDE, POSITION, POSTURE

Dissected : “words, images and ideas are not neutral reflections of reality.”

In my view, words images, and ideas are not neutral reflections of reality because we are all shaped by our own unique perspectives and biases. ------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 3/28/2023 12:42:01
Subject: Beautiful People (MGT 345)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? Referring to the film 'Beautiful People,' in MGT345: Business and Society.

The film is a montage of different frames; a movement of images within each frame, and whenever they intersect, new alignments are formed.

What is depicted (my interpretation and opinion) in the film is a new 'form of society’ known as The Network Society. 

Similar to your experience of Society in a fishbowl, the network society has come about by a number of major social, technological, economic and cultural transformations.

We live in confusing times, as is often the case in periods of historical transition between different 'forms of society.' 

This is because the intellectual categories (structures of words; mental constructs; symbolic structures) that we use to understand what happens around us were coined in different circumstances, and we can hardly grasp what is new by referring to the past, as we see time and again in the film.

The urgency for a new approach to understanding the kind of economy, culture, and society in which we live is heightened by the humungous crises and conflicts that we are facing today.

Please see Emma Grant's postings in the fishbowl about the film Beautiful People.

Coming up:

1. we will define and theoretically understand the film Beautiful People as a Network Society.

2. we will identify four skills necessary to succeed doing business in a Network Society.

3. The Final 10 steps to realize and show case the above skills.

"The fishbowl is an assemblage of beautiful people," she noticed.

"Assemblage is one of my favorite words," he replied.

Sanjiv

What lies ahead...

Beautiful People Movie

1. Scene: in the hospital, the Mrs. Hadzibegovic (MH) is desperately trying to get the attention of Dr. Mouldy (DM) while he is on the phone with his wife about his failing marriage.

DM: You should be in your room

MH: please, please (while tugging his arm)

DM drops the phone and follows MH into her room

DM: Come on, tell me about it. Sit down. Now what's wrong? Hmm?

MH: Dr. Mouldy, please. No baby. No baby

DM: It's alright, it's alright. Young mothers are often very frightened and very anxious when it comes to delivery and that's natural, it's quite natural

MH: no natural

DM: you're a young, healthy woman. I promise you everything will be fine - really

MH: please Dr. Mouldy, no baby. please

DM: Oh, um, now... now your baby sleep. sleep. ummmm, in your belly, yes? Umm, tomorrow baby out and everybody, everybody, everybody happy.

MH: no, no everybody happy Dr. Mouldy

DM: alright, ummm well i'm going to get some medicine to help you feel better, I promise it won't hurt the baby. you just stay here, yes? stay here, everything will be fine. Don't worry, stay here. Good girl.

2. Deconstructing sentences and adding felt experiences

"please, please"

This woman is in a strange country, scared, and alone dealing with the idea of having a baby in such a scary and tumultuous time in her life (and her whole world). It is later discovered that her baby is the result of a rape and she feel that her baby is her enemy.

It can be challenging to be stuck in a situation you feel there is no way out of. This storyline reminds me so much of stories of young women who feel trapped by motherhood and the ups and downs that come along with it. Often, we feel thrust into new situation we are not quite ready for (although, fortunately not quite as extreme as this one) and we must use our morals, background, feelings, and experiences to guide us forward, to find a way through it all, and to continue on with our lives. We learn and grow and accept until we are able to get through it, just like this young woman did.

"tomorrow baby out and everybody, everybody, everybody happy"

Dr. Mouldy quite literally has no idea what to say to this woman to help her feel better - the language barrier is getting the best of both of them and despite the desire for connection, there is not much that is able to be said. This reminded me of an experience I had on a recent trip to Guatemala. I was there to visit some people that I know but along my journey, met a lot of people who were in need of help, who felt stuck or trapped in their situations. I was sitting at a dinner table with one of them and we were working to try and communicate. He shared with me that he tried to go to America but was caught and sent back and that he just thought if he could get there, get through it, he would be happy. He went on to share, through some broken spanish, that he learned to be happy in Guatemala but it was not an easy journey. This scene reminded me of that because Dr. Moudly is so confident that this woman will be happy once the baby is here when in reality she will only begin to find happiness when she starts to adapt and accept the reality that she has now been thrust into.

"stay here, everything will be fine. Don't worry, stay here."

Dr. Mouldy can barely communicate with this woman through her broken English yet still finds the desire to console here and tell her everything will be fine. This is often what we do, tell ourselves and others it will be okay until it becomes okay again. I can think of countless examples in my life of a similar situation where I maybe didn't feel okay in the moment, couldn't see how something was going to play out or work out, but was told it was going to be okay and not to worry. I was guided by people more confident than me until I grew in the confidence myself and was able to see that really everything will be okay.

Post by maryamghazi » Sun Mar 12, 2023 7:53 pm

conjuring and generating

“Vocabulary is fundamental and unique to each and every human being.”

Everyone uses vocabulary in their own way and to their own advantage. When we speak, we use words based on our previous knowledge and experience and often mean it in a certain way. But our audience understands it based on their knowledge and experience and often understands our words in a different manner than we meant.

post by maryamghazi » Sat Mar 25, 2023 5:26 pm

the 'immaterial'

“What is felt in the heart (experience) is difficult to express in words.”

Our everyday emotions, thoughts, and experiences can be very complex and difficult to convey in words alone. This is because experiences are subjective and unique to each individual, and language often falls short in accurately capturing and expressing those experiences.

 post by maryamghazi » Sat Mar 25, 2023 5:26 pm

We experiment with our thoughts in the fishbowl by taking ideas from the letters and each other to create new ideas. We form new ways of thinking and understanding our surroundings, especially everything in the fishbowl.

Going away refers to taking a break or stepping back from a situation or environment, in our case it is the Fishbowl we stepped away from for a week. The game we play in the fishbowl consists of the words and images we use to share our ideas and experiences. Selecting and using specific words and images in the fishbowl help us fully share and understand and create our reality.

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. Hence forth, everything we talk about is explaining the Final. The goal is to have a stress-free closure.

You must get the movies (Kinky Boots for 448 and Beautiful People for 345) out of the way this weekend, because my letters will make better sense.

Please see Grace Stellato’s reflections below. She is working on the surface of complex concepts.

The bottom line is that words, images, and ideas are the means through which we socially make our reality.

We are doing so in the fishbowl.

We are socially making a reality with our selected words, images and ideas.

“Just a lot of individuals developing theories," she complained.

We have established processes and practices, where language and action are intertwined in a “game" of sorting, sifting, selecting, and substituting. 

By socially playing our game in a fishbowl, we understand and experience our reality. 

We are shaping our world in the fishbowl through the constructs (forms of words), actions (choices), and processes (methods) embedded in the game.

We are focusing on language (words) as a means of revealing the role of words (images and metaphors) in the 'social construction' (please google) of reality.

Social constructionism is a theory of knowledge that holds that characteristics typically thought to be immutable and solely biological—such as gender, race, class, ability, and sexuality—are products of human definition and interpretation shaped by cultural and historical contexts. Examples of social constructs include race, gender, nationality, childhood, madness, age, intelligence, and beauty. 

Sanjiv

Deconstruction of "Language Game 1" letter:

"Language and reality are interwoven. The skill being developed in the fishbowl is to create a kind of “language game” (please google Wittgenstein and Language Game) through which we engage, understand and experience our reality in a fishbowl. We are shaping our world through the constructs, actions, and processes already embedded in our game.. We are living our language as part of a broader activity or “form of life.” Or as Heidegger has put it, “language speaks us as much as we speak language.” Please see the next letter Language Game (2)."

The quote I chose from this letter is interesting to me because of the idea of language and reality being intertwined together. Our language makes up our reality because it shows how our perspectives are put into the world in order to communicate with others and how we feed off each others languages. This is an interesting concept because just like in the fishbowl, our understanding and experience becomes our reality. Our language comes from our experiences and understandings and becomes our reality. Our individual worlds are shaped through how our actions progress through our changing perspectives and realities. We are living through our languages and sharing them to the people around us whose experiences change because of it. Our language is a broader form of our lives and changes the more experiences we receive. As much as we speak our languages, languages speak to us.

Deconstruction for "Language Game (2)" letter:

"In the fishbowl, we subscribe to this newer view or perspective. It can be found in the works of the later Wittgenstein (1958) and thinkers like Derrida, Gadamer and Rorty. They all emphasize (and this is important to understand) that there are no sharp distinctions between subjective and objective worlds and that language and reality are part of an integrated life-world, in and through which our realities in fishbowls are coproduced."

In the quote above from this letter, I personally found it interesting how its emphasized that there are no sharp distinctions between subjective and objective worlds. After googling "subjective and objective worlds", I found that subjective is referred to personal perspectives and preferences on the world, and what we observe. IN contrast, objective is referred to as not being influenced by or based on personal viewpoints. But in this quote, it is said that they is no sharp distinction between the two worlds. I believe this is because though an objective world is not solely from a persons perspective, it is still an observation that we as people have created over time through our own experiences and perceptions. The two collide in a way where our perspectives have created the observations in our worlds. Also, the quote says how language and reality are part of an integrated life-world, meaning that our different languages and realities are apart of our world as a whole and makes up everything in our perception.

Reducing Anxiety by Jumping in:

If you haven’t jumped in yet, the best way is to start at the beginning. 

With the first letter, and with every letter thereafter, forge your own trajectory of thoughts and ideas. And go as far as you can. The rest can be accomplished any time in the future. The sequence of letters and the learning is set up like that. We are trying to be a society and establish a culture. 

Most of our learning in the fishbowl is copying, selecting and reconstructing. Nothing difficult nor complicated. It is repeating and tweaking and taking further, whenever you dare. Nothing you cannot do. Please see Grace Stellato’s postings below.

But you are forced to put time aside and focus on words. 

Inescapably, you become aware of the Self, a Being in context, because you are making a selection and exercising a choice that will have consequences down the written line.

We need evidence in a fishbowl that you exist as a human, and you are not a robot. 

We are human whenever we are vulnerable.

We have been following a process and have set up a practice in the fishbowl.
