Post by gracestellato » Tue Mar 07, 2023 7:50 pm

Deconstruction for "post-structuralism":

"Post structuralism evolved in the late 1960s as a critique of structuralist theory. The basis of post structuralist theories lies in the belief of the inadequacy of language. Jacques Derrida's theory of difference proposed that meaning is inherently unstable due to the play of signs within language.” (wiki)

This quote from wiki was interesting to me because prior to reading this letter, I was not aware of post-structuralism. After reading this quote, to me post-structuralism is how through language, we can communicate on a far more redefined level and has made a turn from the structuralist theory. Also, meanings of different words or phrases are unstable because of how differently signs of language are interpreted amongst different groups of people. This can depend on a number of factors such as culture, language, or different experiences people have. The perspectives we have also play into how we view meanings on language and how they differ amongst others. Post-structuralism challenged the tenets of structuralism, which previously held over interpretation of language and texts.

Deconstruction for "Exercise: View Japanese Story; and, Class Time" letter:

"When we post in the Fishbowl, we are not rewriting what is already written in the letters. Instead, we are note-making or processing the words into our own understanding. There is a greater level of understanding and comprehension when text is stripped down, analyzed, and rephrased in one’s own words. Doing so creates effects -- produces a change in one’s knowledge in order to expand and strengthen their mind." (Winifred Mylan)

When deconstructing this letter, this quote stuck with me because I agree with the writer that I am note-making and processing the words from the letters into my own understanding of them and adding my own perspective into the texts. I believe when I read different words in texts, I am understanding and comprehending them in different ways from others. To me, writing these words is a creation of mine from the effects my brain gets from reading them. In order to expand my knowledge, I need to produce changes of my knowledge in order to understand words and texts in new and different ways. This way, I am learning different ways these words can effect each other and create new meanings.

Capturing our thoughts and writing them down from what we feel in the moment is not captured by artificial intelligence. Artificial intelligence involves the development of computer systems. "Developing an abstract is to develop one’s own understanding of the subject matter."

It is important to understand the reason for writing something. In all our papers we write, we think about why we write them. Date: 3/21/2023 11:12:39
Subject: authorship of the abstract
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

THE HUMAN AND ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE CONUNDRUM: WHOSE INTELLIGENCE IS IT ANYWAYS

S. Dugal1, S. Brown1, S. Komiega1, G. Costa1, D. Demarino1, E. Grant1, M. Ghazi1, T. Huff1, S. Lindeland1, W. Mylan1, J. Pateuk1, A. Rue1, E. Polkowski1, P. Amirault1, A.. Beaumier1, R. Bromm1, T. Chan1, E. Dyer1, D. Hatika1, H. Maddox1, P. Esposito1, J. Soucier1, R. Singh2, A. Lee1, E. Sillat1, C. Rodriguez1, C. Somyk1, S. Singh3, M. Troiano4, C. Evers1, J. Ferreira1, I. Ozuna1, E. Cook1, J. Costello1, G. Stellato1, M. Lessard1, C. Sapienza1, R. Berretta1, L. Belka1

1 University of Rhode Island (UNITED STATES)

2 RLDA Architecture, Design Research Studio (INDIA)

3 SavvyMatters.com (UNITED STATES)

4 ClearHead Studio (UNITED STATES)

sanjivdugal@uri.edu, samantha-brown@uri.edu, sean_komiega@uri.edu, gianna_costa@uri.edu, demarino@uri.edu, egrant19@uri.edu, maryam_ghazi@uri.edu, trenthuff@uri.edu, slindeland@uri.edu, winifred_mylan@uri.edu, john_pateuk@uri.edu, ashleyrue@uri.edu, emily_polkowski@uri.edu, peyton_amirault@uri.edu, beaumiera@uri.edu, ryan_bromm@uri.edu, tiffany_chan@uri.edu, emdyer@uri.edu, dhatika@uri.edu, harrisonmaddox@uri.edu, phil-esposito77@uri.edu, jdsoucier@uri.edu, rahoulsingh@gmail.com, amy_lee9@uri.edu, ethan_sillat@uri.edu, crodriguez2020@uri.edu, christian_somyk@uri.edu, shivsingh@gmail.com, michael.troiano1@verizon.net, christian_evers@uri.edu, jeffferreira789@uri.edu, ivy_ozuna@uri.edu, emily_cook@uri.edu, joshua_costello@uri.edu, gracestellato@uri.edu, mlessard@uri.edu, collsapi@uri.edu, richard_beretta@uri.edu, lilybelka@uri.edu

Discipline: Business Adm.& Mgmt. / Business Studies

Type of presentation: VIRTUAL

Introduction

98 participants are responding to text on a digital platform, aka, the fishbowl. Collectively and individually, we are developing ‘general intelligence action’ (1) in order to perceive and infer information, and to retain it as knowledge applicable towards adaptive behaviors within any context. Intelligence is defined as the capacity for abstraction, understanding, self-awareness, learning, emotional knowledge, creativity, and critical thinking.

Purpose

To present intelligent action (decisions taken) resulting in appropriate phenomena (ideas) stemming from the fishbowl's system of physical symbols.

'Physical symbols' are letters, digits, or other discrete elements that represent and manipulate information. Whereas, like the fishbowl, a 'system' is a pattern of rules that manipulate symbols for the performance of various tasks.

Stated formally, “a physical symbol system has the necessary and sufficient means for general intelligence action” (1).

Method

Participants construct word-structures after sorting, sifting, selecting and substituting words in response to symbols from the environment. The ‘physical symbol system’ is a formal system of words that takes physical, material forms, combines them into structures and systemically manipulating them, produces new structures.

The physical symbol system of the fishbowl through which the participant’s attention is enacted and deliberately cultivated, is not intended as a linear, prescribed sequence but as an intermingling of the following four physical symbols:

a. Framing (selecting vocabulary, words, meaning, concepts)

b. Advocating (deconstructing, theorizing, breaking down and building up)

c. Illustrating (sharing felt-experiences, describing past feelings)

d. Inquiring (self-reflexivity; raising questions: how so and why so)

The implication is that our collective intelligence, along with its interrelated structures, is determined by the fishbowl system’s physical symbols 'abcd' above. Any system (living-machine, like the fishbowl, or human being), that has the ability to manipulate these structures fulfills the necessary and sufficient condition for ‘general intelligence action.’

Feeling Human

Soft computing is a set of techniques, including genetic algorithms, fuzzy logic and neural networks, that are tolerant of imprecision, uncertainty, partial truth and approximation. While human information processing is easy to explain, nevertheless, human subjective experience is difficult. Working in the fishbowl is easier when its just work, like doing vocabulary. However, it is much harder when the person actually cares and shares a felt-experience in the moment.

Conclusion

Human expertise depends on unconscious instinct rather than conscious symbol manipulation, and on having a "feel" for the situation,rather than explicit symbolic knowledge (see Hubert Dreyfus). Intuition matters more than data because it allows for spontaneity, impulse, instinct and courage. Ideas lead to a result but 'ideals' result in what makes us human. For instance, in the fishbowl, a cardinal principle is doing right matters more than being right.

Immersed in the language of symbolic interactionism, phenomenology, ethnomethodology and reflexivity, our focus of interest is human agency and individual lived experience. Our approach is to detect feelings and relate them to the structures of our words.

Reference

(1) Newell, A. (1980). Physical symbol systems. Cognitive Science, 4, 135-183.

Keywords: Artificial Intelligence, Physical Symbol Systems, General Intelligence Action.

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well.

We could submit a 3,500 word Abstract to the EDULEARN23 Conference (please google) or any other Conference for that matter, regarding Artificial Intelligence as a metaphor for your practices and processes in the fishbowl. 

For previous Undergraduate Abstracts on Research in the Fishbowl, please visit: https://the-fishbowl.com/ 

II.

Developing thoughts for the Abstract upon scrolling and screening your fishbowls...please see Maddeline Lessard’s postings below.

We declare how our process of posting in the fishbowl is a microcosm of Artificial Intelligence. The fishbowl’s four pillars of postings encapsulates in miniature, and depicts the characteristic qualities and features of something much larger; Artificial Intelligence (please google the term). 

In other words, we are presenting the fishbowl as the epitome of the universe; ours is a correspondence between microcosm and macrocosm; the particular and the general, the individual and the universal.

However, we make the point (evidenced by our postings) that the writing, living and being through the body, is experienced in the moment of posting in the fishbowl, and this cannot be captured by AI. We consider the body central in the subjective experience: the felt-experience.

"It really boils down to the act of sorting, sifting, selecting and substituting," she announced. "And don’t forget sharing," I countered.

We make the distinction between Being (in the fishbowl) and Having (it all in Artificial Intelligence). 

We conclude by suggesting changing the way we think about the individual, technology and the relationship between them. We do this by defining “Individuation” (the manner in which one is different) and citing Gilbert Simondon’s work (please google).

“Cool," she said, uncharacteristically.

Sanjiv

Once you’ve understood where, how, why, what holds your attention, you can manipulate it. Mastering attentional practices is possible. Shifting the importance and hooking feeling something/ someone has is possible. You just need to pay attention to your attention. I want to accomplish such. I think the ability to deploy your own attention easily is the most important tactic one could have.

Plane of immanence

How we think about our world and how we live in it are entwined.

The world is made up of perception, a mental impression. A common regard has been shared and accepted by all of us. We’ve accepted words to stand for feelings, physical and mental structures, concepts. You manifest your world. Your thoughts, emotions, words, actions, meanings, all design your world. The inner is always reflected in the outer. How you live is the surface to the deeper concepts.

In our Fishbowl we see how our thoughts are changing. We remove this ability when we reply separately. Replying separately alienates our words.

Our reality is a reading relationship in a visual culture.

Within our fishbowl we read and write. That is our relationship (tie) to each other and the connection between our interpretations. This is also true outside of the fishbowl. Your reality only circles around what you ‘read’. What you pay attention to, what you think about, what you interpret, analyze, and see. Your reality has nothing that your brain isn’t connected to (isn’t reading into).

Hi Everyone,

How are you?

In the fishbowl, 

each return over the same ground, 

represents 

layers of change: 

in you, 

in your text, and 

in the environment. 

Even what appears to be a repetition is often a return at the next level of a spiral of understanding...

Like flipping through or scrolling images in a favorite magazine. It’s all in the head, she proclaimed. Ephemeral and ethereal, fleeting and in formation...

Infusing felt-experiences and empowering your text: 

PLease see Trent Huff’s posting below. It is an excellent example of constructing and developing theory. 

Next step, as a pragmatist, if you select one sentence from your constructed theory and expand it (take it further) to describe an ‘episode' from a past experience, plus describe how you felt at that time, you empower your text by making possible connections among your audience. It is one’s perceived difference (brought to light by the effect of your felt-experience) that makes a difference to the social group, and makes perceptual connections possible. 

Recalling something makes it possible to experience it again, to discover another 'way of seeing' in ones own skin. 

For instance, one’s visions during childhood can be treasured as alternative ways of seeing the world. 

Perceptions and experiences from the past pervade the present; they are peripherally visible to us. That is the purpose of the exercise on the meaning of your name and whether you relate to it. 

The felt-experience is the process of individuation, and it is what ultimately counts in a digital environment. Please google Gilbert Simondon and Individuation. More coming up.

In L'individuation psychique et collective, Gilbert Simondon developed a theory of individual and collective individuation in which the individual subject is considered as an effect of individuation rather than a cause. Thus, the individual atom is replaced by a never-ending ontological process of individuation.

Sanjiv

Re: Plane of Immanence (Deconstructing Letters)

post by TrentHuff » Mon Feb 27, 2023 4:09 pm

Deconstructing Letters - "Lessons from Japanese story"

"Whenever different culturally and historically determined structures intersect, it must be remembered that in such encounters, participants come with pre-narratives."

All people have values and perspectives that are formed as a result of their experiences and upbringing. Many large groups of people create a culture where they share similar beliefs and perspectives that affect how they all think about other people. Across the world, these cultures can vary largely, creating many different perspectives about the same concept. The culture that someone is brought up in is what they consider to be normal, and they may see other cultures as outsiders. In the modern world, it is not rare for these different culture to meet or cross paths for various reasons. When these people come together, they have narratives and perspectives on each other prior to actually meeting. These predetermined thoughts may or may not be true, but they will certainly have an impact on how the people of different cultures think about and communicate with each other.

Date: 2/27/2023 14:59:43
Subject: Uncertainty Avoidance by Focusing on Words
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? It is difficult to focus under conditions of uncertain outcomes, particularly if one’s culture is High on Hofstede’s score of Uncertainty Avoidance (please google). 

Hofstede defines uncertainty avoidance as the lack of tolerance for ambiguity and the need for formal rules. This dimension measures the extent to which people in a society feel threatened by and try to avoid ambiguous situations. They may do this by establishing more formal rules, rejecting deviant ideas and behavior, and accepting the possibility of absolute truths and the attainment of unchallengeable expertise.

Cultures in other parts of the globe may have higher tolerance for ambiguity and uncertainty. 

These are high/low dimensions. 

"Put two words together, and you got yourself a dimension, she said. 

What dimension are you sliding on today?"

What we acquire from a culture is a set of labels (words with meanings), whose theoretical character (underlying dimension) is invisible to us, until one is jolted by a detail. 

Our experience is structured in advance by cultural stereo-types and idealizations, blurred by images: caricatures and diagrams from childhood.

We are increasingly intersecting and interacting across different symbolic (word-image-meaning) systems (structures) on our (mental) screens. 

II.

"Chaos and Confusion reigns, she laughed. You got to focus. To do so, you have to lose yourself in a fishbowl. Looking at yourself looking at yourself."

What do you mean?

You are trying to understand and remember what you saw, and at the same time, you are also trying to establish an interpretation appropriate to the situation. Out of the tension of this multiplicity of ‘vision' comes the possibility for insight.

III.

All I really wanted to say is that your fishbowl is a stream of stories and reflections strung together to suggest a style of learning from experience. 

Please see Jake Soucier’s reflections below.

Wherever a story comes from, whether it is a familiar myth or a private memory, retelling exemplifies the making of a connection from one pattern to another: a potential translation in which narrative becomes parable and the once upon a time comes to stand for some renascent truth. This approach applies to all the incidents of every day life: the phrase in the newspaper; the endearing or infuriating game of a toddler; the misunderstanding at the office. Our species thinks in metaphors and learns through stories.

Sanjiv

STYLE, MYTH, EXEMPLIFY, NARRATIVE, PARABLE, STORY, RENASCENT, TRUTH

"I'm not your … girlfriend." - Spoken by Sandy to Hiromitsu.

Clearly Sandy does not like how she is being treated and does not want to be spoken to like that which is the reason why she is frustrated and says these things.

"I can't take my eyes off you." - Spoken by Hiromitsu to Sandy.

Deconstruction: This sentence shows Hiromitsu's fascination with Sandy and his desire to connect with her on a deeper level.

Felt-experience infusion: This sentence reminds me of a time when my friend felt strong connection with someone who they had just met. He could not stop thinking/talking about the individual and wanted to see if things would workout with her. However, he was hesitant to express his feelings in fear of rejection but also the loss of a close friend.

"I'm sorry. I thought you were someone else." - Spoken by Hiromitsu to the woman in the hotel lobby.

Deconstruction: This sentence shows Hiromitsu's mistake in thinking that the woman was Sandy, and his embarrassment of what he just did. Saying hi to a random stranger can be awkward and most of the time requires an apology.

Felt-experience infusion: This sentence reminds me of a time when I mistook someone for a friend and approached them, only to realize that they were a stranger. I felt embarrassed and apologized profusely, and the stranger was kind and understanding, but it still felt awkward for making the mistake.

Date: 2/26/2023 16:44:02
Subject: lessons from Japanese Story
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well in these troubling times.

Lessons from Japanese Story

1. Japanese Story is a “story" of connecting across different symbolic systems; across different word-structures. 

Whenever different culturally and historically determined structures intersect, it must be remembered that in such encounters, participants come with pre-narratives.

Please google David Boje and Ante-narrative. 

Sandy’s ante-narrative is of being perceived a “Geisha” instead of a “Geologist”. 

Her frustration with her male colleagues' perceptual structures and Hiromitsu’s arrival with his own foreign perceptual structures, presses all the wrong buttons, and we have a “situation” on our hands.

The film has many lessons to think about, but one thing is clear, if Sandy and Hiro are unable to connect across their “structures" of words, symbols, perceptions and images, they will not come out alive. They are in dire straits and they had better be quick learners. I believe, all said and done, they did very well for themselves. They broke their pre-conceived structures, and forged a friendship, one word at a time...but fate had something else in store for them.

Bottom line: Sandy and Hiromitsu had to learn to show greater concern for the "relational character of the production of meaning." As a business student, I trust you are taking note. A knowledge worker in a knowledge economy, produces meaning by creating social capital (please google Pierre Bourdieu and Cultural Capital).

Things to be aware of:

Whenever different word-structures (symbolic systems) intersect, the chances of not ‘bringing the contract home" can be costly. Please think of Sandy and Hiromitsu’s encounter, right from the start.

Opening paragraph in Lisa Hoecklin’s “Managing Cultural Differences” (please google):

“People are increasingly having to interact, manage, negotiate and compromise with people from other cultures. The potential for management frustration, costly misunderstandings and even business failures increases significantly when dealing with people whose value, beliefs, customs and first language are different from your own. However, when understood and successfullly managed, differences in culture can lead to innovative business practices and sustainable sources of competititve advantage."

Words have images and meanings attached and these are culturally and historically determined, for example “geisha” and “geologist.” 

Please see Samantha Brown’s postings below. A clear example of how meaning is created relationally whenever we share our subjective images attached to the words we selected. This action creates your competitive advantage.

Sanjiv

SYMBOLIC, PERCEPTUAL, SYSTEM, RELATIONAL, INTERSECT, SITUATION, CONNECT

Meaning of a Name

Samantha has many different meanings, with many of them being religious due to it being a feminine version of Samuel. The religious version has a few different meanings, like "listener of God" or "in the name of God". Secular definitions are "listener"/"listens well" and "flower"/"blossom" as it stems from Aramaic word for listen. My parents named me Samantha after the main character in Bewitched.

Listener: someone who listens

Listen: to give attention to someone or something in order to hear him, her, or it

I think that my name only coincides with half of my personality. I have a talkative side but I also have a quiet side. My quiet side is a good listener and can go hours without talking and just listening. I'm good at identifying things by sound, like which of my family members car is running, which guinea pig is squeeking, or which cat is meowing. These are all subtle differences that not everyone would pick up on. I also enjoy listening to the sounds of my life and music. So while the meaning of my name only coincides with half of my personality, I do believe that it is a good fit for me.

Post by samanthabrown » Sat Feb 25, 2023 8:33 pm

Japanese Story

"There is nothing sick about death. It's part of life."

-Deconstruction: This is so heavy to start with. Starting something with such heaviness and weight only suggests bad things and creates expectations that we may feel we need to live up to. Or we will act with this subconsciously guiding us. We will use it to unknowingly create unrealistic standards for ourselves. How do we make our own path when we feel like it is decided for us? Can we break out of the path that either we created or was created for us? We love certainty but we fall victim to it restraining us. We need to take the time for deep thought and deep reflection. This is the way that we will stay innovative and creative. Certainty kills creativity.

-Infuse with felt experience: I have experienced this many times in my life. I feel frustrated when others make judgements about me or set a standard for me. I've always had high expectations set for me and I have always achieved them or pushed myself as hard as I could to achieve them. Others making judgements about me feels like it's setting an expectation. I want to be the one that follows my own path and makes my own expectations. I was always an outsider in elementary school, bullied for being a weird kid. Others made judgements about me and set expectations for me. They decided my path for me and I didn't like that. So I broke out of that and decided to write my own narrative about myself. Of course, I didn't know thats what I was doing at that time, but I see that now. I strive to not follow the path that is written for me, I strive to forge my own path. Of course, I'm not perfect about it, but I feel like having the experiences that I have had has made this a part of me. It's become a part of my reality and a guiding principle in my life.

---

"I read the book. I begin to understand. Then, I am possessed, like a man who is very strong."

-Deconstruct: True understanding is only created through putting in the effort. We always have to frame ourselves as a learner. Go into every situation willing and wanting to learn. This gives us a better understanding of everything. The key is preparing ourselves with the tools that are essential and the tools that will give us the ability to always find the meaning and the tools that will help us produce thoughts. These tools and the associated knowledge make us feel confident and give us the ability to be prepared for any situation.

-Infuse: Walking into things blindly with no knowledge of what's going to happen is one of the scariest things to me. If the world ran my way, everything ever would be planned and prepared for. It's not necessarily wanting certainty, it's wanting to be prepared. I had a class that had frequent random presentations. There was no way to be perfectly prepared for that situation. That horrified me. How was I supposed to maintain my personal presentation standard? How was I supposed to not make a fool out of myself? The solution wasn't predicting the future to know exactly what I would present on or when I would be asked to present. The key was getting the tools to be properly prepared. To know the vocabulary, so I would be pulling from the correct word pool and have the necessary background knowledge to generate ideas. Another key was knowing current events because it helped to further my understanding of vocabulary and help me have real-world examples. It also helped me develop the correct frame of reference. Once I had the tools, I was able to be confident in that class.

---

"I have heavy obligations and I must get through it."

-Deconstruct: Everyone's life has necessary difficulties. It's never just simple and easy. A lot of the time, it's difficult or it's complicated. But we persist. We continue. We must determine what motivates us and hold them close. Sometimes we have to hold onto what we find important and weather the storm. It will be an experience that will reshape our future mindset and change our future frame of reference. It will likely change the meaning of words, feelings, and objects for us. We get through them by preparing ourselves, using the tools that we have, and focusing on what's important. We make our reality and while it may be difficult or near impossible, we can adjust our obligations to make them work for ourselves.

-Infuse: I could name thousands of difficult obligations or necessary difficulties within my life, as could anyone else. In sophomore year, I was working a lot at a miserable job with a mean boss, both during the week and for most of the weekend while juggling classes. I know this is a familiar struggle to most other college students. It was really draining and felt like a constant struggle. I never felt like I could get ahead. I weathered through that difficult period by taking putting some time aside for what was important to me and I know that that job and that boss have affected my frame of reference and my mindset. I had to use my tools like planning and mindfulness to make it through that situation. I'm glad I did because I gained experience and I ended up getting a better job without an awful boss.

Date: 2/23/2023 15:56:18
Subject: Language Game (2)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? I wanted to bring your attention to the vocabulary (meaning of words), images and ideas posted by Caitlyn Rodriguez below.

An earlier view, expressed in Wittgenstein’s (1922) “picture theory” of language, was that reality gives us language: that Caitlyn's words, images, and ideas are reflections of the world “out there.”

The newer view reverses this, suggesting that words, images and ideas are not neutral reflections of reality. They are the means through which Caitlyn makes her reality. 

In the fishbowl, we subscribe to this newer view or perspective. It can be found in the works of the later Wittgenstein (1958) and thinkers like Derrida, Gadamer and Rorty. They all emphasize (and this is important to understand) that there are no sharp distinctions between subjective and objective worlds and that language and reality are part of an integrated life-world, in and through which our realities in fishbowls are coproduced.

Please view the postings below in this light. We have the potential to make and transform ourselves and our world through individual and collective postings that can “real-ize” new images, ideas and worldviews. In principle we are active agents in perceiving, constructing, and acting in the fishbowl.

Sanjiv

MOVEMENT- an act of changing physical location or position or of having this changed; a change or development.

COMPOSE- write or create (a work of art, especially music or poetry); (of elements) constitute or make up (a whole).

COMBINE- unite; merge.

PREROGATIVE- an exclusive or special right, power, or privilege.

Deconstructing Letters

“You are deconstructing a text (a sentence) and thereby developing your own voice”

By deconstructing text, you are putting it into your own words which allows you to have a better understanding of what the person is saying.

II. Playing a Language Game

Let’s consider Christian Evers posting above on the subject: Why Deconstruct a Text? 

Evers has constructed three categories

1. Vocab: meaning

2. Germinating Ideas

3. Images, and furthermore, 

Evers has deconstructed a common text for each of the categories.

How do we take the next step and develop a “voice"? A point of view? A new perspective.

It is a game in which language and action are interwoven, creating a “language game” through which we as participants engage, understand, and experience our reality, shaping our world through the constructs, actions, and processes embedded in the game itself. 

Playing the game:

1. I intuitively, and with practice, randomly select one word from each category and link these three words by taking them further into the dictionary,... until a felt-experience can easily be done.

2. Acting, Encounter, Attitude

3. I would take these three words further in the dictionary until I found words that were expressing my felt-experience, which is perpetually in a state of making; emerging and unfolding.

4. By reflecting and sharing our felt-experiences we are doing what is known as "experiential learning.” Please google. We learn from experience, but only in retrospect and through introspection and by sharing (doing reality checks). 

III. Language and Reality

Language and reality are interwoven. The skill being developed in the fishbowl is to create a kind of “language game” (please google Wittgenstein and Language Game) through which we engage, understand and experience our reality in a fishbowl. We are shaping our world through the constructs, actions, and processes already embedded in our game.. We are living our language as part of a broader activity or “form of life.” Or as Heidegger has put it, “language speaks us as much as we speak language.” Please see the next letter Language Game (2).

Bottom Line Tip: sorting, sifting, selecting, substituting.

Every body can do that!

Sanjiv

We venture (go forth with words) into a past experience (feeling), and this entails two activities: memory (image) and interpretation (text). It is what you recall (image and feeling) and how you interpret it (transform the meaning).

When reading a text in the fishbowl, it is the ‘mediation' (intervention, intercession) of images and feelings from the past, that our interpretation of the text being read, done in the present, transforms the original meaning. Letter One: Genesis of a Fishbowl

"The genesis of a Fishbowl occurs whenever we pose the question: how might one live?"

Despite each member of this class being a student in the College of Business at the University of Rhode Island, we each live each day differently. We have different priorities, thought patterns, behaviors, and ways of being yet when it is all put together, we are able to create a functioning society with a distinct culture. Together, we can draw on the ideals of one another to relate or refute, learn, and understand. That is, in essence, the genesis of this fishbowl - to take our own beings and work them together with that of our peers and to learn and grow from that cohesion.

Generating Text:

"Ethnography is a ‘method' for collecting data. Data is collected through ‘observation' which is then used to ‘draw' conclusions about ‘how' groups and individuals ‘function.'"

Data collection happens in every moment of everyday. We are constantly taking in our surroundings and the multitude of information being shared with us at any given moment. For example, right now I am reflecting on this letter while the sun is warmly shinning on my desk and I can hear the birds outside chirping. My keyboard is clattering with each letter and the pages in my planner are fluttering since I am now towards the middle of the book and it is too heavy for one side to remain down without help. All of these "data" points can be observed by me or an onlooker in this moment and can be used to draw a conclusion about how productive I may be in this moment. Am I reflective? Pensive? Distracted? All of these points factor into the quality of analysis I am putting into the fishbowl, into my society. It shapes the data collected about me by my group and those who review this analysis. This is a micro example of this vary vast topic explored in this quote and is important to refer back to as the fishbowl and the society within it adapts and grows and shapes.

Date: 2/6/2023 12:59:36
Subject: the notion of ontology
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? Take it slow, you’re dealing with a lot, but don’t lose the thread (metaphor) of your fishbowl. That is key.

You are all doing good work in the fishbowl. Such labor never goes unnoticed. The average grade looks like a B+. In class today, I will address the need for assurance (am I doing it right) regarding one’s work. The underlying questions are always: who are we, what are we doing, and why? Please see the attached image.

I.

How might I live (in the fishbowl, or anywhere else), is a question raised by Deleuze and, it is worth looking into from the point of Society and Culture, the subjects of our concern.

To answer such a question (how might I live?) from a Deleuzian perspective, we must (tip) grasp the notion of ‘ontology.' 

on·tol·o·gy 

noun

1. the branch of metaphysics dealing with the nature of being. 

2. a set of concepts and categories (words) in a subject area or domain (like the fishbowl) that shows their properties and the relations between them.

The ontology in the fishbowl is visible and shows the predominance of ’selection’ and ‘difference.’ Freedom and Democracy are the guiding principles. By seeing ‘difference' between our ‘selections,' we discover our ‘possibilities'; we probe what it means to be ‘us' and what our difference is capable of achieving. 

II.

Our reality is a reading relationship in a visual culture. We are 'reading-into’ text (diagnostic reading) and thereby writing our organizational life (society and culture).

We are an ‘interpretive community’ (please google Stanley Fish; he is from RI)) and we are following an ‘interpretive strategy’.

We are using images and metaphors (all words) to engage in a continuous construction and deconstruction of meaning in our encounters with everyday reality (made up of words).

The fishbowl’s organizational reality is a “living text” that is simultaneously “written” and “read.”

III.

We are showing (through our selection of words) how traditional concepts (archaic words) of organizations can be radically transformed through imaginative processes (innovative use of words) whereby new images and metaphors (represented by words) are used to create evocative (words) and energizing patterns (made by words) of shared meaning ( that are words).

We are unleashing our powers of creative thought, interpretation, and insight to broaden the possibilities for creative action.

IV.

In terms of specific practice in the fishbowl, our visible processes build on three key principles:

1. the interconnection between “reading” words and “writing” words.

2. how images (words) can be used as “mirrors” and “windows.”

3. practice as personal empowerment.

Please see Des Hatika’s excellent notes below. Taking and making notes is done to get our own understanding right, never mind what another Genius said or did. One’s understanding of anything is an ongoing process. I return to Deleuze every few years or so. Most useful for understanding one's present ethos, particularly for doing business.

Sanjiv

post by deshatika » Sun Feb 05, 2023 11:00 pm

Gilles Deleuze was one of the most influential and prolific French philosophers of the second half of the twentieth century. He conceived of philosophy as the production of concepts, and he characterized himself as a "pure metaphysician". Deleuze tried to develop a metaphysics adequate to contemporary mathematics and science- a metaphysics where the concept of multiplicity replaces that of substance, event replaces essence and virtuality replaces possibility. The plane of immanence is a founding concept in the metaphysics or ontology of Gilles Deleuze. Immanence which means residing or becoming within, generally offers a relative opposition to transcendence, that which extends beyond or outside.

Post by samanthabrown » Fri Jan 27, 2023 3:05 pm

Letter 1

The sentence that resonated with me: "When figuring out The Fishbowl, or indeed anything else, you’re dealing with words and images, and they are all you got."

In the vocab part of this letter, words and images were defined as symbols that can look like anything, yet have specific meanings attached to them. Words and images also encapsulate felt-experiences. All you got refers to the fact that everything is some kind of symbol for some sort of message. The messages are assigned by culture, but we all acknowledge them. Experience alters our perception of the meaning, but the core meaning remains the same. All you got also refers to the fact that words and images are so powerful that we can summarize almost everything with them. The Fishbowl is home to the society that we are creating so this sentence can be further interpreted to mean that words and images are the building blocks of society.

This sentence speaks to the fact that we are constantly bombarded with information all time, weather we want to be or not. It is impossible not to be given that we have meaning attached to everything.

When reading the original sentence, I also reassured because in a very simple interpretation, it is saying that we have the tools to solve any problem.

I would reconstruct this sentence as: "Our society is based on giving meaning to everything and we can draw meaning from everything, allowing us to better understand ourselves and others."

Post by samanthabrown » Sat Jan 28, 2023 7:17 pm

Letter 2: Living Legend

Selected: "Every thing starts with reading because it generates thoughts, feelings and images."

Everything in this case seems to refer to culture and society and interpreting this leads to the message that was evident in both letter 1 and 2, that words, language, and symbols are the building blocks of our society. That draws from this line mentioning reading and while it is referring to the process of reading, it is also referring to the words and symbols that make up the reading. Words are symbols for meaning and if they are able to start things and generate things, it points to a very circular process of always drawing from the past and building upon what we already know and have. This line mentions that thoughts and feelings are generated through words which are themselves symbols for thoughts and feelings. This cyclicality feels weird to think about but maybe culture and society are based solely on the same thoughts and feelings, just continually reinterpreted and built upon. Our experiences alter our perception and it would therefore make sense that our society has never really changed, just altered as we perceive things differently. Thinking about all of this makes me feel connected to the writers of words and symbols throughout history.

To put this sentence back together, I would say: "Sharing meaning is a part of human nature and because of this we are never stationary as a society, but we are experiencing gradual change to our society."

Post by samanthabrown » Mon Jan 30, 2023 9:42 am

Letter: Generating Text

Selected Sentence: Ethnographic methods are qualitative, ‘inductive,' exploratory and longitudinal.

I chose this sentence because it challenges me. It feels overwhelming to look at because of the terms used to describe ethnographic methods and something about it interested me. As described in the letter, ethnographic methods are simply data collection methods. Methods are a way of doing something in a specific manner. Inductive, as discussed in vocab, is inferencing or drawing conclusions from data. This makes sense for ethnographic methods because that is their purpose. Qualitative refers to looking at the quality of something, in this case it would be data. This makes sense for data collection because you do not want erroneous data to be the base of your conclusions. Exploratory is referring to the fact that ethnographic methods involve looking around and seeing where the research takes you. Longitudinal is looking at the same thing over time when referring to studies. In the case of ethnographic methods, longitudinal refers to the fact that there is research available from any time available.

Putting the sentence back together: "Data collection methods assess quality and age of data, and also inferences from the data to further the process. While being a process, it is also somewhat exploratory, allowing for a more comprehensive generation of data."

Letter: Doing of the Social Meeting Exercise

"The everyday world is concrete, real, and ordered on the surface, but it is underpinned by more complex structures and forces beyond the reach of traditional explanations."

--

This sentence immediately popped out at me. For some reason, I knew it was the one I wanted to deconstruct. It starts by saying that the "real world" (or what we consider it to be) appears to be ordered and concrete. Concrete is being used as to say that it is clear and certain. Then the sentence moves and says that the clearness, the certainty, and the order is only due to the support that complex structures and forces are giving it. Force is something powerful that is able to move other things. Things that defy traditional explanations would typically be magic, religion, and the supernatural, but in this case I feel like the sentence is not saying that. I feel as if it is speaking to something bigger picture. I think it is referring to forces of humanity, human nature, and the human desire to connect. In a broader sense, the sentence is saying "we cannot have order without some chaos". I connect with that because in my life I have this balance of order and chaos. This is likely why I was drawn to this line. Another way to reconstruct this sentence would be to say: "culture and society are created via the human desire for connection and need for certainty".

Letter: Social Meeting: Interpretive Interactionism

"Interpretive interactionism asserts that meaningful interpretations of human experience can only come from those persons who have thoroughly immersed themselves in the phenomenon they wish to interpret and understand."

--

This sentence feels like it has a lot of meeting. Right on the top layer, it says that to really get something meaningful and really understand, we must fully immerse ourselves. I've never thought about it in this way before. I've experienced this phenomenon before and it never occurred to me to put it into words this way. I literally had a lightbulb moment reading this line and I can feel the power that this line holds. Interpretations are unique to the person that creates them, meaning that everyone could immerse themselves in the same experience and each have a different one. Phenomenons are different for everyone because, as previously defined, they are experiences that are hard to explain. This creates a 2 layers of differences: phenomenons and interpretations. To put this sentence back together, I would say: "Experience is the only way to truly understand something." Looking from the outside can never provide the same experience and perspective that living the experience can.

Letter: Why deconstruct a text?

This sentence resonated with me because the message behind it feels very powerful. Everything can be interpreted in a different way from the way that we interpret it. post by samanthabrown » Sat Feb 04, 2023 12:57 pm

Letter: Deploying Attention

When you can look at your own attentional practices, you begin to think in new ways about how to deploy your attention.

---

Pay attention to how you pay attention. What is it that draws you in and catches your eye. Why does it do that? What if something else caught your attention? How would that change the meaning? Based on our past experiences, we all have developed a filter for our perception that causes certain things to resonate with us and that changes the meaning of the collective to fit our attention. If we acknowledge what catches our attention and focus and what causes us to focus, we can use that strategically to look for new meaning or different meanings. We have to have self-awareness before any of this is possible.

Genesis of a Fishbowl

GENESIS: an origin, creation, formation

Genesis is the beginning or generation of something.

WORD: a meaningful element of language, which is used in speech and writing

All words have a meaning attached to them and when used together create a greater meaning.

IMAGE: a visual representation of something

An image can also be defined as a mental conception or impression of an idea or thought.

ATTENDANCE: act of being present at a place or event, discipline of showing up

Attendance is a similar concept to presence and participation in an activity.

REGULAR: recurring at fixed or normal intervals, scheduled

Regular also relates to a routine.

REFLEXIVE: a reaction immediately after in response to something that happens

A person who does the action is also the person affected by it, this is also seen as reflexive.

SOCIETY: organized group of people with similar views or beliefs

A society is a form or companionship between people who have similar interests and views.

CULTURE: shared beliefs, values, and attitudes that characterizes a group of people

The term culture also refers to the common norms and social behaviors shared by people in a society.

Date: 2/4/2023 14:56:12
Subject: &quot;plane of immanence&quot;
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I trust you are keeping warm during these extreme temperatures. 

In this letter, I want to talk about the manner of your posts in the fishbowl.

How we think about our world and how we live in it are entwined. In other words, our ontology (please google) and our practical engagements are woven together.

This is true for everyone. A world that consists of particular things with strict borders that interact with other particular things (with their strict borders) according to particular natural laws will call us to certain kinds of living.

For instance, if particular things are what they are and nothing else, like every posting is a New Posting in the fishbowl, then we will not waste time imagining what else they might be or might become. We will conform ourselves to the possibilities presented to us by their actuality; by your posting.

If we abandon this way of thinking (and doing) of our world, particularly in the world of the fishbowl, then alternative ways of living (and Being) may appear to us.

We post in a way that we get to see the following...

perspective, the whole picture, development, growth, pattern, thread, weave, structure, connection of concepts...myriad, varied and multifarious.

I will be introducing the concept of immanence (existing or operating from within, inherent). Before I can do that, please view attributes of fishbowl postings under the following 4 Topic Heads with option to vary:

1. Vocabulary. 

You may also name it Definition of concepts; Meaning of concepts; or, Word-images.

2. Google Searches

You may name it Taking & Making Notes or Germinating Ideas

The above two may be combined into one topic head and named Connecting Concepts

1+2 done regularly, gets you a B+.

3. Deconstructing letters.

This section may be called Plane of Immanence. More on this later, as we go along. You are off to a good start. Congratulations.

In the Deconstructing letters you are in the A- category. Be sure to keep the thread. In your content, identify the subject of the letter. This is important.

4. Exercises

These are more of the same attributes but from different perspectives. Watching movies would fall in this category.

The Key to your postings in the above categories is to hit Post Reply when making a new posting under each category. That way, continuity will be maintained and we will be on what Deleuze calls the "plane of immanence."

A concept (word) does not stand alone. It links up with other concepts(words), coexists with them on a “plane of immanence” that allows different concepts (words) to resonate together in a multitude of ways. "It is the plane that secures conceptual linkages with ever increasing connections, and it is concepts that secure the populating of the plane on an always renewed and variable curve.” (please google Deleuze & Guattari and Plane of Immanence).

I will address questions and clarifications in Monday's class.

Sanjiv

Hi Everyone,

How are you?

Old definitions in business, as in most disciplines, are now defunct; terms such as ‘exporting’ and ‘importing’, ‘domestic’ and ‘overseas’ are now largely irrelevant.They encourage a mind-set that is in danger of being insular and limited by obsolete boundaries and distinctions. I see this a lot in my workplace.

Today, many companies are searching for a new language (words); a fresh way of perceiving their environments (through words); more complex and fluid organizational structures (made-up of words); new strategies and new leadership styles (visualizing words).

Rosabeth Moss Kanter (please google) identifies the search for a new business mind-set (structures of words) as one of the most important changes happening today. She points to the ‘triumph of process over structure’ as a key indication of this change. What is important is not how responsibilities are divided (by words) but how people can pull together (words) to pursue new opportunities (more words).

Whatever one's current organizational structure, there is a need to break down compartmentalized thinking--- whether between different disciplines, products, markets or cultures --- in order to adopt innovative business approaches.

"These are all words, where is the bacon," she shouted and slammed the door on her way out.

Hi Everyone,

How are you?

Please see the postings of Gianna Costa and Ethan Sillat below. Both are ‘immersed' in the phenomena at hand, because they choose the words they want to attend, and take them further...

Whenever we take original words further, by looking up the dictionary (sorting, sifting, selecting and substituting), we are embellishing, enhancing, repeating, and thereby, constructing new structures... of words, feelings, norms, values, experiences, interpretations and understandings.

Substituting words and constructing new structures...structures of words.

Whenever we do this, we 'reveal' ourselves by the words we choose to attend; paying attention, regardless of the author’s intent.

We are experiencing large scale shifts in attentional practices and norms all around us, according to Howard Rheingold ('Net Smart, How to Thrive Online’). Please google.

When you can look at your own attentional practices, you begin to think in new ways about how to deploy your attention.

Post by giannacosta » Mon Jan 30, 2023 2:33 pm

Generating Text-

"Data is collected through ‘observation' which is then used to ‘draw' conclusions about ‘how' groups and individuals ‘function.'"

Data collected through observation is an invaluable tool for understanding how groups and individuals function. Observation allows researchers to gain insight into the behavior of individuals and groups in their natural environment, without the need for intrusive or artificial methods. This data can then be used to draw conclusions about how groups and individuals interact, how they make decisions, and how they respond to different stimuli.

Post by giannacosta » Wed Feb 01, 2023 11:09 am

Letter: Doing the Social Meeting Exercise

"How does workplace friendship differ, from the general meaning of friendship, is a question that has not been addressed much in University life."

This sentence greatly stood out to me. I have both workplace friendships and real friendships. Workplace friendship is a unique type of relationship that is often overlooked in university life. It is different from the general meaning of friendship in a few keyways. First, workplace friendships are often based on mutual respect and trust. This is because the workplace is a professional environment and the people involved are expected to act in a certain way. This means that workplace friendships are often more formal than other types of friendships. They are also often based on shared interests and goals, as opposed to the more casual relationships that are often found in university life. Workplace friendships are often more focused on the work itself. This means that the conversations and interactions between colleagues are often centered around the tasks at hand. This is in contrast to the more casual conversations that are often found in university life, which can range from discussing current events to talking about personal interests. Workplace friendships are often more short-term. This is because the workplace is a dynamic environment and people often move on to different jobs or roles.

Post by giannacosta » Wed Feb 01, 2023 11:31 am

Letter- Social Meeting: Interpretive Interactionism

“Interpretations of human experience can only come from those persons who have thoroughly immersed themselves in the phenomenon they wish to interpret and understand”

This statement is an interesting one, as it suggests that the only way to truly understand and interpret a human experience is to have experienced it firsthand. This idea is not without merit, as it is often said that experience is the best teacher. It is true that those who have experienced a phenomenon are likely to have a more nuanced understanding of it than those who have not. For example, a person who has experienced the death of a loved one is likely to have a more profound understanding of grief than someone who has not.

post by ethansillat » Thu Feb 02, 2023 2:20 pm

“You are deconstructing a text (a sentence) and thereby developing your own voice.”

When we read a text, or the written word presented, we need to deconstruct its meaning, pick it apart, and look for its intent. We find flaws in the text and we can assign meaning which is not there. When we deconstruct, we look for the hidden in the written (and verbal text), often to find ways to criticize it and argue with its rhetoric, or find rhetoric in it that may or may not be there. When we deconstruct, we put our own voice into the text, and it might not be what was intended. But, we have to take ownership, and responsibility for it, knowing that someone else will deconstruct our words and our voice, also in sometimes unintended ways. But, they are our voice, and, although it can be challenged, it is ours, not to be taken away. We own it. We take responsibility for it, and we must also take responsibility for how we choose to deconstruct the text. Jacques Derrida said, “I speak only one language and it is not my own.” but that does not mean you cannot take ownership of it, only that it was formed from the deconstruction of other’s meanings.

“To read a text in this way (by substituting words and taking them further) is a mindset”

Mindsets are often already there. When we deconstruct we have to have a new mindset. We need to take our natural ability to deconstruct when we talk to someone or argue with someone every day and transfer it to the text. We all can deconstruct. It is not a new concept, but we now have a word for what we are doing and can apply this mindset to all readings. We have to take our already developed mindset and develop and implement a new mindset of interacting and interpreting the text to weed out its meaning and deconstruct its symbols. When we develop, we create, we experiment, we fail, and we try again.

“Through this mindset, what can be potential ‘dislocations' are really 'altered states of being' in different geographical and cultural locales.”

To dislocate means to disturb what was originally there. It can be to a new place or it can lead you to a new meaning or a new idea. Dislocation does not have to be a bad thing. It can lead to discovery. It does not have to be feared. We can deconstruct the circumstances behind the dislocation and create positive situations. When things aren’t working in the way that they used to, we have to adapt and discover whether those changes can be good. People do not like it when you deconstruct their meaning. Derrida stated, “No one gets angry at a mathematician or a physicist whom he or she doesn’t understand, or at someone who speaks a foreign language, but rather someone who tampers with your own language.” We have to accept the disturbances to our texts, so we can grow and learn

“Every setting, (posting in the fishbowl) presents itself as a watering hole, an arena; every encounter becomes an enactment in which articulate informants vocalize, whether they realize it or not, a script.”

When we encounter or have an unexpected meeting which sometimes can be unwanted, we enact a performance. To find ourselves at a watering hole, we can encounter things we do not want. Things other than water lurk within and around the watering hole. The same within an arena. In an arena, we can be a witness, or we can be a participant. We must enact, and bring new things into existence as we encounter new things in the arena. We must also sometimes alter what needs to be done, or change it, enact a new state, or way of being to help us adapt to what is around us and what we interpret has been said.

Our ethos is everything. It tells our observers who we are, defines us, and is what gives us credibility. If our ethos is unworthy, we cannot create valuable discourse, we cannot be successful in our rhetoric, and we cannot even successfully participate if our ethos is seen to be lacking. Our very character is at stake when we put forth our ethos. How we interact in the fishbowl, at the watering hole, and in the arena defines us. We must strive to create an acceptable ethos as we interact, enact, and deconstruct in our environment.

“If this work seems so threatening, this is because it isn't simply eccentric or strange, but competent, rigorously argued, and carrying conviction” – Jacques Derrida

Re: What Happened!

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope your finals are behind you and you are preparing for a well-earned holiday.

What Happened is the title of the book by Hilary Clinton, and I raise the same question regarding your participation in the fishbowl. 

At the outset, I want to say that nothing is etched in stone, I.e., if you feel I should re-evaluate your fishbowl because I overlooked something you said or did during the semester, I will be happy to do so in the interest of transparency, accountability, justice and flexibility.

1. The Final was required across the board. Reading your finals proved satisfying because you displayed, regardless of your grade, that you “Got it.” There were a handful who did not post the final and your grade went down a notch. For instance, if you just did the vocabulary, you got a B-.

2. The A category was easy to determine. You were regular in sharing and posting your labor during the semester. The experience of the Fishbowl could not have happened without you. Thank you!

3. The difference between A- and B+ was determined by deconstruction of sentences from the films and other exercises.

4. The difference between B+ and B was determined by the amount and regularity of your google searches. Those who posted vocabulary as a New Topic each time proved a pain, because I had to make sure you hadn’t co-joined google searches and deconstructions.

5. Your fishbowls were about sharing and forming a learning community. Regularity and showing-up was key! You depicted an assemblage of singular ideas that generated unique knowledge content. We created each other!

6. The culture of your fishbowls is steeped in American values and you might look at the life and technique of Jackson Pollock’s drip paintings.

https://www.invaluable.com/blog/the-originality-of-jackson-pollocks-drip-paintings/

“When I am in my painting, I’m not aware of what I’m doing… I have no fears about making changes, destroying the image, etc., because the painting has a life of its own,” Jackson Pollock

Re: finally the final (2)

Hi Everyone,

How are you? This email illustrates the first 5 Steps laid out in the previous letter. The Steps are easy to do because you have been doing them all semester. Each characteristic of MNCs, i.e., the opening structure that you begin with and follow through to Step 9, should not take more than 30minutes. Follow the KISS principle. There is no right nor wrong. Only, did you do it?

In other words, you are learning to write a brief that follows your original thinking. It cannot be replicated and it is done in the moment. It is an event and a situation of your own making. If you are having fun with it, you are doing it right.

REPLICATE 

I. Doing the Final

Step 1. Opening structure

You ‘enter the unknown’ from an opening structure, and the purpose is to develop knowledge and knowing. 

We ineluctably start from a previous structure, like one’s DNA or culture or language, and jump off a cliff or platform

Our imperative is to ‘un-think’ the opening structure as the key to conceptual debate from which we array and define an alternative agenda around which we can effect and judge other potential points of transformative application upon the world. 

This way of thinking highlights the spatiality of the ‘event’ and the materialization of the ‘situation’. You are thinking aside from structural normatives and the ethics of anti-foundational thought.

SPATIAL, EVENT, MATERIALIZE, SITUATION

IMPERATIVE, UN-THINK, CONCEPT, DEBATE

INELUCTABLE, ENTER, UNKNOWN, STRUCTURE

ASIDE, NORMATIVE, ANTI, FOUNDATIONAL, THOUGHT

Step 2. Word-pool

A random collection of words, used as inspiration for writing.

An organization of resources that can be shared.

A communal combination of words.

Generating words is generating ideas, categories, classifications, commonalities.

It is creating possibilities for changing structures.

GATHER, GENERATE, COLLECT, ORGANIZE, COMBINE

Step 3. Re-structuring

It is the act of organizing in a new way to make it operate more effectively. 

Organizational restructuring involves conducting an organizational assessment to identify areas of competence, improvement, and potential risks and applying the findings to inform strategic solutions.

Other words:

REORGANIZE, REARRANGE, REFORM, RESHUFFLE, REDISTRIBUTE, REFACTOR, STREAMLINE, REMODEL, REVAMP, RECONFIGURE

Difference between restructuring and reorganizing?

Reorganization may range from a relatively simple reconfiguration – splitting, dissolving, or merging words – to much more complex restructuring – fundamentally changing the resources, activities, and product offerings.

Difference between redesign and restructure?

Restructuring is changing the structure and reporting relationships. This is best suited for situations where the structural changes are straightforward fixes that resolve accountability confusion and goal alignment. Redesign, or transformation, is more comprehensive.

Step 4. Felt-Experience

Sometimes, we need to feel something rather than analyze it. To feel time, to feel space and place, to feel love and to reflect, to touch and go into nature and revel in the crafting of something unique. Feelings are our primary way of interacting with the world, yet many of us don't pause and unravel how they impact us.

Both emotional experiences and physical sensations — such as hunger or pain — bring about feelings, according to Psychology Today. Feelings are a conscious experience, although not every conscious experience, such as seeing or believing, is a feeling.

If you can feel something, you are aware of it because it is touching you. If you feel something happening, you become aware of it because of the effect it has on your body.

Step 5. Constructing Dichotomies

A dichotomy is a contrast between two things. When there are two ideas, especially two opposing ideas — like war and peace, or love and hate — you have a dichotomy.

A division into two especially mutually exclusive or contradictory groups or entities. The process or practice of making such a division into two opposed classes.

Dichotomy means that something has been divided into two parts. These two parts are usually in opposition to each other and create conflict or tension in the story. Dichotomy can occur within a single character who experiences an inner conflict, or it can apply to the broader theme or storyline of a narrative.

MUTUAL, EXCLUSIVE, OPPOSE

II. Fishbowl Society and Culture:

The Fishbowl challenges the Ivory Tower of academia by defining the “expert” not as someone who extracts data from a community, but someone who works within and alongside communities, gives back, and amplifies voices. The Fishbowl is interdisciplinary and international in scope, and provides rigorous analysis and radical thinking in clear language that is accessible to readers both within and outside of academia. The Fishbowl is a radical intervention in the COB, offering a vision of what we can be: accessible, inclusive and working towards a shared social justice, which benefits all. 

The Fishbowl reflects URI’s mission-driven approach to scholarship by platforming emerging voices and enabling the dissemination of bold thinking that will inform the work of future generations of scholars and change-makers. We togeth conceived the idea for the Fishbowl as a challenge to traditional academic frameworks and standards that have been exclusionary to undergraduate students and people of color.

Best of luck! I hope you will treat the assignment as an exercise in creativity. 

You are producing a short essay that presents a cutting-edge interpretation of the evolving gestalt of the global social whole by addressing the intersection between theory, production, circulation, and consumption of “new” global visual imagery.

INTERSECTION, EVOLVE, GESTALT, VISUAL, IMAGERY

Sanjiv

Re: Finally the Final

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. 

We are nearing the end of this Dramaturgy which is our fishbowl.

Dramaturgy is a sociological perspective on identity that employs a theatrical metaphor to explore issues of identity formation and reformation. As such, dramaturgy assumes a place, a moment, and an audience to whom the identity is being presented.

There are a few thoughts I’d like to share before I get to the FINAL exercise. Please watch two films attached below: Strictly Ballroom and Beautiful People and deconstruct one sentence from each film along with a reflection. In present day Society and its Culture, we are experiencing and confronting many aspects worth considering closely. 

1. Strictly Ballroom

Strictly Ballroom mimics the social structure of a “mechanistic” organization in pursuit of "social inclusion" and "obedience to authority" as the way to act and behave towards each other. It is "militarized capitalism," and “organized time” according to Richard Sennett, The Culture of the New Capitalism (please google). The price individuals pay for organized time is freedom or individuality; this “iron cage” is both prison and home. It is represented by targets and goals, expectations and achievements that are symbols of success/failure.

My task, as leader/manager is to protect and promote your creativity as a social group: the undergraduate experience! 

When I fail to do that, I make myself “redundant." Like Lola said to Charlie Boy, “you made them redundant, you miserable sod.”

The specter of “uselessness” and redundancy haunts everyone today.

2. Beautiful People

The film Beautiful People depicts the chaos of global organizational spaces. What we realize and understand is that any pursuit of a universal objective meaning is woefully misguided and it is such pursuits that disconnect and prevent us from creating meaning and coherence in our lives. In the film, we see for ourselves, there is no clear system or meaning that can be learnt or taught and implemented with success; and, there are no universal objective truths to be known and there are no facts only interpretations. Emphasizing objectivity takes the spirit out of the experience of meaning which is inherently subjective, independent and expressive.

*****************

Doing the FINAL is an exercise in ‘tacit’ knowledge. Tacit knowledge is the knowledge you've gained through living experience, both in your personal life and professional development. ‘Tacit knowledge or implicit knowledge—as opposed to formal, codified or explicit knowledge—is knowledge that is difficult to express or extract, and thus more difficult to transfer to others by means of writing it down or verbalizing it. This can include personal wisdom, experience, insight, and intuition.’ Wikipedia.

Empirical research (done by Bartlett and Ghoshal in Harvard/London School of Economics) identified four characteristics of successful transnational organizations, viz.,

Integrated Networking Structures,

Complex Adaptive Systems,

Dynamic Decision-Making, and

Unique Innovative Capabilities.

Please undertake the following steps for each of the four characteristics in order to ENHANCE your understanding, knowledge and experience:

Step 1. First characteristic: Integrated Networking Structures

Step 2. Take each word further, (and further again, when necessary) from the dictionary/thesaurus and create a Word-pool of 10 or more words. Sort, select and sift.

Step 3. From your Word-pool in Step 2, construct a sentence structure that expresses your understanding of the characteristic under development.

Step 4. From your sentence structure in Step 3, do a felt-experience of your fishbowl; self-reflexivity. Be specific with examples and instances from the fishbowl. 

Tip for being specific: for every statement that you write in the first round of your felt-experience, answer the question: How so?

Inflection Point

Step 5. From the four Steps above, select two disparate words/symbols and create a dichotomy.

Step 6. Take the two words further in Step 5, and further again if necessary, and create a Word-pool.

Step 7. Construct a sentence structure from your Word-pool in Step 6.

Step 8. Do a felt experience from your fishbowl on the structure above; self-reflexively. Be specific with examples and instances. Use the Tip mentioned in Step 4. Doing so is essential to empower your text.

Step 9. A final reflection (one paragraph) on your process when developing tacit knowledge above.

I will be with you till the end and writing subsequently to further elucidate the Steps above. Develop the FINAL in a separate file at first and post it in the fishbowl only on 12/12, the last day of classes. You must show all your iterations, edits, deletions and re-writes. We are evaluating your thought process and not a neatly packaged final product. Please keep that in mind.

Best wishes, Be Safe and Stay Hydrated,

Sanjiv

Re: Critical-thinking skills

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well. In case you missed them, please see Caitlyn Rodriguez’ reflections below as an example of creating knowledge and knowing content.

Looking at your fishbowls, I’ve been thinking of abstracting your works along the thoughts of John Dewey and Jacques Derrida. Please google their names, if you haven’t done so. Your reflections are a form of critical analysis. Critical analysis is the detailed examination and evaluation of another person's ideas or work. It is subjective writing as it expresses your interpretation and analysis of the work by breaking down and studying its parts.

Critical analysis allows you to have greater clarity on the issues and information you process. Academic disciplines are kept alive through constant reflection, debate and refinement of ideas. Critical analysis is thus crucial to the survival and renewal of all fields of enquiry.

The 21st century learning skills are often called the 4 C's: critical thinking, creative thinking, communicating, and collaborating. These skills help students learn, and so they are vital to success in school and beyond. Critical thinking is focused, careful analysis of something to better understand it.

Critical-thinking skills connect and organize ideas. Three types distinguish them: analysis, inference, and evaluation.

Sanjiv

Letter: Aesthetic Response Again

Structure: "You develop a theory of aesthetics which rejects strict categorization, emphasizing instead the crucial importance of individual subjectivity as a counter to the latent dangers of collective cultures and authoritarianism."

Breakdown:

THEORY- a supposition or a system of ideas intended to explain something, especially one based on general principles independent of the thing to be explained.

AESTHETICS- a set of principles concerned with the nature and appreciation of beauty, especially in art.

REJECT- dismiss as inadequate, inappropriate, or not to one's taste.

STRICT- demanding that rules concerning behavior are obeyed and observed.

CATEGORIZATION- the action or process of placing into classes or groups.

CRUCIAL-decisive or critical, especially in the success or failure of something.

SUBJECTIVITY- the quality of being based on or influenced by personal feelings, tastes, or opinions; the quality of existing in someone's mind rather than the external world.

COUNTER- in the opposite direction to or in conflict with; responding to something of the same kind, especially in opposition, speak or act in opposition to.

LATENT- (of a quality or state) existing but not yet developed or manifest; hidden or concealed.

DANGERS- a person or thing that is likely to cause harm or injury.

COLLECTIVE- done by people acting as a group; a cooperative enterprise.

AUTHORITARIANISM- the enforcement or advocacy of strict obedience to authority at the expense of personal freedom; of blind submission to authority.

Felt-experience & elaboration:

In the context of the letter, I understand this structure stresses the importance of individuality in our writing and reinforces the free-flowing nature of this course under Professor Dugal. Here in the fishbowl, we are free to write and reflect in our own words with a loose prompt, allowing for more diverse writing that better shows our true character and our thinking. We are not bound by a textbook and strict lesson plans that so many courses require. I am grateful to be able to write with my own voice, as over the years the writing required by my classes have called for more a formal, unopinionated, scientific tone. Of course some types of papers need to have that neutrality, but it has taken away a lot of joy around writing for me. When I was younger, I was a huge bookworm and I always had ideas for creative writing pieces that I would put together for fun. Nowadays, I don't write for fun much, except for the occasional diary entry. Will this be my catalyst for change? We'll see.
