Letter: Completing the Social Meeting Exercise

Structure: "I believe that the best hope for our species lies in learning new patterns of attention to each other and to the biosphere, patterns that grow out of curiosity and respect and allow for wonder and learning."

Breakdown:

BELIEVE- accept (something) as true; feel sure of the truth of; hold (something) as an opinion; think or suppose.

HOPE- a feeling of expectation and desire for a certain thing to happen; a feeling of trust.

SPECIES- a group of living organisms consisting of similar individuals capable of exchanging genes or interbreeding. The species is the principal natural taxonomic unit, ranking below a genus and denoted by a Latin binomial, e.g. Homo sapiens; a kind or sort.

BIOSPHERE- the regions of the surface, atmosphere, and hydrosphere of the earth (or analogous parts of other planets) occupied by living organisms.

GROW- (of a living thing) undergo natural development by increasing in size and changing physically; progress to maturity; become larger or greater over a period of time; increase.

CURIOSITY- a strong desire to know or learn something; a strange or unusual object or fact.

RESPECT- a feeling of deep admiration for someone or something elicited by their abilities, qualities, or achievements; due regard for the feelings, wishes, rights, or traditions of others.

ALLOW- give (someone) permission to do something.

WONDER- a feeling of surprise mingled with admiration, caused by something beautiful, unexpected, unfamiliar, or inexplicable; desire or be curious to know something.

LEARNING- the acquisition of knowledge or skills through experience, study, or by being taught.

Felt experience/elaboration:

The hope expressed in this sentence is one I align with. So much creation and innovation comes from collaboration. Creation and innovation is exactly what is needed to tend to the anthropogenic damages that now afflict our biosphere, our environment, our planet. One person can be very productive on their own, but impactful inventions and ideas need help to get noticed and started up. For the collaboration needed, it is indeed true that we need to learn to better understand one another and learn to listen and focus and reflect. This could be difficult to accomplish as our society becomes more dependent on our smartphones for entertainment. Studies have shown that this constant usage is ruining our ability to focus for long periods of time and results in less idle time to stumble upon creativity. Many times in my life, I have been told that boredom breeds creativity, that it's good to be uncomfortably restless with nothing to do because then you'll be forced to find your own entertainment or occupation. Nowadays, this relief is often found on our phones or by watching TV. There is absolutely an addictive, dopamine-linked effect that occurs here, but it should also be noted that our phones and other devices have provided comfort during hard times like the recent pandemic. Some people fear being idle, allowing boredom to creep across them, lest they begin to think bad, traumatic, harmful thoughts. However, strong emotions like anger, fear, and sadness bring beautiful inspirations and ideas to the surface. Our time is short and valuable on this planet, so whether it is to cope or to pass the time, it is ideal to discover ones passions, curiosities, and wonderment to form new bonds and learn from others.

Letter: Linguistic Turn Oct 4

Structure: "You are indeed a visionary when you develop your own dichotomies and categories and structures... It is tantamount to changing labels on boxes and changing the shelves they go on…”

Breakdown:

VISIONARY-(especially of a person) thinking about or planning the future with imagination or wisdom; relating to or able to see visions in a dream or trance, or as a supernatural apparition.

DEVELOP-grow or cause to grow and become more mature, advanced, or elaborate.

OWN- something that belongs to the person or thing mentioned.

DICHOTOMIES- a division or contrast between two things that are or are represented as being opposed or entirely different.

CATEGORIES- a class or division of people or things regarded as having particular shared characteristics; one of a possibly exhaustive set of classes among which all things might be distributed.

STRUCTURES- the arrangement of and relations between the parts or elements of something complex.

TANTAMOUNT- equivalent in seriousness to; virtually the same as.

LABELS- a small piece of paper, fabric, plastic, or similar material attached to an object and giving information about it; assign to a category, especially inaccurately or restrictively; a classifying phrase or name applied to a person or thing, especially one that is inaccurate or restrictive.

Felt experience/elaboration-

When we were assigned to do the dichotomy activity for the social meeting activity, it became clear that any two words can be connected or linked in some ways. When we define words in the fishbowl, and sometimes even redefine words several times, we find that there are multiple definitions to each word and dependent on the context of the letters we may be drawn to different definitions. When creating and linking dichotomies, we can alter the definition of the words that are being juxtaposed to show a stronger relationship between them. By doing this, we are liberating the words of their strict, shallow definitions and constructing a universal truth. This reminds me of Lola from Kinky Boots and the resistance she faces when she would desire to present herself authentically was seen a threat to categorization around her. The definitions of "woman" and "man" were strict in the minds of those who were uncomfortable with her expression. This led to the questioning of Lola's validity by her critics and herself. Through the progression of the story and at the end, those words are redefined not by the physical characteristics but by the actions and measures of the characters that validate how they present to the world.

Letter: Production of Subjectivity Oct 9

Structure: “It is our subjective process that produces outcomes of value.”

Breakdown:

SUBJECTIVE- based on or influenced by personal feelings, tastes, or opinions.

Felt-experience/Elaboration-

It is up to you to define the value of your own work, whether you consider the opinions and perspectives of your critics or not. Still, one should have standards for their own work to be able to determine the threshold above which outcomes excel those standards or not.

Subject: Intercultural Competence
------------------------------------------------------------
Re: Intercultural Competence

Hi Everyone,

How are you?

Culture has five basic characteristics: It is learned, shared, based on symbols, integrated, and dynamic. All cultures share these basic features.

I would like to comment on two specific issues:

1. An individual always keeps a dialogue with his/her own culture. So culture makes who you are and you also make culture. It's a very dialectic process. Please see Marisa Cayer’s posting and Matthew Byrne’s postings below. Also, when we talk about the relation between culture and identity, an individual is not made only by national culture. There are other levels of culture which compose who you are (e.g. organizational culture, community culture, regional cultures...etc).

2. It is essential to look at differences but also to reflect on how they have a common ground and on how they might complement each other when having to work together.

Yes, culture is something really hard to run away from. We are inserted in culture from the moment we are born and it gets under our skin. So even when we are not aware, it has an influence on us. Each person, who grows up in a specific cultural context, can develop their own perceptions and share features of their own culture, in a relation of mutual influence.

You have Intercultural Competence (please google) when you are able to talk and work with people from different cultures having respect for each of them and trying not to judge when they act differently from you. It entails reflection about oneself and others.

Watch the videos Outsourced and Iron & Silk and answer the questions:

1. What kind of barrier does the American find when trying to communicate with the other culture? 

2. Why do you think it happened?

Our Method: the best way to proceed when considering such questions is to select a sentence from the videos, deconstruct, and share a felt-experience from your personal life.

Sanjiv

DIALECTIC, MUTUAL, INFLUENCE

OUTSOURCED DECONSTRUCTI

post by marisacayer » Sun Nov 06, 2022 12:34 pm

OUTSOURCED:

“Sometimes destruction is a good thing, she ends one cycle so another can begin”

Asha says this sentence to Todd when they are in the taxi together and he asks what a certain Indian symbol means. Asha describes the importance of the symbol. It shows the difference between American and Indian culture. Americans hear the word “destruction” and think of bad things such as tragedy, sadness, misfortune, etc. On the other hand, in Indian culture, they see destruction as a new opportunity or fresh start. They see destruction as a possibility of something better than before. This is a way to start a new cycle, learn from the old. From this destruction of the ferry, Todd and Asha were brought together and showed their feelings for one another. Without destruction of the ferry, they would have never had the chance to connect.

Post by MatthewByrne » Sat Nov 05, 2022 5:09 pm

From: The Culture Exercise: Comparing cultures in terms of broad value differences:

Sentence chosen: Every ‘word' comes attached with an ‘image' and their meaning is culturally determined.

Word- a single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing, used with others (or sometimes alone) to form a sentence.

Attached- joined, fastened, or connected to something.

Image- a representation of the external form of a person or thing.

Meaning- what is intended by a word, text, concept, or action.

Culturally- in a way that relates to the ideas, customs, and social behavior of different societies.

Determined- ascertain or establish exactly, typically as a result of research or calculation.

I chose this sentence because of its relation to the ‘intercultural awareness’ theme. Every ‘word’ does in fact come attached with an ‘image;’ it is important to use ‘intercultural awareness’ and understand that people can have different images attached to certain words based on their culture. Different cultures can have different meanings and images attached to words. The fishbowl is a collection of interpretations of different words and images.

Hi Everyone,

Whenever you make a posting in the fishbowl, you are being a reflective practitioner. Please see Evan Sanford’s posting below.

How so? 

Every decision that you are making (before the act of posting in the fishbowl) has to do with sorting, sifting and selecting words. 

This is what reflection in-action and reflection upon-action are about in my opinion. Please fact-check your process. 

Our reflections are generated by our perceived differences. By comparing and contrasting. 

What I learn from Charlie Price and Lola (Kinky Boots), Sandy and Hiromitsu (Japanese Story) is that in order to connect across each other’s differences, we have to change our perceptual structures (change the words/labels that we have given to our categories and dichotomies). Please think about it. We got to be able to change our metaphors and our structures; thinking on our feet.

You see the meaning of this statement in the stories of Japanese Story and Kinky Boots. Particularly Charlie Price and Lola, who are truly a success story for doing business in the 21st. “Being able to evaluate thoughts, decisions, and actions while experiencing something can be very essential in making quick business decisions.” ( Sansford, E. 2022 fishbowl)

Donald Schön, The Reflective Practitioner

post by evansanford » Mon Oct 24, 2022 6:41 pm

"He theorized that practitioners solve these problems through use of conscious analysis of what they are experiencing and why their usual actions are not helping them to work effectively. This consideration is termed ‘reflection-inaction’, and becomes the basis from which practitioners create, in motion, new practice that allows them to solve their practice conundrums."

This excerpt is from a review of Donald Schön's, "The Reflective Practitioner." It goes more in-depth on the term reflection-in-action. I think this method of thinking is one that is very important to have as a trait and can be used in many different practices around the world. Being able to evaluate thoughts, decisions, and actions while experiencing something can be very essential in making quick business decisions. Making rapid decisions on the spot can be very challenging, but being able to use reflection-in-action may make for a more effective business.

“As we globalize, we increasingly have to interact, manage, negotiate and compromise with people from different cultures. Working with people whose values and beliefs, not to mention languages and customs are different from your own can make for costly misunderstandings. Experience tells us, often painfully, that one’s behavior, actions and decisions are not separate from one’s values and beliefs. All social behavior is embedded in a particular context and is connected to other deeply held values and beliefs. This means that the stakes are high for mismanaging cultural differences.” (Lisa Hoecklin, 'Managing Cultural Differences: Strategies for Competitive Advantage,' The Economist Intelligence Unit Series, Addison-Wesley, 1995)

post by EricCosta » Sun Oct 23, 2022 8:02 pm

Excerpt from Generation Online - Immaterial Labor by Maurizio Lazzarato

Immaterial labor finds itself at the crossroads (or rather, it is the interface) of a new relationship between production and consumption. The activation of both productive cooperation and the social relationship with the consumer is materialized within and by the process of communication. The role of immaterial labor is to promote continual innovation in the forms and conditions of communication (and thus in work and consumption). It gives form to and materializes needs, the imaginary, consumer tastes, and so forth, and these products in turn become powerful producers of needs, images, and tastes. The particularity of the commodity produced through immaterial labor (its essential use value being given by its value as informational and cultural content) consists in the fact that it is not destroyed in the act of consumption, but rather it enlarges, transforms, and creates the "ideological" and cultural environment of the consumer. This commodity does not produce the physical capacity of labor power; instead, it transforms the person who uses it. Immaterial labor produces first and foremost a "social relationship" (a relationship of innovation, production, and consumption). Only if it succeeds in this production does its activity have an economic value. This activity makes immediately apparent something that material production had "hidden," namely, that labor produces not only commodities, but first and foremost it produces the capital relation.

Post by EricCosta » Tue Oct 18, 2022 6:24 am

Excerpt from Interpretive Methodologies and Methods

Interpretive methodologies and methods are informed by philosophical traditions such as hermeneutics, phenomenology, pragmatism, symbolic interaction, and critical theory. Notwithstanding their differences, these traditions presuppose that the meaningfulness and historical contingency of human life sets the social realm apart from the natural and physical worlds, when it comes to research. Although diverse in their modes of generating and analyzing data, research processes in the interpretive tradition are typically characterized by an empirical and normative prioritizing of the lived experience of people in research settings, including the documentary and visual tracings and heritage of these (what Clifford Geertz referred to as “experience-near” research), a focus on the meaning(s) of acts, events, interactions, language, and physical artifacts to multiple stakeholders, and a sensitivity to the historically contingent, often contested character of such meanings.

Post by EricCosta » Tue Oct 18, 2022 11:44 am

Excerpt from Forbes, The Year of the Knowledge Worker

Knowledge workers have proved instrumental to the economy, especially over the last 20 years, and are now more critical than ever as society shifts to remote work.

Noted for high levels of creativity and productivity, knowledge workers began as technology-based professionals such as web programmers or web designers and have since expanded to include writers, researchers, accountants, engineers, designers, physicians and more.

The key indicator is that a knowledge worker "thinks" for a living instead of performing physical tasks. Other indicators may include the ability to:

• Develop new products or services.

• Solve complex problems.

• Handle complex mechanisms autonomously.

• Focus on quality over quantity.

• Work relatively independently.

Knowledge workers use high-level communication skills to work independently and collaboratively in order to accomplish complex tasks, usually by using the latest technology. Most notably, a knowledge worker is someone who can learn and adapt to a shifting workplace.

Excerpt from WorldBank.org

The following pillars are four critical requisites for a country to be able to fully participate in the knowledge economy:

Education & Training

An educated and skilled population is needed to create, share and use knowledge.

Information Infrastructure

A dynamic information infrastructure-ranging from radio to the internet-is required to facilitate the effective communication, dissemination and processing of information.

Economic Incentive & Institutional Regime

A regulatory and economic environment that enables the free flow of knowledge, supports investment in Information and Communications Technology (ICT), and encourages entrepreneurship is central to the knowledge economy.

Innovation Systems

A network of research centers, universities, think tanks, private enterprises and community groups is necessary to tap into the growing stock of global knowledge, assimilate and adapt it to local needs,

and create new knowledge.

Post by EricCosta » Wed Oct 19, 2022 3:46 pm

Excerpt from WSJ, Why Really Smart Executives Do Really Stupid Things by Rosabeth Moss Kanter

Here are a few tendencies that, when left unchecked, might help explain why so many top executives make surprising stumbles.

Feeling insulated

It’s amazing how easy it is for top executives to feel they have a cloak of invisibility, even if they operate in the public eye. They have backdoors into the ballroom for the convention. Chauffeured cars to whisk them away from crowds and lines. Private showers near their offices. A small number of close personal aides who keep doors closed and clean up messes. Because of this insulation, some top executives who should know better may falsely believe they can separate their personal lives and conduct from their official role. To them, even email seems private, so they send line-crossing messages impulsively.

Feeling entitled

Self-confidence can veer into arrogance if an executive isn’t careful. Surrounded by flatterers exaggerating the brilliance of their words, top officials can start feeling superior to the mere mortals below. They have incentives or punishments to dangle that can inspire fear and keep people in line. So in addition to feeling invincible, these leaders can start to feel indispensable. They begin to think that they are the company, essential to its success. Therefore, they feel justified in seizing what they want for themselves, believing they are entitled to indulge.

Buying their own hype

Those at the top of organizations learn to tell a good story. Exuding optimism and putting a positive spin on events attracts investors/voters/talent. Some executives, however, start believing their own hype about how the only important thing is the quarterly earnings report or the next big donation. As for a bit of misconduct, they tell themselves they can compensate for it with good performance, or end it before anyone notices. The problem is, the impulse remains. They seek the same burst of gratification again. And once they relax self-control, it’s easier to do it the next time.

Failing to admit mistakes

It can be hard for some people at the top to say, “I was wrong,” which is why misconduct often continues and requires covering up. Sometimes executives don’t want to admit flaws even to themselves, fearing it could lead to second-guessing of other decisions. They might know they are breaking a rule but delude themselves into thinking that the rule doesn’t apply exactly to their situation. They tell themselves it’s consensual. It’s just harmless banter. It will be over soon. Whatever the excuse, they cling to it to avoid having to express self-doubt.

Underestimating opponents

When questionable behavior comes to light—even if the problem is a misunderstanding, or ethically fuzzy, like words being taken out of context—what happens next depends on internal political dynamics, and who is on the CEO’s side. Executives, however, sometimes fail to realize the implications when not everyone is pulling for them, and they let down their guard. But colleagues can be envious. They wonder and whisper and are ready to pounce at the mere hint of a slip. And depending on whether they have created a positive, supportive culture for everyone, CEOs can find that flatterers quickly turn into gossips and whistleblowers, eager to push them out.

Excerpt from The New Yorker, A Celebrity Philosopher Explains the Populist Insurgency

In Germany, where academic philosophers still equate dryness with seriousness, Sloterdijk has a near-monopoly on irreverence. This is an important element of his wide appeal, as is his eagerness to offer an opinion on absolutely anything—from psychoanalysis to finance, Islam to Soviet modernism, the ozone layer to Neanderthal sexuality. An essay on anger can suddenly plunge into a history of smiling; a meditation on America may veer into a history of frivolity. His magnum opus, the “Spheres” trilogy, nearly three thousand pages long, includes a rhapsodic excursus on rituals of human-placenta disposal. He is almost farcically productive. As his editor told me, “The problem with Sloterdijk is that you are always eight thousand pages behind.”

This profligacy makes Sloterdijk hard to pin down. He is known not for a single grand thesis but for a shrapnel-burst of impressionistic coinages—“anthropotechnics,” “negative gynecology,” “co-immunism”—that occasionally suggest the lurking presence of some larger system. Yet his prominence as a public intellectual comes from a career-long rebellion against the pieties of liberal democracy, which, now that liberal democracy is in crisis worldwide, seems prophetic. A signature theme of his work is the persistence of ancient urges in supposedly advanced societies. In 2006, he published a book arguing that the contemporary revolt against globalization can be seen as a misguided expression of “noble” sentiments, which, rather than being curbed, should be redirected in ways that left-liberals cannot imagine. He has described the Presidential race between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump as a choice “between two helplessly gesticulating models of normality, one of which appeared to be delegitimatized, the other unproven,” and is unsurprised that so many people preferred the latter. Few philosophers are as fixated on the current moment or as gleefully ready to explain it.

Post by EricCosta » Sun Oct 23, 2022 2:37 pm

Excerpt from the University of London

The expression 'linguistic turn' can be seen as a shorthand for the impact of the focus on the relationship between philosophy and language, which began to be significant in the early 20th century. This has challenged the traditional tenets of historical objectivity, which assume that there is a real past which can be described (to the extent to which sources are available) as it actually happened. Instead, proponents of the linguistic turn argue that the past does not exist outside our textual representations of it, and that these representations cannot be separated from the ideological baggage that historians bring to them. British historians have been reluctant to allow these ideas influence over their actual practice, and the issues (connected with developments in cultural and gender history particularly) remain contentious.

Re: Reflective practitioner

Hi Everyone,

How are you?

REFLECTION can be understood as: ‘An important human activity in which people recapture their experience, think about it, mull it over and evaluate it.. 

We act, see what happens and try to learn.

When circumstances and conditions change, we have to think more deeply about various matters; from the meaning of life to what is worth doing and how you can deal with people in your surroundings.

Reflective Practice (please google Donald Schön, The Reflective Practitioner) is often described in terms of reflection-in-action (thinking what one is doing while one is doing it — thinking on one’s feet) and reflection-on-action (after the experience one analyses one’s reaction to the situation and explores the reasons around, and the consequences of, one’s actions). You see both Charlie Price and Lola do it in Kinky Boots, and you saw Sandy and HIromitsu do it in Japanese Story. None of them would have survived, had it not been for their reflective practices. It is leadership that is visible and transparent. It is being unafraid of sharing one’s thoughts.

You are following a reflective practice in your fishbowls. Please see Bryan Ellis’ posting below.

REFLEXIVITY is defined as “the ambition to carefully and systematically take a critical view of one’s own assumptions, ideas and favored vocabulary and to consider if alternative ones make sense.” To understand this statement, we will be watching the films, Moonrise Kingdom, Outsourced and Iron & Silk.

Through these three films, we will be looking at American culture, Indian culture, and Chinese culture, respectively. 

What is culture, and what are we looking for? 

We are framing our ‘looking’ by using the term Cultural Democracy. Cultural Democracy is a term used in The 2020 Rome Charter. 

Please google The 2020 Rome Charter and study what the charter is saying by picking sentences that resonate with you. The term “city” in the Charter may be taken as a surrogate for Providence, for RI, for the fishbowl, college and university. 

We are taking a “cultural turn” (please google) in the fishbowl.

Events for Deleuze (please google) are part of the process of ‘becoming’ and ‘differentiation’ – while they are connected, the events do not comprise a unity because each instance is marked with differentiation. In other words, Deleuzian events are rhizomatic and part of an ever-changing, ongoing process.

The knowing of research methods: symbolic interactionism and social constructivism. Please google.

symbolic interactionism: A perspective on the world where symbols are recognized across the world and within society and people’s views are created and transferred, using language, to discuss things related to those symbols.

social constructivism: Social constructivism revolves around the idea that social groups create meaning for specific cultural artifacts and knowledge is shared through these artifacts through various ways.

Experimentation: carrying out a scientific procedure in order to understand a problem or idea

Improvisation: carrying out an actin with preparing for it beforehand

Self-discovery: gaining knowledge of one’s own self

Imagination: the ability to create and ideas and thoughts of thing that are present externally

Relaxation: fulfilling the potential of one’s self

Attention: notice or observation of something significant

Communication: written or verbal transmission of information

Emotion: feelings that occur instinctively within a circumstance due to one’s personality and mood

Memory: the faculty by which the mind is able to retain information

Re: vocabulary and google searches/felt experiences

post by Chase LaMountain » Thu Oct 13, 2022 2:53 pm

10/11 post

doing the Kinky Boots exercise

You are watching Kinky Boots and constructing meaning for yourself by ‘active listening’ (please google).

Active listening is more than understanding the words of someone else. It is about mutually understanding the speaker through visual and auditory cues. It is also about the subsequent follow up feedback that is spoken after digesting what the speaker has said to you.

There are five key techniques to develop your ‘active listening’ skills when watching Kinky Boots.

Charlie Price used these techniques in Kinky Boots and turned his business around.

He took a shoe factory from fordism, to post-fordism, to understanding his business in a ‘networked society.’ (Please google).

A networked society is a modern term to describe society and how communication technologies and other technologies have allowed for a more integrated and connected society between people. Further, these technologies are also capable of altering society for the better to develop and improve businesses and individuals alike.

Watch: to stare at or observe attentively over a certain period of time

Context: the conditions surrounding an event or idea that allow it to be understood better

Listen: to concentrate on a sound

Active: be ready to engage or be currently engaged in a physical activity

Expectation: as assumption that an event will unfold in the future

Judgment: the shrewdness to come to sensible conclusions

Speak: utter or declare something in order to convey information

10/12 post

five attributes of Active Listening

Attribute: to accredit the cause of something or the characteristics of something

Trait: distinguishing characteristic of a person

1.Pay attention.

2.Show that you're listening.

3.Provide feedback.

4.Defer judgment.

5.Respond appropriately.

Felt experience: Like the five above ways in which Charlie behaved to turn his business around, we can also apply to the fishbowl. In order to have effective communication, we need to pay attention to others in the fishbowl. To show that we are being attentive, we should reflect on their posts and subsequently provide thoughtful feedback towards what they are discussing. That way, we are mutually sharing this process of learning through new experiences by having thought-provoking discussions.

Translation: transferring words from one language into another

Frame: a rigid mount that surrounds something

Shift: to transport an object or to change the direction or position of something

Habit: a routine that is particularly hard to stop

Style: a technique or method of doing or completing something

Distinctive: distinguishing one person or thing from another

Emerge: to physically make an appearance or become noticeable

Pattern: a repeated design or behavior

Recurrence: occurring more than once

Analogy: something that is able to be compared to something else normally for explanation purposes

Matrix: a surrounding environment that is conducive to development

Hi Everyone,

How are you?

Taking stock of where we’re at. I will talk process and practice and both are familiar to you, either in your role as a Knowledge-worker or as a Voyeur.

1. You have a handle (metaphor) on the ‘process of translation.’ It is the effort to frame the same message (sentence structure) in different ways, even as new meanings are created by a shift in context (subjects in letters), in the fishbowl

2. The lesson of whatever I have learned over time in the fishbowl is that looking carefully at anything informs looking at everything. Our task is to learn again to see things whole by respecting and treasuring their “minute particulars.” Most of your postings bear testimony to this. You are priceless!

3. As distinctive as your style in clothes, your habits of thought are gradually emerging and made visible as a pattern and recurrence in different contexts.

4. Analogies and metaphors are never perfect, so they can lead to misunderstandings, yet they are often surprising, opening doors of understanding from one realm of experience to another. Your felt-experiences are its manifestation.

5. We create each other, bring each other into being by being part of the matrix in which the other exists.

You are exploring the ‘nature of attention’ that makes such relationships possible. I think that the best hope for our species lies in learning new ‘patterns of attention’ to each other and to the biosphere, patterns that grow of curiosity and respect and allow for wonder and learning. It seems to me that in trying to develop an understanding of matters of this sort, one has to move back and forth between very abstract (your sentence structures) and very specific levels of focus (your felt-experiences), and indeed between types of discourse varying from poetry to formal analysis.

Re: Google Searches - Alexis Hogan - symbolic interactionism and social constructivism

post by alexishogan » Tue Oct 11, 2022 6:31 pm

Symbolic interactionism and social constructivism are two theoretical perspectives that can be used to explain how people interact with each other and how they understand the world around them. Both perspectives emphasize the role of symbols and meanings in social interaction, but they differ in their emphasis on individual agency and the role of social structures.

Symbolic interactionism is a micro-level perspective that focuses on the way that individuals interact with each other and how they create meaning in their everyday lives. This perspective emphasizes the role of symbols and language in social interaction, and it argues that people use symbols to create meaning in their lives. Symbolic interactionism also emphasizes the role of social interaction in the construction of reality. This means that people interact with each other to create an understanding of the world around them.

Social constructivism is a macro-level perspective that focuses on the way that social structures shape the way that people interact with each other. This perspective emphasizes the role of social institutions in the construction of reality. Social constructivism argues that people interact with each other within the context of larger social structures and that these structures shape the way that people understand the world around them.

Re: Google Searches - Alexis Hogan - active listening

post by alexishogan » Tue Oct 11, 2022 6:35 pm

Active listening is a communication technique that is used to encourage understanding and collaboration. It is a way of listening and responding to another person that is designed to promote communication and understanding.

The key elements of active listening are paying attention, paraphrasing, and asking questions. When you are actively listening, you are not only hearing what the other person is saying, but you are also trying to understand the message they are trying to communicate. You can show that you are actively listening by making eye contact, nodding your head, and giving verbal and nonverbal cues that indicate that you are paying attention.

Active listening is a skill that can be learned and developed with practice. It is an important communication tool that can be used in a variety of settings, such as in the workplace, in personal relationships, and in customer service.

Re: Google Searches - Alexis Hogan - networked society

post by alexishogan » Tue Oct 11, 2022 6:38 pm

A networked society is a society in which social relationships are based on networks of communication and exchange. The networked society is a global phenomenon, and it is characterized by a number of features, including the following:

-The rise of the networked individual: In the networked society, the individual is the center of the social universe. The individual is connected to a vast network of other individuals, and he or she has the ability to communicate and exchange information with anyone in the world.

-The rise of the networked organization: In the networked society, organizations are no longer hierarchical and centralized. They are decentralized and networked.

-The rise of the networked economy: In the networked society, the economy is global and interconnected.

-The rise of the networked culture: In the networked society, culture is created and shared by individuals in a networked environment.

Re: Google Searches

post by anthonykozaritz » Mon Oct 10, 2022 9:04 pm

Symbolic Interactionism- The view of social behavior that emphasizes linguistic or gestural communication and its subjective understanding, especially the role of language in the formation of the child as a social being. For example, the word 'dog' is just a series of letters. Through your interactions with the letters dog you see this as a furry, four-legged canine. Through text, we are able to make an image in our heads that relate to the text. In the fishbowl, this is important as we can take the text from other students and picture it in a way that makes sense to us.

Social Constructivism- This is a sociological theory of knowledge according to which human development is socially situated and knowledge is constructed through interaction with others. Like social constructionism, social constructivism states that people work together to construct artifacts. Social constructivist approaches should require the students to collaborate and critically analyze the issue at hand. Some examples of collaborative learning activities are group problem-solving, group inquiry, simulations, and debates. We are working in a group in the fishbowl to learn from each other's text.

Re: Process is the product

Post by harryrunci » Sat Oct 01, 2022 6:21 pm

Selected sentence: ‘the process is the product.’

Process: a series of actions or steps taken in order to achieve a particular end

Product: a thing or person that is the result of an action or process

If you constantly live your life getting caught up in achieving objectives, you will miss out on enjoying the process along the way. There is nothing wrong with setting goals for yourself but often times we get sucked into these goals and overlook what we do to get there. If your goal is to earn x amount of dollars from your work, how will you get there. What steps will you take in personal development to achieve this end result? If your sole focus in life is to earn a certain amount of money and you aren't able to do so, then what happens? This is an oversimplified example, but still it emphasizes why the process in achieving our goals is sometimes as important, if not more important, than the end product itself.

Re: Taking and Making Notes (Google Searches)

Post by harryrunci » Tue Sep 27, 2022 10:40 pm

Knowledge workers:

(from Wiki): "knowledge workers are workers whose main capital is knowledge"

(from corporate finance institute): "Knowledge workers are said to think for a living, unlike manual laborers who are paid for performing physical tasks... Knowledge workers receive high salaries that reflect the complex nature of their work and their relative independence in relation to the work process"

Most of us are going to college because we want to be knowledge workers. We are paying (tuition) in exchange for the opportunity to learn - for most of us - about the field of business. Other people go to school to become "knowledge workers" in the fields of medicine, pharmacology, history, engineering, or science. While we sometimes learn hard skills, like, how to use Microsoft Excel, we are also paying to learn soft skills like problem solving, collaboration, and leadership. If we opted not to go to college, we could have tried to get jobs in manual labor. However, we chose to go to college and accumulate knowledge in hopes of earning a higher salary which returns our investment we make by paying college tuition. College tuition, however, is not the only path to becoming a knowledge worker. There is no one path that is right for everyone. Some entrepreneurs become knowledge workers by bootstrapping without finishing or ever starting college. Look at the recent example of Dylan Field, CEO and co-founder of software company "Figma." Field dropped out of Brown University to pursue his entrepreneurial vision. He learned through his own personal experiences running a business, even though he didn't follow the typical model of a "knowledge worker." I would say it worked out for him though - his company sold to Adobe for $20 billion...

Knowledge economy (from corporate finance institute): "The knowledge economy is a system of consumption and production that is based on intellectual capital... The knowledge economy is focused on the essential importance of human capital in the 21st-century economy. The rapid expansion of knowledge and the increasing reliance on computerization, big data analytics, and automation are changing the economy of the developed world to one that is more dependent on intellectual capital and skills, and less dependent on the production process."

One interesting observation I would make in terms of the knowledge workers is that the COVID-19 pandemic probably decreased the demand for these knowledge/skilled workers, and increased the need for manual laborers. This probably marks a reversal of the trend prior to pandemic. Before the pandemic it seemed like the need for skilled workers was on the rise, but the pandemic created so many openings in lower-income/blue-collar jobs that required less knowledge capital.

Re: Google Searches - Alexis Hogan Immaterial Labor

post by alexishogan » Wed Oct 05, 2022 12:34 pm

In the most general sense, immaterial labor is any form of labor that does not produce a physical product. This includes service work, knowledge work, and emotional labor. It is often said that we live in an economy increasingly driven by immaterial labor, as the production of physical goods has become increasingly automated.

There are a few key characteristics of immaterial labor that distinguish it from other forms of labor. First, immaterial labor is often invisible or hidden. This is because it is often done in the background, or because it is not recognized as labor at all. For example, domestic work or care work is often not seen as labor, even though it is essential work that requires time, energy, and skill.

Second, immaterial labor is often unpaid or underpaid. This is because it is often seen as less valuable than other forms of labor, or because it is done by women, people of color, and other marginalized groups who are already paid less for their work. For example, women are often paid less than men for doing the same job, even though they may have the same qualifications.

Third, immaterial labor is often precariously employed. This means that it is often done on a part-time, temporary, or contract basis, without the benefits or protections of full-time employment. For example, many people who work in the gig economy are precariously employed, as they are often paid by the task and do not have access to benefits like health insurance or paid leave.

Fourth, immaterial labor is often invisible to those who benefit from it. This is because it is often done behind the scenes, or because the people who benefit from it do not see the labor that goes into it. For example, when you order a meal at a restaurant, you do not see the labor that goes into cooking and cleaning up afterward.

Finally, immaterial labor is often undervalued and underpaid. This is because it is often seen as less valuable than other forms of labor, or because the people who do it are not given the same recognition or compensation as those who do other forms of labor. For example, childcare workers are often paid very little, even though they provide an essential service.

In conclusion, immaterial labor is a form of labor that is often invisible, underpaid, and undervalued. It is essential to the functioning of our economy, but the people who do it are often not given the recognition or compensation they deserve.

From rheingold.com on Net Smart: "Mindful use of digital media means thinking about what we are doing, cultivating an ongoing inner inquiry into how we want to spend our time. I outline five fundamental digital literacies, online skills that will help us do this: attention, participation, collaboration, critical consumption of information (or “crap detection”), and network smarts. I explain how attention works, and how we can use our attention to focus on the tiny relevant portion of the incoming tsunami of information. I describe the quality of participation that empowers the best of the bloggers, netizens, tweeters, and other online community participants; I examine how successful online collaborative enterprises contribute new knowledge to the world in new ways; and I present a lesson on networks and network building."

Net Smart seems like an insightful book that is extremely relevant to our times. The rapid and explosive growth of social media has created a bit of a free for all in online environments. This book gives some helpful reminders about how we can be mindful of our use of the internet and focus our attention utilizing it effectively.

Deconstructing sentence structures

Post by evansanford » Wed Sep 21, 2022 9:26 pm

"To unearth, that is to dig deep is called self-reflexivity."

Unearth: discover (something hidden, lost, or kept secret) by investigation or searching.

Dig: push or poke something in or into.

Deep: very intense or extreme.

Self-reflexivity: a way for you to super power your reflective process, and deepen on your path of personal growth

I've done much research on self-reflexivity and what it truly means, and reading this quote really emphasizes the truth behind it. To really be able to grow and develop as a person, you have to look at yourself very deeply. You have to unearth things about yourself that you wouldn't have been able to notice before. As mentioned before this quote, something speaks to someone because of some experience in the past. Looking at past experiences and how you reacted, processed, and thought about that experience is just the beginning of digging deep and achieving self-reflexivity. When I see this quote, I think of many decisions made in my past, and why I made those decisions. It is not an easy task, but it is crucial to developing on my path of personal growth and being the best person I can be.

About symbols

Post by evansanford » Wed Sep 21, 2022 9:44 pm

"The role of the symbolic is, then, to bring together and to unify."

Role: the function assumed or part played by a person or thing in a particular situation.

Symbol: a thing that represents or stands for something else, especially a material object representing something abstract.

Together: a thing that represents or stands for something else, especially a material object representing something abstract.

Unify: make or become united, uniform, or whole.

This quote is something that strikes me as fascinating is the word symbolic, which is something that represents or stands for something else, especially a material object representing something abstract. However, in the case of this quote, the symbolic is made to bring together and unify. In this quote, the symbolic are the symbols. I find it interesting that the ideas of symbols are symbolic themselves, in which they represent togetherness and unity. They bring together different ideas and thoughts into one entity. It could be anything, it could stand for anything, however, the idea of symbols is symbolic for bringing ideas into one.

Social constructionism

Post by evansanford » Wed Sep 21, 2022 9:55 pm

"Differences among people are created through social processes."

Differences: a point or way in which people or things are not the same.

People: human beings in general or considered collectively.

Created: bring (something) into existence.

Social Processes: the pattern of growth and change in a society over the years.

The definition of social processes is what's key in this quote. Very often in society, and as explained in class today, people often look into what is similar between each other to create and build relationships. When in reality, it is the differences between people that should be celebrated. There are billions of different people in this world that make up society and what it is today. It is constantly growing and ever-changing with different people, customs, and traditions. And this change is good. In the social processes definition, it is important to note that it is the pattern of growth in society over the years. As society changes, differences among people are created and this is a byproduct of the growth of society. The differences between people are what makes society work, it is crucial to maintaining a healthy place to live and develop.

About dichotomies

Post by evansanford » Wed Sep 21, 2022 10:05 pm

"We are suggesting that words, images, and ideas are not neutral reflections of reality."

Words: a single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing, used with others (or sometimes alone) to form a sentence and typically shown with a space on either side when written or printed.

Images: a representation of the external form of a person or thing in art.

Ideas: a thought or suggestion as to a possible course of action.

Neutral: not helping or supporting either side in a conflict, disagreement, etc.; impartial.

Reflections: caused by that attitude or situation and therefore reveals something about it

Reality: the world or the state of things as they actually exist, as opposed to an idealistic or notional idea of them.

This quote is one that really intrigued me in this letter. Reality is not one that is objective. Everything is subjective, whether consciously or subconsciously. Words, images, and ideas, which were present in our social meeting, are co-produced by the people involved. They are not neutral, as the quote explains. "They are the means through which we make our reality." We are in control of what we make of our reality through words, images, and ideas. Our reality is not set in stone. Our free will is what creates what life truly is.

The game of the social meeting exercise

Post by evansanford » Wed Sep 21, 2022 10:13 pm

"Our focus throughout the semester, in the fishbowl, is on language as a means of revealing how we construct and make reality."

Language: the principal method of human communication, consisting of words used in a structured and conventional way and conveyed by speech, writing, or gesture

Reveal: make (previously unknown or secret information) known to others.

Construct: an idea or theory containing various conceptual elements, typically one considered to be subjective and not based on empirical evidence.

Make: cause (something) to exist or come about; bring about.

Reality: the world or the state of things as they exist, as opposed to an idealistic or notional idea of them.

This quote from the letter is one that rings true in everyday life as well as in Japanese Story. In the movie, Sandy and Hiromitsu had very different cultures that at first didn't mesh well with each other. They didn't get along and were never on the same page. This caused a lot of problems with each other. However, the power of language is something that helped save them. Them talking to one another allowed them to learn more about each other's culture, and how to adapt to each of them and communicate the most efficiently. It may have seemed at first that their reality was very bleak and dangerous. However, through the use of language, they constructed and made a new reality, where a strong and fruitful relationship was built. Although Hiromitsu did tragically die, he did construct a different reality than the one Sandy and himself had before.

Aesthetic response again

Post by evansanford » Wed Sep 21, 2022 10:20 pm

"He suggests that we might think of the literary work as having two poles: the 'artistic' pole is the text created by the author, and the 'aesthetic' pole refers to "'the realization accomplished by the reader.'"

Literary: concerning the writing, study, or content of literature, especially of the kind valued for quality of form.

Artistic: having or revealing natural creative skill.

Text: a book or other written or printed work, regarded in terms of its content rather than its physical form.

Aesthetic: concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.

Realization: an act of becoming fully aware of something as a fact.

Accomplished: achieve or complete successfully.

This quote from Bryan's google search of Wolfgang Iser is similar to my research on him. When looking at literature, and any type of media in general, there are always two sides to it. What the author intends the reader to see, and what the reader actually realizes it. This is something that is very important to understand. One thing that makes this somewhat tricky is that everyone has their own biases, ideologies, and other thought processes that make that realization entirely different. It is something that many people look over in today's world, in which people are so quick to judge and criticize.

Mindfulness- the quality or state of being conscious or aware of something.

Google Searches - Ryan Loring

Post by ryanloring » Mon Sep 12, 2022 10:53 pm

9/10

The famous sociologist, Anthony Giddens, was known for his theory of structuration. He believed the actions of individuals along with the social forces that maintain societies were the two main driving factors in shaping our social reality. His outlook was that neither of these factors alone held the sole responsibility of forming societies. He also was known for his political philosophy, the third way, which proposed a new political standing located between the far right and far left. This was his alternative to capitalism.

Luce Irigaray is a well known French feminist who fights stereotypes based on differences in sexuality. She believes that Western cultures have no basis of a female subject when the conversation of sexuality arises. Specifically in American cultures, we resort to placing men above women when comparing the two. Throughout Irigaray's work, she explains that our conversations should shift to respecting the qualities of men and women as two separate entities.

Post by ryanloring » Tue Sep 13, 2022 1:02 pm

9/12

The founder of SOL (the Society of Organizational Learning), Peter Senge, works to create learning communities for primary and secondary education. He questioned, "how do we create the conditions for people to work together at their best, cultivating the innate systems intelligence that is our birthright but is all but lost in modern culture?". Senge wants to create a way of learning that would not be negatively affected by our culture, where people are capable of creating whatever they can think of.

The "Fifth Discipline", written by Peter Senge, delves into how we can transform our environment in order to nurture learning. The five disciplines discussed in the book come together to form a learning organization. Each discipline provides a theory that aids learning within a group.

Post by ryanloring » Tue Sep 13, 2022 1:25 pm

9/13

Wolfgang Iser was a scholar, famous for his reader-response criticism. He argues the meaning of a literary text is found somewhere between the connection of the text itself and the reader. While the text is a constant in each new connection it makes, each reader can interpret the text differently, thus shifting the meaning of the text. Iser believes these different interpretations readers can have on the same text, stem from unwritten words. Meaning the areas where an author might choose to exclude detail, leave space for each reader to let their imagination take control of the text and create their own understanding of what they are reading.

Post by ryanloring » Mon Sep 19, 2022 4:34 pm

9/17

The famous philosopher, Ludwig Wittgenstein, was known for his two publications, "Tractatus Logico Philosophicus" (1921) and the "Philosophical Investigations" (1953), which dove into the philosophy of language. Wittgenstein claimed, "The world is the totality of facts, not of things". He believed if one is not certain about what they are going to say, they shouldn't say anything at all. His goal was to peel back the layers of meaningless words and sayings of our languages, leaving us to strictly speak with certainty.

The well known sociologist, Pierre Bourdieu, thoroughly researched the sociology of culture, comprising many theories that connect one's social status to their personal taste. He outlined social capital as something that had to be earned through an individual's ability to utilize the resources available to them. Bourdieu believed people can be put into positions of power where social norms work to their advantage, but this doesn't give them the ability to gain further advantages in social status.

Self-reflexivity is the original act of self-poises and it comes into existence by virtue of its own activity.

Post by ryanloring » Mon Sep 19, 2022 5:25 pm

9/19

Social constructionism is a theory of knowledge in sociology that examines how individuals develop their knowledge and understanding of the world. It represents how our society tends to categorize individuals based on characteristics out of their control. Some of these would be race, gender, and ethnicity.

9/25 - Cognitive Mapping

Cognitive mapping refers to the mental picture our brain creates when we are given information. The most common form of this comes when we picture locations and other environmental landmarks.

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well.

Please see Jack Puccetti posting below regarding the social meeting exercise. It is well done and excellent in its 'cognitive-mapping’ (please google).

Some key considerations in the exercise.

1. Developing a good “word pool” is important. It is by substituting words that we move our thoughts, ideas and images forward.

2. The symbols (6 words from your ethnographic text) you select are culturally based and, pairing them into dichotomies is a creative act.

3. The structure of words (sentence) that you develop must be in relation to each other in the dichotomy. 

4. The particulars of your felt-experience of the social meeting must ‘fit’ with the generic structure of words that you constructed.

Ultimately, your social meeting (156 people in groups of three) will be ‘fragments’ on a digital screen, forever open to interpretation and re-interpretation. This is known as The Interface Effect (please google Alexander Galloway).

After you complete the exercise, I will be sure to congratulate you for the following reasons:

1. Your fragments are about thresholds. ‘Those mysterious zones of interaction that mediate between different realities.’ (Galloway)

2. Your fragments are autonomous zones of activity.

3. Your fragments illustrate, more or less, a specific interpretive method (please google)

4. Your method shares a great deal with what is known as ‘cognitive mapping’.

Please view your fragments in this light.

Sanjiv

Social Meeting Exercise

post by jackpuccetti » Sun Sep 25, 2022 4:24 pm

Nothing/Commute

Nothing - not anything; no single thing. Nil, Zero, Nought

Commute - travel some distance between one's home and place of work on a regular basis. Shuttle, Travel

The commute towards something, replaces the emptiness of the nothing; overcoming the nil through traveling towards a cure to void.

Before the social meeting, I had known nothing about my group mates and who they were. Our relationship represented the nothing. In our time together we commuted towards something. We grew as a group and learned about each other.

Think/Hand

Think - direct one's mind toward someone or something; use one's mind actively to form connected ideas. Ponder, Reflect, Deliberate, Contemplate, Cogitate

Hand - used in reference to the power to direct something. Control, Power, Charge, Responsibility, Jurisdiction, Grasp

With varying responsibilities at hand, leaders are forced to ponder, reflect, and make decisions based on prior situations and outside thinking.

During our time together, we took some time to speak about the class. Thinking before speaking, we were communicating our successes and understandings. We discussed our roles as participants in the fishbowl and our resources at hand.

Communication/Absence

Communication - the successful conveying or sharing of ideas and feelings. Contact, Relations, Connection, Interaction, Correspondence, Speaking

Absence - the nonexistence or lack of. Lack, Want, Nonexistence, Unavailability, Without, Exclusion

Through contact and interaction, individuals representing different parties are able to overcome a lack of information and create a better understanding of each other.

Our group used the meeting as a monumental point, the first time to communicate with one another. We rescheduled our meeting after the absence of one group member. He had been called into work. Our ability to overcome the obstacle prevented exclusion, made the meeting more cherishable, and forced the group to connect again and enabled the formation of relations.

Post by meehan392 » Sat Sep 24, 2022 4:04 pm

Learning through osmosis

What I learned and experienced....

The global revolution of thinking and perception is an evolving theory that proves itself quite often. Covid changed the outlook on many peoples lives, in the sense that it forced s to care about the ones that were not doing as well as us financially or physically. We also became more accustomed to living and working in the same environment. Covid made your average 8-5 worker realize the family time they were missing out on while working and commuting long days. From this status shift, we have experienced a large decline of people who want to work and actually put in the time to make a living for themselves and loved ones. Workers also realized that most of the work can be done at the house without productivity decreasing, eventually coming to the realization that a commute was a waste of money. Because of this, lots of workers whose jobs went fully remote during Covid are quitting their jobs since all their positions are demanding physical presence in the office.

THE DEPTH

		OF AN EXAMINED RELATIONSHIP 

		

		IS MATCHED

Management Passion in the New Millennium

Prologue

Midway, this way of life we’re bound upon

I woke to find myself in a dark wood,

Where the right road was wholly lost and gone.

Aye me, how hard to speak of it,

The rude and rough and stubborn forest,

The mere breath of memory stirs the old fear in the blood.

But when, at last, I stood beneath a steep hillside,

Which closed the valley’s wandering maze,

Whose dread had pierced me to the heart root deep.

Then I looked up and saw the morning rays

Mantle its shoulder from that planet bright

Which guides men’s feet aright

On all their ways.

		(from “Divina Commedia” by Dante Alighieri)

	

		 IN THE FISH-BOWL

Creating this fish-bowl is a performative act. It is a gesture for the continuation of a story... we’re writing as we go along… we do not know where it will lead, nor where it will end…but we know this for sure, it exists in our heads.

		

This is the story of two characters, matt and sanjiv, and the narrative unfolds in new england, at a small university near the ocean…where they’re swimming in a mental fish-bowl, combining Western sensibilities with Eastern ideas…in tryst with purpose, but shunning all direction, except an inner pressure to radicalize. One Viking, the other Sikh, they progress from liberating ego structures, through deeply bled wounds onto downward spirals of hatred and feelings of isolation, and then returning with renewed joy of understanding, forgiveness, and anticipation. Bringing a surging heritage (of bravery in battle) in their bloods, their forays range from existential arguments, to sudden affectionate détentes, and finally onto other arguments. Their relationship mirrors the profound changes in their lifestyles, in their conceptions of work, and of themselves. Determined to move away from conventional categories (of the division between self and other, of the representation of individuality, of established academic standards) in order to reflect a vision of themselves that transcends these boundaries in a new way. The two characters have an odd volatile nature to their wooing…their interactions end suddenly, and generally with puzzled amusement. They improvise, fabricate, and talk about dimensions and chemistry between people… at times their minds almost meet on the same page, until one makes a tiny faux pas that the other sees as shattering…they’re able to maintain this fragility by improvising from moment to moment. That is, they allow themselves to let their personalities and moods influence their performance but not alter the words or circumstances of the scene they enact in their minds…they really have very different ways of thinking, but are able to pass the ball back and forth easily, making for spontaneous fun.

So how do they do this in the fish-bowl? Like their characters, matt and sanjiv can’t agree. “The more I do it,” sanjiv said, “ the more I realize the character is me.” For matt, “it’s a matter of stripping down my defense mechanisms to being that vulnerable again.” Sanjiv countered: “I think for me it’s more building on top of me. I think.”

This interaction ended suddenly, as many interactions between matt and sanjiv, with puzzled bemusement.

Creating a Concept: the Fish-bowl

Instead of the idea of a relationship (like, teacher/student), attached to a real place (like, College of Business at URI), we created the idea of a place, attached to real people, namely, matt-and-sanjiv-in-a-fish-bowl. In this imaginary place, the Fish-bowl, with extraordinary patience and power, through words, we agreed to project awareness and unity of self as the principle theme. 

The Fish-bowl is a meeting place of the mind; it is a metaphysical place. There is no hiding here for matt-sanjiv because they’re simultaneously, observers and observed. 	

It cannot be assumed that the Fish-bowl is a determined, ordered system intelligible to the outsider who can discover the natural laws that govern matt-sanjiv, or that the role of reason is the power guiding matt-sanjiv.

Rationally and empirically, the Fish-bowl has no significance. It can only be seen in terms of the impact that the matt-sanjiv experience will make on its existence.

			

		2.20.99

My Dear Siddharatha,

During our period of estrangement, our inward journey was around doubts as to “who I am” and, “what I stand for,” i.e. who is the authentic self? Am I this, or, am I that? 

Through thought alone, one transcends a situation (of this/that), and thus we transcended our 

situation, comprising of hurt and feelings of insult, by conceiving the fish-bowl. However, to act upon thought, (beginning with the memo allocating matt’s assistantship to sanjiv), is a contingent act… to survive, to live, to be represented. Our contingent act was a gesture demarcating matt-sanjiv representation. Gesture demarcates, and so we conceive of ourselves…

				

The fish-bowl is

 			a contingent act 

a gesture 

 			to exist. 

The betrayal 

of ideas 

is a death 

to being. 

To open one’s mind 

and one’s mental routine 

to the world

is to open one’s heart.

From, 

your very dear friend, Hermann Hesse.

Our Intent: to Play a Unique Role

Our intent is to play a unique role in education: to gain intellect not through verbal discourse per se but through presentation of thought and action; not through involvement with people in an outside world but in a Way Within or an Inward Way that presents world as inner landscape, and so carry out in practice our theme of awareness and unity of self.

Fear of Expressing Feelings

We do not always express Feelings because they’re often Confused, and even Frightening. However, to deny Feelings is to make false, restricted work. To be inauthentic and fake.

In the fish bowl we’re learning to touch Feelings. We touch through expression, i.e. expressing conceptions and perceptions of things, including each other. Particularly, differences like viking/sikh, west/east, physical/ mental, student/teacher,love/hate, and other such dimensions. 

We touch Feelings under public gaze. We have a need to go public with every thing that we say or do.

We’re developing a need to write.

Management Principle 1: Conceiving Ambiguity, Creating Possibility

Ambiguous space is nonhierarchical, horizontal. Its nodes intersect in random, unregulated networks in which any node can interconnect with any other node. We create a new form of rhizomatic knowledge by mixing metaphors. Rhizome is a complex metaphor that contrasts with rooted, 

traditional metaphors, such as, teacher/student. In the fish-bowl, matt-and-sanjiv celebrate their nomadic and schizophrenic qualities. 

We’re motivated to do this because to conceive of ambiguity is to create possibility, and the stronger the ambiguity, the greater is our creativity, and the more powerful our felt-experience.

In the fish-bowl, we’ve created an ambiguious relationship between ourselves: 

we’ve fulfilled all formal requirements (papers, etc.), yet we’re inconclusive about them (grades, etc.); 

we’re not involved in each others research, yet our interaction is research; 

matt is paid fifteen hours/week to assist sanjiv, yet it is sanjiv who assists matt.

The ambiguity in our relationship creates possibility because it allows us to be anything we want. This freedom makes us examine each other in ways we hadn’t been able to see before.

				

Management Principle 2: Creating Myth

The “fish-bowl” is an example of creating a myth. Myth is created inter-subjectively between matt and sanjiv.

“Myth (of matt-sanjiv-in-a-fish-bowl) is a system of communication, it is a message. It is a mode of signification, a form. We assign to this form historical limits, conditions of use, and reintroduce community into it: we must nevertheless first describe it as a form.” (roland barthes)

We use our imagination to describe our form of myth.

The matt-sanjiv form is diasporic ambiguity.

The college of business at URI is percieving and experiencing it.

	Management Principle 3: Create Myth/Intersubjectivity/Intertextuality

Intersubjectivity helps matt-sanjiv to see that most human experience and action goes on between the self and others.

Myth creates Inter-subjectivity; and Inter-subjectivity creates Myth. However, in the fish-bowl the notion of Intertextuality replaces that of Intersubjectivity. “Every text is constructed as a mosaic of other texts, every text is an absorbtion and transformation of other texts” (julia kristeva). Through their intersubjectivity and intertextuality, around the texts of T.E. Lawrence (Lawrence of Arabia), Rainer Rilke (German poet), and Thomas Becket (Archbishop of Canterbury), among others, matt-sanjiv create the myth of the fish-bowl. 

					2.19.99

Dear Matt,

Thank you for expressing feelings so eloquently through the mouth of Mr. Kappus. 

You are Mr. Kappus. 

When reading our exchange of letters, it is evident that one’s authentic self is indeed problematic in a situation where one can be anything one wants. 

		 			We can be friends forever.

Between ourselves: Mr. Kappus, T.E Lawrence, the English, Rilke, Sartre, Hesse, the German, Eriksen, Viking, Siddharatha, Buddha, the Indian, Eakins, the American, Dugal, Sikh, Baudelaire, the French, the West and the East, we’re creating an inter-textuality, an inter-subjectivity, and a shared memory. Indeed, we’re creating our context. We’re laying the foundation. 

Through this labyrinthe lies the inward journey of the subjective self. 

I find your words,“ Even when overcome by feelings of hate, I still knew that our relationship was a source of great knowledge and understanding” to be most telling of our universal condition, because the central problem is not an abstract one, but one of contingency: what we lack is certainty, confidence, sense of purpose to break paradoxical situations like feelings of hate/ and feelings of great understanding. That is, the more I hate, the more I understand, and the more I understand, the more I hate. 

			

If we had more access to our own past, to memory, to inter-textuality and inter-subjectivity, our sense of purpose would be immensely augmented. Hesse’s Steppenwolf expressed this sense of meaning due to re-possession of the past: 

“For moments together my heart stood still between delight and sorrow to find how rich was the gallery of my life, and how thronged the soul of the wretched steppenwolf with high eternal stars and constellations… the kernel of this life of mine was noble. It came of high descent and turned, not on trifles, but on the stars…”(Steppenwolf, Hesse).

From your friend, Sanjiv

Dear Lief Erikson theViking,

One’s position within a relationship, like,Viking-Sikh, has to do with intersubjective interpretation, in other words, position is determined by our past (shared memory), our present (interpretation), and, our future (imagination). 

The activities representing the past, present, and future, are overlapping in the new millennium to the extent of becoming indistinguishable. We’re experiencing confusion, loss of control, etc. In such a situation, how do I determine my sense of self? 

To do so, I reveal a structure, or deconstruct one, or imaginatively construct one…here’s mine: “I was sent to these Arabs as a stranger, unable to think their thoughts or subscribe their beliefs, but charged by duty to lead them forward and to develop to the highest any movement of theirs profitable to England in her war. If I could not assume their character, I could atleast conceal my own, and pass among them without evident friction, neither a discord nor a critic but an unnoticed influence. Since I was their fellow I will not be their apologist or advocate. Today in my old garments, I could play the bystander, obedient to the sensibilities of our theatre…but it is more honest to record that these ideas and actions then passed naturally. What now looks wanton or sadic seemed in the field inevitable or just unimportant routine.” (T.E. Lawrence, Seven Pillars of Wisdom, 1926)

What is our intersubjective interpretation of the above text with regard to us, as Viking-Sikh? Here is a random list of specifics for us to address in the fish-bowl:

 4. raise the stakes

Yours truly,

				

Sardar Bahadur Singh the Sikh

Management Principle 4: Experiencing Learning

In the fish-bowl the problem of Being takes precedence over that of Knowing (when acquiring a Ph.D. or anything else). 

“Being cannot be made a subject of objective enquiry; it is revealed to the individual by reflecting on his own unique concrete existence in time and space. Existence is basic: it is the fact of the individual’s presence and participation in a changing and potentially dangerous world. Each self-aware individual understands his own existence in terms of his experience of himself and of his situation. The self of which he is aware is a thinking being which has beliefs, hopes, fears, desires, the need to find a purpose, and a will that can determine his actions.” (sartre)

	Real and Unreal:

We are free to choose between authentic and fake as a form of existence. Freedom distinguishes between “authentic” and “inauthentic” forms of existence. 

In the fish-bowl we distinguish between authentic/fake on the basis of our endeavor to transcend a particular dimension or form. 

This endeavor is the matt-sanjiv form of Authenticity.

We are free to choose our reality.

Our Method: the Interplay between Verbalized-Thought and Felt-Experience

In the fish-bowl, the interplay between our two distinct identities brought complexity and depth to our respective worlds. We interpreted text (and each-other), as we saw (perceived) and felt (experienced) it. Even as we respect another’s text, we brought our subjectivity to bear upon it. We infused the text with our individual being; not the other way round. The text did not infuse us. 

In other words, we used words as expressions of sensed-thought (felt-experience) rather than as verbalized-thought in promoting the idea of unity above the inner divisions between us. Our interpreted text reveals us and reflects on us.

Example of Verbalized-thought:

“That evening, I found that I had to untangle two different reactions, writing a description of the conversation and, carefully separated, an expression of my feelings as a member of another culture. Each person is calibrated by experience, almost like a measuring instrument for difference, so discomfort is informative and offers a starting point for new understanding. Indeed, what I had seen and heard would not have pushed me to reflection and generalization were it not for the urgency produced by the sense of difference.”

(Mary Catherine Bateson, Peripheral Visions, page 17)

Example of Felt-experience:

In the fish-bowl we found

we had to untangle two processes:

description of the script (between us), 

and carefully separated, 

expression of (our) feelings.

WORDS DESCRIBE, STEP BACK, FEELINGS EXPRESS

We experience difference through the expression of feelings.

Discomfort from difference is Information;

Information is a starting point for new Understanding.

		

EXPERIENCE DIFFERENCE THRU EXPRESSION

	(My) experence, 

Makes (me)

different (from you).

difference (from you)

Makes (me) 

experience (you).

 DIFFERENCE CREATES SOMETHING NEW

The urgency 

produced by our sense of difference

Forces us to 

Reflect and Transcend the situation.

From the above method, what we learned about ourselves and for the practice of management were the following:

Construct a text/written script

express feelings

expressing feelings makes for difference 

sense of difference produces urgency

 			urgency requires us to reflect, and to transcend

			the written text…

Principle activity: create a sense of difference to achieve unity above inner divisions.
