Date: 9/23/2022 0:29:56
Subject: completing the social meeting exercise
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well. Whenever I experience anxiety and distress, I have found, being close to text invariably leads to survival, sustainability and success. This is true for both the individual and the group.

Being close to text is a practice of mindfulness. Please google the term. What does it mean?

‘Mindfulness is the basic human ability to be fully present, aware of where we are and what we’re doing, and not overly reactive or overwhelmed by what’s going on around us.

While mindfulness is something we all naturally possess, it’s more readily available to us when we ‘practice’ on a daily basis.

Whenever you bring awareness to what you’re directly experiencing via your senses, or to your state of mind via your thoughts and emotions, you’re being mindful. And there’s growing research showing that when you train your brain to be mindful, you’re actually remodeling the physical structure of your brain.’

To complete the social meeting exercise, we raise the question, how is one to be mindful of what transpired at the social meeting?

Step 1. Select 6 symbols from your ethnographic text

From your ethnographic text and your pre-narrative, select 6 words that are symbols, word-images and metaphors. That is, each word represents something else. It is a symbol for something else. So say, if your group member didn’t respond, leaving a gap in the social meeting, what would that be a symbol of, what word? ‘Neglect,’ or something else, ‘anxiety,’ ‘overwhelm?’ 

You are selecting 6 symbols. Tread carefully my friend!

Be aware of your mind when making the selection. You are watching your decision making process, and sharing it.

Step 2. Create 3 dichotomies

Create three dichotomies from the six words, I.e., pair them up.

The dichotomy words must be different from each other and not an adjective to the other. They are to be two disparate elements.

This step calls for your creativity. The best way to put it would be by analogy: which two colors are you selecting to paint the sunset?

Your dichotomy lays the foundation for the structure of the sentence and the felt-experience that you are about to do in the following steps.

Step 3. Word-pool

For each dichotomy, create a word-pool by taking each of the two words further (look up dictionary and thesaurus). You are looking to substitute the original words, to further your understanding.

The word-pool marks the boundary of words from which you are going to make a structure (one sentence) that relates the two words of the dichotomy.

Keep it simple. Very important. More interested in see you getting familiar with the process.

You are taking two disparate elements, and relating them together.

Step 4. Sentence structure

From the word pool, you are creating a structure of words, I.e., a syntax.

Your sentence is an abstraction of universal meaning that relates two disparate elements into a structure.

Keep it simple but beautiful. See it as a work of art. Like fine food, some people appreciate fine sentences.

“ And the words slide into the slots ordained by syntax, and glitter as with atmospheric dust with those impurities which we call meaning.” (Anthony Burgess)

Step 5. Felt-experience

A description of a particular incident that you experienced and felt at the social meeting exercise. This feeling must fit the abstract sentence in Step 4. It is moving from the general to the specific.

Purpose of the Exercise

I believe that the best hope for our species lies in learning new patterns of attention to each other and to the biosphere, patterns that grow out of curiosity and respect and allow for wonder and learning.

Please see the attached prototype of the fishbowl

Sanjiv

Steps for Doing The Friendship/Social group exercise: a conversation to get to know each other.

Ethnography is defined as the ‘scientific description’ of the customs of individual peoples and cultures.

Sacred Space

post by Erikyoungstrom » Tue Sep 13, 2022 7:16 pm

"Sacred spaces are ambivalent. They are located in the here and now and at the same time function as openings, thresholds, portals to another world, a world of gods and spirits, a larger universe, the cosmos."

A holy asylum, especially a church or other sacred location, linked the right to provide shelter from arrest and the usual operation of the law to criminals, debtors, and others who take refuge inside its borders.

A sacred space is a must-have for anybody nowadays. You must have a room, or a set hour or so each day, where you don't know what was in the news that morning, who your friends are, what you owe anyone, and what anyone owes you. This is where you may be and express who you are and who you could become. This is the incubator for unique ideas. You may initially discover that nothing happens there. I believe if you have a sacred site and use it, something will happen eventually.

Date: 9/13/2022 13:57:06
Subject: about reading and aesthetic responses
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? It is wise to attend classes these days, particularly when attendance is not mandatory. You and I are going to class these days in order to REALIZE any one or more of the following metaphors:

get the drift; 

be in the mood; 

on the same page; 

get the hang of it; 

get a sense of; 

be ahead of the game; 

discern and visualize the end; 

be with it; and, 

so on. 

This letter is about reading. 

The text in my letters represents a potential effect that is realized in the reading process.

Reading is therefore the focal point, for it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend both on the text and on the exercise of certain basic human faculties.

The poles of text and reader, together with the interaction that occurs between them, forms the ground-plan on which our semester is to be built. 

An “aesthetic response” (please google Wolfgang Iser) is analysed in terms of a DIALECTIC relationship between text, reader, and their interaction. 

It is called aesthetic response because, although it is brought about by the text, it brings into play the imaginative and perceptive faculties of the reader, in order to make them adjust and even differentiate their own focus.

Since our work in the fishbowl arises from our interaction with texts, there can be no denying the importance of what happens to us through these texts.

For this reason, your fishbowl is to be considered not as a documentary record of something that exists or has existed, but as a reformulation of an already formulated reality which brings into the world something that did not exist before.

Sanjiv

Post by harryrunci » Sun Sep 11, 2022 10:50 pm

‘There is a global revolution going on in how we think of ourselves and how we form ties and connections with others.’

Despite the fact that this quote comes from a 1999 lecture series, it remains very relevant today, especially in the age of the Internet, smart phones, and social media. These networks and instruments have drastically impacted how we form ties and connections with others, and have great influence on Giddens' noted three "forms of relations": sex and love; parent-child relations; and friendship. From the invention of dating apps like Tinder, to the simple text message from a parent to child living across the country, to using Instagram to keep tabs on your friends, the global revolution is abundantly clear. Today's society is one of interconnectedness, that is impacted greatly by ever-changing technology. This affects not only our relations with others, but also how we think of ourselves. Social media influencers can share media that reinforce unrealistic expectations, specifically of their bodies, which can be damaging to their followers who may idolize them.

Post by harryrunci » Sun Sep 11, 2022 10:59 pm

"We cannot share the world as it already is, with the exception of the natural world. The world that we can share is always and still to be elaborated by us and between us starting from the perception and affirmation of what and who we are as humans here and now.”

I do find this quote to be a bit confusing, and I am not exactly sure what to make of it. However, the message I take from it is that the world is what we choose to make of it, and we are in control of what we do and how we perceive what we do. While the natural world may be more fixed, as humans we make things happen and it is on us to make progress.

September 7 to October 31 will be an intense time. 

To be intense, you have to immerse yourself in a particular context and figure out what is going on.

INTENSE, IMMERSE, CONTEXT

The construction of the syllabus was indeed an intense time, as I’ve been immersed in the subject matter, via text, images and self-reflections. 

I’ve been developing a ‘lens’ through which to view the world and our situation in it. Yours and mine. 

Vision, Entrepreneurship, and Leadership.

How we perceive the world, impacts our experience of it.

As an example of this truism, your introductory assignment will be addressing the question: how does one forge a friendship in the digital workplace? Underlying this question is the ability to ‘see’ the other, the different. When we can ‘see’ each other, an authentic dialog and friendship becomes possible. More details will follow.

FORGE, FRIENDSHIP

All the best for the semester. Wishing you a wonderful time, good health and lots of learning. In that order!

Sincerely,

Sanjiv Dugal

Ps: we will not be working through Brightspace because it doesn’t meet the objectives of this course.

Date: 5/2/2022 18:36:27
Subject: participation in learning (1)
------------------------------------------------------------
High Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are doing well.

When giving an account of one’s participation in learning, acknowledging divergent meanings is essential when trying to make sense of our learning in MGT345 and 448, for there are often taken-for-granted assumptions about participation; what is its form, what is its doing and its effects.In the literature, in management education and organizational practice it is often assumed that there is an agreement on the type of participation carried out, for example, that this is task orientation, this is coaching, this is delegation, etc. In other words all involved agree what will take place and how to label this participation.

However, this alignment of meaning --- shared understanding of what is going on --- cannot be taken for granted. Often people participating in learning view things differently. Our participation and the role we play are no exception. For instance, I have a colleague who sees herself as a Leader, but i see her as an Administrator. Another example: those who receive an A in MGT345 and 448, I perceive them to be co-authors and not students. We have co-produced a text of value and proven merit as collaborators in a knowledge economy. 

In other words, the categories one creates, has little to do with how others perceive it and nor what they feel about it.

The purpose of this email is to facilitate a more qualified understanding of the significance of the alignment of meanings in constructions of work, learning, participation and outcomes. Non-participation may be about disagreements and conflicts, but also ambiguities and confusions. Forms and sources of non-participation are topics of continual interest for creating added value.

Most traditional understandings of learning participation includes a speaker at a podium saying something and followers responding to that, together shaping some form of influencing process and resulting outcomes. This framework provides for 

what the speaker brings to the podium and does (i.e., the influencing process)

and 

how the followers perceive and attribute meaning to their learning participation (i.e., the resulting outcome).

An effort to influence through one’s text does not necessarily lead to the targeted outcome. 

The influence of selected words, 

their perception by a participating viewer, and 

the resulting feeling or outcome,

should not be labeled together for they don’t necessarily coincide.

Combining one’s influence, the other’s perception and the overall feeling in one box (Yes/No) encourages a tendency to produce built-in results and insensitivity to the learning process and relational issues. For, the words you select may have nothing to do with how I, the other, came to see it, nor what I feel about it. 

Bottom line: When it is learning, participation and work that one is focusing on, the participant’s dispositional characteristics and behaviors, perceptions and attributions, and the context --- should each be considered separately, if participation in learning is to be investigated seriously.

I am talking about making money doing business across borders and mental structures. Please see Grant Fawcett’s reflection below.

Sanjiv

ALLIGNMENT, INFLUENCE, DIVERGENT, ACKNOWLEDGE

from the fishbowl...

The fishbowl has digital citizens and eager learners. We are hungry for knowledge and thirsty for realizations. We are indulging together and digesting these tasty morsels of information while thinking about the how so question. This will ultimately allow us to shake hands with words and sentences that are relevant when interacting with cultures unknown. This capability can be used as a weapon in an arsenal of diplomacy. Being able to connect with those who have disparate value-systems is a skill that will open doors not thought possible.

Date: 5/2/2022 0:08:50
Subject: self-valorization
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope the ending of the semester is going well for you. 

In the fishbowl, there is no right/wrong answer nor a right/wrong way of doing things.

Digital technology has transcended this dichotomy, that is to say, in the digital world, you have the power to be and do anything you want.

In which case, the more relevant question becomes: 

Did You or Did You Not Do It? The process and practice, that is. 

And, the how becomes the next logical question.

The 'How you did it' creates 'use-value' and 'exchange-value’ and has financial implications in a knowledge economy

"No ambition, however extravagant, no fantasy, however outlandish, can any longer be dismissed as crazy or impossible. This is the age when you can finally do it all ...

Suddenly technology has given us powers with which we can manipulate not only external reality -- the physical world -- but also, and much more portentously, Ourselves. You can becomw whatever you want to be”

Ed Regis, On Extropians

In other words, you select the word(s), and construct any dichotomy and position yourself on any dimension. 

Structure/Plane: 

Dichotomy/Dimension 

MGT345 is about dichotomies; MGT448 is about dimensions.

Did you select the right/wrong word?

Does your dichotomy and dimension create value?

Only the artistic entrepreneur can answer these questions for themselves. 

The digital production process is both a labour process creating use-values and a value-creation process through which additional new value is created. 

If your work has no satisfactory value, do it again, i.e., change and re-create your selection of word(s).

Your freedom to choose is the working of artists in a creative process.

Autonomous, self-development and self-valorization are at the heart of pricing in the digital economy.

Please see Rowan Coleman’s reflection below.

Sanjiv

VALORIZE, AUTONOMOUS, DEVELOPMENT, CHOICE, TRANSCEND, DICHOTOMY, STRUCTURE, DIMENSION, PLANE

from the fishbowl...

rowancoleman

Posts: 108

Joined: Mon Jan 24, 2022 2:13 pm

Post by rowancoleman » Sat Apr 30, 2022 2:56 pm

Google Search: Stanley Fish

Fish’s importance resides mainly in that he is an exemplar of recent academic trends. He chiefly represents himself—he does that quite well—but he may also represent something of the postmodern academic life: its self-satisfaction, its self-promotion, its glibness. If the humanities are in trouble today, humanists like Fish are one of the reasons (https://newrepublic.com/article/114224/stanley-fish-careerism)

My take: I think it is rather pretentious to assume that simply because Fish is exploring new forms of representing academia, rather in a buisness, social, or personified, is bad. Exploring new realms of thought should never be frowned upon or seen as "suppressing humanities" Humanities are faced with their own problems caused by a lack of inspired creativity, and a lack of awareness, there are in fact not dying however. Yes, this is my opinion, but I see the humanities as evolving, and those who do not see that are stuck in the pre-digital age.

From the "narration: ways of operating" letter:

"Your "ways of operating" or doing things is made possible by your inquiries and hypotheses (vocabularies, google searches and felt-experiences), that indicate pathways for further research. Please fact check in these terms".

Fact check: We are all operating in our own way in the fishbowl. More specifically, we are all posting vocabulary words, google searches, and felt-experiences at different times and in different ways. We are allowed to post whenever we want, and we are able to expand our thoughts without having to write them in a specific way. We can even organize the content how we like in our fishbowl. We have the freedom to learn, create, and be ourselves in the fishbowl. I believe this is an impactful way of learning because we can choose to learn in the ways we learn best. Only we can know that for ourselves. The "way" we do all of these things in the fishbowl defines our ways of operating (and additionally, our ways of learning).

chloedegrauw

Posts: 48

Joined: Mon Jan 24, 2022 11:01 am

Post by chloedegrauw » Wed Apr 20, 2022 7:08 pm

Natural Language Generation: NLG is the use of artificial intelligence programming to produce written or spoken narratives from a data set. NLG can generate thousands of data-driven narratives in minutes using the right data in the right format. In addition, NLG is one of the fastest growing technologies being adopted into companies with cases commonly focused on the automation of time-intensive copywriting and reporting activities. NLG is very beneficial to companies in these fields because it provides high-quality content, increased content generation, conserving human energy for high-value activities, and being able to personalize at scale. NLG is known to become highly prevalent in the future as companies will be more dedicated to have technological advancements. 

Karl Weick and Sense Making: Karl Weick was an organizational theorist who introduced the concepts of loose coupling, mindfulness, and sense making into organizational studies. Weick defines sense making as "the ongoing retrospective development of plausible images that rationalize what people are doing". Sense making requires a focus on what people do, how they do it, and why they do it that way. This is important as others experiences can be interpreted in multiple ways.

Post by chloedegrauw » Tue Apr 26, 2022 8:17 pm

Empire by Hardt and Negri: Empire is a book written by Michael Hardt and Antonio Negri who were post-Marxist philosophers. The book tells a story of the Empire and the Multitude, the Empire is the form of sovereignty that exists under conditions of globalization. Hardt and Negri constitutes a new theory on the transition from modern to postmodern imperialism and ruling powers. 

EDULEARN22: EDULEARN is an international conference on education and new learning technologies taken place each summer. It is one of the largest conferences for lecturers, researchers, technologists, and professionals from the educational sector. In this conference, experts will get together to share their knowledge on teaching and learning methodologies and educational innovations. In addition, EDULEARN provides the opportunity for strategic international networking. 

Richard Rorty: Rorty was an American philosopher who had strong interests and training in the history of philosophy and in contemporary analytic philosophy. Rorty developed a distinctive and controversial brand of pragmatism that expressed itself along two main axes of modern philosophy and traditional problems with epistemology and metaphysics. Rorty's work consisted of the integration and apply milestone achievements of Dewey, Hegel, and Darwin in a pragmatist synthesis of historicism and naturalism. 

Gestalt Psychology and Phenomenology: Gestalt psychology is a movement in psychology founded in the early 20th century seeking to explain perceptions in terms of gestalts rather than by analyzing their constituents. Gestalt psychology suggests that structures have specific properties that are different from the sum of their individual parts. The Gestalt therapy have been known as the "therapy of the obvious" because phenomenology involves the process of discovering the obvious rather than relying on interpreting. 

Reflexive Methodology: New Vistas for Qualitative Research: This book was written by Mats Alvesson and Kaj Skoldberg. The writers associate techniques used in empirical research with different research traditions, giving a theoretically informed approach to qualitative research. In addition, the book involves questioning one's own taken for granted assumption and draws attention to the researcher as opposed to pretending they did not have an impact or influence. 

Reflexive Leadership: Organising in an Imperfect World: This book was written by Martin Blom, Mats Alvesson, and Stefan Sveningsson. In this book, the writers focus on an reflexive approach on leadership and discuss alternatives to leadership. The writers center around how leadership is a source of organizations problems. With in depth studies and interviews of professionals, managers, and subordinates the writers interpret their observations of others perspectives to question dominant leadership thinking. 

Net Smart by Howard Rheingold: Net Smart shows readers on how to use social media intelligently, humanely, and mindfully. To have a mindful use of digital media means to think about what we are doing and an inner question on how we want to spend our time. Rheingold wants to help others reach this mindset by outlining five fundamental digital literacies that are attention, participation, collaboration, critical consumption of information, and network smarts. As well as pointing out a bigger social issue at work in digital literacy. Rheingold believes if we all combine our individual efforts wisely will result in a more thoughtful society. 

Discourse Analysis: Discourse analysis is a research method for studying written or spoken language in relation to its social context. This analysis is used to examine and deconstruct the underlying meanings 'beyond the sentence'. It is a qualitative method of ways of constituting knowledges with social practices and forms of subjectivity to make relations between them.

Post by chloedegrauw » Tue Apr 26, 2022 11:08 pm

Relational Thinking: Relational thinking is the capacity to manipulate in our minds abstract mental representations of relations among objects, attributes, and events is central to human thinking and learning. Relational thinking allows you to have an understanding of knowing both what to do and why. Having relational understanding can allow you to learn new concepts easier, retain previous concepts, and are able to deviate formulas or rules given different problems easier because of the connections they have made. 

Critical-making: Critical-making is a process-oriented and scholarship-oriented that emphasizes the shared acts of making rather than the graphic object. It refers to the hands-on productive activities that link digital technology to society.

Conversation Analysis: Conversation analysis is an approach to the study of social interaction, embracing both verbal and non-verbal conduct, in situations of everyday life. Conversation analysis focuses on how sequences of action are generated. When conducting the analysis, analysts identify three elements of a conversation which is the speaking turn, the adjacency pair, and the sequential implicativeness. 

Cultural Communication: Cultural communication is the use of language and other communicative means to carry out the activities and commitments of their particular communities in and through the use of symbolic resources. Ways to approach cultural communication are social science, interpretive, critical, and dialectical. 

Cultural Capital: The French sociologist, Pierre Bourdieu, developed the idea of cultural capital as a way to explain how power in society was transferred and classes maintained. Cultural capital is the accumulation of knowledge, behaviors, and skills that a person can tap into to demonstrate one's cultural competence and social status. Cultural capital is having assets that give us social mobility to help achieve goals without necessarily having wealth or financial capital. It influences the ways in which individuals and groups define and access other forms of capital. In addition, it can be acquired through daily, mundane interactions with acquaintances and even strangers. 

Pierre Bourdieu: Pierre Bourdieu was a French sociologist and public intellectual who made significant contributions to general sociological theory. Bourdieu theorized the link between education and culture, and research into the intersections of taste, class, and education.

Post by chloedegrauw » Tue Apr 26, 2022 11:08 pm

Relational Thinking: Relational thinking is the capacity to manipulate in our minds abstract mental representations of relations among objects, attributes, and events is central to human thinking and learning. Relational thinking allows you to have an understanding of knowing both what to do and why. Having relational understanding can allow you to learn new concepts easier, retain previous concepts, and are able to deviate formulas or rules given different problems easier because of the connections they have made. 

Critical-making: Critical-making is a process-oriented and scholarship-oriented that emphasizes the shared acts of making rather than the graphic object. It refers to the hands-on productive activities that link digital technology to society.

Conversation Analysis: Conversation analysis is an approach to the study of social interaction, embracing both verbal and non-verbal conduct, in situations of everyday life. Conversation analysis focuses on how sequences of action are generated. When conducting the analysis, analysts identify three elements of a conversation which is the speaking turn, the adjacency pair, and the sequential implicativeness. 

Cultural Communication: Cultural communication is the use of language and other communicative means to carry out the activities and commitments of their particular communities in and through the use of symbolic resources. Ways to approach cultural communication are social science, interpretive, critical, and dialectical. 

Cultural Capital: The French sociologist, Pierre Bourdieu, developed the idea of cultural capital as a way to explain how power in society was transferred and classes maintained. Cultural capital is the accumulation of knowledge, behaviors, and skills that a person can tap into to demonstrate one's cultural competence and social status. Cultural capital is having assets that give us social mobility to help achieve goals without necessarily having wealth or financial capital. It influences the ways in which individuals and groups define and access other forms of capital. In addition, it can be acquired through daily, mundane interactions with acquaintances and even strangers. 

Pierre Bourdieu: Pierre Bourdieu was a French sociologist and public intellectual who made significant contributions to general sociological theory. Bourdieu theorized the link between education and culture, and research into the intersections of taste, class, and education.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 4/18/2022 2:06:07
Subject: journey that interrogates and explores
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? 

The fishbowl takes us on a journey that interrogates and explores.

How so?

Every posting in the fishbowl is an “Event" whose occurrence (for instance, please see Daelynn Casavant’s fishbowl postings below) brings to light possibilities that were invisible or even unthinkable; they propose something to the viewer.

After that, every thing depends on how the possibility, opened up by the “event," is 'grasped, elaborated and embedded' in the world. 

Alain Badiou (please google) calls this the “truth procedure.”

The “event" by each of your postings creates a possibility, but there then has to be an effort---a group effort in the case of politics, an individual effort in the case of love or art--- for this possibility to become real and inscribed in the world. To that end, I wish to congratulate all of you receiving this letter. Our Abstract, which represents our knowing and knowledge content in the fishbowl, has been accepted. I will forward the acceptance letter and what possibilities this “event" opens for you. It is indeed, a feather in our caps! Running with the wolves! A star in our crowns!

Tomorrow, Monday I will be available for any questions or clarifications regarding your process in the fishbowl and your grade expectations; please stop by at any of the venues:

110 Bliss Hall at 10am

244 Chafee at 1pm and

104 Quinn Hall at 2.

Sanjiv

EVENT, CREATE, POSSIBILITY, EFFORT, GRASP, ELABORATE, EMBEDDED, INSCRIBE

from the fishbowl...

Joined: Mon Jan 24, 2022 9:36 am

Post by daelynncasavant » Sun Apr 17, 2022 11:44 am

Deep Thinking 

Essential Ingredient 

An essential ingredient is something that creates an experience or physical item. It can be either small or large yet its impact is critical to the overall result. 

How to deploy Attention 

Knowing how to Deploy Attention is an important skill in order to enhance relationships in life. Being able to listen and pay attention is an extremely important attribute to have. 

Know -How 

I interpret know-how as almost a way of possessing common sense. Knowing how to do something or being aware of what's around you without being told directly. 

Personal Empowerment 

Personal empowerment is being able to encourage yourself and embrace the best parts of yourself. This will help you succeed and achieve a sense of confidence and pride within yourself and your work. 

Right Know-how 

The Right Know-How is almost an extension of Know-How yet is being right about your instincts and your interpretation of the situation. 

Enhance 

The ability to enhance or something in which is enhanced is very important. It takes the best aspects of something and increases their impact. 

Add up to a public good 

This phrase is very important, it implies that simple aspects build up to create something of importance. 

Enriches 

To enrich something can mean to find a deeper meaning. Or to look for other connections to one aspect, to find the connections it has. Enrichment is a powerful tool and something that allows us to grow as humans and a society. 

Vocab 

Deploy:bring into effective action; utilize.

My Interpretation: When I hear this term it makes me think of the military phrase. However I also find this interpretation very interesting. 

Attention:notice taken of someone or something; the regarding of someone or something as interesting or important. 

My interpretation: I interpret this as the undivided focus of a subject or person 

Architecture:the art or practice of designing and constructing buildings

My interpretation: I interpret Architecture as the creation of stable structures often times revolutionary to their time. 

Participate :take part in an action or endeavor.

My interpretation: I interpret participate as the active engagement in an activity 

Know-How:practical knowledge or skill; expertise

My Interpretation: I interpret Know-How similarly to as i described above, another way of mentioning common sense. 

Empower:make (someone) stronger and more confident, especially in controlling their life and claiming their rights.

My interpretation: I interpret empower as a way to increase the capability of yourself or others. 

Enrich:improve or enhance the quality or value of. 

My interpretation: I interpret enrich as finding the deeper meaning behind something. 

Enhance:intensify, increase, or further improve the quality, value, or extent of.

My Interpretation: I interpret Enhance as the greater magnification of a topic or subject.

Date: 4/15/2022 19:08:10
Subject: being a 'critically autonomous person'
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? 

What does it mean to lead an ethical life under vexed social and linguistic conditions that you experience in the fishbowl?

 

The fishbowl, upon completion, offers a provocative outline for a new ethical practice --- one responsive to the need for 'critical autonomy' (please see attached note) yet grounded in the ‘opacity' of the human subject. Please see Alex Miller’s posting below.

In which case, the central question in the fishbowl becomes one of ‘recognition’ and, the question is a direct one addressed to the other: 

“Who are you?”

You and I began our relation in digital space, i.e., the fishbowl, when you first addressed the question to the Course's Instructor, Professor Sanjiv Dugal: "who are you?"

Now, having been on a cerebral journey together in the fishbowl, we raise the question: who are you?

For me, your response to the question 'who are you’ is categorized collectively by yourselves as: A, A-, B+ and B.

It is basically three boxes that the majority of you represent: A, A- and B+ with a few outliers.

I hope my understanding alleviates any stress around the matter of grades.

Sanjiv

VEX, SOCIAL, LINGUISTIC, CONDITION, RECOGNITION, ETHICAL, PRACTICE, AUTONOMY, OPACITY

from the fishbowl...

Notes On Critical Autonomy...

The basic idea of critical autonomy (as I understand it) is that 

one holds oneself to consistent criteria for evaluation of traits, like 

credibility, accuracy, point of view, etc. 

Every man should have a built-in automatic crap detector operating inside him (Ernest Hemingway, 1965).

The basic features of most informational texts, like our postings in the fishbowl, is an understanding (or, when necessary, seeking understanding) of the “how and why” of the constructedness of our text, from the most personal/amateur (a YouTube video or an email from a friend, say) to the most professional (a Hollywood blockbuster or fashion magazine).

A “critically autonomous person” can either answer questions about a given thing or would also know what kinds of questions to ask about the thing. 

Tthe critically autonomous person watching Kinky Boots and Japanese Story understands the nuts and bolts of its construction, and the variety of context for its presentation, and ways of finding out more information (by exploring spaces like fishbowl postings) to TRIANGULATE the source. The critically autonomous person watching ‘film' knows something about film production and film financing, and knows something about genre, and knows something about values embedded in the representation of subjects on the screen.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

post by alexamiller » Wed Apr 13, 2022 4:22 pm

Step 1: 

Word Pool: 

Integrate: fused, assimilate, combine, intermix, join, blend, together, mesh, unite, coordinate

Network: associate, mingle, meet, interconnections, organization, similarity, community, connect, interchange

Structure: formation, makeup, layout, construct, build, assemble, organization, composition, order, arrangement

Symbols Definition: a thing that represents or stands for something else, especially a material object representing something abstract.

Images Definition: a representation of the external form of a person or thing in art.

Representations Definition: the description or portrayal of someone or something in a particular way or as being of a certain nature.

Step 2: 

My Sentence: 

- When mingling and associating with others, it is possible to gain insight as to what their community consists of; and what makes the people unite and blend together.

Step 3: 

When coming to college a lot of mingling and blending together with new groups of people occurred to me. I am from out of state, so coming to URI and Rhode Island in general was like diving into a whole new community of people. Even though I lived only a few hours away from URI, initially everyone and the community that was already built here was foreign to me. It was interesting to learn what was different about the communities and types of people up here, and what specific things caused them to come together and unite under one identity.

Date: 4/13/2022 18:26:17
Subject: the how of what, and why
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? 

So how do I think what I think, and why.

As an example, I select a quote from Grant Fawcett’s text below: 

“The point is, in a space like this where we think for ourselves, I view the fishbowl as a force that release the manacles of perceived performative work.”

Another great sentence: “ You grab what words and sentences that resonate with you.” 

And you run with it.

I select the first quote because I think by reflecting upon it; taking each word deeper into its meaning; and, by re-writing it through a process of sort, sift and select; and, thereby clarifying my understanding of it, my expectation is that this process, with its promise, will evoke some good insights for functioning in a digital society.

If you had a lot of money riding on this, you would look up the meaning of each word: space, think, view, force, release, manacles, perceive, 'performative-work' (please google). 

You would sort, sift and select, like at a drawing board, and construct a structure of words (sentence), which creates a space for generating insights in the viewers mind.

This constructed structure, this sentence, has a form which follows the idea of the word(s) listed from Fawcett’s quote.

Please google Maxine Naylor and Ralph Ball, “Form Follows Idea, An Introduction to Design Poetics". The form of your constructed sentence follows the idea of Fawcett’s structure.

So this is how I think what I think and why. It is the how of the what, and why.

Sanjiv

CONSTRUCT, FORM, STRUCTURE, MANACLES, FORCE, RELEASE, PERCEIVE, PERFORMATIVE, WORK

from the fishbowl...

grantfawcett

Posts: 66

Joined: Mon Jan 24, 2022 12:51 am

Post by grantfawcett » Tue Apr 12, 2022 11:50 am

When Sanjiv asked for fishbowl citizens to "Please reflect upon the extent your activities in the fishbowl characterize the work of a performing artist," I mentally jumped for joy. I do enjoy sharing and reacting to thoughts in this digital universe. It is a space or sort of a vessel where there is no gravity. There is nothing weighing you down. There are no standard that push you back to the ground. You have freedom to float and create your own landscape. You are in control of all of your elements. You grab what words and sentences resonate with you.

In this way, I do not feel like a performing artist. I am not a street performer that seeks to get a dollar by impressing passersby. I play my guitar for myself. I don't care if other people think it is out of tune because I am creating my own music. And as that music is made, there is not telling me that I am not making a grammy-award winning rock album.

This has been one giant analogy. The point is, in a space like this where we think for ourselves, I view the fishbowl as a force that release the manacles of perceived performative work.

Date: 4/12/2022 14:21:59
Subject: the fishbowl is a thought and an idea
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

Our postings, like etchings in a cave, and like Jackson Pollock’s Action Painting (please see video below), all stitched together, can be seen as a ‘product' that is an intangible, and it has a beginning and an end. The fishbowl is a ‘thought' and an ’idea' which we have experienced together in the context of a digital culture (please google). Please read Rowan Coleman’s posting below.

Our method in the fishbowl is known as self-reflexivity (please google), and we are participant-observers (please google) to each other in an imaginary mental space known as the fishbowl. We manifest in the materiality of text in the fishbowl. Our text shows how to think about what it means to look and see, when navigating the complexities of a digital culture. 

It is about how we think what we think and why. 

Exercise: 

I’d like you to consider the following two films (text and images) as metaphors, symbols and word-images:

Megacities: Parag Khanna Ted Talk,

Documentary on Jackson Pollock’s drip method 

Please select sentences after due consideration from the above viewing, and use those terms as metaphors, symbols and word-images for describing your experience in the fishbowl. When you do that, you will be addressing 'how you think what you think and why.'

A quote from John Perry Barlow (please google):

“All the goods of the information age---all of the expressions once contained in books or film strips or records or newsletters---will exist either as pure thought or something very much like thought: voltage conditions darting around the Net at the speed of light, in conditions that one might behold in effect, as glowing pixels or transmitted sounds, but never touch or claim to “own” in the old sense fo the world.” 

Sanjiv

post by rowancoleman » Mon Apr 11, 2022 11:42 pm

Google Search: Howard Rheingold

Howard Rheingold is an American critic, writer, and teacher, known for his specialties on the cultural, social and political implications of modern communication media such as the Internet, mobile telephony and virtual communities. In 1998, he created his next virtual community, Brainstorms, a private successful web conferencing community for knowledgeable, intellectual, civil, and future-thinking adults from all over the world. In 2002, Rheingold published Smart Mobs, exploring the potential for technology to augment collective intelligence. Shortly thereafter, in conjunction with the Institute for the Future, Rheingold launched an effort to develop a broad-based literacy of cooperation. and in 2008, Rheingold became the first research fellow at the Institute for the Future, with which he had long been affiliated. 

My take: Rheingold seems to enjoy looking at the possibilities of the internet and the digital communities one can form within, " Instead of confining my exploration to whether or not Google is making us stupid, Facebook is commoditizing our privacy, or Twitter is chopping our attention into microslides (all good questions), I've been asking myself and others how to use social media intelligently, humanely, and above all mindfully." (https://rheingold.com/). However, I myself am of the personal belief that the internet and social media can never be used humanely. Mindfully, yes, intelligently, yes; but never humanely. Granted, this may be me sticking to the one word and being overly critical, I haven't studied these communities for years so why should I have a say? Admittedly, this is all true, however I have in fact lived in these communities my entire childhood "chronically online" as some refer to us. I have seen the positive side, the friends I've made solely through the internet, the books I've read, or hobbies I've picked up. But, I have also seen much of the bad, the child grooming, the porn addiction, the manipulative advertising that feeds on any insecurity it can lay its eyes on. So, I may have to read Rheingolds book, see if he can change my perception on this.

Google Search: Howard Rheingold

Howard Rheingold is an American critic, writer, and teacher, known for his specialties on the cultural, social and political implications of modern communication media such as the Internet, mobile telephony and virtual communities. In 1998, he created his next virtual community, Brainstorms, a private successful web conferencing community for knowledgeable, intellectual, civil, and future-thinking adults from all over the world. In 2002, Rheingold published Smart Mobs, exploring the potential for technology to augment collective intelligence. Shortly thereafter, in conjunction with the Institute for the Future, Rheingold launched an effort to develop a broad-based literacy of cooperation. and in 2008, Rheingold became the first research fellow at the Institute for the Future, with which he had long been affiliated. 

My take: Rheingold seems to enjoy looking at the possibilities of the internet and the digital communities one can form within, " Instead of confining my exploration to whether or not Google is making us stupid, Facebook is commoditizing our privacy, or Twitter is chopping our attention into microslides (all good questions), I've been asking myself and others how to use social media intelligently, humanely, and above all mindfully." (https://rheingold.com/). However, I myself am of the personal belief that the internet and social media can never be used humanely. Mindfully, yes, intelligently, yes; but never humanely. Granted, this may be me sticking to the one word and being overly critical, I haven't studied these communities for years so why should I have a say? Admittedly, this is all true, however I have in fact lived in these communities my entire childhood "chronically online" as some refer to us. I have seen the positive side, the friends I've made solely through the internet, the books I've read, or hobbies I've picked up. But, I have also seen much of the bad, the child grooming, the porn addiction, the manipulative advertising that feeds on any insecurity it can lay its eyes on. So, I may have to read Rheingolds book, see if he can change my perception on this.

How To Write a Sentence, And How To Read One is the title of a book by Stanley Fish (please google).

Some people are bird watchers, others follow celebrities; still others are whale watchers and also flora and fauna. Stanley Fish belongs the tribe of sentence watchers.

Appreciating fine sentences and looking out for them, because they can take your breath away and you go, “Phew, isn’t that something?” 

In the fishbowl, you are wordsmiths crafting sentences. Constructing a structure of words by going deeper into their meaning. 

Your restructured sentence creates a space for felt-experiences to be reflected upon.

How so?

Piling up words, one after the other, won’t do much of anything until something else has been added. That something is named quite precisely by Anthony Burgess in this sentence from his novel Enderby Outside (1968):

And the words slide into the slots ordained by syntax, and glitter as with atmospheric dust with those impurities which we call meaning.

The words you elect are subjects or objects or actions or descriptives or indications of manner, and as such they combine into a statement about the world, that is, into a meaning that one can contemplate, admire, reject, or refine.

Before the words slide into their slots, they are just discrete items, pointing every where and nowhere. Once the words are nestled in the places “ordained” for them, they are tied by ligatures of relationships to one another. 

Sanjiv

SYNTAX, LIGATURE, ORDAIN

Interacting with words and sentences in the fishbowl lets us interact with units of value that can be spent in the knowledge economy. This is a budgetary decision. We are meaning making with the value we have obtained. The catch in this economy? Adding more words and concepts, the pillars of this economy, does not lead to inflation. Because of this, we are at an advantage. The fishbowl is a unique network and snapshot of society. We create culture in our meaning-making and taking and making of notes. By embracing reflexivity and recreating our learning habitat as something not bound by authority and roles in learning, the flow of information is free and uninhibited. This lack of obstruction strengthens ability to learn and positively benefits us as we assess our capacity for shaping culture and promoting interaction in business and RELATIONS.

Multi-dimensional - Action

The actions we carry out on a daily basis are rooted in multi-dimensional motivations. 

Why do we do the things we do? Why am I motivated to be introspective and think about my thinking? Because it helps me cultivate my sense of self and answer the How so question when I do things each and every day. Why am I doing this? How does this further my human experience and help me to learn?

I posed a lot of questions just then. That was intentional. Life is about asking questions and examining the multi-dimensional nature of why we do the thing we do.

Post by grantfawcett » Mon Mar 21, 2022 8:20 am

In the fishbowl we are architects. We construct a foundation with our words to build skyscraper in the form of sentences. These sentences form the community of the fishbowl. In this way we are establishing a village of learning. Art within our community happens to be the original knowledge content we produce and put out to be interacted with. Interpreting each others thoughts an acknowledging the singular nature of the sentences we create promotes reflection. 

I want to REMIND us what sanjiv said in an earlier letter: "Transparency and sharing your trajectory of thoughts has become a key skill for leadership and management." Establishing this culture in business and with people you work with and around will pay dividends when trying to coexist and conduct business simultaneously. Sanjiv elaborated, "Fear of getting it wrong and not getting it right is an inhibiting factor. Drop the fear. Wasted emotion in a learning environment. Sincerity and integrity and focus are of value." In this knowledge economy, the rich can get richer. There are no poor. We are all affluent together. Wealthy in the form of reflection and learning.

Post by grantfawcett » Tue Mar 29, 2022 8:04 pm

"Culture is the collective programming of the mind which distinguishes the members of one human group from another.”

This definition of culture is textually beautiful and is the fruit of the the tree that is the fishbowl. Culture is something that we interact with every day. We encounter cultures that are not our own and unite with others based on shared cultural values and beliefs. Imagining the amount of unexplored culture out there is simultaneously mind-bending and motivating. As we toss around words and form sentences in this digital universe, it is crucial to remember that pedagogical device that the fishbowl forms also is a mechanism for informing us of vital information about how society is structured around the world.

post by grantfawcett » Sun Apr 10, 2022 6:01 pm

Upon reading my sentence deconstruction for sentences gathered from Japanese Story, I am eager to record a felt experience that demonstrates the amount of resonation that occurred while viewing this film. I must also remark about the acting prowess of Toni Collette. She masterfully played a culturally incompetent host who became someone drawn and more respectful of Japanese culture. Hats off to her.

Now for my felt experience. It also has a tie to Asian culture. When I was a sophomore in high school, I was a wise fool (meaning of sophomore in Latin). But seriously, I knew a lot, but thought I knew more than I did. I took on the privilege and opportunity of hosting a Chinese exchange student as soon as I could. I thought it would be like just having another sibling in my house. It turned out to be a 2 month experiment where I interacted and got accustomed to socializing with an individual who lived a totally different life with disparate routines and values. It was a dive into what life was like across the pond in China. At first I was annoyed by the disagreements Jack (my exchange student's English name) and I would have. They seemed to happen quite often. I soon realized that we actually shared many values, we just expressed them different while interacting due to our cultural differences and understanding of social norms. One principal example of this would be my propensity to tell him if I didn't care for something or preferred something. He would remain quiet and let the circumstance be as it happened. I wished that he would speak up more. Over time, I began to understand that I needed to pay more attention to his cultural values to make sure I wasn't disrespecting him without knowing I was doing so.

This experience enhanced my thirst for cultural learning opportunities. Now I invest in experience, for this is the ticket to grasping the full picture of how beautifully diverse and expansive the world is and how wonderfully complicated and interesting people are.

Subject: how to deploy attention
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you?

Please see Michael Bergantine’s knowledge creation and knowing, and how he deploys attention in the fishbowl.

How to make use of digital environments, like the fishbowl, without being overloaded with too much information is, like it or not, an essential ingredient to personal success in the twenty-first century. 

Learning how to deploy attention in relation to an overloaded availability of information is key today for success in education, business and social life.

According to Howard Rheingold (please google) those who understand the fundamentals of digital participation, online collaboration, informational credibility testing (through online search engines) and network awareness will be able to exert more control over their own fates than those who lack this know-how.

I see a bigger social issue at work with the fishbowl, in addition to personal empowerment: if we combine our individual efforts wisely, enough of the right know-how could add up to a more thoughtful society as well as enhance those of us who master networking skills.

It is the "architecture of participation” that enables countless small acts of self-interest like your postings or sharing a link to add up to a public good that enriches everybody.

Sanjiv

To think deeply means to go beyond what you think you know. It means to let go of preconceived ideas in order to discover the truth. By cultivating the skill of deep thinking, we can gain freedom of thought. The deeper your thinking becomes, the more focused and meaningful your actions will be.

Post by michaelbergantine » Mon Feb 07, 2022 3:14 pm

(About not being confused)

"It is a knowledge economy that you are becoming a part of."

KNOWLEDGE: facts, information, and skills acquired by a person through experience or education; the theoretical or practical understanding of a subject.

BECOMING: the process of coming to be something or of passing into a state.

From the time we are born we, in a sense, begin our journey of learning in a knowledge economy. I feel it's a repetitive process we experience over and over throughout our lives. Over the past 3 years in college I have cultivated a metamorphosis transforming from a Freshman with little experience to a Junior where I have gained confidence and skills through education. This growth is something that is going to continue in a repetitive cycle in life. I look forward to becoming a "Freshman" at an entry level management position and acquiring more expertise to eventually become a "Senior" leader in the business world.

Post by michaelbergantine » Tue Feb 08, 2022 9:38 am

(About Deconstruction)

"Deconstruction is a way of understanding how something was created, usually things like art, books, poems and other writing, like the sentences you are posting in the fishbowl."

UNDERSTANDING: The knowledge and ability to judge a particular situation or subject He has a thorough/full understanding of the subject.

DECONSTRUCTION: The term deconstruction refers to approaches to understanding the relationship between text and meaning.

When you look at different cultures and societies a word or symbol may look or sound the same, but the meaning could be completely different. In the United States if someone were to say "wagon" the image that would come to mind is a red object with wheels that you pull around. That same word in Ireland is used to describe an unpleasant woman. Another more powerful example would be the word "kiss." In the U.S., we view it as a form of affection, but in Sweden it is used to say you have to pee. Our views and interpretations are shaped by our culture and forms our societal interpretations of the art and literature we observe. In France nudity is celebrated, but is distasteful in our culture. By taking the time to identify the multiple meanings and the context of which it was built we can develop an understanding the way the original author or artist intended us to see.

Post by michaelbergantine » Sat Feb 12, 2022 11:21 am

(The Challenge of Learning)

"This requires meditation and contemplation and turning down noise and all distractions."

CONTEMPLATION: The action of looking thoughtfully at something for a long time; deep reflective thought.

DISTRACTIONS: A thing that prevents someone from giving full attention to something else; extreme agitation of the mind or emotions.

As I sift and sort through my growth and learning in the fishbowl I have to develop my strategy to succeed. It requires my careful attention, first observing and visualizing the thoughts that come to me while reading the letters. It is easy to become overwhelmed, but by breaking it down into small pieces I find it does not complicate my focus. As images form in my mind I attempt to zero in on what was most important to me. From there I can develop my personal meaning and interpretations of the text.

Post by michaelbergantine » Mon Feb 14, 2022 7:42 am

(several aspects of your learning in the fishbowl)

"At the same time, we are dissecting text by evoking the past to re-create meaning for ourselves going forward."

DISSECTING: Analyze (something) in minute detail.

EVOKING: Bring or recall to the conscious mind.

We are attempting to examine and analyze our letters to elicit new thoughts and ideas on old ways of practice. They say that doing the same thing over and over again, expecting a different result, is the definition of insanity. We can apply our method in the fishbowl to our lives. We will encounter issues others have faced before us in business or society. It is essential to creatively brainstorm new solutions rather than just repeating past practices. It is the only way to bring about effective change.

Post by michaelbergantine » Thu Feb 17, 2022 1:01 pm

(Being Mindful and Being Reflective in the Fishbowl)

"By being mindful on the other hand, we are able to press the Pause button between the stimulus and response."

PAUSE: A temporary stop in action or speech.

STIMULUS: A thing that rouses activity or energy in someone or something; a spur or incentive.

RESPONSE: A reaction to something.

Life comes at us fast, and sometimes we need to stop and take in our surroundings. We all have immediate reactions to things that happen in life. Some of those are positive, and some are negative. In our relationships, at work or school, taking the extra second to pause and think before we react could prevent a situation from becoming more than it needed to be. Being conscious and focusing on. one thing at a time will also remove some of the stress in a situation, making our reactions come from a place of rational thought.

Post by michaelbergantine » Mon Feb 28, 2022 4:45 pm

(tips for creating and constructing structures)

"In fact it is most profound when you touch on the mundane and banal."

MUNDANE: Lacking interest or excitement; dull.

Synonyms: banal, everyday, humdrum, normal, prosaic, commonplace, earthly, lowly, routine, workday, worldly

BANAL: So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.

Synonyms: bland, corny, dumb, hackneyed, mundane, stupid, trite, vapid

PROFOUND: penetrating or entering deeply into subjects of thought or knowledge; having deep insight or understanding:

Synonyms: deep, intelligent, philosophical, serious, subtle, thorough, weighty

REFLECTION: In fact it is most philosophical when you touch on the commonplace and bland. Isn't most of life just this? The everyday, commonplace and bland that we encounter at work or school? It is up to us to extract what is abstract and deeper than what is merely visible on the surface.

Post by michaelbergantine » Tue Mar 15, 2022 3:56 pm

(Feedback Again)

"Fear of getting it wrong and not getting it right is an inhibiting factor. Drop the fear. Wasted emotion in a learning environment."

INHIBITING: Hinder, restrain, or prevent (an action or process).

WASTED: use or expend carelessly, extravagantly, or to no purpose.

I can remember many times growing up where I held back from trying something new because of fear. I now try to think of FEAR as False Evidence Appearing Real. I eventually learned that often times my worries were unfounded, and I was not as bad as I had expected myself to be. Fear can be what prevents us from raising our hand in class. "What if I have the wrong answer?" Fear can hold us back from sharing a new idea at work. "What if my boss hates it, and I get fired?" It can also affect our personal life and sports. "What if they laugh at me?" Rather than allowing my angst to ruin an opportunity to grow, I've learned to shut those negative voices down and take a chance. It is almost always for the better.

Post by michaelbergantine » Tue Mar 15, 2022 5:08 pm

(the doing of the exercise)

"Reality is based on perception; so regardless of any situation, if we are aware things, we can achieve any reality."

PERCEPTION: the state of being or process of becoming aware of something through the senses.

REALITY: the world or the state of things as they actually exist, as opposed to an idealistic or notional idea of them.

Our perception of our fishbowl world and felt experiences are individually shaped by our characteristics and culture. We are all sharing the fishbowl experience; however, each has our sapience which shapes our thoughts. We are all correct in our interpretations and reflections; although different, they are still the reality of the same event.

Post by michaelbergantine » Sat Apr 09, 2022 8:02 am

(On the matter of performance)

Performers need the presence of others: their ephemeral performance only exists if it is seen or heard, and therefore only when there is a “public.”

PUBLIC: done, perceived, or existing in open view; open to or shared by all the people of an area or country.

PERFORMERS: a person who entertains an audience.

EPHEMERAL: lasting for a very short time; (chiefly of plants) having a very short life cycle.

We are all the cast and crew of the fishbowl joining together in an ensemble to create our event. If we were alone, our experience would not create value since the essence of our shared interpretations generates our new context. We may be together for a brief and fleeting moment in our history, but our etchings will remain, leaving us an impression of knowledge far beyond this momentary event.

Post by michaelbergantine » Sat Apr 09, 2022 5:40 pm

(Technologies of lived abstraction)

"It is known as the technology of lived abstraction."

TECHNOLOGY: the application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes, especially in industry.

LIVED: supply oneself with the means of subsistence; survive in someone's mind; be remembered.

ABSTRACTION: the quality of dealing with ideas rather than events; freedom from representational qualities in art.

“What moves as a body, returns as the movement of thought.” Of subjectivity (in its nascent state) Of the social (in its mutant state) Of the environment (at the point it can be reinvented) “A process set up anywhere reverberates everywhere.” 

I find I must deviate from the acceptable social norms of education society to be able to understand the interpretations of lived abstraction. During the majority of our lives in school, we are merely taught to regurgitate the thoughts and actions of others. If none of us deviated from this path, new ideas and concepts would not be developed. We are taking the original information and then forming secondary images & thoughts that we can invoke a feeling, therefore living out the experience or event.

Date: 3/28/2022 16:00:39
Subject: going about the final assignment (345)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well.

We are developing a "knowing and knowledge content" for four characteristics of successful Global businesses.

We are considering the following characteristics suggested by research (Bartlett and Ghoshal, please google):

1. Integrated networking structure

2. Dynamic decision-making

3. Adaptive coordination mechanisms

4. Unique innovation capabilities 

How do you go about creating a knowing and a knowledge content for each of the above?

Before you do so, this a good time to re-read the Abstract, reproduced below: The Production of Space: Online Experiential Learning.

The method and process for creating a knowing and a knowledge content is contained in the Abstract. And, many of you have co-authorship.

Before we tackle the four characteristics, let us consider a working definition for understanding Globalization. What does it mean?

According to Anthony Giddens (please google) globalization is: “the intensification of worldwide social relations which link distant localities in such way that local happenings are shaped by events occurring many miles away and vice versa”, thereby changing all aspects of our everyday life.

Sanjiv

CHARACTERISTIC, KNOWING, KNOWLEDGE, AUTHORSHIP

from the fishbowl...

THE PRODUCTION OF SPACE: ONLINE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING

Introduction: Our paper is about the production of experiential learning in digital space we call the fishbowl. We are concerned with how learning is produced online. Shifting away from individual meaning-making in the form of cognitive learning cycles (1), we recognize that experiential learning is a collaborative process, mediated through embodied experience and situated within contextualized space and time (2). Following a socio-spatial perspective, we explore ways in which learning experiences are both socially produced and socially producing through engagement (3). We see our paper as joining conversations that enrich research, practice and knowledge production. 

Purpose: To present a multi-stage process, with each stage further refining learning that is realized by the participant. To realize is "to convert something imagined into real existence or fact.” Realization is the process by which surface representation is derived from its underlying representation, that is, the way abstract object of analysis comes to be produced in actual language and felt experientially. 

Method: As active learners, we are in a collaborative process of making sense of ourselves, the world, and places within it. Henri Lefebvre’s spatial Triad provided the framework to recognize three elements of producing space. Conceived space is “what is thought,” “perceived space is what is seen,” and “lived space is what is felt” (3). 

Our method examines the experimental genre of writing known as Denkbild or ‘thought-image’ (4). The thought-image borders on traditional genres like the parable and the aphorism, and relates to the short story and prose poem.

Our paper presents the following 5 steps:

1. Select three words, e.g., Growth, Discipline, Integrity.

2. Capture thought-images for each word. Describe the image and relate a personal event.

3. Reflection is consciously looking at, thinking about and interpreting experiences, actions, feelings and responses.

4. Identify two qualities constituting one’s unique experience by making Self the object of its own reflective consciousness.

5. Return to step 1.

Outcome: The fishbowl exchanges were aesthetically prominent structures that gave rise to conceptual thought, constituting a fluidity that resists definition. As a material and virtual artifact, the authors produced a unique circuit of exchange and a sharper picture of reality. By sharing content and images of their thoughts with regard to each of the words: Growth, Discipline, Integrity, the authors created a disconnected and non-binding form capable of building a shared community and culture from the standpoint of subjective experience. Foregoing the claim to completeness, and relying instead on the fragment (5) and anecdotal evidence (6), the fishbowl offered the best option for keeping the original three concepts alive. The thought-image with its evocation “of something that cannot be said in words” became the singular and unpredictable but not arbitrary or facile acts of conceptual creation. 

References

1. Kolb, D. A. (1984). Experiential learning: Experience as the source of learning and development (Vol. 1) Prentice-Hall

2. Kolb, A. Y., & Kolb, D. A. (2005). Learning Styles and Learning Spaces, Academy of Management Learning & Education, 4, 193-212. 

3. Lefebvre, H. (1991). The production of space. Blackwell

4. Richter, G (2007) Thought-Images, Stanford

5. Baudrillard, J (2004) Fragments, Routledge 

6. Gallop, J. (2002) Anecdotal Theory, Duke University

Keywords: THOUGHT-IMAGES, CONCEPTUAL SPACE, PERCEPTUAL SPACE, LIVED SPACE

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 3/26/2022 13:20:38
Subject: relative, learned, shared, system, meanings (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? 

And what about culture?

We’re making a textual turn in the course towards culture.

A bend in the road.

There are over 40 excellent definitions of culture and each one is different. Google the term and get a sense of the concept of culture. Well worth your while. By the end of the semester, your goal should be to have the beginnings of an understanding of the concept known as culture.

For our purposes in the fishbowl, G. H. Hofstede’s definition of culture works the best: 

"Culture is the collective programming of the mind which distinguishes the members of one human group from another.”

It is the programming of our minds that distinguishes us from each other in the fishbowl.

So what is this 'collective programming of my mind that distinguishes me from you?

1. It is my shared system of meanings.

2. It is relative.

3. It is learned.

4. It is about groups.

Culture dictates what we pay attention to. It guides how we perceive the world, how the self is experienced and how life itself is organized. When individuals of a group share patterns that enable them to see the same things in the same way, it holds them together. We carry within us learned ways of finding meaning in our experiences. In order for effective, stable and meaningful interaction to occur, we must have a shared system of meaning.

Each culture s relative to other cultures’ ways of perceiving the world and doing things.

My culture is derived from my social environment, and from my genetic make-up.

Culture is a collective phenomenon that is about shared values and meanings.

What culture is not:

1. Right or wrong.

2. Inherited.

3. About individual behavior. There are wide variations in individual values and behavior within each group’s culture.

Sanjiv

RELATIVE, LEARNED, SHARED, SYSTEM, MEANINGS

from the fishbowl...

CULTURE, MATRIX, BEHAVIOR, PATTERN, PARTICULAR

Culture is what creates us and makes us. We are cultured by behavior, and patterns in our lives, particularly from our families. This is a created matrix and what we believe is the truth and beliefs of our lives.

Date: 3/23/2022 11:24:13
Subject: constructing word-pools
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I am looking forward to our class today. How should we do the letters? How do I learn from an exchange of words?

To address this question, I would like to say that the fishbowl represents what we are seeing happening all around us. On account of communication technology like Brightspace, Starfish and the Fishbowl, we are perceiving the outlines of "large scale shifts in attentional practices and norms." (Please google Net Smart by Howard Rheingold)

Shift in attentional practices and norms? What does that mean? I picked that out right away. 

Selection is key. What and whom and why did I select what I did? It can be random, or a lucky number, It could be intuitive, or thought-out. It could have an ulterior motive. It really has to do with context. So what is your context when you make a selection of a sentence structure?

The phrase means that there is a shift in how we do things; what do we pay attention to? And this shift is in our practices and in rules and norms of behavior. 

Next: So what do i do with the above reflection? 

I look up the words: shift, attention, practice, norm. 

I selected these words to look-up from my text above and, by going through the dictionary and thesaurus, I gather more words and make a word-pool (metaphor). Around twenty words I would think.

My word-pool is the boundary line for discourse (google Discourse Analysis). Discourse allows us to develop a dialog. More on this thought later. 

The word-pool is my resource for creating things like new thoughts, ideas, images, portrayals, vignettes, fragments, vision, flashes, camera shots, moving images, frameworks.

Our world is increasingly constituted by information (words) rather than pre-modern modes of conduct. It is how we live.

We meet on the same page today. No?

.

Sanjiv

Post by pageelliott » Tue Mar 22, 2022 9:37 pm

Henri Lefebvre's Spatial Triad.- perceived space... deep thinking- Everyone around the world sees different areas or spaces everyday of their lives. We have places where we live, work, visit, and act. All of the spaces in which we experience daily, carry meaning and perspective. We all look at spaces differently based on the feelings we have there, and what experiences occurred in that space. Spaces are shared by everyone, but also quite different experiences for everyone. Spaces carry perspective, emotion, and visuals.

from the dictionary... 

CONCEIVE, imagine, think... When I was little I would look up into the sky and imagine the clouds as being different objects. I would think deeply about what the clouds looked like, and what is beyond our sight in the sky.

PERCEIVE, aware, recognize....It is important to be aware if your surroundings, and recognize people's feelings, emotions, fears, and thoughts.

FEEL, examine, touch... we can examine different words in a book, touch the book, and read until our heart's content. 

VISUALIZE, image, picture. I used to be really interested in photography and i would take thousands of pictures of nature. then, I would keep these images for the rest of my life and be able to remember experiences, emotions, and places I have been.

SOCIETY, people, community... many people in a community learn, see, and communicate with one another

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 3/23/2022 1:19:15
Subject: felt-experiences and thought-images (Denkbild)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I was thinking about tomorrows class and i would like to talk about word-images. Every word has an image attached to it and these images are different among us for the same word. The word-image for “cancer" is different for each of us, and when we share our images, we get a better handle on our knowing and knowledge building around the word “cancer." This simple sharing and posting helps us raise meaningful questions, create new ideas, and develop an original point of view.

Word-images are also known as “thought-images” or “denkbild.”

Please see the following video: 

https://www.theoryculturesociety.org/blog/video-monique-tschofen-on-the-denkbild-thought-image-in-the-age-of-digital-reproduction

We will cite Monique Tschofen’s work for completing our paper for Edulearn22, if the Abstract is accepted.

The felt-experience that you are describing in the fishbowl is akin to the "thought-image." 

The felt-experience/thought-image is a description of something in your memory that your mind visualizes.

It is a fragment of thought images.

Our thuoght-images influence how we conceive, perceive and feel about something.

Please google Henri Lefebvre's Spatial Triad. Our social space in the fishbowl is an intersection of conceived space, perceived space and lived space. Our thought-images influence these three spaces and create our society; the fishbowl.

Sanjiv

CONCEIVE, PERCEIVE, FEEL, VISUALIZE, SOCIETY
