Subject: about not being confused
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well. 

There is a practice and process that must be followed, if you are to comprehend words and sentences in the fishbowl. 

What is this PRACTICE and PROCESS?

It is your dictionary that has the answer, in plain sight.

Copy it out. You are not being dishonest when you copy!

From the dictionary, you are COPYING out capitalized words in my letters and, DOING google searches requested in parentheses.

You are not doing cut-and-paste. You are copying after SELECTING. 

In so doing, you are exercising CHOICE and making it visible. 

It is not done in secrecy, and it is not between you and me.

It is among us. 

You are learning to COMPREHEND when you READ and WRITE. 

To do so, there is a PRACTICE and there is a PROCESS.

It is done in SOLITUDE, with a paper and pencil.

There is no other way known to human kind.

You will UNDERSTAND, but only after reading every letter, three times at least (take a break and come back to it), 

and so you will ASCERTAIN the practice and process to be followed.

I can only write my letter in English and I can only re-send the same letter, again and again.

But it is you who has to eat your vegetables (metaphor). I can’t eat them for you! That is a hard lesson.

The metaphor I prefer, is “you can take a horse to the water, but you can’t make it drink."

I found myself in this situation with my Dad. He wouldn’t read, and he wouldn’t listen either.

Nor did he write much. He sent Hallmark cards instead, which he would sign with a flourish.

They were never enough!

One’s IDIOM is culturally based, and it has to be DECIPHERED.

For the most part, the grade in the course gets determined sooner than later, because we are visible to each other. 

When you scroll the Active Topics, you can see for yourself who is heading for the A. 

If you’re not, then hitch your wagon (metaphor) to the one who is.

Read, read, read. Copy, copy, copy. Edit, edit and edit, until you make the text your own...until it begins to sound like you.

Take ownership of your constructed text. It is a knowledge economy that you are becoming a part of. 

Each of us is BECOMING something else. (Please google search: "Deleuze and Becoming." Select one sentence which makes sense to you and you wish to keep for later reference.)

Don’t be shy and don’t be afraid. We are among friends, and we don’t judge each other on this journey.

Sanjiv

ps: We have covered the notion of Reflection and we will move into the concept of Deconstruction.

Date: 2/4/2022 3:08:33
Subject: why reflect?
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope your week is going well. I am going to address why is it important for you to reflect and do reflective thinking?

The SIGNIFICANCE of reflection is that it allows you to see the importance of your own learning process. ... REFLECTION provides you with MOTIVATION to learn and enjoy the PROCESS of learning. This motivation comes from you reflecting on your THOUGHTS, FEELINGS and EMOTIONS. 

Being able to EXAMINE your own feelings, reactions, and motives (= reasons for acting) and how these influence what you do or think in a situation, is to BECOME AWARE of your IMPLICIT knowledge base and to learn from this experience.

Posting in the fishbowl is largely an INTUITIVE ACTION. However, it can also be seen as SCRIPTED to some extent. You post what you first VISUALIZE and then attempt to predict what may happen. Please read Jenna Sousa’s posting below in this light. Posting in any manner requires a person to see within the "mind’s eye.” 

Once you have posted, that is when unpredictability and reflection SURFACES. This surfacing often occurs in the midst of the ACT of posting, when you think about what has just happened in a COGNITIVE sense. 

Reflection seems to be a means to MONITOR oneself as life unfolds. You sense, comprehend and process the events in a millisecond. 

Reflection is SYSTEMATIC, even habitual. You MULL over your thoughts, you reflect on your actions. 

The instant you post, your actions are followed by feedback from your senses. Your muscles deliver kinesthetic information and your EVALUATIVE thoughts of yourself are weighed immediately. You hear yourself speak and judge your word choice and tone. The feedback loops are numerous and if you attend to each, you are in a position to make adjustments. 

But why reflect?

You do this because you are interested in improving (which means ALTERING your PRACTICE). 

Society (MGT345) and Culture (MGT448) cannot stand still. It changes moment by moment, day by day, and year to year. Some people would like if change didn’t happen as predictability would ensure certain outcomes. However, change can be a useful element in our lives as it gives us an opportunity to improve whatever we are doing or have done. You find that by every post, you improve and add novelty via new material.

While posting, you reflect on your actions and SCRUTINIZE what has just happened with a desire to get better. The RECURSIVE process does improve your COMPREHENSION and UNDERSTANDING of SELF, the EVENTS and the CONTEXT. You are FOCUSED on the present with an eye to the future and this PERSPECTIVE motivates and encourages you to change each day. No matter how much you change and improve, you can connect (relations) where you are at present with where you were at some point in the past. 

CONNECT, RELATIONS

Your first AUDIENCE is self: The notebooks of the molecular biologist, the industrial sociologist, or the clinical drug tester during the pandemic help each keep track of what was done along the way, suggesting ways of improving next steps, and give reassurance about the reproducibility of the results. 

The need to reflect on self as a means of self-development is widely endorsed. The work of John Dewey (please google) and Donald Schön (please google), put forward the notion that reflection is a critical UNDERPINNING of growth and learning. Indeed, Dewey (1934) argued, “all direct experience is qualitative, and qualities are what make life-experience itself directly precious. Yet reflection goes behind immediate qualities, for it is interested in relations . . . (p. 293)." 

We can do something yet not be aware of how various ELEMENTS are related and this lack of awareness can impede immediate understanding and growth. 

Please see Jenna Sousa’s Google Searches below. They are excellent and her desire to learn must be commended. I have inserted reflective questions: when she addresses them, she will indeed be EMPOWERING her text and Individuating herself.

*******************************

jennasousa

Joined: Mon Jan 24, 2022 1:34 pm

Re: GOOGLE SEARCHES

Post by jennasousa » Fri Jan 28, 2022 7:25 pm

Knowledge Economy: an economy in which growth is dependent on the quantity, quality, and accessibility of the information available, rather than the means of production. 

My take on this definition: When I read this definition, I get the sense that a knowledge economy is an economy that bases growth off of how much knowledge/education it has. It is built on what we know and what is available for us to know. I feel this type of economy is important because with knowledge, we are capable of many things. {HOW SO? GIVE PERSONAL EXAMPLE} As long as there is knowledge available, we are pretty much able to figure anything out. We are certainly capable of growing an economy to the extreme if knowledge is present. Knowledge and learning increase innovation. {HOW SO? GIVE PERSONAL EXAMPLE} Innovation can lead to growth.

Knowledge Workers: Knowledge workers are workers whose main capital is knowledge. Examples include programmers, physicians, pharmacists, architects, engineers, scientists, design thinkers, public accountants, lawyers, editors, and academics, whose job is to "think for a living".

My take on this definition: Knowledge workers are people that work by using their knowledge. Knowledge workers are indeed essential. If we think about it, we wouldn't even have any knowledge of anything if we didn't have teachers, professors, or people that post informational videos online for a living. The whole purpose of their job is to use their education to provide others with education. Additionally, what would we do if we didn't have doctors that relied on their knowledge in order to diagnose us, heal us, etc.? Knowledge workers are key to society and also the economy. If we weren't able to benefit from the work these people perform using their knowledge, we wouldn't have half of the things we have (including our own education). {GIVE ONE PERSONAL EXAMPLE AND EMPOWER YOUR TEXT}

Social Constructivism: Social Constructivism is a sociological theory of knowledge according to which human development is socially situated and knowledge is constructed through interaction with others. 

My take on this definition: In my opinion, this definition means that we gain knowledge (and grow) from our interactions with others. I tend to agree with this. When I study with a study partner, that person always broadens my horizon as to what everything means. They think of it in ways that I didn't before. {GIVE EXAMPLE AND EMPOWER YOUR TEXT} This allows me to expand my thinking by thinking of it in that way as well. I believe I do the same for them when I share my ideas. In addition, I feel I have learned a lot in life by just being around others. I have learned how to cook and clean from my mom. I also picked up skills {GIVE EXAMPLE} from my boyfriend and my friends by just being around them. I have also learned a lot about myself by being around others. {GIVE EXAMPLE} I think this is what we are doing in this class. We are publicly exploring new concepts along with our thinking so that we are able to gain knowledge from each other. {GIVE EXAMPLE AND EMPOWER YOUR TEXT}

"Social Construction of Reality" by Peter Berger and Thomas Luckmann: In 1966, sociologists Peter Berger and Thomas Luckmann wrote a book called "The Social Construction of Reality". In it, they argued that society is created by humans and human interaction, which they call habitualization. Not only do we construct our own society, but we also accept it as it is because others have created it before us. Society is, in fact, “habit.”

My take on this definition: I have not read this book. However, this explanation gives me great insight into what this text is about. I agree with the notion that society is habitual and we tend to follow it as others lived before us. {GIVE EXAMPLE FROM YOUR FELT-EXPERIENCE} If we think back in time, we live similarly as our ancestors did. We eat breakfast, lunch, and dinner. We wake up at sun rise and fall asleep at night time. No one ever really stops to debate any of that. This exemplifies our topic of social constructivism. We learn from each other. We learn from our parents that we should take showers to stay clean. We learn these things and then we will teach them to our future kids too. Therefore, our society is created by our habits. If everyone started waking up at 11p.m. and going to sleep at 2p.m., this would become the new normal. We create our society and our norms.

**************************

Schön defines reflective practice as the practice by which professionals become aware of their implicit knowledge base and learn from their experience. ... Another term he introduces is “knowing in action” to describe TACIT knowledge.

What is a reflective question?

A reflection question is HOW SO? and GIVE PERSONAL EXAMPLE. It is any question that makes you look back over what or how you have learned. Reflection questions often assess META-cognitive skills, otherwise known as thinking about how we think and learn. 

When you write a reflection, you write your thoughts about something, rather than writing a summary or a description of that something itself. It you want to get a deeper understanding of what you read or what you see, write reflectively. It will get you an A in the course.

Sanjiv

While posting, you reflect on your actions and SCRUTINIZE what has just happened with a desire to get better. The RECURSIVE process does improve your COMPREHENSION and UNDERSTANDING of SELF, the EVENTS and the CONTEXT. You are FOCUSED on the present with an eye to the future and this PERSPECTIVE motivates and encourages you to change each day. No matter how much you change and improve, you can connect (relations) where you are at present with where you were at some point in the past. 

CONNECT, RELATIONS

Your first AUDIENCE is self: The notebooks of the molecular biologist, the industrial sociologist, or the clinical drug tester during the pandemic help each keep track of what was done along the way, suggesting ways of improving next steps, and give reassurance about the reproducibility of the results. 

The need to reflect on self as a means of self-development is widely endorsed. The work of John Dewey (please google) and Donald Schön (please google), put forward the notion that reflection is a critical UNDERPINNING of growth and learning. Indeed, Dewey (1934) argued, “all direct experience is qualitative, and qualities are what make life-experience itself directly precious. Yet reflection goes behind immediate qualities, for it is interested in relations . . . (p. 293)." 

We can do something yet not be aware of how various ELEMENTS are related and this lack of awareness can impede immediate understanding and growth. 

Please see Jenna Sousa’s Google Searches below. They are excellent and her desire to learn must be commended. I have inserted reflective questions: when she addresses them, she will indeed be EMPOWERING her text and Individuating herself.

*******************************

Re: GOOGLE SEARCHES

Post by jennasousa » Fri Jan 28, 2022 7:25 pm

Knowledge Economy: an economy in which growth is dependent on the quantity, quality, and accessibility of the information available, rather than the means of production. 

My take on this definition: When I read this definition, I get the sense that a knowledge economy is an economy that bases growth off of how much knowledge/education it has. It is built on what we know and what is available for us to know. I feel this type of economy is important because with knowledge, we are capable of many things. {HOW SO? GIVE PERSONAL EXAMPLE} As long as there is knowledge available, we are pretty much able to figure anything out. We are certainly capable of growing an economy to the extreme if knowledge is present. Knowledge and learning increase innovation. {HOW SO? GIVE PERSONAL EXAMPLE} Innovation can lead to growth.

Knowledge Workers: Knowledge workers are workers whose main capital is knowledge. Examples include programmers, physicians, pharmacists, architects, engineers, scientists, design thinkers, public accountants, lawyers, editors, and academics, whose job is to "think for a living".

My take on this definition: Knowledge workers are people that work by using their knowledge. Knowledge workers are indeed essential. If we think about it, we wouldn't even have any knowledge of anything if we didn't have teachers, professors, or people that post informational videos online for a living. The whole purpose of their job is to use their education to provide others with education. Additionally, what would we do if we didn't have doctors that relied on their knowledge in order to diagnose us, heal us, etc.? Knowledge workers are key to society and also the economy. If we weren't able to benefit from the work these people perform using their knowledge, we wouldn't have half of the things we have (including our own education). {GIVE ONE PERSONAL EXAMPLE AND EMPOWER YOUR TEXT}

Social Constructivism: Social Constructivism is a sociological theory of knowledge according to which human development is socially situated and knowledge is constructed through interaction with others. 

My take on this definition: In my opinion, this definition means that we gain knowledge (and grow) from our interactions with others. I tend to agree with this. When I study with a study partner, that person always broadens my horizon as to what everything means. They think of it in ways that I didn't before. {GIVE EXAMPLE AND EMPOWER YOUR TEXT} This allows me to expand my thinking by thinking of it in that way as well. I believe I do the same for them when I share my ideas. In addition, I feel I have learned a lot in life by just being around others. I have learned how to cook and clean from my mom. I also picked up skills {GIVE EXAMPLE} from my boyfriend and my friends by just being around them. I have also learned a lot about myself by being around others. {GIVE EXAMPLE} I think this is what we are doing in this class. We are publicly exploring new concepts along with our thinking so that we are able to gain knowledge from each other. {GIVE EXAMPLE AND EMPOWER YOUR TEXT}

"Social Construction of Reality" by Peter Berger and Thomas Luckmann: In 1966, sociologists Peter Berger and Thomas Luckmann wrote a book called "The Social Construction of Reality". In it, they argued that society is created by humans and human interaction, which they call habitualization. Not only do we construct our own society, but we also accept it as it is because others have created it before us. Society is, in fact, “habit.”

My take on this definition: I have not read this book. However, this explanation gives me great insight into what this text is about. I agree with the notion that society is habitual and we tend to follow it as others lived before us. {GIVE EXAMPLE FROM YOUR FELT-EXPERIENCE} If we think back in time, we live similarly as our ancestors did. We eat breakfast, lunch, and dinner. We wake up at sun rise and fall asleep at night time. No one ever really stops to debate any of that. This exemplifies our topic of social constructivism. We learn from each other. We learn from our parents that we should take showers to stay clean. We learn these things and then we will teach them to our future kids too. Therefore, our society is created by our habits. If everyone started waking up at 11p.m. and going to sleep at 2p.m., this would become the new normal. We create our society and our norms.

**************************

Schön defines reflective practice as the practice by which professionals become aware of their implicit knowledge base and learn from their experience. ... Another term he introduces is “knowing in action” to describe TACIT knowledge.

What is a reflective question?

A reflection question is HOW SO? and GIVE PERSONAL EXAMPLE. It is any question that makes you look back over what or how you have learned. Reflection questions often assess META-cognitive skills, otherwise known as thinking about how we think and learn. 

When you write a reflection, you write your thoughts about something, rather than writing a summary or a description of that something itself. It you want to get a deeper understanding of what you read or what you see, write reflectively. It will get you an A in the course.

Sanjiv

Hi Everyone,

How are you this evening? I hope things are looking up and you have your courses and schedule sorted.

We are 140 of us 'knowledge-workers,' knocking about (metaphor) in a Fishbowl (metaphor): 43 in MGT 345-0005 and 47 in 345-0006 and 49 in MGT 448-0002.

The dust has mostly settled (metaphor) with a remaining few still trickling in (metaphor).

I. Vocabulary

Metaphors define how we see the world. It is a word or phrase that is used in an imaginative way to show that somebody/something has the same qualities as another thing. ‘Her words were a knife in my heart’ is a metaphor.

Every time you enter the fishbowl, like the Letters, it will ask for a password. Type: fishbowl

I am watching you, 24/7 by clicking Active Topics (on top right hand corner).

When I was told to get a life, I did. It was you!

I read every word you post and in this way, I get to know you. I form an image in my mind.

Words form images but they must be established in deeds; in actuality.

Let me put it another way. Your image is represented by a word like your grade, but it is your deeds that exist in actuality.

IMAGE, WORD, REPRESENT, ESTABLISH, EXIST, DEED, ACTUALITY

Be conscious of your learning and be transparent and authentic about it on your page in the fishbowl.

How so?

Learn by adapting what and how the others are writing about the same thing.

That is, tweak (metaphor) your words, to add value for others who are reading your work.

ADAPT, TWEAK, VALUE, SEEK

Your postings must add value in the fishbowl, if we are go grow and BECOME a society (MGT345) with a distinct culture (MGT448).

We are seekers of truth, seated at a round table. Eyes watching Eyes!

II. Google Search, Reflect, Felt-Experience

You are searching concepts and following thinkers that are relevant in our time.

For example, you searched the concept Individuation and followed the work of Gilbert Simondon. That is cool!

And you applied it to yourself; you put it to use.

A word is a concept.

A word is an image

To apply a word is to comprehend it and put it to use.

When google searching a Concept, you are scrolling and looking for a sentence, just one, that resonates with you. That makes sense to you.

In order to do so, you are sorting, sifting and selecting. Please bear that in mind.

When google searching a Thinker, you are identifying what that person is known for. For instance, I have been grappling with the concept of Transindividual (please google) which Simondon is known for. It never comes easy, nor does it stick, as you will discover!

Your goal is to add value. You are creating value for your readers, that is us.

CONCEPT, COMPREHEND, APPLY, SORT, SIFT, SELECT, IDENTIFY

Your postings are terrific. Be sure of that. We are learning from each other. Read, take a break and think, and then re- read again. There is no speeding this process. You are learning how to create knowledge content, one step at a time.

Thoughts on Felt-experience and Reflection will follow in the next letter.

Sanjiv

"We are neither perceiving nor conceiving the environment as fixed or static in any way, but shifting and moving in action. We are in charge of our own destiny because we are creating and constructing our realities" 

As humans, we have the opportunity to be in control of our thoughts, actions, and our future. Each day we are faced with different situations and decisions to make. The way we handle every situation and choice helps create the path to our future. There are many obstacles we encounter in life but it is important to remember that things don't happen to us, they happen for us. You are in control of the way you react and respond to all the different situations life throws at you. In this course, we are in charge of our own destiny. We have the resources available to excel, and it is up to us if we decide to utilize them.

Date: 2/1/2022 12:52:08
Subject: thinking and learning skills
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are safe and doing well with your studies.

Every letter in the fishbowl is organized and designed to be as clear and simple as possible to improve your critical thinking and reflective skills.

The letters are self-contained and deal with particular aspects of the subject matter so that you can read them through from beginning to end, or in sections, or dip into specific letters as you need them.

I. ORGANIZE, DESIGN, IMPROVE, NUANCE, MEANING

Key terms are capitalized letters whose meaning may be used in a particular way in the letter. If you are in both courses (345 & 448), the nuance (use Thesaurus) of these words should be used in your vocabulary section. There is little point in duplication.

1. Vocabulary of capitalized letters emphasize key advice that you think will be particularly useful to your readers.

2. Google searches provide additional information that will broaden your understanding and that of your readers by giving examples and definitions.

3. Felt-experiences raise questions for your readers to consider about your personal approach to the topic.

You should regard the above as a menu from which to select the ideas that appeal to you and for developing your learning style. Ultimately, the above three categories are arbitrary and will blend into your specific point-of-view, whose development must be transparent and authentic.

II. THINKING, LEARNING, MODE

We routinely think without really contemplating what we are doing. However, in academic contexts there are benefits from a deeper understanding of the various modes of thinking, including reflection and creativity. An insight into these concepts and skills can help to improve learning. Moreover, advanced thinking skills are highly valued by employers, so being able to communicate and evidence these attributes is essential.

Having a deeper understanding of HOW you think and reflect will help you feel more confident in your studies and ensure you are equipped to perform better. Beyond this, it is important to grasp the value of ‘thinking skills’ as a product of your higher education experience. Increasingly, students are expected to be able to convince potential employers through their transcript, curriculum vitae and letter of application that they can demonstrate their abilities in this area.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

Individualization and Gilbert Simondon

Individualization: being unique in the way you learn and needs to be met. It is to engage in the right environment to support or express yourself with comfort. 

Gilbert Simondon is a philosopher known for his work or study in individualization. He inspired others to continue to study individualization. He believed that each individual was connected but still boils down to each individual. In a way we are connected but each atom has to be in a spot in order to make a whole.

Sanjiv

**********************************

Re: Grades and Grading

Hi Everyone,

How are you? The best thing we learn from storms is they end. I hope you got to play after this one.

I want to talk about grades and grading in the fishbowl. 

Historically, there have been four grades:

30% fall in the straight-A box, 

30% in the A-minus box, and 

30% get a B+. 

Around 10 percent get a B.

My job is to distinguish between the A-minus and the straight-A. The straight-A gets a letter of recommendation (please see below) and co-authorship on a research abstract developed during the semester. The latter is not always possible because it is peer reviewed before acceptance. 

The straight-A is reserved for those IMMERSED in the fishbowl. 

They are visible to all during the course of the semester.

They DISPLAY leadership in their text, i.e., their postings are helpful to readers seeking greater understanding of the subject matter.

This is achieved whenever you are AUTHENTIC and TRANSPARENT regarding your LEARNING.

You will receive specific steps regarding this process.

Process and Practice of Learning are the CORNERSTONES for getting the COVETED A.

You are adding value to the fishbowl, and not just copying the next person to complete your work.

EVIDENCE of your work and learning is visible to all; it is not between you and me for there is no place where we cannot be seen.

The difference between B+ and A- is in the quantity and quality of your postings. 

You are expected to complete all assignments on a regular and timely fashion.

Every thing less than the above is a B. No one deserves below a B because the EXPECTATION is that you are reading, reading and reading. 

Why wouldn’t you, is the question.

You get collective feedback regularly with regard to process. My letters in the fishbowl will have selected postings attached to make a point as to what you are doing and how you are doing it. One-on-one feedback is frowned upon and considered FUDGING. We are 140 of us together in the fishbowl. 

Explanations regarding process are encouraged but not whether you did it right/wrong because there is no such thing in the fishbowl. 

The question is only whether you are SATISFIED or not. If you are not, then edit, and re-edit until you feel you have done your best. 

You can improve/change your postings at any point in the semester because there are no deadlines. 

However, it is only regular work that makes the straight-A; not those who pile it on at a later date.

It’s about being ENGAGED with your learning on a CONTINUAL BASIS. 

There is no escaping this if you want an A in the course. 

I'm reproducing two letters of RECOMMENDATION as examples earned by straight-A students ....

To,

The Admissions Committee, 

I am happy to write this letter of recommendation for Mr. XXXX. He successfully completed BUS448: International Dimensions of Business and BUS443: Organizational Design & Change in the Spring of 2020. Mr. XXXX is a diligent student and completed both courses through academic excellence and hard work, earning the grades of A. 

Mr. XXXX displayed a superior ability to articulate complex concepts and apply them in various contexts, readily and effectively. 

1. In BUS448, Mr. XXXX reached a level of achievement in ‘constructing meaning’ across different world-views. He led his group by developing a complex interactive communications system that was extraordinary in its effectiveness, versatility and potential. 

XXXX displays an innate ability to discern subtle yet critical international and cross-cultural elements of communication in various contexts. 

2. During the crisis of COVID-19 this past semester, XXXX developed a framework for learning online. He has developed a mature understanding of the fundamentals of digital participation, online collaboration, and network awareness.

3. XXXX has learnt to exert control over the use of always-on communication channels. His work depicts the mindful use of digital media. ‘Thinking about what you are doing and why you are doing it instead of going through the motions’ is fundamental to Mr. XXXX working practice. This is a relevant attribute for people entering the workplace in post COVID-19. 

4. Finally, XXXX is versed in the following research methodologies: Social-Reflexivity, Participant-Observation and Symbolic-Interactionism. He co-authored a research paper titled “Immersive Learning: Heuristic Device for Transmitting Social Imaginaries.” The Abstract and full paper were accepted at the International Conference: EDULEARN20, after blind-review by International faculty.

I believe XXXX has the intellect, personality and ambition that will allow him to be successful in whatever pursuit he chooses to undertake. He is particularly suited for graduate studies. I recommend him with great enthusiasm. 

If you have any questions regarding Mr. XXXX or this letter, please be free to email me.

Thank you.

Sd/

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well; being well is central to all learning. There are several things I must attend to before this week is over. I hope they redress some of the confusion, misconception and miscommunication that surely prevails.

1. Both MGT345 and MGT448 went online/blended because of reasons beyond my control. Those who elected for in-class and face-to-face instruction may please add/drop other sections offered. Specifically, MGT 345 sections 1 to 4 and MGT 448 section 1.

There will be no Zoom, only our text in the Fishbowl, visible to all under Active Topics on the top right hand corner button.

The courses are Asynchronous. You can complete your work in your own time and, your learning can proceed at your own pace and, always in your own space. You are never behind nor left out. You can join in at any point by jumping in.

2. There are several students enrolled in both courses, and some are in the fishbowl for the second time around. Most of my letters are common to both courses. This raises the immediate question of doing vocabulary and google searches twice? 

Your learning experience and its expression in the fishbowl is differentiated by the meaning you construct. 

We are applying the following tools to generate ideas (i.e., words), structures (i.e, sentences), knowing (i.e.,experience) and knowledge (i.e., content): sorting, sifting, selecting, comparing, contrasting, categorizing, shading, gradation, variation, modulation, subtlety and nuance. These will be part of our vocabulary subsequently.

We are neither perceiving nor conceiving the environment as fixed or static in any way, but shifting and moving in action. We are in charge of our own destiny because we are creating and constructing our realities. 

In other words, the same word and the same image (in the two courses) offers the possibility and opportunity of a different interpretation and meaning. And the same google search has different notes in the taking and making. How far you wish to take your learning in each course is solely in your hands.

I will talk about grades and grading in my next letter. What is the reward for striving for a higher grade in the fishbowl where there is no distinction between right and wrong?

A suggestion and a tip before closing. Read, read and read everything three times. Mull and ponder over words. Growth happens only in the mind, and only upon reflection. More on this later. 

Please don’t hesitate in emailing me directly if anything is bothering you or confusing you. Identifying your course number and section is helpful. If I don’t respond within a day, it is never intentional.

Be safe.

Sanjiv

The courses are Asynchronous. You can complete your work in your own time and, your learning can proceed at your own pace and, always in your own space. You are never behind nor left out. You can join in at any point by jumping in.

2. There are several students enrolled in both courses, and some are in the fishbowl for the second time around. Most of my letters are common to both courses. This raises the immediate question of doing vocabulary and google searches twice? 

Your learning experience and its expression in the fishbowl is differentiated by the meaning you construct. 

We are applying the following tools to generate ideas (i.e., words), structures (i.e, sentences), knowing (i.e.,experience) and knowledge (i.e., content): sorting, sifting, selecting, comparing, contrasting, categorizing, shading, gradation, variation, modulation, subtlety and nuance. These will be part of our vocabulary subsequently.

We are neither perceiving nor conceiving the environment as fixed or static in any way, but shifting and moving in action. We are in charge of our own destiny because we are creating and constructing our realities. 

In other words, the same word and the same image (in the two courses) offers the possibility and opportunity of a different interpretation and meaning. And the same google search has different notes in the taking and making. How far you wish to take your learning in each course is solely in your hands.

I will talk about grades and grading in my next letter. What is the reward for striving for a higher grade in the fishbowl where there is no distinction between right and wrong?

A suggestion and a tip before closing. Read, read and read everything three times. Mull and ponder over words. Growth happens only in the mind, and only upon reflection. More on this later. 

Please don’t hesitate in emailing me directly if anything is bothering you or confusing you. Identifying your course number and section is helpful. If I don’t respond within a day, it is never intentional.

Be safe.

Sanjiv

MULL, PONDER, WORD, POSSIBILITY, PERCEIVE, CONCEIVE, OPPORTUNITY, ENVIRONMENT, GENERATE, EXPRESSION, MEANING, REWARD 

from the fishbowl...

 post by AidanSousa » Thu Jan 27, 2022 7:09 pm

I really enjoyed this song, and its a nice twist on ignorant patriotic songs, which often over-glorify our country. The lyrical content focuses on our short comings, and how we cradle the best and worst, which I believe to be true. The song mentions the grief, greed, and hate, implying they are all fundamental parts of our society, as much as they shouldn't be. "Democracy coming to the USA" is a really well thought out line, because although we believe our nation to be the epitome of fairness and equality, we couldn't seem farther away, and the hopefulness of the lyrics should help us believe that someday we can reach that goal.

Pragmatics and Caveats...

In MGT 345-5 we are 43 in number.

In MGT 345-6 we are 42.

In MGT 448-2 we are 45.

by 

Sharing the Meaning 

of your name, and 

whether you personify your name.

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well and getting school underway.

There are several things I must convey so you experience MGT 345 and MGT 448 with a particular frame of mind.

CONVEY, EXPERIENCE, PARTICULAR, FRAME, MIND

We will not be meeting in the allotted classrooms and scheduled time on MWF. 

We have gone online for the present and we will remain asynchronous for the most part.

ASYNCHRONOUS

What this means is you will enter and exit in digital space whenever you want. 

There will be no show-and-tell in a zoom meeting and nor are there any deadlines for assignments.

We are striving for maximum learning and minimum tension.

STRIVE, LEARN, TENSION

Our digital space aka The Fishbowl has been set up and I will send you instructions before long.

Basically, you will have your own space in which you will do your postings and your work during the semester.

There are responsibilities, however, that we must fulfill if we want to get our show on the road.

The show is the on-going creation of a Society in 345 and a Culture in 448.

The fishbowl is founded upon freedom of thought, movement and perception.

The fishbowl is the bedrock of American Society and American Culture.

The fishbowl belongs to you, individually and collectively.

At this point in time, you have opened a folder: Letters, and you are placing my letters in them.

You are reading and contemplating everything three times and, you are getting to be in the know of things.

READ, CONTEMPLATE, KNOW

Happy to be here with you!

Sanjiv

Date: 1/22/2022 11:54:19
Subject: Syllabus MGT 448: International and Cultural Dimensions of Business
------------------------------------------------------------
UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION

SPRING 2022

Sanjiv S. Dugal, Ph.D.

Human Resource Management

Address: sanjivdugal@uri.edu

Office Hours: Upon Request

MGT 448

INTERNATIONAL AND CULTURAL DIMENSIONS OF BUSINESS

PREFACE

“Culture is the expression of values, a common, renewable resource in which we meet one another, learn what can unite us and how to engage with differences in a shared space. Those differences exist within and between cultures. They must be acknowledged and engaged with. An inclusive, democratic, sustainable city enables that process, and is strengthened by it too. Culture is the creative workshop with which citizens can imagine responses to our common challenges. Sometimes it is a solution, sometimes it how we discover other solutions.” (The 2020 Rome Charter)

Taking this understanding of cultural democracy further, this semester’s agenda focuses on the key question laid out by the Rome Charter:

Culture provides its inhabitants with opportunities of shared spaces, places of learning and engagement which is led by an experience of differences and diversity within. What are these enablers which help cities to move towards an inclusive, democratic and sustainable way of life?

I. INTRODUCTION 

How do you navigate and negotiate a situation that is foreign and strange? A situation where the Other's language, customs and culture are unknown, and you have no predetermined script nor map on the ground. Under these circumstances, what skills are necessary to successfully collaborate on projects together.

“As we globalize, we increasingly have to interact, manage, negotiate and compromise with people from different cultures. Working with people whose values and beliefs, not to mention languages and customs are different from your own can make for costly misunderstandings. Experience tells us, often painfully, that one’s behavior, actions and decisions are not separate from one’s values and beliefs. All social behavior is embedded in a particular context and is connected to other deeply held values and beliefs. This means that the stakes are high for mismanaging cultural differences.” (Lisa Hoecklin, 'Managing Cultural Differences: Strategies for Competitive Advantage,' The Economist Intelligence Unit Series, Addison-Wesley, 1995)

ii. PERSPECTIVE: PROBING DIFFERENCES

As participants in the course, we are comparing each other’s cultural assumptions in terms of broad value differences. Values, according to Hofstede’s definition, is ‘a broad tendency to prefer certain states of affairs over others.’ The course identifies four dimensions of work-related value differences across cultures and builds on Hofstede’s research on power distance, uncertainty avoidance, individualism/collectivism and masculinity/femininity. In MGT 448, our individual differences in preferences, or values, have important implications for the outcome of your semester.

The course focuses on learning ‘how to probe’ for differences among ourselves in the belief that differences give a comparative perspective that provides a reflective lens for understanding why we do things the way we do them. Managing differences gives your group not only its identity but also its competitive advantage.

"In a global marketplace, many leading international business scholars are arguing that sustainable competitive advantages are increasingly changing from ‘harder ’ efficiency sources to ‘softer ’ effectiveness sources, such as, managing differences in values and beliefs. Our differences provide a reflective lens to see where we're positioned with regards to each other." (Hoecklin).

Empirical evidence suggests that creating sustainable advantages when operating with different cultures will take the following skills:

a. an ability to express;

b. flexibility in thought and action;

c. sharing and disclosing one’s position in a situation; and,

d. abstracting from the particulars of an interaction.

In order to develop these capabilities, you are being asked to communicate, collaborate, create and connect in digital space, which the course dubs as The Fishbowl.

III. CREATING A GLOBAL EXPERIENCE: THE FISHBOWL

The Fishbowl is a social network of writing/viewing/experiencing. The Fishbowl is something knowable only in specific Fishbowl practices and contingencies during the course of the semester. Understanding globalization is recognizing 'networks of meaning,’ such as those experienced in your Fishbowl, on a vast scale. In other words, we are constructing and creating meaningful experiences among ourselves that is made:

of subjectivity (in its nascent state); 

of the social (in its mutant state); and, 

of the cultural (at the point of reinvention).

IV. METHODOLOGIES: PARTICIPANT OBSERVATION, INTERPRETIVISM, SYMBOLIC INTERACTIONISM

The course fulfills the logical sequence of awareness (of differences among ourselves), knowledge (of those differences) and communication (of those differences). These three traits, viz., awareness, knowledge and communication, underlie the development of cross-cultural skills (Geert Hofstede).

The course utilizes Participant Observation, Interpretivism and Symbolic Interactionism as research methods for addressing cross-cultural questions such as:

How do you experience the ‘other’ culture?

That is, how do you experience the other’s deeply held values and beliefs?

What do you see?

How do you feel?

What did you do?

V. TEXT

1. ‘Exploring Culture, Exercises, Stories and Synthetic Cultures,’ by Gert van Hofstede, Paul B. Pedersen, Geert Hofstede. Intercultural Press, Boston, London, 2002.

Real-life exercises and stories, all with debriefings, make much of this book ideally suited for self-study. Specific activities and exercises are steps towards awareness and knowledge of differences. We will practice intercultural communication skills, and playfully experience what it feels and means to be a ‘foreigner.’

2. 'Managing Cultural Differences: Strategies for Competitive Advantage,' by Lisa Hoecklin, 'The Economist Intelligence Unit Series, Addison-Wesley, 1995. ON RESERVE IN LIBRARY.

VI. GRADE DISTRIBUTION

1. Regularity and Quality of Posting in the Fishbowl: 50%

Your grade is based upon your efforts in developing a network of symbolic structures within the Fishbowl. There will be interactive and ongoing assignments that will help you create a knowing and knowledge content around four dimensions of culture-related values, viz., identity (individualism/collectivism); gender (masculinity/femininity); power distance; and, uncertainty avoidance. These interactive assignments are 50% of your grade.

2. Attending to Meaning in Social Space: 30%

We 'attend to meaning' by sharing, responding and listening to each other. Your process will be assessed on the importance you place on 'attending to meaning.' Working in the Fishbowl is an interactive practice of shared words, symbols, images and felt-experiences. 

“When operating in a global economy, if you want your philosophies, objectives, products and services to be not only understood but also believed by employees, customers and partners in different cultures, you must attend to what these things mean to the people in each culture.” (Hoecklin, p.3)

Faster and better learning through realization is a large part of the assessment logic.

3. Final: A Self-Reflexive Process 20%

In the final analysis, you’re exploring differences in meanings that exist between group members working together on a particular idea. Your final paper (three pages, double–spaced and written individually) presents your group-experience as a coherent idea. You're obliged to become self-reflexive, suspend preconceptions, and imagine being a resident-alien researcher, who has come to study the culture of an American group in Rhode Island; Your fishbowl.

VII. SELF-ASSESSMENT IN THE FISHBOWL

Learning is about actively combining enriching experiences with academic rigor and creative opportunities. Interaction during the semester requires courage to push back boundaries of past experiences and explore the possibilities available to you. In the Fishbowl, you experience the excitement of discovering what you are capable of achieving, far more than you ever felt or thought possible. 

The following Elements are Essential:

* Knowledge

* Concept

* Skill

* Attitude

* Action

The student is able to make accurate self-assessments at any point during the semester based upon the following criteria:

BEGINNING (B) 

You have basic knowledge and skills. 

DEVELOPING (D)

You are making conceptual connections. 

ACHIEVING (A)

You have acquired knowledge and skills and making conceptual connections, and thereby developing new learning.

EXCELLING (E)

You are applying knowledge and skills beyond grade-level expectations and demonstrate self-initiated action in unfamiliar situations. You are self-motivated and an independent learner.

VIII. CONCLUSION: FISHBOWL LEARNER PROFILE

The aim of the Fishbowl is to develop global-minded participants who recognize their common purpose and shared responsibility when creating a learning environment. 

Fishbowl participants strive To Be the following:

1. Inquirers 

We nurture our curiosity, developing skills for inquiry and research.

2. Knowledgeable 

We develop and use conceptual understanding, exploring knowledge across a range of disciplines. We engage with issues and ideas that have local and global significance.

3. Thinkers 

We use critical and creative thinking skills to analyze and take responsible action on complex issues. We exercise initiative in making reasoned, ethical decisions.

4. Communicators 

We express ourselves with confidence and creatively in many ways. We collaborate actively, listening carefully to the perspectives of other individuals and groups.

5. Principled 

We act with integrity and honesty with a strong sense of fairness and justice, and with respect for the dignity and rights of Fishbowl participants.We take responsibility for our actions and their consequences.

6. Open-minded 

We critically appreciate our own cultures and personal histories, as well as the values and traditions of others. We seek and evaluate a range of points of view, and we are willing to grow from the experience.

7. Caring 

We show empathy, compassion and respect. We have a commitment to service, and we act to make a positive difference in the lives of others and in the world around us.

8. Risk-takers 

We approach uncertainty with forethought and determination; we work independently and cooperatively to explore new ideas and innovative strategies. We are resourceful and resilient in the face of challenges and change.

9. Balanced 

We understand the importance of balancing different aspects of our lives, intellectual, physical, and emotional, to achieve well-being for ourselves and others. We recognize our interdependence with other people.

10. Reflective 

We thoughtfully consider the world and our own ideas and experience. We work to understand our strengths and weaknesses in order to support our learning and personal development.

WELCOME TO MGT 448

ADDENDUM 1: TECHNOLOGIES UNDERLYING MGT 448

ADDENDUM 2: FIVE OBJECTIVES STATED BY UNIVERSITY OF Rhode Island:

1. Acquiring skills in working with others as a member of a team.

2. Developing creative capacities (writing, inventing, designing, performing).

3. Developing skill in expressing oneself in writing.

4. Learning how to critically evaluate ideas, arguments, and points of view.

5. Acquiring an interest in learning more by asking questions and seeking answers.

Success requires that you keep pace with the work, understand course concepts, and study effectively. The Academic Enhancement Center (www.uri.edu/aec) is a great place to do this. At the AEC you can work alone or in groups, and tutors and professional learning specialists are available to help you to learn, manage your time and work, and study well. They’re open Monday through Thursday from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. and Fridays until 1 p.m. All services are free (the coffee is free as well!), and no appointment is needed. You can call them for complete information at 874-2367, or just stop by the center on the fourth floor of Roosevelt Hall. 

THANK YOU

Date: 1/22/2022 11:50:02
Subject: Syllabus MGT 345: Business in Society
------------------------------------------------------------
University of Rhode Island

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS

Spring 2022

BUSINESS IN SOCIETY

MGT 345

INSTRUCTOR: SANJIV S. DUGAL

ADDRESS: sanjivdugal@uri.edu

OFFICE HOURS:

Upon Request 

PREFACE

“Word-work is sublime because it is generative; it makes meaning that secures our difference, our human difference—-the way in which we are like no other life.” 

Toni Morrison

 

I. INTRODUCTION: BUSINESS IN SOCIETY

All major social changes are ultimately characterized by a transformation of space and time in the human experience. The most profound social change is taking place in new communication technologies that are fostering the development of social spaces of visual reality. The Internet is the backbone of this global computer-mediated communication. Please see: https://www.internetsociety.org/internet/

MGT 345: Business in Society is placed within the framework of two fundamental transformations in our daily lives: the fragmentation of societies and the individualization of work. 

II. BUILDING A SOCIETY: A NETWORK OF VISUAL REALITY

Participants in MGT 345 develop and experience two interrelated concepts during the semester: The Network Society and Visual Reality. We will be developing networks of visual realities characterized by the instantaneous flow of “thought-images” among ourselves. Our networks reflect distinctive realities that are “individuations,” outside any academic or state regulation. That is to say, we will be developing unique social relations (forms of relatedness) that are manifestations of our personal network and flow of information. In organically formed groups, we develop a ‘flow’ of information among ourselves in a network shaped by algorithms, and continually accessible on our screens. The result is a visual reality, a ‘way of seeing’ and ‘being’ in the world that is unique to us, the participants. A ‘way of seeing’ is the key manifestation of ‘the network society’ according to Manuel Castells (2010). The question we’re confronting in the course: what is our ‘way of seeing’ the world? What is the visual reality of our network society?

III. COURSE DICTUM: DESCRIBE THINGS

In the course, you work like phenomenologists whose dictum is: Describe Things. The things that are described denote any ordinary thing or object or event as it presents itself to one’s experience, rather than as it may or may not be in reality. To ‘describe’ is to strip away distractions, habits, cliches of thought, presumptions and received ideas, in order to return attention to what is called ‘things in themselves.’ To capture them exactly as they appear, rather than as you think they are supposed to be. Like blind-tasting. In the course, you ‘set aside’ or ‘bracket out’ theorizing and moralizing about what the thing is, so that we are left only with the intense and immediate experience of the phenomenon. The result is a great liberation. It frees you to talk about your experience as a serious topic of investigation. The course gives a formal mode of access to one’s human experience. 

In other words, we’re concerning ourselves with concrete felt-experiences and individual aesthetic responses. We talk about our own lives while still being methodical and rigorous. Our rigor has to do with describing phenomena. Saying the music concert or the homework assignment was great is not enough. You have to stay committed to describing experience. Traditionally, we begin learning with theories from textbooks. In this course, you’re going straight for life as you experience it, moment to moment. What does it mean to be in the moment? Anticipation, perhaps? What is it for the thing ‘anticipation’ to exist, to Be? Until we ask such fundamental questions, we will not get anywhere. The method is to disregard intellectual clutter and pay attention to ‘things’ and let them reveal themselves to you.

IV. COURSE METHOD: ETHNOGRAPHIC ACTION RESEARCH

Ethnographic Action Research (EAR) is a form of participatory action research. The ethnographic approach combined with action research means that the course builds upon notions of immersion, long-term engagement and understanding local contexts holistically. Basically, the course combines three approaches: participatory techniques, ethnography and action learning. Participatory techniques are used to help participants understand complex issues in an inclusive and participatory manner. Ethnography has traditionally been used to understand different cultures in detail, and rejects preconceived ideas and categories in favor of locally emergent ones. Action learning allows us to turn what we learn from re-search into actions, then re-search those actions, and adjust and adapt accordingly.

A foundational concept of EAR is ‘communicative ecologies.’ A communicative ecology is made up of communicative assemblages and refers to the complex systems of communication, media and information flows in a community. Whenever we start to notice HOW participants communicate around certain themes, or HOW they accomplish certain tasks, we start to appreciate which channels and flows are used and why; and, how this relates to other possible uses, and therefore, where are the opportunities and barriers to a development initiative.

V. “IS THERE A TEXT IN THIS CLASS?” 

You will receive around 100 letters during the trajectory of the semester. What happens to you as readers of these letters, and what does their text make you feel and do is bring into the world something that hitherto did not exist. At best this can be qualified as visual reality. Reading the letters in a particular way is the focal point in the course because it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend on both, the text and on the exercise of your human faculties (senses, wits, reason, intelligence). In other words, the letter’s text represents a potential effect that is realized in the reading process. This happens whenever you, as reader, assemble the meaning of the letter in a process of ‘re-creative dialectics.’ 

To get the participation going, there are necessary prerequisites. These prerequisites are laid out in the letters in a wide range of specific instructions. By the end of the course, you are able to see how you generate and occupy ideas, abstractions and words; how you move about and how you conduct yourself in perceptual space.

The following seminal Texts are used by the Instructor as references in MGT 345:

Reference:

1. Manuel Castells, 2010, The Rise Of The Network Society, Vol.1-3, Wiley-Blackwell

2. Margaret Dikovitskaya, 2005, Visual Culture, M.I.T. Press

3. David Harvey, 1990, The Condition of Post Modernity, Blackwell

4. Nicholas Mirzoeff, 2016, How To See The World, Basic Books

5. Mike Chang and Nigel Thrift, Eds, 2000, Thinking Space, Routledge

6. Zygmunt Bauman, 2003, Liquid Love, Polity

7. Anthony Giddens, 1986, The Constitution of Society, California University Press

8. Antonio Negri, 2008, The Porcelain Workshop: For a New Grammar of Politics, Semiotext(e)

9. Bruno Latour, 2007, Reassembling the Social, Oxford

10. Muriel Combes, 2013, Gilbert Simondon and the Philosophy of the Transindividual, The MIT Press.

11. Wolfgang Iser, 2006, how to do theory, Blackwell Publishing, MA, USA; Oxford, UK; Victoria, Australia

VI. PRACTICE AND PROCESS

The method that is practiced in MGT345 begins with the simple act of paying attention to a word with care and respect. Word-practices are found in many traditions around the globe. It is having awareness that arises by non-judgmentally paying attention, on purpose, to the present moment. Such awareness is a combination of receptivity, like listening, alertness and attentive presence. That is, letting everything else be in the background or letting it go entirely.

The course requires a different thinking; a thinking that ‘knowing,’ reminds you, awakens you, brings you to yourself, transforms you. Besides claiming to transform the way you think about doing business in society, the course promises to change how you think about yourselves. There is no traced-out path that will lead you; you must constantly invent your own path. But to invent it, you have to be free, responsible, without excuse, for every hope lies within you. In the end, we have no other interest than this: to reconnect with normal lived-experience. 

VII. ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATION: FORMING A SOCIETY

In MGT 345, we are developing skills to convince viewers of the advantages of one’s semantic and action-orienting powers. Our success, under the circumstances, will have the following two characteristics: first, multiple channels of communication that helped us frame issues; and second, credibility that is enhanced by sustained practices and processes. When undertaking any developmental initiative, it is, ultimately, our sustained practices and processes that will determine success.

VIII. GRADE: DISTRIBUTION

1. Transnational Organizations 40%

Empirical research identifies four characteristics of successful transnational organizations, viz., 

Integrated Networking Structures, 

Complex Adaptive Systems, 

Dynamic Decision-Making, and 

Unique Innovative Capabilities. 

Each characteristic is developed by participants in an interactive exercise of 10 steps.

2. Deep Reading: Concepts, Images, Perspectives: 20%

You are developing slower and essential cognitive processes such as critical thinking, reflection, and empathy—-all parts of deep reading. 

What you read, how you read, and why you read what you read changes how you think. The quality of your reading is not only an index of the quality of your thought, it is the best-known path to developing whole new path-ways.

3. Deconstructing Letters: 20%

The act of taking on the perspective and feelings of others is communication effected in solitude and depicts an intimate emotional dimension within the course experience. Through analogies, drawing inferences, and arriving at independent judgments, you learn to “deconstruct” text and thereby generate feelings and experiences.

4. Final Reflection: Visual Reality and Network Society: 20%

Reflecting on your visual reality and network society by “looking at yourself looking at yourself.”

IX. POSTSCRIPT: INDIVIDUATION 

Individuation, or the way you distinguish yourself from others, is always in relationship and, it is a process. Individuation makes awareness, action and evaluation possible. 

At the end of the day, after it is all said and done, your grade is determined by two things: level of engagement and creation of value. How often, how much and to what end did you develop and individuate yourself? To address that, you’re expected to regularly respond under the following Topic heads:

1. Notes: Taking and Making 

2. Vocabulary: Concepts and Thought-images

3. Reading Process and Deconstructing Text 

4. Four Interactive Assignments

EPILOGUE

“MGT 345 is about becoming who you are. Upon completing the course, you are not arriving at any fixed destination nor will you find some permanent room with a view. But you will see and experience for yourselves that whenever you reach for the highest, you become who you are.”

Addendum 2: Five Objectives stated by the University of Rhode Island

1. Acquiring skills in working with others as a member of a team.

2. Developing creative capacities (writing, inventing, designing, performing).

3. Developing skill in expressing oneself in writing.

4. Learning how to critically evaluate ideas, arguments, and point of view. 

5. Acquiring an interest in learning more by asking questions and seeking answers.

Success requires that you keep pace with the work, understand course concepts, and study effectively.

The Academic Enhancement Center (www.uri.edu/aec) is a great place to do this. At the AEC you can work alone or in groups, and tutors and professional learning specialists are available to help you to learn, manage your time and work, and study. The URI Writing Center, located in Roosevelt Hall 009 (lower level, Memorial Union end), offers one-on-one and small group peer tutoring for student writers in all majors who need help developing ideas or would benefit from advice on any aspect of writing. The Center serve all student writers, not just “beginners.” Writers are encouraged to bring a draft, notes, syllabus, or any relevant information to help facilitate the session. Appointments are 45 minutes in length and can be scheduled online at uri.mywconline.com. It's best to make appointments in advance, especially during midterms and finals, but we often have same-day and drop-in appointments available throughout the day so writers can stop by to see what's open. For more information visit uri.edu/aec/writing.

They’re open Monday through Thursday from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. and Fridays until 1 p.m. All services are free (the coffee is free as well!), and no appointment is needed. You can call them for complete information at 874-2367, or just stop by the center on the fourth floor of Roosevelt Hall.

Thank You

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 1/22/2022 11:43:36
Subject: Welcome Aboard!
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

My name is Sanjiv Dugal and I am a professor in Human Resource Management, teaching MGT 345 and MGT 448. You may call me Sanjiv. I welcome you to 2022 Spring semester. You will NOT find me in Bright Space but in my letters. So please set up a Folder and call it: Sanjiv’s Letters.

Ten years from now, my guess is that I will remember, not just the destruction wrought by the pandemic, but also many valuable lessons it taught me.

I think the first lesson was the Value of Gratitude. 

During the pandemic, every morning I started making a list of things that happened the previous day that I needed to be grateful for. It turned out to be a surprisingly long list, day after day. As the pandemic raged on, the list doubled and tripled in length because there was so much more to be grateful every day. A warm bed. The roof over my head. Food on the table. And most of all, civility with which I'm always greeted.

The second great lesson was the Value of Resilience. 

I know my work stayed on track because students showed amazing resilience. Each of you is an inspiring example of resilience. For you, life changed overnight. At a very crucial time, schools closed, but you adapted quickly. You faced constraints but you found creative solutions to overcome them. You learned to study online. You gave exams without physical proximity. You sent-off university applications and pursued educational goals. You used hard technology to sustain softer aspects of life such as friendships and camaraderie. Life turned upside down, but you did not let it keep you down.

 

The third great lesson was the Value of Recognition.

I began to recognize how much my welfare depends on the welfare of others. When the crisis first struck, I hardly thought the pandemic could shatter lives. But after that, I began to realize how your absence makes my life and work so much more difficult. It hit home to me that in a crisis, the most vulnerable are the foundation on which economic prosperity and the quality of our life depends.

So let us congratulate each other for arriving at this point. Through collaboration and coordination, aspiring for clarity, coherence and connection, we shall prevail once more.

I am attaching the syllabi for MGT 345 and MGT 448 The courses are not difficult, as you will discover during the course of the semester. Further clarifications and explanations of the syllabi will follow.

Welcome aboard!

Sanjiv

9/12

"To address the meaning of anything, we turn to the dictionary, aka the carpenter's tool-box."

A tool-box is an arsenal of tools that someone may need to accomplish a task. In the task of searching for meaning behind words, we always look in the dictionary. This may not always give a full picture, as it does not interpret between the lines.

Post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:47 pm

9/15

"In this reality, which is perceptual and visual, we lead a double life"

There is an objective and subjective reality. The objective reality is what is seen, what is visual. This is not disputable, because it is quite literally what has occurred and been seen. What can be disputed is the perception of that visual reality. The same reason why eyewitness testimony is not heavily favored in court is because perception can be deceiving.

Post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:47 pm

9/17

"Because there is no right nor wrong in such a reality"

The fishbowl has no right and no wrong answer. This forum is about determining what sounds and appears to be the correct meaning in the eyes of the beholder.

9/19

"A daily practice of reflection, contemplation and meditation is a good idea."

Practicing meditation, reflection and contemplation can lead to discovering new areas of your psyche that you were locked away from. Reflecting on yourself and your actions at the end of a day can help you make more educated decisions in the future.

This reminds me of the terms “deafening silence,” and “silence speaks volumes.” Sometimes, not saying something at all can be more impactful than saying anything. In a technological world, silence is much easier to come by as textual communication is easily ignored.

Post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:50 pm

9/28

"Copying is an essential part of being human because without copying we cannot understand ourselves or the world we live in. "

Humans by nature are social creatures. We mimic the world around us in an attempt to become part of a social and cultural structure. By copying what is said and done around us we assimilate to cultural norms and find a place in the world.

Post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:51 pm

9/29

"The nature and effect of metaphor is complex and fundamental"

Metaphors create analogies between ideas. If something is explicitly told, it is either not a metaphor or is a lackluster one at best. Being able to interpret words beyond literal meaning is a key skill in the textual world we live in, it is fundamental.

Post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:51 pm

10/5

"We live in a textual world and we are made by language."

This is true now more than ever. Text is the primary form of communication in the modern world. I have many more conversations over textual mediums than face-to-face or via audio/video. Humans are social creatures and we communicate to stay alive.

Post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:51 pm

10/6

"Your work is ’singular' and lives only for the moment and then it is archived."

In an educational sense, this is true. Work is completed and accomplished and then sent for grading, never to be touched again. From a societal point of view, this can be disputed, as one could argue the legacy of one’s work lives for more than just the moment.

post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:52 pm

10/9

"reading allows us to recognize each other."

Reading teaches language and thoughtfulness. By reading, we are able to better engage and recognize what is meant between the lines, developing the third eye. Developing the third eye is key to understanding and recognizing what people mean when they speak to you. Certain mannerisms can be distinguished textually allowing someone to be identified just through speech.

post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:53 pm

10/12

"reading is the focal point because it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend on words and on your ability to express them. "

Reading is a focal point because it expands our vocabulary and better allows us to express the message we are trying to convey. When one person’s vocabulary is more advanced than another's, a disconnect can occur.

post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:56 pm

10/14

"As humans we are both spirit and flesh"

This sentence encapsulates the spiritual belief that we have about our world around us and our place in it. There is a physical, objective, tangible world, and there is a metaphorical, non-physical, psychological world that exists within ourself.

 post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:57 pm

10/22

"we convey the making of ourselves"

I took this sentence to mean that we convey what we want others to see about ourselves and who we are. These posts convey the inner workings of our minds, and the way we portray ourselves is effectively the "making of ourselves" in the sense that we create a perception to the outside world, an alias is created.

post by andrewbarr » Fri Dec 10, 2021 11:58 pm

11/05

"One's 'frame of mind' is a reflexive one."

Being able to develop a frame of mind requires the ability to reflect and create thoughts about yourself from an objective standpoint. Taking stock of your thoughts, words and actions is crucial to developing an accurate and stable perception of the world.

11/08

"being adrift on the high seas in a fishbowl."

The fishbowl can be compared to an entire sea when you consider the scale of a fishbowl compared to the fish inside of it. To us from an outside perspective, a fishbowl is small, but to a fish, the fishbowl is massive and daunting. This is a metaphor for the fishbowl being difficult to maneuver and create inside of due to the need for reflection and interpretation.

post by andrewbarr » Sat Dec 11, 2021 12:00 am

11/08

"being adrift on the high seas in a fishbowl."

The fishbowl can be compared to an entire sea when you consider the scale of a fishbowl compared to the fish inside of it. To us from an outside perspective, a fishbowl is small, but to a fish, the fishbowl is massive and daunting. This is a metaphor for the fishbowl being difficult to maneuver and create inside of due to the need for reflection and interpretation.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 12/10/2021 19:08:21
Subject: bitter-sweet
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? 

How does one leave a ‘sphere,' which was an ‘assemblage' of concepts, images, affects and feelings, with its own vocabulary and ‘discourse’? 

A 'perceptual space' where we were 'participant-observers,' conscious of being in the act of perceiving each other; apperception. A space where true knowledge was only the knowledge of knowledge, and reference to something was founded upon reference to oneself.

Upon leaving, I would say that our relation to every ‘sphere' tends to articulate itself primarily through possibilities, opportunities, and chances, instead of according to linear and univocal directions. 

As we leave with our experiences, our theoretical challenge remains to identify new and important ways of experiencing things through forms of re-arranged word structures. For example, I would say that in your fishbowls (through new vocabulary, google searches and letters), you artfully weaved together historical and contemporary perspectives with emerging technological developments to reveal innovative possibilities for creation. Congratulations!

Please see reflection below.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

Date: 12/8/2021 23:00:53
Subject: construct a knowing
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I was in self-doubt as to what I must write to MGT448. 

That is, what frame or structure; and which dimension and dichotomy must I adopt? 

I do know that whenever you are stuck, it is words that show you the way. 

Of course, they can also lead you astray.

I also know the spark for creativity can come from anywhere, so long you stay close to text. That is, being in awareness of the differences in meaning, and the significance of one's words. Anyway, upon reading Mat Greene’s posting below, and his juxtaposition of text, I knew then the framework with which to construct a knowing and knowledge.

II.

The “other” in the films (Japanese Story and Outsourced) are operating on different dimensions entirely. We experience that when we watch the films as ethnomethodologists.

How do you spot the concept (that is, one word) and the dimension (of two words)?

Example: Identity: collective/individualist

Navigating and negotiating in unchartered terrain, one word (step) at a time...until trust and friendship is established. See Japanese Story.

You pick a word or phrase spoken, and along with the context (image in the film) you deconstruct the text/image and above all, share it with the other.

Observation and Interpretation. The cornerstone of communication across cultures.

You don’t have to get stuck with Hofstede’s dimensions. I’m not particularly fond of them myself. The world is far more complex. But they are a good starting point. We create dimensions and concepts with words, and whenever we are rigid with our dimensions, and the meaning of words, we fail to make a connection. You see this repeatedly in Outsourced. We see how quickly Todd Anderson adapts and comes out ahead. He visited URI, you know. Smart guy. He made a film of his experience with strong messages.

What were Todd's attributes?

Curiosity and wonder is big.

Showing Respect is a given.

Listening to a local person for explanation.

Reflecting, continuously.

Understanding how symbols work. Asha explaining Goddess Kali (please google) as a symbol.

Bottom line: Listen and watch the Other, simultaneously maintain your Critical Autonomy, but above all, share your reflection. By so doing, Todd Anderson in Outsourced and Sandy in Japanese Story transformed themselves.

Sanjiv

SHARE, REFLECTION

from the fishbowl...

post by mgreene3146 » Wed Dec 08, 2021 12:45 pm

11-29

Other- In phenomenology, the terms the Other and the Constitutive Other identify the other human being, in his and her differences from the Self, as being a cumulative, constituting factor in the self-image of a person; as acknowledgement of being real; hence, the Other is dissimilar to and the opposite of the Self, of Us, and of the Same. The Constitutive Other is the relation between the personality (essential nature) and the person (body) of a human being; the relation of essential and superficial characteristics of personal identity that corresponds to the relationship between opposite, but correlative, characteristics of the Self, because the difference is inner-difference, within the Self. The condition and quality of Otherness (the characteristics of the Other) is the state of being different from and alien to the social identity of a person and to the identity of the Self.

Critical Autonomy- The basic idea of critical autonomy (as I understand it) is that one holds oneself to consistent criteria for evaluation of traits like credibility, accuracy, point of view, etc. – the basic features of most informational texts – as well as understanding (or, when necessary, seeking understanding) of the “how and why”/constructedness of all forms of media, from the most personal/amateur (a YouTube video or an email from a friend, say) to the most professional (a Hollywood blockbuster or fashion magazine).

A “critically autonomous person” can either answer questions about a given thing or at least tell you how one would reasonably find those answers; this person would also know what kinds of questions to ask about the thing.
