Date: 12/2/2021 20:51:57
Subject: rules of grammar and syntax
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? You’ve been on my mind.

It is always a reflexive space. 

Your text has the ability to generate more text 

We are inspiring each other by viewing each other’s text. 

We view our differences represented by our choice of words.

Like being on a catwalk.

Whenever a group of people, like ourselves in a fishbowl, occupy a common mental space (vocabulary) and a reading and writing strategy together (our procedures for posting), 

they form a society of extraordinary social complexity and ‘assemblages’ is one way of looking at it in visual space. 

Please google Assemblage Theory. 

From wiki:

Assemblage theory is an ontological framework developed by Gilles Deleuze and Félix Guattari, originally presented in their book A Thousand Plateaus(1980). Assemblage theory provides a bottom-up framework for analyzing social complexity by emphasizing fluidity, exchangeability, and multiple functionalities.[1] Assemblage theory asserts that, within a body, the relationships of component parts are not stable and fixed; rather, they can be displaced and replaced within and among other bodies, thus approaching systems through relations of exteriority.[1]

What makes us distinct as a fishbowl is that 

we are sharing strategies for reading and writing texts.

Namely, doing vocabulary, sharing google searches and deconstructing text.

We are what Stanley Fish calls an Interpretive community. Please google.

As a group of people, we share a common relation to a Text in the fishbowl. All of our writing brings the same transformational/interpretative procedures to bear on the text-to-be-interpreted or to be understood.

From this perspective, we are a textual society (please see Bettencourt’s posting), unified around adherence to a common set of rules which 'enable meaning transformation and mediations.’ That is to say, our society and culture in the fishbowl is comparable to the transformations made possible by the rules of grammar and syntax.

The world needs a new grammar and syntax. We need to describe the formation of an alternative horizon and look for a way to define the practices and modes of expression that democracy can take. 

The simple and concrete possibility of transforming the world is still here. 

The fishbowl that you have constructed is testimony to a new world order. 

Sanjiv

GRAMMAR, SYNTAX, ENABLE, TRANSFORMATION AND MEDIATION

from the fishbowl...

Date: 12/2/2021 1:03:00
Subject: creating, constructing and revealing phantasms
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you?

When you scroll the active topics at any time in the fishbowl, what you see is your "ability to construct and reveal phantasms--- blends of cultural ideas and sensory imagination.” (D. Fox Harrell) Please see Jillian Stack’s posting below.

How so? What does this mean? How do I interpret it and understand it? This is frightening to me!

What is my ability to construct and reveal what? 

Please cut the mumbo jumbo.

In the fishbowl you are constructing and revealing a "blend of cultural ideas and sensory imagination."

Deconstruct and substitute the words till you arrive at an understanding that is unique to you and your trajectory.

A blend of cultural words and sensory images.

A blend of community words and visual-experiences.

A blend of fishbowl words and felt-experiences.

Through this blend,

this merging and combination

of "cultural ideas and sensory imagination," 

this experience of the last several months, 

you have created and constructed 

"history as possibility" (Paulo Freire). Please google.

We are indeed a society and a sub-culture.

You are to be congratulated, mostly for your perseverance and discipline.

Sanjiv

BLEND, CULTURAL, IDEA, SENSORY, IMAGINATION, HISTORY, POSSIBILITY, PERSEVERANCE

Letter 11/30

Phantasmal Media:

In Phantasmal Media, D. Fox Harrell considers the expressive power of computational media. He argues, forcefully and persuasively, that the great expressive potential of computational media comes from the ability to construct and reveal phantasms—blends of cultural ideas and sensory imagination.

Post by jillianstack » Tue Nov 30, 2021 10:07 pm

Letter 11/30

Phantasmal Media:

In Phantasmal Media, D. Fox Harrell considers the expressive power of computational media. He argues, forcefully and persuasively, that the great expressive potential of computational media comes from the ability to construct and reveal phantasms—blends of cultural ideas and sensory imagination.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 11/30/2021 22:31:15
Subject: about phantasms
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? There are some natural concerns among you, which I will address here.

There is no Final Exam as such.

Your final posting in the fishbowl must be before the day is out on December 10.

Your grades are sorted into: B, B+, A- and A.

I have pretty-much read every word you have posted.

If you only read the text generated in the fishbowl, and barely posted, nevertheless, your experience and learning warrants a B.

This is the period you can move one notch up.

There is a finale to the course which is going-on right now, and it consists of 12 and 16 words in the two courses. 

The How To is underway and it is on my end.

I am one letter behind in Culture (448). It is a difficult subject. 

Culture's contemplation and conversation invariably saves whatever catastrophe we find ourselves in, like Sandy and Hiromitsu in Japanese Story.

What an unlikely pair!

It boils down to stopping in our tracks and sincerely asking the “other": what did you mean by that?

Please remember that as a mantra. It was the hallmark of Todd Anderson in Outsourced (448), and got him home, transformed.

He was into self-reflexivity.

So was Lola in Kinky Boots (345). That’s an amazing story when you look at it closely. Charlie Price and Lola have made a ton of money, because they interpreted their story and framed themselves as iconic figures. Avatars from a mystical place, the Price Shoe Factory became a Factory of Fantasy. 

Please google Phantasmal Media and D.Fox Harrell. 

In Phantasmal Media, D. Fox Harrell considers the expressive power of computational media. He argues, forcefully and persuasively, that the great expressive potential of computational media comes from the ability to construct and reveal phantasms—blends of cultural ideas and sensory imagination.

 

It is what we are suggesting in the fishbowl: to do business in a digital society is to be in the production of icons. Producing and exchanging symbols. They are self-generated words. All words, interrelated in specific ways.

Please see Christina Germino’s posting below.

Sanjiv

ICON, MYSTICAL, AVATAR, FANTASY

from the fishbowl...

christinagermino

Joined: Tue Sep 14, 2021 2:17 pm

Tue Nov 30, 2021 4:25 pm

vocab: 

1. incarnate (adj): (especially of a deity or spirit) embodied in flesh; in human form.

2. spirit (noun): the nonphysical part of a person which is the seat of emotions and character; the soul.

3. embody (verb): be an expression of or give a tangible or visible form to (an idea, quality, or feeling).

4. symbol (noun): a thing that represents or stands for something else, especially a material object representing something abstract.

"symbols are a constant requirement of human nature which is made up of both soul and body" This stuck out to me because this is very true, and also we as humans love and gravitate towards symbols as they provide a sense of strong meaning and convey something that we can understand and relate to. Symbols are used in everyday life and in every industry. They make up our society and the way people feel about them is heavily dependent on their perspective and their individual experiences.

vocab: 

1. incarnate (adj): (especially of a deity or spirit) embodied in flesh; in human form.

2. spirit (noun): the nonphysical part of a person which is the seat of emotions and character; the soul.

3. embody (verb): be an expression of or give a tangible or visible form to (an idea, quality, or feeling).

4. symbol (noun): a thing that represents or stands for something else, especially a material object representing something abstract.

"symbols are a constant requirement of human nature which is made up of both soul and body" This stuck out to me because this is very true, and also we as humans love and gravitate towards symbols as they provide a sense of strong meaning and convey something that we can understand and relate to. Symbols are used in everyday life and in every industry. They make up our society and the way people feel about them is heavily dependent on their perspective and their individual experiences.

11/29 Expansion, Exploration, Resolve 

“It is more a question of understanding your process and giving evidence. Show and Tell. The process is the product. Please keep that in mind.”

The purpose of our posts in the fishbowl are to show that we have deepened our understanding of the topics in the letters. We show that we understand the topics and how this course works by posting our definitions of the vocabulary, showing our results of the Google searches, and displaying our deconstructions. This shows everyone that we were able to follow the rules and complete what was asked by us while expanding our learning and our ways. We are completing a ‘show and tell’ or some sort by showing our classmates the process that we completed with each letter and telling them our thoughts and connections to the topics.

11/29 Expansion, Exploration, Resolve 

“It is more a question of understanding your process and giving evidence. Show and Tell. The process is the product. Please keep that in mind.”

The purpose of our posts in the fishbowl are to show that we have deepened our understanding of the topics in the letters. We show that we understand the topics and how this course works by posting our definitions of the vocabulary, showing our results of the Google searches, and displaying our deconstructions. We are completing a ‘show and tell’ or some sort by showing our classmates the process that we completed with each letter and telling them our thoughts and connections to the topics.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 11/21/2021 13:34:25
Subject: Grades, Assignment and Method
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope to allay any anxiety you might be feeling on account of the course and lay out how I see things, particularly in our circumstances from covid to climate change. 

I. Grades

1. The course has been designed in a way that so long you are receiving the letters, you can complete the course anytime in the future by following the reading strategy laid out in the letters. You have paid for the letters and they come with the grade B. You are a legitimate member and have access to inter-subjective things you can see. 

In a visual culture, voyeurs pay to see and to learn by looking. Same as not opening your window during a zoom faculty meeting.

2. If you do your vocabulary in its entirety, and some deconstruction and google searches, it is a B+. 

3. The As are divided into A- and A, and evaluated on quantity and quality of postings; value added.

4. Only the straight A will be entitled to a letter of recommendation describing their skills evidenced in the course. I will send a draft before long.

II. Assignment: General Framework

To complete the course, you are deconstructing and reflecting on the following 12 words in MGT345 and 16 words in MGT448.

Your work is carried out online in your fishbowls, and can be completed any time before the date of the final exam. 

After that, lights out for evaluation.

MGT345: Characteristics of global business: 12 words

1. Integrated, networking structure (3 words)

2. Dynamic decision-making

3. Adaptive coordination mechanisms

4. Unique innovation capabilities

MGT448: Hofstede’s Dimensions: 16 words

1. Collectivism / Individualism

2. Large Power Distance / Small Power Distance

3. Femininity / Masculinity

4. Strong Uncertainty Avoidance / Weak Uncertainty Avoidance

Reading text and reflecting in writing and watching the following films: 

Strictly Ballroom and Kinky Boots in 345.

Japanese Story and Moonrise Kingdom and Outsourced in 448.

There will be a couple of films and further instructions to follow.

You are observing incidents in the films, and then selecting an incident to explain the above terms (12 and 16 words).

You are putting yourselves in the shoes of the characters you are watching. Why are they behaving the way they are behaving? 

Where’s the beef? Where do the 12 and 16 words fit in the films?

To empower your text, you give personal felt-experiences as examples to explain the 12 words (MGt345) and 16 words (MGT448)..

III. Theory and Research method

1. We are expressing points-of-view and showing their development by sharing our constructed and reconstructed sentences; sharing our compositions.

2. Resources are words from dictionary, thesaurus, internet and postings in the fishbowl.We are limited only by our vocabulary and imagination.

3. Our method is to “deconstruct" a word by substituting other words, to get to its true significance and meaning.

4. We are restructuring structures of words. In simple terms, changing the structure of sentences; the arrangement of words, its form and its composition. 

5. Why are we doing this? Because in the virtual and visual world, without construction, and without a constructing and constructed self, there is no meaning. 

6. Meaning is constructed in acts of interpretation. It becomes our point-of-view. Please verify this in your postings.

We are social constructivists. It is how society, culture and interaction takes place in a visual world.

To accomplish the above, we follow a reflexive methodology.

"Whenever we reflect, we think about our thoughts, our observations and our use of language. Consequently, reflection is difficult." (Alvesson and Skoldberg, p. 245).

1. Premise of my thoughts. Where did my thoughts come from? From something in my memory.

2. What am I observing? What is the thing I am looking at? What does the image represent?

3. Use of language. What words am I selecting over others to express myself.

More letters on method and steps for doing the above final assignment will continue for deeper understanding. Please see Jean Cazeau’s posting below.

I want to close by saying you are doing well in the course, and we are an inspiration to each other. 

We raised ourselves above the rabble and rubble and focused together for a while.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

post by jeancazeau » Sun Nov 21, 2021 12:33 am

Actor

An actor is someone who participates in an action or process. Actors express ideas and portray characters in film or other media. They interpret script to inform or entertain the audience. The fishbowl represents the set, and we have been given a blue print or a script. Our performance earns us the title and rights of an actor. The real question is what are we performing? Who are we portraying?

Could it be that we are portraying ourselves and the wholeness of who we are? I would argue that we are indeed learning to become who we already are. We are embodying a future version of ourselves filled with knowledge that we either have yet to learn or in the process of learning.

Hi Everyone,

I hope you are staying well. I’ve read your fishbowls and submitted the abstract. The deadline for submission has been extended to Dec.2. Please visit web site at INTED22. 

Those who wish to step onto the digital stage and be Actor and not Audience or Voyeur, you have time yet to write your script. That is, step-up your postings of: Vocabulary, Google Searches and Deconstructing letters.

Learning takes place in our heads. Our process and practice is evidence of what is going on in our heads; mental frameworks.

As an example, our process and practice in the fishbowl brought about the mental framework, depicted by the word-images: Actor/Audience/Voyeur.

The metaphor is theatre or play.

We created it. Yes you, and I.

It’s in our heads.

And we included everyone. I’m generally in the audience, but we’re all voyeurs as well. Be a professional foreigner. It’s my nature. Apperception is the skill to get into and Empathy as well. These are learnable and essential in the digital world.

You have got the process and practice down, from what I can tell.

No more theory,...well, I don’t know if that is possible for any deeper understanding.

You will get specific assignments and steps, which hopefully will bring the course together for you. But you must follow instructions and work on the balance between films, textbook and letters. They must feed off each other, if you look deeper. When watching film, focus on expression of the face. It depicts attitude. 

Ultimately, its your observations (sentences spoken) and your interpretations (selected words) that must be shared. 

You’re developing the skill of having a logical point of view. 

You separate what you observe in a scene from the film, 

and then you interpret it. 

You do this by selecting sentences spoken in the film, they are examples of mental framework, 

and after that, you project your interpretation.

Easy enough, but if we can write it out and share it, we might save the planet and the fishbowl.

Sanjiv

CONSTRUCTING SOCIAL SPACES OF LEARNING THROUGH REFLEXIVE READING IN A VISUAL REALITY

S. Dugal1, E. Torgersen1, J. Stack1, S. Santa Barbara1, T. Murphy1, A. Catanzaro1, D. Volpe1, H. Schmidt1, S. Olivo1, M. Greene1, D. Garcia1, N. Stpierre1, J. Machado1, C. Staples1, A. Carollo1, J. Cazeau1, E. Chratian1, S. Scymcyk1, S. Watelet1, B. Murphy1, H. Logue1, A. Lavecchia1, T. Norbury1, C. Auclair1, C. Benbenek1, A. Brink1, J. Hallas1, H. Pangburn1, T. Sanfilippo1, Z. Spinella1, M. Bergantine1, S. James1, M. Baran1, M. Capuano1, E. Dapprich1, R. Murawski1, K. Susi1, E. Youngs1, C. Longworth1, C. Morelli1, R. Winn1, A. Ortega1, L. Alvernaz1, R. Singh2, M. Troiano3, S. Singh4

1 University of Rhode Island (UNITED STATES)

2 RLStudio (INDIA)

3 ClearHead (UNITED STATES)

4 Savvy (UNITED STATES)

sanjivdugal@uri.edu, erin_torgersen@uri.edu, jillian_stack@uri.edu, ssantabarbara@uri.edu, timmurphy561@uri.edu, andrewcatanzaro@uri.edu, dominic_volpe@uri.edu, hschmidt@uri.edu, scott_olivo@uri.edu, mgreene3146@uri.edu, daniel_garcia2@uri.edu, nathan_stpierre@uri.edu, machadojake2000@uri.edu, colin_staples@uri.edu, antonio_carollo@uri.edu, jean_cazeau@uri.edu, erin_chratian@uri.edu, sscymcyk@uri.edu, swatelet@uri.edu, bridgetmurphy13@uri.edu, haley_logue@uri.edu, alavecchia@uri.edu, taro_norbury@uri.edu, ciara_auclair@uri.edu, connorbenbenek@uri.edu, alexa_brink@uri.edu, justinhallas15@uri.edu, hpangburn@uri.edu, taliasanfilippo@uri.edu, zspinella@uri.edu, mcbergantine@my.ccri.edu, sara_james@uri.edu, michael_baran@uri.edu, michael_capuano@uri.edu, evelindapprich@uri.edu, rafal_murawski@uri.edu, katysusi11@uri.edu, emily_youngs@uri.edu, coreylongworth@uri.edu, cmorelli1@uri.edu, ryan_winn@uri.edu, arturo_ortega@uri.edu, l_alvernaz8@uri.edu, rahoulsingh@gmail.com, michael.troiano1@verizon.net, shivsingh@gmail.com

Introduction:

New communication technologies are fostering social spaces in visual realities that are essentially participative and collaborative in nature. According to Peter Sloterdijk, this ever-changing socio-technological environment reveals the necessity of a new conception of the human as inherently relational and spatially determined: a being in spheres. We are 150 humans in a digital Fishbowl where we can ‘see’ each other in a textual reality. 

Our paper presents a “reading strategy” and a "practice" that sets in motion experientially-felt human responses, thereby creating conditions for the objective study of topics usually regarded as subjective. In the Fishbowl, participants systematically contemplate ‘learning structures’ and the phenomena that appear in acts of conscious thought. According to Wolfgang Iser, ‘effective learning’ is an ongoing interaction between Author, Text and Reader, for it brings into play the imaginative and perceptive faculties of the reader. Reading sets in motion activities that depend both on the text and the exercise of basic human faculties. Wolfgang Iser posits that ‘effective learning’ and ‘aesthetic responses’ have characteristics that are neither of the text nor the reader, but instead, the text represents a ‘potential effect’ that is ‘realized’ in the ‘reading process.’ Only when we give a text the power to have meaning by realizing it, does it become effective.

Purpose:

To show a process of “reflexive” reading that facilitates experientially-felt responses and creates intersubjective ‘spaces’ of learning in a visual reality.

Method:

1. Conscious experience and self-reflexivity, rather than Cartesian method of analysis. Through reflection, participants discover the Self and others; how they differ and coalesce. 

2. Redirect reading from prescribed text to seeking essential learning from each other’s text. 

3. Using anecdotal felt-experiences, participants temporally and spatially zigzag with the text, filling-in new and unknown details.

4. Focus on learning structures created in the moment. The new does not exist before the initial act of reading and every subsequent reading produces newer realizations. 

5. Meaning is assembled dialectically by reading multiple texts in the Fishbowl and arriving at an individual point-of-view.

Outcome:

1. The social space of learning in a visual reality was constituted by multi-layered text with flexible structures and interpretations.

2. Reading was not static but dynamic and evolving; an ongoing process of interaction between author, text and reader. 

3. There is a verifiable rationale for each participant’s learning, grounded not in right or wrong but ideas, themes and images, held true at a moment in time. 

References:

[1] Patrick Roney & Andrea Rossi (2021) SLOTERDIJK’S ANTHROPOTECHNICS, Angelaki

[3] Henri Lefebvre, The Production of Space, 1974. Oxford: Basil Blackwell 

[4] Wolfgang Iser, The Act of Reading, A theory of Aesthetic Response, John Hopkins, 1980

[5] Alvesson and Skoldberg, Reflexive Methodology, Sage, 2001

Keywords: Reading Strategy, Reflexive Methodology, Social Space, Visual Reality, Effective Learning

------------------------------------------------------------

Constructing Social Spaces of Learning Through Reflexive Reading in a Visual Reality

Introduction:

New communication technologies are fostering social spaces in visual realities that are essentially participative and collaborative in nature. According to Peter Sloterdijk, this ever-changing socio-technological environment reveals the necessity of a new conception of the human as inherently relational and spatially determined: a being in spheres. We are 150 humans in a digital Fishbowl where we can ‘see’ each other in a textual reality. 

Our paper presents a “reading strategy” and a "practice" that sets in motion experientially-felt human responses, thereby creating conditions for the objective study of topics usually regarded as subjective. In the Fishbowl, participants systematically contemplate ‘learning structures’ and the phenomena that appear in acts of conscious thought. According to Wolfgang Iser, ‘effective learning’ is an ongoing interaction between Author, Text and Reader, for it brings into play the imaginative and perceptive faculties of the reader. Reading sets in motion activities that depend both on the text and the exercise of basic human faculties. Wolfgang Iser posits that ‘effective learning’ and ‘aesthetic responses’ have characteristics that are neither of the text nor the reader, but instead, the text represents a ‘potential effect’ that is ‘realized’ in the ‘reading process.’ Only when we give a text the power to have meaning by realizing it, does it become effective.

Purpose:

To show a process of “reflexive” reading that facilitates experientially-felt responses and creates intersubjective ‘spaces’ of learning in a visual reality.

Method:

1. Conscious experience and self-reflexivity, rather than Cartesian method of analysis. Through reflection, participants discover the Self and others; how they differ and coalesce. 

2. Redirect reading from prescribed text to seeking essential learning from each other’s text. 

3. Using anecdotal felt-experiences, participants temporally and spatially zigzag with the text, filling-in new and unknown details.

4. Focus on learning structures created in the moment. The new does not exist before the initial act of reading and every subsequent reading produces newer realizations. 

5. Meaning is assembled dialectically by reading multiple texts and arriving at a point-of-view.

 

Outcome:

1. The social space of learning in a visual reality was constituted by multi-layered text with flexible structures and interpretations.

2. Reading was not static but dynamic and evolving; an ongoing process of interaction between author, text and reader. 

3. There is a verifiable rationale for each participant’s learning, grounded not in right or wrong but ideas, themes and images, held true at a moment in time. 

References:

1) Patrick Roney & Andrea Rossi (2021) SLOTERDIJK’S ANTHROPOTECHNICS, Angelaki

2) Henri Lefebvre, The Production of Space, 1974. Oxford: Basil Blackwell 

3) Wolfgang Iser, The Act of Reading, A theory of Aesthetic Response, John Hopkins, 1980

4) Alvesson and Skoldberg, Reflexive Methodology, Sage, 2001

Date: 11/16/2021 21:18:20
Subject: emerging structure for the abstract

EMERGING STRUCTURE FOR THE CONFERENCE ABSTRACT

Title: Social Spaces of Learning in a Visual Reality

Introduction:

We are 150 participants in a digital fishbowl where we can see each other seeing each other.

New communication technologies are fostering social spaces in visual realities that are essentially participative and collaborative in nature. According to Peter Sloterdijk, this ever-changing socio-technological environment reveals the necessity of a new conception of the human as inherently relational and spatially determined: a being in spheres. Our paper presents a “reading strategy” that sets in motion experientially-felt human responses.

We suggest a “practice” that creates conditions for the objective study of topics usually regarded as subjective, I.e., consciousness and the content of conscious experiences, such as choices exercised and emotions felt. We are primarily concerned with the systematic reflection on, and the study of, our cognitive structures and, the phenomena that appear in acts of conscious thought. There is an evolution to ‘effective’ learning in our fishbowls that involves an ongoing process of interaction between author, text and reader. The authors embody all three in the fishbowl: Author, Text, and Reader. Our learning became a function of the interplay between these three embodiments.

Purpose:

Our intent is to show how a reading process facilitates experientially-felt responses that lead to intersubjective ‘spaces’ of learning.

Method: Reading Strategy

1. Reading is the focal point that set in motion a chain of activities that depend both on the text and on the exercise of certain basic human faculties. Wolfgang Iser posits that ‘effect’ and ‘response’ are properties neither of the text nor of the reader. Instead, the text represents a ‘potential effect’ that is ‘realized’ in the ‘reading process.’ Only when you give a text the power to have meaning by realizing it, does it become effective.

2. As authors in the fishbowl, we purposefully create a series of gaps and blanks in our text in order to induce participants, first, to recognize that such a gap exists and second, to use felt-experiences to temporally and spatially zigzag back and forth with the text and fill these spaces with new and unknown details; anecdotal incidents. 

3. For every such ‘reading,’ the participant is not seeking a hidden meaning or even a correct one. Rather, the focus is on the learning created in the moment. The participant’s new learning does not exist before the initial act of reading; and, every subsequent reading will likely produce newer learning still. It follows, concepts like "right" and "wrong" are irrelevant. It is only by interacting with the text that we imbued it with relevance.

4. Using a reflexive methodology, participants seek essential properties and structures of their learning experiences.

5. Reflexivity is the process by which we reflect on our own and other people’s personal and social characteristics, how they differ and coalesce, and shape the social space.

Outcome: What we learnt

1. By combining unfamiliar text with an evolving perspective, participants opened gateways to create novel higher-order understanding and authorship. 

2. For every individual there is a verifiable rationale for their particular learning, one that is not grounded in argumentative concepts of right or wrong but in ideas, themes and images that hold true for the time in which they were considered and understood. 

3. We redirected reading from prescribed text, and instead, we were understanding our learning processes when reading each other’s text in a fishbowl.

4. As readers of each other’s text, we assembled meaning in a process of re-creative dialectics.

5.Individuals shaping their own norms, tastes, politics, desires, and so on, is defined as a high-level of social reflexivity.

6. The relationship between reader and text itself needs an impulsion to set it in motion if it is to come to real fruition.

References:

1) The Production of Space, Henri Lefebvre, Donald Nicholson-Smith trans., Oxford: Basil Blackwell. Originally published 1974. ISBN 0-631-14048-4

2) Alvesson and Kaj Skoldberg, Reflexive Methodology, New Vistas for Qualitative Research, Sage, 2001.

3) Wolfgang Iser, The Act of Reading, A theory of Aesthetic Response, John Hopkins, 1980

4) Patrick Roney & Andrea Rossi (2021) SLOTERDIJK’S ANTHROPOTECHNICS, Angelaki, 26:1, 3-8, DOI: 10.1080/0969725X.2021.1863585

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well.

The fishbowl is a museum of rhode island business students’ stories, aspirations and learning. Their creations and compositions have regularly been presented to international audiences and published in refereed research journals from the last twenty-five years. 

Presently, we are working together to write a 3500 word abstract for INTED22 for acceptance by an international refereed committee of experts.

We are 150 participants in all: 

Actors (who are writing the script), 

Audience (who are watching the act), and 

Voyeurs (who cannot be seen).

In the fishbowl, we are on the brink of a new world. With the decline of old traditions, we now face more choices than ever before. 

{That is, the words (metaphors) we can choose and select from an ever expanding vocabulary.}

This is a time when you must be particularly attentive to the signs of the new {your selected words} and have the courage to venture forth with them and find out what you’re capable of, without being constrained by the old prejudices {histories} and hierarchical ideas {patriarchal perspectives} of the past. The aim of the fishbowl is to help you see that you don’t have to go down the paths (sequence of words) already mapped out for you, that you are not just condemned to obey social customs (of diversity and inclusivity) that you can create something new (word structures) and propose a different direction (images and metaphors) as regards your authentic life.

Please see Erin Chratian’s reflection below.

Sanjiv

Breaking metaphors 

“It is linear thinking and confined to a strict vocabulary and meaning formation.”

Linear thinking can be detrimental to creativity and to communication. It takes away any special spark that comes from the guy outside the box. When linear thinking is forced, it prohibits those from excelling. I'm moving to the next level. When we are confined to limiting what we can say think and do, it becomes challenging to show how we really feel. some of us may feel confined to think many different things such as political views, religious views, and even views about family values. this is not letting us explore into the realm of what could be. I am so grateful to have parents who have never confined me within some dots or beliefs and because of this I feel as if I've made my own independent views and can express myself freely.

Subject: assignments for MGT448: constructing coordinates

Hi Everyone,

Good morning and how are you today? I will lead you through the path you must follow as a learning MECHANISM to satisfactorily finish the course. 

We are not seeking answers because they are already known, we are learning how to FORMULATE our questions. 

What does one think? How so and why so and when so and where so?

I trust you have the text, Exploring Culture on your computer. Open and keep on your desk top.

The book has exercises and stories for you to acquire skills for understanding people from other cultures.

I.

So far, you have reached page 27 of the textbook. Chapter one is read and understood. You interpreted the words spoken by Hiromitsu and Sandy in Japanese Story. You deconstructed selected text from the film. You identified feelings of 'culture shock' by juxtaposing the words taken from the textbook onto the film. Coordinating text and image. You are learning to EXPAND your understanding of the Other’s world-view: feelings, images, and meaning of words.

Please google the term “other."

 

You are constantly posting reflections. Let your fingers do the talking, the expressing, the reflecting, the sharing. There is no Zoom, but I can see you, as you can see me, in the Mind’s Eye (please google). It’s the way of the future. A world of SIMULATION.

II.

Chapter 2 is titled, Culture: The Rules of the Social Game.

Please think about these words. That is the game plan. We are thinking about words. We define them for ourselves, and we are using 3 sources of information and putting this information together, in a way that FURTHERS understanding. 

1.Text book pages 29-46. Read several times. Take notes of key points.

2. View Three films (Japanese Story, Moonrise Kingdom, Outsourced) as an ethnomethodologist. Select sentences for interpretation. 

3. Letters and Postings in the Fishbowl. Stay tuned to overall themes in my letters. 

You are learning skills to DISCERN and ASCERTAIN foreign situations and, 'bring the contract home.’

I hope you will find the doing of the above interesting and the words and images so presented inspire you to go further. 

This is the first step or introduction to the vast topic of Culture. 

The approach in the fishbowl is to CONSTRUCT COORDINATES between one’s SUBJECTIVITY and LANGUAGE.

This is a Lacanian approach to culture. Please google Lacan.

I will be watching your back through my letters and thinking of you by reading into your words, but for now I must create 'mental space’ (please google) and ATTEND to the abstract. Time eventually does run out.

Please see Timothy Murphy’s posting below. Please contemplate the DIMENSIONS. 

Sanjiv

Post by timothymurphy » Fri Nov 12, 2021 9:47 am

Hofstede’s cultural dimensions.

The Hofstede model of national culture consists of six dimensions. The cultural dimensions represent independent preferences for one state of affairs over another that distinguish countries (rather than individuals) from each other.

The country scores on the dimensions are relative, in that we are all human and simultaneously we are all unique. In other words, culture can only be used meaningfully by comparison. The model consists of the following dimensions:

POWER DISTANCE INDEX (PDI)

INDIVIDUALISM VERSUS COLLECTIVISM (IDV)

MASCULINITY VERSUS FEMININITY (MAS)

UNCERTAINTY AVOIDANCE INDEX (UAI)

LONG TERM ORIENTATION VERSUS SHORT TERM NORMATIVE ORIENTATION (LTO)

INDULGENCE VERSUS RESTRAINT (IVR)

Subject: entering the unknown

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. I’ve been distracted all day, something we experience as holidays approach, but then I entered the fishbowl and I found clarity in the reflection by Skylar Santabarbara. He is describing the opening structure for the abstract and I found it useful in this moment of decision.

Whenever we don’t know anything, discipline is all we got.

Discipline equals: 

doing your vocabulary, 

google searches and 

deconstructing sentences from the letters.

Always reading, actively! 

Our environment (in the fishbowl) is made of text (words) and images they evoke. 

We are screening and scrolling them constantly, even in our sleep!

From this environment, made of text and images, we are selecting text and images that resonate with oneself. 

And from our collection, this gathering of text and images, we are to construct an opening structure. 

The Social Construction of Reality by Berger and Luckmann. Please google.

What I am really trying to say: we enter the unknown with a syntax.

It is an authentic entry because we felt every word and image. 

We set up the process and practice at the very start.

The abstract aside, going forward, we will focus on specific readings and assignments for each course. More structure. You have got the discipline down. I congratulate you!

Post by skylarsantabarbara » Tue Nov 02, 2021 1:02 pm

EMERGING STRUCTURE FOR THE CONFERENCE ABSTRACT

Reading is the focal point in the social space of the fishbowl because it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend both on the text (our words) and on our exercise of certain basic human faculties. Effects and responses in the fishbowl are properties neither of the text nor of the reader; the text represents a potential effect that is realized in the reading process. 

Reading each other's posts and shared ideas, help us not only learn, but sprout new ideas in our minds that are built off the origins of one another's. Making sure to read, however, is extremely important to getting the full experience from the fishbowl. The aesthetic response facilitates intersubjective discussion of individual interpretations. The fishbowl fosters the development of our own intellectual community and social spaces for our visual reality.

Date: 11/1/2021 20:39:24
Subject: struggling with structuring
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you doing? I am struggling with the opening sentence for the abstract. The opening structure is the genesis. Every hour I change it. I am circling around it and fighting distractions. Going for the kill. Here’s the latest version:

The authors are participants in the construction of social space in a visual reality; a simulated experience, where learning outcomes are of great consequence. Learning outcomes are learning situations which the participant experiences as effective, exceptional, or personally meaningful. Critical thinking, communication, collaboration and creativity are the four Cs vital to learning outcomes (National Education Association, 2014). Participants took all four Cs into account in the construction of social space.

I’m not happy with the above, and wonder if it would be better to emphasize social space, where learning is relational instead of learning as outcomes. Either way ‘reading' and 'aesthetic response’ and ‘deconstruction' are the key methodological practices being followed. Please see Colin Staples post below.

It will all look different tomorrow morning after a night’s dreaming. You are the inspiration.

Sanjiv

SIMULATE, EXPERIENCE, OUTCOME, RELATIONAL, SITUATION, LEARNING

Post by colinstaples » Mon Nov 01, 2021 12:57 pm

Intersubjectivity: 

- created by philosopher Edmund Husserl

- the interchange of thoughts and feelings, both conscious and unconscious, between two persons or subjects. 

Visual Reality:

- a simulated experience that can be similar or completely different from the real world. 

- In the 21st century, artificial intelligence is making it possible for humans to experience visual reality and even interact with this type of society.

Hi Everyone,

How are you doing? I am struggling with the opening sentence for the abstract. The opening structure is the genesis. Every hour I change it. I am circling around it and fighting distractions. Going for the kill. Here’s the latest version:

The authors are participants in the construction of social space in a visual reality; a simulated experience, where learning outcomes are of great consequence. Learning outcomes are learning situations which the participant experiences as effective, exceptional, or personally meaningful. Critical thinking, communication, collaboration and creativity are the four Cs vital to learning outcomes (National Education Association, 2014). Participants took all four Cs into account in the construction of social space.

I’m not happy with the above, and wonder if it would be better to emphasize social space, where learning is relational instead of learning as outcomes. Either way ‘reading' and 'aesthetic response’ and ‘deconstruction' are the key methodological practices being followed. Please see Colin Staples post below.

It will all look different tomorrow morning after a night’s dreaming. You are the inspiration.

Sanjiv

SIMULATE, EXPERIENCE, OUTCOME, RELATIONAL, SITUATION, LEARNING

Intersubjectivity: 

- created by philosopher Edmund Husserl

- the interchange of thoughts and feelings, both conscious and unconscious, between two persons or subjects. 

Visual Reality:

- a simulated experience that can be similar or completely different from the real world. 

- In the 21st century, artificial intelligence is making it possible for humans to experience visual reality and even interact with this type of society.

Responsibility

For me, being in college was my first real test of responsibility. Of course, before college, I had responsibilities like jobs, school, and sports. The main difference between College and these other types of responsibilities is time. In college, you have more free time than anything, you may only be in class for an hour or 2 and the rest of the day is up to you what you do. Time Management also plays a large role with responsibility, knowing when to get your assignments done and actually doing them is tough for some people. To stay on top of all my assignments, I like to take note of what I need to be done each week. This helps keep me on top of everything each week and makes managing my time much easier.

Post by timothymurphy » Tue Oct 26, 2021 2:53 pm

"It is the Grandmother who knows how to change the metaphor. Always listen to them."

I found this sentence or two in the letter rather interesting as it's something I was always told as a child. Always listen to your grandparents. When I was young I didn't understand the real meaning behind what I was being told. I was too young and ignorant at the time to comprehend. Now that I am older, I understand that they have much more life experiences than I do. Just as we learn from our mistakes, they did too. The only difference is that they are trying to help us out based on what they have lived through. If I wanted to travel in the woods and my grandparents say no. It's not because they don't want me to have fun, its because they know that I have no idea the possible dangers.

Hi Everyone,

How are you this Friday morning?

So what does one’s life symbolize is a relevant question to ask, if one wants to consider the concept of culture. 

What does my life symbolize?

‘Resistance’ is an important symbol, word and concept for me. 

Resisting everything false is my ‘chosen' symbol. It is also a word and a concept and has an image. And, of course, emotion. 

A symbol unifies body and spirit, and the symbol 'resistance' represents who I am; it a word that unifies my mind, body and spirit. 

It is a feeling (spirit), it is the imagination (mind) and felt in experiences (body) over a life-span. 

One’s symbol is a composite of culture, family, religion, society and education: text and images. 

We lead symbolic lives. We can be anything we want.

I’d like to leave you with a quote:

“No ambition, however extravagant, no fantasy, however outlandish, can any longer be dismissed as crazy or impossible. This is the age when you can finally do it all...

suddenly technology has given us powers with which we can manipulate not only external reality---the physical world---but also and much more portentously, ourselves. You can become whatever you want to be.” Ed Regis, "Meet the Extropians,” WIRED. (Please google)

Date: 10/28/2021 13:24:45
Subject: emerging structure for the Conference Abstract
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? I have been ‘reading' your fishbowls, off and on, and have a fair idea of what is going on with you; in your head, that is.

I have been thinking about the Abstract, and it is emerging from your writings in the fishbowl. 

Corey Longworth’s posting below has an effect that shapes the emerging abstract.

Looking at your postings, I see the structure being formed in the Fishbowl.

How does one do that? See a structure being formed?

You have to change the nomenclature (label) on each box. 

This is an imaginative and creative act.

A box is where you determine what goes-in/goes-out.

Inclusion/exclusion is the starting block of a structure.

For example, one starting structure was A, A-, B+ and B. Instead, I can ‘see’ you in a structure of boxes with the following labels:

Box 1. Actors, Directors, Producers, Screenwriters

Box 2. Interacting Audience

Box 3. Voyeurs

The social space of the fishbowl has the above structure, at least how I ‘see' it for the time-being.

Other structures could be: a catwalk or a play-pen, etc.

The following are the 'beginning ideas' for the Abstract, and subject to change. 

Our inspiration is coming from each other’s postings.

Suggested Title: "Social Spaces of Visual Reality: Passion for Learning"

Introduction

The most profound social change is taking place in new communication technologies that are fostering the development of social spaces of visual reality. 

The Internet is the backbone of this global computer-mediated communication (https://www.internetsociety.org/internet/)

What is the social space of a visual reality? What is it constituted by?

Any theory on social spaces is bound to be in the nature of a ‘construct.’

Reading is the focal point in the social space of the fishbowl because it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend both on the text (our words) and on our exercise of certain basic human faculties. Effects and responses in the fishbowl are properties neither of the text nor of the reader; the text represents a potential effect that is realized in the reading process. 

We show how an 'aesthetic response' is set in motion through the reading process.

The aesthetic response facilitates intersubjective discussion of individual interpretations.

These theoretical ideas will be illustrated by example, and, indeed, some are actually developed through the examples. 

In other words, the reader assembles the meaning of the text in a process of re-creative dialectics.

The relationship between reader and text itself needs an impulsion to set it in motion if it is to come to real fruition. To get the interaction going, there are necessary prerequisites. These prerequisites are laid out in the fishbowl in a wide range of specific instructions.

Sanjiv

EMERGE, NATURE, CONSTRUCT, AESTHETIC, RESPONSE, EFFECT

from the fishbowl...

CoreyLongworth

10/24 Social Space in a Visual Reality

Lefebvre argued that every society—and, therefore, every mode of production—produces a certain space, its own space. The fishbowl is our social space. If every society produces its own space, any "social existence" aspiring to be or declaring itself to be real, but not producing its own space, would be a strange entity, a very peculiar abstraction incapable of escaping the ideological or even cultural spheres. Based on this argument, Lefebvre criticized Soviet urban planners on the basis that they failed to produce a socialist space, having just reproduced the modernist model of urban design interventions on physical space, which were insufficient to grasp social space. Lefebvre's argument in The Production of Space is that space is a social product, or a complex social construction (based on values, and the social production of meanings) which affects spatial practices and perceptions.

Date: 10/27/2021 16:30:51
Subject: about culture (2)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? 

Please see Lucas Alvernaz’s process of ‘taking and making notes' as a critical ethnographer.

Lucas is an excellent example of Active Learning. Please google the term.

In Japanese Story we saw the INTERSECTION of two different cultures as represented by HIromitsu and Sandy’s mental structures, which as you know, are made up of text and images. 

A structure starts with a dichotomy (two words placed next to each other, like, resilience/speed) and our dichotomies come from past experiences which occur within one's cultural context. We are following Hofstede’s definition of culture: a collective programming of the mind that distinguishes one culture from another. Cultures are mental constructs. 

Please be sure to complete your reading from the workbook, so that we can proceed forward. 

Currently, you are watching Moonrise Kingdom to figure-out American culture. To attempt such a challenge, Hofstede classified national cultures in terms of the importance attached to different values. We see that clearly in Japanese Story.

A culture’s value-structure is a word-structure. That is what you are being asked to ascertain in the films that we are watching. A word is a symbol, a concept and an image, as you well know.

What exactly are cultural values? Cultural values are very difficult to talk about because they are taken for granted. They become like a problem solved regularly in the same way: it ceases to be a problem. Rather, it ceases to be a conscious act and become just another assumption. It is only when a person’s assumptions are challenged that they realize that these assumptions even exist.

Our endeavor is to uncover assumptions. To do so, you have to be able to see what is not visible to the naked eye.

Sanjiv

TAKE, MAKE, NOTES, ACTIVE, LEARNER, ASSUMPTION, MENTAL-CONSTRUCT (not construction), STRUCTURE

Japanese story notes

(1)

Sandy, he's Japanese.

- They're not interested in exploration.

I'm not traipsing around the desert

with some Japanese prick...

...who wants a glorified tour guide!

I'm a geologist!

Not a bloody geisha! You haven't

factored in the landfall properly here.

Sandys co co-worker makes an inference that Hiromitsu isn't going to want to explore the country land because he is a conservative businessman and strictly wants to figure out the deal at hand. Sandy doesn't care regardless and believes she is above escorting him around and doesn't want to waste her time. 

Geisha - Japanese girl whose profession is to sing and dance to entertain men

Traipsing - cross, traverse, transgress

(2)

In Australia...

...you have a lot of space,

no people.

In Japan

...we have many people,

no space. 

Yeah. 

You ready to go? 

There is nothing.

It scares me.

Hiromitsu is used to living in the city in Japan and receives a culture shock when he sees the great open and vastness of the Australian desert. He describes the open land as space and creates a vivid scene in my head in comparison to the crowds in the streets of Japan.

Space - period of time, distance, interval, stellar depths, immense emptiness between the worlds

(3)

You can't send a condolence card

to a complete stranger.

You don't know her.

You don't know her culture. 

You know nothing about her

or her marriage!

Sandy's mother doesn't believe she should send a condolences card to Hiromitsu’s wife because they are not familiar with one another and she doesn't know her culture well enough where that could potentially offend her. 

Condolence - sympathetic grief, sorrowing with another, expression of sympathy to one in distress, mourning, compassionate 

(4)

What is this "hai"? 

Yeah, "hai. "

I mean, what does that mean? 

- It means "yes. "

- "Yes"? 

But not "yes" like in English. 

It means, "I am listening. 

Go on. Yes. " 

Hai is "what. " 

Hai is "I don't know. 

Can be just thinking.

And sometimes... 

...it means "no. "

But no one says no.

Just hai, which means "yes. "

Even if they mean no?

In the desert...

...I was wrong.

It is very bad to make

so many mistakes.

So I must fix them myself.

I'm sorry. 

And that's why you couldn't ring?

Yes.

And then I read the book.

I begin to understand.

And then I am possessed...

...like a man who has

the strength of many.

Very strong!

Never felt so strong!

And you.

You don't even want

to speak to me.

Oh, no. I want to kill you.

But without me, you are alone.

And then you die.

- Oh, maybe.

- Yes, you die. In the dessert.

Hiromitsu explains how in his culture it is looked down upon to ask for help after making a mistake and that he must figure it out. He needed to get Sandy couldn't understand that at first similar to how she didn't understand the multiuse meaning of “HAI” in the Japanese language until he had to explain it.

(5)

Do you love your wife?

No need to say it.

When you say it...

...then, not so true.

You give up.

It's bad for you.

No photo?

No photo. 

Very old rock.

Beautiful.

Before...

...I came to Australia...

...I was sad.

I have...

...heavy obligations.

But...

...I must get through it.

Here in the dessert...

Desert!

You have shown me...

...something beautiful.

Thank you.

Hiromitsu was a bit depressed and in a rut due to his rigorous duties and expectations set back home in Japan. Although he has a wife and kids Sandy was able to give him experiences and show and teach him things he had no idea about. He was in awe with her and what she was able to do for him and relieve the stresses clouding his mind.

Moonrise Kingdom Notes:

1)If we find him i won't be the one who forgot a weapon 

Many U.S. citizens like to carry around weapons in the case of rather having one and not needing it instead of needing it and not having it. Guns especially, Americans harp having them because it is included in our Bill of Rights (2nd Amendment) and they feel it is protection from attackers and those who try to infringe on their rights

2)Well, it doesn’t matter, anyway. You don’t have that authority. We’ve been deputized. Now are you going to come along peacefully or not?

Many Americans believe that they are superior to others even if they are a little different and can order them around. Police in the U.S. have been notoriously discriminatory and authoritative to minorities in the past and current times.

3)SUZY - It helps me see things closer. Even if they’re not very far away. I pretend it’s my magic power. 

SAM - (impressed) That sounds like poetry. Poems don’t always have to rhyme, you know. They’re just supposed to be creative

As a kid many of us used to dream of magic powers like super speed, strength, ability to fly etc… whereas Suzy is much more practical but uses her binoculars to get a visual of everything around her. 

4)Wait. Just in case this is a suicide, or 99. (more) they capture us, and we never see each other again anymore -- thank you for marrying me. I’m glad I got to know you, Suzy.

This is like a Romeo and Juliet/ Bonnie and Clyde like scenario where they feel like they'd rather die together than live apart from one another. Many people in my experience would ideally like to find a significant other who will stick by them through the thick and the thin

5)He’s a fellow Khaki Scout, and he needs our help. Are we man enough to give that? So part of his brain doesn’t get removed out of him.

This common phrase in the western world to “be a man” insinuates that they need to step up and do what they believe is right despite the consequences. Gives a bit of a negative connotation that only “men” can do the right thing and have to be the saviors where that is not always the case.

Date: 10/27/2021 13:49:42
Subject: de-materialization of society
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Your Fishbowls are A Globalizing Economy with Knowledge-based Assets:

In the twentieth century, mankind made a transition from a matter-based economy to one based on ideas from an emphasis on natural resources to focusing on thought, design and organization. Accompanying this were two trends. 

First, services displaced manufacturing as the major component of economic activity. 

Second, manufactured items themselves were designed leaner, or more precisely, could produce larger quantities of output from the same, or a lighter design. 

By the end of the twentieth century, the de-materialization of the economy had advanced to the point where 79 percent of jobs, and 76 percent of the GNP in the USA were in the service sector (Survey of Current Business, 1995). Europe and Japan lagged only slightly behind. Emerging nations are also moving along a developmental path that seems to culminate with intangibles ultimately comprising the dominant portion of the economy. Several developing nations are already at or near the point where the service sector is worth more than half their economy (UNCTAD,1992, 1995).

An economy based on ideas rather than material objects has several distinct characteristics. An economy of objects emphasizes mass production, internalized ownership, control and vertical integration. You see this in the organizational structure depicted in the film, Strictly Ballroom (MGT345). 

On the other hand, an economy based on knowledge favors customization, ﬂexibility, rapid response and dis-internalization or deconstruction of the value chain. This favors alliances, as different pieces of the value chain (vocabulary) under different ownership cooperate with each other. You see this in the alliances and relations forged in Strictly Ballroom. 

Please consider your postings in your fishbowl in this light. Please see Charlie Chaplin (1936) in Modern Times (4mts).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6n9ESFJTnHs

Sanjiv

MATERIALIZE

What does this mean: 

we are taking words seriously and contemplatively. 

For instance, Strictly Ballroom is a great metaphor, don’t you think! 

Even the word ‘strict' has an other-world ring to it.

In the film, we together experience a magical story of a championship ballroom dancer who breaks all the rules. We see what Scott Hastings has to go through. First and foremost he had to work through his sexism towards Fran, and the same by his mother towards him. All about the words and images they use in creating their reality. Wrong words create misperceptions and causes suffering. 

In the film, we see the classical example of the metaphor machine and mechanistic thinking. It is linear thinking, and confined to a strict vocabulary and meaning formation. A closed and insular society unto itself. It is the Grandmother who knows how to change the metaphor. Always listen to them. Listen to the Rhythm instead of perfecting Steps. She shows Scott how to do so and change the metaphor. The best part is we don’t have to be like Tina Sparkle. No longer the way to succeed. We have to form new relations, new collaborations, and work on our mental frameworks to make them flexible, ready for anything and everything.

Please see the advise from Grace Arruda for Scott Hastings: 9/23 Co-Jointly in the Making. It is the use of language (for example “Scott was boxed in” and “flashy steps") that creates our reality.

9/23 Co-Jointly in the Making

“We are developing a reading and writing strategy (in case you hadn’t noticed), and 

learning to deconstruct text (please google Jacques Derrida and Deconstruction), and 

experientially (by bringing in emotion), we are creating a point-of-view.”

Reading and writing strategy – the way in which every individual chooses to interpret a reading and explain it in writing routinely 

Deconstruct text – break down the deeper meaning of the words and phrases 

Point-of-view- an opinion of an individual 

As we go through this course and learn vocabulary and Google search philosophers and ideas, we are developing our own strategies. Every one of us will create our own way to interpret the letters and explain them in writing. We ‘deconstruct the text’ by breaking down certain parts of the letters and diving into the deeper meanings of the words and phrases. As we deconstruct, our own opinions and emotions become infused into the explanation. This infusion of our opinion creates our personal ‘point-of-view’ that can be seen by everyone in the Fishbowl.

Date: 10/25/2021 20:12:59
Subject: what are American values?
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? Tomorrow on Tuesday, I will not be coming to campus because of heavy rains and strong winds. 

I am presuming you have understood and experienced, at least intuitively, as to what we are doing in the fishbowl thus far. 

Please fact check for yourselves. If you have doubts, then the beginning is the best place to start. Read the syllabus and move up to subsequent letters. 

You may also email directly with your questions.

In this email, what I want to say is that we are confronting a situation, across the board in my opinion, where the old vocabulary in most of our textbooks encourages a mind-set that is in danger of being insular and limited by obsolete boundaries and distinctions. Please think about it.

INSULAR, OBSOLETE, BOUNDARY, DISTINCTION

We badly need a new vocabulary, a new expression. 

The old definitions of international business are now DEFUNCT; terms such as ‘exporting’ and ‘importing’, ‘domestic’ and ‘overseas’ are now largely IRRELEVANT. 

The distinction between domestic and international markets has crumbled fast in virtually every part of the world.

"Emerging along with increasingly global markets and global competition are new organizational forms and competitive requirements which absolutely demand that we pay attention to differences in our individual cultures.” (Hoecklin)

GLOBAL, MARKET, COMPETITION

What are the new organizational forms?

And what are the new competitive requirements?

and how do we pay attention to differences in culture?

Please be aware, that we will have to give an account of ourselves at the end of the semester. 

In the meantime, please be sure to finish your reading from Exploring Culture, and ‘critically watching’ Wes Anderson’s Moonrise Kingdom. It was shot in Rhode Island, and like Wes Anderson, you are reflecting upon American culture. What are American values is a question that concerns most everyone on the planet.

When reading about ‘culture shock’ in Exploring Culture, please think of Hiromitsu in Japanese Story. The expression on his face, DEPICTS cultural SHOCK.

Sanjiv

VALUE, DIFFERENCE, REFLECT

VALENCIA (SPAIN)	SUBMIT YOUR ABSTRACT NOW »

JOIN US!

Dear Sanjiv Dugal,

You are invited to join the 16th edition of INTED, one of the largest international conferences for lecturers, educational researchers and technologists.

For the last 15 years, INTED conferences have been held as both in-person and virtual events, welcoming more than 700 participants in the field of education. Last March 2021, due to the COVID outbreak, INTED2021 was successfully held as a virtual conference.

This year 2022, if the health conditions and travelling restrictions do not allow INTED2022 to be held in-person, the conference will be moved to a fully virtual format. Please, find more information here.

Learn more »

CALL FOR ABSTRACTS

You can present your projects and experiences on education and innovation in any of the following formats:

- Virtual presentations

- Oral and poster presentations

The deadline for abstracts submission is 18th of November, 2021.

You can find the conference topics here.

Learn more »

TOP 5 REASONS TO PARTICIPATE AT INTED2022

- Present your paper in one of the largest international conferences on education.

- Interact with international educators and technologists for future cooperation.

- Meet 700 participants from more than 80 countries.

- Learn about education innovations and strategies in 70+ thematic sessions.

- Publish your paper in INTED2022 Proceedings.

Discover who will attend »

PUBLICATIONS

- INTED2022 Proceedings will be submitted for evaluation for their inclusion in Web of Science (Conference Proceedings Citation Index). Previous editions were already accepted.

- An individual DOI number will be assigned for each accepted paper.

- Also, INTED2022 Proceedings will be included in IATED Digital Library.

Learn more »

VIRTUAL PARTICIPATION

This option will enable authors to submit their abstracts and papers for INTED2022 Proceedings without attending the conference in-person.

Also, authors will be able to submit their virtual presentation files (slides, video or poster). These presentations will be uploaded onto the conference website and Technical Program.

Registered virtual authors will receive a virtual package (INTED2022 Proceedings, participation/author certificate, and conference materials) that will be sent by courier after the conference dates.

In order to promote a maximum interaction, different thematic chats, private chats and other networking live activities will be offered for virtual participants.

Learn more »

PROPOSE A SPECIAL SESSION

If you want your own topic being covered, you are invited to propose a special session where you and your colleagues can share novel ideas and experiences and discuss them with the audience.

Discover how »

Exhibit your products to more than 700 leading decision-makers, lecturers, educational researchers and practitioners in education and research from more than 80 different countries.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/12/2021 18:11:28
Subject: mindfulness
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? 

Thus far you have been introduced to new know-how (and how to know in new ways) by sharing what you have learned. 

According Howard Rheingold (please google) there are five literacies that are in the process of changing our world:

attention,

participation,

collaboration,

crap detection (the critical consumption of information), and

network smarts.

When enough people become proficient at these skills, then healthy new economies, politics, societies and cultures can emerge. The free flows of information that digital technologies have made possible are enriching if used properly, but unhealthy if we don't know how to selectively shut them out.

At the heart of this know-how being used in the fishbowl is learning mindfulness (please google) in cyber culture. Thinking about what you are doing and why you are doing it instead of going through the motions is fundamental to the definition of mindful, whether you are deciding to follow someone on Twitter, shutting the lid of your lap-top in class, looking up from your BlackBerry in a meeting, or consciously deciding which links not to click.

Learning how to deploy attention in relation to available media is key today for success in education, business, and social life. Similarly, those who understand the fundamentals of digital participation, online collaboration, informational credibility testing, and network awareness will be able to exert more control over their own lives.

At this point in the semester, please identify your perceptual shifts in behavior emanating from the above literacies.

Sanjiv

LITERACY, MINFULNESS, DEPLOY, ATTENTION, PARTICIPATION, COLLABORATION, CREDIBILITY, NETWORK, AWARENESS

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/12/2021 15:30:09
Subject: structuralism and post-structuralism
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? We are at a turning-point (metaphor, image), post Columbus Day. 

In this letter I will frame the skills you have been ‘displaying,' thus far, in both MGT345 & MGT448..

1. You have understood through lived-experience, the notion of structure and re-structure.You accomplished this by deconstructing words, selecting and substituting them, to construct new meaning. You could call yourselves, almost, ‘structuralists' and 'post-structuralists.' Please google both these terms.

2. You have understood through lived-experience, how structures structure our interpretations (i.e., how we see things) and our felt-experiences (i.e., how we feel). You understood this through language used in the fishbowl.

3. You have understood through lived-experience, the distinction between ‘observation' and ‘interpretation.’

4. You have understood through lived-experience, that reading is the focal point because it sets in motion a whole chain of activities that depend on words and on your ability to express them. Text represents a potential effect that is realized in the reading process. 

5. You have understood through lived-experience, that as the reader, you assemble the meaning of the text through a process of re-creative dialectics. You experienced how the relationship between reader and text needs an impulsion to set it in motion if it is to come to real fruition. 

Sanjiv

DISPLAY, DIALECTIC, OBSERVATION, INTERPRETATION, EXPRESSION, REALIZE, EFFECT, READING, FOCAL, IMPULSION

INTERPLAY, ALCHEMY, ORIGINAL, ACCOUNT, HABIT

Post by Luke Tolar » Sat Oct 09, 2021 11:38 am

I have found that in any setting, when confronted with a task, your unethical goals will bleed through to your execution. It is incredibly easy for any onlooker to distinguish execution of an individual wanting to succeed and better themselves, and the execution of someone who is simply trying to move through the motions. When you simply move through the motions, you lose the fire and liveliness that makes that motion unique to you, and end up with a robotic sequence of events unoriginal and stopping you from alchemy of any kind. The more these robotic decisions are made, the more they become habit, and at some point lead you to becoming a product of those robotic motions, a robot programmed by the historical actions of those around you.

Define:

Deep thinking: To think beyond beliefs, preconceived ideas and prevailing opinions

Interplay: The way in which two or more things have an effect on each other.

Alchemy: A seemingly magical process of transformation, creation, or combination.

Original: Created directly and personally; not a copy or imitation.

Account: A report or description of an event or experience.

Habit: A settled or regular tendency or practice, especially one that is hard to give up.

Hi Everyone,

How are you this Saturday?

In your fishbowls, we SEE 'deep thinking’ (please google) and an ability to capture the ZEITGEIST. 

This is an important skill to develop in a knowledge economy that is digital and predominantly a visual reality made up of text and images.

Your interplay of words and images in the original offer an intriguing historical account of a thoughtful life of the undergraduate.

Your writing stands alone. It transforms the reader and raises the question, how did you write this and how did you know that it would affect the reader?

Your fishbowl is testimony that your alchemy is a result of a habit of careful observation and reflection.

ryanwinn

Posts: 30

Joined: Mon Sep 20, 2021 8:25 pm

Letters: Deconstruction

Fri Oct 08, 2021 3:34 pm

9/26

Quote: "The fishbowl is not about ‘catching-up’ but ‘jumping-in.’ This requires you to 'jump-start' a failing battery"

Deconstruction: Fishbowl is about channeling our inner thoughts and putting them to words. Fishbowl shouldn't feel like a task but rather a getaway to express ourselves. Therefore, it is important to keep up and 'dive in' to Fishbowl rather than fall behind and make it feel like an annoying task. Jump-starting the battery is the first step to getting a consistent flow with Fishbowl.

9/27

Quote "Along the same vein, to create a society, we must first examine our intentions. If the motivation for action in the fishbowl does not transcend the desire for a high grade, the quality of the results will be inferior."

Deconstruction: We must realize what Fishbowl is and why it is worth our time to put in the effort. Without the motivation and will for a high grade, Fishbowl will become of little importance and receive half-ass effort. By aiming high and striving for greatness, Fishbowl will become a lot easier and fluent resulting in a high grade.

9/28

Quote: "Copying is an essential part of being human because without copying we cannot understand ourselves or the world we live in."

Deconstruction: Copying happens everyday and everywhere as it is an essential and important part of life. Some may call it copying but I view it as 'guidance'. By "copying" you're learning and interpreting someone else's information and using it to expand your knowledge. Copying allows us to generate answers or views that we support as it may be too difficult for one to put it in their own words.

9/29

Quote: "Applied in this manner, metaphor exerts a formative influence on how we think, how we see, and how we express ourselves on a day-to-day basis."

Deconstruction: By utilizing, applying, and understanding metaphors in our daily lives, it broadens our perspective on particular views. It can alter the way one may view or think of a particular thing or situation. Utilizing metaphors can give someone an imagination they've never seen before.

10/1

Quote: "The fishbowl, simply, is somewhere where fact and imagination fuse."

Deconstruction: Fishbowl can be thought as a free-roaming world for our minds to escape and express our opinions and feelings. It allows us to communicate and view other people's imaginations and personal feelings and standpoints. With no set rules, we can expand our knowledge and vocabulary and utilize copying to a certain extent to help express ourselves in ways we couldn't do it ourselves.

10/2

Quote: "Skills that connect elements (words) from various fragments to form a structure that is a cohesive whole. To create structure or unity from a variety of reflections is the individual's charge."

Deconstruction: Fishbowl is a digital structure that allows us to utilize our skills and construct abstract sentences to create a reflective community. We are in the drivers seat and control the setting and vibe of Fishbowl and our attitude will reflect that through our posts.

10/3

Quote: "We are building knowledge and a knowing, a society and a culture, among ourselves by viewing films (moving images) and sharing our reflections and process of word-image constructions."

Deconstruction: Fishbowl is becoming a community and culture and we are creating that by expressing and reflecting our point of views by watching movies, looking at images, and reading words. Whilst doing so, we are building knowledge and becoming more aware of how this community operates everyday throughout the semester. The deconstruction section allows us to break down these sentences and broaden our knowledge beyond the scope of our imagination.

10/4

Quote: "To know a culture, we have to be IMMERSED in it. It is when we begin taking things for granted; when we are immersed in those things."

Deconstruction: To be part of a culture and know it roots and purpose, you must be actively involved and interested and absorb it's inner purpose. When we become deeply involved, it may snap us out of reality and cause us to take these things for granted. It is always important to stay actively involved and stay on track to create a functioning culture.

10/5

Quote: "Stay close to words. Immerse yourself and engage with them. Replicate, reiterate, reinvent them. Develop a trajectory of thoughts. That is, structures of words."

Deconstruction: Reading is important, soaking up the information and gaining a personal understanding of sentences can broaden you point of views. By copying, replicating, and breaking down sentences in your own words, it allows you to express yourself in different ways and may make you think differently of what you thought at first. The structure of words is important but doesn't follow a particular order which allows us to say how we feel without restrictions.

10/6

Quote: "Every posting that one makes is an “event” that changes the mental landscape."

Deconstruction: Every time a post is made, a new idea or piece of information is brought upon. This expands our knowledge and ways of thinking in which creates a change of our mental landscape. One singular post can completely change the way someone thinks of a certain point of view. That's why it is important to express ourselves and keep up to date with postings to expand and better our mental landscape.
