10/4

Quote: "To know a culture, we have to be IMMERSED in it. It is when we begin taking things for granted; when we are immersed in those things."

Deconstruction: To be part of a culture and know it roots and purpose, you must be actively involved and interested and absorb it's inner purpose. When we become deeply involved, it may snap us out of reality and cause us to take these things for granted. It is always important to stay actively involved and stay on track to create a functioning culture.

10/5

Quote: "Stay close to words. Immerse yourself and engage with them. Replicate, reiterate, reinvent them. Develop a trajectory of thoughts. That is, structures of words."

Deconstruction: Reading is important, soaking up the information and gaining a personal understanding of sentences can broaden you point of views. By copying, replicating, and breaking down sentences in your own words, it allows you to express yourself in different ways and may make you think differently of what you thought at first. The structure of words is important but doesn't follow a particular order which allows us to say how we feel without restrictions.

10/6

Quote: "Every posting that one makes is an “event” that changes the mental landscape."

Deconstruction: Every time a post is made, a new idea or piece of information is brought upon. This expands our knowledge and ways of thinking in which creates a change of our mental landscape. One singular post can completely change the way someone thinks of a certain point of view. That's why it is important to express ourselves and keep up to date with postings to expand and better our mental landscape.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/7/2021 14:05:45
Subject: re-viewing Japanese Story
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? I want to step-back and wrap-up where we are thus far. The following assignment will do that, and when you are done, we can move onto the next subject matter: American values.

Please have it done within the week. It is not difficult but will require your solitude.

Please refer to section IV in your syllabus; it is posted in the fishbowl under Letters.

Please re-view the film Japanese Story keeping the following steps and approaches in mind:

1. 

You are viewing Japanese Story as an Ethnographer and a Phenomenologist.

Please google both terms and pull out One sentence that you are willing to observe yourself doing.

By so doing, you will experience being both observer and the observed. Simultaneously.

This is a key concept to understand. But you have to realize it.

2.

You have been reading and writing the following four research methodologies:

Participant Observation

Interpretivism

Symbolic Interactionism

Reflexivity

Please define each method in one sentence that makes sense to you.

You have been practicing these research methods in your fishbowls and some of you have defined some of them.

3.

Re-visit and re-view Japanese Story, keeping the above Research Methodologies in mind.

4.

Please read the section IV of your syllabus.

Sandy and Hiromitsu had no idea of the logical sequence to follow when they found themselves in a strange encounter. 

Awareness that their mental programs are different; 

having Knowledge of those differences; and 

Communicating those differences.

In a Do or Die situation, they learnt pretty fast.

The outcome is invariably a deep friendship in the field. 

A connection like no other. Something to aspire for with each Other in the fishbowl.

Please identify Sandy and Hiromitsu’s sequence of learning about their differences.

Thank you.

Sanjiv

METHOD, SIMULTANEOUS, OBSERVER, OBSERVED, SEQUENCE, ENCOUNTER, FRIENDSHIP, REALIZE, ASPIRATION

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/6/2021 21:33:07
Subject: postings as truth event
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? Most of you are 'getting the drift' (image, metaphor) of what the fishbowl is generally about, and what it entails.

It is not difficult nor complicated. It looks complex because it cannot be replicated. 

Your work is ’singular' and lives only for the moment and then it is archived. 

Please see Danman007' posting below.

What am I talking about? I've lost you!

I'm talking about the action, decision and selection it takes when making your postings.

Vocabulary, Notes, Letters, are the basic ingredients for interpretation and understanding. 

Whomsoever TAKES and MAKES NOTES, gets to go to the top.

Every posting is a fragment and an etching.

Every posting that one makes is an “event” that changes the mental landscape.

How so?

Your postings are known as "truth-events”. That is, 'the event of your posting sets-off a set of statements and discourses which are always “the truth of that particular situation.” (please google Alain Badiou)

Please think about that.

These events (that is, our postings) are landmarks and happenings; digital footprints that construct identity and position in visual space.

Please see Sara James’ and Danman’s postings as "truth-event".

Sanjiv

TRUTH, EVENT, FRAGMENT, ETCHING, SINGULAR, ENTAIL, INGREDIENT, INTERPRETATION, UNDERSTANDING

from the fishbowl...

Danman002

Posts: 37

Joined: Tue Sep 14, 2021 2:44 pm

Danman002 » Wed Oct 06, 2021 3:21 pm

At this point in time, we are beginning to engage (read and write) in the fishbowl as a daily practice (ritual).

We are developing a reading and writing strategy, and learning to deconstruct text, and experientially (by bringing in emotion), we are creating a point-of-view.

Doing vocabulary and google searches with focus and sincerity are expected from each of us. We are 'co-jointly in the making' of society and culture.

Focus on ‘words' and let intuition do the work, all for the love of society and culture.

Be a conduit for several flows of information, namely, dictionary, letters, postings, reflections, images

from the fishbowl...

sarajames

Posts: 66

Joined: Tue Feb 02, 2021 6:20 pm

Post by sarajames » Thu Sep 16, 2021 4:36 pm

"We reveal ourselves by the choices we make" 

The choices we make say something about who we are, and we can learn a lot about ourselves by simply analyzing our choices. With every choice we make, a piece of our personality comes out. In the past, it used to be that our path of life was determined by what family we happened to be born into or where we were born. But in today's world, culture allows for self-discovery, and we now get to choose who we involve ourselves with and what we do. If the choices we make say something about who we are, we can learn a lot from ourselves by simply analyzing our choices. So, reflecting on our choices is very important for self-knowledge. Choices give form to who we are and in my eyes are data for self-understanding. They can take you out of your comfort zone and give you clarity of your personality, identity, and path.

Date: 10/6/2021 1:24:34
Subject: &quot;reflexivity&quot;
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. 

Haley Logue’s 'way of doing knowledge’ is an excellent example of your process of knowledge development in the fishbowl.

This 'way of doing knowledge' is known as ‘reflexivity' or reflection and it typically turns attention ‘inwards’ towards the person of the knowledge-worker (researcher). We maintain the belief that the study of suitable (well thought-out) excerpts from any reality can provide an important basis for generation of knowledge that opens up rather than closes, and furnishes opportunities for understanding rather than establishes truths.

Sanjiv

REFLEXIVITY (please google), SUITABLE, EXCERPT, WAY, DOING, KNOWLEDGE, GENERATE, UNDERSTANDING

haleylogue

Joined: Mon Sep 13, 2021 6:36 pm

Re: Letters: Deconstruction

	

Post by haleylogue » Mon Sep 27, 2021 2:15 pm

9/26 "word-image: flounder":

"I fear, you must be floundering, and so I project my imagination":

Floundering means to struggle mentally; show or feel great confusion. I think this a perfect word to describe those just starting out in the Fishbowl for the first time. I have previously never heard about this learning platform. I also was confused at first on what to write, expect, etc. Doing something new for the first time can be very scary. Some people can let fear take over and prevent them from branching out. Going to class we can address our fears and hopefully overcome them. Talking about the thing that fears us is often the best way to get over the fear. Once we overcome this fear and confusion we can succeed. We must jump into the Fishbowl whole-heartedly. We cannot hold back our thoughts and feelings. Throughout the semester, we will become more comfortable and posting in the Fishbowl will become second nature. We can just let the thoughts, opinions, feelings come through.

haleylogue

Post by haleylogue » Mon Sep 27, 2021 3:09 pm

9/27 Transcend/Transform:

"the outcome of a creative process contains the energy of our commitment to it": 

If your posts are solely meant for getting a good grade in this class, you will never succeed. Your posts will come across to the readers as forced and no longer genuine. On the other hand, if your motivation for posting is to better yourself and have an understanding of each of the letters you will succeed in this class. This class is meant to expand your vocabulary and better be able to explain your points of views. This will help you far after graduation.

haleylogue

Post by haleylogue » Fri Oct 01, 2021 12:26 pm

9/28 "In defense of copy":

Copying sometimes comes with a negative connotation. It can lead to cheating, plagiarism, etc. However, it is acceptable in this class. By copying these definitions we pick certain words, phrases, metaphors, etc. that catch our eyes and what we believe to be the best way to define these terms. Copying is a way we can understand who we are and who/what we surround ourselves with. 

Gertrude Stein: This quote is from the novel "the making of American's: being a history of a family's progress". In this book Gertrude discusses genealogy, history, as well as psychological development of the fictional characters. This quote somewhat relates to the topic of copying. It talks about repeating things to truly be able to understand something. You must talk about it, listen about it, to get the true meaning. This repetition allows you to pick up things you did not previously know. In the sense of copying, these definitions will soon stick into our minds. The repetition of some of the vocabulary words are done on purpose. We will pick up on things we did not remember of unde

haleylogue

Post by haleylogue » Fri Oct 01, 2021 12:34 pm

9/29 Metaphors and Images:

"Applied in this manner, metaphor exerts a formative influence on how we think, how we see, and how we express ourselves on a day-to-day basis": 

Metaphors are helpful when writing or speaking to help get points across. They can create images in people's heads which can help people understand the message. Many people are visual learnings. In the case of the man is a lion. Someone can imagine a lion and connect the personality trait that is being compared to the man. Metaphors can be very effective when used in the correct way.

haleylogue

Post by haleylogue » Sat Oct 02, 2021 6:10 pm

10/1 Framing the Situation:

Parag Khanna's Ted Talk: In this Ted Talk Khanna talks about how the world is connected. While we may be separated by city lines, state lines, water, etc., the power of the digital world helps keep us all in the know. We are able to learn new things from all over the world and still be in our homes. The internet is the reason for this. We are able to understand different points of views, cultures, and more. This is sort of like the Fishbowl. We all deconstruct these letters in our own ways in our own place. The Fishbowl is where we can come together and share/read all of these thoughts and feelings. We show our individualism and entrepreneurialism in each of our posts. The Fishbowl is showing our classmates our personal identity, our way of thinking. 

"So often it seems like the world is falling apart but building more connectivity is how we put humpty dumpty back together again much better than before. And by wrapping the world in such seamless physical and digital connectivity, we evolve towards a world in which people can rise above their geographic constraints. We are the cells and vessels pulsing through these global connectivity networks. We don't just build connectivity, we embody it."

haleylogue

post by haleylogue » Tue Oct 05, 2021 3:35 pm

10/2 watching movies together:

"to display our myriad-word images, we need a common agreed upon text (the script) that we individually deconstruct, and re-structure into new experiences":

In order to create a visual for us to understand, we need to take apart what we a learning and relate it back to something we know. Breaking sentences down, word by word, makes it more conceptual. This is how we can truly understand and visualize something.

haleylogue

post by haleylogue » Tue Oct 05, 2021 5:27 pm

10/3 "Reading and viewing strategy":

Strictly Ballroom is an older movie where a very talented ballroom dancer is paired up with a girl who can't dance to save her life. In the end, they end up making it to the National Championship and win. 

"a life lived in fear is a life half lived":

Fran says this to Scott while they are arguing. Scott has never danced with someone with this little of experience before. This is not the normal for him. He wants to win the championship, but believes it to be impossible with an incompetent partner. Fran tells him he is blaming this feeling of losing on fear. He should not be afraid to teach a new dance partner. If he is as good as he says he is, he should have no problem training a new partner. Living in fear stops us from living our best lives. Most of the time we are afraid of failing. But failing is how we learn - how we grow. We must fail, and then fail better the next time.

haleylogue

post by haleylogue » Tue Oct 05, 2021 5:32 pm

10/4: "Images and Structures of Words"

"to know a culture, we have to be immersed in it"

This is so true. We can think of it for those studying a language. Most of the time they end up studying abroad to fully learn the language and culture. It is not enough to simply speak, let's say Spanish, in class everyday. Traveling to Spain, you are forced to think on the fly. You don't have time to write it out or discuss with a partner what to answer. To immerse yourself in a culture is way different than learning about it in a classroom setting. You can experience for yourself first hand to what the locals of this culture do, say, eat, act, etc. The Fishbowl creates a culture. We must google the vocabulary, deconstruct the letters, and read other peoples posts. This is how we can immerse ourselves into the Fishbowl culture.

haleylogue

post by haleylogue » Tue Oct 05, 2021 5:39 pm

10/5 "on a dreary Tuesday morning" 

"develop a trajectory of thoughts": 

A trajectory is a path followed. Developing a trajectory helps guide us where are thoughts are headed. Without this we can be all over the place. This could become incoherent fast. Following the path that the words are making you feel helps guide your response to the letters.

Date: 10/5/2021 13:08:35
Subject: on a dreary Tuesday morning
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone, 

How are you this tuesday morning?

Please see Skylar SantaBarbara’s posting below.

What Skylar is talking about are structures of words. Composition, mosaic, lego, montage.

In MGT 345 and MGT448 we are ethnographers looking at ‘us,' as a Society and a Culture.

Stay close to words. Immerse yourself and engage with them. Replicate, reiterate, reinvent them. Develop a trajectory of thoughts. That is, structures of words.

We live in a textual world and we are made by language. 

Read, read, read and edit, re-edit, re-edit your own self-created and constructed sentences.

You do it one word at a time, fearlessly.

Sanjiv

ETHNOGRAPHER, US, STRUCTURE, WORD, COMPOSITION

from the fishbowl...

skylarsantabarbara

Posts: 58

Joined: Tue Sep 14, 2021 10:58 am

post by skylarsantabarbara » Tue Oct 05, 2021 12:29 am

The fishbowl develops a reading and viewing strategy that results in what is fecund and bountiful. There is no going wrong here, nor losing your path. 

We are building knowledge and a knowing, a society and a culture, among ourselves by viewing films (moving images) and sharing our reflections and process of word-image constructions

Skills that connect elements (words) from various fragments to form a structure that is a cohesive whole. 

To create structure or unity from a variety of reflections is the individual's charge

We are interested in each other. The other’s mystery. 

There are infinite selections recurring that are witnessed and experienced in the fishbowl. Soon patterns and trajectories will emerge and blaze across our mental landscapes.

The city, where most people conglomerate, same as in the fishbowl, is much too complicated a place ever to be disciplined. We are a labyrinth, an encyclopedia, an emporium, a theatre. The fishbowl, simply, is somewhere where fact and imagination fuse. It is 'subjective individualism.'

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/4/2021 19:43:40
Subject: images and structures of words
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? 

To know a culture, we have to be IMMERSED in it. It is when we begin taking things for granted; when we are immersed in those things. 

We will see examples of it in a subsequent film in MGT448.

To know a society, on the other hand, we have to PARTICIPATE in it.

Don’t you think? Is it a good distinction and comparison?

Two words, immersion and participation, are the kind of things we dwell upon as knowledge-workers in a knowledge economy. 

Concepts.

Such distinctions and thoughts are necessary to sustain growth in a knowledge-economy.

You’re learning to make your own.

Yo’re learning to DISMANTLE structures of words aka SYNTAX, and re-structure them again in order to add value.

One’s re-structuring process must add value to the WHOLE.

The process SERVES the whole; the bigger picture. 

The whole can’t be seen, only imagined. 

You must do your google searches ASSIDUOUSLY. Add value to your own understanding and share it. No one is judging, but we are looking.

Looking at each other, looking at each other.

You are building Social Capital. It is digital in nature. It can make you rich. Very, very rich.

You will see that in the course of the semester.

You are works in progress. 

But you can’t eat your vegetables at the end. 

Furthermore, if you drop the ball, you can’t play the same game again.

Sanjiv

SEARCH, UNDERSTAND, PROGRESS

nathanstpierre

Posts: 45

Joined: Mon Sep 13, 2021 6:14 pm

Re: Letters: Deconstruction- Nathan St. Pierre

	Mon Oct 04, 2021 12:13 pm

Letter 13: Metaphors and Images

"We say “life is a game.” No point in saying “life is life” because that is flat, static and meaningless"

Metaphors influence how we view and think. In this example, saying "life is life" makes me think that we have no choice what happens in our own lives. That no matter what we do in our lives, it will not matter. But in fact we do have a choice. Our decisions and actions influence the course of our futures, as do how we navigate problems and tragedies. The metaphor "life is a game" better explains this. In a game, there are a variety of things that can happen. Decisions you make, actions you take, and luck determine how the game will end and what will happen along the course of the game. Games are like life. Every time we do something: that matters. It determines what path we will take in the game of life.

nathanstpierre

 Mon Oct 04, 2021 12:26 pm

Letter 14: Framing the Situation

"Personal identity is rendered soft, fluid, endlessly open to the exercise of the will and the imagination."

People are ever-changing, never staying the same. This can be influenced by a variety of things, such as change in environment, changes of likes/dislikes, the effects of a tragedy, peer pressure, and more. Here lies the quote "Every morning we wake up is the first day of our new life." I like to say that each morning I wake up as a new, different person than I was the day before; influenced by the actions and happenings that occurred the day before. This is why personal identity is so fluid, because we are constantly learning more and more about ourselves as each day passes.

nathanstpierre

Mon Oct 04, 2021 12:46 pm

Letter 15: Watching Movies Together

"We are interested in each other. The other’s mystery."

Fishbowl is a place that we our learning to generate ideas and opinions, using what we've learned, our own experiences, and our imaginations. But fishbowl is more than that: it's also a place we learn from and about our peers. We can view what each other is posting, and this gives more insight into each person. Everyone in our class is a mystery to one another, even if we know that person. It is hard to truly get to know a person, and even if you know them well, it is impossible to know the way their brains works. These fishbowl deconstructions are giving insight into how each student's brains works and how experiences and imagination influence it.

nathanstpierre

Mon Oct 04, 2021 12:50 pm

Letter 16: Reading and Viewing Strategy

"There is no going wrong here, nor losing your path"

As we reflect on the film and our life experiences, we are sharing more about ourselves in Fishbowl. Therefore, nothing we put can be wrong or off-path. We each have our own experiences, and those experiences have influenced the people that we have become today. No one can critique or try to change our experiences, because they were not the ones who went through them: we are. Sharing these may create fear or nervousness, but sharing can be therapeutic and reflection that we may need.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/4/2021 19:43:09
Subject: images and structures of words
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? 

To know a culture, we have to be IMMERSED in it. It is when we begin taking things for granted; when we are immersed in those things. 

We will see examples of it in a subsequent film in MGT448.

To know a society, on the other hand, we have to PARTICIPATE in it.

Don’t you think? Is it a good distinction and comparison?

Two words, immersion and participation, are the kind of things we dwell upon as knowledge-workers in a knowledge economy. 

Concepts.

Such distinctions and thoughts are necessary to sustain growth in a knowledge-economy.

You’re learning to make your own.

Yo’re learning to DISMANTLE structures of words aka SYNTAX, and re-structure them again in order to add value.

One’s re-structuring process must add value to the WHOLE.

The process SERVES the whole; the bigger picture. 

The whole can’t be seen, only imagined. 

You must do your google searches ASSIDUOUSLY. Add value to your own understanding and share it. No one is judging, but we are looking.

Looking at each other, looking at each other.

You are building Social Capital. It is digital in nature. It can make you rich. Very, very rich.

You will see that in the course of the semester.

You are works in progress. 

But you can’t eat your vegetables at the end. 

Furthermore, if you drop the ball, you can’t play the same game again.

Sanjiv

SEARCH, UNDERSTAND, PROGRESS

Date: 9/24/2021 13:33:49
Subject: technologies of lived abstraction
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? I hope your week went well. We are formulating working definitions for, and developing an understanding of, several concepts. During the semester we will implement these concepts together as “technologies of lived abstraction.” 

Your fishbowls are presenting "transdisciplinary works that critically and creatively inquire into processes of emergence in the (digital) world today. Thought and body, abstract and concrete, local and global, individual and collective: works in the fishbowl are not content to rest with such habitual divisions (dichotomies). We are exploring how these facets come together, if only to form the movement by which they come again to differ.

Please see Henry Schmidt’s postings in this light.

Sanjiv

henryschmidt

Posts: 28

Joined: Tue Sep 14, 2021 2:43 pm

Contact: Contact henryschmidt

	

 Thu Sep 23, 2021 7:04 pm

9/15

"In this reality, which is perceptual and visual, we lead a double life"

There are rudimentary pieces that make up our everyday lives yet, we breeze past them. We are painfully aware and painfully unaware at the same time. We walk on campus everyday and see others passing us by -- the first existence of their being. We contemplate their thoughts and actions, "Where are they headed? What are they thinking about?" -- the second existence of their cognitive templates. We must always consider the philosophical and psychological.

Post by henryschmidt » Thu Sep 23, 2021 7:10 pm

9/16 

"attend to the things, then life goes smoothly"

Like my previous post, there is minutia that gets lost in the shuffle of our existence. It is imperative to bring it into our awareness. Professor makes us all consider this period of transition. Starting a new schedule; people may see this as a source of stress or strain on their lives but, we must be conscious of these things. In a way, we should appreciate the chaos. Soon enough, this period of concern melts away it all becomes an unconscious process.

Post by henryschmidt » Thu Sep 23, 2021 7:13 pm

9/17

"Adrift on the high seas and a feeling there is no relief in sight"

Imagery is a powerful tool that allows us to bring our ever changing emotions to the forefront of our thought process. Stress, uncertainty, and anxiety are overpowering and all-consuming. These feels can make people respond differently, some shut down and have a difficult time motivating themselves to move forward, some thrive in it and feel exhilarated by a challenge. There is a sense of over-functioning and under-functioning in these situations. With no end in sight it can be difficult to find a happy medium.

Post by henryschmidt » Thu Sep 23, 2021 7:20 pm

9/18 

"listen and not just hear" 

In any setting, whether it be personal or professional, we must be listeners; not just listeners, but ACTIVE listeners. People yearn for a place of understanding, where they can share and be open. For me, the connotation of "hear" connects with sharing a sentiment and then having to repeat it again later. It was clearly only heard and not listened to. We need to take this action a step further than just sitting in a space and being an auditory deposit. When truly listening, we feel the need to learn more on the topic being spoken about, ask clarifying questions, etc. There is a difference between listening to respond and listening to understand. Sharing thoughts and feelings can be a personal act, it makes us vulnerable. If we feel understood in the end, the risk is worth it.

Post by henryschmidt » Thu Sep 23, 2021 7:25 pm

9/19

"systematic reflection and cognitive structure"

We need to break down our monotony and take moments to look inward. Revisiting things we thought we knew and gaining new knowledge reinforces our understanding and broadens our field of intellect. Consistently incorporating reflection into our daily routine acts as a grounding exercise. However, it can be difficult to prioritize taking a break. Sometimes it can be hard to conceptualize its value when there is a full schedule ahead of us. There is always a to-do list: read for class, do laundry, call home, go to the gym. These are all things we deem necessary for our own success and they are scheduled into our day creating a vortex of things to keep us busy. But maybe it is time for me to schedule a moment of reflection into my schedule as well.

Post by henryschmidt » Thu Sep 23, 2021 7:29 pm

9/20 

"Interpenetration, inter-causality, inter-being"

We are all sharing an experience, just being enrolled in this course and this institution. We are all depositories of the same knowledge when we gather in our shared space each week. We all receive the same tools but, how we use those tools differ. Every person has a completely unique perspective that grants us all access to a new pool of knowledge to draw upon. The people, places, and things I have seen give me a perspective and understanding that only I can speak on, similar to every other human being. And yet, we seen interconnectivity every day.

Post by henryschmidt » Thu Sep 23, 2021 7:34 pm

9/21

"combines thought and emotion" 

All thought could include emotion and an opinion can force us to consider bias and perspective. Facts and intellectual property can be utilized to propel a certain point. When we mix these pieces of knowledge with personal sentiments and feelings we bring in a new layer to consider. Emotion is a highly human capability, it is what delineates us from other beings sentient or not. Emotion drives action and also drives response. We must celebrate emotion but also be wary of its ability to seep into every aspect our our existence.

Post by henryschmidt » Thu Sep 23, 2021 7:40 pm

9/21 

"Please take a 'look' "

In this course and in life, it is imperative to consider other perspectives. We can learn so much from other people. I find it inspiring to see what my fellow classmates are sharing about things I have considered myself. It brings a concept to life, there is more to something than a personal thought. We must research, question, ponder, research again, share. The process is not linear. These topics are open-ended in a sense. There is no clarity. Sometimes that can be difficult, leaving us with no direction but, other times it is exciting. It allows us to take something and run with it. Other perspectives change the path but many times, enhances the path leaving us in awe. Looking at other work allows our own work to improve and teaches us something new.

Post by henryschmidt » Thu Sep 23, 2021 7:46 pm

9/22 

"our i-phones become redundant"

We are in a hyper-electronic world. The influx of information is never ending. Our consciousness ebbs and flows with the stream of notifications: texts, emails, direct messages, instagram posts. The push notification has the power to grasp our awareness away from the focus we work so hard to foster. If you walk down a sidewalk on campus it is easy to spot the tops of peoples heads. Faces are a rarity. People's faces are aglow with a damaging blue light that seems to have hypnotic power. Phone calls, AirPods, text messages: all distractors from existence. I am not immune to this. The here and now is background noise.

Post by henryschmidt » Thu Sep 23, 2021 7:49 pm

9/23 

"creating point-of-view"

There is a clear delineation between what could be considered "normal" reading and writing and a more intentional strategy for reading and writing. We are considering every detail and nuance and then interpreting its impact and ability to completely change our prior understanding. It is giving us tools to be critical of the information we are consuming, whether it be from another person, our phones, or our own selves. We are forming our own consciousness, existence and overall purpose.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/23/2021 15:02:17
Subject: co-jointly in the making
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I think we are all on board (metaphor, image), with one exception. I hope he makes it! 

At this point in time, we are beginning to engage (read and write) in the fishbowl as a daily practice (ritual). 

We are developing a reading and writing strategy (in case you hadn’t noticed), and 

learning to deconstruct text (please google Jacques Derrida and Deconstruction), and 

experientially (by bringing in emotion), we are creating a point-of-view. 

Doing vocabulary and google searches with focus and sincerity are expected from each of us, including myself. We are 'co-jointly in the making' of a society and culture.

Please see Jillian Stacks postings below.

They are helpful, like most of you, if you are figuring out the fishbowl.

They make a good read, but HOW has she done them?

You can view her postings as ‘spheres of knowing'; or, ‘fragments of knowledge,’ or, ‘streams of thought-images.’

ETHEREAL, EPHEMERAL

We can view them anyway we like, but she is developing herself by following the trajectory of her own thoughts. 

You could say she is a work of art in the making.

How does she do it? 

She is a conduit for several flows of information, namely, dictionary, letters, postings, reflections, images ... all in the past, brought forth, to configure and compose, in the present?

TRAJECTORY, CONDUIT, CONFIGURE, COMPOSE, THOUGHT, MAKE

She focused on ‘words' and let her intuition do the work, all for the love of society and culture. But one day, we’ll be paying for her!

Sanjiv

FRAGMENT, FOCUS, KNOWLEDGE, KNOWING, THOUGHT-IMAGE (please google), STREAM, SPHERE, ART, MAKING, INTUITION

from the fishbowl...

Behind our masks, we were Eyes looking at Eyes.

Although we were all wearings masks during class, each student was observing one another. This has become the new normal in 2020-2021. 

Were you looking, or were you asleep?

Were you paying attention in class or were you simply unaware. 

You ’navigated’, like an explorer, an unknown and unchartered terrain. 

This is a new class with a new structure, we each need to take time to figure it out on our own in order to thrive in this class.

Post by jillianstack » Sun Sep 19, 2021 4:59 pm

Letter 9/16 

Reading is the focal point of the fishbowl:

Reading is the main area of focus when posting on the fishbowl. Each letter must be read thoroughly. 

In this mental space, the fishbowl, we are learning how to attend to our differences. 

All students will post different opinions on the fishbowl, which is reasonable. Differences in the meaning of a word that we selected to describe or visualize or imagine something.

Fishbowl state-of-mind

Interpret each letter in your own way, and post on the fishbowl.

Post by jillianstack » Sun Sep 19, 2021 5:16 pm

Letter 9/17

What mark, what etching do you leave?

The mark is each student going to leave on the fishbowl is based on their personal thoughts, opinions, and posts. 

To Be or not to Be?

"To be, or not to be" is the opening phrase of a soliloquy given by Prince Hamlet in the so-called "nunnery scene" of William Shakespeare's play.

How are you? 

Is there a great deal of confusion when starting the fishbowl? I feel as though the fishbowl is a learning process that each student must take advantage of.

Post by jillianstack » Sun Sep 19, 2021 5:30 pm

Letter 9/18

It is quite simple really if you listen and not just hear me.

Genuinely try to understand what Sanjiv is teaching us, instead of just hearing his words, think about them and deconstruct. 

We’re 'reading into' each other's words

We are looking at each other's posts, and understanding them, not just reading. 

Resonating heart

To continue to produce a loud, clear, deep sound for a long time

To have particular meaning or importance for someone

To affect or appeal to someone in a personal or emotional way

Post by jillianstack » Mon Sep 20, 2021 8:54 pm

Letter 9/19

"A daily practice of reflection, contemplation and meditation is a good idea"

Make sure to take advantage of the fishbowl, constantly interpreting what others say and comment on their topics. This is a place to develop your thoughts and trust the process. 

"In other words, he opened his tool box and let it lead the way"

Your toolbox is a set of activities and resources that support your mental health. Because everyone's mind and body respond differently to stress, what is effective for you may not be the same as what works for a family member or friend.

"Setting up rituals before you enter this sacred space is a way of demarcating the space. Washing dishes is a common one."

Washing dishes is a common routine that many families have. It is something that must be done. The same rules apply to the fishbowl. You must make the fishbowl a part of your routine and constantly tend to it, just like the dishes.

Post by jillianstack » Mon Sep 20, 2021 9:18 pm

Letter 9/20

"Please think about it. You are reflecting on your experience of what Sloterdijk is saying because you are learning to develop an 'opinion and a position that is authentic."

My experience with the fishbowl is very similar to what Sloterdijk is referring to when he says, "our ever-changing socio-technological environment reveals the necessity of a new conception of the human as inherently relational and spatially determined: a being in spheres."

We are constantly reading the fishbowl letters and creating our own position on them. This is extremely important for our personal growth. 

"There is no camera pointing at you, but we can see each other." 

We have to be our truest selves on this platform, unconcerned with others' thoughts and opinions on our posts. This will provide the best outcome and will allow each of us to embrace the fishbowl in our own way.

Post by jillianstack » Tue Sep 21, 2021 12:56 pm

Letter 9/21 

No one gets left behind on this boat because Eat, Read, Sleep is its daily bread. 

The fishbowl is now part of our everyday lives. We need to go about our normal routine while also logging onto the fishbowl to read others thoughts and write our own. 

We’re riding slow, waiting for the moon to show.

This is a long-term process, constantly learning as we go. Do not rush your thoughts in the fishbowl, embrace the process and learn from Professor Sanjiv's letters.

Post by jillianstack » Wed Sep 22, 2021 5:20 pm

Letter 9/21 

She can charge a price, and that is what it is about. 

This is applicable in finance, accounting and sports, indeed, everywhere text and reader interact.

Anyone can charge a price for a commodity, like supply and demand. 

Students supply others with their own knowledge and demand to have access to their peer's knowledge as well. 

It is a process of giving and taking. 

Pushing and pulling.

Post by jillianstack » Wed Sep 22, 2021 5:45 pm

Letter 9/22

"You have to sit quietly in solitude; no multi-tasking, I’m afraid."

We must sit quietly to "sail forth into an imaginary world where anything can happen." 

We are not allowed to multi-task because our attention must be set to one subject at a time. 

We are so used to multitasking in our everyday lives. 

"Our i-phones become redundant" 

We are on our Iphones so much, but I do not want to focus on how much we are personally using our technology. I would like to refer to the redundancy of technology and devices nowadays. Consumers today own laptops, desktops, tablets, televisions, e-readers, smartphones, smartwatches, smart speakers, smart displays, smart TVs, and smart everything-elses in myriad combinations. So many of these devices do the same things. There may be small differentiations in what one device can do as opposed to another, but the Venn diagram of gadget functionality in 2021 is looking more and more like a single circle all the time. For example, you might own a phone, tablet, watch, and even a television that all run Android. You might also have a Chromebook laptop that runs Android apps. The Google Assistant probably lives on all of these devices as well, ready to respond when you speak the wake word. But of course, your smart speaker does too.

"What does it mean to be reflexive?"

The definition of reflexive is thinking deeply. An example of something reflexive is a piece of art which makes the viewer ponder life. We need to be reflexive in the fishbowl. It is the best metaphor to understand the fishbowl. The fishbowl is about our ability to see our words as symbols, metaphors and images.

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I think we are all on board (metaphor, image), with one exception. I hope he makes it! 

At this point in time, we are beginning to engage (read and write) in the fishbowl as a daily practice (ritual).

learning to deconstruct text (please google Jacques Derrida and Deconstruction), and 

experientially (by bringing in emotion), we are creating a point-of-view. 

Doing vocabulary and google searches with focus and sincerity are expected from each of us, including myself. We are 'co-jointly in the making' of a society and culture.

They are helpful, like most of you, if you are figuring out the fishbowl.

They make a good read, but HOW has she done them?

You can view her postings as ‘spheres of knowing'; or, ‘fragments of knowledge,’ or, ‘streams of thought-images.’

ETHEREAL, EPHEMERAL

We can view them anyway we like, but she is developing herself by following the trajectory of her own thoughts. 

You could say she is a work of art in the making.

How does she do it? 

She is a conduit for several flows of information, namely, dictionary, letters, postings, reflections, images ... all in the past, brought forth, to configure and compose, in the present?

TRAJECTORY, CONDUIT, CONFIGURE, COMPOSE, THOUGHT, MAKE

She focused on ‘words' and let her intuition do the work, all for the love of society and culture. But one day, we’ll be paying for her!

Sanjiv

"Our i-phones become redundant" 

We are on our Iphones so much, but I do not want to focus on how much we are personally using our technology. I would like to refer to the redundancy of technology and devices nowadays. Consumers today own laptops, desktops, tablets, televisions, e-readers, smartphones, smartwatches, smart speakers, smart displays, smart TVs, and smart everything-elses in myriad combinations. So many of these devices do the same things. ------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/22/2021 14:40:32
Subject: overcoming fear of nothingness through reflexive action
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? I hope you are well.

It is the individual's ‘learning’ that interests us in the fishbowl. 

What are you learning and realizing, and how are you doing so?

LEARN, REALIZE, FUNDAMENTAL, QUESTION, SOLITUDE, REDUNDANT, RECLAIM, EXPANSE

To answer such fundamental and persistent questions, you have to be “reflexive.” 

You have to sit quietly in solitude; no multi-tasking, I’m afraid. 

Our i-phones become redundant and we reclaim the expanse of our imagination. I’ve begun leaving this device behind, so I can sail forth into an imaginary world where anything can happen. Please google Never Ending Story. It is the best metaphor to understand the fishbowl. In the fishbowl, we are a world of symbols, metaphors and images. Our fear is Nothingness. The fishbowl is about our ability to see our words as symbols, metaphors and images.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lHytjEj7B9g

The Upshot: we can’t survive without constructing imaginary realities consisting of symbols, metaphors and images. One brick at a time. Now that is a symbol, a metaphor and an image!

II.

What does it mean to be reflexive? Reflexivity is the process of reflecting on yourself the researcher, to provide more effective and impartial analysis. It involves examining and consciously acknowledging the assumptions and preconceptions you bring into the research and that therefore shape the outcome. None of us are detached, objective observers. The definition of reflexive is thinking deeply. It is a grammatical structure where the subject and object are the same person or thing and the verb is directed back at the subject.

Reflexive words show that the person who does the action of posting in the fishbowl is also the person who is affected by it: In the sentence "She prides herself on doing a good job," "prides" is a reflexive verb and "herself" is a reflexive pronoun.

Reflexive pronouns are words like myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves and themselves. They refer back to a person or thing. We often use reflexive pronouns when the subject and the object of a verb are the same.

Sanjiv

ASSUMPTION, PRECONCEPTION, IMPARTIAL,

Date: 9/21/2021 23:45:06
Subject: aesthetic response
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well.

Please see an example of what is known as an ‘Aesthetic Response’ (please google the term) in Emily Youngs’ reflection below.

Emily Youngs’ aesthetic response is to be analyzed in terms of a dialectic relationship between text, reader, and their interaction. It is called aesthetic response because, although it is brought about by the text, it brings into play the imaginative and perceptive faculties of the reader (emily youngs), in order to make her adjust and even differentiate her own focus. She combines thought and emotion.

She is constructing meaning and an understanding for herself in the awareness that others can access and read it, and thus there is no right or wrong. She can charge a price, and that is what it is about. This is applicable in finance, accounting and sports, indeed, everywhere text and reader interact.

Sanjiv

ANALYZE, DIALECTIC, INTERACT, IMAGINATIVE, PERCEPTIVE, ADJUST, DIFFERENTIATE, FOCUS, THOUGHT, EMOTION

from the fishbowl...

Letters: Deconstruction

	 Tue Sep 21, 2021 5:13 pm

Letter: systematic reflection and cognitive structures

The name of the letter "Systematic reflection and cognitive structures" captured my interest immediately. It almost sums up exactly what we are trying to do here in the fishbowl.

Beginning with "systematic", the American Heritage dictionary has a few definitions for this word. However, the meaning that I liked the most was that systematic can be defined as "methodical". The term "reflection" has the meaning of a manifestation or result. The first two words together define our posts here in the fishbowl. They are the result of our methodicalness. Methodicaness is a word that is defined in the American Heritage dictionary, essentially meaning our normal orderly habits. 

Moving on to the latter half of the title of the letter, "cognition" is our entire mental process and awareness. Our cognition is the most crucial factor involved in the fishbowl. Without our cognition we have nothing. The fishbowl is a place to even further strengthen our cognition and get it moving. 

"Structures" are the way parts of a whole are arranged to complete the entire "whole", in this case the whole being a metaphor for our whole being.

I find the title, as a whole, to be a metaphor for the base of our experiences here in the fishbowl. 

We are a methodical result of the way in which our own mental processes, thoughts, emotions and knowledge are arranged to form our complex whole being.

Post by arturoortega » Tue Sep 21, 2021 1:50 am

09/20/2021

"a being in spheres."

We are actors within the social circles which we choose and do not choose to be a part of. These spheres however, overlap into each other, and those overlapping spheres overlap other spheres. In this way some portion of us is always carried out sphere to sphere regardless of how we may be perceived in each. 

In the context of this class we are each crafting a persona through our fishbowl posts. The goal and the perpetuity of that persona, or lack thereof, being known only to us within our own personal sphere. 

Theres a type of code switching which happens within my own being where the "me" that I am at home is different from the "me" that I am at school with my friends, and the "me" that I am with my friends is different from the "me" that I am with my professors.

Even within the role of a friend, the actor which I embody differentiates himself depending on the audience, creating different performances between different spheres.

But what happens in the event that multiple social "spheres" are in the same audience?

Well, it's almost like an actor who was hiding among the audience has stood from his seat and revealed himself, reciting line by line from memory there in the middle of the audience. After a few carefully delivered verses the actor proceeds to the stage and is forced to walk down the aisle, across the stage, and perform. Which role the actor wants to deliver is entirely up to him. However, now within the audience there are those left wondering whether they missed something, those wondering whether they are now part of the act, and those who are there to just sit back and enjoy the performance.

This notion is not limited to the performance we put on as a friend. This notion is true across every sphere. We have to prepare to pick a role and which audience to perform it for.

From Luce Irigaray, Sharing the World (p.9)

To Venture Upon the Path

If in ourselves, in our dwelling, space and spacing must be safeguarded and cultivated, the arrival at the borders of ourselves, of our world, opens out onto new places that are still virgin or to be cleared. We can venture into them alone and try to appropriate them, to make them our own. But if the threshold has been built with the intention of meeting with the other, there is no doubt that, beyond this threshold, his or her call will join our own, paving new paths in the spaces opened.

Images

Sent from my iPhone

Date: 9/20/2021 13:17:50
Subject: relational and spatially determined conception of the human
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you this monday morning? I hope you are keeping well.

According to Peter Sloterdijk (please google) "our ever-changing socio-technological environment (fishbowl and brightspace) reveals the necessity of a new conception of the human as inherently relational and spatially determined: a being in spheres."

Please think about it. You are reflecting on your experience of what Sloterdijk is saying, because you are learning to develop an 'opinion and a position' that is authentic. There is no camera pointing at you, but we can see each other. For, the fishbowl is a room of mirrors in which we are experiencing the well known concept of Indra’s Jewel Net (please google). We are in a reality where even silence speaks. How so? Postings aside, your fishbowls illustrate the "interpenetration, inter-causality, and inter-being” within each of us. Please verify this. The metaphor of Indra’s Net illustrates the interpenetration (mixing and merging) of all phenomena.

Ultimately and unavoidably, we want (desire) to turn our self-knowledge (opinion and position) and global awareness (experience) into an advantage for our business, our projects, our art work in theatre, painting, music, and sports. We are both, pragmatic and poetic at heart. Like Spiderman and WonderWoman (images)

Sanjiv

AWARE, EXPERIENCE, INHERENT, RELATIONAL, SPATIAL, DETERMINE, BEING, HUMAN, CONCEPTION, SPHERE

Deconstructing letters

 Fri Sep 17, 2021 7:37 pm

Re-arranging chairs:

I chose this phrase because it tells a story. Every good story must be accompanied with sensory details that allows the reader to see something without using their eyes; smell something without using their nose; and hear sounds without using their ears. Re-arranging chairs is a great metaphor for what needed to be done to make learning seamless for everyone in these two classes. Here is how I would bread down the phrase. 

“Re” can be synonymous to the word again or anew. 

“Arranging” is the process of organizing and putting in a particular order. 

and, while “chairs”, on the surface might mean an object that allows people to sit, contextually however, I would describe as our very lives in the moment in time. 

This compound phrase made up of these three words, together, describes this progressive time we’re currently living in where we constantly have to adjust to currently condition and adapt to our environment. We've all had to do some chair re-arrangements this past 18 months whether we wanted to or nor. I am grateful for this rearrangement, as it allowed me to get a sit in this class, and after the first week, I realized that my success in this class, and in life for that matter, requires constant rearrangements on my part so I’m not left behind. The reason is because the world around me is not static but rather it’s progressive and we must re-arrange constantly to keep up.

jeancazeau

Joined: Mon Sep 13, 2021 6:26 pm

Deconstructing letters

	Sun Sep 19, 2021 9:57 pm

Perceive:

Our first meeting on Tuesday was a fairly standard one. It was a class full of students with one professor giving a lecture. Most students were taking notes, taking heed to the Chinese proverb “a short pencil is better than a long memory”. We were all attentive at least from my perspectives. The professor had a captive audience and his performance was not short of that of a professional. He alerted us that at some point we’d be so focused on what we’re working on that someone could walk in that class and feel something brewing in the atmosphere without us uttering a word. 

In fact, I witnessed exactly that. I felt that tension on Tuesday afternoon. Albeit, I could not immediately identify what it was at that moment. I realized later what I was observing. As the professor elegantly spoke, it was no longer what he was saying that captivated me. It was my perception of what he was saying that kept my interests. I suddenly became aware of what was happening. It was the beginning of something special. My eyes saw more than I intended too. I came for a class, rather I saw anonymous travelers, all with a different trajectory in life, meeting at one point in time and space. Many of us will never physically see one another again. Even if by chance we did cross paths, the masks would have kept our identity concealed. Yet, despite our differences, I felt that our focus was singular. With that type of unity, comes power - the power to accomplish great things. We have a unique opportunity to create something that does not yet exist. In fact, whatever it is that we are going to create cannot be created by anyone else but us. Our uniqueness will be the special ingredient needed for success. So, I’m excited for what is to come.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/20/2021 3:00:18
Subject: systematic reflection and cognitive structures
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? The majority have made contact in the fishbowl. 

A daily practice of reflection, contemplation and meditation is a good idea. 

Please carve out a special time; known as 'sacred space' in every culture and society. 

Setting up rituals before you enter this sacred space is a way of demarcating the space. Washing dishes is a common one.

Please see Jean Cazeau’s postings below. WHAT did he do and HOW did he do it?

Through systematic reflection, he sought to determine the essential properties and structures of his experience. You could say, his reflection on his experience is a medium for conceptual creation. In other words, he opened his tool box and let it lead the way. And as his thoughts began to emerge he attended to them.

Sanjiv

REFLECTION, CONTEMPLATION, MEDITATION, SACRED, SPACE, RITUAL, DEMARCATE, EXPERIENCE, STRUCTURE, CREATION, CONCEPTUAL

from the fishbowl...systematic reflection and cognitive structures

jeancazeau

Posts: 6

Joined: Mon Sep 13, 2021 6:26 pm

Deconstructing letters

 Fri Sep 17, 2021 7:37 pm

Re-arranging chairs:

I chose this phrase because it tells a story. Every good story must be accompanied with sensory details that allows the reader to see something without using their eyes; smell something without using their nose; and hear sounds without using their ears. Re-arranging chairs is a great metaphor for what needed to be done to make learning seamless for everyone in these two classes. Here is how I would bread down the phrase. 

“Re” can be synonymous to the word again or anew. 

“Arranging” is the process of organizing and putting in a particular order. 

and, while “chairs”, on the surface might mean an object that allows people to sit, contextually however, I would describe as our very lives in the moment in time. 

This compound phrase made up of these three words, together, describes this progressive time we’re currently living in where we constantly have to adjust to currently condition and adapt to our environment. We've all had to do some chair re-arrangements this past 18 months whether we wanted to or nor. I am grateful for this rearrangement, as it allowed me to get a sit in this class, and after the first week, I realized that my success in this class, and in life for that matter, requires constant rearrangements on my part so I’m not left behind. The reason is because the world around me is not static but rather it’s progressive and we must re-arrange constantly to keep up.

Deconstructing letters

	Sun Sep 19, 2021 9:57 pm

Perceive:

Our first meeting on Tuesday was a fairly standard one. It was a class full of students with one professor giving a lecture. Most students were taking notes, taking heed to the Chinese proverb “a short pencil is better than a long memory”. We were all attentive at least from my perspectives. The professor had a captive audience and his performance was not short of that of a professional. He alerted us that at some point we’d be so focused on what we’re working on that someone could walk in that class and feel something brewing in the atmosphere without us uttering a word. 

In fact, I witnessed exactly that. I felt that tension on Tuesday afternoon. Albeit, I could not immediately identify what it was at that moment. I realized later what I was observing. As the professor elegantly spoke, it was no longer what he was saying that captivated me. It was my perception of what he was saying that kept my interests. I suddenly became aware of what was happening. It was the beginning of something special. My eyes saw more than I intended too. I came for a class, rather I saw anonymous travelers, all with a different trajectory in life, meeting at one point in time and space. Many of us will never physically see one another again. Even if by chance we did cross paths, the masks would have kept our identity concealed. Yet, despite our differences, I felt that our focus was singular. With that type of unity, comes power - the power to accomplish great things. We have a unique opportunity to create something that does not yet exist. In fact, whatever it is that we are going to create cannot be created by anyone else but us. Our uniqueness will be the special ingredient needed for success. So, I’m excited for what is to come.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/18/2021 13:22:30
Subject: fishbowl process in a nutshell (metaphor, image)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Please see Colin Staples post below. I am using it as an example, to get across what each one of us is doing, including myself. 

It is quite simple really, if you listen and not just hear me. 

Broadly speaking, all semester, we’re 'reading into' each others words and, no one can tell you what to say and do.

HOW did Staples write such a text (Fishbowl, fall 21) is the question, and how should a reader RESPOND to it?

First step: he presents two phrases that he selected because it challenged his frame of mind; his thinking. 

Fearlessly, he will see where it will lead; the TRAJECTORY of his THOUGHTS.

Second step: How to understand the CONTEXT?

With tool-box (American Heritage Dictionary in hand, he explores the ELEMENTS, i.e., the words in the selected phrases.

He TRANSCRIBES precisely what he sees.

Simple and straightforward thus far. Staples re-creates and SHARES the context. 

That is to say, he shares his selection of words and his play with nuance in a grey area (metaphor, image).

Third step: He INFUSES his personal felt experience and MARKS his position in the reader’s mind. 

His EFFECT is complete. You can no longer forget his words, i.e., his point-of-view.

Bottom Line: you are taking a phrase and re-writing it from a place of understanding, achieved through reflection and contemplation. 

And all you have is your tool-box and a resonating heart.

At this point I invariably bring up Luce Irigaray (please google), some one I have studied (following) for a long time.

“We cannot share the world as it already is, with the exception of the natural world. The world that we can share is always and still to be elaborated by us and between us starting from the perception and affirmation of what and who we are as humans here and now.” (Irigaray)

Sanjiv

UNDERSTANDING, REFLECT, CONTEMPLATE

from the fishbowl...

colinstaples

Posts: 7

Joined: Tue Sep 14, 2021 11:43 am

Letters: Deconstruction

 colinstaples » Fri Sep 17, 2021 11:59 am

Searching for a new language: 

We are not searching to speak a foreign language, but we are looking to expand on our vocabulary and knowledge which will allow us to become wiser and gain a better understanding of the English language. From reading the daily letters, phrases such as "objectivity of the 1st order" and "objectivity of the 2nd order" are a new language to myself. Understanding the context of a "new language" rather than the literal meaning is the goal. 

New Images of Ourselves: 

As the "Re-arranging chairs" letter stated, we are "actors, avatars, and acolytes." The definitions of actors, avatars, and acolytes all have one common theme: representation. At the end of the day, we are what we choose to represent ourselves as: hard-workers, lazy, curious, etc.. In MGT 345, we are being introduced to a "new language" where we challenge ourselves to become more philosophical and figurative. As an individual, I am usually literal and to the point so this course has challenged me to become a new image of myself. It is very hard to come out of a comfort zone, but with a new perspective we can attempt to better ourselves and understanding.

Date: 9/15/2021 15:24:51
Subject: after our first meeting
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? I feel our first meeting went well.

Behind our masks we were Eyes looking at Eyes. 

MASK, EYE

What did you see? What did you perceive? What did you visualize?

Were you looking, or were you asleep?

SEE, PERCEIVE, VISUALIZE, LOOK

Looking at you looking at me looking at you. In this reality, which is perceptual and visual, we lead a double life. We exist twice. 

In the 'objectivity of the first order' which is the distribution of material things, like the size of the room, number of chairs, etc. We experience this reality on Tuesdays.

And, we exist in the 'objectivity of the second order' which are classifications that function as templates for the practical activities that we do, like our conduct, thoughts, feelings, expectations and judgements.

CLASSIFICATION, TEMPLATE 

II.

I am assuming you have made your presence known in the fishbowl. Got over it and past it. Absorbed and owned your space. You ’navigated’, like an explorer, an unknown and unchartered terrain. Some of you are better than others, and I hope it wasn’t too much of a stress.

Henceforth, simplicity is key. KISS principle: keep it simple stupid!

How so?

Post everything in your space in the fishbowl. 

Open the following Topic Heads but keep your structures flexible:

STRUCTURE, FLEXIBLE

1. Vocabulary

2. Google Searches

3. Letters: deconstruction

4. Reflections: Taking and making notes

5. Exercises

1. Vocabulary is key. It determines the boundary of every discourse. Some words just aren’t allowed. Context is everything because it gives meaning to our words.

VOCABULARY, BOUNDARY, DISCOURSE, CONTEXT, MEANING, WORD

2. Google searches are surfing, sliding, but always looking for what RESONATES. Don’t forget we reveal ourselves by the choices we make. Be yourself. Pull out and look out for ideas more than facts. You will get better at it with practice.

#3,4,5 we will be developing in the next several weeks. 

We are setting up a process and a practice, and we working one word at a time.

Please see Erin Torgersen’s Notes in the fishbowl. Her words are concepts and she is gathering and assembling them.

Riding slow...waiting for the moon to show...

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

Taking and Making Notes

Class 9/14: 

Culture is big 

Usually when there are problems in a company with cultural problem is from a lack of understanding 

Understanding culture from a research method point of view 

Must be skilled in research 

We are learning how to: Discern, Distinguish, Develop, Describe 

Work on the process- how do i do this, not the outcome 

Learning how to decipher and discern text (the letters)

Decipher = Read

Learning how to decode and deconstruct 

In the letters: 

Pull out one thing and deconstruct it 

Requirements:

Vocabulary

Google Searches- looking for a sentence/phrase that resonates with you 

Decoding Letters: Pulling out a phrase to decode and open up letter 

Taking and Making Notes 

Homework Exercises

Looking at Hofstede’s Dimensions (4 out of 5).

Where we fall into these dimensions and how they fit into particular cultures and situations 

Dimensions in the workbook

Selection is very important: When you're making a choice, you are declaring who you are

You don’t want to see what others have done until after you do your own work 

Redundant: We live in a redundant age- workers are turned into each other

Be looking at others work but not until you finish your work so that it wont be redundant 

Learning to Individuate ourselves 

Always working on sentences, constructing sentences (like a carpenter)

Dictionary = toolbox 

“Using the toolbox one word at a time to construct sentences”

Using reading and writing strategy

Learning about Value Structures: Word Structures 

Keeps coming down to words

Don’t focus on goals, we are practicing a nonlinear education through osmosis 

Learning how to research, read and write

Process and Practice

Following a Practice of a certain Process

Practice: Doing it on a regular daily basis 

Immerse yourself in text 

Must love words, have a love affair with words (we are learning to)

Although this course is not linear, it still builds on each other- must start at first letter

**Active Topics** how the professor views the fishbowl

Knowledge Economy = must have value = value comes from being original 

Metaphor: Career Ladder

Different cultures have people on different ladders

Word-Image: Culturally determined 

Google: a graphic or vivid description in words.

When decoding: how did you do it, what direction did you take 

Action Research - Not passive

Date: 9/13/2021 1:52:54
Subject: re-arranging chairs
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope your first week went well and I wish you the best for our first class this Tuesday.

It’s a time we are living on the edge. 

Edge of what?

To live on the edge is to live a life of text and images.

Those of us who understand this in a global knowledge economy are duly rewarded.

I.

In MGT345 and MGT448, we are searching for a new language; a fresh way of perceiving our environments; more complex and fluid organizational structures; new strategies and new leadership styles. In a nutshell, new metaphors and word-images. 

Above all, we are searching for new images of ourselves in a perceptual environment made up of text and images streaming across our mental landscapes.

I am writing this introductory letter to expound on the word; the image; the metaphor; the perception; the idea known as BLENDED. 

In other words, to raise the question, what does BLEND mean for us in MGT345 and 448, particularly with regards to complex and fluid organizational structures; and, new strategies and leadership styles?

To address the meaning of anything, we turn to the dictionary, aka the carpenter's tool-box.

As we proceed in this fashion during the semester, we will learn that our text and images have direct effect on the ground in the physical and material world.

How so?

After contemplating the word BLENDED by looking-up the latest edition of the American Heritage dictionary, I came up with the following organizational structure that is both complex and fluid and has a new strategy which depicts a particular leadership style...

We are 50 registered in MGT345-1 meeting in 105 Ballantine at 11am and, 

we are 50 in MGT345-2 meeting at 2pm in 204 White Hall. 

Ballantine has more registered students than the number of seats, and White Hall has 10 seats available.

We are 40 registered in MGT448 meeting in 045 Engineering Bldg at 3.30pm, and all seats all taken.

All three meetings listed above are happening once a week on Tuesday.

II.

Coming up with an Organizational STRUCTURE, that is COMPLEX and FLUID and a new PEDAGOGY and STRATEGY that DEPICTS a new APPROACH.

Both MGT345 and MGT448 are going online. 

The allotted room in real time is to be considered as office hours for those who have questions, concerns, problems and wish to bring them face to face. 

There will be no attendance taken and your presence or absence will not affect your grade.

You are going to class on Tuesday only because you have a question, and are seeking organizational clarification. 

Students have the flexibility to go to either Ballantine, White Hall and Eng Bldg for office hours at 11am, 2pm and 3.30pm respectively.

First class is essential for introductions and should not be treated as office hours. 

For the first class on 9/14, students must go to their assigned class room. 

345-1 will go to Ballantine, and 345-2 will go to White Hall. 448 to the Eng. Bldg. 

We are in this together.

III.

Our entire work this semester will be done on a digital platform known as The Fishbowl. I will send you a subsequent letter tomorrow. At this point you have absorbed the Syllabus and you harbor several questions in-formation. There will be many more questions to come for some time. Take things in stride is how I can caution you. Don’t jump the gun. I will watch your back.

Before I sign off, I want to say that both courses have been designed in a way that no one gets below a B (very difficult to do) and, your assignments have no deadlines so you can never be late and, there are no exams for there are no right nor wrong answers. 

The only question you will be confronting all semester is: Did you do it? 

Just do it is never truer said. It’s a hands-on course and your learning has worth when it is experiential. 

So, did you do it? Just do it! 

It is the individual's responsibility to be in the mode of “performative writing” and “aesthetic responsiveness.” For, we are actors, avatars and acolytes. We alight, appear and descend from above.

Getting to know, one step at a time...

Sanjiv

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 4/24/2021 20:48:38
Subject: diving off the edge (345)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? It is a challenge to be focused and stay the course. 

Staying focused is the practice of everyday living, I.e., the way you individualize text, alter things, in order to make them your own. (Michel de Certeau).

I am going to tie up the syllabus, your fishbowls, the films in 345, all together within a framework through which I view your knowledge and knowing as manifest in your postings.

As a society, we left mental structures depicted in Strictly Ballroom behind by the time the 1980s rolled in.

Cultural and historical ways of thinking.

In recent years, reformers of both private and public institutions have preached that flexible, global corporations, like your fishbowls, provide a model of freedom for individuals, unlike the experience of fixed and static mental structures we saw in Strictly Ballroom.

And so you studied, experienced, witnessed, participated and thought about the characteristics of transnational corporations. They were: Integrated Networking Structures, Dynamic Decision-making, Adaptive Coordination Mechanisms and Unique Innovation Capabilities. Please see Bartlett and Ghoshal. 

Each of these characteristics, on your part, implied a sophisticated understanding of and ability to self-reflexively manage your expression and experience. You adapted as quickly as Charlie Boy in Kinky Boots and came through.

You brought your specific abilities of working in a diverse context to the table. 

Like Lola in Kinky Boots you worked only for adulation.

Building flexibility, sharing information and developing collective know-how into a worldwide network is what sustained you through navigating and negotiating the unknown.

An organization in which the contents are constantly shifting requires the mobile capacity to solve problems; getting deeply involved in any one problem would be dysfunctional, since projects end as abruptly as they begin. You see this again and again in every posting of yours in the fishbowl. The person who can move on, whose posting is possibility, seems more attuned to the instabilities which rule the global market place. 

In banishing old ills seen in Strictly Ballroom, the new-society model creates new social and emotional traumas you saw in Beautiful People with everyday lives. Old dichotomies and dimensions morphing into evanescent and effervescent forms...a liquid society (see Zygmunt Bauman).

Only a certain kind of human being can prosper in unstable, fragmentary institutions.

The culture of our new society (Richard Sennett) demands an ideal Self oriented to 

the short term, 

focused on potential ability rather than accomplishment, 

willing to discount or abandon past experience. 

You taught me this in your fishbowl postings and personified by Lola in Kinky Boots.

The social skill required by a flexible organization is the ability to work well with others in short-lived teams, others you won’t have the time to know well. Whenever the team dissolves and you enter a new group, the problem you have to solve is getting down to business as quickly as possible with these new teammates.

“I can work with anyone” is the social formula for potential ability. Your skill lies in cooperating, whatever the circumstances. Please see Erin Torgersen’s reflection below.

And so we come to the edge. I would like to conclude by assessing three critical values—- narrative, usefulness, and craftsmanship—-that might create an anchor diving off the cliff. Please stay tuned. 

Sanjiv

CHALLENGE, INDIVIDUALIZE, PERSONIFY, MANIFEST, DEPICT, UNSTABLE, POTENTIAL, ABANDON, DISSOLVE, LIQUID, COOPERATE, ANCHOR

from the fishbowl...

Getting real: We are now looking at the bigger picture (microscope to telescope). The lens is zooming out and getting wider. Feelings and emotions are often confusing and not straightforward. It can be hard to keep them straight and to pinpoint particular feelings. While we have traveled through this long journey together, we are about to turn the corner and come to an end. Our fishbowl postings are giving everybody else a glimpse into who we are, a small look into our lives. We look at each of our similarities and differences when seeing how we interact together. But, we cannot conform, we must make our own paths, lead our own lives. We have put ourselves on the line and shown our true colors.

No one listens to me, said my grand nephew.

It’s good to have a favorite poet; read sacred text.

I return to Rilke and Akhmatova every time, she noticed.

It gets you on the right path, and never fails, I replied.

We travelled so many roads together. What am I to say.

You saw me through the pandemic.

Your postings in the fishbowl, like etchings, read as a memoir of unfolding curiosity.

The connections and echoes among your notings are as intriguing as the contrasts in style and subject matter.

Your work is grounded in 'cultural anthropology’ (please google) 

but shaped by the observation that, 

in a world of rapid change and encounters with strangers, 

we can no longer depend on following traditionally defined paths.

We survived the fishbowl by forging our own path into the unknown.

You jumped off the cliffs of the heart, without hesitation.

We came for adulation (Lola in Kinky Boots).

We are stars in each other’s crown.

Title: Online Learning Process in Sequential Events 

Introduction:

In our experience, ‘online learning process’ is about participating in and sustaining joint performances, in spite of differences in competence. It is a process that is fragile and subject to continual change, not unlike wikipedia or EDULEARN21. 

Our process of online learning took place in a community managed site, known as the Fishbowl (1). 

Our paper is based on the premise that the process of online learning is a dynamic interaction that is continually in a state of “becoming” something else. We distinguish our learning between two kinds of becoming or, learning occurrences. One, the uniform ‘going-on’ of learning activities that prevailed among us, and two, the ‘coming-about’ of learning development. Our paper presents the ‘coming-about’ of online learning as “events” that are “ruptures” in one’s ‘going-on’ learning activities (2). 

Literature and Method:

From the literature in Process Organization Studies (3) and notions of Competency Based Education, we identified fundamental aspects of the learning process as creativity, organic change over time, subjectivity and interdependence. 

Our method for learning in the Fishbowl gives ontological primacy to individual self-reflection and self-realization (4), and records three sequential “events.”

The first event focuses on participation as providing context for the development of learning a particular competence.

The second “event” uses joint participation to bring about change in one’s subjective understanding of a competence.

The third “event” is sharing fragmentary reflections of felt-experiences regarding the competence.

Finding: 

We present three instances for each of the three sequential “events.” A study of these sequences establishes that as participants we were collaborating in a pattern of more or less alternating, non-overlaying vocalization, where we spoke pithy sentences in response to each other, together producing a brief joint performance similar to conversation.

Conclusion:

Our paper is a study of learning performances as events, events with several participants, communication in several modalities and a contextual structure, rather than the acquisition of a single competency. We found the process of online learning requires special theoretical efforts that undertake the double task of developing new explanatory concepts and providing arguments as to why these concepts better serves one’s online learning experience. 

References

[1] YouTube Student Video Channel 

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCJX57VhQs_biMyT8lokULzQ/videos

[2] Badiou, Alain. Being and Event (1988)

[3] Ann Langley and Haridimos Tsoukas (2016). The SAGE Handbook of Process Organization Studies

[4] Mats Alvesson and Kaj Skoldberg, Reflexive Methodology (2001). Sage

Keywords: ONLINE LEARNING PROCESS, EVENT, RUPTURE, COMPETENCY LEARNING
