Title: Online Learning Process

Introduction:

In our experience, online learning process is learning how to participate in and sustain joint performances, in spite of differences in competence. It is a process that is fragile and subject to continual change, not unlike wikipedia or EDULEARN21. Our process of online learning took place in a community managed site, known as the Fishbowl. Our paper is based on the premise that the process of online learning is a dynamic interaction that is continually in a state of “becoming” something else. We distinguish our learning between two kinds of becoming or, learning occurrences. One, the uniform ‘going-on’ of learning activities that prevailed among us, and two, the ‘coming-about’ of learning development. Our paper presents the ‘coming-about’ of online learning as “events” that are “ruptures” in one’s ‘going-on’ learning activities. 

Method:

From the literature in Process Organization Studies, we identified fundamental aspects of the learning process as creativity, organic change over time, subjectivity and interdependence. Our method for learning in the Fishbowl gives ontological primacy to individual self-reflection and self-realization, and follows three sequential events.

The first event is to focus on participation as providing context for the development of learning a particular competence.

The second event uses joint participation to bring about change in one’s subjective understanding of a competence.

The third event are reflections in fragments of felt-experiences.

Conclusion and Finding: 

Our paper is about the study of learning performances as events, events with several participants, communication in several modalities and a contextual structure, rather than the study of a single competence. We found the process of online learning requires special theoretical efforts that undertake the double task of developing new explanatory concepts and providing arguments as to why these concepts better serve one's aim of online learning. 

In the space and time permitted, we present three instances of our online learning process.

(3/28) Social ontology - 

Social ontology - the study of the nature and properties of the social world. It is concerned with analyzing the various entities in the world that arise from social interaction. A prominent topic in social ontology is the analysis of social groups.

Thought leader - one whose views on a subject are taken to be authoritative and influential.

The fishbowl is an interpretation or form of social ontology. We all have our own ways in nature and properties within the world, and we are all able to arise from the social interaction. 

How are we social in the fishbowl? Learning from each other, sharing experiences, practicing our words, deconstructing the meaning behind the text. We are in a movie, looking through the peep-holes. Eyes looking at eyes.

carolinemahoney

Posts: 115

Joined: Tue Feb 02, 2021 8:34 pm

Sun Apr 18, 2021 10:58 pm

(3/29) Post-structuralists -

study/reflection

"While studying for my business in society class, I found myself reflecting on past memories to connect my past with what I am currently learning."

study - to read, memorize facts, attend school, etc., in order to learn about a subject, to give careful attention to (something).

reflection - serious thought or consideration.

We are all increasing our knowledge in the fishbowl by researching, analyzing, reflecting, and studying the different forms of text. We learn from others, and also ourselves while we write down our stream of consciousness onto the "page" on our screens.

Date: 4/13/2021 10:54:10
Subject: critical spatial practices
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I withdrew for a few inorder to create greater distance between us. I hope you are well. We are nearing the end of the road, and tenaciously, you hung in there. You never left my mind nor my sight and you continue to evoke deeply felt emotions.

Your fishbowls are representational spaces that are directly linked to your lived spaces, the spaces of everyday experiences.

Representational space does not involve too much head: it’s rather felt more than thought.

Representational space is lived. It speaks. It has an affective kernel or center.

It may be explained in various ways: it may be directional, situational or relational, because it is essentially qualitative, fluid and dynamic.

It is simply alive! 

Structures create spaces and spaces have structures. Please see Mitchell Dickson's vocabulary postings below as an example. 

Please see these words as symbols and word-images that evoke further images and feelings.

Your fishbowl is representational space experienced through complex structures of symbols and images and they overlay your physical space.

There is a triad of ’space' which must be aligned because they aren’t ever stable and they exhibit historically defined attributes and content:

conceived space (structure of your sentence)

perceived space (your perceptual category; one word)

lived space (felt experience; paragraph in first person)

So there you have the methodology again! 

Through dialectical interaction, you have been following a ’critical spatial practice’ (please google the term, along with Henri Lefebvre).

The key qualities of a critical practice are self-reflection and social transformation.

In 345 we are critically practicing a knowing and knowledge content for each of the 4 characteristics of successful transnational corporations. 

In 448, we are critically practicing a knowing and knowledge content for Hofstede’s dimensions of national cultures.

In a few more letters, I will wrap up the course plus link the purpose of watching films during the semester. Please be sure to see them.

Sanjiv

TRIAD, SPACE, REPRESENTATION, DIALECTIC, PRACTICE

Vocabulary

mitchelldickson

Posts: 16

Joined: Thu Feb 04, 2021 9:00 pm

Mon Apr 12, 2021 3:41 pm

IDIOM: a phrase or expression that represents a figurative, non literal meaning to the phrase.

LEXICON: the vocabulary of a person, language or branch of knowledge.

FEELING: an emotional state or reaction either through touch or perception.

EXPERIENCE: the process through which conscious beings the world around them.

DICHOTOMY: a division or contrast between two things that are seen as opposed or entirely different. 

CONSTITUTE: to be a part of a whole. 

METAPHOR: a figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action that is not literally applicable. 

WAY: a method or style of doing something. 

RELENTLESS: something that is harsh or oppressively constant.

RESISTANCE: the refusal to accept or comply with something. 

VOCABULARY: a body of words used in a particular language. 

WORD: a single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing used with others or alone. 

IMAGE: a representation of the external form of a person or thing in art. Can be physical or digital. 

ASSEMBLAGE: a collection or gathering of things or people.

FORM: the visible shape or configuration of something. 

DOING: the activities that an individual partakes in. 

LOOP: a shape produced by a curve that bends around and crosses itself. 

RECURSIVE: characterized by recurrence or repetition. 

CREATE: to bring something into existence. 

INTERRELATE: relate or connect with one another.

INDRA'S NET: a metaphor used to describe emptiness, dependent origination and interpretation in Buddhist philosophy. 

PICTURE: a painting, drawing or image. 

GRADE: a level of rank, quality, intensity or value.

 

Mon Apr 12, 2021 3:52 pm

EXPERIENCE: the process through which conscious beings the world around them.

TRAVERSE: to travel across or through. 

NAVIGATE: to plan or direct the route or course of a ship, plane or any form of transportation usually through maps.

NEGOTIATE: to try to reach an agreement or compromise by discussion with others.

UNCERTAINTY: the state of being uncertain or unsure about something. 

FOCUS: the center of interest or activity.

MINDFUL: being conscious or aware of something. 

MEDITATE: to think deeply or focus ones mind for a period of time in silence.

CONTEMPLATE: to look thoroughly for a long time at.

THOUGHT: an idea or opinion produced by thinking or occurring suddenly in the mind. 

TRAJECTORY: the path followed by a projectile flying or an object moving under the action of given forces. 

POSSIBILITY: a thing that may happen or be the case.

Mon Apr 12, 2021 4:55 pm

BODY: the physical structure of a person or animal including the bones, flesh and organs. 

MIND: an element of a person that allows them to be aware of the world and their experiences, to think and feel.

SPIRIT: the nonphysical part of a person which is the seat of emotions or character, the soul. 

DOMAIN: an area of territory owned or controlled by a ruler or government. 

INTERTWINE: twist or twine together.

EXTRICATE: someone or something that is free from a constraint or difficulty.

OPERATE: (a person) to control the functioning of something (machine, process or system)

ETYMOLOGY: the study of the origin of words and the way in which their meanings have changed throughout history.

COMPLEXITY: the state or quality of being intricate or complicated.

GENESIS: the origin or mode of formation of something.

DESIRE: a strong feeling of wanting to have something or wishing something to happen.

LEARN: gain or acquire knowledge of or skill in (something) by study, experience or being taught.

Mon Apr 12, 2021 5:01 pm

PROCESS: a series of actions or steps taken in order to achieve a particular end. 

RECONSTRUCT: build or form something again after it has been damaged or destroyed. 

MEDITATE: to think deeply or focus ones mind for a period of time in silence.

OPPOSITE: having a position on the other or further side of something.

OTHER: used to refer to a person or thing that is different or distinct from one already mentioned or known about.

Mon Apr 12, 2021 5:18 pm

CONSTRUCT: to build or erect something, usually a building, road or machine.

INTERPRET: explain the meaning of information, words or actions.

Date: 4/13/2021 10:53:19
Subject: critical spatial practices
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I withdrew for a few inorder to create greater distance between us. I hope you are well. We are nearing the end of the road, and tenaciously, you hung in there. You never left my mind nor my sight and you continue to evoke deeply felt emotions.

Your fishbowls are representational spaces that are directly linked to your lived spaces, the spaces of everyday experiences.

Representational space does not involve too much head: it’s rather felt more than thought.

Representational space is lived. It speaks. It has an affective kernel or center.

It may be explained in various ways: it may be directional, situational or relational, because it is essentially qualitative, fluid and dynamic.

It is simply alive! 

Structures create spaces and spaces have structures. Please see Mitchell Dickson's vocabulary postings below as an example. 

Please see these words as symbols and word-images that evoke further images and feelings.

Your fishbowl is representational space experienced through complex structures of symbols and images and they overlay your physical space.

There is a triad of ’space' which must be aligned because they aren’t ever stable and they exhibit historically defined attributes and content:

conceived space (structure of your sentence)

perceived space (your perceptual category; one word)

lived space (felt experience; paragraph in first person)

So there you have the methodology again! 

Through dialectical interaction, you have been following a ’critical spatial practice’ (please google the term, along with Henri Lefebvre).

The key qualities of a critical practice are self-reflection and social transformation.

In 345 we are critically practicing a knowing and knowledge content for each of the 4 characteristics of successful transnational corporations. 

In 448, we are critically practicing a knowing and knowledge content for Hofstede’s dimensions of national cultures.

In a few more letters, I will wrap up the course plus link the purpose of watching films during the semester. Please be sure to see them.

Sanjiv

TRIAD, SPACE, REPRESENTATION, DIALECTIC, PRACTICE

Date: 4/8/2021 13:49:12
Subject: vocabulary as learning cycles
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are doing well.

Please see Lance Waranis’s postings on “vocabulary" in his fishbowl as a recent example.

Lance Waranis shows the dynamic interplay between the main dimensions of any research when taking an action research approach.

The dimensions are interactive, always open to revision as his learning develops. 

He goes onto generate and refine questions or issues and find appropriate ways to explore them.

In all your fishbowls, we see how individual learning is fed from one phase of inquiry into new questions and inquiry processes for the next phase, in emergent, strategic design. In other words, the experience in each of your fishbowls, where even silence speaks, happens as learning cycles, with periodic reviews informing and shaping each next cycle, rather than being wholly intellectually pre-determined at the outset.

Any feature of your researching can be radically reviewed and changed, as an inherent, iterative quality process. 

Sanjiv

Date: 4/7/2021 20:44:11
Subject: action learning (345)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

All your postings in the fishbowl are products of an action-learning style of research that evolved as a result of your attempts to develop a possible social among yourselves.

I wish to describe the basic principles as well as the status of the ideas and knowledge that you have generated so that you may repeat the process in the future to your advantage.

Your Action-learning approach to research is built on the idea that it is possible for the research process to have a dual objective in (a) trying to produce useful research knowledge while (b) using a process that can help the people involved in the research gain a better understanding of their situations.

Please fact check the fishbowl. 

As the term “action learning” suggests, you are seeking to combine action and learning, to create a situation whereby everyone involved (in the fishbowl) learns while doing. Please see Hannah Veltry’s postings below as an excellent example. As such, her posting provides an ideal style of research for people, such as myself or senior managers, who are concerned to fuse the development of theory and practice and who wish to understand more about their organizations through some kind of direct involvement and problem-solving activity rather than detached academic observations we dish out in business schools.

Your approach is most often used in problem-oriented contexts where the leader/researcher is asked to help explore a problem or set of issues or to unlock some kind of new initiative.

Sanjiv

DUAL, OBJECTIVE, FUSE, THEORY, PRACTICE, INVOLVEMENT

Hermeneutic Perspective

Tue Mar 02, 2021 10:36 am

Hermeneutic Perspective:

“ Hermeneutics is the study of interpretation. Hermeneutics plays a role in a number of disciplines whose subject matter demands interpretative approaches, characteristically, because the disciplinary subject matter concerns the meaning of human intentions, beliefs, and actions, or the meaning of human experience as it is preserved in the arts and literature, historical testimony, and other artifacts.”

“Within philosophy, however, hermeneutics typically signifies, first, a disciplinary area and, second, the historical movement in which this area has been developed.”

Disciplinary: of or relating to a particular field of study

Movement: a group of people working together to advance their shared political, social, or artistic ideas

When I read the last sentence in quotations, I cannot help but draw parallels to Iris Young’s theory of ethics. Iris Young shaped a theory of ethics around the “Five Faces of Oppression”. Oppression was traditionally seen as an exercise of tyranny by a controlling group over others. In the 60s and 70s, a movement shifted society’s view on oppression to one that recognizes the disadvantages and injustices some people experience because of everyday practices within society, not because they are being ruled by a tyrannical power.

This parallel exists in all other disciplines as well. Historical movement drives historical change. When you think about great advances in certain disciplines (medicine, science, etc) can we not see the same likeness?

Social Construction of Reality 

Tue Mar 02, 2021 10:44 am

Social Construction of Reality:

In 1966 sociologists Peter Berger and Thomas Luckmann wrote a book called The Social Construction of Reality. In it, they argued that society is created by humans and human interaction, which they call habitualization. Habitualization describes how “any action that is repeated frequently becomes cast into a pattern, which can then be … performed again in the future in the same manner and with the same economical effort” (Berger and Luckmann 1966). Not only do we construct our own society but we also accept it as it is because others have created it before us. Society is, in fact, “habit.”

Individuals create habits through consistent repetition. Individuals create society through this reiteration. Habits of society form individuals. Individuals create society, society creates individuals. We are all connected.

Joined: Wed Feb 03, 2021 10:47 am

Immersive Technologies

Thu Mar 11, 2021 11:06 am

Immersive technologies create distinct experiences by merging the physical world with a digital or simulated reality. Augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) are two principal types of immersive technologies

Physical: relating to things perceived through the senses as opposed to the mind

Virtual: not physically existing as such but made by software to appear to do so.

Physical existence is tangible, concrete. Something you can touch, feel, see. Recognition of the physical being requires presence of mind. Similar to my analogy of image and emotion, separation of the emotion is necessary for the perception of the physical. It is necessary because we cannot see the physical as is when we include our felt experiences. That is when the physical becomes altered by our feelings and interpretations. They no longer exist as is.

Virtual existence is intangible. It is malleable. Virtual experience is fueled by falsehoods and felt experiences. It is not a true representation of existence. This intangible world is often distorted by desires and emotions. 

So how do we create a virtual world of authenticity to reflect the physical existence of reality? When we are authentic with in our beings, and ourselves, we are able to lead a life of truth, without comparisons to others. This allows us to mirror this authenticity in the virtual world, as we are in the fishbowl. This is not social media. We are connecting with our true beings, without images, without judgement, and creating a virtual world reflective of physical existence.

Present Moment Awareness

 Fri Mar 12, 2021 12:06 pm

Being in the present moment, or the “here and now,” means that we are aware and mindful of what is happening at this very moment. We are not distracted by ruminations on the past or worries about the future, but centered in the here and now. ... It is the point between past and future

Present: existing or occurring now. Also: fully focused on or involved in what one is doing or experiencing.

Past: occurring before and leading up to the time of speaking or writing.

Future: the time or a period of time following the moment of speaking or writing; time regarded as still to come.

The past is not easily forgotten. Those previous experiences shape the present self. It is easy to draw connections between new experiences and past ones, and allow the past to influence the present. The past is known. I have lived it. I know every detail in actuality. There is no doubt as to its occurrence. The future is filled with uncertainty, confusion and doubt. 

Present moment awareness is about separating the self from the past felt experiences and the uncertainty of the future, and seeing the here and now for what is, not seeing our interpretations muddled by thoughts of past and future.

Individual's Sense-Making

Tue Mar 16, 2021 1:58 pm

Individual's sense-making: is the process by which people give meaning to their collective experiences. It has been defined as "the ongoing retrospective development of plausible images that rationalize what people are doing"

Why are we here in the fishbowl? Why are we here on this Earth? 

Rationalize: attempt to explain or justify (one's own or another's behavior or attitude) with logical, plausible reasons, even if these are not true or appropriate

Development: the process of maturing or growing

It is natural to seek rationalization. Constantly looking to understand. But in this exploration for answers, the truth is not always found. Simply put, there is not always an answer or explanation to an event. Sometimes, it just is what it is. It is only through personal development that we can recognize this. The constant search for rationalization or logic in a situation can drive a person mad. It creates falsehoods and excuses. Develop acceptance. Acceptance to take events as they are, without the need to internalize and explanation.

Metaphorical Thinking

Tue Mar 23, 2021 2:00 pm

Metaphorical thinking: is a substitutional mental process in which implicit comparisons are made between qualities of objects which are usually considered in separate classifications.

Implicit: implied though not plainly expressed.

Substitutional: the act, process, or result of replacing one thing for another

There has been much talk about the impression words have on others. They are open to interpretation because of their many meanings. Left to ambiguity, words are implicit, not direct. That is the beauty of the metaphorical thinking process. So many ways to see something, a panopticon where all outer points experience their own interpretation. 

It is the substitutional process that creates this implicit meaning within words. If spoken directly, words have one meaning, one interpretation. “Go to bed”, I tell my kids. They don’t question the meaning. With the slip of the tongue, I tell them it is time for bed, and they no longer scurry off. 

I am here and you are there, but here we are together.

Phenomenology

Fri Apr 02, 2021 11:39 am

Phenomenology: Phenomenology is the philosophical study of the structures of experience and consciousness.

Experience: an event or occurrence that leaves an impression on someone.

Consciousness: the awareness or perception of something by a person.

Life is a series of experiences. Some far more impactful than others, but all experiences are strung together; connected. Consciousness of these experiences is what determines their effect. Often we remain unconscious to what is happening until the experience has passed. Awoken and conscious we can truly understand and see what has occurred. Are you conscious within the fishbowl? Or are you going through the motions? Are you experiencing the effects, or allowing the moments to pass you by? Presence and awareness help guide the conscious to full comprehension of the experience.

Knowledge Workers

 Fri Apr 02, 2021 11:45 am

Knowledge workers are workers whose main capital is knowledge. Examples include programmers, physicians, pharmacists, architects, engineers, scientists, design thinkers, public accountants, lawyers, and academics, whose job is to "think for a living".

Knowledge is an asset. Here to think, not just repeat motions. How do you demonstrate your asset to potential employers? How to prove in a brief moment of time that you are worth the gamble and should be selected for a position. Think ahead, plan. Know. Think critically, problem solve, multitask, we’ve heard it all. Strategize and demonstrate practical application of knowledge, not just regurgitate textbooks set before you.

Vygotsky Language and Thought

“Vygotsky believed that language and thought initially have different roots but converge during the course of development and are influenced bi-directionally thereafter “

Language: the principal method of human communication, consisting of words used in a structured and conventional way and conveyed by speech, writing, or gesture

Thought: an idea or opinion produced by thinking, or occurring suddenly in the mind.

Language is verbal, speech or even gestures. A communication of ideas. Thought it everything in between. Thoughts incited by communication and words. It’s impact solidified. Maybe others can take it from there.

Immaterial Labor

Tue Apr 06, 2021 11:40 am

immaterial labor: "Immaterial labor is an academic term used to describe the affective and cognitive commodities produced by work that exist outside the traditional wage-based consideration of labor as a material-commodity-producing activity, as well as the activity of producing this new form of commodity.

Cognitive: of, relating to, being, or involving conscious intellectual activity (such as thinking, reasoning, or remembering)

Labor: work, especially hard physical work.

Knowledge is immaterial labor. It is intangible, untouchable, but there. In business, knowledge is one of the most, if not the most, important commodity one can contribute. Labor is often thought of as hard physical labor. But it is much more than that. Cognitive labor extends beyond basic knowledge and includes the four characteristics that were explored in “Truth Seekers and Knowledge Workers” (March 10, 2021)

1. Integrated networking structure

2. Dynamic decision-making

3. Adaptive coordination mechanisms

4. Unique innovation capabilities

Anyone can get good grades, pass a test and acquire basic knowledge through school and life. Companies and hiring agents look beyond this. Practical knowledge is simply a basis. They are looking beyond that. Developing and understanding these characteristics are what sets one candidate apart from the rest.

Sat Mar 13, 2021 8:24 pm

Geert Hofstede:

Professor Geert Hofstede conducted one of the most comprehensive studies of how values in the workplace are influenced by culture. He defines culture as “the collective programming of the mind distinguishing the members of one group or category of people from others”.

The Hofstede model of national culture consists of six dimensions. The cultural dimensions represent independent preferences for one state of affairs over another that distinguish countries (rather than individuals) from each other.

The country scores on the dimensions are relative, in that we are all human and simultaneously we are all unique. In other words, culture can only be used meaningfully by comparison. The model consists of the following dimensions:

POWER DISTANCE INDEX (PDI)

This dimension expresses the degree to which the less powerful members of a society accept and expect that power is distributed unequally. The fundamental issue here is how a society handles inequalities among people.

People in societies exhibiting a large degree of Power Distance accept a hierarchical order in which everybody has a place and which needs no further justification. In societies with low Power Distance, people strive to equalize the distribution of power and demand justification for inequalities of power.

INDIVIDUALISM VERSUS COLLECTIVISM (IDV)

The high side of this dimension, called Individualism, can be defined as a preference for a loosely-knit social framework in which individuals are expected to take care of only themselves and their immediate families.

Its opposite, Collectivism, represents a preference for a tightly-knit framework in society in which individuals can expect their relatives or members of a particular ingroup to look after them in exchange for unquestioning loyalty. A society’s position on this dimension is reflected in whether people’s self-image is defined in terms of “I” or “we.”

MASCULINITY VERSUS FEMININITY (MAS)

The Masculinity side of this dimension represents a preference in society for achievement, heroism, assertiveness, and material rewards for success. Society at large is more competitive. Its opposite, Femininity, stands for a preference for cooperation, modesty, caring for the weak, and quality of life. Society at large is more consensus-oriented.

In the business context, Masculinity versus Femininity is sometimes also related to as “tough versus tender” cultures.

UNCERTAINTY AVOIDANCE INDEX (UAI)

The Uncertainty Avoidance dimension expresses the degree to which the members of a society feel uncomfortable with uncertainty and ambiguity. The fundamental issue here is how a society deals with the fact that the future can never be known: should we try to control the future or just let it happen?

Countries exhibiting strong UAI maintain rigid codes of belief and behavior, and are intolerant of unorthodox behavior and ideas. Weak UAI societies maintain a more relaxed attitude in which practice counts more than principles.

LONG TERM ORIENTATION VERSUS SHORT TERM NORMATIVE ORIENTATION (LTO)

Every society has to maintain some links with its own past while dealing with the challenges of the present and the future. Societies prioritize these two existential goals differently.

Societies who score low on this dimension, for example, prefer to maintain time-honored traditions and norms while viewing societal change with suspicion.

Those with a culture that scores high, on the other hand, take a more pragmatic approach: they encourage thrift and efforts in modern education as a way to prepare for the future.

In the business context, this dimension is referred to as “(short-term) normative versus (long-term) pragmatic” (PRA). In the academic environment, the terminology Monumentalism versus Flexhumility is sometimes also used.

INDULGENCE VERSUS RESTRAINT (IVR)

Indulgence stands for a society that allows relatively free gratification of basic and natural human drives related to enjoying life and having fun. Restraint stands for a society that suppresses gratification of needs and regulates it by means of strict social norms.

"In Badiou’s theory, Truth is closely connected to Events. Basically, a Truth is a particular set of statements and discourses which are set off by an Event, and follow from it. A Truth is always the “truth of a particular situation”. It is the truth of the situation because it speaks from or about the excluded part. A Truth is never recognisable by the state of the situation – including the dominant regime of knowledge. However, a Truth is only the truth for its particular situation. It is only the truth because this particular part is currently excluded. Past Truths are not less true than today’s. It is just that today’s truths are more true “for us” – more immediately pressing."

Sanjiv

Subject: about symbols

Hi Everyone,

How are you? When you address the letters in your fishbowls, please refer to incidents from the films you are watching. Look at scenes in the film as episodes, and use them for reference when deconstructing a sentence. Return to the film and mark the episodes out in minutes. 

Your method: You are juxtaposing images (from the films) with text (from letters) and in the act of so doing, you are sharing of yourself; how you see things.

In this letter, we have to understand how symbols work.

The true nature of any symbol is both material and imaginary: concrete reality conveying an unseen truth.

The lion for example symbolizes strength, just as the snake symbolizes cunning and the dove, peace.

The role of the symbol is to bring together and unify. Lion/strength; snake/cunning; dove/peace.

Symbols are a constant requirement, because the individual is made up of both: 

material/imaginary. 

Body/spirit.

Symbols allow us to pass from one to the other by means of an image or of a text.

By uniting body and spirit, symbols make our personal selves whole and allow us to communicate with others. 

As human beings we are both spirit and flesh, “incarnated” spirits, and we live on both levels.

Symbols act as linchpins or hinges and are essential to us.

Signs and symbols refer to a reality which transcends them.

Please interpret the films that are coming up and the ones you have seen in terms of the vocabulary (word-images and symbols) used in these letters.

It will make your understanding deeper and easier.

Sanjiv

SYMBOL, TRANSCEND, INCARNATE, LINCHPIN

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 3/12/2021 13:14:56
Subject: culture as a mental construct (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you this evening? 

Today we must raise fundamental questions regarding culture: 

what is it, 

what is it not, and 

how does it affect behavior?

We agree that cultural differences exist in the workplace and among us. Just look at the fishbowl.

Think of the Japanese Story. These differences are most often noticed in a particular situation, we label them as ’strange’ or different and disregard them because we have no way of classifying these peculiarities into a ‘language of culture.’ 

It is indeed difficult to find a language with which to discuss it or explore its consequences, because culture is about pervasive, deeply held and implicit beliefs and values. 

Culture does not exist in a simple and easily defined form for a specifiable number of people in a bounded area. 

And, obviously, a society does not consist of individuals with entirely uniform mental characteristics or personalities.

Culture is not a ‘thing' which can be experienced directly through the senses, just as ‘social systems’ are not directly tangible or visible. 

They are ideas constructed from within a society. 

What is culture, then:

1. A shared system of meanings 

The culture (like that of the fishbowl) dictates what groups of people pay attention to. It guides how the world is perceived, how the self experienced and how life itself is organized.

Each person carries within them learned ways of finding meaning in their experiences. In order for effective, stable and meaningful interaction to occur, people must have a shared system of meaning. There must be some common ways of understanding events and behavior and ways of anticipating how other people in your social group are likely to behave.

The intended meaning of a gesture need not coincide with the perceived meaning except where cultural identities match. It is only when the meanings do coincide that effective communication can happen.

2. Relative

There is no cultural absolute. People in different cultures perceive the world differently and have different ways of dong things, and there is no set standard for considering one group as intrinsically superior or inferior to any other. Each culture is relative to other cultures’ ways of perceiving the world and doing things.

3. Learned

Culture is derived from your social environment, not from your genetic make-up.

4. Specific to groups

Culture is a collective phenomenon that is about shared values and meanings. 

Geert Hofstede (please google his name and work) describes culture as the ‘collective programming of the mind’ which distinguishes the members of one human group from another. He further explains that culture lies between human nature on the one side and individual personality on the other.

We will be getting into Hofstede’s dimensions of culture next.

What culture is not...

It is not about individual behavior. There are wide variations in individual values and behavior within every culture.

Assignment:

Please watch the film Outsourced. The way to watch the film is to witness each scene as a separate vignette, or episode. In that way, you will be able to share where you stand in the situation you are witnessing. Observation and Interpretation. More on that coming up.

Outsourced is a true story of an American who shows up at a call-center in a small town in India. His dilemma is that he has to survive in his job, if he is to get out of there. How is he going to do it?

Outsourced

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1pFOnJ4i7yBC7AWbzmdR7TlZ_cINUvBMl/view?usp=sharing

Sanjiv

VALUE, BELIEF, COLLECTIVE, PROGRAM

collective programming...mental structures

Date: 3/11/2021 13:33:38
Subject: phenomenology and metaphor (345)

Hi Everyone,

Domain and Boundary

Domain: a specified sphere of activity or knowledge.

Boundary: a limit of a subject or sphere of activity.

While careful selecting the definitions for each word that I found most appropriate to me I noticed something about these two definitions (that I selected) that caught my eye. Both obtained the world "sphere". When one thinks of this word several things come to mind. A ball, the earth, or in my instance of sphere of energy that creates an environment. Whether this be a school, a playing field, or a community in large this type of sphere describes a denoted area of energy with life, love, interaction, and liveliness occurring within it. As a Narragansett native I use to have a teacher who referred to Narragansett as the "bubble" inferring that residents here are protected from the outside world and have a bias perception on reality. While that's a whole another conversation to be had this "bubble" represented a sphere outlining the Narragansett community and everything within. And this "bubble" also featured a boundary (not physical) protecting it's residents from the outside world. 

As you can see here spheres represent areas and boundaries represent the outside of the sphere for which crossing would indicate one's no longer within the sphere. As individuals and learners we possess a sphere (a domain) of knowledge that we encompass making each of us who we are. In order to progress, develop, and change, one must go beyond the boundaries of their sphere to learn. One must explore the unknown and go outside of their comfort zones. Whether this be physically, mentally, or emotionally no progress occurs without variation and introduction to new experience.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 3/11/2021 0:02:30
Subject: cultures are not converging (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? You have to keep going. Entering other structures, other worlds, other vocabularies.

We feel confusion, chaos and stress whenever we experience structures (of text and images) that are new and different.

Many of us are experiencing this in the fishbowl.

The purpose of forthcoming assignments will be to help you come to terms with the importance of cultural differences within organizations and to provide some practical insights and frameworks in order to manage these differences more successfully. 

In the workplace and on our screens, like the fishbowl, we are increasingly having to interact, manage, negotiate and compromise with people from different cultures. 

When you’re operating across several cultures, and you want your postings, philosophies, objectives, products (ideas and insights) and services (sharing of process) to be not only understood but also believed by the viewer, then you must attend to what these things mean to the people in each culture. 

However uniform we make our communications, they will not have the same meaning for individuals from different cultures.

Similarly, social technologies, like matrix structures, reward systems, performance appraisal, empowerment or consultative management, may seem uniform, but will have very different meanings to individuals from different cultures. It all depends on the cultural context.

The essence of culture is not what is visible on the surface. It is the shared way groups of people understand and interpret the world. 

These different interpretations that cultures give to their environment are crucial influences on interactions between people working and managing across cultures.

Bottom line: cultures are not converging.

Sanjiv

ATTEND, COMPROMISE, INTERPRET, DIFFERENCE, NAVIGATE, NEGOTIATE

from the fishbowl...

Date: 3/10/2021 15:30:03
Subject: truth seekers and knowledge workers
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? To post something in the fishbowl is a challenge because our process is a “truth-seeking” one. 

My particular challenge is to make it as simple as possible for you, because that's what it is: simple.

This time, we are “truth-seeking” the ‘characteristics' essential for setting up an enterprise successfully in a global society. 

In their book Managing Across Borders, Christopher Bartlett of Harvard Business School and Sumantra Ghoshal of INSEAD assert that "businesses need to organize themselves in a dramatically different way if they are to survive in a global society."

Bartlett and Ghoshal’s central argument is that successful businesses must become what the authors call a 'transnational corporation.' Such an organization has the following characteristics according to their research findings:

Integrated networking structure

Dynamic decision-making

Adaptive coordination mechanisms

Unique innovation capabilities

“Each of these characteristics implies a sophisticated understanding of and ability to manage successfully cultural differences.” (Lisa Hoecklin, "Managing Cultural Differences” p.52).

You may google these authors 

any time, and 

learn what they have to say. 

However, in the fishbowl, 

we want to experience these 4 characteristics for ourselves, 

in the now, in the present moment and,

(consequently) 

with a confident flip, 

make ourselves The Tellers and not The Told, 

when it comes to talking about the characteristics of successful global enterprises.

Please keep your experience in mind.

II.

First characteristic: Integrated networking structure

1. We are truth-seekers. 

We start from a structure and step into the unknown.

We don’t know the outcome.

We are Explorers and Discoverers 

of Mental Structures; 

that is us. 

2. The starting sentence structure provides the domain we are operating in.

Construct your domain: a word-pool. 

Gather words that symbolize, in this instance,

 

integrate 

network 

structure

It is the circle, 

the boundary of discourse. 

The limits of perception.

3. Re-structure opening structure

Select and substitute original elements

Stay within domain

Create an axiom, an adage, an abstraction

Individual's sense-making (google)

4. Felt Experience

subjective

past occurrence

happening

“It happened to me too” (Sandy in Japanese Story)

anecdotal

first person

feeling experienced

circumstantial

unverifiable

describe in one short paragraph

it has to “fit” the re-structure

critical to knowing abstract/real

There are six more steps that will follow.

In all it doesn’t take more than 45 mts. 

 

Another film also coming up.

From Strictly Ballroom to Kinky Boots.

The Society of the Spectacle

by Hannah Veltry

Tue Mar 09, 2021 3:37 pm

“You are sharing what you deciphered by posting in the fishbowl.

How do you see (image) the word?

How do you feel (emotion) about this word?”

Image: a visual representation of something

Emotion: a natural instinctive state of mind deriving from one's circumstances, mood, or relationships with others.

Images are seen with the eyes. Emotion is felt with the heart. Images insight emotion, and emotion insights (mental) images. To decipher (interpret), one must separate the images and the emotions. But the learning takes place when you connect the two back together. What are they as individuals and what are they as a unit? Disengage the feeling to understand, but re-engage to spark thought and deeper meaning.

 Mon Mar 08, 2021 11:20 pm

"The conversation among individuals must be self-referential, for it creates the possibility of being internally motivated."

Conversation/Internal

CONVERSATION: chat, colloquy, converse, dialogue, discourse, discussion, exchange

INTERNAL: inner, inside, interior, inward, inmost, innermost

When there are self-referential elements in a discussion between people, it allows the people to express their innermost thoughts.

I am learning more about this as I study the craft of working with actors as a film director. Actors are very vulnerable because they are channeling deep-rooted emotions into a performance to portray a character with honest humanity. To help bring this emotion out and protect the actor as well, you must build trust. You do this by having private conversations with them about the emotional arc of their character, and by being willing to become vulnerable yourself. Sharing your own relevant stories and emotions is the technique. This opens the door for the actor to access their inner emotions as well.

AlyssaBotelho

Mon Mar 08, 2021 11:35 pm

"We must "recognize that the things that motivate, inspire and generate commitment depend on each individual’s culture of origin.""

MOTIVATE/ORIGIN

Motivate: arouse, encourage, excite, fire (up), impassion, incite, instigate, move, pique, provoke, rev (up), spark, spur, stimulate, stir

Origin: cradle, font, fountain, fountainhead, root, seedbed, source, spring, well, wellspring, germ, root, seed

Like a flower, the soil that we grow in affects the way we develop and determines the kind of flower we'll be later in life.

So much of who we are is cultivated by the culture we are raised in. The things that impassion us, excite us, drive us can be found in the environment around us. I have always lived in an artistic community. My mom got me a library card at 2 weeks old and I spent countless days at the library growing up. I am now a writer/director pursuing a career in the film industry. Of course I didn't realize it at the time, but my environment affected my choices. This is just one small example of how culture has impacted the person I am today.

Date: 3/8/2021 20:01:12
Subject: costs of cultural mismanagement (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? We are going to take a bite out of “cultural studies.” It is worthy of your scrutiny and consideration. 

Cultural mismanagement costs the world billions of dollars in wealth, finance and lives.

There is extraordinary interdependence across cultures.

Differences among us are not going away, they are here to stay and are entrenched.

The cost of not understanding differences is getting greater and greater.

The difference among us is in the way we view the world.

The way we structure things perceptually. 

How we see things is closely identified with how we think. 

He thought she was hot.

Clearly Hiromitsu and Sandy had different structures when they met.

They are both excellent actors as you saw. Hiromitsu is the Brad Pitt of Japan, if you know what I mean (about structures).

Internationally knowledgeable companies with big names and techniques about cultural management, often have "great difficulty recognizing that the things that motivate, inspire and generate commitment depend on each individual’s culture of origin." 

I mean when you enter the fishbowl, you surely have a culture of origin. We must "recognize that the things that motivate, inspire and generate commitment depend on each individual’s culture of origin." 

When we consider cultures of origin into account, then that means different structures or separate categories or ‘modes’ of thought.

At birth, we each enter the world and, every encounter thereafter, with a pre-narrative; a culture of origin; a pre-structure, a vocabulary.

In Japanese Story, opposing attributes (structures) of west and east are made visible and are in conflict.

 

Sandy: objective, analytical, logical, consistent, impersonal, absolute and intellectual.

Hiromitsu: subjective, synthetic, non-logical, inconsistent, personal, relative and emotional.

In sum, value differences between the east and west can be seen in terms of the logical and scientific versus the instinctive and subjective. The rigid distinction between rationality and non-rationality is unique to the West whereas in the Japanese word omoi, both elements are integrated and indistinguishable. 

It is for this reason that one must proceed one word at a time, as did Sandy and Hiromitsu. Only at first, until trust and friendship are established. After that, differences don’t matter. You can do anything together, as you saw getting out of the dessert, I mean desert.

Sanjiv

Date: 3/8/2021 14:28:05
Subject: self-referential conversation
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? We have bifurcated society (345) and culture (448) but our learning process remains, not only common, but universally true.

We self-reflect on the past. (Interpretation)

We act in the present. (Focus)

We believe in the future. (Visualize).

The above three statements are not from a book. They are mental activities. In the act of writing them, I fulfill them. Karissa Rovella in her postings does the same.

Whenever you do that, you succeed in getting the attention of your audience. Indeed, in my experience, you succeed every time. Sincerity and Authenticity are its hallmarks.

It is not difficult. It is self-referential. The motivation is not money, but internal satisfaction. 

The conversation among individuals must be self-referential, for it creates the possibility of being internally motivated.

Sanjiv

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. 

I have been shunning zoom meetings, so I can pursue learning at full throttle during this period.

We learn through reflection. That is, after you have read, seen or experienced something, you learn from it upon reflection. 

Our learning is when we think about it later and, abstract from it.

We are students of life.

Sandy and Hiromitsu in Japanese Story survived, in my opinion, because they were both self-reflective.

They were both doing what we are doing in the fishbowl: attending to meaning.

If you were Baird or the CEO, what would you do to prevent the “incident” from happening?

1. First, you would make everyone in your office AWARE that we differ in social behavior and assumptions.

2. We have to learn to KNOW our differences from each other.

3. We have to learn SKILLS to communicate across our differences.

The logical sequence of awareness of differences, knowledge of differences, and skills to bridge these differences is the basis of your workbook in the syllabus.

If you can access the book, go through the exercises.

If not, then please pay particular attention to the films and my letters. My letters talk in abstract terms, and the films link you to the visual and contextual. 

More on this later.

We will soon get into dimensions and start doing specific exercises. You have the process down by now.

Please see Abigail Alvarez’ posting below. It is an example of cultural awareness through self-reflection. Hiromitsu achieved this as seen in the photograph where he is smiling with his friend Sandy.

Date: 3/6/2021 15:40:57
Subject: inflection point (MGT345)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well. I miss you in the fishbowl. 

When asked to hold the thread, stay engaged, and be inspired, he raised his hand and quietly asked, for what purpose? 

If he eats right, exercises daily, reads constantly, respects elders, says his prayers and has a good night’s sleep, then what thread, engagement and inspiration does he need in a world that is visual and virtual? In such a world, what is the individual's purpose?

To reply, you could reflect upon a text and your personal experience, and say that “connectivity” is the purpose. In other words, you developed your own point-of-view; you came to your own conclusion. To lead a meaningful, reflective and experiential life, we have to learn to first develop and then share our points-of-view. More to come on this.

We’re at an inflection point in our trajectory of thoughts in 345. But here I want to highlight grades and homework assignments. We have removed the uncertainty of grades from the picture, I trust. No one gets below a B. The grade distribution moves upwards from there. I have communicated this earlier. The real competition is between A- and A. We are visible to each other in a community.

I am reproducing a portion of your syllabus that highlights grade distribution. Most of it will be familiar, and we are practicing it. We will be getting into the characteristics of transnational organizations next. We will learn experientially as to what these characteristics mean. There will be a rubric of 10 steps that will be used. Nothing outside what you are already doing.

Letters will continue, as we follow abstract ideas that lead us to unknown paths.

If things continue to look confusing or lacking structure, please don’t stress about it, so long as you are listening to what I am saying. That translates into doing what I am asking you to do. Furthermore, you’re not being asked to do it right/wrong or good/bad; just do it, period. Never difficult, and always taking your circumstances into account. 

Sanjiv

from the syllabus... 

VIII. GRADE: DISTRIBUTION

1. Transnational Organizations 40%

Four characteristics of successful transnational organizations have been identified by empirical research, viz., Integrated Networking Structures, Complex Adaptive Systems, Dynamic Decision-Making and Unique Innovative Capabilities. This is an interactive exercise done in your fishbowls where you learn experientially by performing each of the characteristics.

2. Deep Reading: Concepts, Images, Perspectives: 20%

You are developing slower and essential cognitive processes such as critical thinking, reflection, and empathy—-all parts of deep reading. What you read, how you read, and why you read what you read changes how you think. The quality of your reading is not only an index of the quality of your thought, it is the best-known path to developing whole new path-ways.

3. Deconstructing Letters: 20%

The act of taking on the perspective and feelings of others is communication effected in solitude and depicts an intimate emotional dimension within the Fishbowl experience. Through analogies, drawing inferences, and arriving at independent judgments, you learn to deconstruct text and thereby generate feelings and experiences.

4. Final: Your Visual Reality and Network Society: 20%

An experiential exercise in Visual Reality and the Network Society: “looking at yourself looking at yourself.”

IX. FINALLY: INDIVIDUATION 

Individuation, or the way you distinguish yourself from others, is always in relationship and it is a process. Individuation makes awareness, action and evaluation possible. 

At the end of the day, after it is all said and done, your grade is determined by two things: level of engagement and, creation of value. How often, how much and to what end did you develop and individuate yourself? 

To address that, you are expected to post regularly under the following Topic heads in your Fishbowl:

1. Notes: Taking and Making 

2. Vocabulary: Concepts and Word-images

3. Reading and Deconstructing Text 

4. Four Interactive Assignments

Being in touch with words. What does that mean, he asked.

The internet has made it possible that a single selected word can have the power to impact our lives.

Is it Red or Green?

Is it IN or OUT?

She refused to divulge against all odds.

Thumbs UP, you made it.

Thumbs DOWN, you die.

We are in a Gladiators' Arena.

We are a Catwalk

(What will she wear this time, I wondered.)

We are a Roundtable

(Knights in Armor: blue jeens and white t-shirts)

A Play Pen or a Fishbowl

We are a Chess Board.

These are metaphors, images, symbols, but always words.

In the beginning is indeed the word.

We lead metaphorical lives, you must have heard that said.

We lead symbolic lives. What does it mean?

It means that we create our living realities through a process of selecting words.

Here’s one, aka The Fishbowl During A Pandemic, and I quote:

“There’s a new and virulent cultural virus ripping through the world. The symptoms of those infected include attacks of optimism, strong feelings of community, lowered stress levels and outbreaks of pronoia: the sneaking feeling that someone is conspiring behind their backs to help them.” Jules Marshall

II.

'Present moment awareness’ (please google the term) is the technique and goal of the fishbowl. 

In the fishbowl, (every time you post, say your vocabulary) you learn to be fully aware and respectful of your own inner state while being present with other people. 

In this way, you are learning to let go of old relational habits and the self-limiting beliefs that lead you to them. 

Words evoke Emotions and, instead of being overwhelmed by them, make them a guide to who you are and what you need from life. 

As you begin to respect your feeelings and perceptions as valid, you realize you are free to live your life in a way that naturally flows from who you are. You become yourself.

Please see Nora Dougherty’s posting as an example of working her text. The doing is a practice and it is far easier than it looks or sounds. I hope you realize that by now. Be a Pro and take charge.

Sanjiv

"Selection and Calibration of words.”

Selection - (N) the action or fact of carefully choosing someone or something as being the best or most suitable.

Calibration - (N) the action or process of calibrating an instrument or experimental readings.

Selection and calibration go hand and hand when it comes to choosing words and word structures. The selection of words is important to form impactful sentences and phrases. One word is selected and you can then use calibration in order to create a nice flowing sentence structure. 

Calibrate

mark (a gauge or instrument) with a standard scale of readings: the depth gauge is calibrated in centimeters. 

• correlate the readings of (an instrument) with those of a standard in order to check the instrument's accuracy: a separate control experiment is then carried out to calibrate the calorimeter. 

• adjust (experimental results) to take external factors into account or to allow comparison with other data: the radiocarbon results would need to be calibrated to convert them to calendar ages. 

• carefully assess, set, or adjust (something abstract): the regulators cannot properly calibrate the risks involved. 

correlate, adjust, assess

"We are Reflexive and Thought Leaders."

- Reflexive - denoting a pronoun that refers back to the subject of the clause in which it is used, e.g. myself, themselves.

Reflexive words show that the person who does the action is also the person who is affected by it: In the sentence "She prides herself on doing a good job," "prides" is a reflexive verb, and "herself" is a reflexive pronoun.

- thought - an idea or opinion produced by thinking, or occurring suddenly in the mind.

- leaders - the person who leads or commands a group, organization, or country.

Pictures:

1. selecting the word: being communal

2. self-reflexivity: being authentic

3. Society of the Spectacle (Guy Debord)

Letter: Lacing your shoes (345)

DELEUZE:

-Gilles Deleuze was a French philosopher

-Considered himself a metaphysician.

-Metaphysics: the branch of philosophy that examines the fundamental nature of reality, including the relationship between mind and matter, between substance and attribute, and between potentiality and actuality

-He claimed that all identities are effects of difference.

Letter: Idiom and Lexicon

Jan 27, 2021

INDRA'S NET:

-Buddhist philosophy.

- A metaphor used to illustrate the interpenetration, inter-causality, and interbeing of all things.

- Interpenetration: mix or merge together.

- Inter-causality: is the interaction between different causes and their simultaneous effects on results.

- Interbeing: (Buddhist belief) recognizes the dependence of any one person or thing as to all other people and objects.

- "Everything contains everything else."

Wed Mar 03, 2021 6:08 pm

Letter: Fishbowl technology being repaired

Feb 2, 2021

ALDOUS HUXLEY:

-Writer and philosopher

-His most famous novel is "Brave New World": a dystopian social science fiction novel.

-Dystopian: relating to or denoting an imagined state or society where there is great suffering or injustice.

- The government of Brave New World retains control by making its citizens so happy and superficially fulfilled that they don't care about their personal freedom.

LUCE IRIGARAY:

-French philosopher and cultural theorist

-Breathing with Luce Irigaray: a spiritual shift in human awareness to the needs of the other figured through breathing

-"As a way to connect body and spirit, self and other, nature and culture, and East and West, breathing emerges as the significant theological and philosophical gesture of our time."

"TO BE TWO":

-Luce Irigaray's take on the feminist redefinition of Being and Identity.

-Identity can be created or discovered, in relation to others.

OTHER/OTHERNESS:

-The result of a dominant in-group constructing one or many out-groups by stigmatizing a difference, real or imagined, presented as a negotiation of identity and thus a motive for potential discrimination.

SYLLABI: MGT345 & MGT448: An introduction to the class with emphasis on being flexible, working in, and understanding the ever-changing environment around us. COVID is compared to “carrying a bunch of bags up a hill and not knowing how long you had to go” as we still don’t know when a “normal” will return, so the class has been designed to be a mode of open communication, rather than cause a great amount of stress. Through metaphor, we are told to take it slowly in the first few weeks to get used to the class. 

Lacing your shoes (345): As we go through the course it will make more sense through more letters, text we write, and text our peers write. By the end of the semester we will aim to have grown through these texts, especially in finding ourselves. Here we are compared to Deleuze to master the art of taking on new and different challenges to be constructive in what we are doing. In a digital world, we need to be able to express ourselves in a way to be seen and heard through our words. We are told to “hold our horses” aka be patient. We are said to be “climbing a rope” instead of “sliding a slope” which shows we are on a slow, steady incline to be building up to the end where we will look back and see how much we grew. “When the dust settles” refers to after the first few weeks of figuring out what we are doing to then go to the fishbowl. The final metaphor, “working side by side, shoulder to shoulder” says we are all in this together, and we are all doing the same work, and are going to get through the course with each other. 

Trilogy: “The stragglers are still trickling in” as before the drop add period ends there are slowly but surely more people entering the two classes. However, this is out of our control so “don’t sweat it,” or don’t worry about it. The larger idea of the fishbowl is to interact with our classmates, particularly those in our group to create a “culture” and communication around the letters. Because we can see each other's posts it is like a fishbowl, clear. We can see the fish, the fish can see us, just as each other’s writings. Eyes looking at eyes can be our own eyes staring at someone else's eyes on the other side of the fishbowl, or it can be our eyes staring at the fish’s eyes and vise versa. Write honestly and truthfully, and see where it takes you. 

Idiom and Lexicon: To begin with “this too shall pass” shows we are almost there in learning about the fishbowl and what it entails. We will know what to do soon, just as the early years of high school and elementary school seem very overwhelming, and confusing but eventually puts us on a track of where we are supposed to be. We will soon be in growth mode for the fishbowl just as after WWII. As we continue to grow and go into the real world, we will carry with us images that define us, as well as the words to describe them specifically creating who we are. We are often entering new things, which are fun and exciting, but it takes us a while to open up sometimes and get to know people. In contrast it can take a very short time for us to leave. While we are all watching each other, we are doing so as equals, not one is an actor, nor the other an audience. The vocabulary will help us to be able to get our point across in the best way possible. We can use it as needed (tools) or to make what we are saying sound better (jewelry). Practicing vocabulary will help to portray yourself and your thoughts through words. 

Re: Apology for Jumping the Gun: Explains the fishbowl and how it is set up. The professor did not mean to “jump the gun” as we are slowly building up to completing the fishbowl. All we can do is to get ready, or “sharpen our pencils.” The letters will hold different meanings based on our experience and how we interpret the words. 

The desire to learn and genesis of the fishbowl: Each of the parts of our mental, physical, emotional, and spiritual health are all intertwined. They affect each other both positively and negatively, as well as working together to form each of us individually. Through the fishbowl when we are working with others, presenting ourselves through text, and actively creating the environment that is the fishbowl, we are learning. The fishbowl is something that we slowly create together, to create the society or culture we desire. 

Fishbowl is set up: Basic instructions on how to set up the fishbowl. 

Fishbowl technology being repaired: Although there was a technological error, that is not the main subject of focus for the fishbowl. Rather it is how to make do in difficult situations, and make the best of them. This was explained in Aldous Huxley’s “Brave New World” when he discusses surviving a scary, dystopian world. It is about adapting to situations and overcoming them. To be most successful, we need to come to the fishbowl with an open mind, as explained in Luce Irigaray’s book To Be Two, which explains her process of reconstructing the women’s image. Men and women must mutually learn from each other, as they each have different perspectives. 

The fishbowl is on. Please register: More information on the fishbowl and what is expected of us. Continue practicing vocabulary.

Setting up 4 Topics in your fishbowl: Although we have thus far been “peering in the dark,” or trying to see what is ahead with very little information, we will soon be using the fishbowl. However, peeing in the dark has a bad connotation, so we are “standing on a diving board of a swimming pool” as that sounds much more exciting, and our fishbowl is going to be exciting. We are going to come together through the fishbowl and work with each other in the four categories listed in the letter. 

Being in the fishbowl: We have to work together to balance this course among otters, the level of participation in the fishbowl with our other responsibilities. Once this is achieved, we are most successful. Once again, the text we are creating is to be able to portray what we wish to portray through our words. We can describe specific images of what we are thinking with our words. Although there are four categories in the fishbowl, they are all intertwined, they relate to each other and depend on each other. Although we are all posting about the same topics, we will have different interpretations that we can learn from with each other. 

Google searches: co-existing visually: We are “inching forward,” or slowly getting the semester started. But once we better understand the fish bowl, we will be able to move forward much quicker, with leaps and bounds. It is compared to the Matrix, as if the professor is including how we are acting. By being told what to google, it is influencing the meaning we take away from the letters and the class. The metaphors are meant to stick with us, something that we can remember the ideas by. We should propose different and new ideas to continue allowing the conversation to flow. 

Surviving thus far: In this changing world, the wants of employers has also been changing. We need to be flexible and able to adapt in new environments. The fishbowl will help us do just that. In the fishbowl, the professor will be watching each of us closely. However, we are both looking at each other mutually, it is not one-sided.

erintorgersen

 Fri Feb 05, 2021 4:26 pm

Sorting, sifting and selecting: We are told to be “polishing our shoes, steer clear from complexity, and press on” for now. This can be taken as getting ready, and preparing, keeping things simple (emphasised by the KISS principle mentioned later on), and continuing on in what we are doing through the fishbowl and course. For the fishbowl, we want to keep it very short but have impactful meanings. We should be carefully choosing the perfect words to explain what we are describing. We now have a more direct differentiation between the categories in the fishbowl, but that could only be found after we analyzed, learned, and prepared through more letters as the Fishbowl is a work-in-process. This is similar to Alain Badiou. He, as a philosopher, could not contain himself to one category, and neither should we in our work or in the fishbowl. 

Grades and Letters: Although those who do the vocabulary will succeed in learning new words, that is not enough. It is necessary to think of the vocabulary in its context. Therefore, while it is helpful to know the meaning of a word, it is not enough. One must also know how to use it to make it effective. Similarly, one cannot just be healthy by eating vegetables, they must also be put to work through exercise, and other healthy living activities. In this letter Derrida is relevant as he studied the connection between experience and consciousness. Each of us will, because of our experience and consciousness, will have slightly different interpretations of the letters. However, this will stimulate the sharing of ideas and communication to make the class more interesting.

erintorgersen

 Mon Feb 08, 2021 12:22 pm

Developing a practice and a process: We are slowly building the fishbowl by creating more information and analysis. We are asked to think about what we would do if we were to create a big business of learners. What would the format be? How would we attract customers, or learners. The point is, we should each be learning something new everyday, big or small. We should first reflect how we as the individual learns, and how it may compare to other individuals. We are all individual thinkers, and we are creating an individual identity as learners. The fishbowl is giving us an opportunity to learn through action in what we are doing rather than just in class taking notes. Through each posting, we are changing the trajectory of the fishbowl, and ideas in line with Alain Badiou’s ‘Event’. Through the fishbowl, we are creating the direction of our learning by what we post, how we interpret letters, and what others post. 

Wondering on a gloomy Sunday morning: The professor is trying to understand how we are feeling about the fishbowl, and how it can be a better or worse process for us. In the fishbowl, we can compare ourselves to others. We can compare our learning techniques, similarities, and differences between us and the others in the fishbowl. We are also learning from ourselves when we construct our own profile in the fishbowl, and how we form analyses in the fishbowl. Then, through the peripheral vision, or what is not in our immediate direct vision, which is our group, we are still learning. The peripheral vision influences our thoughts and how we analyze the letters. We are creating our own learning journey that is influenced by the others in our group. 

Metaphorical thinking: We are using metaphors in the letters to relate them to our own lives and better understand the world around us in an imaginative way, that may not be immediately obvious. The metaphors we take away from the letters are how we can understand things in our own lives, and better understand them.

erintorgersen

Tue Feb 09, 2021 2:18 pm

Interrelation between two words: We are now really starting to get into the exciting part of the fishbowl, as we have prepared to begin the fishbowl (our journey), and now we are officially on our way; but we are still slow moving. We are creating value in our discussions of the letters. The fishbowl is like an arena because it gives us a chance to show off our skills through words and writings. Through the toolbox of our words we are acknowledging how we can best showcase our skills. In the fishbowl we can put two words up against each other side by side to see how they compare to each other, and analyze them together fully. The words can be related to each other, just as the categories of the fishbowl.

erintorgersen

 Wed Feb 10, 2021 3:06 pm

Constructing Knowledge/Creating Knowing: The Fishbowl is a method of learning that is breaking away from the typical curriculum, and all of the constraints that are entailed with it. We can better connect with each other as well as showcase our differences through the method of the fishbowl. The fishbowl, unlike the regimented curriculum, allows us to be ourselves as an individual without being bound to significant restrictions. Being ourselves as individuals and connecting with other individuals is one of the best parts about the fishbowl. If we allow our thoughts and identities to be changed by society and those around us, we will lose our sense of identity, and we will lose ourselves. We will simply become a part of the crowd with our soul and identity lost forever, just as the women alluded to at the end of the letter.

Be a Thought Leader: Today, we live in a materialistic world where people think to be happiest, they have to have as many things as they can get. However, that is not the case, thoughts are much more valuable. Thoughts are what are going to help us to grow and be the best we can be, not things. We can use our thoughts to be just as, if not more influential than using things by being a thought leader. However, it is not just learning that can help you be a better person, but you also have to be open to such learning, and mentally prepared. In the business, this is crucial. One must be able to learn, but to learn, one must first be open to new ideas. All too often, we are in a situation where we can and should be learning; however, we are not, only because of the state of mind we are in, which is not open. We are using the fishbowl to satisfy other’s learning. While we may not be successful in the exact format immediately, we are learning along the way of how to help others learn from us. 

The fishbowl: We are using the fishbowl to create similar meanings in different ways. The different ways we express these meanings we have are how we differentiate between each other, and in our postings. Through watching each other (eyes watching eyes), and constructing our own posts, we are creating meaning and learning. When we strip words down to their literal meaning, we are taking away from learning. Leaving room for interpretation fosters learning. We cannot separate words fully and not pay attention to their meaning and use. Rather, we are learning through interpretation in the fishbowl.
