SYLLABI: MGT345 & MGT448: An introduction to the class with emphasis on being flexible, working in, and understanding the ever-changing environment around us. COVID is compared to “carrying a bunch of bags up a hill and not knowing how long you had to go” as we still don’t know when a “normal” will return, so the class has been designed to be a mode of open communication, rather than cause a great amount of stress. Through metaphor, we are told to take it slowly in the first few weeks to get used to the class. 

Lacing your shoes (345): As we go through the course it will make more sense through more letters, text we write, and text our peers write. By the end of the semester we will aim to have grown through these texts, especially in finding ourselves. Here we are compared to Deleuze to master the art of taking on new and different challenges to be constructive in what we are doing. In a digital world, we need to be able to express ourselves in a way to be seen and heard through our words. We are told to “hold our horses” aka be patient. We are said to be “climbing a rope” instead of “sliding a slope” which shows we are on a slow, steady incline to be building up to the end where we will look back and see how much we grew. “When the dust settles” refers to after the first few weeks of figuring out what we are doing to then go to the fishbowl. The final metaphor, “working side by side, shoulder to shoulder” says we are all in this together, and we are all doing the same work, and are going to get through the course with each other. 

Trilogy: “The stragglers are still trickling in” as before the drop add period ends there are slowly but surely more people entering the two classes. However, this is out of our control so “don’t sweat it,” or don’t worry about it. The larger idea of the fishbowl is to interact with our classmates, particularly those in our group to create a “culture” and communication around the letters. Because we can see each other's posts it is like a fishbowl, clear. We can see the fish, the fish can see us, just as each other’s writings. Eyes looking at eyes can be our own eyes staring at someone else's eyes on the other side of the fishbowl, or it can be our eyes staring at the fish’s eyes and vise versa. Write honestly and truthfully, and see where it takes you. 

Idiom and Lexicon: To begin with “this too shall pass” shows we are almost there in learning about the fishbowl and what it entails. We will know what to do soon, just as the early years of high school and elementary school seem very overwhelming, and confusing but eventually puts us on a track of where we are supposed to be. We will soon be in growth mode for the fishbowl just as after WWII. As we continue to grow and go into the real world, we will carry with us images that define us, as well as the words to describe them specifically creating who we are. We are often entering new things, which are fun and exciting, but it takes us a while to open up sometimes and get to know people. In contrast it can take a very short time for us to leave. While we are all watching each other, we are doing so as equals, not one is an actor, nor the other an audience. The vocabulary will help us to be able to get our point across in the best way possible. We can use it as needed (tools) or to make what we are saying sound better (jewelry). Practicing vocabulary will help to portray yourself and your thoughts through words. 

Re: Apology for Jumping the Gun: Explains the fishbowl and how it is set up. The professor did not mean to “jump the gun” as we are slowly building up to completing the fishbowl. All we can do is to get ready, or “sharpen our pencils.” The letters will hold different meanings based on our experience and how we interpret the words. 

The desire to learn and genesis of the fishbowl: Each of the parts of our mental, physical, emotional, and spiritual health are all intertwined. They affect each other both positively and negatively, as well as working together to form each of us individually. Through the fishbowl when we are working with others, presenting ourselves through text, and actively creating the environment that is the fishbowl, we are learning. The fishbowl is something that we slowly create together, to create the society or culture we desire. 

Fishbowl is set up: Basic instructions on how to set up the fishbowl. 

Fishbowl technology being repaired: Although there was a technological error, that is not the main subject of focus for the fishbowl. Rather it is how to make do in difficult situations, and make the best of them. This was explained in Aldous Huxley’s “Brave New World” when he discusses surviving a scary, dystopian world. It is about adapting to situations and overcoming them. To be most successful, we need to come to the fishbowl with an open mind, as explained in Luce Irigaray’s book To Be Two, which explains her process of reconstructing the women’s image. Men and women must mutually learn from each other, as they each have different perspectives. 

The fishbowl is on. Please register: More information on the fishbowl and what is expected of us. Continue practicing vocabulary.

Setting up 4 Topics in your fishbowl: Although we have thus far been “peering in the dark,” or trying to see what is ahead with very little information, we will soon be using the fishbowl. However, peeing in the dark has a bad connotation, so we are “standing on a diving board of a swimming pool” as that sounds much more exciting, and our fishbowl is going to be exciting. We are going to come together through the fishbowl and work with each other in the four categories listed in the letter. 

Being in the fishbowl: We have to work together to balance this course among otters, the level of participation in the fishbowl with our other responsibilities. Once this is achieved, we are most successful. Once again, the text we are creating is to be able to portray what we wish to portray through our words. We can describe specific images of what we are thinking with our words. Although we are all posting about the same topics, we will have different interpretations that we can learn from with each other.

This is similar to Alain Badiou. He, as a philosopher, could not contain himself to one category, and neither should we in our work or in the fishbowl. 

Grades and Letters: Although those who do the vocabulary will succeed in learning new words, that is not enough. It is necessary to think of the vocabulary in its context. Therefore, while it is helpful to know the meaning of a word, it is not enough. One must also know how to use it to make it effective. Similarly, one cannot just be healthy by eating vegetables, they must also be put to work through exercise, and other healthy living activities. In this letter Derrida is relevant as he studied the connection between experience and consciousness. Date: 2/16/2021 0:26:56
Subject: power of words
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? Brian Castle’s posting below is inspiring for a simple reason: it is a felt-experience. Of course, it also has to do with the choice of his two words: overwhelm and resist.

A felt-experience is a story expressed within a context and to an invisible audience.

How does one create and express a felt-experience that inspires the unknown reader; the viewer in the stalls?

Good question, he said.

The word ‘resistance' resonates during the experience of the pandemic. It’s selection began with a feeling. 

"For me, these words closely align to formulate two fazes of my day today. Being extremely overwhelmed and anxious today, I came to the realization that I need to resist these feelings and get down to work. The ability to not be affected, or the refusal to accept and comply to my anxiety and a state of being overwhelmed is what got me through today.” (Castle, B., spring21, Fishbowl)

Words are concepts.

They are also symbols that evoke feelings.

They are images and metaphors.

Sanjiv is a Dawg.

We evolve, develop and grow through words.

We do both, create and solve our problems with words.

Words get us in trouble and they get us out of trouble.

We construct structures with words, which create spaces of felt-experiences.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QYcXTlGLUgE

Social and cultural theory has recently taken a "spatial turn” (place/space)---using geographical concepts and metaphors to think about the currently complex and differentiated world. We will look at a range of visionary theorists during the course of the semester.

Sanjiv

RESONATE, INSPIRE, EVOKE

from the fishbowl...

Mon Feb 15, 2021 6:28 pm

1. Overwhelming, resistance

overwhelming=

1.

adjective

very great in amount.

Resistance=

noun

1.

the refusal to accept or comply with something; the attempt to prevent something by action or argument.

"she put up no resistance to being led away"

2.

the ability not to be affected by something, especially adversely.

"some of us have a lower resistance to cold than others"

For me, these words closely align to formulate two fazes of my day today. Being extremely overwhelmed and anxious today, I came to the realization that I need to resist these feelings and get down to work. The ability to to not be affected, or the refusal to accept and comply to my anxiety and a state of being overwhelmed is what got me through today.

Hi Everyone,

How are you today? I got an email from Chris Ferrigno and am taking my reply to him as an example of what is required of us, as we begin the process of constructing structures. There is a lot of freedom. However, we are only able to experience this freedom and creativity whenever we immerse ourselves in text and images.

Only what you post in your fishbowls will be evaluated. Please keep that in mind. I am hoping that this letter will clarify any doubts as to how to approach the letters. You are pairing two words and setting upon a journey. That is all. Take the first step. After that it is a breeze. I will be sending you assignments next. from the fishbowl... 

Dear Chris,

Thank you for your response below. I quote, 

I picked the words feeling and experience because I feel they are connected in the idea that we remember good or bad experiences better by how strong the feeling of that experience was. 

This is well done. To be honest with you, I find your reflection, your structure, and your sentence and your selection of two words to be quite extraordinary. Thank-you. Your sentence structure brings the element of ‘strength' to light by your insight; that is your working the text.

But to address your original email and any distress you might be having, here’s what I am suggesting to you and to the class: whenever you wish to focus on a text...

1. Select any two words, as you have, Feeling and Experience (from the letter, paragraph or sentence on hand). Do it as a practice. Otherwise, what is the point of reading?

2. Your purpose, at the back of your head, is to create a structure of words (sentence) originating from these two words that you have selected and, your structure will be of use to the viewer, reader, customer, etc. Your audience. We’ll soon be talking about structures and mental spaces.

3. We are developing a rubric and a practice, visible to all. It is known as Performative Writing and Performative Inquiry. Please google those terms.

4. So I did, and here’s what I found regarding performative inquiry: it is a different kind of learning that becomes possible when we release ourselves from our expectations, and surrender to that which arrives on the page. Like right here. The here and now.

5. "Performative inquiry performs writing as performative explorations interweaving narratives of singular moments of lived experience and reflection into performative texts of learning, breath by breath.”

6. "Performative writing as scholarly writing abandons conventional academic text, dispels third person detachment, interrupts linearity, avoids the explanatory, the expected. Performative writing mischievously plays with space, time, form, metaphor, writing knowing, and not knowing into presence, making visible the gaps between. Performative writing is evocative, acoustic, poetic, performative, inviting recognition, resonance, and understanding through the imagination, listening, meaning making and active participation embodied in the presence of the reader.”

7. Coming back on track: I looked up the dictionary meaning of Feeling and Experience and was inundated with words (ideas), and I wanted to keep it simple for the sake of clarity. So, I looked up the word Feel instead of Feeling and constructed the following ideas (words), known as a word-pool:

8.

Feel

1 to feel touch, texture 

2 to perceive, sense, detect, discern, make out, notice, observe, identify; be aware of, be conscious of.

3 to experience, undergo,

4 to explore.

5 to test, try out, assess.

6 to believe, think, consider it right, 

7 to sense, have a feeling, get the impression, atmosphere 

8 to seem, appear, strike one as, aptitude.

9.to feel sympathy 

10.to feel want 

And then I looked up the meaning of Experience and constructed the following word-pool:

An incident, occurrence, event, happening, affair, episode, encounter; adventure, exploit, escapade; circumstance, case; test, trial, ordeal. An involvement in, a participation in; contact with.

After all that, having immersed myself totally in a pool of words, the structure that resonated with me was: "a felt-experience is an event or occurrence that leaves an impression on someone, like a learning experience.” 

I liked the word impression and promised myself to look it up...in a never-ending sort of way. The trajectory of our lives!

Now after developing my process, and arriving at my sentence through a process of iteration and selection, I look over to see your sentence structure and see the difference. And I say, your structure, and the space that you constructed is extraordinary. 

Is that an A? No, it is an A- because, if you were to share your journey of getting to your structure, that would be an A. Your journey could even be, that you got it down from a dictionary without following any process. Or you dreamt it up. It is still an A. The reason is because we are sharing a knowing with each other. Every selection or exercise of choice is a knowing act. It is called the individual's agency. PLease google the term.

Sanjiv

Constructing Knowledge/Creating Knowing

II. Doing Letters: Immersion

A. Terms

Always identify at least two or three words from whatever sentence, phrase, paragraph you chance upon.

Do it as a practice.

Do what? Identify words.

Look up their definitions and write them out.

B. Close Reading

Raise the question: what are the qualities of these terms?

Why are they juxtaposed, inter-facing, interacting and interrelating?

Use Thesaurus and Search engines.

C. Reflection

Write your experience and your feelings around these terms.

-------------------------------------------

"Why are they juxtaposed, inter-facing, interacting and interrelating?"

JUXTAPOSED: Placed side by side; Place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.

INTER-FACING: Interact with (another system, person, organization, etc.)

INTERRELATING: Relate or connect to one another.

Reflection:

How do the words you are reading connect the thoughts and ideas? Why are they placed in the positions they are? The same words in a different context can bring a different meaning to the entire idea.

Subject: creating structures
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? I got an email from Chris Ferrigno and am taking my reply to him as an example of what is required of us, as we begin the process of constructing structures. There is a lot of freedom. However, we are only able to experience this freedom and creativity whenever we immerse ourselves in text and images.

Only what you post in your fishbowls will be evaluated. Please keep that in mind. I am hoping that this letter will clarify any doubts as to how to approach the letters. You are pairing two words and setting upon a journey. That is all. Take the first step. After that it is a breeze. I will be sending you assignments next. They will be more of the same, except I will distinguish between 345 and 448. 

The assignments are meant to be easy, revelatory and entertaining.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl... 

Dear Chris,

Thank you for your response below. I quote, 

I picked the words feeling and experience because I feel they are connected in the idea that we remember good or bad experiences better by how strong the feeling of that experience was. 

This is well done. To be honest with you, I find your reflection, your structure, and your sentence and your selection of two words to be quite extraordinary. Thank-you. Your sentence structure brings the element of ‘strength' to light by your insight; that is your working the text.

But to address your original email and any distress you might be having, here’s what I am suggesting to you and to the class: whenever you wish to focus on a text...

1. Select any two words, as you have, Feeling and Experience (from the letter, paragraph or sentence on hand). Do it as a practice. Otherwise, what is the point of reading?

2. Your purpose, at the back of your head, is to create a structure of words (sentence) originating from these two words that you have selected and, your structure will be of use to the viewer, reader, customer, etc. Your audience. We’ll soon be talking about structures and mental spaces.

3. We are developing a rubric and a practice, visible to all. It is known as Performative Writing and Performative Inquiry. Please google those terms.

4. So I did, and here’s what I found regarding performative inquiry: it is a different kind of learning that becomes possible when we release ourselves from our expectations, and surrender to that which arrives on the page. Like right here. The here and now.

5. "Performative inquiry performs writing as performative explorations interweaving narratives of singular moments of lived experience and reflection into performative texts of learning, breath by breath.”

6. "Performative writing as scholarly writing abandons conventional academic text, dispels third person detachment, interrupts linearity, avoids the explanatory, the expected. Performative writing mischievously plays with space, time, form, metaphor, writing knowing, and not knowing into presence, making visible the gaps between. Performative writing is evocative, acoustic, poetic, performative, inviting recognition, resonance, and understanding through the imagination, listening, meaning making and active participation embodied in the presence of the reader.”

7. Coming back on track: I looked up the dictionary meaning of Feeling and Experience and was inundated with words (ideas), and I wanted to keep it simple for the sake of clarity. So, I looked up the word Feel instead of Feeling and constructed the following ideas (words), known as a word-pool:

8.

Feel

1 to feel touch, texture 

2 to perceive, sense, detect, discern, make out, notice, observe, identify; be aware of, be conscious of.

3 to experience, undergo,

4 to explore.

5 to test, try out, assess.

6 to believe, think, consider it right, 

7 to sense, have a feeling, get the impression, atmosphere 

8 to seem, appear, strike one as, aptitude.

9.to feel sympathy 

10.to feel want 

And then I looked up the meaning of Experience and constructed the following word-pool:

An incident, occurrence, event, happening, affair, episode, encounter; adventure, exploit, escapade; circumstance, case; test, trial, ordeal. An involvement in, a participation in; contact with.

After all that, having immersed myself totally in a pool of words, the structure that resonated with me was: "a felt-experience is an event or occurrence that leaves an impression on someone, like a learning experience.” 

I liked the word impression and promised myself to look it up...in a never-ending sort of way. The trajectory of our lives!

Now after developing my process, and arriving at my sentence through a process of iteration and selection, I look over to see your sentence structure and see the difference. And I say, your structure, and the space that you constructed is extraordinary. 

Is that an A? No, it is an A- because, if you were to share your journey of getting to your structure, that would be an A. Your journey could even be, that you got it down from a dictionary without following any process. Or you dreamt it up. It is still an A. The reason is because we are sharing a knowing with each other. Every selection or exercise of choice is a knowing act. It is called the individual's agency. PLease google the term.

Sanjiv

interface: a shared boundary

interact: a reciprocal action

interrelate: a connection with

Whenever all three elements co-exist, there is fluidity and the project becomes a living, independent text.. The three elements feed-off each other and, their movement can be tracked. For instance, I would next look-up the following: shared, boundary, reciprocal, action, connection...it is a “never-ending story’...

Constructing Knowledge/Creating Knowing

II. Doing Letters: Immersion

A. Terms

Always identify at least two or three words from whatever sentence, phrase, paragraph you chance upon.

Do it as a practice.

Do what? Identify words.

Look up their definitions and write them out.

B. Close Reading

Raise the question: what are the qualities of these terms?

Why are they juxtaposed, inter-facing, interacting and interrelating?

Use Thesaurus and Search engines.

C. Reflection

Write your experience and your feelings around these terms.

-------------------------------------------

"Why are they juxtaposed, inter-facing, interacting and interrelating?"

JUXTAPOSED: Placed side by side; Place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.

INTER-FACING: Interact with (another system, person, organization, etc.)

INTERRELATING: Relate or connect to one another.

Reflection:

How do the words you are reading connect the thoughts and ideas? Why are they placed in the positions they are? The same words in a different context can bring a different meaning to the entire idea.

Date: 2/12/2021 14:13:39
Subject: Becoming, Seeing the Whole, Patterns of Attention
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I wonder about you, out there in the wilderness, everyone and everything demanding your attention.

I stay committed to being focused on words, concepts, ideas, word-images. In this way of Being I am forever in a state of Becoming. To focus is to generate new ways of Being.

How does one do that: be in a state of becoming?

Let me ask in another way: What is the process of removing an element (a word) from its original meaning and bring about a new one?

Here’s how...

You are doing three activities right now in your fishbowls...

vocabulary, google searches and letter responses.

You are developing an oeuvre. 

Focus on your learning; start by raising the question: what does it (focus) mean?

Keeping It Simple is the mantra.

Well, the lesson of whatever I have learned over time is that looking (focusing) carefully at anything, like a word, a gesture, an image, a feeling, informs looking at everything. In other words, in the fishbowl, in order to see things whole, we have to respect and treasure their minute particulars. The world in a grain of sand, as the saying goes.

So how do we do it?

Do what?

See things whole.

I think that the best hope for our species lies in learning new 'patterns of attention' to each other and to the biosphere, ‘patterns' that grow out of curiosity and respect and allow for wonder (wow factor) and learning.

That’s all we’re being asked in the fishbowl: new patterns of attention. 

Please think upon it. 

It’s no big deal and the payoff is tried and tested. 

Keep the thread of the letters like in the image below. You don’t have to be lost nor fall down. It is not that difficult.

Sanjiv

BE, BECOME, GENERATIVE, FOCUS, MINUTE, WHOLE, PATTERN, ATTENTION, CURIOSITY, WONDER

from the fishbowl...

Through analogies, drawing inferences, and arriving at independent judgments, you learn to deconstruct text and thereby generate feelings and experiences.

Date: 2/11/2021 14:28:23
Subject: the fishbowl
------------------------------------------------------------
Dear John,

Thank you for your letter, and thank you for your insightful reflections and contributions in the fishbowl.

 

I am addressing the points you raise in a particular way that creates the context; the backdrop as it were.

I have always been interested in the process of translation, the effort to frame the same message in different ways, even as new meanings are created by a shift in context. It is precisely what we are doing in our fishbowls.

I am observing participants in the fishbowl (it is a fertile ground for anyone's learning to grow) and I am participating as well. 

By observing each other, we change each other. 

We are, simultaneously, observers and the observed in a space where even silence speaks.

Familiar texts in the fishbowl, reencountered in a new language, and going back and forth, seems to me to enrich our understanding. And the effort to present an idea in the academic form appropriate to a scholarly quest may show up hollow when explained in ordinary language, stripped of jargon --- or it may emerge from the cocoon as piercing insight.

Our practice of 

looking up the meaning of words, 

searching for the meaning of new words, and 

interpreting words in letters 

are conversations with the Self, and 

we are sharing our process in the fishbowl as a practice.

In this process of reshaping, we discover much about what we are saying. Juxtaposing styles and genres produces oddities and is sometimes uncomfortable, but segregating them produces distortion. In the same way, I believe, a division into conventional subject areas is inappropriate. Society and Culture are not divisible.

A couple of your questions regarding interaction and assignments remain. I will be sure to address them subsequently. In the meantime, we are singularly working the text. 

Best,

Sanjiv

TRANSLATION, JUXTAPOSE, OBSERVATION, PARTICIPATE, SINGULAR, SIMULTANEOUS, ENCOUNTER, INSIGHT, CONTEXT

Date: 2/10/2021 21:12:15
Subject: be a thought-leader
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you doing? 

We are living increasingly with our thoughts. Selected words. 

Nonetheless, we seek to accumulate things, not thoughts. We fight over things and forget thoughts. So please, let's get with the program. 

Growth in thought brings about growth in action. Be a 'thought-leader.' Please google the term. It’s the real thing. It is not difficult and actually fun, but we resist advice and instructions. I am so much like that myself. To teach, we have to learn to let go. I have to be willing to learn, so growth can happen. We are in a cycle, you and I. We are bound together. I hope you can see that.

That growth in thought brings about growth in action is particularly true in business: teaching and learning is cyclical. It is not linear from teacher to student. Looking at you looking at me looking at you. Only when I am willing to learn from you will growth in thought happen.

To provoke thought, we have to learn patience. Immerse the mind in words. We are forcing the mind to expand because we face our own stubbornness; rigid 'mental structures' (please google the term).

When you post in your fishbowl, that is your forum, you are taking on the role of teacher. You are saying something in a way that will be of use to the reader, unconditionally. Not expecting a return, just fulfilling an inner desire to connect. 

"Can’t see you, but I know you are out there," he said, as he closed one eye and took focus. 

You discover the essence of communication, what works and what does not work, why something works and why something does not. This learning makes you less impatient and more wise. Wisdom can be acquired in this way; by discovering the essence. Please see Jacob Gilman’s posting below as one example.

Sanjiv

THOUGHT, LEADER, ROLE, GROWTH, MENTAL, STRUCTURE, COMMUNICATION, ESSENCE

from the fishbowl...

Post by jacobgilman » Wed Feb 10, 2021 1:15 pm

Constructing Knowledge/Creating Knowing:

Every assignment we do is just adding one more piece to the puzzle. It is learning one more thing to add to the entire collection. I feel the question of how we are connecting so well is a trick question. The goal of the fishbowl is to learn in whatever way makes you feel comfortable and the more comfortable people feel, the better connection we will have. With everyone being comfortable we are able to connect and share more than ever.

Hi Everyone,

We are living increasingly with our thoughts. Selected words. 

Nonetheless, we seek to accumulate things, not thoughts. We fight over things and forget thoughts. So please, let's get with the program.

I am so much like that myself. To teach, we have to learn to let go. I have to be willing to learn, so growth can happen. We are in a cycle, you and I. We are bound together. Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope the multitude of postings in the fishbowl are not overwhelming you.

I. Multitude/Solitude

The fishbowl has a multitude of fragmentary postings as a new model of resistance against global systems of power like curriculum designs and academic standards during vexatious times.

Multitude of fragments

model of resistance

How do you connect with the Multitude, the crowd, without losing the self’s Solitude?

How are you connecting so well in your fishbowl?

It is what I want to know.

I certainly feel it, as must you.

Is this an assignment or a trick question? 

Please reflect upon the above question some, and express your feelings in the crowd, before they are lost.

II. Doing Letters: Immersion

A. Terms

Always identify at least two or three words from whatever sentence, phrase, paragraph you chance upon. 

Do it as a practice.

Do what? Identify words.

Look up their definitions and write them out.

B. Close Reading

Raise the question: what are the qualities of these terms?

Why are they juxtaposed, inter-facing, interacting and interrelating?

Use Thesaurus and Search engines.

C. Reflection

Write your experience and your feelings around these terms.

III. Universal Communion

She walked alone with her thoughts drawing a singular intoxication from a universal communion.

And disappeared forever in the crowd.

Sanjiv

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 2/9/2021 13:01:47
Subject: interrelation between two words
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I trust you’re onto it and up for it. We're on a journey. The boat has embarked and left the shores. We’re on our way without map nor goal, led only by word-images.

We’re going slow ... and working step by step, i.e., word by word. Every now and then, we fly and perch on a branch, but most of the time, we will be going: "one word at a time.”

When responding to a letter, you are constructing and creating knowledge content. 

Otherwise, why respond.

We are knowledge workers and we’re developing our skills in a fishbowl which is a digital arena.

An arena? What is an arena? Why is this word selected over others?

(we are proceeding one word at a time and we elected to start with the word Arena)

I go to my tool box to address the questions above that I myself have raised. (address, hmm, another good word. I must come back to it)

I am inescapably constructing a reality. The game has begun and it did so with a word.

The world is an oyster and I am in charge.

Here’s what I find in my tool-box:

An arena is a level area surrounded by seats for spectators, in which public events are held. 

It is a place or scene of activity. stadium, amphitheater, theater, coliseum; ground, field, ring, rink, court, stage, platform. 

Some gems from my tool box: in ancient Rome a circus was called hippodrome. Then you have a British pitch in cricket; North American bowl; informal park; a cirque. 

More gems: area, scene, sphere, realm, province, domain, sector, forum, territory, theater, stage, world; 

battleground, battlefield, area/field of conflict, sphere of action/activity, lists.

So returning to where I selected the word Arena. The fishbowl, of which we are a part, may be described by any one of the words above.

The word you select is the trajectory of thought you elect to follow. It is the beginning.

At the heart of the matter is always the question, which word did you have in mind?

II.

To respond to a letter, to a text, to a paragraph, to a sentence, to a phrase, here’s what you must do:

select two words from the sentence and place them side by side, like a dichotomy.

religion/life

multitude/solitude

When you do that, you are exercising your freedom of choice. 

You are developing an ‘interrelation' between two words of your choice.

The moment you put them side by side, 

You are looking at the relation between two concepts, ideas, symbols, words.

From the toolbox:

You understood the meaning of ‘relation' between two words, e.g., religion and life. It is about their connection, relationship, association, link, correlation, correspondence, parallel, tie-in, tie-up, alliance, bond, interrelation, interconnection; interdependence of.

This interrelation that you are developing must have relevance, applicability, application, reference, pertinence, bearing on, regard. It must have value.

Please see Alyssa Botelho’s postings below. She is writing in a way that works for her. She is after all creating her own knowledge content. However, underlying her text is always an interrelation between two things and this event gives birth to something new.

Sanjiv

WORD, RELATION, JOURNEY, EMBARK, RESPONSE

AlyssaBotelho

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Mon Feb 08, 2021 7:21 pm

"The ultimate purpose for any enterprise is to survive in a rapidly changing environment."

PURPOSE: have as one's intention or objective.

ENTERPRISE: a project or undertaking, typically one that is difficult or requires effort.

SURVIVE: continue to live or exist, especially in spite of danger or hardship.

RAPIDLY: very quickly; at a great rate.

ENVIRONMENT: the surroundings or conditions in which a person, animal, or plant lives or operates.

The grand objective for any project is to live in a setting where things are always changing very quickly.

Whether it's a business, a school, a non-profit, a passion project, every entity is subject to the dangerous waters of a rapidly changing world. The baseline goal, then, is to have the entity survive against all odds. From there, efforts can be made to see that the entity thrives.

AlyssaBotelho

Sorting, sifting, and selecting

Mon Feb 08, 2021 7:33 pm

"You are learning to develop a point of view (POV), and you are doing it through the following steps: sorting, sifting and selecting words."

Through words, we define ourselves. The words we choose and use say a lot about who we are, what our history is, and what our viewpoints are as a result.

AlyssaBotelho

Grades and Letters

Mon Feb 08, 2021 7:41 pm

"Learning is non-linear, and it happens through reflection in the head"

LEARNING: the acquisition of knowledge or skills through experience, study, or by being taught.

NON-LINEAR: not linear, sequential, or straightforward; random.

REFLECTION: serious thought or consideration.

The acquisition of knowledge is random and it happens though serious thoughts.

Our knowledge grows through a multitude of mediums (reading, listening, first-hand experience, writing). All of them share the same thing: our reflection on them. One could be presented with all the knowledge in the world and it wouldn't matter if they didn't take the time to try to understand it. It is our mental effort that allows learning to occur.

AlyssaBotelho

Developing a practice and a process

Mon Feb 08, 2021 8:00 pm

"The world that we can share is always and still to be elaborated by us and between us starting from the perception and affirmation of what and who we are as humans here and now.”

ELABORATE: develop or present (a theory, policy, or system) in detail.

PERCEPTION: the state of being or process of becoming aware of something through the senses.

AFFIRMATION: emotional support or encouragement.

Our shared space has and will be developed through awareness and support of who we currently are as people.

AlyssaBotelho

Wondering on a gloomy sunday morning

Mon Feb 08, 2021 8:13 pm

"We are working and living under vexing conditions."

VEXING: causing annoyance, frustration, or worry.

CONDITION: the circumstances affecting the way in which people live or work, especially with regard to their safety or well-being.

We are operating in an annoying, frustrating, and worrisome circumstances. The pandemic is like a blanket that covers every inch of our lives. Everything has been disturbed in one way or another. It is difficult to resist the temptation to let the annoyances, the frustrations, and the worry consume you. Focus on the present and let the good things in front of you shine.

AlyssaBotelho

Metaphorical thinking

Mon Feb 08, 2021 8:22 pm

“Imagination is more important than knowledge. To raise new questions, new possibilities, to regard old problems from a new angle, requires creative imagination and marks real advance in science.”

IMAGINATION: the faculty or action of forming new ideas, or images or concepts of external objects not present to the senses.

KNOWLEDGE: what is known in a particular field or in total; facts and information.

CREATIVE: relating to or involving the imagination or original ideas, especially in the production of an artistic work.

ADVANCE: make or cause to make progress.

The ability to form new concepts and ideas is more valuable than known facts. Conceiving new questions, opportunities, and reframing old issues demands artful thinking. It is progression.

Sent from my iPhone

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 2/8/2021 11:56:08
Subject: metaphorical thinking
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

In this letter I'd like to talk about metaphorical thinking. Ideas about organizing and organizations (structures and forms) are always based on implicit images or metaphors that persuade us to see, understand, and manage situations in a particular way. Please see Erin Torgersen’s postings below. 

To think metaphorically is to be imaginative. Quoting Albert Einstein: “Imagination is more important than knowledge. To raise new questions, new possibilities, to regard old problems from a new angle, requires creative imagination and marks real advance in science.”

Whenever we think in metaphors, we are able to develop new ways of thinking. We are able to re-image ourselves and what we do. 

Metaphors create insight.

However, they also distort.

The way we see the world, the way we enter the unknown, the way we imagine the future, the way we do things, 

we often get trapped by our perspectives and assumptions,

ways of seeing become ways of not seeing.

There can be no single theory or metaphor that gives an all-purpose point of view, and there can be no simple “correct theory” for structuring everything we do.

Sanjiv

IMPLICIT, IMAGE, INSIGHT, PERSPECTIVE, ASSUMPTION, TRAP, IMAGINATION, METAPHORICAL-THINKING (please google)

From the fishbowl…

Letters: Interpreting and deconstructing sentences

Thu Feb 04, 2021 7:34 pm

SYLLABI: MGT345 & MGT448: An introduction to the class with emphasis on being flexible, working in, and understanding the ever-changing environment around us. COVID is compared to “carrying a bunch of bags up a hill and not knowing how long you had to go” as we still don’t know when a “normal” will return, so the class has been designed to be a mode of open communication, rather than cause a great amount of stress. Through metaphor, we are told to take it slowly in the first few weeks to get used to the class. 

Lacing your shoes (345): As we go through the course it will make more sense through more letters, text we write, and text our peers write. By the end of the semester we will aim to have grown through these texts, especially in finding ourselves. Here we are compared to Deleuze to master the art of taking on new and different challenges to be constructive in what we are doing. In a digital world, we need to be able to express ourselves in a way to be seen and heard through our words. We are told to “hold our horses” aka be patient. We are said to be “climbing a rope” instead of “sliding a slope” which shows we are on a slow, steady incline to be building up to the end where we will look back and see how much we grew. “When the dust settles” refers to after the first few weeks of figuring out what we are doing to then go to the fishbowl. The final metaphor, “working side by side, shoulder to shoulder” says we are all in this together, and we are all doing the same work, and are going to get through the course with each other. 

Trilogy: “The stragglers are still trickling in” as before the drop add period ends there are slowly but surely more people entering the two classes. However, this is out of our control so “don’t sweat it,” or don’t worry about it. The larger idea of the fishbowl is to interact with our classmates, particularly those in our group to create a “culture” and communication around the letters. Because we can see each other's posts it is like a fishbowl, clear. We can see the fish, the fish can see us, just as each other’s writings. Eyes looking at eyes can be our own eyes staring at someone else's eyes on the other side of the fishbowl, or it can be our eyes staring at the fish’s eyes and vise versa. Write honestly and truthfully, and see where it takes you. 

Idiom and Lexicon: To begin with “this too shall pass” shows we are almost there in learning about the fishbowl and what it entails. We will know what to do soon, just as the early years of high school and elementary school seem very overwhelming, and confusing but eventually puts us on a track of where we are supposed to be. We will soon be in growth mode for the fishbowl just as after WWII. As we continue to grow and go into the real world, we will carry with us images that define us, as well as the words to describe them specifically creating who we are. We are often entering new things, which are fun and exciting, but it takes us a while to open up sometimes and get to know people. In contrast it can take a very short time for us to leave. While we are all watching each other, we are doing so as equals, not one is an actor, nor the other an audience. The vocabulary will help us to be able to get our point across in the best way possible. We can use it as needed (tools) or to make what we are saying sound better (jewelry). Practicing vocabulary will help to portray yourself and your thoughts through words. 

Re: Apology for Jumping the Gun: Explains the fishbowl and how it is set up. The professor did not mean to “jump the gun” as we are slowly building up to completing the fishbowl. All we can do is to get ready, or “sharpen our pencils.” The letters will hold different meanings based on our experience and how we interpret the words. 

The desire to learn and genesis of the fishbowl: Each of the parts of our mental, physical, emotional, and spiritual health are all intertwined. They affect each other both positively and negatively, as well as working together to form each of us individually. Through the fishbowl when we are working with others, presenting ourselves through text, and actively creating the environment that is the fishbowl, we are learning. The fishbowl is something that we slowly create together, to create the society or culture we desire. 

Fishbowl is set up: Basic instructions on how to set up the fishbowl. 

Fishbowl technology being repaired: Although there was a technological error, that is not the main subject of focus for the fishbowl. Rather it is how to make do in difficult situations, and make the best of them. This was explained in Aldous Huxley’s “Brave New World” when he discusses surviving a scary, dystopian world. It is about adapting to situations and overcoming them. To be most successful, we need to come to the fishbowl with an open mind, as explained in Luce Irigaray’s book To Be Two, which explains her process of reconstructing the women’s image. Men and women must mutually learn from each other, as they each have different perspectives. 

The fishbowl is on. Please register: More information on the fishbowl and what is expected of us. Continue practicing vocabulary.

Setting up 4 Topics in your fishbowl: Although we have thus far been “peering in the dark,” or trying to see what is ahead with very little information, we will soon be using the fishbowl. However, peeing in the dark has a bad connotation, so we are “standing on a diving board of a swimming pool” as that sounds much more exciting, and our fishbowl is going to be exciting. We are going to come together through the fishbowl and work with each other in the four categories listed in the letter. 

Being in the fishbowl: We have to work together to balance this course among otters, the level of participation in the fishbowl with our other responsibilities. Once this is achieved, we are most successful. Once again, the text we are creating is to be able to portray what we wish to portray through our words. We can describe specific images of what we are thinking with our words. Although there are four categories in the fishbowl, they are all intertwined, they relate to each other and depend on each other. Although we are all posting about the same topics, we will have different interpretations that we can learn from with each other. 

Google searches: co-existing visually: We are “inching forward,” or slowly getting the semester started. But once we better understand the fish bowl, we will be able to move forward much quicker, with leaps and bounds. It is compared to the Matrix, as if the professor is including how we are acting. By being told what to google, it is influencing the meaning we take away from the letters and the class. The metaphors are meant to stick with us, something that we can remember the ideas by. We should propose different and new ideas to continue allowing the conversation to flow. 

Surviving thus far: In this changing world, the wants of employers has also been changing. We need to be flexible and able to adapt in new environments. The fishbowl will help us do just that. In the fishbowl, the professor will be watching each of us closely. However, we are both looking at each other mutually, it is not one-sided.

Re: Letters: Interpreting and deconstructing sentences

Fri Feb 05, 2021 4:26 pm

Sorting, sifting and selecting: We are told to be “polishing our shoes, steer clear from complexity, and press on” for now. This can be taken as getting ready, and preparing, keeping things simple (emphasised by the KISS principle mentioned later on), and continuing on in what we are doing through the fishbowl and course. For the fishbowl, we want to keep it very short but have impactful meanings. We should be carefully choosing the perfect words to explain what we are describing. We now have a more direct differentiation between the categories in the fishbowl, but that could only be found after we analyzed, learned, and prepared through more letters as the Fishbowl is a work-in-process. This is similar to Alain Badiou. He, as a philosopher, could not contain himself to one category, and neither should we in our work or in the fishbowl. 

Grades and Letters: Although those who do the vocabulary will succeed in learning new words, that is not enough. It is necessary to think of the vocabulary in its context. Therefore, while it is helpful to know the meaning of a word, it is not enough. One must also know how to use it to make it effective. Similarly, one cannot just be healthy by eating vegetables, they must also be put to work through exercise, and other healthy living activities. In this letter Derrida is relevant as he studied the connection between experience and consciousness. Each of us will, because of our experience and consciousness, will have slightly different interpretations of the letters. However, this will stimulate the sharing of ideas and communication to make the class more interesting.

From the fishbowl...everything has been strange lately

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 2/8/2021 11:53:46
Subject: metaphorical thinking
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

In this letter I'd like to talk about metaphorical thinking. Ideas about organizing and organizations (structures and forms) are always based on implicit images or metaphors that persuade us to see, understand, and manage situations in a particular way. Please see Erin Torgersen’s postings below. 

To think metaphorically is to be imaginative. Quoting Albert Einstein: “Imagination is more important than knowledge. To raise new questions, new possibilities, to regard old problems from a new angle, requires creative imagination and marks real advance in science.”

Whenever we think in metaphors, we are able to develop new ways of thinking. We are able to re-image ourselves and what we do. 

Metaphors create insight.

However, they also distort.

The way we see the world, the way we enter the unknown, the way we imagine the future, the way we do things, 

we often get trapped by our perspectives and assumptions,

ways of seeing become ways of not seeing.

There can be no single theory or metaphor that gives an all-purpose point of view, and there can be no simple “correct theory” for structuring everything we do.

Sanjiv

IMPLICIT, IMAGE, INSIGHT, PERSPECTIVE, ASSUMPTION, TRAP, IMAGINATION, METAPHORICAL-THINKING (please google)

From the fishbowl…

SYLLABI: MGT345 & MGT448: An introduction to the class with emphasis on being flexible, working in, and understanding the ever-changing environment around us. COVID is compared to “carrying a bunch of bags up a hill and not knowing how long you had to go” as we still don’t know when a “normal” will return, so the class has been designed to be a mode of open communication, rather than cause a great amount of stress. Through metaphor, we are told to take it slowly in the first few weeks to get used to the class. 

Lacing your shoes (345): As we go through the course it will make more sense through more letters, text we write, and text our peers write. By the end of the semester we will aim to have grown through these texts, especially in finding ourselves. Here we are compared to Deleuze to master the art of taking on new and different challenges to be constructive in what we are doing. In a digital world, we need to be able to express ourselves in a way to be seen and heard through our words. We are told to “hold our horses” aka be patient. We are said to be “climbing a rope” instead of “sliding a slope” which shows we are on a slow, steady incline to be building up to the end where we will look back and see how much we grew. “When the dust settles” refers to after the first few weeks of figuring out what we are doing to then go to the fishbowl. The final metaphor, “working side by side, shoulder to shoulder” says we are all in this together, and we are all doing the same work, and are going to get through the course with each other. 

Trilogy: “The stragglers are still trickling in” as before the drop add period ends there are slowly but surely more people entering the two classes. However, this is out of our control so “don’t sweat it,” or don’t worry about it. The larger idea of the fishbowl is to interact with our classmates, particularly those in our group to create a “culture” and communication around the letters. Because we can see each other's posts it is like a fishbowl, clear. We can see the fish, the fish can see us, just as each other’s writings. Eyes looking at eyes can be our own eyes staring at someone else's eyes on the other side of the fishbowl, or it can be our eyes staring at the fish’s eyes and vise versa. Write honestly and truthfully, and see where it takes you. 

Idiom and Lexicon: To begin with “this too shall pass” shows we are almost there in learning about the fishbowl and what it entails. We will know what to do soon, just as the early years of high school and elementary school seem very overwhelming, and confusing but eventually puts us on a track of where we are supposed to be. We will soon be in growth mode for the fishbowl just as after WWII. As we continue to grow and go into the real world, we will carry with us images that define us, as well as the words to describe them specifically creating who we are. We are often entering new things, which are fun and exciting, but it takes us a while to open up sometimes and get to know people. In contrast it can take a very short time for us to leave. While we are all watching each other, we are doing so as equals, not one is an actor, nor the other an audience. The vocabulary will help us to be able to get our point across in the best way possible. We can use it as needed (tools) or to make what we are saying sound better (jewelry). Practicing vocabulary will help to portray yourself and your thoughts through words. 

Re: Apology for Jumping the Gun: Explains the fishbowl and how it is set up. The professor did not mean to “jump the gun” as we are slowly building up to completing the fishbowl. All we can do is to get ready, or “sharpen our pencils.” The letters will hold different meanings based on our experience and how we interpret the words. 

The desire to learn and genesis of the fishbowl: Each of the parts of our mental, physical, emotional, and spiritual health are all intertwined. They affect each other both positively and negatively, as well as working together to form each of us individually. Through the fishbowl when we are working with others, presenting ourselves through text, and actively creating the environment that is the fishbowl, we are learning. The fishbowl is something that we slowly create together, to create the society or culture we desire. 

Fishbowl is set up: Basic instructions on how to set up the fishbowl. 

Fishbowl technology being repaired: Although there was a technological error, that is not the main subject of focus for the fishbowl. Rather it is how to make do in difficult situations, and make the best of them. This was explained in Aldous Huxley’s “Brave New World” when he discusses surviving a scary, dystopian world. It is about adapting to situations and overcoming them. To be most successful, we need to come to the fishbowl with an open mind, as explained in Luce Irigaray’s book To Be Two, which explains her process of reconstructing the women’s image. Men and women must mutually learn from each other, as they each have different perspectives. 

The fishbowl is on. Please register: More information on the fishbowl and what is expected of us. Continue practicing vocabulary.

Setting up 4 Topics in your fishbowl: Although we have thus far been “peering in the dark,” or trying to see what is ahead with very little information, we will soon be using the fishbowl. However, peeing in the dark has a bad connotation, so we are “standing on a diving board of a swimming pool” as that sounds much more exciting, and our fishbowl is going to be exciting. We are going to come together through the fishbowl and work with each other in the four categories listed in the letter. 

Being in the fishbowl: We have to work together to balance this course among otters, the level of participation in the fishbowl with our other responsibilities. Once this is achieved, we are most successful. Once again, the text we are creating is to be able to portray what we wish to portray through our words. We can describe specific images of what we are thinking with our words. Although there are four categories in the fishbowl, they are all intertwined, they relate to each other and depend on each other. Although we are all posting about the same topics, we will have different interpretations that we can learn from with each other. 

Google searches: co-existing visually: We are “inching forward,” or slowly getting the semester started. But once we better understand the fish bowl, we will be able to move forward much quicker, with leaps and bounds. It is compared to the Matrix, as if the professor is including how we are acting. By being told what to google, it is influencing the meaning we take away from the letters and the class. The metaphors are meant to stick with us, something that we can remember the ideas by. We should propose different and new ideas to continue allowing the conversation to flow. 

Surviving thus far: In this changing world, the wants of employers has also been changing. We need to be flexible and able to adapt in new environments. The fishbowl will help us do just that. In the fishbowl, the professor will be watching each of us closely. However, we are both looking at each other mutually, it is not one-sided.

From the fishbowl...everything has been strange lately

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 2/7/2021 11:54:32
Subject: developing a practice and a process
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well and the fishbowl is not causing you distress. The fishbowl is a platform you are constructing, brick by brick (metaphor). It is the contribution of one responsible human creating use-value for viewers. I hope the grading system was agreeable to you. I repeat, no one will get below a B. The fact that you are here, and you are receiving my letters in your mailbox and in the fishbowl, entitles you to a B. 

At this point you should be registered and introduced yourselves in your forum.

Question: What would you do, if your task were to form a Society of Learners (345) and a Culture of Learning (448), because Learning is big business? And you have three months.

To begin with, we are not taking individual and collective learning for granted. At the end of the day, you want to be able to answer the question: what did you learn today? So when I asked a 5 year old, what did he learn in school today, "you don’t want to know," he replied, and ducked my question entirely, smashing through the wall!

How do I ‘look' at myself learning? 

In other words, how do I ‘observe' the Self engaged with Learning? 

And, how do I ‘see'? 

The emphasis is on process. On the “how so.” About the way of doing things. We’re big on it in the fishbowl. I refer to it as “experiential learning” (please google the term and pull out one idea).

“There you again," she said. “it is always about you, why don’t you look at me instead.” 

"Is this a gender issue or just my personality” he asked.

Please take a look at your four (fluid) categories. We’re already so different from each other; each on a trajectory in space among the stars. 

Every posting of yours in this constellation is an event. PLease google Alain Badiou and ‘event.' Every posting by you brings to light possibilities that were invisible or even unthinkable at the moment of viewing. 

Your four categories are creating a word-pool in which we are immersed. 

You are drawing a boundary around a collection of words. 

You are forming a language in use, known as 'discourse situations.’ 

Please google Discourse.

By definition, discourse is the use of language for communicative purposes in specific contextual and generic situations. This will make sense to you later, but keep it in mind.

vocabulary

notes

letters

assignments

What are we doing with these categories? That is to say, what are we doing with this on-going discourse; with these discourse situations

Developing a voice, a point of view, an image, and feelings. Always stay with the Feeling. There has to be Desire.

So How are we going about it? This development.

We are setting up a practice and a process.

And, we talk endlessly about our practices and processes; our pathways into the unknown...

You could say, we are developing a practice and a process to share a world that is yet to be.

"The world that we can share is always and still to be elaborated by us and between us starting from the perception and affirmation of what and who we are as humans here and now.” (Luce Irigaray, Sharing the World.)

In our fishbowls, everything we do, and every decision we take, every selection we make, we will be guided by the Gurus. 

And we will be open-minded and keep our word structures fluid as we stand on their shoulders.

Sanjiv

DEVELOP, PRACTICE, PROCESS, PATHWAY, DISCOURSE, LEARNING, BOUNDARY, IMMERSE, EVENT

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 12/18/2020 13:04:53
Subject: and finally ... self-valorization again
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you doing? I hope you are keeping well. We have reached the end of our rope, but we survived. We could only have done it together through participation and engagement.

Your self-generated text asserts that the experience of globalization is one of experiencing 'mass autonomous labor,' or, more precisely still, a 'multitude of productive singularities.’ Globalization radically blasts away the set of old criteria for measuring and evaluating your knowledge, learning and productive value and this triggers a whole sequence of conceptual dissolutions. 

There has been a transformation of concepts and we must take stock of the irreversible character of the globalization process in all spheres of activities.

By irreversibility, I mean, first of all, the objective impossibility of reinstating the conditions of Taylorism, and Fordist production. These can no longer be recovered, I’m afraid. 

Second, this irreversibility of globalization applies to the modification of subjective behavior both in terms of one's labor, learning and generating 'productive value' and, from the point of view of the constitution of the social tie. Please see April Younkin’s posting below.

Third, globalization represents destruction of the spatial determination of things, like organizational charts, work-load/assessment criteria, course/curriculum design, and dichotomies, like, professor/student. This crisis is irreversible, so is the emergence of new concepts around People, Personhood and Sovereignty. A discussion on the concept of measuring and evaluating your fishbowl is therefore essential. In this regard, what I have to say is that we must concern ourselves with the measure of productive value and not global knowledge per se. Consequently, self-valorization has become a key concept.

Finally, no more letters from me in the fishbowl. After tomorrow, December 19, I will be in retreat, working on your grades. The process has begun in earnest. Looking in the mirror is always a difficult time, more so than being stuck inside.

Sanjiv

TAYLORISM, FORDISM, IRREVERSIBLE, MEASURE, EVALUATE, VALORIZE, PERSONHOOD, SOVEREIGNITY

Self-Valorization

“Takes responsibility and ownership of self-created text.”

I feel proud of the work I have created in The Fishbowl and I have surprised myself multiple times with the ideas and thoughts that flow out of me. I do not take from outside sources when I am “Making Notes.” I feel like I have the most flexibility and versatility in this category because I can just let loose whatever comes to mind.

Date: 12/17/2020 2:09:44
Subject: intertextuality and intersubjectivity: palimpsest
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

We create knowledge and a knowing by juxtaposing layers of "intertextuality" and "intersubjectivity" and then peeling back the layers.

I describe this process by extracting from Joseph Dugas’ posting below.

"a) You should always take your own thoughts into consideration, and to always strive to study and contemplate yourself for your true self-aware self."

"Often I forget what is most important, my mental health. Most days I use my thoughts just to get by day to day. But, lately I have learned to listen to my own thoughts and truly understand them. It is important to understand yourself. Before you find yourself, you must strive to. If you do not use your own thoughts and ideas, you just are a sheep. Self reflection is essential. The time I truly self reflected and became self-aware is when I got alopecia universalis when I was 19. I found myself lost, and worried that I wouldn't be like others. But as time passed I realized it doesn't matter what people think. It doesn't affect me. My self reflection has shown me that I was unique, and to always embrace that. Without self reflection I do not believe I would truly accept these thoughts." (Joseph Dugas)

To begin with, I choose to edit and simplify his original structure for my own understanding, and without apology:

My edit to read: 

"Being True to your Thoughts leads to Self-Awareness.” (Dugas, J., Fishbowl, 2020)

Then through iteration and a back and forth of editing, I proceed to answer the How so and Why so question for real, and 

take my understanding further by juxtaposing new text that makes sense for me.

“Being True to your Thoughts leads to Self-Awareness"

How so?

The courage to be yourself.

How so?

Being Unafraid to feel.

How so?

“No one can build you the bridge on which you, and only you, must cross the river of life,” wrote the thirty-year-old Nietzsche. 

“The true and durable path into and through experience,” Nobel-winning poet Seamus Heaney counseled the young more than a century later in his magnificent commencement address, “involves being true … to your own solitude, true to your own secret knowledge.”

How so?

In his assignment below, Joseph Dugas, (like each of you Actors, Stars in your Crown) is "true to his own solitude, true to his own secret knowledge.”

This is important. Why so? 

Your expression of a real life experience is to empower your text and your self.

My knowledge creation and knowing process above is arbitrary and it cannot be copied nor repeated. It makes sense to me and hopefully to you. That has been the objective of your postings in the fishbowl all along.

Welcome to our phantasmal world aka the fishbowl, where our minds meet without fear nor prejudice. And we give meaning to each other’s personhood.

Sanjiv

Please google INTERTEXTUALITY, INTERSUBJECTIVITY

Re: Individual Assignments

Wed Dec 16, 2020 12:50 pm

Final Assignment

"Steps for the Assignment

1. Scroll down the fishbowl.

2. Select 6 words that are symbols having an image. These are six perceptual categories.

3. Pair the six words in step 2, and create 3 dichotomies.

4. Construct word pools for each of the dichotomies in step 3.

5. Create 3 sentence structures from the dichotomies and word pools in step 4.

6. Do 3 felt-experience paragraphs that “fit" the sentence structures in step 5."

1. Scroll down the fishbowl.

I went through letters sent by Sanjiv and tried to pick out the essential topics we went over this semester.

2. Select 6 words that are symbols having an image. These are six perceptual categories.

Audience, self, procedure, pandemic, knowledge, reflections

3. Pair the six words in step 2, and create 3 dichotomies.

a) self reflections

b) pandemic procedure

c) audience knowledge

4. Construct word pools for each of the dichotomies in step 3.

a) subjective, thoughts, reflecting, self-aware, yourself, you, I, me, consideration, view, idea, contemplation, study, brainwork, opionion

b) health, action, safe, sickness, agenda, strategy, performance, mode, channels, form, conduct, diffuse, prevalent, restricted, alone

c) people, perception, public, fans, spectators, viewers, listen, theory, instruction, aware, judgement, insight

5. Create 3 sentence structures from the dichotomies and word pools in step 4.

a) You should always take your own thoughts into consideration, and to always strive to study and contemplate yourself for your true self-aware self.

b) People's health is the most important, we must diffuse this sickness with safe action.

c) The public are just spectators to your own play, but it is important to be aware of their insight.

6. Do 3 felt-experience paragraphs that “fit" the sentence structures in step 5.

a) You should always take your own thoughts into consideration, and to always strive to study and contemplate yourself for your true self-aware self.

Often I forget what is most important, my mental health. Most days I use my thoughts just to get by day to day. But, lately I have learned to listen to my own thoughts and truly understand them. It is important to understand yourself. Before you find yourself, you must strive to. If you do not use your own thoughts and ideas, you just are a sheep. Self reflection is essential. The time I truly self reflected and became self-aware is when I got alopecia universalis when I was 19. I found myself lost, and worried that I wouldn't be like others. But as time passed I realized it doesn't matter what people think. It doesn't affect me. My self reflection has shown me that I was unique, and to always embrace that. Without self reflection I do not believe I would truly accept these thoughts.

b) People's health is the most important, we must diffuse this sickness with safe action.

Nowadays, it is difficult to imagine us without COVID. But, until that time comes we must take into account other peoples safety and health. A lot of people are disregarding others just because they are impatient for things to be back to "normal". In order to get rid of COVID, we need to do so with a safe action. If we don't leave our house for 2 weeks, theoretically, the coronavirus should go away. But for the most part, irresponsible people are making COVID continue. An experience of mine was when I was in public and a person refused to wear a mask in public. This view was baffling to me. To think people think that wearing a mask is a "statement", or some means of being controlled. If wearing a mask means making a step to truly help society for the greater good, it is the least I can do. I hope people realize they are wasting time, and it is time to go back to "normal", without COVID.

c) The public are just spectators to your own play, but it is important to be aware of their insight.

In life, you go day by day in your head. In your own actions. In your own little world. As you pass people on the street, converse with family members, or friends, you realize they have their own world. You act as if you are the most important entity in this world, naturally, because it is all you have very known. Your own play, if you will. But, it is essential to to be aware of other peoples insight, words, thoughts, or perception. An experience of this is The Fishbowl. I found my self not caring about other people's perception on certain aspects of life. But I quickly realized it will add to my own perception. Giving me words, experiences, thoughts, that I didn't know could live within my own mind, or world, or play. It is interesting to see how other peoples words can add to your own, even if they are not talking to you directly. I appreciate The Fishbowl for giving me this notion of the importance of being aware of other people's insight.

Hi Everyone,

We create knowledge and a knowing by juxtaposing layers of "intertextuality" and "intersubjectivity" and then peeling back the layers.

"a) You should always take your own thoughts into consideration, and to always strive to study and contemplate yourself for your true self-aware self."

"Often I forget what is most important, my mental health. Most days I use my thoughts just to get by day to day. But, lately I have learned to listen to my own thoughts and truly understand them. It is important to understand yourself. Before you find yourself, you must strive to. If you do not use your own thoughts and ideas, you just are a sheep. Self reflection is essential. The time I truly self reflected and became self-aware is when I got alopecia universalis when I was 19. I found myself lost, and worried that I wouldn't be like others. But as time passed I realized it doesn't matter what people think. It doesn't affect me. My self reflection has shown me that I was unique, and to always embrace that. Without self reflection I do not believe I would truly accept these thoughts." (Joseph Dugas)

To begin with, I choose to edit and simplify his original structure for my own understanding, and without apology:

My edit to read: 

"Being True to your Thoughts leads to Self-Awareness.” (Dugas, J., Fishbowl, 2020)

Then through iteration and a back and forth of editing, I proceed to answer the How so and Why so question for real, and 

take my understanding further by juxtaposing new text that makes sense for me.

“Being True to your Thoughts leads to Self-Awareness"

How so?

The courage to be yourself.

How so?

Being Unafraid to feel.

How so?

“No one can build you the bridge on which you, and only you, must cross the river of life,” wrote the thirty-year-old Nietzsche. 

“The true and durable path into and through experience,” Nobel-winning poet Seamus Heaney counseled the young more than a century later in his magnificent commencement address, “involves being true … to your own solitude, true to your own secret knowledge.”

How so?

In his assignment below, Joseph Dugas, (like each of you Actors, Stars in your Crown) is "true to his own solitude, true to his own secret knowledge.”

This is important. Why so? 

Your expression of a real life experience is to empower your text and your self.

My knowledge creation and knowing process above is arbitrary and it cannot be copied nor repeated. It makes sense to me and hopefully to you. That has been the objective of your postings in the fishbowl all along.

Welcome to our phantasmal world aka the fishbowl, where our minds meet without fear nor prejudice. And we give meaning to each other’s personhood.

Sanjiv

Please google INTERTEXTUALITY, INTERSUBJECTIVITY

from the fishbowl...
