Re: Individual Assignments

Wed Dec 16, 2020 12:50 pm

Final Assignment

"Steps for the Assignment

1. Scroll down the fishbowl.

2. Select 6 words that are symbols having an image. These are six perceptual categories.

3. Pair the six words in step 2, and create 3 dichotomies.

4. Construct word pools for each of the dichotomies in step 3.

5. Create 3 sentence structures from the dichotomies and word pools in step 4.

6. Do 3 felt-experience paragraphs that “fit" the sentence structures in step 5."

1. Scroll down the fishbowl.

I went through letters sent by Sanjiv and tried to pick out the essential topics we went over this semester.

2. Select 6 words that are symbols having an image. These are six perceptual categories.

Audience, self, procedure, pandemic, knowledge, reflections

3. Pair the six words in step 2, and create 3 dichotomies.

a) self reflections

b) pandemic procedure

c) audience knowledge

4. Construct word pools for each of the dichotomies in step 3.

a) subjective, thoughts, reflecting, self-aware, yourself, you, I, me, consideration, view, idea, contemplation, study, brainwork, opionion

b) health, action, safe, sickness, agenda, strategy, performance, mode, channels, form, conduct, diffuse, prevalent, restricted, alone

c) people, perception, public, fans, spectators, viewers, listen, theory, instruction, aware, judgement, insight

5. Create 3 sentence structures from the dichotomies and word pools in step 4.

a) You should always take your own thoughts into consideration, and to always strive to study and contemplate yourself for your true self-aware self.

b) People's health is the most important, we must diffuse this sickness with safe action.

c) The public are just spectators to your own play, but it is important to be aware of their insight.

6. Do 3 felt-experience paragraphs that “fit" the sentence structures in step 5.

a) You should always take your own thoughts into consideration, and to always strive to study and contemplate yourself for your true self-aware self.

Often I forget what is most important, my mental health. Most days I use my thoughts just to get by day to day. But, lately I have learned to listen to my own thoughts and truly understand them. It is important to understand yourself. Before you find yourself, you must strive to. If you do not use your own thoughts and ideas, you just are a sheep. Self reflection is essential. The time I truly self reflected and became self-aware is when I got alopecia universalis when I was 19. I found myself lost, and worried that I wouldn't be like others. But as time passed I realized it doesn't matter what people think. It doesn't affect me. My self reflection has shown me that I was unique, and to always embrace that. Without self reflection I do not believe I would truly accept these thoughts.

b) People's health is the most important, we must diffuse this sickness with safe action.

Nowadays, it is difficult to imagine us without COVID. But, until that time comes we must take into account other peoples safety and health. A lot of people are disregarding others just because they are impatient for things to be back to "normal". In order to get rid of COVID, we need to do so with a safe action. If we don't leave our house for 2 weeks, theoretically, the coronavirus should go away. But for the most part, irresponsible people are making COVID continue. An experience of mine was when I was in public and a person refused to wear a mask in public. This view was baffling to me. To think people think that wearing a mask is a "statement", or some means of being controlled. If wearing a mask means making a step to truly help society for the greater good, it is the least I can do. I hope people realize they are wasting time, and it is time to go back to "normal", without COVID.

c) The public are just spectators to your own play, but it is important to be aware of their insight.

In life, you go day by day in your head. In your own actions. In your own little world. As you pass people on the street, converse with family members, or friends, you realize they have their own world. You act as if you are the most important entity in this world, naturally, because it is all you have very known. Your own play, if you will. But, it is essential to to be aware of other peoples insight, words, thoughts, or perception. An experience of this is The Fishbowl. I found my self not caring about other people's perception on certain aspects of life. But I quickly realized it will add to my own perception. Giving me words, experiences, thoughts, that I didn't know could live within my own mind, or world, or play. It is interesting to see how other peoples words can add to your own, even if they are not talking to you directly. I appreciate The Fishbowl for giving me this notion of the importance of being aware of other people's insight.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 12/16/2020 12:16:19
Subject: mirrors and windows: participatory action research
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are well.

I. Mirrors and Windows 

Both metaphors for the fishbowl. 

Mirror/Window--------Reflection/Frame

We grow and change through new metaphors and images. 

And thus we begin new lives, realities and experiences. 

Looking 

in Mirrors (reflection) and 

out of Windows (frameworks).

Inwards/Outwards

What do you see and, what action did you take?

II. Action and Learning

Your fishbowl postings are known as Action Learning or Action Research (please google).

Your process and practice combines both action and learning. 

Your process builds on the idea that it is possible (for your process) to achieve the dual objective of:

1. producing useful knowledge

2. helping your viewers gain a better understanding of their own situations

"How so? This sounds too intellectual. Why don’t you beam me up."

Whenever you create a dichotomy and construct an abstract structure, (I trust you are with me) you are producing knowledge and creating theory whose application are of use to your readers.

After that, whenever you “fit" a felt-experience to your abstraction, you open up the possibility for your viewer to gain a better understanding of their own situation. They do so by comparing and contrasting felt-experiences.

"Ok. Do you want to dumb it down? How will this be useful to me at my stage and circumstance in life?"

To get that job, here’s what you are claiming in your skill set...

You are concerned with 

fusing the development of theory and practice and 

to understand your group participants 

in some kind of direct involvement and problem-solving activity, 

rather than as more detached academic observers.

Your skill is most often used in problem-oriented contexts, where you are helping to explore a problem or set of issues or to unlock some kind of new initiative. It is Participatory Action Research (please google).

Please view your fishbowl in this light.

Let me put it another way...

The aim of the fishbowl is to create a learning setting

where different perspectives

are brought to a common problem

so that the problem can be solved and,

in the process, everyone improves their problem-solving skills.

At the end of the day, when it is all said and done, please know, you are liked best when you are most yourself.

Sanjiv

ACTION, LEARNING, MIRROR, WINDOW, REFLECT, FRAME

from the fishbowl...

alexrampone

Posts: 72

Joined: Wed Sep 02, 2020 2:01 pm

Re: Individual Assignments

Tue Dec 15, 2020 8:34 pm

Reflective Practice - the ability to reflect on one's actions so as to engage in a process of continuous learning. According to one definition it involves "paying critical attention to the practical values and theories which inform everyday actions, by examining practice reflectively and reflexively.

I feel as if this class has greatly improved my reflective practices. After reading your emails and doing research, I often think about these concepts throughout the day and acknowledge them on a day to day basis. It has changed my scope on life to have a more theoretical view on life and show the reason behind the actions of a person, group or culture.

The same also goes for this class. As the class has progressed, I have thought of ways that I can improve my thought process from the beginning of the semester versus now. I have even though of more ways that I can improve my past in general. I believe this class should be taught at many different levels because it can be used to give people the opportunity to truly think about their actions and enter "the fishbowl state of mind" where you can learn to build on yourself and understand the way others act.

Date: 12/15/2020 12:12:17
Subject: self-valorization
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Please see Dana DiCristofaro’s posting regarding the final assignment below:

"When crafting an inspiring theatre production a writer must dismantle their current life and combine it back together in a cohesive story." (DiCristofaro, Fishbowl, 20)

Suggestions:

1. I would return to this structure and 'further tighten and expand' (paradox) its meaning:

Re-edit: “Crafting production is to dismantle and re-combine elements in a cohesive way.”

2. The above abstraction is created and constructed by Dana DiCristofaro through an iterative process. 

3. It is an abstraction because it is a general statement and contains universal truth. 

4. When Dana DiCristofaro “fits” a felt-experience to his abstraction, he takes responsibility and ownership of his self-created text. 

He gives it worth. It is self-valorization.

"Growing up, one of my favorite weekend activities with my mother was attending Broadway plays As I have grown older I have been able to spend more time researching and immersing myself in the broadway production process. I learned that when crafting an inspiring theatre production a writer must dismantle their current life and combine it back together in a cohesive story. One of our favorite plays was Come From Away. This play was about an island that was forced to invite airline passengers to stay for over a month because of the 9/11 travel ban. This play was a theatrical retelling of real events that allowed each viewer to understand what the passengers went through during this experience. By transporting ourselves into this new experience we were able to gain a new perspective when approaching problems." (DiCristofaro, Fishbowl, 20)

5. The outcome that we see in Dana’s process is a generative text and moving images. 

6. He has created knowledge content through a process of knowing and being in the moment. His is "lived abstraction." 

How did he do it? What are his techniques?

7. Reflective Practice; Participant-Observation; Symbolic Interactionism.

8. Dana DiCristofaro is apparently an Interpretivist and Social Constructivist and he may be considered to be a Post-structuralist.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

danadicristofaro

Coming to the end...

 Mon Dec 14, 2020 10:13 pm

1. Scroll down the fishbowl.

2. Select 6 words that are symbols having an image. There are 6 perceptual categories

Absorb Embed. Contemplate Dismantle Adopt Theatre

3. Pair the six words in step 2, and create 3 dichotomies

Dismantle - Theatre. Absorb - Embed Contemplate - Adopt

4. Construct word pools for each of the dichotomies in step 3

Dismantle - Theatre: disassemble, destroy, strip, dramatics, combine, link

Absorb - Embed: ingest, consume, sponge, enclose, ingrain, install

Contemplate - Adopt: Consider, ponder, propose, weigh, embrace, maintain, adapt, support

5. Create 3 sentence structures from the dichotomies and word pools in step 4

When crafting an inspiring theatre production a writer must dismantle their current life and combine it back together in a cohesive story.

Each of Sanjiv's letters contains embedded meanings that we are allowed to absorb through repetition like a sponge.

Through exposing new readings and experiences I have been able to contemplate, adapt, and adopt new routines into my life.

6. Do 3 Felt experience paragraphs that "fit" the sentence structures in step 5

Growing up, one of my favorite weekend activities with my mother was attending Broadway plays As I have grown older I have been able to spend more time researching and immersing myself in the broadway production process. I learned that when crafting an inspiring theatre production a writer must dismantle their current life and combine it back together in a cohesive story. One of our favorite plays was Come From Away. This play was about an island that was forced to invite airline passengers to stay for over a month because of the 9/11 travel ban. This play was a theatrical retelling of real events that allowed each viewer to understand what the passengers went through during this experience. By transporting ourselves into this new experience we were able to gain a new perspective when approaching problems.

Upon entering this class I had no previous assumptions about the structure or learning style I would be exposed to. But, through carefully reading and rereading each of Sanjiv's letter I have been able to introduce new words and sentence structures into my own life. Each of Sanjiv's letters contains embedded meanings that we are allowed to absorb through repetition like a sponge. I found the most influential letters were the ones that quickly allowed for a connection into my daily life.

Through exposing new readings and experiences I have been able to contemplate, adapt, and adopt new routines into my life. I am currently reading a book called "Lean Brands" that focuses on the way marketing can change and transform throughout decades in different countries. My favorite example thus far has been about coke and their change in logo depending upon the distribution site. When I was in Europe, I was able to experience this change first hand. I found the coke in Europe was marketed different and contained less of a syrupy flavor than the United state's coke.

Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you will continue to err on the side of caution during the holidays.

Your process in the fishbowl supports a creative process steeped in exploration and results in tangible outcomes while promoting self-knowledge, self-expression, and an understanding of your relation to the world. During the pandemic you fostered and formed relationships that were expansive and multivalent.

Your postings return to the idea that an individual’s relationship to a text is itself a dialogue, in which both you and the text participate, listen to one another, and evolve together. Please see Lindsay Dowd’s reflections below. All semester you described the elements of narrative and visual linguistics that formed and transformed you in becoming uniquely inventive thinkers and makers. 

In the end, while committed to sharing your special skills, expertise, and writing strategies, you were largely about cultivating the opportunity and freedom to enter the unknown.

Sanjiv

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 12/14/2020 12:28:26
Subject: The Little Prince as metaphor
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Why The Little Prince is a metaphor?

The little prince represents the open-mindedness of children. He is a wanderer in a fishbowl who restlessly asks questions and is willing to engage the invisible, secret mysteries of the universe. Your fishbowls suggest that such inquisitiveness is the key to understanding and to happiness. 

Though the little prince can't fathom what it is he actually does, he learns that judging yourself is far more difficult, and at times far more important, than judging others. It is only through judging ourselves that we can grow as individuals. This lesson is apparent in your reflections in the fishbowl. Please see Abigail Brown’s posting below.

The metaphor, the image, and the symbol indicates just how small and meek the little prince actually is, though he is often loud and querulous and questioning. Towards the end of the prince’s time in the fishbowl, I realize he was even more fragile than I had thought.

Learning is fragile.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

abigailbrown

Joined: Tue Sep 01, 2020 2:47 pm

Re: Interactive Assignments

Sun Dec 13, 2020 9:13 pm

Reflective Practice

"Reflective practice is, in its simplest form, thinking about or reflecting on what you do. It is closely linked to the concept of learning from experience, in that you think about what you did, and what happened, and decide from that what you would do differently next time."

In the fishbowl I read the letters, interpret the readings, analyze, and put my thoughts and knowledge in the post. Then, I read my classmates posts, and see how they thought. Sometimes, it creates me to analyze even more and compare it to what I said. This allows me to see multiple views, find new ways to interpret, and learn.

Reflective Practice

"Reflective practice is, in its simplest form, thinking about or reflecting on what you do. It is closely linked to the concept of learning from experience, in that you think about what you did, and what happened, and decide from that what you would do differently next time."

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 12/14/2020 0:57:27
Subject: reflective practice
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

If you shared an image, a picture in a frame, to people from different cultures, they would each create a composition of symbols (way of seeing) that would be representative of their cultures. 

In this sense, every image embodies what John Berger calls "a way of seeing": a record of how its creator saw the world. Images can preserve things as they once were, and simultaneously, preserve how their creator once saw their subject.

We each see the same thing differently. We interpret and express ourselves in different ways. Even our silence speaks. We are, each and every one, singular.

The concept of “multiplicity” is a Deleuzian concept and is central to the fishbowl.

You have been following a "reflective practice" and thereby created a "reality of multiplicity" in the fishbowl?

Please relate your fishbowl skills to the skills of reflective practice described in the following:

 

https://www.skillsyouneed.com/ps/reflective-practice.html

Please see Kelsie Poplawski’s posting below.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

kelsiepoplawski

Posts: 213

Joined: Wed Sep 09, 2020 11:45 am

Re: Deconstructing

Sat Dec 12, 2020 5:50 pm

Email: Unity to diverse thoughts 11/27

How does one bring unity to diverse thoughts which we witness as ‘fragments' in the fishbowl?

In the fishbowl we learn from gaining bits and pieces from our letters. We create meaning from new concepts and store then as new learned information and connect them to prior knowledge. It is the building blocks of learning. We are expanding our mindset by witnessing new thoughts and connecting them to past experiences creating a fishbowl of learned and known information to their individual. How does one do it? By observation, perception and analysis. We are developing our take on the concept and how we interpret its meaning. Reading others ideas is the process of seeing the other side to a thought process from another view.

Email: Unity to diverse thoughts 11/27

How does one bring unity to diverse thoughts which we witness as ‘fragments' in the fishbowl?

In the fishbowl we learn from gaining bits and pieces from our letters. We create meaning from new concepts and store then as new learned information and connect them to prior knowledge. It is the building blocks of learning. By observation, perception and analysis. We are developing our take on the concept and how we interpret its meaning. Reading others ideas is the process of seeing the other side to a thought process from another view.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 12/12/2020 19:27:59
Subject: of symbols
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Flesh and Spirit is the true nature of any symbol. It is both material and spiritual; concrete reality conveying an unseen truth. The lion symbolizes strength, the snake is cunning and the dove is peace. I hope you can see how the word, the image, the symbol and the metaphor all sort of overlap in meaning.

Symbols are a constant requirement of human nature, which is made up of both a soul and a body. They allow us to pass from the one to the other by means of an image or a text.

The final assignment, which is optional, requires you to identify six symbols from the fishbowl. You are to select 6 ‘words' that represent your experience and, place them on the table for scrutiny.

Please see Nick Colicci’s postings below. In each posting you have two paragraphs. He takes a symbol, a word, re-searches it and then reflects on his own experience next to it. Some time back, I dubbed him The Little Prince by Antoine de Saint-Exupery (please google). 

"I believe what we do is merge ideas, information, and experiences to move our world forward. We have seen our country hit a roadblock of progress; no one seems to understand or empathize with one another. By sharing ideas and information, we are working to restore the civility and progress of our community. This is our attempt to fight off the "evil" we encounter.” (Colicci, N., Fishbowl, 2020)

You will not recall the face, and surely forget the name, but it is his voice that will live forever.

Sanjiv

DUB

nickcolicci

Posts: 769

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 9:40 am

Constructing your swan song- Google

Wed Dec 09, 2020 11:56 am

Phantasmal Media: An Approach to Imagination, Computation and Expression by D. Fox Harrell- "D. Fox Harrell considers the expressive power of computational media. He argues, forcefully and persuasively, that the great expressive potential of computational media comes from the ability to construct and reveal phantasms—blends of cultural ideas and sensory imagination. These ubiquitous and often-unseen phantasms—cognitive phenomena that include sense of self, metaphors, social categories, narrative, and poetic thinking—influence almost all our everyday experiences. Harrell offers an approach for understanding and designing computational systems that have the power to evoke these phantasms, paying special attention to the exposure of oppressive phantasms and the creation of empowering ones. He argues for the importance of cultural content, diverse worldviews, and social values in computing. The expressive power of phantasms is not purely aesthetic, he contends; phantasmal media can express and construct the types of meaning central to the human condition."

After reading this excerpt I pulled from a Google search, I pulled out the following line "the great expressive potential of computational media comes from the ability to construct and reveal phantasms—blends of cultural ideas and sensory imagination." This stood out to me because it seems our fishbowl is a form of Phantasmal media. By applying our felt experiences to course content, and ultimately blending our perspectives with that of our peers, we are learning how to approach future situations with more of an open mind. In addition, we are creating value for the community and helping our world overcome the constant tension we seem to live in. I would argue that it is time for people across the world to become more invested and concerned with the well-being of others and by engaging ourselves in this form of media, we are taking the necessary step to reach this goal.

context, dichotomy, selection, juxtaposition, making - Google

Sat Dec 12, 2020 10:17 am

Goddess Kali- Ali's earliest appearance is that of a destroyer of evil forces. She is the most powerful form of Shakti, and the goddess of one of the four subcategories of the Kulamārga, a category of Tantric Saivism. She destroys the evil in order to protect the innocent. Over time, Kali has been worshipped by devotional movements and tantric sects variously as the Divine Mother, Mother of the Universe, Adi Shakti, or Adi Parashakti. Shakta Hindu and Tantric sects additionally worship her as the ultimate reality or Brahman. She is also seen as the divine protector and the one who bestows moksha, or liberation.[1] Kali is often portrayed standing or dancing on her consort, the Hindu god Shiva, who lies calm and prostrate beneath her. Kali is worshipped by Hindus throughout India and Nepal.

In reading this quote that I pulled from Wikipedia, I was drawn to the line "he destroys the evil in order to protect the innocent,". I believe our work in the fishbowl serves a similar purpose, though it may not be fighting off "evil" in the severe sense of the word. I believe what we do is merge ideas, information, and experiences to move our world forward. We have seen our country hit a roadblock of progress; no one seems to understand or empathize with one another. By sharing ideas and information, we are working to restore the civility and progress of our community. This is our attempt to fight off the "evil" we encounter.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 12/12/2020 12:55:32
Subject: patterns of attention
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you today? I hope you are keeping well.

I think the message we learn from our time together in the fishbowl is the simple truth that we create each other, bring each other into being by being part of the matrix in which the other exists. 

What is the center of this truth? What did we do or not do? 

How do we turn knowledge, understanding and experience of this truth into money? 

This is after all a business course and not a feel-good session; we have that on demand.

I find myself often exploring the 'nature of attention' that makes such relationships like ours, or any other, possible. 

I think the best hope for making money lies in learning 'new patterns of attention' to each other and to the biosphere, patterns that grow out of curiosity and respect and allow for wonder and learning. 

How so? How do I learn new patterns of attention? How do I determine the nature of my attention currently towards you? It seems to me, that in trying to address such questions, one has to move back and forth between very abstract and very specific levels of focus, and indeed between types of expression varying from poetry to formal analysis. 

Using examples from our felt-experiences is a way of moving from the general to the specific, and also a way of bridging metaphors...a motion through concentric metaphors. We collect stories and weave them together, and a few underlying themes keep surfacing, while any given story suggests new applications. The lesson of whatever I have learned over time is that looking carefully at anything, informs looking at everything. Our task is to learn again to see things whole by respecting and treasuring their “minute particulars.”

In this way we listen with genuine interest to new ideas and questions. Caring attention is surely the basis for our own continuing curiosity and desire to learn. Please see Alyssa Botelho’s reflection below.

Sanjiv

ATTENTION, PATTERN, THEME, MATRIX

from the fishbowl...

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 196

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Technologies of Lived Abstraction

Tue Dec 01, 2020 11:51 am

"Staying with the notion of fragments, we return to them to pick up pieces.

We return to the origin as we continue to be original.

Sharing your notes and note-making is the way of intimacy. "

FRAGMENTS: a small part broken or separated off something.

ORIGIN: the point or place where something begins, arises, or is derived.

ORIGINAL: not dependent on other people's ideas; inventive and unusual.

NOTES: a short informal letter or written message.

INTIMACY: close familiarity or friendship; closeness.

When we go back to broken parts, we try to put them back together. We go back to the place where something begins as we continue to be inventive. Sharing our letters and creating more letters is the way of closeness.

To continue to be "original", we've got to see where our ideas and notes and fragments began. What prompted us to be on the path we're on now? The fragments we share through letters are pieces in a puzzle. They clue us as actors and others as spectators into the intimate details of our origins.

Date: 12/11/2020 22:45:56
Subject: societal impact through thought leadership
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well. 

I was thinking that in a time of stress, I don’t wish to be guilty of piling it on. 

Interaction in the digital environment, every text and image that is exchanged or evoked and brought to mind, will affect us physically and psychologically.

The final assignment is up to you entirely. 

Your grade for the course depends upon both quantity and quality of your postings thus far.

The grading is seldom if ever been an issue because our work is visible. Transparent and authentic.

Ironically, it is the community that determines our grades and the standards that we adhere to. The ideals that we protect.

Fairness is a very American ideal.

If you chose to be in The Audience the entire time, you get a B.

The presumption is that you are reading the text and following it.

B+ is when you made an attempt, vocabulary and google searches, but were more comfortable in the role of The Viewer.

The As and the A minus are The Actors, and I will distinguish them after the 19th.

From today until the 19th, the fishbowl is open for reflection. I will continue to write until then, and continue to talk about the assignment. 

It will sum up the semester for both courses. 

When I scroll your postings I find the focus to be on societal impact through thought leadership. Please see Samantha Plourde’s reflections below.

Sanjiv

IMPACT

samanthaplourde

Posts: 40

Joined: Thu Sep 03, 2020 4:03 pm

Thu Oct 01, 2020 3:25 pm

Soft power- the ability to attract and co-opt rather than coerce. Shaping the preferences of others through appeal and attraction. Joseph Nye was the person to popularize the term in his book Bound To Lead: The Changing Nature of American Power.

Panopticon- type of institutional building and a system of control designed by Jeremy Bentham in the 18th century. The design is supposed to allow all the prisoners of a prison to be observed by only one security guard. The inmates were not able to tell when they were being watched so it made them act as though they were being watched at all times.

David- Goliath story- a biblical story about a giant being defeated by David in single combat.The phrase though “David and Goliath” has become a metaphor for an underdog situation. An underdog situation is when a smaller opponent faces someone with more chances of winning but the smaller opponent wins.

samanthaplourde

Posts: 40

Joined: Thu Sep 03, 2020 4:03 pm

Thu Oct 01, 2020 4:45 pm

Abstract art- “Uses visual language of shape, form, color and line to create a composition which may exist with a degree of independence from visual references from the world”

Other- the constitutive other identify the other human being, in his and her differences, from self, as being a cumulative, constituting factor in the self- imagine of a person; as acknowledgement of being real; hence, the other is dissimilar to and the opposite of the Self, of Us, and of the Same.

samanthaplourde

Posts: 40

Joined: Thu Sep 03, 2020 4:03 pm

Thu Oct 01, 2020 5:24 pm

Deep thinking- the article I looked at was called “Deep thinking in the Age of Distraction.” Deep thinking is a way to increase our number of valuable thoughts, because we are constantly plugged in to our electronics there is a barrier between us and our deep thoughts. I think deep thinking does not have to be meditating as some people think but it can be unjust unplugging and taking deep breaths and connecting to your thoughts.

samanthaplourde

Joined: Thu Sep 03, 2020 4:03 pm

 Tue Nov 10, 2020 9:13 pm

Immersion Technology- refers to technology that attempts to emulate a physical world through the means of a digital or simulated world by creating the sensory feeling, thereby creating a sense of immersion.

Logistics- The detailed organization and implementation of a complex operation. Logistics is the management of the flow of things between the point of origin and the point of consumption to meet requirements.

Social Constructivism- a sociological theory of knowledge according to which human development is socially situated and knowledge is constructed through interaction with others

Johnathon Livingston Seagull- A book written by Richard Bach and illustrated by Russell Munson. A fictional story about a seagull who is trying to learn about life and flight. It was written as a series of short stories published in Flying Magazine in the late 1960s.

Big data- a field that treats ways to analyze, systematically extract information from, or otherwise deal with data sets that are too large or complex to be dealt with by traditional data processing application software.

Reflexive thinking- Refers to circular relationships between cause and effect, especially as embedded in human belief structures. A reflexive relationship is bidirectional with both cause and effect affecting one another in a relationship in which neither can be assigned as causes or effects.

samanthaplourde

Posts: 40

Joined: Thu Sep 03, 2020 4:03 pm

Thu Dec 03, 2020 6:33 pm

Bergsonism- The theories of the philosopher Bergson according to whom the world is a process of creative evolution in which the novelty of successive phenomena rather than the constancy of natural law is a significant fact, reality being regarded as time or duration that is the same as free motion and that is the expression of a vital impetus or creative force.

samanthaplourde

Posts: 40

Joined: Thu Sep 03, 2020 4:03 pm

Thu Dec 10, 2020 8:02 pm

Linda Smircich- professor of management in the isenberg school of management. She teaches organizational alternative paradigms.

Experiential learning- the process of learning through experience, and is more specifically defined as “learning through reflection on doing”. Hands on learning is not the same as experiential learning because during hands on learning you are not always reflecting.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 12/11/2020 22:44:49
Subject: societal impact through thought leadership
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are keeping well. 

I was thinking that in a time of stress, I don’t wish to be guilty of piling it on. 

Interaction in the digital environment, every text and image that is exchanged or evoked and brought to mind, will affect us physically and psychologically.

The final assignment is up to you entirely. 

Your grade for the course depends upon both quantity and quality of your postings thus far.

The grading is seldom if ever been an issue because our work is visible. Transparent and authentic.

Ironically, it is the community that determines our grades and the standards that we adhere to. The ideals that we protect.

Fairness is a very American ideal.

If you chose to be in The Audience the entire time, you get a B.

The presumption is that you are reading the text and following it.

B+ is when you made an attempt, vocabulary and google searches, but were more comfortable in the role of The Viewer.

The As and the A minus are The Actors, and I will distinguish them after the 19th.

From today until the 19th, the fishbowl is open for reflection. I will continue to write until then, and continue to talk about the assignment. 

It will sum up the semester for both courses. 

When I scroll your postings I find the focus to be on societal impact through thought leadership. Please see Samantha Plourde’s reflections below.

Sanjiv

IMPACT

from the fishbowl...

Thu Oct 01, 2020 3:25 pm

Soft power- the ability to attract and co-opt rather than coerce. Shaping the preferences of others through appeal and attraction. Joseph Nye was the person to popularize the term in his book Bound To Lead: The Changing Nature of American Power.

Panopticon- type of institutional building and a system of control designed by Jeremy Bentham in the 18th century. The design is supposed to allow all the prisoners of a prison to be observed by only one security guard. The inmates were not able to tell when they were being watched so it made them act as though they were being watched at all times.

David- Goliath story- a biblical story about a giant being defeated by David in single combat.The phrase though “David and Goliath” has become a metaphor for an underdog situation. An underdog situation is when a smaller opponent faces someone with more chances of winning but the smaller opponent wins.

samanthaplourde

Posts: 40

Joined: Thu Sep 03, 2020 4:03 pm

Thu Oct 01, 2020 4:45 pm

Abstract art- “Uses visual language of shape, form, color and line to create a composition which may exist with a degree of independence from visual references from the world”

Other- the constitutive other identify the other human being, in his and her differences, from self, as being a cumulative, constituting factor in the self- imagine of a person; as acknowledgement of being real; hence, the other is dissimilar to and the opposite of the Self, of Us, and of the Same.

samanthaplourde

Posts: 40

Joined: Thu Sep 03, 2020 4:03 pm

Thu Oct 01, 2020 5:24 pm

Deep thinking- the article I looked at was called “Deep thinking in the Age of Distraction.” Deep thinking is a way to increase our number of valuable thoughts, because we are constantly plugged in to our electronics there is a barrier between us and our deep thoughts. I think deep thinking does not have to be meditating as some people think but it can be unjust unplugging and taking deep breaths and connecting to your thoughts.

Joined: Thu Sep 03, 2020 4:03 pm

 Tue Nov 10, 2020 9:13 pm

Immersion Technology- refers to technology that attempts to emulate a physical world through the means of a digital or simulated world by creating the sensory feeling, thereby creating a sense of immersion.

Logistics- The detailed organization and implementation of a complex operation. Logistics is the management of the flow of things between the point of origin and the point of consumption to meet requirements.

Social Constructivism- a sociological theory of knowledge according to which human development is socially situated and knowledge is constructed through interaction with others

Johnathon Livingston Seagull- A book written by Richard Bach and illustrated by Russell Munson. A fictional story about a seagull who is trying to learn about life and flight. It was written as a series of short stories published in Flying Magazine in the late 1960s.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 12/1/2020 21:41:35
Subject: self valorization
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

In certain sectors all over the world, we’re moving toward new forms of production that involve more ‘immaterial’ forms of labor, flexible and precarious networks, and commodities increasingly defined in terms of culture and media. If we view our situation in the fishbowl in these terms and also in our personal lives, we won’t be far from the truth. 

Please consider your fishbowl as a new form of production that is constituted by ‘immaterial' forms of labor. Please google Immaterial labor by M. Lazzarato.

Please see an example of new forms of production by Alyssa Botelho below.

1. You have been experimenting in new forms of thinking in a digital environment. Your purpose is to help your viewers conceive innovative practices for themselves, aka, entrepreneurship, yours and theirs. Your primary focus has been to present a contemporary mode of thinking and communicating it. You clearly succeed in being transparent and authentic. Every single posting of yours.

2. You are experimenting together in new democratic forms of social organization and action in horizontal, nonhierarchical networks. You value Autonomy and Resist control from any kind of Authority arising from within the fishbowl, except your own inner passion and drives. 

3. You raise the question of the moment: how do you 'give or ascribe value or validity' to what you post. You teach the viewer that the concept of self-valorization is the building block for constructing a new form of sociality, a new society. Please consider that thought from Marx.

Sanjiv

CONTEMPORARY, FORM, MODE, AUTONOMY, CONTROL, AUTHORITY, RESIST, DRIVE, LABOR, FLEXIBLE, PRECARIOUS, VALORIZE, ASCRIBE, VALID

from the fishbowl...

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Sat Nov 14, 2020 11:43 am

“Followers (i.e., the audience) and leaders (i.e., the actors) are bound together in the transformation process, which I think helps describe pretty well what is happening here. We should all strive to be a transformational leader in the fishbowl.” (Olivia Palumbo, Fishbowl, 20)

FOLLOWERS: a person who moves or travels behind someone or something.

AUDIENCE: the assembled spectators or listeners at a public event, such as a play, movie, concert, or meeting.

LEADERS: the person who leads or commands a group, organization, or country.

ACTORS: a participant in an action or process.

BOUND TOGETHER: share a particular experience or situation that causes them to have a relationship.

TRANSFORMATION: a thorough or dramatic change in form or appearance.

Those who travel behind and those who command the expedition (the spectators and participants) have a relationship through their sharing of the process of dramatic change.

Whether you choose to be a leader or you choose to be a follower, we are all in this together. By experiencing The Fishbowl together, we undergo a transformation, a change, an influencing of the mind and intellect. We are learning about each other in a way that only The Fishbowl can provide.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Tue Nov 17, 2020 4:11 pm

"If you don’t read, then you are not listening to the text."

READ: look at and comprehend the meaning of (written or printed matter) by mentally interpreting the characters or symbols of which it is composed.

LISTEN: make an effort to hear something; be alert and ready to hear something.

TEXT: a book or other written or printed work, regarded in terms of its content rather than its physical form.

If you don't look and and comprehend the words, then you aren't making an effort to hear what the content of the written work has to say.

In a digital learning environment, we have even more responsibility to be active readers. We must go out of our way to dig deep into the words on our screens so that we may understand their meaning. If we don't, we will be lost and learn very little (if anything at all).

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Tue Nov 17, 2020 4:27 pm

"Without this critical, judging faculty the doer or maker would be so isolated from the spectator that he would not even be perceived."

CRITICAL: expressing or involving an analysis of the merits and faults of a work of literature, music, or art.

FACULTY: an aptitude or talent for doing something.

DOER: the person who does something.

ISOLATED: having minimal contact or little in common with others.

SPECTATOR: a person who watches at a show, game, or other event.

PERCEIVED: become aware or conscious of (something); come to realize or understand.

Without the capability to analyze, the performing part of the actor would be so removed from the watching part that the actor would not even be aware of what they're doing.

The ability to reflect and analyze our actions is what makes us aware of what we are doing. It is when our brain goes on "auto pilot" that we forgot what we have done. When I routinely shop at the grocery store, I am not conscious of everything I'm doing. On the other hand, if I were being watched by a marketing surveyor, I would become self-conscious of my actions. I would begin to reflect and analyze what I am doing, because I know that someone else is doing it too.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Tue Nov 17, 2020 5:58 pm

"Acting by focusing on words became a search for self-knowledge and awareness."

ACTING: the art or occupation of performing in plays, movies, or television productions.

FOCUSING: pay particular attention to.

WORDS: something spoken or written; a remark or statement.

SEARCH: try to find something by looking or otherwise seeking carefully and thoroughly.

AWARENESS: knowledge or perception of a situation or fact.

Performing by paying close attention on something that's written became a quest to find information about the self and general knowledge.

In The Fishbowl, we have been concentrating on written text and reforming it with our own personal filters. We are remolding words to express and discover our feelings and knowledge. When we share this with others, we put on a performance. Through our writings, we act for the spectator as the spectator themself begins to reform our words with their personal filter. The cycle continues.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Sat Nov 21, 2020 12:14 am

“Suddenly technology has given us powers with which we can manipulate not only external reality---the physical world--- but also, and much more portentously, ourselves. You can become whatever you want to be,” (Ed Regis)

TECHNOLOGY: the practical application of knowledge especially in a particular area

POWER: ability to act or produce an effect

MANIPULATE: to manage or utilize skillfully

PORTENTOUSLY: self-consciously solemn or important

The practical application of knowledge has given us new abilities to manage our worlds and even more importantly, ourselves. We can develop into anything we imagine.

I have always been a "dreamer". Growing up, my dad always said that I could achieve anything I set my mind to. I took that to heart and when I found my passion for filmmaking, I chased it unrelentingly. Even though it may seem impossible and impractical to want to become a successful filmmaker, I know that I am in charge of my own destiny. Technology has already brought me so many incredible opportunities that my ancestors have not had. Especially as a woman pursuing a career in a male-dominated field, I recognize and deeply appreciate these new technological resources that I have to leverage my goal of breaking the glass ceiling!

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Mon Nov 23, 2020 2:59 pm

"The world is a stage and we are merely players."

WORLD: all of the people, societies, and institutions on the earth.

STAGE: a raised floor or platform, typically in a theater, on which actors, entertainers, or speakers perform.

PLAYERS: an actor.

All of earth's societies form a raised platform for performing where we are the actors.

The quote above is from Shakespeare's play "As You Like It" where he writes about there being multiple stages of a person's life and in each of them, a person plays a different role. Every day, we are presented with a set of opportunities to perform and play the role of ourselves. As we grow older, our choices shift and grow and develop. We become different than the person, the performer, that we once were. Even as our current performances grow different than our past, there is still a thread that runs through them all, connecting them. It is this thread that identifies us as the performer, the person, that we are.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Tue Nov 24, 2020 6:04 pm

"One thing is clear: old boundaries and categories, old frames and frameworks no longer apply. Nevertheless, it is the awareness and ability to identify and respect tradition that is at the heart of success in the 'business of ideas', and the whole shebang in 345 and 448."

BOUNDARIES: a limit of a subject or sphere of activity.

CATEGORIES: a class or division of people or things regarded as having particular shared characteristics.

FRAMEWORKS: a basic structure underlying a system, concept, or text.

IDENTIFY: recognize or distinguish (especially something considered worthy of attention).

RESPECT: due regard for the feelings, wishes, rights, or traditions of others.

TRADITION: the transmission of customs or beliefs from generation to generation, or the fact of being passed on in this way.

Old limits, divisions of things, and system structures aren't necessarily relevant anymore. Even so, it is important to know, to recognize, and to have regard for generational customs that have defined what success means in the business world for so long.

Even though the technology age that we are living in has transformed so much of the business world to the point where old customs don't make much sense anymore, it is important to still know the history. By knowing the history, we can take away certain values and beliefs that still apply today, like behaving ethically. We can also have a deeper appreciation for the resources that the technology age has brought us when we realize how much more difficult it was to conduct business in the past.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Fri Nov 27, 2020 5:37 pm

"The one thing we cannot afford is inaction due to despair or indifference."

AFFORD: be able to do something without risk of adverse consequences.

INACTION: lack of action where some is expected or appropriate.

DESPAIR: the complete loss or absence of hope.

INDIFFERENCE: lack of interest, concern, or sympathy.

We cannot risk a lack of action because of the absence of hope or interest.

To achieve our goals, we must keep moving. We've got to keep going when we are downtrodden and tired -- ESPECIALLY when we are downtrodden and tired. It is in these times of despair, indifference, exhaustion, when we have the opportunity to redefine our limits. If we are never pushed beyond our perceived limitations, we will never grow. If we never grow, we will never achieve our goals.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Sun Nov 29, 2020 2:40 pm

“Everything then depends on how the possibility opened up by the ‘event' is grasped, elaborated and embedded in the world."

GRAPSED: get mental hold of; comprehend fully.

ELABORATED: develop or present (a theory, policy, or system) in detail.

EMBEDDED: (of an object) fixed firmly and deeply in a surrounding mass; implanted.

Everything relies on how the impact of the thing that took place is comprehended, developed, and implanted into the world.

When Steve Jobs released the iPhone, a huge possibility was opened up in the world. Although the creation of the device itself was significant, it was how this creation was grasped, elaborated, and embedded into the world that was truly transformational. If the world chose not to comprehend the device, to develop it further, or to implant it into everyday life, it would have remained just that. A device. The technological revolution was sparked by Steve Jobs' contribution to the world, but it was the way the world reacted to his contribution that sustained the tech revolution's fire, forever changing the way we all work and live.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Sun Nov 29, 2020 3:26 pm

"Any outcome of a creative process contains the energy of commitment to it."

CREATIVE: relating to or involving the imagination or original ideas, especially in the production of an artistic work.

PROCESS: a series of actions or steps taken in order to achieve a particular end.

ENERGY: a person's physical and mental powers, typically as applied to a particular task or activity.

COMMITMENT: the state or quality of being dedicated to a cause, activity, etc.

Any product of imaginative action is evidence of a person's physical and mental powers as well as their dedication to their work.

This is a good explanation for why artists are heavily identified by their work. An artist's creations are the result of an intensive process that requires all of their mind, body, and dedication. As "actors" here in the Fishbowl, we are going through a creative process that requires us to interpret and redefine words. Through our writings, our mental powers and dedication are revealed. Spectators can then identify who we are.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Tue Dec 01, 2020 11:51 am

"Staying with the notion of fragments, we return to them to pick up pieces.

We return to the origin as we continue to be original.

Sharing your notes and note-making is the way of intimacy. "

FRAGMENTS: a small part broken or separated off something.

ORIGIN: the point or place where something begins, arises, or is derived.

ORIGINAL: not dependent on other people's ideas; inventive and unusual.

NOTES: a short informal letter or written message.

INTIMACY: close familiarity or friendship; closeness.

When we go back to broken parts, we try to put them back together. We go back to the place where something begins as we continue to be inventive. Sharing our letters and creating more letters is the way of closeness.

To continue to be "original", we've got to see where our ideas and notes and fragments began. What prompted us to be on the path we're on now? The fragments we share through letters are pieces in a puzzle. They clue us as actors and others as spectators into the intimate details of our origins.

It is in these times of despair, indifference, exhaustion, when we have the opportunity to redefine our limits. If we are never pushed beyond our perceived limitations, we will never grow. If we never grow, we will never achieve our goals.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Sun Nov 29, 2020 2:40 pm

“Everything then depends on how the possibility opened up by the ‘event' is grasped, elaborated and embedded in the world."

GRAPSED: get mental hold of; comprehend fully.

ELABORATED: develop or present (a theory, policy, or system) in detail.

EMBEDDED: (of an object) fixed firmly and deeply in a surrounding mass; implanted.

Everything relies on how the impact of the thing that took place is comprehended, developed, and implanted into the world.

When Steve Jobs released the iPhone, a huge possibility was opened up in the world. Although the creation of the device itself was significant, it was how this creation was grasped, elaborated, and embedded into the world that was truly transformational. If the world chose not to comprehend the device, to develop it further, or to implant it into everyday life, it would have remained just that. A device. The technological revolution was sparked by Steve Jobs' contribution to the world, but it was the way the world reacted to his contribution that sustained the tech revolution's fire, forever changing the way we all work and live.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Sun Nov 29, 2020 3:26 pm

"Any outcome of a creative process contains the energy of commitment to it."

CREATIVE: relating to or involving the imagination or original ideas, especially in the production of an artistic work.

PROCESS: a series of actions or steps taken in order to achieve a particular end.

ENERGY: a person's physical and mental powers, typically as applied to a particular task or activity.

COMMITMENT: the state or quality of being dedicated to a cause, activity, etc.

Any product of imaginative action is evidence of a person's physical and mental powers as well as their dedication to their work.

This is a good explanation for why artists are heavily identified by their work. An artist's creations are the result of an intensive process that requires all of their mind, body, and dedication. As "actors" here in the Fishbowl, we are going through a creative process that requires us to interpret and redefine words. Through our writings, our mental powers and dedication are revealed. Spectators can then identify who we are.

AlyssaBotelho

Posts: 184

Joined: Mon Sep 07, 2020 5:26 pm

Tue Dec 01, 2020 11:51 am

"Staying with the notion of fragments, we return to them to pick up pieces.

We return to the origin as we continue to be original.

Sharing your notes and note-making is the way of intimacy. "

FRAGMENTS: a small part broken or separated off something.

ORIGIN: the point or place where something begins, arises, or is derived.

ORIGINAL: not dependent on other people's ideas; inventive and unusual.

NOTES: a short informal letter or written message.

INTIMACY: close familiarity or friendship; closeness.

When we go back to broken parts, we try to put them back together. We go back to the place where something begins as we continue to be inventive. Sharing our letters and creating more letters is the way of closeness.

To continue to be "original", we've got to see where our ideas and notes and fragments began. What prompted us to be on the path we're on now? The fragments we share through letters are pieces in a puzzle. They clue us as actors and others as spectators into the intimate details of our origins.

Date: 11/30/2020 12:54:16
Subject: technologies of lived abstraction
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I’ve found I learn in fragments. 

I like the word and its image, i.e., the concept ‘fragment.’ 

What does it mean?

The fishbowl, of which you are authors and creators, is "a work of brief meditations, of poetic musings": in a word, of fragments.

‘Fragment' has a meaning worth checking for clarity and nuance. See Fragments by Jean Baudrillard.

I started with the word fragment based upon a feeling this morning regarding the fishbowl.

My life, i.e., the fishbowl, is made of fragments. 

Please google Baudrillard’s “precession of simulacra."

If you can experience this abstraction in the fishbowl (technology of lived abstraction) and get it under your belt, you’re ahead of the game when you graduate. 

Staying with the notion of fragments, we return to them to pick up pieces. 

We return to the origin as we continue to be original. 

Sharing your notes and note-making is the way of intimacy. 

Ours is a living text. It is work in motion and progress. 

Nothing is fixed. It is never finished nor completed, for it lives, like a never-ending story, breathing forever. Please google Scheherazade.

Our challenge then is to find a thread, a link, a bridge, a structure, a sentence that connects different events that constitute our fragments.

How do we do that? How do I first, link my own fragments, and then, How do I connect the links made by others with their own fragments?

Complexity and Chaos is the name of the game. All metaphors. What would we do without them? I never leave home without one.

Fragments as a whole is the Context. I determine that after scrolling the fishbowl. “You’re always thinking,” she said.

This linking between scenarios, between scenes, between paragraphs, between fragments is a technique that we are acquiring in both courses; Society and Culture.

We are moving ideas (words), we are inching forward. We are accounting for our knowledge content and, in-keeping with the metaphor of theatre, we are actors, writing and performing our lines. Also known as "Performative writing/performative inquiry." please google the term.

Implementing a technique for creating knowledge content.

An example:

 

I choose to Engage with April Younkin’s text by Selecting one sentence from it.

I choose to Engage with Joseph Dugas’ text by Selecting one sentence from it.

1."It is important to recognize and reflect on significant images and to formulate ideas within an interconnecting network." (Younkin, 2020)

2. "You develop a point of view by diving deep into your inner thoughts and progress what is important to you." (Dugas, 2020)

So I Juxtapose the two ideas, all the while I am working hard and focused and energized and interested in the possibilities of the outcomes. 

I start by constructing dichotomies. How so? Got to Feel your way.

"seeing the bigger picture and thinking in systems, you have to recognize and reflect on significant images (Younkin)-------"dive deep into inner thoughts and progress, for it is essential to individuality in the world" (Dugas). "You have to formulate ideas within an interconnecting world”. (Younkin).

recognize and reflect on images

formulate ideas by interconnecting networks

dive deep into inner thoughts for progress

essential to determine your place in the world.

Getting specific with creating dichotomies:

recognize/formulate

reflect/network

image/inner

deep/essential

determine/thoughts

Next step for creating/constructing knowledge content is to Develop your dichotomies. 

Please stay tuned. We’re back and we never left (contradiction, paradox and irony are part of this new order).

Please google the term Technologies of Lived Abstraction.

Sanjiv

FRAGMENT, SIMULACRA, CONTEXT, DETERMINE, DEVELOP, DICHOTOMY, LINK

from the fishbowl...

“What is required is keeping the faith”

Word Pool:

- Required: Stipulated as necessary to be done, made, or provided and/or essential.

- Keeping: The action of owning, maintaining, or protecting something.

- Faith: Complete trust or confidence in someone or something.

Reconstruction:

- Maintaining complete trust in oneself and/or each other is essential.

Felt-Experience:

- To have faith in oneself and/or each other is especially important during these trying times. Although I think that the pandemic will get worse before it gets better, I believe that we will persevere. I trust that we will find a way to pull ourselves out of such a scary and vulnerable situation. There doesn’t seem to be an end right now, but I am still hopeful.

“To see the bigger picture and to think in systems.”

Word Pool:

- See: To discern or deduce mentally after reflection or from information.

- Bigger: Of considerable size, extent, or intensity and/or of considerable importance.

- Picture: A design or representation of an image made by various means.

- Think: To have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.

- Systems: A set of things working together as parts of a mechanism or an interconnecting network.

Reconstruction:

- It is important to recognize and reflect on significant images and to formulate ideas within an interconnecting network.

Felt-Experience:

- This reminds me of when I used to be on a sports team. We had to think as a team. For every play, each team member had a different place to be. We had individual tasks and positions, but ultimately, we were one system working towards to same goal. I had to pull my own weight; otherwise I would have let the team down. On the other hand, I had to trust my team members to play their position well. We played as a team, and we won or lost as a team. We had to look and think broader to see that each player’s unique expertise contributed to the overall bigger picture. We were many parts that made up a whole.

josephdugas

Sat Nov 28, 2020 12:03 pm

unity of diverse thoughts

"How do we state a clear message in a simple sentence. Something coherent and of value. To someone.

How do we develop a point of view?

How do we lead and show the way? "

You develop a point of view by diving deep into your inner thoughts and progress what is important to you. Having a point of view is essential to your individuality in this world. For me, it is often hard for me to change my view when I have articulated it myself, but I am always open to hear others. And we lead and show the way by verbalizing and expressing our view to others. It is important not to expect someone to accept it, but hearing you out is what you should expect. Overall, different point of views are the glue that sticks society together, to bring new ideas and challenge each other for a value of change.

Date: 11/28/2020 0:25:14
Subject: unity to diverse thoughts
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

The challenge and task before us as humans is to give meaning to one's self-generated text, as we see in jbutler17's postings.

The world applauds this courage and desire, and effort to learn. To express. To create. 

How does one bring unity to diverse thoughts which we witness as ‘fragments' in the fishbowl? 

How do we state a clear message in a simple sentence. Something coherent and of value. To someone.

How do we develop a point of view? 

How do we lead and show the way? 

How do I give an account of myself?

In other words, what do I have to do: To create and construct meaning. 

Any outcome of a creative process contains the energy of commitment to it. 

You have to do something. 

jbutler has to “make the text more real." 

If I select theatre as a metaphor, then my lines as an actor have to be addressed. What is the final scene going to be? The final act. 

How do you say good bye?

The selection of theatre was a creative act. An important decision because it affects both process and the outcome.

The ground work (metaphor) is already set up in jbutler17's text.

How so? 

When I examined the tools needed for taking action, in order to create meaning, I came up with the following basic necessary ingredients, and the postings below cover most of them...

1. context....laid out in jbutler's postings

2. articulation...expression and voice of postings

3. intention...engagement and course grade

4. attention...scrutiny and focus

5. magnetism ... interest and appeal

6. attitude...learning and growth

7. content...knowledge and experience

8. time...contemplation and meditation

The classic recipe for effective theatre is threefold:

1. you need something to say

2. you need technique, and

3. you need passion.

Like a stool, if one leg is missing, the stool will topple over. It’s as simple as that.

What is one's technique whenever one says something meaningful?

What is one's process when creating a sentence?

How does one evoke interest and appeal?

The point is how do you create and construct meaning from the text below: it is the question on the table. 

For convenience, I think about what I am doing in terms of the following injunctions (Gareth Morgan, Images of Organizations, p.301), 

same as you are doing in your fishbowls (please fact check in the fishbowl):

1. “Get inside”

2. Adopt the role of learner

3. “Map the terrain”

4. Identify key themes and interpretations (to produce an evolving “reading” of the situation)

5. Confirm, refute, and reformulate throughout

At another level, what is required is keeping the faith, but you have to work, work and work. Reading and writing. There is nothing outside text. In the beginning is the word!

We will discuss how to give meaning to diverse thoughts in one’s text. Stay with the process of deconstruction and vocabulary and felt-experiences. IT is work. Labor. It is learning to think in metaphor; to see the bigger picture and to think in systems. Like theatre in my example. At a scientific level it is one’s right side of brain which allows us to do that.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

Pre-Letter 01: Syllabus - Summary and Paraphrase

Introduction: The emphasis of this class is the study and observation of social transformations and interactions during the current era of CMC. We'll focus on two parts called "the individualization of work and the fragmentation of societies".

Building A Society | The Network and Visual Reality: Treating one's group of three members as a world unto itself, students should closely observe the "flow" of information both to and from yourself and your teammates. The eventual lesson should incorporate an understanding of how the student perceives both the world in which he or she sees and how they have thus far interacted within. Side note: keep in mind how outside experiences and personalities may affect either interpretation or misinterpretation to/from one another within the networked society created by the three members.

Course Method | Ethnographic Action Research: Keeping an objective understanding of various societal influences in mind, students are expected to become somewhat fully immersed within multiple informational forces to include both content and means or influences behind the method of delivery. [keep in mind epistemology (distinction btw knowledge, beliefs, and perceived truths), is the purpose to expand the understanding of our own visual realities?] Part of the immersion involves the deconstruction of Letters, observation of peers' method of articulation, understanding of effective communication, and adaptation or re-adjustments to communication methods.

New words: Ethnographic, 'communicative ecologies'.

Course Dictum | Describe Things: [check old notes relating to David Hume, the limits of causal relationships and experience in general (resemblance, contiguity, and cause and effect?)] The goal is to attempt to identify objective descriptors for the things presented throughout the course of instruction while remaining aware but separate from independent or personal influences/biases towards the describing of a thing. Things may include anything from written works and texts, correspondence, one's personal experiences, and anything in-between.

New/interesting words: phenomenology, intellectual clutter

Practice and Process: Start things off in this course by being non-judgementally receptive to words in and of themselves. Comprehension of words and phrases can lead to the respect of the thing/word as well as it's application to one's self such that mental freedom and a clear understanding of one's ideas or experiences within a society are gained.

"Is there a text in this class?": There's no official class textbook; instead, various supplementary readings will be made available. See the syllabus for listing.

Assessment and Evaluation | Forming a Society: Grade based on the perceived development and ability to convince others of "semantic and action-orienting powers". Emphasis is on information channel diversity and perceived credibility.

Grade | Distribution: 40% = Interactive Activities focusing on characteristics of Transnational Organizations. 20% = Quality of presentation in forums requiring deep reading and understanding of "concepts, images, and perspectives" (hint: slower in-depth reading is critical). 20% = Letter Deconstruction and Analysis (requires identifying implied premises/points and analogies for proper understanding). 20% = ability to self-reflect and adapt throughout this course as new information is received.

Finally | Individuation: (Individuation = Projection of one's self and their independent qualities from other's as well as the understanding of how/why such projection is made and how it may be perceived) Grade = level of engagement with groups/materials + creation of value through thoughtful or quality posts in Fishbowl. Ended with a list of required forum subjects to be posted under (Notes: Taking and Making, Vocabulary: Concepts and Word-images, Reading and Deconstructing Text, Interactive Assignments, and Individual Assignments).

Epilogue: Quote about sublime word-word, Addendum 1 = required statement of objectives of the course from URI, Addendum 2 = primary technologies required/used by the course, Social technologies, educational technologies, and intellectual technologies.

Letter 02: Welcome again and again...always welcome

Summary/Paraphrase with own thoughts:

The point of repetitious statements is for the reinforcement of ideas for the course (reminiscent of the idea that if you hear something three times then it's harder to forget).

The approach to this class should include thinking of The Fishbowl as THE METAPHOR for your mental space, visual space, and inter-subjective space.

Between us = you + me, you + your group, you + your class. (Navy saying, "One team, one fight!")

Process > outcome

Opportunities to show our processes are how we learn to acquire "soft-power". A wordsmith can be anyone who expresses themselves with some manifestation of their inner visualizations with an emphasis on the process (how they express it) rather than their outcome (the result of the expression).

Asynchronous = nobody is required to be on at the same time as another.

This approach is metaphorically similar to a "David-Goliath" story for doing business. Expect letters to be akin to a higher peak (more intense plateau) which builds upon the previous letter while remaining chiefly independent. Look up Deleuze and Guattari's "A Thousand Plateaus". (Concept of interconnectedness reminds me of "The Web of Life" by Fritjof Capra.)

Keywords and Vocab will be in all CAPITAL letters within the emails.

Vocab: ASYNCHRONOUS, SELECT, EVOLVE, UNFOLD, ABSORB, soft-power

Letter 03: searching for nuggets: watching, looking, seeing

The course made for developing the skill of "Abstraction".

Consider differences in what's seen, said, etc. (The implication is something like a student who's unsure if he/she is doing a project correctly, so they ask how another group is "going about" the project, and then upon seeing their approach/method/effort adjusts his/her own.)

Letter 06: some logistics on a Sunday morning

Summary and Paraphrase with personal thoughts:

There's a lot to do but we should have some type of routine by this point and be thinking of ourselves as "craftsmen of words".

*Metaphor: "this semester is precarious and fragile, like a porcelain workshop". --> So, my question or line of thought to this is: Within the bounds of this "workshop", if we break up the tools, the clay and such, and the shelves which the vases rest before going to a store shelf, then what makes up or represents each component? Obviously, The Fishbowl represents the structure or building itself for the workshop; but then are the Letters the raw clay, are our hands and eyes the tools by which we shape and add styles to the newly made vases, and our classmates the shelves that we must then place the vases? If so, then we must consider the strength of each as well as ourselves because even if our tools are sharp, the clay is pure, and the building sound, a weak shelf could leave everything shattered... However, until I provide my own shelf the quality of another's will remain an unknown factor.

The purpose of The Fishbowl's structure is not to allow forums subject to criticism, but forums for openly silent observation. Replies and messages should be private, not public.

Repeat about posting in your own space while comparing content production to your team's products.

It's about the symbol = language game requiring avoidance of distractions and focus. This is all one big experiment. --> So, then are we the lab rats? Is this about intuitively building up the ability to navigate mazes (another metaphor).

Consider both implied and stated premises. --> Perhaps put certain statements into argument structure to make identification easier.

Letter 11: a fishbowl state of mind

Summary/Interpretation/Takeaways: Reiteration about us a) learning at our own paces and b) learning to stay abreast with our group/fishbowl.

We will get a B by entering the door, some effort is required to get higher but there are no such performance expectations nor deadlines (I can reasonably assume that if one has not at least made their Subtopic headings then they cannot be seen to have entered through the door of said course, therefore failure to attempt anything whatsoever could be justified with a C or less). ------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 11/28/2020 0:24:39
Subject: unity to diverse thoughts
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

The challenge and task before us as humans is to give meaning to one's self-generated text, as we see in jbutler17's postings.

The world applauds this courage and desire, and effort to learn. To express. To create.

How does one bring unity to diverse thoughts which we witness as ‘fragments' in the fishbowl?

How do we state a clear message in a simple sentence. Something coherent and of value. To someone.

How do we develop a point of view?

How do we lead and show the way?

How do I give an account of myself?

In other words, what do I have to do: To create and construct meaning.

Any outcome of a creative process contains the energy of commitment to it.

You have to do something.

jbutler has to “make the text more real."

If I select theatre as a metaphor, then my lines as an actor have to be addressed. What is the final scene going to be? The final act.

How do you say good bye?

The selection of theatre was a creative act. An important decision because it affects both process and the outcome.

The ground work (metaphor) is already set up in jbutler17's text.

How so?

When I examined the tools needed for taking action, in order to create meaning, I came up with the following basic necessary ingredients, and the postings below cover most of them...

1. context....laid out in jbutler's postings

2. articulation...expression and voice of postings

3. intention...engagement and course grade

4. attention...scrutiny and focus

5. magnetism ... interest and appeal

6. attitude...learning and growth

7. content...knowledge and experience

8. time...contemplation and meditation

The classic recipe for effective theatre is threefold:

1. you need something to say

2. you need technique, and

3. you need passion.

Like a stool, if one leg is missing, the stool will topple over. It’s as simple as that.

What is one's technique whenever one says something meaningful?

What is one's process when creating a sentence?

How does one evoke interest and appeal?

The point is how do you create and construct meaning from the text below: it is the question on the table.

For convenience, I think about what I am doing in terms of the following injunctions (Gareth Morgan, Images of Organizations, p.301),

same as you are doing in your fishbowls (please fact check in the fishbowl):

1. “Get inside”

2. Adopt the role of learner

3. “Map the terrain”

4. Identify key themes and interpretations (to produce an evolving “reading” of the situation)

5. Confirm, refute, and reformulate throughout

At another level, what is required is keeping the faith, but you have to work, work and work. Reading and writing. There is nothing outside text. In the beginning is the word!

We will discuss how to give meaning to diverse thoughts in one’s text. Stay with the process of deconstruction and vocabulary and felt-experiences. IT is work. Labor. It is learning to think in metaphor; to see the bigger picture and to think in systems. Like theatre in my example. At a scientific level it is one’s right side of brain which allows us to do that.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...
