Pre-Letter 01: Syllabus - Summary and Paraphrase

Introduction: The emphasis of this class is the study and observation of social transformations and interactions during the current era of CMC. We'll focus on two parts called "the individualization of work and the fragmentation of societies".

Building A Society | The Network and Visual Reality: Treating one's group of three members as a world unto itself, students should closely observe the "flow" of information both to and from yourself and your teammates. The eventual lesson should incorporate an understanding of how the student perceives both the world in which he or she sees and how they have thus far interacted within. Side note: keep in mind how outside experiences and personalities may affect either interpretation or misinterpretation to/from one another within the networked society created by the three members.

Course Method | Ethnographic Action Research: Keeping an objective understanding of various societal influences in mind, students are expected to become somewhat fully immersed within multiple informational forces to include both content and means or influences behind the method of delivery. [keep in mind epistemology (distinction btw knowledge, beliefs, and perceived truths), is the purpose to expand the understanding of our own visual realities?] Part of the immersion involves the deconstruction of Letters, observation of peers' method of articulation, understanding of effective communication, and adaptation or re-adjustments to communication methods.

New words: Ethnographic, 'communicative ecologies'.

Course Dictum | Describe Things: [check old notes relating to David Hume, the limits of causal relationships and experience in general (resemblance, contiguity, and cause and effect?)] The goal is to attempt to identify objective descriptors for the things presented throughout the course of instruction while remaining aware but separate from independent or personal influences/biases towards the describing of a thing. Things may include anything from written works and texts, correspondence, one's personal experiences, and anything in-between.

New/interesting words: phenomenology, intellectual clutter

Practice and Process: Start things off in this course by being non-judgementally receptive to words in and of themselves. Comprehension of words and phrases can lead to the respect of the thing/word as well as it's application to one's self such that mental freedom and a clear understanding of one's ideas or experiences within a society are gained.

"Is there a text in this class?": There's no official class textbook; instead, various supplementary readings will be made available. See the syllabus for listing.

Assessment and Evaluation | Forming a Society: Grade based on the perceived development and ability to convince others of "semantic and action-orienting powers". Emphasis is on information channel diversity and perceived credibility.

Grade | Distribution: 40% = Interactive Activities focusing on characteristics of Transnational Organizations. 20% = Quality of presentation in forums requiring deep reading and understanding of "concepts, images, and perspectives" (hint: slower in-depth reading is critical). 20% = Letter Deconstruction and Analysis (requires identifying implied premises/points and analogies for proper understanding). 20% = ability to self-reflect and adapt throughout this course as new information is received.

Finally | Individuation: (Individuation = Projection of one's self and their independent qualities from other's as well as the understanding of how/why such projection is made and how it may be perceived) Grade = level of engagement with groups/materials + creation of value through thoughtful or quality posts in Fishbowl. Ended with a list of required forum subjects to be posted under (Notes: Taking and Making, Vocabulary: Concepts and Word-images, Reading and Deconstructing Text, Interactive Assignments, and Individual Assignments).

Epilogue: Quote about sublime word-word, Addendum 1 = required statement of objectives of the course from URI, Addendum 2 = primary technologies required/used by the course, Social technologies, educational technologies, and intellectual technologies.

Letter 02: Welcome again and again...always welcome

Summary/Paraphrase with own thoughts:

The point of repetitious statements is for the reinforcement of ideas for the course (reminiscent of the idea that if you hear something three times then it's harder to forget).

The approach to this class should include thinking of The Fishbowl as THE METAPHOR for your mental space, visual space, and inter-subjective space.

Between us = you + me, you + your group, you + your class. (Navy saying, "One team, one fight!")

Process > outcome

Opportunities to show our processes are how we learn to acquire "soft-power". A wordsmith can be anyone who expresses themselves with some manifestation of their inner visualizations with an emphasis on the process (how they express it) rather than their outcome (the result of the expression).

Asynchronous = nobody is required to be on at the same time as another.

This approach is metaphorically similar to a "David-Goliath" story for doing business. Expect letters to be akin to a higher peak (more intense plateau) which builds upon the previous letter while remaining chiefly independent. Look up Deleuze and Guattari's "A Thousand Plateaus". (Concept of interconnectedness reminds me of "The Web of Life" by Fritjof Capra.)

Keywords and Vocab will be in all CAPITAL letters within the emails.

Vocab: ASYNCHRONOUS, SELECT, EVOLVE, UNFOLD, ABSORB, soft-power

Letter 06: some logistics on a Sunday morning

Summary and Paraphrase with personal thoughts:

There's a lot to do but we should have some type of routine by this point and be thinking of ourselves as "craftsmen of words".

*Metaphor: "this semester is precarious and fragile, like a porcelain workshop". --> So, my question or line of thought to this is: Within the bounds of this "workshop", if we break up the tools, the clay and such, and the shelves which the vases rest before going to a store shelf, then what makes up or represents each component? Obviously, The Fishbowl represents the structure or building itself for the workshop; but then are the Letters the raw clay, are our hands and eyes the tools by which we shape and add styles to the newly made vases, and our classmates the shelves that we must then place the vases? If so, then we must consider the strength of each as well as ourselves because even if our tools are sharp, the clay is pure, and the building sound, a weak shelf could leave everything shattered... However, until I provide my own shelf the quality of another's will remain an unknown factor.

The purpose of The Fishbowl's structure is not to allow forums subject to criticism, but forums for openly silent observation. Replies and messages should be private, not public.

Repeat about posting in your own space while comparing content production to your team's products.

It's about the symbol = language game requiring avoidance of distractions and focus. This is all one big experiment. --> So, then are we the lab rats? Is this about intuitively building up the ability to navigate mazes (another metaphor).

Consider both implied and stated premises. --> Perhaps put certain statements into argument structure to make identification easier.

Vocab: MENTAL, SPACE, LABORATORY, EXPERIMENT, TEXTUAL, CONCEIVE, FORM, DEPICT, LOOK, COMPARE, CONTRAST, LOGISTICS (wiki)

Date: 11/27/2020 14:42:56
Subject: &quot;truth procedure&quot;
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Your postings take us on a journey that interrogates and explores the following techniques: 

reflexivity, symbolic interactionism, participant-observation and auto-ethnography. 

IN all these domains, your postings are ‘events' that bring to light possibilities that were invisible or even unthinkable; they propose something to us.

Please see April Younkin’s posting below.

“Everything then depends on how the possibility opened up by the ‘event' is grasped, elaborated and embedded in the world" --- yours is what Badiou calls a ”truth procedure.”

The event of your posting creates a possibility but there then has to be an effort for this possibility to become real and inscribed in the world, as you have done extremely well!

Sanjiv

INTERROGATE, EXPLORE, DOMAIN, EVENT, POSSIBILITY, TRUTH, PROCEDURE, INSCRIBE

“How does one make the viewing interaction (eyes looking at eyes) more intimate, so we can travel together, far and wide?”

I think of Walt Whitman:

“Listener up there! What have you to confide to me?

Look in my face…

(Talk honestly, no one else hears you, and I stay only a minute longer.)

How so? I don’t think I can improve on Whitman, but what does he mean? He talks directly to the reader from the page (up there, eyes looking at eyes). He questions the listener, the reader. He wants to know what the reader has to offer. He wants raw emotion, honesty, and clarity. He will not let the reader look away until there is a true connection between the two, yet it is fleeting, a quick connection that is long lasting.

letter #1

I have taken two of Sanjiv's classes before and I believe it took me all of those combined months to fully understand what we were trying to get at when we were creating the fishbowl. His class is a conversation, not a lecture. It is more than anything, a process.

I kept on looking for some end product, some rubric that would tell me how to get an A, what was due, and what he wanted me to say so I could pass the class. Little did I know that was the opposite of the point.

The point is not to regurgitate information back to him, but rather to DEVELOPE and CULTIVATE our own methods of expression and communication. All of the little vocab words and google searches were not busy work, but weapons put into our hands. I remember a saying that asked if the pen or the sword was more powerful. I think Sanjiv would say that a pen is both a tool to build and a weapon of destruction if need be. WORDS ARE POWER.

Perhaps as a native English speaker, I have taken it a bit for granted how easy it is for me to express myself, but whenever I enter a foreign language class I realize just how vital our vocabularies are. If you can hold an audience's attention during a story or anecdote, you have the power to implant ideas or impressions in their minds that will stay long after you finish speaking.

I know sometimes it can be confusing because we aren't always sure of our professors' expectations. But after two previous semsters with Sanjiv, I think I can say that his only expectations are that we try and that we grow. And really, it is impossible not to grow if you read the letters and reflect on them. It can even be slightly therapeutic, as all self-reflection can be. Ok, that's all for now, in the coming week my personal goal with this class is to share my experience, and to really dive deep into the structures of the letters.

sophievicedomine

Joined: Tue Sep 10, 2019 11:02 am

Mon Sep 14, 2020 1:27 pm

letter: the third eye: taking words further

Making Sense/ Producing Sense/ Being Sensible

Making sense - discerning meaning. Organizing thoughts and facts into your own words. Arriving at a conclusion that was embedded in the information.

Producing sense - creating meaning where there previously was none. When I produce sense, I arrive at a conclusion that was not already there.

Being sensible - listening to others, following a logical and occasionally methodical method of thinking. Realism. Being grounded.

I don't know why, but thinking about my own thinking helps me feel less overwhelmed. If I feel like something is insurmountable and impossible, and then consciously take a moment to step back from the problem, it often seems less drastic. I often recognize myself hyperbolizing a situation: oh my God if I don't get a 92 or above on this exam my whole life is over and I'll be homeless and miserable forever. And 99.99% of the time this is just my own mind giving my anxieties life. But When I step back and recognize that I am essentially freaking out over something that will be nothing to me in five years, I tend to calm slightly. By thinking about my thinking, I can correct patterns that concern me, and encourage patterns that tend to lead towards my happiness.

sophievicedomine

Posts: 52

Joined: Tue Sep 10, 2019 11:02 am

Thu Sep 24, 2020 2:21 pm

I remember when I took a few previous courses with Sanjiv, and the dichotomies were really where I began to understand how we create knowing through our words. Knowledge is what is communicated through text, but knowing is how we process and internalize that knowledge into wisdom. It is easy to spit out facts and statistics, that is knowledge. But when you take in the information and can put it into your own words, draw your own conclusions, and facilitate your own opinion, that is when we become intelligent in a way that is applicable in everyday life. Connecting words through dichotomies is a really good exercise for me when I want to expand my knowing of a word or concept. Connecting two unlike things can be difficult, and it helps me to have a tab to dictionary.com open and at the ready.

Apperception letter reflection

Apperception is how I view the fishbowl. Apperception is defined as "the mental process by which a person makes sense of an idea by assimilating it to the body of ideas he or she already possesses" on Google.com, which means next to nothing to me on the first read. It is erroneous and abstract, not a concrete noun or adjective easily thrown around in text.

In the fishbowl, Sanjiv always asks us to take a step outside of our perceptions of our reality and to view our situation, ourselves, and our words, from a more global or universal point of view. This is extremely hard to do. Even though we can see the writings of our peers and live through their felt experiences, we are at the end of the day, alone in our own realities. By logging our thoughts, our learning, and our knowledge in the fishbowl, it can help to create a platform from which to view your life from an outside perspective. All of our collective texts laid bare before us make the human experience slightly less daunting, and slightly more enchanting.

So in sum, apperception is what we are trying to create in the fishbowl. A platform is just a tool that we use to help us step outside of ourselves, and look at a grander picture.

I feel most apperceptive when I am alone strangely enough. Being with others is wonderful, but it clouds my mind and brings me more into my own world view. When I am alone and I consider ideas presented to me by others, I can actually process those ideas and make my own sense of them. I like to do this at Narragansett beach or even on my daily drives to work. Though it sometimes leaves me uncomfortable, apperception always leaves me with a better knowledge of others, and more importantly of my place in the world next to others.

sophievicedomine

Posts: 52

Joined: Tue Sep 10, 2019 11:02 am

Tue Nov 24, 2020 7:37 pm

If Sanjiv is our "top-dog" or "prima-ballerina" in the fishbowl, I surely have been part of the corps de ballet for most of my time in his classes. I am onstage (metaphor) and participating in the steps by reading the letters and forming my own thoughts. Perhaps when we respond to letters or expand our word pools or document our experiences through text, we take three steps forward on the stage, and the spotlight finds us (metaphor (obviously)). From this harsh light, I have shirked, cowered, dodged, and downplayed my performance on our fishbowl-of-a-stage, trying in vain to avoid notice.

I usually prefer to fly under the proverbial radar, especially in online classes. I find that although I am outspoken in person, it is often difficult for me to express myself through text when I am unsure of what is expected of me. To put this sentiment into the context of my current metaphor: I kept on feeling like if I were in the spotlight, I would forget the steps and run off stage in embarrassment and anguish. But am I even really performing if no one can see me?

If I step outside of my apprehension, my fear that words will abandon me, and just start writing, the text flows out of me like I knew what I wanted to say all along. And then I feel like I am dancing through an assignment, articulating thoughts like motions in a piece I've known for years.

The fishbowl is a stage, to pretend it is not would be to discredit its core purpose. When I view it through that lens, my normal patterns start to change, and I become more willing to speak out, and even excited for my time in the spotlight (which in this metaphor I guess translates to posting in the fishbowl). Even though Sanjiv is our star, each student contributes (or doesn't) to the performance, and has a chance to leave their mark on the audience (our peers).

sophievicedomine

Posts: 52

Joined: Tue Sep 10, 2019 11:02 am

 Wed Nov 25, 2020 4:47 pm

This letter came as somewhat of a comfort to me as I am almost never sure what I am doing in the fishbowl. Perhaps I am too aware of being watched to truly just write out my personal felt experiences, but that is part of the challenge is it not?

Being bold is a virtue, though it is often not treated as such. But if David had not called out that he could defeat Goliath, his whole town may have met an unfortunate end. I am seizing my own destiny, becoming my own David, and using my words like a slingshot.

I carefully carve out the wood that will make the handle and select a rock to fit into my new weapon. (I curate word pools for myself, and decide on what I truly want to express in my writings.) To open my mouth and assert that it is I, and no one else who can defeat the giant threatening my home, feels like opening the sky, and I feel my nerves rattle and shake my heart. (Opening my computer is the modern equivalent of opening one's mouth to call out to a crowd is it not?) With shaking hands I take the field and observe the giant; towering, imposing, and daunting he stands before me in the form of a blank page. But I have come prepared. Words in hand I load sentence after sentence into my slingshot and create meaning. I forge my own truths and my own reality through shaking fingers, and before I know it, the page is no longer blank but flooded with my thoughts become reality. The giant of my own expectations for myself falls to his knees, and is not dead, but rather temporarily sedated by the might of my conviction, of my own belief in my self. He will rise again when Sanjiv sends another letter for us to respond to. I remember how the bolt of terror struck through me, and also remember how one stone (words/metaphors) and one slingshot (my thoughts and ideas) brought down a mountain of a challenge.

 Fri Sep 11, 2020 12:57 pm

letter #1

I have taken two of Sanjiv's classes before and I believe it took me all of those combined months to fully understand what we were trying to get at when we were creating the fishbowl. His class is a conversation, not a lecture. It is more than anything, a process.

I kept on looking for some end product, some rubric that would tell me how to get an A, what was due, and what he wanted me to say so I could pass the class. Little did I know that was the opposite of the point.

The point is not to regurgitate information back to him, but rather to DEVELOPE and CULTIVATE our own methods of expression and communication. All of the little vocab words and google searches were not busy work, but weapons put into our hands. I remember a saying that asked if the pen or the sword was more powerful. I think Sanjiv would say that a pen is both a tool to build and a weapon of destruction if need be. WORDS ARE POWER.

Perhaps as a native English speaker, I have taken it a bit for granted how easy it is for me to express myself, but whenever I enter a foreign language class I realize just how vital our vocabularies are. If you can hold an audience's attention during a story or anecdote, you have the power to implant ideas or impressions in their minds that will stay long after you finish speaking.

I know sometimes it can be confusing because we aren't always sure of our professors' expectations. But after two previous semsters with Sanjiv, I think I can say that his only expectations are that we try and that we grow. And really, it is impossible not to grow if you read the letters and reflect on them. It can even be slightly therapeutic, as all self-reflection can be. Ok, that's all for now, in the coming week my personal goal with this class is to share my experience, and to really dive deep into the structures of the letters.

sophievicedomine

Mon Sep 14, 2020 1:27 pm

letter: the third eye: taking words further

Making Sense/ Producing Sense/ Being Sensible

Making sense - discerning meaning. Organizing thoughts and facts into your own words. Arriving at a conclusion that was embedded in the information.

Producing sense - creating meaning where there previously was none. When I produce sense, I arrive at a conclusion that was not already there.

Being sensible - listening to others, following a logical and occasionally methodical method of thinking. Realism. Being grounded.

I don't know why, but thinking about my own thinking helps me feel less overwhelmed. If I feel like something is insurmountable and impossible, and then consciously take a moment to step back from the problem, it often seems less drastic. I often recognize myself hyperbolizing a situation: oh my God if I don't get a 92 or above on this exam my whole life is over and I'll be homeless and miserable forever. And 99.99% of the time this is just my own mind giving my anxieties life. But When I step back and recognize that I am essentially freaking out over something that will be nothing to me in five years, I tend to calm slightly. By thinking about my thinking, I can correct patterns that concern me, and encourage patterns that tend to lead towards my happiness.

sophievicedomine

Posts: 52

Joined: Tue Sep 10, 2019 11:02 am

Thu Sep 24, 2020 2:21 pm

I remember when I took a few previous courses with Sanjiv, and the dichotomies were really where I began to understand how we create knowing through our words. Knowledge is what is communicated through text, but knowing is how we process and internalize that knowledge into wisdom. It is easy to spit out facts and statistics, that is knowledge. But when you take in the information and can put it into your own words, draw your own conclusions, and facilitate your own opinion, that is when we become intelligent in a way that is applicable in everyday life. Connecting words through dichotomies is a really good exercise for me when I want to expand my knowing of a word or concept. Connecting two unlike things can be difficult, and it helps me to have a tab to dictionary.com open and at the ready.

Apperception letter reflection

Apperception is how I view the fishbowl. Apperception is defined as "the mental process by which a person makes sense of an idea by assimilating it to the body of ideas he or she already possesses" on Google.com, which means next to nothing to me on the first read. It is erroneous and abstract, not a concrete noun or adjective easily thrown around in text.

In the fishbowl, Sanjiv always asks us to take a step outside of our perceptions of our reality and to view our situation, ourselves, and our words, from a more global or universal point of view. This is extremely hard to do. Even though we can see the writings of our peers and live through their felt experiences, we are at the end of the day, alone in our own realities. By logging our thoughts, our learning, and our knowledge in the fishbowl, it can help to create a platform from which to view your life from an outside perspective. All of our collective texts laid bare before us make the human experience slightly less daunting, and slightly more enchanting.

So in sum, apperception is what we are trying to create in the fishbowl. A platform is just a tool that we use to help us step outside of ourselves, and look at a grander picture.

I feel most apperceptive when I am alone strangely enough. Being with others is wonderful, but it clouds my mind and brings me more into my own world view. When I am alone and I consider ideas presented to me by others, I can actually process those ideas and make my own sense of them. I like to do this at Narragansett beach or even on my daily drives to work. Though it sometimes leaves me uncomfortable, apperception always leaves me with a better knowledge of others, and more importantly of my place in the world next to others.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 11/25/2020 18:16:02
Subject: Happy Thanksgiving and a safe break
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

The pandemic taught me that I cannot expect other people to create meaning, like a metaphor, for me. I cannot wait for someone else to define my life; impose their metaphor upon me, like actor/audience. I must make meaning by forging it with my hands. It requires sweat and commitment. Working toward the creation of meaning is the point. It is action that forges the meaning and significance of a post.

Action that forges? What do you mean?

To achieve your possible goals, you must be bold enough to speculate, postulate and imagine on the basis of partial knowledge. At the same time, you must remain open to the very strong possibility that in fact you are way off the mark. The one thing we cannot afford is inaction due to despair or indifference.

In order to engage in effective action, you must first find something that you value (your choice of word) and put it at the center. This action will engender other values (words) and beliefs. Please see Chris Goglia’s posting below as an example. Through this engagement with words, things happen. Movement is all. Keep moving and yet slow down simultaneously. In Latin this is known as festina lente, “make haste slowly.” Within this DIALECTIC, you will find a special freedom and the space and time to explore complexities. It does not cost you anything. It can cost your organization millions, no billions of dollars.

Principles and Steps that you are following in your fishbowl...

Principle:

1. Learning is movement. 

2. All movement is change. 

3. All change is creation.

Step: Acknowledge yourself as the creator of all that you wish to recreate.

Principle: No creation nor the creator is bad.

Step: Finish your unfinished business in the fishbowl.

Principle: Conscious choice creates new consciousness. New consciousness creates new experience.

Step: Decide what is true for you now.

I wish you a happy thanksgiving and, a safe break from it all.

Sanjiv

SPECULATE, POSTULATE, IMAGINE

from the fishbowl..

Tue Nov 24, 2020 8:48 pm

Life is a play...

If life is a play, is it quantifiable in parts? I would certainly like to try?

If we say that a play is

Introduction

Rise

Climax

Fall

End (instead of catastrophe)

The introduction: The beginning of a new life. The bright eyed and bushy tailed toddle looking to take on absolutely everything the world has to offer. Nothing can stop him (while he/she is nurtured by their parents). I like to believe these are the preteen / early teen years when understandings, character, and knowledge is being built .

The Rise: The college/ early post grad years. The character is figuring themselves out and what they want to do with this life/ stage time they've been given. Knowledge continues to accumulate, character develops, and exploration continues.

The climax: Usually I feel the climax is dramatic an often quick, but I don't often watch plays. The climax for me is the 30's-50's. At this time or character is uniquely themselves. Maybe they have kids, get married, or are becoming wealthy from the job they now have settles in to. This is a meaningful part of the character's life and gives them a huge sense of MEANING.

The Fall: This is the time after the climax. Kids off to college, considering retirement, and finding new things about one's self they may not have known. This is where life seems to slow down and routine is built. The character can have more freedom to do as they please and find new things that they enjoy; a new hobby for example:

The End: The end is pretty self explanatory, but I can only hope our character enjoyed their stage time. I hope every character finds their purpose and fulfills themselves in the time they are given before the curtains close. Hopefully they please their audience and are well liked throughout the community. Hopefully they don't have tomatoes thrown at the stage.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 11/24/2020 13:00:58
Subject: participatory research
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you are making sensible decisions during the holidays. 

We are being asked to trust each other's better judgement under vexatious conditions.

I.

Better safe than sorry (image). To err on the side of caution (image).

1. Dimension: sensible decision/vexatious condition.

See these words as symbols that are sliding on a plane, a surface, a range, a dimension.

2. Dichotomies: Sensible/Decision, Vexatious/Condition

See these words as symbols that are interacting, interfacing, interrelating.

3. We need word-pools (metaphor) for the elements (words) that we have above.

See word-pools as context, boundaries, limits, spreads, spaces, images...that we impose upon ourselves. They are the imprint.

4. We re-structure our thoughts and our ideas and our words and our symbols and images. Metaphorical images can provide powerful tools for helping people took at themselves and their situations in new ways.

One thing is clear: old boundaries and categories, old frames and frameworks no longer apply. Nevertheless, it is the awareness and ability to identify and respect tradition that is at the heart of success in the 'business of ideas', and the whole shebang in 345 and 448. 

What does this mean for us? Keep It Simple, please! 

We are students of business. We are practical, pragmatic and performative

II.

In the situation of a pandemic, we perforce turn inwards (image) and embark on a journey (image) without goal or destination (image), only outcome and experience (images again). We carry inner resources comprising of things like imagination, metaphor, image, symbol, words, perceptions. 

Our intention throughout is to disrupt normal ways of seeing, so that we can ask constructive questions about what we are seeing and what we should do. I find the use of metaphor particularly powerful in this activity, because it creates distance and space from conventional ways of thinking: space in which people can feel free to think and act creatively.

Our Abstract is performative writing. We did it and said it at the same time.

Each and everyone of you has been fantastic. You did it. Think about that. Congratulations!

How so?

We changed the metaphor (word-image) of teacher/student into one of actor/audience.

The environment, the circumstance, the situation, the context, the horizon demanded it.

What did it take to do? To change the metaphor?

Metaphor works by playing on a pattern of similarity and difference. Sanjiv is Top Dawg or the Fishbowl is Theatre. We are seeking to evoke similarities while downplaying the differences. It involves the generation of a “constructive image” that helps to break the bounds of normal discourse. This plays a crucial role in creating space for change.

Using metaphor as a tool for change requires us to find and create meaning. Metaphors invite a conversational style where meaning and significance emerge through dialogue; resonant meaning cannot be imposed, it has to be evoked. We were in process all along.

Because of the conference deadline, we had to find the similarities between fishbowl and theatre, to find the relevance of theatre, to find the precise way in which the image of theatre can create relevant insights.

Sanjiv

ps; all these words above, these terms, have to be seen in their nuances and shades of meaning. So please open your dictionaries, if you haven’t already done so. It is in the grey area that meaning is found.

from the fishbowl...

“Why the metaphor of theatre? Why actor/audience? Why not a catwalk, or a garden, or a kitchen, or an organic farm?”

I think that the Abstract came together nicely. I think that the metaphor of a theater is an appropriate representation of what we are doing in The Fishbowl. However, the questions posed above make me think deeper though.

- What if we chose a different metaphor to associate with?

- What new images would arise from a different theme?

- Would a different metaphor change the meaning of the Abstract?

- Can any metaphor be appropriately applied to The Fishbowl?

“The world is a stage and we are merely players.”

The world is our stage. We control what we put into this world and what we get out of it. Our actions everyday are a reflection of the person we are and the person we are becoming. We are the eyes and the ears of our story and others stories around us. Who do you want to be? Who do you want to become? What do you want your life to look life? We are the drivers of our story, we control the gears and the shifts of motions with out thoughts, actions, intuitions, perspectives, insights and experiences. The fishbowl is just one small part of our story, where we are seeing insight from other actors stories. We lean on each other, we learn and grow from each others thoughts and insights.

Date: 11/21/2020 23:10:22
Subject: about the abstract
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

The fishbowl exists in the moment of interconnection between ‘reading' and 'writing,' and this reading/writing interconnection makes the reality of our fishbowl a living text. 

If one thinks about it, the language, images, ideas and actions through which we respond in the fishbowl, parallels how we use words to fix and communicate meaning. 

As readers of each others text, we interpreted and created our own meaning; in effect we added our own authoring to the text.

I congratulate you. We’ve come a long way.

How so? 

You’ve begun authoring the text by interpreting what you read in your own voice.

In this way, the whole of life can be seen as a living "real time" process of simultaneous reading and writing, producing evolving and diverse patterns of meaning.

To create one's own meaning in an uncertain world.

How does one do that?

How do we interpret a text and create meaning is the question we're faced with every moment in our fishbowls.

Please see Alyssa Botelho’s posting below.

About the abstract. 

What did we create and why and how and when and where and for whom?

These questions have to be addressed.

First and foremost, I PARTICIPATED and OBSERVED the text and images being generated in the fishbowl... 

What is the reading/writing going on? What is their interconnection in the fishbowl? 

I faced the challenge of interpretation.

Interpretation is an act of courage because it creates categories, boxes, concepts, and labels which affects people’s lives.

From a DISTANCE, you gain PERSPECTIVE. 

I ‘saw' the fishbowl as theatre.

It was a moment of inspiration coming from something she said.

“The world is a stage and we are merely players.”

The fishbowl is show business.

The word-image, Theatre, is used as a metaphor 'to make' an interpretation of the chaos and mayhem we perceive, aka, the fishbowl.

The metaphor of theatre is an individual choice. 

You can be anything you want to be. Desire is essential.

After this inspiration, the re-search of the word ‘theatre' began in EARNEST. 

The wider the word-pool the greater the OPPORTUNITY. 

I must produce (MAKE) opportunities at this stage (pun).

Doing so by generating text: dichotomies, dimensions, perspectives, insights, word-categories, structures, and felt experiences. 

To generate text is to create spaces.

Our fishbowl is ’social space’ (please google). 

It is not a place. 

In the theatre of the fishbowl, we are actors and audience; producer and consumer; buyer and seller; competitor and collaborator; teacher and student; teller and told, both at the same time. 

Old dichotomies and ways of thinking no longer apply. 

In such a landscape (metaphor), we are learning to create dichotomies and perceptual categories ANEW, as we ENTER the unknown, fueled by INSIGHT, INTUITION AND IMPULSE. Always on ALERT, like a sniper (metaphor).

We are actors playing roles, and 

we are the audience watching, and 

self-reflecting, 

we’re eyes looking at eyes...

There were 45 actors among us, who for any given situation in the fishbowl, made possible to generate multiple authentic readings and story lines. 

The abstract gives them due authorship and show of gratitude. They are celebrated for their efforts. 

The remaining of us chose to play the audience for the time being. 

Together, actor/audience, we are an entity that participated and put forth our best shoe forward for the INTED20 conference.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

“Suddenly technology has given us powers with which we can manipulate not only external reality---the physical world--- but also, and much more portentously, ourselves. You can become whatever you want to be,” (Ed Regis)

TECHNOLOGY: the practical application of knowledge especially in a particular area

POWER: ability to act or produce an effect

MANIPULATE: to manage or utilize skillfully

PORTENTOUSLY: self-consciously solemn or important

The practical application of knowledge has given us new abilities to manage our worlds and even more importantly, ourselves. We can develop into anything we imagine.

I have always been a "dreamer". Growing up, my dad always said that I could achieve anything I set my mind to. I took that to heart and when I found my passion for filmmaking, I chased it unrelentingly. Even though it may seem impossible and impractical to want to become a successful filmmaker, I know that I am in charge of my own destiny. Technology has already brought me so many incredible opportunities that my ancestors have not had. Especially as a woman pursuing a career in a male-dominated field, I recognize and deeply appreciate these new technological resources that I have to leverage my goal of breaking the glass ceiling!

ERVING GOFFMAN

"Choose your self-presentations carefully, for what starts out as a mask may become your face."

How we choose to present ourselves, even if it is different than our true selves, may eventually define who we are. In The Fishbowl, I chose to present myself in a way that is consistent with how I have presented myself in my other business classes since I entered URI. My self-presentation has been a confident, detail-oriented student who has an affinity for the arts. Most of these "masks" were already part of my "face", except for the presentation of confidence. I have always struggled with confidence, but when I came to URI I decided to "fake it till I make it" and that's what has happened. My self-presentation of confidence started out as a mask and it has become my face.

MEISNER TECHNIQUE

"Sanford Meisner said that his approach to training 'is based on bringing the actor back to his emotional impulses and to acting that is firmly rooted in the instinctive. It is based on the fact that all good acting comes from the heart, as it were, and that there’s no mentality to it.'"

In The Fishbowl, my most valuable writings are the ones where I did not overthink. It took about a month for me to get to this point where I was writing instinctually. There is much more truth in the writings where I did not overanalyze and cover up what I really wanted to say- my soul is laid bare there.

JERZY GROTOWSKY

"It is true that the actor accomplishes this act, but he can only do so through an encounter with the spectator - intimately, visibly, not hiding behind a cameraman, wardrobe mistress, stage designer or make-up girl - in direct confrontation with him, and somehow 'instead of' him."

Our mission in The Fishbowl has only been accomplished in the moments where actors are directly encountering spectators. That is, writers are directly engaging with readers. When I have been honest in expressing my thoughts and feelings, I have engaged in the work that allows spectators to directly interact with me.

REFLEXIVE LEADERSHIP

"Reflexive leadership is based on the increasing awareness of the value of self-reflection in practice – whether it be as a therapist, student or business person."

Self-reflection is a key component in the process of writing in The Fishbowl. It is only through reflecting on one's own actions, thoughts, and emotions that one knows what to write. With the intensity and frequency that I want to write responses to Sanjiv's letters, I have engaged in much self-reflection and have realized the great value in it as it has uncovered my true self.

ACTOR AND AUDIENCE: THEATRE AS METAPHOR FOR ASYNCHRONOUS ONLINE PEDAGOGY

“Followers and leaders are bound together in the transformation process, which I think helps describe pretty well what is happening here. We should all strive to be transformational leaders.” (Olivia Palumbo, Fishbowl, 2020)

I. Introduction

During the pandemic, across two semesters and a summer, in an asynchronous digital environment, the authors (business students at the University of Rhode Island) are generating text by creating new metaphors and word structures in acts of ‘reflexive leadership’ (1). They are evoking images (scenes and scenarios) in a never-ending play in which they themselves are the actors. Erving Goffman (2) first presented this idea that a person is like an actor on a stage who uses “impression management” to present the Self to others as the actor hopes to be perceived. In other words, according to Goffman, “the self is a sense of who one is, a dramatic effect emerging from the immediate scene being presented.” By using Goffman’s metaphor of theatre, the authors understood that elements of human interaction are dependent upon time, place and audience; the same elements they were experiencing as participants (220 in number) in asynchronous online pedagogy. 

Essentially, we are playing out some role on a visual and virtual stage. One third of us are active actors and the rest are either rehearsing or playing at being the audience. One’s role is the combination of one’s choices, dedication, actions, and reactions. 

II. Purpose:

 

1. To provide a theatrical stage of visual and virtual effects to an invisible and asynchronous audience. 

2. To establish a process (for the actor) that connects the audience (viewers) to their own lives in the world.

In the paper-presentation, we selected the following ‘scenes’ from a visual and virtual environment, where some of us emerged as actors, creating dramatic effects played for an asynchronous audience.

Scene 1: Self-reference and social reflexivity

Scene 2: Social isolation

Scene 3: Memory: Temporal and spatial forms

III. Method

1. Goffman’s ‘dramaturgy' as a method allows actors to tell stories they have felt and experienced, and in the process, teach their audiences both how to locate themselves and to relate their own accounts.

2. Theater is sharing stories using words. According to Jerzy Grotowski, it is what takes place between at least one spectator and one actor (4). By forming ourselves into groups of three interactants, at least one spectator was assured. We connected to each other as actor and audience. It made every individual’s activity of producing, directing and writing into a performance. 

3. In Meisner's technique (3), great acting depends on the actor's impulsive response to what's happening around him or her. “Acting is living truthfully under imaginary circumstances.” We instinctively and impulsively selected and focused on words, evoking images, symbols and concepts. We made “the reality of doing” into a performance.

4. The use of “emotion memory” was a part of Stanislavski’s Method acting; to recall an experience and recreate the feeling that went with that memory. By reflecting on felt-experiences, we incorporated the devices of storytelling and reflexivity (1). Using words alone, we created characters, settings, conflict, and a message. 

IV. Findings and Result:

1. A connection between actor and audience only developed when we learned to look at each other and listen to each other. If we did not listen to the character and what is going on in the scene, we lost the atmosphere and the believability of the scene. Both, actors and audience, became more aware of the impact they had on each other. 

2. Acting by focusing on words became a search for self-knowledge and awareness. Through dramaturgy, actors and audience came closer to knowing the truth about themselves. 

3. Actors innately sought to understand their experiences by organizing them into stories. Stories helped express who, what, when, how, and why. An actor’s performance was genuine whenever they were true to their memory.

4. The metaphor of dramaturgy provided increasing access to different world-views.

 

V. Conclusion

In preparing an actor to act, one should not attempt to 'teach' or tell the actor 'how to act' but instead, remove the blocks- physical or mental, so as to enable the actor to express impulses freely. On the other hand, the actor must not forget the discipline of structuring the words in which they choose to express their role.

REFLEXIVITY, DRAMATURGY, STORY-TELLING, METHOD-ACTING, ACTIVE-LISTENING

References

1. Reflexive Leadership, Organizing in an imperfect world, by Mats Alvesson, Martin Blom, Stefan Sveningsson, Sage 2017

2. ‘The Presentation of Self in Everyday Life’, by Erving Goffman, 1959 

3. Sanford Meisner on Acting, by Sanford Meisner & Dennis Longwell Vanguard, 2012

4. Jerzy Grotowski by James Slowiak and Jairo Cuesta, Routledge, 2018

Subject: theatre as metaphor for what we are doing

Hi Everyone,

I hope Actors and the Audience can relate to the metaphor of a theatrical play between us.

Sanjiv

TITLE: THEATRE AS METAPHOR FOR ASYNCHRONOUS ONLINE PEDAGOGY

Introduction

During the pandemic, across two semesters and a summer, in an asynchronous digital environment, 150 participants (business students at the University of Rhode Island) are reflexively generating text by creating new metaphors and word structures (1), thereby evoking 'scenes' in a never-ending play in which they are the Actors (2). Erving Goffman first presented this idea that a person is like an actor on a stage who uses “impression management” to present the Self to others as they hope to be perceived. By using the metaphor of theatre, Goffman understands that elements of human interaction are dependent upon time, place and audience; the same elements in our online experience. In other words, according to Goffman, “the self is a sense of who one is, a dramatic effect emerging from the immediate scene being presented.” 

In this paper and presentation we considered the following “scenes” and actors’ dramatic effects….

Scene 1:

Scene 2:

Scene 3:

Our Purpose is two-fold: 

1. To provide a theatrical stage for Visual and Virtual Affect. 

2. To Establish a Process for Actors that connects the Audience to their own lives in the world.

Method:

 

1. Theater is all about telling and sharing stories using words. It is what takes place between at least one spectator and one actor (4). By forming groups of three participants, at least one spectator was assured. It made the activity of producing, directing and writing into a performance. 

2. In Meisner's view (3), great acting depends on the actor's impulsive response to what's happening around him or her. “Acting is living truthfully under imaginary circumstances.” It is achieving the “reality of doing” in performance: an ability to stimulate instincts and impulses by focusing on words and imagination.

3. The use of “emotion memory” to recall an experience and recreate the feeling that went with that memory. Reflecting on felt-experiences we incorporate the devices of storytelling; by using words alone, we create characters, plots, settings, conflict, and a message. An actor’s performance is genuine whenever they are true to their memory.

Findings and Result:

1. Goffman’s metaphor of dramaturgy provided increasing access to different world-views.

2. Actors innately sought to understand their experiences by organizing them into stories. Stories helped express who, what, when, how, and why. 

3.A connection between actor and audience only developed when they learned to look at each other and listen to each other. If we do not listen to the character and what is going on in the scene we lost the atmosphere and the believability of the scene, 

4. Actors became more aware of the impact they had on other people. Acting by focusing on words became a search for self-knowledge and awareness. Through dramaturgy (Goffman), actors and audience came closer to knowing the truth about themselves. 

Conclusion

1. Essentially, we are playing out some role on a visual and virtual stage. One third of us are active actors and the rest are either rehearsing or playing at being the audience. One’s role is the combination of one’s choices, dedication, actions, and reactions. We are living a movie every day and fulfilling our roles. Are we heroes? are we villains? it is for us to decide.

2. In preparing an actor to act, one should not attempt to 'teach' or tell the actor 'how to act' but instead, remove the blocks- physical or mental, so as to enable the actor to express his impulses freely. On the other hand, the actor must not forget the discipline of structuring the words in which they choose to express their role.

References

1. Reflexive Leadership, Organizing in an imperfect world, by Mats Alvesson, Martin Blom, Stefan Sveningsson, Sage 2017

2. ‘The Presentation of Self in Everyday Life’, by Erving Goffman (1959) 

3. Sanford Meisner on Acting, by Sanford Meisner & Dennis Longwell Vanguard, 2012

4. Jerzy Grotowski by James Slowiak and Jairo Cuesta, Routledge, 2018

1. Theater is all about telling and sharing stories using words. It is what takes place between at least one spectator and one actor (4). By forming groups of three participants, at least one spectator was assured. It made the activity of producing, directing and writing into a performance. 

2. In Meisner's view (3), great acting depends on the actor's impulsive response to what's happening around him or her. “Acting is living truthfully under imaginary circumstances.” It is achieving the “reality of doing” in performance: an ability to stimulate instincts and impulses by focusing on words and imagination.

3. The use of “emotion memory” to recall an experience and recreate the feeling that went with that memory. Reflecting on felt-experiences we incorporate the devices of storytelling; by using words alone, we create characters, plots, settings, conflict, and a message. An actor’s performance is genuine whenever they are true to their memory.

Findings and Result:

1. Goffman’s metaphor of dramaturgy provided increasing access to different world-views.

2. Actors innately sought to understand their experiences by organizing them into stories. Stories helped express who, what, when, how, and why. 

3.A connection between actor and audience only developed when they learned to look at each other and listen to each other. If we do not listen to the character and what is going on in the scene we lost the atmosphere and the believability of the scene, 

4. Actors became more aware of the impact they had on other people. Acting by focusing on words became a search for self-knowledge and awareness. Through dramaturgy (Goffman), actors and audience came closer to knowing the truth about themselves. 

Conclusion

1. Essentially, we are playing out some role on a visual and virtual stage. One third of us are active actors and the rest are either rehearsing or playing at being the audience. One’s role is the combination of one’s choices, dedication, actions, and reactions. We are living a movie every day and fulfilling our roles. Are we heroes? are we villains? it is for us to decide.

2. In preparing an actor to act, one should not attempt to 'teach' or tell the actor 'how to act' but instead, remove the blocks- physical or mental, so as to enable the actor to express his impulses freely. On the other hand, the actor must not forget the discipline of structuring the words in which they choose to express their role.

References

1. Reflexive Leadership, Organizing in an imperfect world, by Mats Alvesson, Martin Blom, Stefan Sveningsson, Sage 2017

2. ‘The Presentation of Self in Everyday Life’, by Erving Goffman (1959) 

3. Sanford Meisner on Acting, by Sanford Meisner & Dennis Longwell Vanguard, 2012

4. Jerzy Grotowski by James Slowiak and Jairo Cuesta, Routledge, 2018

Date: 11/15/2020 22:27:50
Subject: reflections during the pandemic
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

We are developing thoughts as to what we are doing in a digital fishbowl during a pandemic...

The thoughts below are fragmented and the idea, the coherence, the core, is yet to be reached.

The Abstract is due on the 19th, and I’m hoping for an extension.

Title: Actor and Spectator Interacting in a Fishbowl: Reflections During a Pandemic

The question we raised during the pandemic: Can the activity of producing and directing and writing, I.e., can the theatre exist without an audience?

At least one spectator is needed to make it a performance. So we are left with the actor and the spectator. Eye ball to Eye ball. 

We define the theatre of the fishbowl as what takes place between spectator and actor. 

In every actor sits the critic and the spectator. Without this critical, judging faculty the doer or maker would be so isolated from the spectator that he would not even be perceived. (Hanah Arendt) And in every spectator, sits an actor.

The acting technique developed by legendary theatre artist Jerzy Grotowski (please google) aims for complete integration of the actor's mental and physical senses to reveal the core substance of a character, his own. Please see Adam Beckett’s posting below.

Grotowski believed that in preparing an actor to act, one should not attempt to 'teach' or tell the actor 'how to act' but instead, remove the blocks- physical or mental, so as to enable the actor to express his impulses freely. This however does not mean that the actor should not be disciplined. On the contrary, the actor must not forget the importance of structuring the words in which he chooses to express his role.

Sanjiv

SPECTATOR, ACTOR, THEATRE, AUDIENCE, PERFORMANCE

from the fishbowl, during the pandemic...

participatory cultures

"As spectators, we are complicit in our cognition's well-being."

As individuals we are always hoping for the best in every outcome. We do not want others to fail as much as we do not want ourselves to fail. I come from a community that preaches kindness and without the kindness my town would have fallen apart. In order to help the others around you, then you need to contribute at your own pace. If others have to tell you to contribute then your effort will not be all the way there and it will seem face. Time and patience is what you need to truly give a meaningful contribution to society. I always try to pick out one moment in my day where I can make someone happy or at the very least smile. It is things like that that carry society forward and make this place a better world to be in.

KINDNESS

Date: 11/15/2020 16:47:54
Subject: reflexive leadership through generative text
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Please see Michael Degnan’s postings below.

Upon receiving overall direction (open to many interpretations), Degnan ‘makes' and ‘creates' his assignments for himself and shares them as he goes along in his process, visible to all. It is Reflexive Leadership (please google) Through Generative Text.

Degnan and his cohorts in the fishbowl challenge traditional, dominant and fashionable leadership perspectives and encourage us to embrace alternative ways of organizing work in an imperfect world. They follow a deeper process of reflection, a reflexive practice, involving examining one's own thoughts, feelings and actions and their impact on both the Other and on the self as the practitioner.

Reflexive Leadership in the digital world is built upon several assumptions:

1. If you don’t read, then you are not listening to the text.

You’ve got to have your ear to the ground (metaphor) by reading into words.

2. If you’re not listening to the text, then you’re unable to hear anything.

3. If you can’t hear, then you don’t know what is going on. It is a feeling of being lost.

4. We exist only in our bubbles; and, that is causing a problem.

To be reflexive involves thinking from within experiences, or as the Oxford English Dictionary puts it 'turned or reflected back upon the mind itself '.

How do we do that?

You raise the following kind of questions:

’

WHAT am I saying?

HOW am I saying?

WHY am I saying it?

FOR WHOM am I saying it?

WHEN AND WHERE did I say it?

In the first round, Michael Degnan’s postings stands on previous text.

Previous text is the result of his search which is limited by the time spent searching.

In the second round, reflexive thinking begins when the above questions are addressed.

The best way to do this is to select a sentence and expand its understanding by relating a personal experience. 

You enhance the value in some way by your reflective action.

The exercise is not meant to be difficult but self-reflective and self-assertive. The only appropriate selection of a word is one which is owned. When it is disclosed.

Michael Degnan gets an A- for his efforts below. They are an excellent example of the first round. To take these structures, dismantle them and then put them together with a personal anecdote is Reflexive Leadership and its practice will get you or the organization you work for a following of viewers. Also known as fandom (please google).

Sanjiv

c: 345

 from the fishbowl...

Vocabulary for Assignment #1:

Belief: confidence in the truth or existence of something not immediately susceptible to rigorous proof

Value: relative worth, merit, or importance

System: relative worth, merit, or importance

Structure: mode of building, construction, or organization; arrangement of parts, elements, or constituents

Feeling: the function or the power of perceiving by touch

Culture: the quality in a person or society that arises from a concern for what is regarded as excellent in arts, letters, manners, scholarly pursuits, etc.

Google for Assignment #2:

Raymond Williams: a Welsh Marxist theorist, academic, novelist, and critic influential within the New Left and in the wider culture. His writings on politics, culture, the media, and literature made a marked contribution to the Marxist critique of culture and the arts. Some 750,000 copies of his books were sold in UK editions alone and there are many translations available.

Assignment 1

1. Participant-observation: a qualitative research method in which the researcher studies a group not only by observing the group but also by participating in the activities of the group (Exactly what the fishbowl is)

2. Symbolic interactionism: the view of social behavior that emphasizes linguistic or gestural communication and its subjective understanding, especially the role of language in the formation of the child as a social being (behaviors and gestures are extremely crucial in communications in today's world)

3. Social constructivism: a sociological theory of knowledge according to which human development is socially situated and knowledge is constructed through interaction with others (I am a huge supporter of human interaction and its positive correlation with human development)

4. Self-reflexivity: someone making reference to their own artificiality (definitely important to anyone trying to realize their previous mistakes)

Assignment #2

Outsourced Script

1. "Any American job that’s done on the phone or online is going overseas." (Overseas - Many of the things that are bought in America are not made in America, which isn't beneficial for our economy)

2. "Our first mistake, is trying to run this, like an American office." (Mistake - America has made many mistakes when it comes to politics and I do not believe anyone should be looking at America as a role model for politics)

3. "That’s why I want to introduce our products to a potential market of a billion people" (Introduce - There are many people and many markets available for businesses)

4. "Let me speak to your supervisor?" (Supervisor - This is a phrase that is spoken a lot by angry customers. I believe these customers should trust the original employees they are talking to because they generally are the people talking to customers)

5. "You’re a free woman, you can speak intensely as you want." (Free - all people should have the ability to say whatever they want, regardless of any of their qualities)

Moonrise Kingdom

1. "I think you've still got lightning in you" (Lightning - I think people should be trusted until they are proven that they can't be.

2. "We're in love. We just want to be together. What's wrong with that?" (Wrong - I think anyone should be allowed to be together with anyone and no one should be able to tell them otherwise.)

3. "There are no paved roads, but - here comes Jet with the mail -- but instead many miles of intersecting footpaths and dirt trails and a ferry that runs twice daily from Stone Cove." (Paved - Just because the road is not easy, does not mean it is impossible)

4. "You're doing what's right. For everyone. Except me." (Except - People are far too selfish in today's world)

5. "Don't let go!" (Don't - Never give up!)

Assignment #3

Japanese Story

1. "If you want him to come and see, you come and show him yourself, okay?" (Yourself- If people want things done, they should realize that they are the ones that have to do it)

2. "There was a time there when nobody would buy anything made in Japan." (Time- It is interesting how much times have changed and how drastically people's opinions change as well)

3. "Funny thing, life, isn't it?" (Life- There many times in all of our lives that something happens that makes little to no sense and we are not sure why it happened)

4. "Do you love your wife? No need to say it." (Need- People today do not express their truest feelings, even when others need them to)

5. "Life's short." (Short- Life truly is short so people should make the most out of the time they have)

Kinky Boots

1. "And by the time you're old enough, and married probably, taking over the factory from me, believe me, first thing you'll notice about a person is their shoes." (Notice- Too many people notice the wrong aspects about people, and pay the price because of it)

2. "I'm not my dad. OK. You shouldn't expect that." (Expect- Each person is unique and different, even from their own family members)

3. "A Price's shoe will last a man a lifetime." (Lifetime- When buying items, people should worry more about quality rather than quantity)

4. "What can I do?" (Can- People can do anything they put their mind to, as long as they put in the work)

5. "Well, it needs to be a Jimmy Choo, doesn't it? To work." (Doesn't- Sometimes the most expensive items is not always the best and most reliable item)

Assignment #4

4 dimensions of culture-related values (Hofstede)

1. Power Distance: how power is distributed and the extent to which the less powerful accept that power is distributed unequally. Put simply, people in some cultures accept a higher degree of unequally distributed power than do people in other cultures.

2. Uncertainty Avoidance: a society's tolerance for uncertainty and ambiguity. It reflects the extent to which members of a society attempt to cope with anxiety by minimizing uncertainty.

3. Individualism/collectivism: Individualism stresses individual goals and the rights of the person. Collectivism focuses on group goals, what is best for the collective group, and personal relationships. An individualist is motivated by personal rewards and benefits.

4. Masculinity/Feminism: Masculinity (also called manhood or manliness) is a set of attributes, behaviors, and roles associated with boys and men. Although masculinity is socially constructed, research indicates that some behaviors are considered masculine are biologically influenced. Feminism is a range of social movements, political movements, and ideologies that aim to define and establish the political, economic, personal, and social equality of the sexes. Feminism incorporates the position that societies prioritize the male point of view, and that women are treated unjustly within those societies.

Date: 11/13/2020 17:49:04
Subject: dramaturgy notes
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Thinking of a backdrop, in keeping with the dramaturgy metaphor, I generated the following thoughts from your postings regarding what is it that you are doing:

*participating in a system dedicated to providing increasing access to different world-views.

*establishing an innovative process that connects viewers to their own lives in the world.

*providing a platform for visual and virtual affect.

“Followers (i.e., the audience) and leaders (i.e., the actors) are bound together in the transformation process, which I think helps describe pretty well what is happening here. We should all strive to be a transformational leader in the fishbowl.” (Olivia Palumbo, Fishbowl, 20)

There is a lot of material here offering many directions to choose from. I will next link with Goffman’s Dramatrugy.

We are constructing a text. We are generating it and we are creating it. We are looking at phenomena, metaphors, symbols, in other words, we’re looking at words.

We are writing an Abstract of 3,500 words for blind review. Why are we of interest is the question we are confronting.

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

oliviapalumbo

Posts: 302

Thu Nov 05, 2020 3:34 pm

Leaders Generate Text

I found Sanjiv's letter to be very true and eye-opening. As we all have learned in the past year, the digital learning atmosphere can be rather awkward. It is not as easy and natural having interactions with groups over a screen as it is in person. Without lectures in person, we can become confused in direction and feel lost in the shuffle. The leaders in the fishbowl keep us all afloat. They show us a model of what we are supposed to be doing and keep everyone on track. It takes a true leader to overcome obstacles in this digital classroom and keep the class on track.

I find these fishbowl leaders to be transformational leaders. Transformational leadership is a process that changes and transforms, where a person engages with others and creates a connection that raises the level of motivation and morality in both the leader and follower. It involves an exceptional form of influence that moves followers to accomplish more than what is expected of them. Followers and leaders are bound together in the transformation process, which I think helps describe pretty well what is happening here. We should all strive to be a transformational leader in the fishbowl.

Hi Everyone,

About grades and categories, and things like that.

Reflections like Chris Goglia below are a minimum A-minus.

"As November approaches, I get anxious to see what lies before me. I wonder if I've done enough to receive a B even."

There are four boxes. They are not grades at this point (please see your syllabus for that) but an ascending order of work, to help you see where you are positioned:

1. The Box B

The pandemic taught me that everyone deserves at least the box B. So, if you do nothing, you’re indicating that since you are paying for the course, you choose to be a watcher/voyeur and you are learning/absorbing at your own pace and particularly by watching your peers. You’re paying for the experience of a visual and virtual learning culture. You downloaded over 100 letters that were shared among a community of like-minded individuals in a digital environment. 

2. The Box B-Plus

You completed your vocabulary and did a few reflections/deconstructions. 

By so doing you got an idea of the boundary of the field, the discourse and conversation. You will always think about this vocabulary if you have a million dollar business idea or subject that you are considering.

3. The Box A-Minus

You are regular in your postings and completed the assignments to the best of your circumstance in the fishbowl. Quantity and Quality of interpretations and reflections and notes will assure you a place in this box.

4. The Box Straight-A

This box is reserved for those who show leadership by generating text and keeping flailing spirits alive. Chris Goglia will probably make it to this box.

Thank you.

Sanjiv

GRADE, CATEGORY

Jackson Pollock: "Pollock romanticized the tortured artist"

- I feel like this is in a way very ironic. Someone who is a legend in his field frustrated with his work. From his pain and suffering came something beautiful that has went down in history and revolutionized art forever. I guess to be so good at something you have to suffer and grind to make anything of yourself. I can compare that slightly to the real world I'll be entering very shortly. I will be in the field that I love, but may not necessarily be doing the things I love... yet. I will grind out my working career in order to make something beautiful in the end. My pain and suffering could lead me to start a business that helps people. Helping people and changing their environment is what motivates me to persevere.

Thu Nov 12, 2020 5:06 pm

Dramaturgy: the theory and practice of dramatic composition.

Sociologist Erving Goffman developed the concept of Dramaturgy, the idea that life is like a never-ending play in which people are actors. The way he describes this concept is mind bending and makes a lot of sense if you think about it. Its a very interesting outlook on the "why" we do what we do. Sometimes people are two faced and put on an act in front of people or have to learn new characters for different situations. Not everyone is the same person in front of people as they are when they're alone. Sometimes we use Impression management to try and influence the way we're seen on the "front stage." Sometimes we act the way we do to boost our image in a social setting. Appearance is half the battle in life. If we're perceived as good, hardworking, prosperous people, we'll in tern be treated like it.

About grades and categories, and things like that.

Reflections like Chris Goglia below are a minimum A-minus.

So, if you do nothing, you’re indicating that since you are paying for the course, you choose to be a watcher/voyeur and you are learning/absorbing at your own pace and particularly by watching your peers. You’re paying for the experience of a visual and virtual learning culture. You downloaded over 100 letters that were shared among a community of like-minded individuals in a digital environment. 

2. The Box B-Plus

You completed your vocabulary and did a few reflections/deconstructions. 

By so doing you got an idea of the boundary of the field, the discourse and conversation. You will always think about this vocabulary if you have a million dollar business idea or subject that you are considering.

3. The Box A-Minus

You are regular in your postings and completed the assignments to the best of your circumstance in the fishbowl. Quantity and Quality of interpretations and reflections and notes will assure you a place in this box.

4. The Box Straight-A

This box is reserved for those who show leadership by generating text and keeping flailing spirits alive. Chris Goglia will probably make it to this box.

Thank you.

Sanjiv

GRADE, CATEGORY

Jackson Pollock: "Pollock romanticized the tortured artist"

- I feel like this is in a way very ironic. Someone who is a legend in his field frustrated with his work. From his pain and suffering came something beautiful that has went down in history and revolutionized art forever. I guess to be so good at something you have to suffer and grind to make anything of yourself. I can compare that slightly to the real world I'll be entering very shortly. I will be in the field that I love, but may not necessarily be doing the things I love... yet. I will grind out my working career in order to make something beautiful in the end. My pain and suffering could lead me to start a business that helps people. Helping people and changing their environment is what motivates me to persevere.

Dramaturgy: the theory and practice of dramatic composition.

Sociologist Erving Goffman developed the concept of Dramaturgy, the idea that life is like a never-ending play in which people are actors. The way he describes this concept is mind bending and makes a lot of sense if you think about it. Its a very interesting outlook on the "why" we do what we do. Sometimes people are two faced and put on an act in front of people or have to learn new characters for different situations. Not everyone is the same person in front of people as they are when they're alone. Sometimes we use Impression management to try and influence the way we're seen on the "front stage." Sometimes we act the way we do to boost our image in a social setting. Appearance is half the battle in life. If we're perceived as good, hardworking, prosperous people, we'll in tern be treated like it.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 11/12/2020 21:32:11
Subject: abstract on dramaturgy
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Scrolling through your fishbowl entries,

What do I see?

To answer that, a good place to start is to address a prior question:

How are you feeling in this moment?

Feeling takes center stage whenever we are considering the imagination: what do you see when you imagine each other? What is the metaphor, the analogy, the comparison that strikes you? Whatever it is, feeling has everything to do with it. Wouldn’t you agree!

To carry on along these lines of thought for developing the Abstract...

Entering the unknown, we must always return to the original (questions). To the basic questions 

what are we doing, in the fishbowl, 

why are we doing it, and 

how are we doing it? 

In other words, what’s going on in our Fishbowl? 

The Audience wants to know the following:

What was done (action),

When or where it was done (scene, backdrop),

Who did it (agent),

How she did it (agency), and 

Why (purpose)?

By raising the above questions, we are advocating ‘dramaturgy' as a method of social analysis that allows the actors to tell stories about organizational life, and in the process, teach their audiences both how to locate themselves and to relate their own persuasive accounts.

I think Erving Goffman’s concept and Model of Dramaturgy will be an apt metaphor for us. Please google. Please ‘see' Joseph Dugas as actor, action, scene, agency and purpose in his posting below. 

Sanjiv

self-reference and social reflexivity

"Within sociology reflexivity means an act of self-reference where examination or action "bends back on", refers to, and affects the entity instigating the action or examination. It commonly refers to the capacity of an agent to recognize forces of socialization and alter their place in the social structure."

Self-reference is a powerful notion of the human kind. Often I think of what I am doing in the present, reflecting on myself as a person. It can be hard sometimes to realize if what you're doing is affecting someone else. But, as a person, your end result should always be okay with yourself and no one else. I've realized it doesn't matter what people think of you. As long as your okay with your decisions and morals, that's all that matters. That's what self-reference means to me.

Date: 11/12/2020 12:16:14
Subject: self-reference and social reflexivity
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I am going to begin working on the Abstract for the conference. 

You will be participating/witnessing every step of the way, as you will see. 

The project will evolve and we don’t know what shape or form it will take. 

We know that our fishbowls are exercises in Social Reflexivity.

From wiki:

Within sociology reflexivity means an act of self-reference where examination or action "bends back on", refers to, and affects the entity instigating the action or examination. It commonly refers to the capacity of an agent to recognize forces of socialization and alter their place in the social structure. A low level of reflexivity would result in an individual shaped largely by their environment (or "society"). A high level of social reflexivity would be defined by an individual shaping their own norms, tastes, politics, desires, and so on. This is similar to the notion of autonomy. (See also structure and agency and social mobility.)

Please see April Younkin’s reflection below as an example of the definition of Reflexivity.

Sanjiv

Post by aprilyounkin » Wed Nov 11, 2020 10:45 pm

“Labor of Love”

- Labor: Physical or mental work and/or a task to be done.

- Love: An intense feeling of deep affection and/or a great interest and pleasure in something.

In BUS 341 Organizational Behavior, I learned that there are five general factors that determine people’s desire to stay or leave an organization: the work itself, career growth, pay, coworkers, and management. The number one reason why people stay at an organization is because of the work itself. If a person truly enjoys the work they do, they are more likely to stay. The work has to be challenging enough that it is not boring, but still manageable to do within the given restraints. Finding love in the labor I do is the goal in my career. I want to find a job that I will not resent. I know that there will be good days and there will be more mundane days, but I want to believe in the work I do. Work is a “repeated process” and being unhappy doing it will become a dreadful loop that will not yield labor worth loving.
