Date: 9/26/2020 15:04:49
Subject: looking in the mirror
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? Your posts are extraordinary; even the most mundane of activities like doing your vocabulary. 

Re-reading the meaning of words as a daily practice is a ritual that helps enter a space where a particular conversation, a dialog (please google David Bohm, On Dialog), and discourse is taking place. More on this as process. Whenever I enter such spaces, and the reason for my entering such spaces is that I want to be intelligent, focused, alive and imaginative. Eye Ball-to-Eye Ball, Face-to-Face and, Heart-to-Heart. How does one do it?

In the fishbowl, you do it by looking in a mirror. 

"What do you see?" 

It is your imaginary self.

You Fishbowl Society is nothing without imagination.

Is it ourselves we see, or what we imagine of ourselves? This imagination of ourselves is a mental image of ourselves. It has a word-image to it; a metaphor. The strong can imagine themselves as weak, the beautiful can imagine themselves as strong, a villain can imagine himself as a hero. In the digital sphere, no one can stop us from imagining ourselves in any way. We can be whatever we want. By the same token, you can get whatever you want; but that is another story.

I imagine ourselves as Footnotes but in the Center of the Page. Every human being wants to feel they matter; that their contribution to the social has significance. Social structures grant this value through symbols. The symbolic domain is built from our imaginations; our metaphors; our word-images; our feelings. More on symbols to follow. 

Evoke feelings. Put them at the center of everything, so that creativity can proceed. So you are feeling overwhelmed, confused and exhausted. And you want to feel the opposite of that. What should you do? 

This is new to me: Become conscious of your breath. The flow of air through your body. And thus you will arrive in the moment. After that, start with the rituals. It is stretching exercises: Vocabulary and Google Searches. 

Scroll, scroll, scrolling in a haystack, looking for that sentence, that Gem, that is to be the Centerpiece of your understanding.

Get the process and practice down so you can run with the wolves. We are moving along with a handful of concepts. We will keep returning to them. Today I will draw out a conceptual vision of 345 for the rest of the semester. And I have to complete yesterday’s reading of Bateson in 448 and dive into Hofstede’s workbook. You should stay ahead of me, because you are looking for Gems and Insights. You want to be successful! You want to be well and positive.

Sanjiv

Date: 9/26/2020 2:36:45
Subject: the networked individual
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

The Internet has become the fabric into which our lives are woven. Communication is the essence of being human; and, the internet represents a quantum leap in the transformation of communication.

The social meaning of this interactive, multidirectional, global, digital network of communications has emerged on the dimension of utopia-dystopia.

Utopians hail the era of freedom from the state and from big corporations.

Dystopians warn against isolation and alienation in society.

Furthermore, Big Brother uses the internet to construct a digital panopticon and establishes a surveillance system as never before possible.

Both positions on the dimension have been proven to be right and wrong at the same time. 

On the one hand, as individuals we have enhanced capacities to construct networks in our lives and create spaces (structures) of autonomy that impacts everything for us, from business to education to innovation and creativity.

On the other hand, states have rushed to set up sophisticated systems of censorship, by blocking access to websites, by approving and enforcing restrictive legislation, by engaging in cyber warfare, and by inducing massive disinformation, amplified by armies of robots that populate digital networks. The structures of these networks are controlled by massive oligopolies who transform our lives into data, the source of their profits: data capitalism is a fundamental industry of the 21st century economy.

A new pattern of sociability has emerged in the fishbowl: it is what we conceptualize as 'networked individualism.’ In our world of the fishbowl, 'it is the person who is the focus.'

From wiki:

Definition[edit]

The networked individuals are members of diverse groups in which they seek different things; for instance, the same set of individuals could be in a group used to seek emotional support while another group might be used to get good addresses in a city. Those groups can be dispersed around the globe, and the combination of those networks make for a highly individualized, and well-networked, person.

This new world of networked individualism is oriented around looser, more fragmented networks that provide on-demand succor. Such networks had already formed before the coming of the internet. In incorporating the internet and mobile phones into their lives, people have changed the ways they interact with each other. They have become increasingly networked as individuals, rather than embedded in groups. In the world of networked individuals, it is the person who is the focus; more than the family, the work unit, the neighborhood, and the social group.

Sanjiv

SOCIABILITY, PATTERN, NETWORK, INDIVIDUALISM, DIMENSION, UTOPIA, DYSTOPIA

At this point I am presuming you have a sense of the meaning of structure. Structure is an arrangement of elements. This arrangement creates a space. This space determines our physical behavior (movement, flow, position) and emotion, our feelings. Every thing has a structure and a design and it exists in space. Please see the picture below as an example.

Please read wiki on Structuralism. A sweeping introduction. We are not alone. Try and relate to specific sentences. Treat it as a challenge that you cannot miss for fear of being left behind forever. Our behavior and experience of the fishbowl is determined by its structure. If we can see that, then we are ’structuralists.’ 

Anthropologist Adam Kuper (1973) argued that:

'Structuralism' came to have something of the momentum of a millennial movement and some of its adherents felt that they formed a secret society of the seeing in a world of the blind. Conversion was not just a matter of accepting a new paradigm. It was, almost, a question of salvation.

Take the weekend getting a handle on structuralism. I hope the pictures below help. Understanding comes and then it goes, I’ve noticed. Hanging onto understanding is the challenge.

Sanjiv

Experiential Learning

Kolb's theory on experiential learning is as the name describes. People learn best through experience. But the question he poses is what is experience? And how is experience experienced through different minds? It is an experience to go to a bull fight and an altogether different experience to be a bullfighter. At one point in my life I would have said that the bullfighter has the better and more clear experience but is that true? Does the bullfighter experience the jostle of the crowd? The swearing, fights and gambling? Does he hear a lone voice shout over a momentary silent lull? Does he feel the chorus of laughter the comment gets or does he toss his drink at the hammered patron? And what of the onlooker? Does he experience thousands of eyes on him, the skill of his own form, the nervousness or command in his flourishes? 

Kolb has broken down the experiential learning cycle into four parts; concrete experience, reflection, abstract conceptualization, and active experimentation. There is no set starter point for how to learn. If you want to learn how to solve a Rubik's cube, what's the first step? Do you take one out and start twisting? Do you visualize how to move one square to a different corner? Do you watch a YouTube video on how it's done? Do you think about other similar puzzles and how those worked? And moreover, how does your current circumstance change how you wish to learn? Does it change with the project? If something seems like a large daunting task, I will look for examples on how it has been done in the past and create a roadmap for its completion. If it seems small and trivial, I'll dive right in. If eyes are watching and I'm alone, I'll take a measured conceptual approach. In a group setting with a physical task I'll dive right in. 

So how to translate this into an individual or group setting? Individually the answer comes naturally. Whatever you are first drawn to is the right answer. Even if it's slow going, the first step is always the biggest when diving into a new project. In a group it will take a discussion. Can we empathize with another's learning needs? If we can't, can we sympathize and make concessions? Each member can start at a different point of the learning process and compare experiences when the next step is taken. Kolb has created a win-win; learning while producing.

aprilyounkin

Posts: 30

Joined: Wed Sep 09, 2020 8:40 pm

Thu Sep 24, 2020 12:13 am

Prof. Sanjiv clearly expresses the importance of words. Words are the foundation to basically everything. We hear words from the moment we are born. We go to school to learn words and we never stop learning new ones. It is inevitable and ongoing. To jump to the point, games and mobile apps have found fun ways to play with words. We are able to exercise our minds with word exposure without it feeling like we are being schooled. 

For example, word games on mobile apps are popular. There is WordTrip, Wordscapes, Words with Friends, Word Stacks, and Word Search just to name a few. You can play with words whenever and where ever you go. They are challenging yet fun, and you forget that you are learning.

Also, during early quarantine in the summer, my family and I would play Bananagrams to help pass the time. We had nowhere to go and nothing much to do. The goal of the game is to make words as fast as you can and build more words off of the ones you already have. Almost like Scrabble, but slightly different and with speed. The challenge is that you have to work with what you have, which forces you to sort, sift, substitute, and organize your letters in several different combinations to win. My parents have their Master’s degree in English, and my sister is currently getting hers in teaching writing. They love words making my competition tough to beat.

Date: 9/24/2020 13:13:22
Subject: say it like you mean it
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? During this time of the pandemic, I've learnt to keep my use of technology simple because I don’t want to waste the most precious resource: Time.

Time doing what? The answer is best expressed by Kelsie Poplawski in the line below.

There is no need to conform to anything or have the exact answer, your own answer that you come up with is good enough.

I find Kelsie Poplawski’s reflection in her posting below quite extraordinary and her phrase, “come up with" is learning from experience. 

Spend time on "coming up" with your own answer. Doodle with a pen. Edit and re-edit. Be engaged with words in an on going manner. It is How we are most Human. 

Your fishbowl is "experiential learning.” Please be sure to google this term, and enter it in your bio-data. You will be comfortable doing so by the end of the semester.

In 345 we will experientially learn about the characteristics of successful global businesses.

In 448, we are learning to perceive differences in values and beliefs between ourselves; identifying the cultural lenses that we wear.

Our methodological approach is the same in all my courses, and we go through the basics of these methodologies each time. If you’re finding its vocabulary onerous, then you are grounded in the 20th century that required different skills. And, there is of course a place for that in this century. I was trained to be an Econometrician (loved the stuff) and my studies and dissertation was on Technological Strategies of Businesses in New England. I divided firms in three environments and then went about it. 

I was never into touchy-feely and was uncomfortable with ambiguity.

Today, with rapid technological and managerial changes, there is little point in acquiring skills that will be done by Robots by the time you enter the job market. That is to say, you don’t need a college degree to do them. Management was considered a science and all about Taylorism then. Cause and effect. My research too was all numbers. A multivariate analysis which had variables generating enough data to publish forever. I had ‘boxes' and ‘ rrows' all over the place. I was loved by a rapt audience, every time I presented. I got my tenure!

I left all that behind after I learnt to “listen” to those in business in RI. Here’s what I heard: "URI Business students are sincere and make excellent presentations but they don’t know what it means. And so, we’d rather not hire them."

I jumped 20 years later, having taken Linda Smircich’s (please google her name) class in 1985 at UMass, Amherst. Her Doctoral seminar was known as Multi-Paradigm Approaches to Organizational Analysis. She wrote the book with Gareth Morgan. The first text book to hit the business academic scene in America, and I was sitting in her class. I was awe-struck. I will remain in awe of Smircich, because "she says it like she means it,” ... a regular, simple gal from Pennsylvania.

We have to learn how to say it like we mean it. It takes Experience and Reflection. Please keep that in mind.

Sanjiv

EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING (please google), PARADIGM, TAYLORISM,

from the fishbowl...

Email: Bergsonism and Phantasms 9/19/20 

"Bergsonism" 

The theories of the philosopher Bergson according to whom the world is a process of creative evolution in which the novelty of successive phenomena rather than the constancy of natural law is the significant fact, reality being regarded as time or duration that is the same as free motion and that is the expression of a vital impetus or creative force while the space world of science and common sense is taken to be an interpretation put upon sense images in the interest of practical activity and as a falsification of free-moving reality so that a true apprehension of reality is to be gained not by the analytic procedures of mathematics and science but by that intuition that can grasp wholes as such.

""Phantasmal Media"

An argument that great expressive power of computational media arises from the

construction of phantasms—blends of cultural ideas and sensory imagination. In

Phantasmal Media, D. Fox Harrell considers the expressive power of computational media.

He argues, forcefully and persuasively, that the great expressive potential of computational

media comes from the ability to construct and reveal phantasms—blends of cultural ideas

and sensory imagination. 

First looking at these definitions it was very overwhelming for me. Many big words that when put together make a complicated sentence. The fishbowl is not backed by a dictionary definition, by math, by science or anything that has a true definite answer. This is a place to express your own kind of art and imagination. There is no need to conform to anything or have the exact answer, your own answer that you come up with is good enough.

Date: 9/23/2020 13:53:09
Subject: sacred space

Hi Everyone,

I think 345 might read Ramirez’s paragraph at the end of this email. Just didn’t want you to miss it, particularly those struggling with process. If we don’t get the process down, we can’t do the practice either. THere is no faking it and nowhere to hide in the digital world when it comes to process/practice. The buzz words are transparency and authenticity. I’m sure you’ve heard of them. Even if I am role-playing through text and images, you can DISCERN that I’m not really Richard Gere, even though I sound like Gere to you. Whenever we lack discernment, we get duped. We do it to ourselves. Discernment is a skill that we acquire through critical thinking.

Our text, i.e., our choice of words, projects images onto the ‘screens' of each others minds (see Henri Bergson) that evoke emotions in us and this affects our behavior. This circle, due to technology, has become multifarious and gigantic. It is constant and will never end. 24/7 forever. 

In the fishbowl, we go to the mountains to chill. It is sacred space. A place where we can be the most and best of one’s Self through reflection, contemplation and meditation. However, in a visual culture (more on this to come), every business, every individual must have an Audience to exist, to survive and to thrive.

 

In the fishbowl, we are the audience to each other. The teacher/student dichotomy is dissolved. There are things we reflect and write upon that changes our perceptions; how we see the world. How did we do this? Please apply to your favorite business idea, career, or relationship. Think of this in terms of Parag Khanna’s Ted Talk on MegaCities. There is a dissolving and connecting and meshing and collectivity among us already.

Sanjiv

DISSOLVE, DISCERN, DUPE, SCREEN , PROJECT, IMAGE, TRANSPARENT, AUTHENTIC, SPACE, SACRED

Begin forwarded message:

From: Sanjiv Dugal <sanjivdugal@uri.edu>

Subject: Improvisation, diagnostic reading, deconstruction and participant-observation

Date: September 23, 2020 at 8:14:39 AM EDT

To: Sanjiv Dugal <sanjivdugal@uri.edu>

Hi Everyone,

How are you this morning? Stay with it, for you will go onto produce substantial text and prosper. In the digital sphere, words like bountiful have come back into usage. You want to be perceived as bountiful (metaphor). Next time you are describing who you are and what you are, add the word bountiful and attach several of your postings as evidence. 

At this point, we have been exposed to 'reading into’ words, i.e., a diagnostic reading, and we are learning the method of deconstruction (Derrida). We are also getting into the method of participant- observation (please google). 

When I was reading p.7 of Bateson, at the bottom of the page she writes, “I believe that participant observation is more than a research methodology. It is a way of being, especially suited to a world of change."

p.8 “The quality of improvisation characterizes more and more lives today, lived in uncertainty, full of the inklings of alternatives. In a rapidly changing and interdependent world (like that of your fishbowls as an example), single models are less likely to be viable and plans more likely to go awry.”

Reading Bateson is by no means an easy task. You understand her by reading into the text by deconstruction. Don’t try to understand the whole text. You are scrolling to select a sentence structure that you want to work on. One for each page. We see the whole or bigger picture, paradoxically, when we get into particulars.

Please see Tyler Ramirez’s excellent reflection on process below.

Sanjiv

tyler ramirez

Posts: 35

Joined: Sat Sep 05, 2020 6:17 pm

Tue Sep 22, 2020 8:19 pm

"Having said that, we want to take our understanding of the ‘process and practice for learning' in a digital environment, i.e., the fishbowl, to the next level." 

Here are the sequential steps:

Select a sentence

Create a word pool

Re-structure the sentence

Do a felt-experience

Reduce to one word-image.

In order to truly capitalize on the lessons being portrayed in the letters and our responses on the fishbowl, we must look deeper than what's on the surface. By following the sequential steps we gain a deeper understanding and a firmer grasp on topics ranging from complex to straightforward lessons. By focusing on a sentence we can gain further insight into what areas interest us. Creating the word pool draws parallels that we understand. Re-structuring the sentence demonstrates our understanding. A felt experience ties in the personal connection to the subject matter, and reducing the word to an image provides the meaning in its most simplistic form. All of these ways are steps to gain a deeper understanding and a more fundamentally sound approach to deconstructing literature and other people's work.

Date: 9/23/2020 2:11:04
Subject: making conversation again
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I hope you are doing well. I think of you every time I cross someone exercising in the park. 

I trust you are exercising and eating right. Both have nothing to do with covid.

Cut the beer if you can, particularly if you can’t party; instead, take deep breaths and slow the mind down. No kidding. We are consuming much too many images. It’s just not healthy for gaining clarity to take rightful actions and decisions.

Computer generated images are filtered by our mental structures and then projected onto the Other. 

Culturally embedded structures, always have hierarchies of some kind or other. Dichotomous relations: dorks/jocks, cool/hip, hot/nice. (From this starting point, we historically construct a structure of words.) Furthermore, our words are heard/interpreted by the Other to have meanings which are seldom intended.

Miscommunication has resulted in non-cooperation between cultures. 

And, it will do the same between us in the fishbowl. We start with that premise. 

 

Research findings (Hoecklin, Lisa) seems broadly to reveal that:

* The impact of culture differences is relevant to all areas of a global business

* Globally operating companies have used different strategies to manage cultural differences

* Some of these strategies are now inappropriate to emerging organizational structure and competitive requirements

* There are many more examples of companies articulating their intention to use cultural diversity for competitive advantage at a strategic level than there are successful examples at an operational level.

The point (in 448) being, how do we communicate across different cultures? 

Keeping the above in mind, I want to share with you the process/practice that Andrew Bikash (Management major) and I committed during the summer of the pandemic: “Conversation Through Letter-Writing: Participation and Collaboration”. We exchanged about 60 letters over a period of three months, similar to your postings in the fishbowl. We talked about all sorts of things and we intend to publish them, if only because we are such an unlikely pair. Occupying entirely different cultures and generations, we are creating digital products (publication/youtube/podcast/documentary/ etc.) by exchanging ideas (words) through conversation.

I am suggesting a conversation among ourselves in our fishbowls; and, we structure the conversation into a series of steps; a back and forth. Nothing difficult nor complex nor confusing. In the background, while doing this, we learn about theories by utilizing and experiencing them on the subject of Society (345) and on Culture (448).

Stay with it. You are doing well. All your postings. You will forever keep improving. It is engagement with text that you are after...always. “What did she mean by that!"

Things will clarify as we proceed. We are still in September. In BUS345, I would like to know from those who have had me before whether you have done the 10 steps for the four characteristics of transnational corporations as listed in the syllabus. Please email me directly if you have. Thank you.

Sanjiv

Date: 9/23/2020 2:10:14

Hi Everyone,

I hope you are doing well. I think of you every time I cross someone exercising in the park. 

I trust you are exercising and eating right. Both have nothing to do with covid.

Cut the beer if you can, particularly if you can’t party; instead, take deep breaths and slow the mind down. No kidding. We are consuming much too many images. It’s just not healthy for gaining clarity to take rightful actions and decisions.

Computer generated images are filtered by our mental structures and then projected onto the Other. 

Culturally embedded structures, always have hierarchies of some kind or other. Dichotomous relations: dorks/jocks, cool/hip, hot/nice. (From this starting point, we historically construct a structure of words.) Furthermore, our words are heard/interpreted by the Other to have meanings which are seldom intended.

Miscommunication has resulted in non-cooperation between cultures. 

And, it will do the same between us in the fishbowl. We start with that premise. 

 

Research findings (Hoecklin, Lisa) seems broadly to reveal that:

* The impact of culture differences is relevant to all areas of a global business

* Globally operating companies have used different strategies to manage cultural differences

* Some of these strategies are now inappropriate to emerging organizational structure and competitive requirements

* There are many more examples of companies articulating their intention to use cultural diversity for competitive advantage at a strategic level than there are successful examples at an operational level.

MAKING, CONVERSATION, EXCHANGE, WORD, PRODUCT, DIGITAL

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/22/2020 16:55:10
Subject: figuring the process/practice for learning
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

It is important to understand words like Society and Culture; and, to have felt-experienced them (in mind, body and spirit). 

Of course, we all have something to say by way of sharing felt-experiences of both words, Society and Culture. 

The situation is that whatever one elects to say has become a matter of interest to everyone because it is the way we create value in the digital world. 

What we elect to say, as a diverse and varied group of mind-sets, has become an important resource in today's organization.

Well then, what does one say? How do we go about to say it? What is the process? What is the practice? And, what is the product?

The moment we link a word to a felt-experience, an image (mental picture) is evoked from memory.

Think of the word ‘mother’ for example. You will have a felt-experience that evokes an image from your memory. You can also describe an anecdote.

If you don’t have an image or a felt-experience, then the meaning of the word ‘mother’ would only be known to you from what others describe, show, tell, depict. In this case, you are vulnerable because you are dependent upon what the Other tells you. You cannot ascertain the truth/falsity experientially for yourself.

Having said that, we want to take our understanding of the ‘process and practice for learning' in a digital environment, i.e., the fishbowl, to the next level. 

Here are the sequential steps:

Select a sentence

Create a word pool

Re-structure the sentence

Do a felt-experience

Reduce to one word-image.

When we undertake the above process and, practice it for the learning of any subject matter (like a sentence), the shared outcome will be a mental landscape like the following:

A labyrinth, an encyclopedia, an emporium, a theatre, the fishbowl is somewhere where fact and imagination simply have to fuse.

Sanjiv

SOCIETY, CULTURE, LANDSCAPE, FACT, IMAGINATION, FUSE, LABYRINTH, ENCYCLOPEDIA, EMPORIUM, THEATRE

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/16/2020 12:37:08
Subject: a fishbowl state of mind
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I hope you are doing well. 

I want to reiterate the following: 

you are learning at your own pace and 

you are learning how to stay abreast with your group, aka your fishbowl.

There are no deadlines nor expectations as such and hence, there is no stress about performance. We’ve taken the grade out. You will get a B at the entrance door.

However, there are obligations and responsibilities toward your group. Your actions, decisions and behavior have direct consequence to your group's actions, decisions and behavior. We are bound together in our fishbowls. It is this bind that concerns us because there is precious little outside of it.

We are at cross-roads. The virus can never completely go away. Like terrorism, its possibility, henceforth, will always exist. We have to change our lives.

The first thing we have to do is become seamless within our group, that is your fishbowl. To know where the other’s mind is at; to know what the other is thinking and why.

To accomplish this, you have to set up a daily routine, a practice of shifting, sliding and surfacing into your fishbowl.

A fishbowl state of mind. 

Go slow. Pick on words like a bird. Please google Jonathan Livingston Seagull. I hope you know him!

“Don’t believe what your eyes are telling you. All they show is limitation. Look with your understanding. Find out what you already know and you will see the way to fly.” 

― Richard Bach, Jonathan Livingston Seagull

What does this mean and what do I have to do? What is the How and Why of it? To "look with understanding," I have to "find out what I already know” ?

How do you do that; how does one learn from experience is the question.

By living your life as a participant-observer, interacting symbolically and being socially reflexive. More on these as we get along.

Sanjiv

ACTION, DECISION, BEHAVIOR, BOUND, OBLIGATION, SEAMLESS

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/15/2020 14:28:50
Subject: generating text
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you this morning? I hope the dust is settling down, and your minds will soon be free from the realities of technology; a tight grip. If your group member has not been posting, email and ask them if they are OK. By now you should have their emails from my address list.

There have been a couple of changes in your group formations and I’m sorry if it was an inconvenience. For those who are new or missed out thus far, the first step is simple enough: get into the fishbowl. sanjivdugal.net However, you have to register, and before you do, you have to activate your account. How to do that is on page 5 of the instructions sent to you by email. Write directly to me and say you don’t have the instructions so that I can get back to you. Once you are in, you have to work through my letters sequentially. It won’t take you more than a couple of hours. All you have to keep in mind is that you are tackling vocabulary in a new way.

We are not in Brightspace and nor are we Zooming. We are online fully, sharing our words with each other. If you wish to meet your group you may do so in the classroom. Set it up with each other. It’s a good idea to get friendly with each other. You need each other, more than you need me.

There is a commitment that we are making to each other: a promise to read each other’s words in a 'deep learning' kind of way. Thinking about what the other said and how you see it instead. This requires slowing the mind and focusing on words. Focusing, paradoxically, evokes images and feelings from the past: from one's memory. Please see Joseph Dugas' posting below. as an example. It is generative text. Very nicely done! You are learning to generate text that derives from your felt-experiences and is an expression of your images.

Doing Vocabulary is basic. It is the beginning, a Word, and you contemplate it by opening the dictionary and copying out its meaning. Avoid cut-pasting because copying is a fundamental human activity; it is how we learn.

In your fishbowl, for vocabulary don’t do every word as a New Topic because you won’t be able to print them out easily. You are gathering words, like picking flowers for a basket. This collection of words will represent a field of symbols and images. We are social constructivists (please google).

Sanjiv

IMAGE, METAPHOR

IMAGE: 

a physical likeness or representation of a person, animal, or thing, photographed, painted, sculptured, or otherwise made visible.

a mental representation; idea; conception.

- I often have an image of things to expect. Like tomorrow, or things to look for in life. Imagination is a strong tool. 

METAPHOR:

a figure of speech in which a term or phrase is applied to something to which it is not literally applicable in order to suggest a resemblance.

- Metaphors are interesting to use to get a different view on something, or to admire a relationship between entities. School is a castle of knowledge.

FORGE, SPACE, UNCERTAINTY, CLIFF, EDGE

FORGE: 

to form by heating and hammering; beat into shape.

to form or make, especially by concentrated effort

- I forged a friendship. 

SPACE:

the unlimited or incalculably great three-dimensional realm or expanse in which all material objects are located and all events occur.

to fix the space or spaces of; divide into spaces.

- Space is occupied by many planets. The space between is large and uninviting. 

UNCERTAINTY: 

the state of being uncertain; doubt; hesitancy

- I was uncertain whether to be excited for school or not. 

CLIFF:

a high steep face of a rock.

- I was afraid of the cliff, being high up and no where to go. 

EDGE: 

a line or border at which a surface terminates.

- I was on the edge of my seat in anticipation.

ASYNCHRONOUS, SELECT, EVOLVE, UNFOLD, ABSORB

ASYNCHRONOUS:

not occurring at the same time.

- Most of my classes are asynchronous, which I enjoy. 

SELECT: 

to choose in preference to another or others; pick out.

- I tend to select action and comedy movies instead of romances. 

EVOLVE: 

to develop gradually.

- In life the goal is to evolve, to become your best you. 

UNFOLD: 

to bring out of a folded state; spread or open out.

- As time goes on, this class is beginning to unfold in front of our eyes. 

ABSORB: 

to involve the full attention of; to engross or engage wholly. 

to such up to drink in; soak up.

- Im looking forward to absorbing what this course will teach me.

Post by josephdugas » Fri Sep 11, 2020 2:15 pm

TEXT, COMPOSE, EXPRESSION, EMBEDDED, AWARE, KNOWLEDGE, KNOWING, NUGGET, SHARE, CONTENT

TEXT:

the main body of matter in a manuscript, book, newspaper, etc., as distinguished from notes, appendixes, headings, illustrations, etc.

- The text for my courses are often filled with knowledge.

COMPOSE:

to make or form by combining things, parts, or elements.

- I composed a beautiful song. 

EXPRESSION:

the act of expressing or setting forth in word.

a particular word, phrase, or form of word.

- A famous expression can give you a better perspective on things, such as the grass is greener on the other side, etc. 

EMBEDDED:

to fix into a surrounding mass.

to surround tightly or firmly; envelop or enclose.

- I saw someone with a huge diamond embedded into her ring. 

AWARE:

having knowledge; conscious; cognizant:

informed; alert; knowledgeable; sophisticated:

- I was really aware walking around my house at night after a scary movie. 

KNOWLEDGE:

acquaintance with facts, truths, or principles, as from study or investigation; general erudition:

- I am sure to gain a lot of knowledge with this course, I'm looking forward to it. 

KNOWING:

affecting, implying, or deliberately revealing shrewd knowledge of secret or private information:

- The wife gave a knowing glance that her husband was cheating. 

NUGGET: 

a lump of something, as of precious metal.

anything of great value, significance, or the like:

- My parents gave me many nuggets of wisdom throughout my life. 

SHARE:

the full or proper portion or part allotted or belonging to or contributed or owed by an individual or group.

to divide and distribute in shares; apportion.

- My friend gave me a share of his muffin this morning. 

CONTENT: 

something that is to be expressed through some medium, as speech, writing, or any of various arts:

something that is contained:

- I tend to like Youtube content over a long TV episode.

Post by josephdugas » Sat Sep 12, 2020 1:10 pm

SORT: 

a particular kind, species, variety, class, or group, distinguished by a common character or nature:

- I had some sort of fruit today when I woke up. 

SIFT:

to scatter or sprinkle through or by means of a sieve:

- I sifted honey throughout my tea.

SELECT:

to choose in preference to another or others; pick out

- I chose to select tacos for dinner. 

SUBSTITUTE: 

to put (a person or thing) in the place of another.

- Veggie burger is a great substitute for meat. 

WORDS: the text or lyrics of a song, as opposed to the music

- I knew all the words to I Miss You by Blink 182.

Post by josephdugas » Sat Sep 12, 2020 1:18 pm

STRUCTURE: mode of building, construction, or organization; arrangement of parts, elements, or constituents:

- NYC has a great structure to its buildings. 

ORGANIZE: to form as or into a whole consisting of interdependent or coordinated parts, especially for united action:

- I needed to organize my room before my friend came over. 

MAKE: to bring into existence by shaping or changing material, combining parts, etc.:

- I wanted to make a birthday cake for my mom. 

PRODUCE: to bring into existence; give rise to; cause: 

- I wanted to produce a great painting for the art show. 

BE: to exist or live

- Shakespeare's "To be or not to be"

SENSE: any of the faculties, as sight, hearing, smell, taste, or touch, by which humans and animals perceive stimuli originating from outside or inside the body:

- I had a great sense that my friend was stealing money from me. 

RANGE: the extent to which or the limits between which variation is possible:

- the singer had great range in her voice

FEELING: the function or the power of perceiving by touch.

- I lost feeling in my fingers after a long bike ride. 

FOCUS: a central point, as of attraction, attention, or activity:

- I needed to focus to study for my exam. 

MEDITATE: to engage in thought or contemplation; reflect.

- I needed to meditate after a long day of school. 

CONTEMPLATE: to look at or view with continued attention; observe or study thoughtfully:

- I contemplate a lot when I take a shower. 

MINDFUL: attentive, aware, or careful (usually followed by of):

- I'm often mindful of my breathing.

Post by josephdugas » Sun Sep 13, 2020 12:10 pm

MENTAL, SPACE, LABORATORY, EXPERIMENT, TEXTUAL, CONCEIVE, FORM, DEPICT, LOOK, COMPARE, CONTRAST

MENTAL: of or relating to the mind

- People from war have a lot of mental suffering.

SPACE: the unlimited or incalculably great three-dimensional realm or expanse in which all material objects are located and all events occur.

the portion or extent of this in a given instance; extent or room in three dimensions:

- The space between us was large after the break-up. 

LABORATORY:any place, situation, set of conditions, or the like, conducive to experimentation, investigation, observation, etc.; anything suggestive of a scientific laboratory.

- This course is a laboratory for words and thinking.

EXPERIMENT: a test, trial, or tentative procedure; an act or operation for the purpose of discovering something unknown or of testing a principle, supposition, etc.:

- For some products they tend to experiment on rats. 

TEXTUAL: based on or conforming to the text, as of the Scriptures

- People often get a textual interpretation of the bible tattooed on them. 

CONCEIVE: to form a notion or idea of; imagine.

- I can't conceive the idea that Jay-z is better than Kanye. 

FORM: external appearance of a clearly defined area, as distinguished from color or material; configuration:

- Everyone works their whole life to one day become their true form. 

DEPICT: to represent or characterize in words; describe.

- I depict a lot of paintings at the museum in NYC. 

LOOK:to turn one's eyes toward something or in some direction in order to see

- It's hard not to look at a beautiful girl walking by. 

COMPARE: to examine (two or more objects, ideas, people, etc.) in order to note similarities and differences:

- People often compare Michael Jordan to Kobe Bryant. 

CONTRAST: to compare in order to show unlikeness or differences; note the opposite natures, purposes, etc., of:

- I like to contrast certain music to find which I'm more in the mood for.

Post by josephdugas » Mon Sep 14, 2020 11:09 am

LEARNING: knowledge acquired by systematic study in any field of scholarly application.

- For this class I will be doing a different approach to learning that I'm not used to.

COMPETENCE: the quality of being competent; adequacy; possession of required skill, knowledge, qualification, or capacity:

- My competence for the subject matter landed me the job. 

ENHANCE: to raise to a higher degree; intensify; magnify:

- This class will surely enhance my learning here at URI. 

CAPACITY: the ability to receive or contain:

- I'd like to think my brain has a large capacity for new things.

HIERARCHY: any system of persons or things ranked one above another.

- In wildlife, there is a huge hierarchy. To eat of be eaten. There are tiers of prey.

TRAP: a contrivance used for catching game or other animals, as a mechanical device that springs shut suddenly.

- I set an animal trap while hunting in Alaska. 

IMPLICIT: implied, rather than expressly stated:

- We had an implicit agreement not to talk to that girl in math class. 

IMAGE: a physical likeness or representation of a person, animal, or thing, photographed, painted, sculptured, or otherwise made visible.

- I had a great image of a moose, it was even bigger in person.

STRUCTURE: mode of building, construction, or organization; arrangement of parts, elements, or constituents:

- I enjoy the structure of this class. Calm learning.

STYLE: a particular kind, sort, or type, as with reference to form, appearance, or character:

- The model on the fashion run way have a very elegant style.

ALIGN: to arrange in a straight line; adjust according to a line.

- While redecorating my room, I had to align a lot of furniture and photos.

Unread post by josephdugas » Mon Sep 14, 2020 11:17 am

MEANING: what is intended to be, or actually is, expressed or indicated; signification; import:

- I don't think anyone truly knows the meaning of life. 

PERCEPTION: the act or faculty of perceiving, or apprehending by means of the senses or of the mind; cognition; understanding.

- I had a great perception on WWE before I knew it was fake. 

TIME: the system of those sequential relations that any event has to any other, as past, present, or future; indefinite and continuous duration regarded as that in which events succeed one another.

- When you die, you run out of time. 

SPACE: the unlimited or incalculably great three-dimensional realm or expanse in which all material objects are located and all events occur.

- There is a lot of space in the world, looking to be occupied. 

IDEA: any conception existing in the mind as a result of mental understanding, awareness, or activity.

- I had great idea for a new invention.

VARIANCE: the state, quality, or fact of being variable, divergent, different, or anomalous.

an instance of varying; difference; discrepancy.

- There was a lot of variance for the menu at Wendys. 

SOCIAL: relating to, devoted to, or characterized by friendly companionship or relations:

- I enjoy my social clubs at school. 

PROCESS: a systematic series of actions directed to some end:

- All human beings have an oriented process in life. 

VALUE: relative worth, merit, or importance:

- People must have great self-worth to see the true value in themselves.

informed; alert; knowledgeable; sophisticated:

KNOWLEDGE:

acquaintance with facts, truths, or principles, as from study or investigation; general erudition:

- I am sure to gain a lot of knowledge with this course, I'm looking forward to it. 

KNOWING:

affecting, implying, or deliberately revealing shrewd knowledge of secret or private information:

- The wife gave a knowing glance that her husband was cheating. 

NUGGET: 

a lump of something, as of precious metal.

anything of great value, significance, or the like:

- My parents gave me many nuggets of wisdom throughout my life. 

SHARE:

the full or proper portion or part allotted or belonging to or contributed or owed by an individual or group.

to divide and distribute in shares; apportion.

- My friend gave me a share of his muffin this morning. 

CONTENT: 

something that is to be expressed through some medium, as speech, writing, or any of various arts:

something that is contained:

- I tend to like Youtube content over a long TV episode.

Post by josephdugas » Sat Sep 12, 2020 1:10 pm

SORT: 

a particular kind, species, variety, class, or group, distinguished by a common character or nature:

- I had some sort of fruit today when I woke up. 

SIFT:

to scatter or sprinkle through or by means of a sieve:

- I sifted honey throughout my tea.

SELECT:

to choose in preference to another or others; pick out

- I chose to select tacos for dinner. 

SUBSTITUTE: 

to put (a person or thing) in the place of another.

- Veggie burger is a great substitute for meat. 

WORDS: the text or lyrics of a song, as opposed to the music

- I knew all the words to I Miss You by Blink 182.

Post by josephdugas » Sat Sep 12, 2020 1:18 pm

STRUCTURE: mode of building, construction, or organization; arrangement of parts, elements, or constituents:

- NYC has a great structure to its buildings. 

ORGANIZE: to form as or into a whole consisting of interdependent or coordinated parts, especially for united action:

- I needed to organize my room before my friend came over. 

MAKE: to bring into existence by shaping or changing material, combining parts, etc.:

- I wanted to make a birthday cake for my mom. 

PRODUCE: to bring into existence; give rise to; cause: 

- I wanted to produce a great painting for the art show. 

BE: to exist or live

- Shakespeare's "To be or not to be"

SENSE: any of the faculties, as sight, hearing, smell, taste, or touch, by which humans and animals perceive stimuli originating from outside or inside the body:

- I had a great sense that my friend was stealing money from me. 

RANGE: the extent to which or the limits between which variation is possible:

- the singer had great range in her voice

FEELING: the function or the power of perceiving by touch.

- I lost feeling in my fingers after a long bike ride. 

FOCUS: a central point, as of attraction, attention, or activity:

- I needed to focus to study for my exam. 

MEDITATE: to engage in thought or contemplation; reflect.

- I needed to meditate after a long day of school. 

CONTEMPLATE: to look at or view with continued attention; observe or study thoughtfully:

- I contemplate a lot when I take a shower. 

MINDFUL: attentive, aware, or careful (usually followed by of):

- I'm often mindful of my breathing.

Post by josephdugas » Sun Sep 13, 2020 12:10 pm

MENTAL, SPACE, LABORATORY, EXPERIMENT, TEXTUAL, CONCEIVE, FORM, DEPICT, LOOK, COMPARE, CONTRAST

MENTAL: of or relating to the mind

- People from war have a lot of mental suffering.

SPACE: the unlimited or incalculably great three-dimensional realm or expanse in which all material objects are located and all events occur.

the portion or extent of this in a given instance; extent or room in three dimensions:

- The space between us was large after the break-up. 

LABORATORY:any place, situation, set of conditions, or the like, conducive to experimentation, investigation, observation, etc.; anything suggestive of a scientific laboratory.

- This course is a laboratory for words and thinking.

EXPERIMENT: a test, trial, or tentative procedure; an act or operation for the purpose of discovering something unknown or of testing a principle, supposition, etc.:

- For some products they tend to experiment on rats. 

TEXTUAL: based on or conforming to the text, as of the Scriptures

- People often get a textual interpretation of the bible tattooed on them. 

CONCEIVE: to form a notion or idea of; imagine.

- I can't conceive the idea that Jay-z is better than Kanye. 

FORM: external appearance of a clearly defined area, as distinguished from color or material; configuration:

- Everyone works their whole life to one day become their true form. 

DEPICT: to represent or characterize in words; describe.

- I depict a lot of paintings at the museum in NYC. 

LOOK:to turn one's eyes toward something or in some direction in order to see

- It's hard not to look at a beautiful girl walking by. 

COMPARE: to examine (two or more objects, ideas, people, etc.) in order to note similarities and differences:

- People often compare Michael Jordan to Kobe Bryant. 

CONTRAST: to compare in order to show unlikeness or differences; note the opposite natures, purposes, etc., of:

- I like to contrast certain music to find which I'm more in the mood for.

Post by josephdugas » Mon Sep 14, 2020 11:09 am

LEARNING: knowledge acquired by systematic study in any field of scholarly application.

- For this class I will be doing a different approach to learning that I'm not used to.

COMPETENCE: the quality of being competent; adequacy; possession of required skill, knowledge, qualification, or capacity:

- My competence for the subject matter landed me the job. 

ENHANCE: to raise to a higher degree; intensify; magnify:

- This class will surely enhance my learning here at URI. 

CAPACITY: the ability to receive or contain:

- I'd like to think my brain has a large capacity for new things.

HIERARCHY: any system of persons or things ranked one above another.

- In wildlife, there is a huge hierarchy. To eat of be eaten. There are tiers of prey.

TRAP: a contrivance used for catching game or other animals, as a mechanical device that springs shut suddenly.

- I set an animal trap while hunting in Alaska. 

IMPLICIT: implied, rather than expressly stated:

- We had an implicit agreement not to talk to that girl in math class. 

IMAGE: a physical likeness or representation of a person, animal, or thing, photographed, painted, sculptured, or otherwise made visible.

- I had a great image of a moose, it was even bigger in person.

STRUCTURE: mode of building, construction, or organization; arrangement of parts, elements, or constituents:

- I enjoy the structure of this class. Calm learning.

STYLE: a particular kind, sort, or type, as with reference to form, appearance, or character:

- The model on the fashion run way have a very elegant style.

ALIGN: to arrange in a straight line; adjust according to a line.

- While redecorating my room, I had to align a lot of furniture and photos.

Unread post by josephdugas » Mon Sep 14, 2020 11:17 am

MEANING: what is intended to be, or actually is, expressed or indicated; signification; import:

- I don't think anyone truly knows the meaning of life. 

PERCEPTION: the act or faculty of perceiving, or apprehending by means of the senses or of the mind; cognition; understanding.

- I had a great perception on WWE before I knew it was fake. 

TIME: the system of those sequential relations that any event has to any other, as past, present, or future; indefinite and continuous duration regarded as that in which events succeed one another.

- When you die, you run out of time. 

SPACE: the unlimited or incalculably great three-dimensional realm or expanse in which all material objects are located and all events occur.

- There is a lot of space in the world, looking to be occupied. 

IDEA: any conception existing in the mind as a result of mental understanding, awareness, or activity.

- I had great idea for a new invention.

VARIANCE: the state, quality, or fact of being variable, divergent, different, or anomalous.

an instance of varying; difference; discrepancy.

- There was a lot of variance for the menu at Wendys. 

SOCIAL: relating to, devoted to, or characterized by friendly companionship or relations:

- I enjoy my social clubs at school. 

PROCESS: a systematic series of actions directed to some end:

- All human beings have an oriented process in life. 

VALUE: relative worth, merit, or importance:

- People must have great self-worth to see the true value in themselves.

Date: 9/14/2020 13:01:39
Subject: moving into a zone
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone, Good morning,

Glad some of you stuck around in the fishbowl over the weekend. It seems we're moving into simpler spaces and slower times. 

Your fishbowl is about a new management practice in a new society. 

I trust you're making a daily practice of your reading, watching and writing. Please see Michael Degnan’s advice below. 

Keep the thread of communication, I will always say.

We are leaving spaces of organized hierarchal work and moving into a ZONE where the ability to understand, facilitate, and encourage processes of self-organization will be a key competence. Your fishbowl has no presence beyond the three of you who bring it to life. The central theme in the course is Learning. You can’t force nor dictate learning...but you can enhance your group's capacities to learn and align their activities in creative ways.

It is impossible to develop new styles of work while continuing to think in old ways, you’ll agree. However, we are often trapped by the images we hold about ourselves and our group. 

Ideas about the fishbowl are always based on implicit images or metaphors that persuade us to see, understand, and manage situations in a particular way.

Metaphors create insight. Sanjiv is a Dawg. But they also distort. They have strengths. But they also have limitations. In creating ways of seeing, they create ways of not seeing. There can be no simple “correct theory” for structuring everything we do. The challenge facing us is to become accomplished in the art of using metaphor to find new ways of seeing, understanding, and shaping our actions.

Sanjiv

LEARNING, COMPETENCE, ENHANCE, CAPACITY, HIERARCHY, TRAP, IMPLICIT, IMAGE, STRUCTURE, STYLE, ALIGN

from the fishbowl...words of advice from leaders in the field

Post by michaeldegnan » Fri Sep 11, 2020 12:44 pm

Searching for nuggets: watching, looking, seeing

Even though this class is taught in a way that is different compared to any of the other classes at URI, we still have the ability to gain a lot of valuable information in this course. Since I have taken Professor Dugal's course before (last semester), I believe I may have an advantage over others who haven’t yet had a course with him, only because I already have an understanding of what he expects. Over the course of my previous class with him, I have found that as long as you stay organized with all of your work and complete the assignments about the letters on time, the class becomes quite simple to manage.

Post by michaeldegnan » Sun Sep 13, 2020 5:14 pm

Text Books

Personally, I find the idea of reading a few pages each day much easier than reading large amounts of a book at once. Reading 3 pages per day and finding a sentence should not take longer than 10 minutes per day. This means that we will be gaining valuable pieces of information each day with our readings. Additionally, I believe that these books sound interesting because of how Professor Dugal tells us not to rush our readings. The reason he wants to take our time reading these pages is because of the powerful images and messages that this book tells.

Post by michaeldegnan » Sun Sep 13, 2020 6:19 pm

The Third Eye: Taking Words Further

One of the main lessons I learned from Professor Dugal's class is that in order to gain the most information, we have to take the words that he says and make our own interpretations of it. If people only read the letters and do not try to interpret the words into their own experiences, then they will only gain a limited amount of information. "In a nutshell: take a word further by substituting it, after sorting, sifting, and selecting." That is the advice that Professor Dugal gives and it should be followed when reading all of the letters that are sent.

Post by michaeldegnan » Sun Sep 13, 2020 6:48 pm

Some logistics on a Sunday morning

I am a complete believer that the best way to well in this class is to set a continuous routine of when to complete the work for this class. If you wait a few days and attempt to do all of the week's work at once, you will feel overwhelmed and it will take much more time than desired. Additionally, it is much easier to forget one of the assignments if you attempt to do them all at the same time. Last semester, it did take a few weeks for me to get the hang of how Professor Dugal's class works, but once you figure it out, I believe it becomes quite simple.

Date: 9/13/2020 23:35:41
Subject: connectivity over efficiency
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi John,

1. There is vocabulary because you are drawing a boundary for the discourse; you are gathering words. 

2. You are ‘deconstructing' letters because that shows your levels of understanding of concepts. 

3. Then there are google searches. One sentence for each. These are important to learn the underlying theory and know the philosophers.

4. The interactive is your work concerning the four characteristics of transnational organizations for 345. For 448, we tackle Hofstede’s dimensions of culture.

5. Finally, the individual exercises. These are spontaneous and done for understanding some basic concepts.

The above are to be layered with felt-experiences. These come from memory, images and experience; they determine your interpretation of events from your life.

My letters are relentless. They are more concerned with describing phenomena that have changed the workplace like your fishbowl. Your fishbowl, you will discover, is based upon experiential knowing and knowledge building. 

All this might sound overwhelming, but it boils down to simple techniques for word constructions that are authentic and transparent in their intentions. Every one gets-it because it is not rocket science, but it is your outcomes, both individual and collective that continuously overwhelm. 

It is happening in blocks like lego. I don't feel rushed. I feel connected through words with you all. We are going to emphasize “connectivity" and not "efficiency”. 

Connection is emphasized is through process and practice in the course. The following are some of the ways discussed:

in the moment

intuitive and chance

exchange of words

image and imagination

interpretation

on going and flowing

pathway and trajectory

projection 

Sanjiv

Date: 9/13/2020 10:59:08
Subject: some logistics on a Sunday morning
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you this sunday morning? There is much we have to accomplish between ourselves. By the start of next week, you must have introduced yourselves in your group and, you must have the routine down for navigating your fishbowls. Otherwise, you will be falling behind. 

To catch up, you have to read my letters, from the bottom up. You can’t ask me directly, until you have worked through the letters. It’s all there. Instructions, approach, requirements, dates and outcomes. We’re looking at each other in a textual world and, we are together producing a textual outcome which will have repercussions in our lives. There is much at stake here, and we will be talking about that subsequently. 

Creative action is between yourselves in the fishbowl. It’s known as Creaction up at Babson. More on this later. At a fundamental level, you have to get along. I am not the creator of your content. In fact, it is from you, for example, that I am re-learning and reflecting about Deleuze and his idea of plateaus. Some ideas just don’t go out of style. Thank you for that.

See yourselves as craftsmen of words. Our task this semester is precarious and fragile, like a porcelain workshop. I think that is a good metaphor.

What does all this mean and what do you have to do? You might be surprised...reading the other’s text shows respect for the written word and, listening to words shows caring for the written word. It doesn’t go beyond that, as only then can you say something that will add value, without repeating what is already said. 

It is bad etiquette to respond directly to each other in the fishbowl (send a private email instead), and nor do we do affirmation or criticism. Neither agreement nor disagreement. We’re not sitting in judgement of anyone’s selection of words. 

You are being asked to post in your own space, but also to look over and read your groups’ postings, with the purpose of learning from each other. What do you bring to the table; your contribution, and how much did you labor in producing it is the question. What is your process? 

 You labor alone in your own space, and only after that do you ‘look’ over at the others and make comparisons and contrast. It is the act of comparing and contrasting that adds value. Please keep that in mind. We are looking for differences in everything, like how you write your vocabulary, for example.

You’ll soon get the hang of it when you understand symbols! It’s a language game. Not difficult, only challenging and innovative. Don’t rush the process, savor it. 

You are learning to focus on words, and it is difficult because our minds are easily distracted. You are being asked to commit to a 'mental space' among yourselves. To be present, focused, engaged, transparent and authentic whenever you enter this space. Whenever and however you appear, emerge, surface, from everywhere, nowhere and anywhere. The virtual land of the fishbowl.

Letters, Words, Dictionary, Meaning, Select, Substitute, Sentence, Structure, Create, Invent, Reflect. 

In your fishbowls, you are constituting a kind of laboratory for experimentation in new 'forms of thinking' that help you conceive innovative practices applicable to any situation.

The course is not difficult but it does require immersion. Please wiki Immersion Technology

You’ve got to slow down and stare into space, thinking about the path (word) not selected. 

Sharing your process is to ‘depict' yourself. Doing everything together becomes the job. When we’re together, we cannot be stopped. That is the world of The Virus. We’re together whenever we're apart. We’re eyes looking at eyes. I can see you looking at me looking at you. I read into your words and between the lines. Be mindful. We’re not going anywhere in a hurry.

It is incredible the conditions under which we are living and strict puritanical discipline. On the other hand, what I have encountered in the fishbowl is a living portrait of immense vitality, brave, loving, generous. and rebellious, driven by enthusiasms and emotional conflicts that reflect very aptly the struggles of your shifting environments.

Sanjiv

MENTAL, SPACE, LABORATORY, EXPERIMENT, TEXTUAL, CONCEIVE, FORM, DEPICT, LOOK, COMPARE, CONTRAST, LOGISTICS (wiki)

from the fishbowl...caitlynoliver » Sat Sep 12, 2020 5:38 pm

Assembling Text: "welcome again & again always welcome" letter

	

Soft-Power (please google)- a persuasive approach to international relations, typically involving the use of economic or cultural influence.

Panopticon (please google)- (def.) a circular prison with cells arranged around a central well, from which prisoners could at all times be observed. 

Excerpt from the letter, "welcome again & again always welcome": The Big Eye is watching, and I will show you how to take it on the panopticon (please google)." 

From the tower the guards can see every cell but the prisoners can't see the guards.

David-Goliath Story (please google)- Excerpt from the letter, "welcome again & again always welcome": "It is the David-Goliath story (please google) metaphor for doing business.." 

David and Goliath is a secular story often referenced as a moral lesson of how underdogs can overcome the odds and be successful.

Deleuze & Guttari's "A Thousand Plateaus" (please google)- Excerpt from the letter, "welcome again & again always welcome": Instead of writing one long letter, I will write to you in bits and pieces, each letter a plateau like, Deleuze and Guattari’s "A Thousand Plateaus" (please google).

A plateau is an assemblage that organizes intensive processes into temporary stable states that can be given specific dates but can neither persist nor be repeated.

From: "The third eye: taking words further" letter

Deep Thinking (please google): Deep thinking is how we increase our number of valuable and useful thoughts. Your quantity of valuable thoughts has a direct effect on your quantity of valuable actions. We all think, but not all of us think deeply, which is thinking beyond what your mind defaults to.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/12/2020 16:06:48
Subject: The Third Eye: Taking Words Further
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you this morning? You are heroes and we need each other: a heightened respect and regard for the Other. 

Don’t let 'too much' get to you. 

Slow the Mind is the mantra for the semester. How to do that? 

Breathe consciously, as often as you can. Watch your breath, even when someone is talking to you.

1. You are dealing with a wide range of feelings, all jumbled up.

To survive such a situation, you have to be able to make sense.

Making Sense. Producing Sense. Being Sensible. All different things. 

Please reflect on each of them. How are you going to do that?

SORT, SIFT, SELECT, SUBSTITUTE, WORDS.

Have a personal relationship with your dictionary. 

Take a word further by sorting, sifting, selecting and substituting.

In this way, you are never at a loss for words. 

You can get whatever you want, but the outcome depends on what words you said.

2.There is much to absorb. Be a blotting paper (metaphor; see Colicci below). Write your thoughts in your fishbowl under the label Reflections on Letters. Is that what you are calling this box/category? Deconstructing Letters, or Reading Between the Lines are also good labels, I would think. Call it whatever you wish and change it whenever you wish, but here in this space of yours, it is quiet time for reflecting on thoughts. Thinking about thinking!

3. Get the hang of the basic organization of things in the fishbowl. That is, organizing your boxes and their labels. After that there can be little confusion or feeling lost. Our vision, our sight, our trajectory of thoughts become fixed by our mental structures. Our world, our relations, our societies, even our feelings, all have underlying structures. We can’t see them with the naked eye. You need a third eye!

4. Flexible structures are key when the environment is unpredictable and chaotic.

That is, flexibility in labeling our labels. Changing the words, changes the structure.

To change a structure is to change the labels. 

Producing such a change requires the skill of Deep Thinking (please google).

In a nutshell: take a word further by substituting it, after sorting, sifting and selecting. This is to focus on a word. Mindfulness. Meditating and contemplating on one word, every time, again and again. You could be awkward, stumble or fall, but there is no right nor wrong in this matter.

Sanjiv

DEEP THINKING (google), STRUCTURE, ORGANIZE, MAKE, PRODUCE, BE, SENSE, RANGE, FEELING, FOCUS, MEDITATE, CONTEMPLATE, MINDFUL

from the fishbowl...

nickcolicci

Re: Making Notes

Wed Sep 09, 2020 1:03 pm

Per your dicitonary.com: Metaphors help writers and poets make a point in a more interesting way. They also help the reader see something from a new perspective. By describing tears as a river, for example, the writer found a creative way to describe how great the girl's sadness was and helped the reader see a similarity between tears and a river that they might not have noticed before. This makes reading more fun and interesting.

With the Fishbowl being a digital community, the best way to express impact and meaning is through the use of metaphors. They allow us to use powerful examples that resonate with a larger audience. In addition, it makes our reading and exercises more interesting. While it may take time to develop metaphors that fit one's style, we can learn a lot about our thought processes and mental structure while we embark on that journey.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/12/2020 16:06:07
Subject: The Third Eye: Taking Words Further
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you this morning? You are heroes and we need each other: a heightened respect and regard for the Other. 

Don’t let 'too much' get to you. 

Slow the Mind is the mantra for the semester. How to do that? 

Breathe consciously, as often as you can. Watch your breath, even when someone is talking to you.

1. You are dealing with a wide range of feelings, all jumbled up.

To survive such a situation, you have to be able to make sense.

Making Sense. Producing Sense. Being Sensible. All different things. 

Please reflect on each of them. How are you going to do that?

SORT, SIFT, SELECT, SUBSTITUTE, WORDS.

Have a personal relationship with your dictionary. 

Take a word further by sorting, sifting, selecting and substituting.

In this way, you are never at a loss for words. 

You can get whatever you want, but the outcome depends on what words you said.

2.There is much to absorb. Be a blotting paper (metaphor; see Colicci below). Write your thoughts in your fishbowl under the label Reflections on Letters. Is that what you are calling this box/category? Deconstructing Letters, or Reading Between the Lines are also good labels, I would think. Call it whatever you wish and change it whenever you wish, but here in this space of yours, it is quiet time for reflecting on thoughts. Thinking about thinking!

3. Get the hang of the basic organization of things in the fishbowl. That is, organizing your boxes and their labels. After that there can be little confusion or feeling lost. Our vision, our sight, our trajectory of thoughts become fixed by our mental structures. Our world, our relations, our societies, even our feelings, all have underlying structures. We can’t see them with the naked eye. You need a third eye!

4. Flexible structures are key when the environment is unpredictable and chaotic.

That is, flexibility in labeling our labels. Changing the words, changes the structure.

To change a structure is to change the labels. 

Producing such a change requires the skill of Deep Thinking (please google).

In a nutshell: take a word further by substituting it, after sorting, sifting and selecting. This is to focus on a word. Mindfulness. Meditating and contemplating on one word, every time, again and again. You could be awkward, stumble or fall, but there is no right nor wrong in this matter.

Sanjiv

DEEP THINKING (google), STRUCTURE, ORGANIZE, MAKE, PRODUCE, BE, SENSE, RANGE, FEELING, FOCUS, MEDITATE, CONTEMPLATE, MINDFUL

from the fishbowl...

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/12/2020 15:50:07
Subject: text books
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you doing?

In BUS 448 we drop familiar habits of learning and interacting so as to engage more successfully with the unexpected and participate in the diverse world which surrounds us (Bateson).

By now you have both your text books. If you haven’t, please do so. I don’t expect you to encounter any difficulty. 

1. Mary Catherine Bateson’s Peripheral Visions is a classic for ‘learning along the way’ in foreign situations. 

In the fishbowl, you are operating on a plane of intersecting cultural dimensions. In such a situation, where the unexpected can be expected, it is essential to have peripheral vision.

Please read 3 pages of Bateson every day. Please copy one sentence from each page every time. Select the sentence for its abstract value. In this way, by the end of the semester, we will have read 235 pages. You will not be disappointed. Do slow time for this daily practice. Don’t rush the reading; dwell upon words and phrases. Ascertain meaning. 

2. The second text, Exploring Culture is a workbook by the famous Hofstede. More on his body of work later. There is time, and we don’t rush, remember. But we show up and read. We are all Eyes. At this point, read the Introduction with care. Deep learning always happens when you pull-out abstract ideas from every page. Soon you will want to do so from every paragraph. Abstracting. Digging for Gold. Study the Introduction and Table of Contents.

Sanjiv

HABIT, FAMILIAR, UNEXPECTED, PARTICIPATE, PERIPHERAL, VISION, EXPLORE, CULTURE

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/11/2020 22:46:22
Subject: societies and mega cities
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How are you? I hope you have settled into a routine of study for the semester. 

Please watch the Ted Talk by Parag Khanna below on "How megacities are changing the map of the world.”

Please write down 5 abstract ideas posited by the speaker. Abstract ideas are phrases or a sentence that speaks at a universal level. For example, Khanna says the future is about “Connectivity and not Sovereignty” is one such idea presented by the Talk Host.

You are learning to identify abstract ideas. You are learning to take ideas further by re-searching the meaning of the words used in the sentence that captures the idea, and you're editing and re-editing the meaning and in doing so, you are developing the idea in your own words. Always follow the KISS principle.

As an Introduction to the syllabus, the course considers how meaning and perception of time and space themselves vary over time and space, and this variance affects individual values and social processes of the most fundamental kind.

Sanjiv

MEANING, PERCEPTION, TIME, SPACE, IDEA, VARIANCE, SOCIAL, PROCESS, VALUE 

att/

https://www.ted.com/talks/parag_khanna_how_megacities_are_changing_the_map_of_the_world?language=en

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/11/2020 9:39:40
Subject: searching for nuggets: watching, looking, seeing
------------------------------------------------------------
Dear Kara,

Thank your for your email and I hope you are well. 

The course is taught through letter-writing. You receive written text, i.e., prose from me, several times a week. 

You are developing the skill of Abstraction. 

Please google Abstract Art and pull out a Sentence from your search that you wish to bring to the table. That is how the assignments will be. Assignments will always be embedded in my letters. Like nuggets in the sand. 

You are committing to a semester of continual assignments. How many of these assignments you do, how much you learn and absorb by doing them, and how much you share your knowing and knowledge creation, will be entirely up to you. That’s a promise, not a threat.

Whoever does the minimum gets a B. More on that later.

There are research methodologies involved and you will be made aware of them.

In your groups, you are jointly creating a knowing among yourselves and a knowledge content. You are learning how to do so.

The first and most enduring task is that you are reading what your group members are posting in their five subject areas, and you are taking them into account as you do the same. You are interacting only through reading the other’s text. You are not responding to the other’s text. You are merely reading it. You are reading the Text of the Other, looking for the difference between your texts. 

The course is big on the notionS of BETWEEN, DIFFERENCE and PROCESS. Please check out words in capital letters.

You are working on your own all semester, but in the awareness that two other people are reading you every time you make a post. You are looking at each other. So, even as you work alone, you can’t do without the other. You are together apart!

Presently, we are polishing the silver (metaphor), you could say, and we haven’t started to set the table yet. And what is cooking in the kitchen, don’t even ask!

Thus far, you have arrived in the fishbowl and you have set up five subject areas and you’ve read the syllabus and letters three times. You have also noticed some people have posted vocabularies and started researching and reassembling sentences from the internet and you’re wondering, am I behind or what. But you know Sanjiv is working on a letter and it will probably confuse you some more. That is all he seems to be doing. Working the words.

My role is to help you see things as symbols, concepts, and structures. Metaphors and analogies. The bigger picture. Your choices and decisions-making begins to evolve, develop and change. There is no end in sight!

I think it is early for us to meet. It’s all coming up. We are WATCHING ourselves in the fishbowl. We are learning To LOOK, and then, To SEE ourselves.

When you are through with this letter, you will have taken strides in understanding cultural dimensions.

Best wishes,

Sanjiv

ABSTRACT ART (please google), OTHER (google), TEXT, COMPOSE, EXPRESSION, EMBEDDED, AWARE, KNOWLEDGE, KNOWING, NUGGET, SHARE, CONTENT

Hi Tyler,

Thank you for email and your questions. 

Our questions indicate our state of mind.

If you’ve registered and posted your Introduction to your group, you’re on top of things.

Congratulations!

When you click on your group, a page comes up and in a red box says New Topic.

Click on it.

An empty page with a Subject box shows up.

You are to type 5 subject topics. You can see how the others have done it.

1.Vocabulary: meaning

2.Response to Letters: deconstruction

3.Google Searches: assemblage

4.Interactive assignments: back and forth

5. Individual assignments: deep learning

After that you are all set. Whenever you post in a subject say Vocabulary, always hit Reply. That way your vocabulary will scroll down under one Subject and not a New Topic every time.

Take a look at Palumbo’s Vocabulary in 345/1. I love the way she does it. She has taken my class before, and I always read and study her Vocabulary. Neatly, simply and done with Integrity. Such things are now rendered visible.

Read, read, and read, everything slowly, and 3 times.

That is the trick.

Before you enter the fishbowl, get into the right frame of mind: empty the mind, slow it down, focus on words, watch like a Sniper (metaphor). Or, like a sportsman, eye on the ball.

There are no deadlines. Your responsibility is to your group and you must keep up together.

I will answer the rest of your questions as we progress. 

I hope this helps.

Sanjiv
