On Wed, Sep 9, 2020 at 12:41 PM Sanjiv Dugal <sanjivdugal@uri.edu> wrote:

Hi Everyone,

How are you? Welcome! Welcome! So nice to be here together.

I teach through letter writing. Open a file and house my letters in one place. You will also find them in the fishbowl.

I will consciously be repeating myself a lot, until I am blue in the face.

Only to make sure that you are absorbing ideas and developing your points of view.

These are essential skills. Developing Ideas and View-points. Taking Positions and Explaining and Expressing yourself.

Approach to the Course:

We enter the fishbowl in the moment of reading this email.

The fishbowl is a metaphor for mental space, visual space, inter-subjective space.

It is sacred space: Between us. 

Between: you and me. 

Between: you and your group. 

Between you and the class. 

The development of our process can be checked-out in our groups.

We love process over outcome. 

We are continually seeking wider and larger audiences to express and show our process.

It is how we develop in interactive space.

We are learning to acquire soft-power (please google).

Our tools and instruments are text and images. 

We are wordsmiths. Craft people. Designers, artists, poets, painters, sculptors, weavers, stonemasons. Musicians and chefs and entrepreneurs.

And, we are process oriented.

Before you enter the fishbowl, slow the racing mind down. How so? 

Stop thinking about other things, except your breathing. I’m not kidding.

It will help you get in touch with the approach we’re following in class.

None of us have to show up at 3 on wednesdays. That’s what ASYNCHRONOUS time means. It is not like with Zoom. I find Zoom stressful because it is like making it on time to the movies. My girlfriend used to like to arrive at the theatre just-in-time when the credits began rolling. She couldn’t care about Previews. I knew we couldn’t last! 

In the fishbowl, you are showing-up the moment you read this letter, and you wait like a sniper. You become visible the moment you post in your fishbowl. The Big Eye is watching, and I will show you how to take it on. It is the David-Goliath story (please google) metaphor for doing business..

Instead of writing one long letter, I will write to you in bits and pieces, each letter a plateau like, Deleuze and Guattari’s "A Thousand Plateaus" (please google).

Whenever you google search, Please SELECT and post a sentence, a word, a phrase to hang your hat (metaphor) on. By so doing, you are making an original contribution to your group, who are doing the same:

deleuze and guattari: A thousand plateaus.

for example from wiki:

A "plateau", borrowed from ideas in Gregory Bateson's research on Balinese culture, is "a continuous, self-vibrating region of intensities"; the chapters in the book are described as plateaus, while their respective dates also signify a level of intensity, where "each plateau can be read starting anywhere and can be related to any other plateau.”

Post your google searches under Assemblage of Text. You can call it anything you are comfortable with. Call it Google Searches or Taking and Making Notes.

VOCABULARY will be in CAPITALS in the body of the letter and the words will be repeated at the end of my letter.

I will soon stop sending your email addresses. They have been sent until now to help you get in touch with each other whenever need be.

We start of slow at first. There are some heavy-hitters among you. Just to let you know. Let things EVOLVE and UNFOLD.

Sanjiv

ASYNCHRONOUS, SELECT, EVOLVE, UNFOLD, ABSORB

Dear Will Healis,

At the outset thank you for your email. I can well imagine your level of stress and I have every intention of dispelling it in my reply.

To begin with, this entire semester, I will write and tell you the What of the steps and, at the same time, the Why of the steps.

For the moment, what I am asking of you is to slow your mind by becoming conscious of your breathing. Watch and listen to the breath. And keep in mind during the process, that my job is to help you grow as a human being. PLease do this every time you enter the fishbowl. There is no rushing there. We don’t breeze through nor swim fast in the fishbowl. We’re floating or strolling in the park, because we’re watching to make eye contact. These are all metaphors. They help us communicate with each other.

1. During the semester, don’t break the thread (metaphor) of my letters. Read each one at least 3 times. The entire semester will EMANATE and UNFOLD from the Letters. You’re paying me for these letters (words and sentences and paragraphs) but you have to do the work. Like going to the Gym (metaphor again). 

The work you are being asked to do is develop the art of taking and making notes. To be good at doing this in an environment that is unpredictable, fast changing and confusing.

Individual Exercies

I will be helping you develop your process (of taking and making notes) by writing to you regularly.

An Artistʼs New Migration Song - The New York Times

4/29/20, 7)58 AM

https://nyti.ms/3cNxYS3

An Artist’s New Migration Song

Serge Alain Nitegeka can’t leave South Africa, but his art, on the refugee condition, is traveling.

By Siddhartha Mitter

April 26, 2020

Serge Alain Nitegeka hasn’t been free to roam in a while. For over ﬁve years, the Johannesburg artist has been unable to leave South Africa as he waits for his case for citizenship there to be resolved. (He was born in Rwanda.)

Overseas exhibitions, commissions — he’s had them. But from a remove. Paintings are easy enough: You pack them, and give instructions for how they need to hang. Installations are more complicated. One new work involves a plot of fresh soil, a bundle of twigs, as in ﬁrewood, and Mr. Nitegeka’s sculptures of makeshift objects that migrants and refugees often carry.

The work represents a pit-stop on a forced journey; its spirit requires that the dirt and wood be local. For Mr. Nitegeka’s exhibition “Black Migrant,” with the Marianne Boesky gallery (it is viewable by appointment or on the gallery website), he relied on the gallery team to gather New York dirt, which turned out darker and mulchier than the reddish soil Mr. Nitegeka had pictured. That was ﬁne — adaptation was the point of the piece. But the more tactile and sensory these decisions, the more the distance frustrated him.

“It gets in the way of progress,” he said by telephone from Johannesburg recently. “You need to be in there, smell it, feel the presence.”

Nevertheless, he added, “that’s the beauty of art in this day and age, things can go and you can have a show still.” His situation has given him practice in the remote work that many artists will likely confront in the aftermath of the coronavirus pandemic until travel becomes feasible.

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/26/arts/design/south-africa-nitegeka-artist.html

Page 1 of 7 An Artistʼs New Migration Song - The New York Times

4/29/20, 7)58 AM

A view of Serge Alain Nitegeka’s exhibition “Black Migrant” at Marianne Boesky gallery. At center is “Migrant I,” an installation of soil, ﬁrewood and sculpted objects that recall the things that migrants carry on their journey. Lance Brewer

Perhaps ﬁttingly, Mr. Nitegeka’s work is all about displacement and obstacles. Forced migration, he said, is his “lifelong exploration.” Its roots are speciﬁc and intense. He was an 11-year-old in Rwanda when the 1994 genocide occurred. The family left in a hurry.

“I didn’t even have a chance to go back in the house,” he said. “Someone arrived, and my dad was like — your sister, your brother, your mum, you’ve got to go now.” There wasn’t time to put together the “fragile cargo,” the migrant’s bag of essential or treasured items.

Across the Congolese border in Goma, a cholera epidemic swept through the city. The boy roamed the town on his own, from the hillside where the family rented a room on the edge of the refugee camp, down to the lake. “There were dead bodies in the street, rolled up in mats, some not even covered,” he said. “And there was this stench.”

Mr. Nitegeka made it to Nairobi, where he attended high school, and then to Johannesburg. “I had nothing,” he said. “I could survive on ﬁve dollars, even three dollars, for a month.” He found his way to art school at the University of the Witwatersrand.

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/26/arts/design/south-africa-nitegeka-artist.html

Page 2 of 7 An Artistʼs New Migration Song - The New York Times

4/29/20, 7)58 AM

The artist in his studio. Wood is ubiquitous in his practice, as a surface for his paintings, and in his dramatic installations made of criss-crossing planks Gulshan Khan for The New York Times

Since his ﬁrst exhibition in 2008, his career has ﬂourished. In 2015 he had a solo show at SCAD Museum of Art in Savannah, Ga., and Boesky devoted its Armory Show booth to his work. The same year, he participated in the South African pavilion at the Venice Biennale.

Mr. Nitegeka is best known for his use of abstraction, notably his dramatic installations that involve forests of crisscrossing plywood planks, connected at irregular angles, painted black. Each is built to ﬁt the space — a gallery, a museum hallway, or in a spectacular example recently, the atrium of the Norval Foundation in Cape Town.

The installations have a mathematical beauty — a geometry. But they are also unruly, bristling. Visitors have to pick their way through the maze. Though rendered in an elegant formalized language — Mr. Nitegeka, a student of Minimalism, has cited Richard Serra as an inﬂuence, along with architects like Louis Kahn — the works are an obstacle course that symbolizes the migrant’s journey.

His paintings, too, operate in a narrow palette: black, red, yellow, a speciﬁc blue. They are made on wood, often leaving sections exposed. The sense of carpentry runs through all his projects, as when he includes in his installations the wood crates used to ship the art, as ready-mades.

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/26/arts/design/south-africa-nitegeka-artist.html

Page 3 of 7 An Artistʼs New Migration Song - The New York Times

4/29/20, 7)58 AM

“Migrant: Studio Study VI,” 2020. Serge Alain Nitegeka and Marianne

Boesky Gallery

“Migrant: Studio Study VII,” 2020. Serge Alain Nitegeka and Marianne

Boesky Gallery

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/26/arts/design/south-africa-nitegeka-artist.html

Page 4 of 7 An Artistʼs New Migration Song - The New York Times

4/29/20, 7)58 AM

Mr. Nitegeka’s “Things I lost to the soil II,” from 2020, dried and pressed paint on wood.

and Marianne Boesky Gallery

Serge Alain Nitegeka

They invoke the art trade, but also, as the curator Hansi Momodu-Gordon observed in a 2015 essay, “the artist’s personal story of forced migration and perhaps also the forced transportation of African people during the slave trade.”

In the past decade, as the global refugee and migrant crisis became a salient topic for artists, Mr. Nitegeka’s language set him apart from more literal approaches.

“He has a different way of engaging political metaphors,” said the curator Marie-Ann Yemsi, who has included Mr. Nitegeka in an upcoming show at the Palais de Tokyo, in Paris. “These questions of desperation, of loss, are present in his work in an abstract fashion, but at the same time anchor it in the tumult of the world.”

In Johannesburg, Mr. Nitegeka rents a large studio in an industrial zone across the freeway from downtown. The city has a busy art scene but Mr. Nitegeka keeps his own company. When not at home with his wife and two children or working late in the studio, he’s more likely to be cycling the city on an aimless six-hour ride.

Privacy is his default mode. Speaking with me in his studio last year, he had brushed away talk of his personal journey. “It’s a story I don’t want to engage,” he said.

Yet his new work at Boesky strikes a different tone, lyrical and intimate. The installation of dirt has a pathos and directness absent from his geometric pieces. His new paintings mark a return to the ﬁgurative, with a series of charcoal self-portraits: He is nude, standing or crouching, his body barred by black blotches of paint as if pressed by a burden.

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/26/arts/design/south-africa-nitegeka-artist.html

Page 5 of 7 An Artistʼs New Migration Song - The New York Times

If Abstraction was his protective fortress, he is starting to lower the walls.

4/29/20, 7)58 AM

“I wanted to go back to ﬁguration because there is that vulnerability,” Mr. Nitegeka said. “There’s a kind of self-evaluation that comes from looking at myself, the exercise of taking pictures of myself in the studio. It’s quite exhausting.”

Mr. Nitegeka in his studio in Johannesburg. Known for abstraction, he is making new work, including selfportraits, that reveal more of his personal migration story. “I wanted to go back to ﬁguration because there is that vulnerability,” he said. Gulshan Khan for The New York Times

He has also made, for the ﬁrst time, an audio piece, in which a speaker inside an art crate plays his voice, reading an excerpt from his journal. It describes a border crossing: The uncertainty that you will be let through, the moment of fear, and then the march forward.

The entry, from 2012, describes a speciﬁc incident, Mr. Nitegeka said, though he prefers not to say where. But it was a moment when memories of leaving Rwanda came rushing at him.

“It’s part of a kind of healing process,” he said. “Some of the things in there, my wife keeps urging me to talk about them: ‘Have you seen someone? Have you told your friends?’ Dealing with some of this stuff, especially at a young age — my path has been slowly, slowly, slowly. This time felt right to start unpacking.”

For Mr. Nitegeka, one consequence of his displacement is that he is stateless. He has managed to travel in the past but on temporary papers. His application for South African citizenship is underway, he said, but the process takes time.

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/26/arts/design/south-africa-nitegeka-artist.html

Page 6 of 7 An Artistʼs New Migration Song - The New York Times

4/29/20, 7)58 AM

Since late March, South Africa has been under lockdown as the government tries to get ahead of the coronavirus shrinking Mr. Nitegeka’s world even further. From Johannesburg, he sent a message by WhatsApp, expressing concern for New York City.

“I haven’t left the conﬁnes of my home,” he wrote. “Appreciating the surreal silence, the sudden halt to almost everything, spending more time with my loved ones.” He added, “ Trying to focus on the positives.”

Through May 9, Serge Alain Nitegeka, “Black Migrant,” at Marianne Boesky Gallery; viewable by appointment and online.

Correction: April 27, 2020

An earlier version of this article misspelled the given name of a curator. She is Marie-Ann Yemsi, not Mari-Ann.

A version of this article appears in print on April 27, 2020, Section C, Page 1 of the New York edition with the headline: He Can’t Travel, but His Art Can

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/26/arts/design/south-africa-nitegeka-artist.html

Subject: (Final 443) New York Times Article

Hi Everyone,

Please see the article attached below, "An Artist’s New Migration Song” by Siddhartha Mitter, April 26, 2020, Arts & Design section of the New York Times. 

The article constitutes your Final. You are applying your model of five boxes/structures upon this text. You are framing your interpretation of this article by using your design model like a template which you developed separately in a fishbowl over the past three months.

You’re testing the waters of your design. You’re taking a risk. Does it have merit? Can it be generalized? Does it lead to new ideas?

You enter this fray with an advantage: your design is built upon self-reflection and lived-experience within the context of a visual culture. You have lived and felt your concepts, and you know what you are talking about. Your resources are your self-generated text.

Read the article a few times. The third reading is when you pull out phrases and words from the text... and dwell upon them. Think about them from your lived-experience, which can be hypothetical but never hypocritical. You walk the talk. 

You are free to tweak and change what you have done so far, leading up to the model and during its application. The final has to be cohesive. You have to be confident in the words you chose and the design you constructed and the outcome of its application. More instructions to follow. 

You are to post your final at the due date and time. May 4, 6pm. There can be no late-comers after that. 

Right up to that day, you may continue working on 15 words, 2+1 words in 5 boxes, and 5 sentences. But don’t lose your previous text. Your movement to the core is worth showing.

Don’t rush the final and wait for more instructions. Please remember it is a word-game.

Sanjiv

Date: 4/28/2020 23:45:30
Subject: meaning of design (443)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

What is the meaning of design weaves through your fishbowls. To design is much more than simply to assemble, to order, or even to edit; it is to add value and meaning, to illuminate, to simplify, to clarify, to modify, to dignify, to dramatize, to persuade, and perhaps even to amuse.

To design is to transform prose into poetry. Design broadens perception, magnifies experience, and enhances vision. Design is the product of feeling and awareness, of ideas that originate in the mind of the designer and culminates, one hopes, in the mind of the viewer. The designer's skill can also be used for deception, seduction is one of its many masks.

Design is both a verb and a noun. It is the beginning as well as the end, the process and product of imagination. Like an onion with multiple layers, the more it peels, the more it reveals. Content (your felt-experience) is the raw material of design. Form (your structure), in turn, is the reorganization and manipulation of content.

Your Design in 443 is a fusion of form and content.

Keeping it simple is key; two concepts per structure. You arrive at them by way of a journey through a forest of words.

Your labor and thought that you put in, never fails to astound.

Sanjiv

Date: 4/28/2020 22:36:01
Subject: the doing of it (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Your fishbowls examine the relationships between reality (your felt experiences) and symbolic systems (your abstractions).

You are involved in constructing an understanding of shared existence.

Several things:

Keep your abstract structures extremely simple. JUST TWØ concepts and a THIRD to tie them up.

When you re-structure, SUBSTITUTE the words from the original opening structure. You are changing the meaning. You are creating new meaning. YOu are not trying to copy the original structure. So don’t use those words.

443. The five boxes and their sentences must be simple sentences, otherwise you will find it impossible to do the final. Just relate 2 concepts for each box.

In your 10+1 steps, revisit and simplify the conceptual framework and re-interpret the felt-experience. It doesn’t take long. Try not to delete the previous structures, because we want to see your iterations and directions that you choose.

SUBSTITUE, SUBSTITUE. 

CHANGE MEANING BY TAKING IT FORWARD...INTO THE UNKNOWN.

Feedback to Work the following structures again. SImplify.

Sentence construction:

1. We all have feelings, and with these feelings we are able to create emotions and thoughts to share with others and the world.

2. When I breathe, there is warmth in the air and I am filled with passion thinking about the thoughts that flutter my consciounse.

3. Only those with adoration can express both sympathy and empathy, simultaneously.

4. I have an understanding that allows me to devote time to the healing of others with compassion.

5. When I am happy, I have desire and affection to cure myself and to cure others.

Feed Back on Sentence construction:

1. We all have feelings, and with these feelings we are able to create emotions and thoughts to share with others and the world.

I would write: "Share emotions and thoughts with the world.”

2. When I breathe, there is warmth in the air and I am filled with passion thinking about the thoughts that flutter my consciounse.

"Breath is life.”

3. Only those with adoration can express both sympathy and empathy, simultaneously.

Take these words further: adoration, sympathy and empathy and substitute and simplify.

4. I have an understanding that allows me to devote time to the healing of others with compassion.

Understanding compassion for others.

5. When I am happy, I have desire and affection to cure myself and to cure others.

Take the words Desire and Cure further and re-write.

Sanjiv

Subject: free from shackles (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Some general tips, hints, suggestions that I have gathered over the years regarding 10+1 and, deconstruct and infuse...

Your site of operation is Form and Content. That is, Structure and Felt-Experience.

You want to set up a dialog between the two, and you want to be transparent and authentic about it.

You set up this dialog by your Return Visit to the Site of action.

Your purpose and your journey is to get to the essence (the core words) of things.

Like in Strictly Ballroom, the Grandma said, “listen to the rhythm.” She gave Scott the word: rhythm.

And Scott listened. Listening is a key skill in this day and age. 

Please see Yasir Aloshban’s postings on leadership, reflexivity and Giddens.

Whenever you are re-structuring or deconstructing, substitute the original words. By changing the words, you are forging ideas ahead. You are setting yourself and your audience free from the shackles of previous given words. This is where creativity is key. Yours is a structuring, structured text. You are a constructing, constructed individual. Show this progression. It is your act. Your time to be in the lime-light and shine. No one can tell you otherwise, because you created it. Right out of your imagination. Its worth is in the fact that form and content fits. 

You are a reflexive leader and you move your audience by touching them.

Sanjiv

Re: Leadership, Reflexivity and Giddens

 Thu Apr 16, 2020 4:05 pm

Is leadership a skill?

Leadership skills are skills you use when organizing other people to reach a shared goal. Whether you're in a management position or leading a project, leadership skills require you to motivate others to complete a series of tasks, often according to a schedule.

yasir Aloshban

Joined: Mon Jan 27, 2020 3:50 pm

Contact: Contact yasir Aloshban

Re: Leadership, Reflexivity and Giddens

Thu Apr 16, 2020 4:06 pm

What makes a good team?

Good teams don't happen by accident: strong leadership, adaptability, a diverse make, effective communication and skilled conflict management are usually involved in creating successful teams.

Re: Leadership, Reflexivity and Giddens

Thu Apr 16, 2020 4:07 pm

How do you make a leader?

Let them know they're a leader. The first step is to let them know that whatever their title or their position, their actions affect someone else and that puts them in a position to lead.

Treat them like a leader.

Challenge them.

Make them responsible.

Help them communicate like a leader.

Have them act like a leader.

What is the most important skill of a leader?

Leadership Skills You Need

Being Self-Aware. Being self-aware is the most important skill to build, and it's the one that I'd recommend building first.

Trustworthiness.

Thu Apr 16, 2020 4:09 pm

What exactly is a leader?

A simple definition is that leadership is the art of motivating a group of people to act toward achieving a common goal. In a business setting, this can mean directing workers and colleagues with a strategy to meet the company's needs. Put even more simply, the leader is the inspiration for and director of the action.

Thu Apr 16, 2020 4:09 pm

What is leadership behavior?

Definition. Positive leadership behavior is a set of actions, taken by individuals in a position of power and influence, to motivate and cultivate others through mechanisms of empowerment, engagement, and collaborative assignment to meaningful work.

Thu Apr 23, 2020 2:57 pm

What is the theory of reflexivity?

Reflexivity in economics is the theory that a feedback loop exists in which investors' perceptions affect economic fundamentals, which in turn changes investor perception. The theory of reflexivity has its roots in sociology, but in the world of economics and finance, its primary proponent is George Soros.

 Thu Apr 23, 2020 2:58 pm

What is meant by self reflexivity?

adjective. The definition of self reflexive is someone making reference to their own artificiality. An example of a self reflexive critique is a politician who goes back over her life and reflects on where she may not have been totally honest in what she said or did.

Why is reflexivity important?

Reflexivity is really important in qualitative research because there are so many ways in which researcher bias could affect the study, from the creation of data gathering tools, to collecting the data, analyzing it and reporting it. Understanding these effects can be an important part of the research process.

What does reflexivity mean in research?

Reflexivity is an attitude of attending systematically to the context of knowledge construction, especially to the effect of the researcher, at every step of the research process.

Re: Leadership, Reflexivity and Giddens

Thu Apr 23, 2020 3:01 pm

What is the meaning of reflexivity?

Within sociology more broadly—the field of origin—reflexivity means an act of self-reference where examination or action "bends back on", refers to, and affects the entity instigating the action or examination.

Is leadership a skill?

Leadership skills are skills you use when organizing other people to reach a shared goal. Whether you're in a management position or leading a project, leadership skills require you to motivate others to complete a series of tasks, often according to a schedule.

How do you make a leader?

Let them know they're a leader. The first step is to let them know that whatever their title or their position, their actions affect someone else and that puts them in a position to lead.

Treat them like a leader.

Challenge them.

Make them responsible.

Help them communicate like a leader.

Have them act like a leader.

Hi Everyone,

I hope you are doing well. Focusing has been the hard part. Or else, you would have received double the letters under our circumstances. So just as well!

I’m really a socialist at heart. Even Ayn Rand (please google) with her erotically charged novels couldn’t convince me of the tenets of individualism and profit when I was your age. I believe the virus as a metaphor has brought the West closer to considering a new economic system; a new system for measuring use-value and exchange-value in a digitized world.

Talking about finishing-up 448, and what you are being asked to do...

(1) Many years ago, Bartlett and Ghoshal did a research study out of Harvard on the successful characteristics of global businesses. Their statistical analysis showed the following four characteristics: Integrated, networking structures; Dynamic decision-making; Adaptive coordination mechanisms; Unique innovation capabilities. Their central argument was that if companies are to cope with the complex international environment, they must have an equally complex and multi-faceted business strategy. Firms operating worldwide must pursue global, multinational and international strategies simultaneously. They must become what the authors call a transnational corporation.

Your process of deconstruct and infuse was developed in the fishbowl, keeping these four characteristics in mind. 

When you deconstruct and infuse each characteristic, you contemporaneously experience it in the fishbowl. Please make a note of this. Your posting takes on the characteristic of a performance. The saying of it is the doing of it.

Keep it short. First re-structure; pithy and simple and you are relating 3 elements at most. After that carefully do a felt-experience and you may take the example from anywhere within 448.

Keep it short and sweet is the key. KISS PRINCIPLE. Don’t worry about getting it right, because then you are doing it for me. You are taking ownership of your text and sharing it with the universe. And for doing that, your audience will applaud you. Besides, you are making history as possibility. Please see Matthew Boelter’s posting below.

(2) I’ll talk about Hofstede’s four dimensions in subsequent letters.

Sanjiv

shifts in cultural norms

Mon Apr 27, 2020 2:10 am

"It has become a cultural norm to address each other with the words."

Cultural norms are the standards we live by and are the collective expectations and guidelines that lead our behavior with people among social groups. Cultural norms are learned at a very young age and stay with us our whole life unless we break off and start our new cultural norms. Our “new norms” is communicating through the fishbowl. We are like pioneers inventing new ways for our perceived lazy generation to evolve and grow with one another. Even though we are not directly communicating with each other, we are observing every day by looking deeply into each other’s words and analyzing the meaning. As Sanjiv once said, going into the fishbowl is a “test of consistency and perseverance” and that is seen by many in this class. Using our words to create meaning will help us all immensely in the future when it comes to communication. I feel like many of us did not sit down and take the time to think deeply about conversations or written words before this class, so this experience has made most of us grow as human beings.

IF YOU HAVE DIFFICULTY WITH 10+1 STEPS, YOU CAN GO IT ALONE

It is a word-game. The general principles apply through out.

HERE, I’LL MAKE IT SIMPLER IF YOU DON’T WISH TO DO 10+1 AND WOULD GO ALONE.

Select 15 words from your fishbowl, and put them in 5 boxes. Three words in each box. Keep two inside and one as the label.

Make a sentence from the 2+1 words. Keep it simple. Focus on the dichotomy in the box.

So you’re working on 5 sentences in all. In each sentence, you selected the words, and you kept substituting them along the way to make sense in a simple way.

Simplicity means you restrict the key elements in a structure to 2+1. Take Trust+Change inside the box, and Growth as the label. Make a sentence by taking these words further.

You are working to create a pithy statement. An axiom, an aphorism an adage.

Project 1- Nick

Fri Apr 24, 2020 3:57 pm

Step 1-Structure:

"Images, assumptions, frames of reference can act as different lenses, allowing us to see what we otherwise cannot see."

Step 2- World Pool:

Images- appearance, form, portrait, icon, figure, copy, drawing

Assumptions- Belief, expectation, premise, conclusion, supposition, theory, hunch

Frames- Body, frame, structure, physique, scaffolding, fabric, framework

Reference- Allusion, hint, innuendo, mention, note, association

Different- contrasting, disparate, distinct, particular, peculiar, various

Lenses- angle, aspect, attitude, direction, outlook, posture, stance, standpoint

Allow- approve, oblige, support, release, tolerate, permissible, permit

See- determine, discover, experience, feature, feel, observe perceive, realize

Otherwise- differently, in another way, variously

Cannot- unable, restricted, limited, barrier

Step 3- Restructure:

The way we interpret appearances, make inferences, and evaluate the events we encounter on a daily basis permits us to see life from a different viewpoint; a new perspective enables us to pursue life with vigor and confidence, learning from the past but capitalizing on the present opportunities.

Step 4- Felt Experience:

In my first semester of college at the University of Florida, I was on a FaceTime call with a close friend of mine who was at the time a junior at George Washington University (he has gone on to attend Vanderbilt Law School). I remember calling him because I was unhappy at my school and convinced I needed to transfer back closer to home. I went on a rant describing how it looked as if every one of my friends was having a great time at school based on their social media images and posts. He let me talk for a long period of time and finally interrupted me by saying two words: the lens. He meant that no matter how people may project themselves, there is always more to the story and it is important to keep that in mind. This made me think about how there is a lens to everything in life, not just the way people portray themselves on social media. I began to consider this in my study of history and politics, evaluating national figures and landmark events from a variety of different perspectives, namely those groups involved or impacted. It has shaped my behavior and thought processes; I have become more empathetic and concerned with the overall well-being of people. Just because an event or action is positive for me, that does not mean others view it the same way. It all depends on the lens in which we view it and how our lives are affected. I am fortunate this conversation took place in the early stages of my college experience. I often wonder how college would have worked out if I remained blocked off from the world and locked into my own bubble. I am pursuing a law degree and a career in government for this exact reason: I want the responsibility of looking through a variety of lenses and coming up with a solution that is sensible, practical, and positive to the greatest amount of people. I value the different perspectives that the lens yields, and I look forward to evaluating more perspectives as I move forward in my college career and my life.

Step 5- Perceptual Categories

Determination, Optimism

Empathetic, Perspective

Step 6- Dichotomy

Optimism

Empathetic

Step 7- Word Pool (Alone)

Optimism- Confidence, certainty, enthusiasm, expectation, idealism, trust, elation, anticipation

Empathetic- Compassionate, sympathetic, sensitive, affinity, appreciation, insight, commiserate

Step 8- Structure (Together)

Our negotiations and interactions require trust, compassion, and appreciation, as we are obligated to consider the experiences that guide the actions and the motivations of those that we cross paths with.

Step 9- Felt Experience (Alone)

When I was 17, I played for a summer baseball team called the Newport Jr. Gulls. This team was a high school affiliate of the Newport Gulls that focused on player development and college recruiting. My coach was a retired Colonel in the United States Air Force and a stout believer in the importance of team chemistry. We began practicing in the fall of the prior year, leaving 7 months to practice before we played a single game. Our coach partnered up the members of our team and told us that each week we had to learn three new things about our partner and then share them out with the entire team. At the beginning of this process, I was reluctant because I did not see the value in doing this weekly over the course of a couple of months. However, each week my partner and I grew closer and we began to learn about each other’s childhoods, beliefs, and passions. The more I learned about my partner the better we were able to work together at practice. The same went for everything I learned about all of my teammates. We became very close, nearly inseparable. We had a very successful summer, as we won multiple tournaments and had a lot of fun in the process. Those games stand out when I look back on my high school baseball experience because I loved being around those guys and playing with them. What this experience taught me is that we often make judgments based on first impressions. Oftentimes, we do not shake these judgments because we do not take the time to truly learn about others. I believe that as we become responsible for structuring organizations and their design, we must keep this in mind and encourage all members of an organization to understand the motivations and desires of our peers.

Step 10- Perceptual Categories (Together)

Empower, Teaching

Community, Connection

Step 11- Insight (Alone)-

What role does opening our minds and considering various perspectives play in our lives? For one, it is a catalyst for progress and it ensures we are not unjustly ignoring others. Throughout the first project, Lauren and I examined a structure from Sanjiv and deconstructed it and infused our felt experiences. In doing so, we became more familiar with how our mindsets and approaches to life have evolved over time. By exploring new words to describe our feelings, we became more confident in our ability to translate abstract information in our minds into sentences that could be analyzed by others. This is an important component in the process of creating, deriving, and communicating meaning in a manner that adds value to our community or our organization. Most importantly, however, we have begun the process of altering our approach to perspectives to ensure we are effective in our future employment. The world is anything but consistent or predictable and we must expect that at some point we will need to rely on others or be open to change. This is especially pertinent in the time of the Coronavirus; being to analyze a situation and adapt to change will enhance our ability to be productive members of the community. When the world is back to a sense of normalcy, and I am able to physically interact with my peers, I am looking forward to seeing how my ability to walk a mile in someone else's shoes improves my ability to pursue a common goal with others. How we approach others, consider the situations we find ourselves in, and respond to unexpected circumstances will ultimately dictate our success not only in our careers but for our personal lives.

Top

Date: 4/26/2020 14:31:17
Subject: creating value for your Design (443)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

A. New Digital Products

You are creating new digital products (like your Designs in 443) and markets (that are digital platforms for exchange and use) in the digital space of your fishbowls. 

Digitization is radically changing the way we buy and experience products (like your Designs) and services (like your postings in the fishbowl).

The impacts of digitization are enabling fresh approaches to the design and delivery of almost everything. Some impacts---in music and photography --- have been relatively easy to realize but they provide useful clues to future designs.

Basically speaking, the old boundaries between a product and the way it is put to use are shifting --- and with those shifts come new insights into what we, the viewers/customers, may regard as valuable. To make sense of digitally-enabled dimensions of your Design, we must first step back and consider what is meant by ‘value’? And, what is the value of your Design in 443?

B. Use-Value and Exchange-Value

We generally consider value as something ‘good' arising from an object, whether created from the experience of it, or in the essence of it. 

In the fishbowl, we subscribe to the view that the essence of value can be created from production. Over time, the essence of what is good about an object becomes its ‘utility.’ An object is of value because it is embedded with ‘utilities’ that can be bought or exchanged. 

So one might ask, if something is of use, it should also be exchangeable for something else? 

Not really! While both use-value and exchange-value describe the ‘goodness' of something, use-value is the goodness from use/experience, while exchange-value is the goodness for exchange with something else, and that is its worth.

Let's consider BUS443 and the creation and construction of your Final Design. The utility or use-value of 443 and your Design is you get to graduate and you proceed to your next stage in life. But what is the worth of your design? How do you create worth in your design so that someone is willing to give money in exchange for it?

Please stay tuned.

Sanjiv

Re: Letter Interpretations

Sat Apr 25, 2020 2:40 am

MIND AND MINDSET

The sentence that resonated with me in this letter is where Sanjiv wrote, "The present crisis is a reminder the world is not just what we perceive on the outside; it really lies in the unconscious, deep within oneself." This is something that the fishbowl alone has been teaching us since the very beginning. It has been teaching that the most important aspect in any form of writing or personal experiences comes from, not the identifiable meaning, but the one that sits below the surface of what is initially determined. When we first read something, we automatically think of words, phrases, and a certain meaning that goes along with it, but the most important part of it is what we do not initially think of upon reading it. The most important part is what lies beyond what our eyes are reading.

I enjoyed where Dan says, "A friendship is a journey and experience there are pitfalls along the way but you need to do the navigated yourself." This sentence was one that made me immediately think of my friends. I have both a group of male friends and a group of female friends. I have been friends with all of my male friends since I was in high school, so about three, almost four years. My group of female friends however I made this year when I lived on campus. There is no straight path in a friendship just as there are no right ways to maintain one. Friendships are unpredictable, there are some people who are meant to be your friends, but there are also some people who are not.

Re: Letter Interpretations

Sat Apr 25, 2020 3:27 am

SINCERITY IS THE KEY

"Whenever you deconstruct and infuse, you are creating a knowing, a story, an image, an interpretation, a happening, a memory."

When we are faced with words and phrases that we do not know, the best thing to do for ourselves is to partake in deconstructing and infusing. When we deconstruct and infuse unfamiliar words, we are learning them in ways that we are making them familiar to us. We are connecting foreign words with those that we are familiar with in order to find an understanding of what those words mean. We do this in things in our everyday lives as well. When we are faced with problems that we are unsure how to solve, we use techniques that we do know in order to overcome them. Doing this helps expand our knowledge in the way that we are using what we already know in order to understand other things that we do not. Me personally, I do this all the time. One example of this is when I first learned how to shoot a gun. I have always been used to playing video games and my knowledge of guns in the game gave me the knowledge I needed to use in order to reload one.

I immediately was able to understand Elilis when he wrote, "I will always remember that moment, as I sat there confused and feeling out of place." This is a common feeling for people who enter foreign places. This was the way that I felt when I went to my room and first logged into the fishbowl. When I first started trying to figure out how it worked, I was completely lost and just sat at my desk looking at my laptop confused. However, I wanted to understand how to use it so badly that I took the time and put in the effort I needed in order to be able to figure it out, and now I enjoy it.

Date: 4/25/2020 0:10:28
Subject: sincerity is the key (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

“What do you mean by that, she asked again?" 

Today, leaders and managers can no longer remain hiding behind words, but must step in front. They no longer can remain hidden behind the narrative (because we already know the script), but instead they must reveal themselves in all their "cultural nakedness.” 

Please see Elilis’ skill in culturally revealing himself in his posting. He is clearly a leader. He first deconstructs and then infuses (line 5) a felt-experience. He presents himself in his "cultural nakedness" to the Other and brings the contract home.

Whenever you deconstruct and infuse, you are creating a knowing, a story, an image, an interpretation, a happening, a memory. You create an intersubjective space among the different cultures present, and thereby create a culture of your own. You’ve done it many times before.

It’s a process and a practice...stopping in your tracks and asking, what did you mean by that?

Such intensive questioning of the ways in which the Other (like your girlfriend or boyfriend) constructs their text can be a double-edge sword. 

Sincerity is the key.

Sanjiv

SINCERITY

Re: Interpreting Letters

Fri Apr 24, 2020 3:41 pm

Letter Title: Outsourced (448)

"What do you mean by that?"

This simple question serves as a bridge between cultures and opens the door for "the connection of minds". By asking this question, you are able to operate more effectively and you gain a better understanding, or even a mutual understanding, of what it is that is expected. It opens the door for discourse and understanding for both parties and displays a desire for clarity. Without a full understanding of what is meant, you cannot possibly perform to your full potential. I remember asking this question in my first class in high school, after being homeschooled all my life. The teacher asked us to outline a chapter for homework and gave us time to start it in class. At the time, I had no idea what she meant by "outline the chapter" and I felt silly for not knowing as all the students around me seemed to understand. I explained to the teacher that I had never done an outline before and asked the question "what did she mean by that?". We spent the remainder of class working on the outline together and after that, I never had an issue with them again. I will always remember that moment, as I sat there confused and feeling out of place, but my willingness to ask that simple question paid dividends. The culture of high school was essentially a foreign culture for me and the only way I was able to navigate it was through asking questions and making a genuine effort to understand. Its okay to not know what is meant by something, as long as you recognize the lack of clarity and make an effort to understand. That simple question could be the difference between you racking your brain for an hour trying to figure something out, and you tackling that same something within 20 minutes.

There has been a radical mutation in human consciousness as a whole. The present crisis is a reminder the world is not just what we perceive on the outside; it really lies in the unconscious, deep within oneself. It is what we project onto something unknown and unknowable.

The new mind is not merely logical or intellectual; rather, it is a mind that is completely free of all its old patterns and has, therefore, the quality of stillness, love and compassion. Re: Letters

Thu Apr 23, 2020 4:40 pm

"Friendship knows no map, except the one you create in the moment."

Maps are used to navigate from one point to another. They guide us they show us the path. A map is a valuable piece of information, without one you can become lost. In a friendship you can easily become lost but there is no map or answers to get you out. A friendship is a journey and experience there are pitfalls along the way but you need to do the navigated yourself. Maps as valuable as they are have been replaced and no longer carry value. This is very interesting to me and shows how culture and the world evolve and grow. My dad had to look and study a map to know where he was going and you had to learn by making mistakes. Today we use a gps takes seconds and directs us the whole way start to finish and even corrects us. Culture is always changing and there is no map for culture either.

Date: 4/15/2020 20:36:34
Subject: Ruth Benedict's Cultural Relativism and Configuration
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

(Please keep in mind your work on the two films: Moonrise Kingdom and Outsourced.)

The fishbowl has become a homogenous society in which conformity to standardized rules of behavior is highly valued and practiced. Your fishbowls are the best possible illustration for Ruth Benedict’s concept of “cultural relativism” and “cultural configuration.” Please google her name and the concepts and see: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2R4phuBBB1w

After carrying on “silent dialogues,” your postings represent expertise on extracting symbolic meaning from the most varied aspects of experience. Please see Tiana Martinez' postings below.

For an outsider wanting to participate in your fishbowl culture, observation and relentless analysis (think of what Todd did in Outsourced) are simply the only ways to earn an admission ticket. The outsider would have to figure out your fishbowl’s culture from the inside, through description and interpretation of details rather than through the abstract comparison of general characteristics. You strengthen the belief that a culture can truly be studied and understood simply by observing and analyzing the behavior of its members.

Sanjiv

RELATIVISM, CONFIGURATION

BRINGING IT TOGETHER

"It helps to look at culture as a system of communication."

Culture is all about connecting and communicating with others around us. In the fishbowl, it is possible to create a culture amongst one another because we are using the form of communication through writings. Each and every time I read what my group members and classmates have posted, I push myself to compare it to what I immediately thought of upon reading the letters. This is how I am able to understand them as a person because once I understand their thinking process, I am able to understand them. This is why writing about our personal experiences is so important. By writing personal experiences, we are able to connect with others on a deeper level than just our interpretations. Abstract expressionism in the fishbowl is a good way to get a sense of how people are on the interior. It is so easy for people to fake how they are, but it is more difficult to fake how you are in the way that you write.

"You’re Interpreting the other’s behaviors and mental structures by interpreting structures of words; systems of communication."

In the fishbowl, we are interpreting and comparing each others structures of words as a form of communication. In doing so, not only are we developing a relationship with other individuals, but we are pushing ourselves to further our mind skills. In comparing the way others write to the way that we write, we are allowing ourselves to be able to step into their shoes and process our minds in the way that they process their thinking. In thinking about how they express themselves, we are ensuring that we are all participating in creating a system of communication.

YOUR FISHBOWL IS A MOVIE SCRIPT

"Your fishbowl is a movie script and you're acting in it and producing and directing it."

Sanjiv's sentence is extremely rich in the way that it describes exactly what the fishbowl is for us. As each of us partake in writing our expressions down in the fishbowl, we are working together to write a movie script written in cultural richness. As we work together in our groups and form connections with others in the class, we are actors who are rehearsing our lines with one another. In this way, we are helping one another grow and push ourselves to become more skillful and intellectual. As we each write our posts, we are directing and writing what it is that we want our movie to portray, and as we are reading others posts and understanding their interpretations, we are starring in the movie. Just as movies are rich with words that are spoke, the fishbowl is rich in the way that we are writing.

This class has affected not only the way that I read and interpret my writings, but the way that I see everything. Everything that we are viewing in the world goes deep beyond the human eye. With every action there is an interpretation to be understood, there are words to be interpreted, and there are minds to connect to. For example, My friends and I have been watching the show Reign on Netflix. I have previously watched this entire show before but I am rewatching it with my friends. Before this course I would watch it just as average people do without interpreting what is ACTUALLY happening in the show, but after practicing what we do in the fishbowl and knowing how to think beyond physical appearances and actions, I interpret their actions, cultures, and words differently. This makes the show even more culturally rich than it was before. It is a show that is rich in the amount of culture that is present but after taking this course I realize that there is so much more to the show than I initially knew about.

Todd gradually trains himself (same as yourselves) in the fundamental anthropological skills of “attending, observing registering, and correlating.” 

You have to form allies like Asha and Purro. You do the same in your fishbowls.

You should be able to identify the symbols that operate upon you quite easily, and then compare and contrast them with those of Asha and Purro. That is what Todd is doing. This is everybody’s journey, not just his. It is the intersection of belief-structures.

Your structures and their interpretations will determine your success in achieving your objectives. Very often millions of lives are at stake, and certainly lots of money. sorting and 

selecting structures (sentences).

Experiential knowing

Sun Apr 12, 2020 8:58 pm

After reading Michael's post, I felt that I had an eerily similar experience. I grew up a die-hard Florida Gators fan. I was a big fan of Tim Tebow, college Aaron Hernandez, and the hype that surrounded the University of Florida. I knew from a young age that I wanted to attend UF and be a Gator myself. After all, my families were Gator fans and all of the apparel and memorabilia I owned had a Gator on it. Thus, as I began touring colleges, the only thing I had in my mind was "this school is not the University of Florida. Why do I need to tour these schools if I am going to UF?". My true feelings about the school I was touring were hidden in this bias; all I wanted to do was be a Gator. As I look back now, after transferring from UF, this mindset reminds me of having an open mind. We are limited in our ability to grow or see truth if we tell ourselves what we think we want to hear. I believe this can be applied to organizational structure as well. If we structure organizations the way we want, rather than what is best for our employees or the well-being of our company, the company will have a short lifespan.

It is a digital game of "augmented reality.” To further understand the idea of augmented reality, I conducted a quick Google search and found the following description: "When someone talks about AR, they are referring to technology that overlays information and virtual objects on real-world scenes in real-time. It uses the existing environment and adds information to it to make a new artificial environment." Using augmented reality, people can use technology to add to their physical environment. For example, a clip I watched about it had Star Wars characters interacting with real humans. In almost a symbolic but practical way, the Fishbowl is an example of augmented reality. We need to view the Fishbowl as more than just words but a virtual presence that is interacting with us as well. Once we take the contents of the Fishbowl and apply them to our lives, they become real. Simply reading and writing will add no value to our lives. We must take the extra step and ensure that what we learn becomes a part of who we are.

"What most excites me about augmented reality’s future is its role in the arts. It has heaps of potential in this way, to scale cultural experience and make it accessible to broader audiences at lower costs. Imagine, for instance, a live AR performance of Hamlet, that is simultaneously beamed into people’s living rooms across the world." -Catherine Allen. The potential for future AR is exciting and engaging. It may be life-changing and impactful as we dive deeper into the technological age. The confines of our learning will only be expanded. Maybe, AR will become common while I am in law school and I can use it to sharpen my skills as a practicing attorney.

Hi Everyone,

Regarding the Final that you will be submitting for evaluation.

To evaluate anything, I have to look at process and practice. 

You have been learning to distinguish them from the very start in your fishbowls.

You have about 3-4 weeks left. That is, you may keep working until the scheduled date/time of your exam in May.

 Some pointers on process and practice:

1. You are to re-source the internet whenever you gather words-images, concepts and symbols. These are “internet-things.”

2. You are 

searching, 

sorting and 

selecting structures (sentences).

3. These are images, symbols and metaphors (words) and you will be evaluated upon your selections.

4. Thus far you have accomplished the “internet of things” and they constitute your platform. Focusing on words is always the key. Your “internet things" are the boundary of a discourse, a conversation that has its own selected vocabulary known only to the group. It is organic, natural and living. It can’t really be seen, yet it is right in front of you.

5. “Internet of things” are Representations of something else. Please pause and understand this. So you have a bunch of representations in your arsenal.

6. Wait a minute. Where is this all coming from? It starts with my crafted, constructed and created email. From the moment you read one, the process begins in your head. After that, it is the practice of catching your thought-images and expressing them in word-images.

7. Your felt-experiences are Interpretations of your Representational text above.

More explanations are to follow. At this stage you should have seen both the films in 448. I have lots to say, but you have to see the films first.

Experiential knowing

Sun Apr 12, 2020 8:58 pm

After reading Michael's post, I felt that I had an eerily similar experience. I grew up a die-hard Florida Gators fan. I was a big fan of Tim Tebow, college Aaron Hernandez, and the hype that surrounded the University of Florida. I knew from a young age that I wanted to attend UF and be a Gator myself. After all, my families were Gator fans and all of the apparel and memorabilia I owned had a Gator on it. Thus, as I began touring colleges, the only thing I had in my mind was "this school is not the University of Florida. Why do I need to tour these schools if I am going to UF?". My true feelings about the school I was touring were hidden in this bias; all I wanted to do was be a Gator. As I look back now, after transferring from UF, this mindset reminds me of having an open mind. We are limited in our ability to grow or see truth if we tell ourselves what we think we want to hear. I believe this can be applied to organizational structure as well. If we structure organizations the way we want, rather than what is best for our employees or the well-being of our company, the company will have a short lifespan.

It is a digital game of "augmented reality.” To further understand the idea of augmented reality, I conducted a quick Google search and found the following description: "When someone talks about AR, they are referring to technology that overlays information and virtual objects on real-world scenes in real-time. It uses the existing environment and adds information to it to make a new artificial environment." Using augmented reality, people can use technology to add to their physical environment. For example, a clip I watched about it had Star Wars characters interacting with real humans. In almost a symbolic but practical way, the Fishbowl is an example of augmented reality. We need to view the Fishbowl as more than just words but a virtual presence that is interacting with us as well. Once we take the contents of the Fishbowl and apply them to our lives, they become real. Simply reading and writing will add no value to our lives. We must take the extra step and ensure that what we learn becomes a part of who we are.

"What most excites me about augmented reality’s future is its role in the arts. It has heaps of potential in this way, to scale cultural experience and make it accessible to broader audiences at lower costs. Imagine, for instance, a live AR performance of Hamlet, that is simultaneously beamed into people’s living rooms across the world." -Catherine Allen. The potential for future AR is exciting and engaging. It may be life-changing and impactful as we dive deeper into the technological age. The confines of our learning will only be expanded. Maybe, AR will become common while I am in law school and I can use it to sharpen my skills as a practicing attorney.

Those who embark upon their projects, will soon discover they are self-generating text in the most valuable of ways: knowledge content, experientially learnt. It is a word game and does not require physical presence. It is a digital game of "augmented reality.” It doesn’t take time; it takes an instance. Because it is an idea!

Assignment #1

1. Structure:

"Images, assumptions, and frames of reference can act as different lenses, allowing us to see what we otherwise cannot see."

2. Word Pool:

Images: appearance, photograph, portrait

Assumptions: belief, expectation, inference

Frames: body, framework, structure

References: association, connecting, implication

Lenses: monocle, spectacles, bifocal

Allowing: approve, authorize, oblige

Otherwise: differently, contrarily, diversely

3. Deconstruct:

Our previous and current experiences, along with our ability to adapt to our surroundings, are the basis for the interpretations we create.

4. Felt Experiences: There have been multiple examples in my life where I have let my own previous experiences control my current situation. One example is when I had an opportunity to go tour Johnson and Wales University. This occurred approximately 3/4 of the way through my junior year of high school. However, before I even stepped foot on the campus, the school was at a disadvantage. Previous to getting to the school, I talked to some of my older friends who had already gotten into college and had previously toured Johnson and Wales. They told me that they did not believe Johnson and Wales was a school that I should consider because of rumors that they had previously heard. Regardless of the truth of their rumors, I still let it get to my head and it definitely swayed my decision. The odds of me picking Johnson and Wales were almost insurmountable and it was mainly because of assumptions that I had made about the school.

Subject: bringing it together (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

It is possible you are feeling lost out there in 448 and in your groups.

What should one do in that situation is a perennial question across all groups and in all cultures.

The feeling of being lost is a paradox: inability to see what is invisible. 

We are watching two cultures of Moonrise Kingdom and Gharapuri in India. 

While you can recognize what is being said and expressed in the films, 

it is the decoding of its underlying symbolic meaning 

that you are trying to get at.

It helps to look at culture as a system of communication. Think of Japanese Story and Kinky boots as systems of communications.

Systems of communication? Yes, As structures of words. Words that are symbols, representing something else. 

You’re Interpreting the other’s behaviors and mental structures by interpreting structures of words; systems of communication. 

Interpreting the other's symbolic systems. Whenever you get it right, you bring the contract home. 

How do I do this, and how do I talk like this, and do I know this is making sense? 

The truth as we witness it is that if Todd Anderson in Outsourced doesn’t figure it out, he’s not leaving small town India any time soon (Groan).

More to come. So stay tuned. 

You are then to tie up these films with Hofstede’s four dimensions, please keep that in mind.

There is nothing that you are being asked to do or understand that does not have specific steps...that are given for you to tweak and make them work for yourself.

You are reflecting on images, you are making assumptions, you are looking at words, and you are interpreting and expressing what you see. You are doing a great job. Be aware of what you are doing.

Please see Tina Martinez’ decoding of symbolic meanings.

Sanjiv

Structure 1

"Everything I have done, I had to fight for."

Everything- all things around us

Done- brought to an end

Fight- using effort to get through a struggle

This sentence stood out to me because it is one that explains my life and the way that I achieve everything that I have. All throughout my life since I was first able to start working, I have made my own money and worked hard to get the things that I want. I am not someone who likes to rely on other people to buy or obtain things for me, I like to work and push myself in order to get them because I am someone who likes to be independent. I have been an independent woman for as long as I could remember and I am proud of that. I know a lot of people who rely on their parents to buy things for them and get them places in which they need to go and I am glad that I am not like that. Although there is nothing wrong with relying on our parents to get things for us, independence is something that we all need to be comfortable with because there will come a point in time when we will not have our parents there to help us with everything we need.

Structure 2

"Life is like a box of chocolates."

Life- the experience of being alive

Like- having similar qualities

Box- a container that is squared or rectangular shaped used to contain items

This sentence stood out to me because it is one that I used to be told when I was younger. People can interpret this sentence in numerous different ways but to me, this means that life is full of richness and sweet, and it is also unpredictable. You will never know what you will get, whether it is something good or bad. You are always going to be concerned for what is to come, but it is not always what is wanted or expected. Sometimes we are provided with things that push us out of our comfort zones and force us to try new things instead of just those that we are accustomed to. This is something that the fishbowl did for me. I was never used to working strictly online for a class that required me to push myself to see past the black and white definitions of words and phrases, and it allowed me to enhance my skill of adjusting to foreign situations or circumstances.

Structure 3

"Sometimes destruction is a good thing. She ends one cycle so a new one can begin."

Destruction- causing enough damage to completely destroy something

Good- satisfactory

Ends- the final point of anything

Cycle- events that are repeated in the same given order

New- something that did not exist before and was introduced

Begin- to start

I chose this sentence because it is one that I go by to this day. Sometimes in life, new beginnings are the best path that someone could choose to walk through. To completely let go of negative experiences and aspects that we endure and move on to new and better things could change up anyones life in a heartbeat. As sad as it is to say, I had to destroy a relationship that was extremely personal and important to me all because of the toxicity in it. I was being manipulated and mentally abused for too long to the point in which I forgot how to be myself. After I was finally able to release myself from the cycle, I immediately began to feel better and more relieved. Although closing old chapters and cycles may be difficult and upsetting for some, in the end the result is better than repeating a draining cycle.

Structure 4

"Why do you worry so much of what people think."

Worry- anxiety over some circumstances

Much- a large quantity

People- a collective of humans

Think- to have a conscious mind about something or someone

When Todd and Asha are walking together after work, she is worried about people seeing them together since she is engaged to be married. She made it clear that she was concerned with people seeing her that close to him, so Todd says this back to her. I chose this sentence because this is something that many people in the world are concerned with. I am someone who does not care about what other people think of me. I act the way that I am and do not try to change myself just to gain approval of those around me. No one should feel like they have to at a certain way in order for people to like them, instead people should live life the way THEY please.

Structure 5

"It's a third eye. It's the eye with what you see the most important thing. Sometimes two eyes aren't enough."

Eye- globular organs in which people and animals are able to see

See- being conscious of one's surroundings using the eye

Important- of large significance

Thing- a object that does not have a specific name

Enough- a sufficient amount of something

There is more to life than what we can see with our two eyes. There are things that are not visible to the eye but are essential to life, just as there are lessons that are only visible to the mind that we need in order to continue growing as individuals. This is something that I have always known. There are many instances in which the eyes can be deceiving about what is around you and the only way to be able to realize this is due to our knowledge. I am someone who, although I need visible proof that I can see with my eyes, I need to be able to understand it with my mind. The mind is more telling than the eyes are because with my mind I am able to tell when things are not as they seem. I am extremely good at realizing this because I do not usually believe everything that I hear or that I see, instead I rationalize with my mind.

Hi Everyone,

Please see Amiel’s posting below and please pay heed. Thank you.

So what should one do? 

What do these words translate for me?

Well, whenever a student says he is unable to complete the assignment because group members are not responding, and can he complete it with someone else?

My answer is: "Yes you can, and your Mother is the best candidate." Listen to the Woman is a refrain I often say. And if your mothers are old school, less formally educated, or first generation and not speaking english: listen to Her all the more. Bring in those structures into your decision-making. I asked a student once, what did his mother make him for lunch, and he replied, “it is not important.” That was a lost opportunity!

Particularly those in 448, google the film Lost in Translation with Bill Murray and Scarlett Johansson. Directed by Sofia Cappola. You get a sense of modern cultures as microcosms and love, not as romance, but something else entirely.

Sanjiv

#54

What is this "radical mutation in our consciousness" that Professor Dugal speaks of? I believe this to be the "far-reaching change in structure to our surroundings". Our structure is broken and it's out of the bag. It's time to innovate and open our minds to new concepts and processes. Our old structures and ways of being are inadequate in times like this. We all feel flat on our feet because we where not prepared for the worse. This concept of "not being prepared for the worse" is something the baby boomer generation warned us about. They constantly would always warn us about the possible worse outcomes of our actions and most of the time we wouldn't pay attention to them because we thought they where crazy. It caught the majority of us off-guard but it is in our best interest that we see the importance of a new mind because we must build off our previous one. The nation is in a state of urgency and the mind must react pro-actively.

This would fly in a conference on critical thinking and not on education, technology and learning. I re-wrote it, as you see below, and have saved it on the conference site. So keep your fingers crossed this time. This is competition for market space. We are granted time until the 15th. That also permits us to change the author listing. Sanjiv

Revised Abstract for EDULEARN20:

“Immersive Learning: Heuristic Device for Transmitting Social Imaginaries

Introduction

We are 120 participants (students at the University of Rhode Island) presenting the results of an online learning device that we developed in the course of ordering, organizing, and transmitting knowledge among ourselves. We present deep mental involvement that takes viewers to realistic learning situations (social imaginaries) without constraints of reality: logistics, risks, real-time and little right to fail. In 10 +1 steps, our paper presents the outcome of three participants, interacting and experiencing Immersive Learning in a digital environment.

Objective 

To develop a heuristic device that enables participants to discover or learn something for themselves. Examples that employ heuristics include using trial and error, a rule of thumb, an educated guess, an intuitive judgment, a guesstimate, profiling, or common sense. In their initial research, Tversky and Kahneman proposed three heuristics—availability, representativeness, and anchoring and adjustment. Subsequent work has identified many more. 

Methodology 

Reflexive interpretation is built around a multi-layered, flexible structure of interpretation and reflection in which the systematic interplay of reflections are central. Whenever we reflected, we thought about the premises for our thoughts, our observations and our use of language. The core of reflection (reflexivity) is "the way we construct ourselves socially while also constructing ‘internet things' out there. For without construction, and without a constructing and constructed self, there can be no meaning.” 

Results

1. The way we attend to meaning changed. 

2. Enabling experimentation and “learning by doing.” 

3. Encouraging playfulness and theatrics.

4. Interpretation rather than the Representation of 'performative text' became central. 

5. Participants repeated and re-entered learning spaces, creating a self-generating reality.

Conclusion

Immersive Learning is still emerging as a practice in the workforce, but it is clear that given the broad range of employee-training services, understanding heuristics of 'augmented reality’ and ‘extended reality’ technology will be critical to every enterprise in the future.

References

1.Judgment under Uncertainty: Heuristics and Biases by Amos Tversky and Daniel Kahneman in "Judgment and Decision Making, An Interdisciplinary Reader," Second Edition, Edited by Terry Connoly, Hal R. Arkes, and Kenneth R. Hammond, Cambridge University Press, 2000 (p.35)

2.Learning as immersive experiences: Using the four-dimensional framework for designing and evaluating immersive learning experiences in a virtual world by

Sara de Freitas, Genaro Rebolledo-Mendez, Fotis Liarokapis, George Magoulas and Alexandra Poulovassilis, British Journal of Educational Technology, Vol 41 No 1 2010 (p.69-85)

3.Reflexive Methodology, New Vistas for Qualitative Research by Mats Alvesson and Kaj Skoldberg, Sage Publications, 2001 (p.24-247)

4.Personal narrative, performance, performativity: Two or three things I know for sure by Kristin M. Langellier, Pages 125-144 Published online: 05 Jun 2009, Journal of Text and Performativity, Vol 19, 1999-Issue 2.

Key Words: IMMERSIVE LEARNING, HEURISTICS, VIRTUAL REALITY, PERFORMATIVE TEXT

Revised Abstract for EDULEARN20:

“Immersive Learning: Heuristic Device for Transmitting Social Imaginaries

Introduction

We are 120 participants (students at the University of Rhode Island) presenting the results of an online learning device that we developed in the course of ordering, organizing, and transmitting knowledge among ourselves. We present deep mental involvement that takes viewers to realistic learning situations (social imaginaries) without constraints of reality: logistics, risks, real-time and little right to fail. In 10 +1 steps, our paper presents the outcome of three participants, interacting and experiencing Immersive Learning in a digital environment.

Objective 

To develop a heuristic device that enables participants to discover or learn something for themselves. Examples that employ heuristics include using trial and error, a rule of thumb, an educated guess, an intuitive judgment, a guesstimate, profiling, or common sense. In their initial research, Tversky and Kahneman proposed three heuristics—availability, representativeness, and anchoring and adjustment. Subsequent work has identified many more. 

Methodology 

Reflexive interpretation is built around a multi-layered, flexible structure of interpretation and reflection in which the systematic interplay of reflections are central. Whenever we reflected, we thought about the premises for our thoughts, our observations and our use of language. The core of reflection (reflexivity) is "the way we construct ourselves socially while also constructing ‘internet things' out there. For without construction, and without a constructing and constructed self, there can be no meaning.” 

Results

1. The way we attend to meaning changed. 

2. Enabling experimentation and “learning by doing.” 

3. Encouraging playfulness and theatrics.

4. Interpretation rather than the Representation of 'performative text' became central. 

5. Participants repeated and re-entered learning spaces, creating a self-generating reality.

Conclusion

Immersive Learning is still emerging as a practice in the workforce, but it is clear that given the broad range of employee-training services, understanding heuristics of 'augmented reality’ and ‘extended reality’ technology will be critical to every enterprise in the future.

References

1.Judgment under Uncertainty: Heuristics and Biases by Amos Tversky and Daniel Kahneman in "Judgment and Decision Making, An Interdisciplinary Reader," Second Edition, Edited by Terry Connoly, Hal R. Arkes, and Kenneth R. Hammond, Cambridge University Press, 2000 (p.35)

2.Learning as immersive experiences: Using the four-dimensional framework for designing and evaluating immersive learning experiences in a virtual world by

Sara de Freitas, Genaro Rebolledo-Mendez, Fotis Liarokapis, George Magoulas and Alexandra Poulovassilis, British Journal of Educational Technology, Vol 41 No 1 2010 (p.69-85)

3.Reflexive Methodology, New Vistas for Qualitative Research by Mats Alvesson and Kaj Skoldberg, Sage Publications, 2001 (p.24-247)

4.Personal narrative, performance, performativity: Two or three things I know for sure by Kristin M. Langellier, Pages 125-144 Published online: 05 Jun 2009, Journal of Text and Performativity, Vol 19, 1999-Issue 2.

Key Words: IMMERSIVE LEARNING, HEURISTICS, VIRTUAL REALITY, PERFORMATIVE TEXT

Subject: steps in the fishbowl (443 &amp; 448)
