IMMERSIVE LEARNING: HEURISTIC DEVICE FOR TRANSMITTING SOCIAL IMAGINARIES

S. Dugal1, N. Colicci1, A. Bikash1, A. Weston1, L. Janz1, N. Katchen1, K. Bugbee1, T. Martinez1, L. Denicola1, L. Cardono1, M. Degnan1, A. Roberti1, O. Palumbo1, K. Solomon1, S. Wordell1, B. Bolofsky1, T. Mulligan1, A. Lopez1, C. Morganelli1, B. Matarese1, K. Jensen1, A. Sullivan1, B. Mulligan1, D. Jones1, N. Amodio1, M. Augustine1, K. Fasano1, R. Forte1, H. Mecca1, V. Volpe1, M. Oppliger1, T. Ritacco1, M. Boelter1, M. Bowman1, C. Chen1, M. Pelisson1, B. Nong1, S. Costello1, P. Costanzo1, Z. Buckley1, K. Naranjo1, E. Lis1, D. Ayrassian1, J. Milder1, Y. Aloshban1, J. Repoza1, M. Fuhrman1, R. Kattan1, C. Hladick1, D. Brysch1, S. Vicedomine1, M. Volpe1, M. Troiano2, R. Singh3, S. Singh4

1 University of Rhode Island (UNITED STATES)

2 Clearheads Films (UNITED STATES)

3 RL Studio (INDIA)

4 Savvy Matters (UNITED STATES)

sanjivdugal@uri.edu, ncolicci@my.uri.edu, andrew_bikash@my.uri.edu, aydan_weston @my.uri.edu, lea_janz@my.uri.edu, natalie_katchen@my.uri.edu, kevin_bugbee@my.uri.edu, tiana_martinez@my.uri.edu, lea_denicola@my.uri.edu, lauren_cardono@my.uri.edu, michael_degnan@my.uri.edu, alexroberti@my.uri.edu, olivia_palumbo@my.uri.edu, kyra_solomon@my.uri.edu, samwordell@my.uri.edu, brooke_bolofsky@my.uri.edu, pmulligan@my.uri.edu, amiel_lopez@my.uri.edu, cmorganelli@my.uri.edu, bimmer105@my.uri.edu, kayla_jensen@my.uri.edu, andrea_sullivan@my.uri.edu, brady_mulligan@my.uri.edu, dawson_jones@my.uri.edu, nicholas_amodio@my.uri.edu, matt_augustine@my.uri.edu, kyra_fasano@my.uri.edu, raisaforte@my.uri.edu, hamzamecca16@my.uri.edu, vincent_volpe@my.uri.edu, moppliger@my.uri.edu, thomasritacco@my.uri.edu, matthew_boelter@my.uri.edu, madison_bowman@my.uri.edu, cchiehyu_0915@my.uri.edu, mpelisson@my.uri.edu, branden_nong@my.uri.edu, shancostello3@my.uri.edu, paige_constanzo@my.uri.edu, zachary_buckley@my.uri.edu, kylenaranjo@my.uri.edu, eli_lis@my.uri.edu, david_ayrassian@my.uri.edu, juell_milder@my.uri.edu, yasir_aloshban@my.uri.edu, jacob_repoza@my.uri.edu, mfuhrman@my.uri.edu, ramakattan@my.uri.edu, chladick@my.uri.edu, dominik_brysch@my.uri.edu, svicedomine@my.uri.edu, mary_volpe@my.uri.edu, michael.troiano1@verizon.net, rahoulsingh@gmail.com, shivsingh@gmail.com

Introduction: 

We present a heuristic device for ‘reading’ and ‘writing’ in the context of online sharing. Our paper presents a new kind of sharing between reader/writer or author/viewer that transmits a social imaginary and puts into play active humanistic participation. We are 120 participants (students at the University of Rhode Island) presenting the ‘way’ in which we made possible the formulation of our text and its subsequent transformation into knowledge. In other words, we’re presenting the ‘manner’ in which we produced categories and concepts for ordering, organizing, and transmitting knowledge among ourselves. In so doing, we realized the more we “immersed” ourselves in something, the more we “connected” to universal principles and processes. The deeper we went, the farther we could see all around. In our simulated world, The Fishbowl, looking carefully at anything informed looking at everything, creating a surrounding sensory feeling of immersion and humanistic participation.

Our purpose is twofold. To present the ‘way’ we deployed attention to text and, the ‘way’ in we formed ourselves into a cohesive group. There is large variation in attentional practices among us, ranging from rigid to flexible. Our overarching purpose as a group was to manage new digital spaces and produce valuable knowledge for the participants. 

Our paper presents a process and practice for socially constructing reality by using a reflexive methodology. Over a period of 12 weeks we combined real and virtual environments and human-machine interactions to create an experiential learning. Operating in groups of three, every participant in The Fishbowl is visible upon entry. We were looking at ourselves, looking at ourselves.As participant-observers, we interacted by projecting symbolic word-structures; creating abstractions through dialogism and reflexive practices. 

Method: 

We collapsed the differences between readers and writers by providing continuous edits and modifications, becoming ‘embedded’ in each other’s text. Our paper offers a more controlled format for producing an equivalent to Wikipedia.

Multiple and deliberative authorship calls for an equivalent form of reading, one that is not a re-reading but instead, a reading ‘anew’ each time. As Readers creating their own meaning, we were adding our own authoring to the text. In this way, we became a living “real time” process of simultaneous reading and writing, producing, evolving and having diverse patterns of meaning.

By shifting attention to focusing on the meaning of words, we constructed a knowing and a feeling among ourselves which helped connect in personally significant ways. Simply, we set up a heuristic for ‘deconstructing’ word-structures and, we extended our reality of the deconstructed text by infusing individual felt-experiences. 

Outcome: 

Our heuristic device helped us imagine, create and deliver innovative experiences. It enabled immersive learning, reduced time spent, while increasing engagement and ability to mirror real-life situations. By following the practice of carefully looking at every word, our “writing” became a process of self-interrogation motivated by a concern for the group.

So what: 

Immersive learning is still emerging as a practice in the workforce, but it’s clear that given the broad range of employee-training services, understanding concepts of ‘augmented reality’ and ‘extended reality’ technology will be critical to the enterprise of the future. 

Keywords: VIRTUAL COMMUNITY, IMMERSION LEARNING, HUMANISTIC PARTICIPATION

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 3/12/2020 2:34:41
Subject: creating meaning and significance (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

How do we endure and find meaning in a crazy world (fishbowl) has plagued us from the start. ‘Mindfulness' and ‘wholeheartedness' have been extolled in your fishbowls. Both have to do with staying close to text. Staying close to the meaning of words. Even if you didn’t know how to read or write, in times of trouble and anxiety, we gather around the meaning of words. Whenever you stay close to text, it surrounds you with a sense of connection to something great. When you write from a place of truth (your selection of words), spirit (resonates with you) and generosity (flexibility in your selections) you create significance and meaning in your fishbowls.

Stay close to text and ride the wave.

Sanjiv

SIGNIFICANCE, MEANING, ENDURE

Hi Everyone,

How do we endure and find meaning in a crazy world (fishbowl) has plagued us from the start. ‘Mindfulness' and ‘wholeheartedness' have been extolled in your fishbowls. SIGNIFICANCE, MEANING, ENDURE

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 3/11/2020 15:34:46
Subject: first draft: abstract (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Below is the latest interpretation of what you have been doing thus far in your fishbowls. Please note.

Sanjiv

ABSTRACT DEVELOPMENT

TITLE: Immersive Learning, Heuristic Devices and Transmitting Social Imaginaries 

INTRODUCTION: Immersion and Humanistic Participation

Our paper presents a new kind of sharing between author/reader and writer/viewer that transmits a social imaginary and puts into play active humanistic participation. We present a heuristic device for ‘reading’ and ‘writing’ in the context of online sharing that is egalitarian, horizontal and non-hierarchical. We are 120 participants (students mostly, at the University of Rhode Island) presenting the ‘way’ in which we make possible the formulation of our text (I.e.,, raise questions) and its subsequent transformation into knowledge (I.e., innovative felt-experiences). In other words, we’re presenting the ‘manner’ in which we produce categories and concepts for ordering, organizing, and transmitting knowledge among ourselves. In so doing, it came as a revelation that the more we “immersed” ourselves in something, the more we “connected” to universal principles and processes. The deeper we went, the farther we could see all around. ‘Looking carefully at anything, informs looking at everything.’ Our simulated world, we call The Fishbowl, created a surrounding sensory feeling of immersion and humanistic participation.

PURPOSE: Attentional Practice

Our purpose is twofold. One, to present the ‘way’ we deployed attention to text and two, the ‘way’ in which we formed ourselves into a cohesive group. 

There is large variation in attentional practices among us, ranging from rigid to flexible. Our overarching purpose as a group is to manage new digital spaces that produce valuable knowledge for the group. 

METHODOLOGY: Heuristic Device

Our paper presents a process and practice for socially constructing reality, using reflexive methodology over a period of 12 weeks. Combining real and virtual environments and human-machine interactions, we created an experiential learning. 

Operating in groups of three, every participant in The Fishbowl is visible. We are looking at ourselves, looking at ourselves.

As participant-observers, we are interacting by projecting symbolic word-structures and visually constructing abstractions through dialogism and reflexive practices. 

METHOD: Meaning of Words

We collapsed the differences between readers and authors by providing continuous edits and modifications, becoming embedded in each other’s text, until we become one. We offer a more controlled format for producing an equivalent to Wikipedia.

Multiple and deliberative authorship calls for an equivalent form of reading, one that is not a re-reading in the classical sense of the term, but instead a reading anew each time. 

As Readers creating their own meaning, in effect, we were adding own authoring to the text. In this way, we became a living “real time” process of simultaneous reading and writing, producing, evolving and having diverse patterns of meaning.

We did this by shifting attention to focusing on the meaning of words that were raised in the situations with which we were involved, thereby constructing a felt-knowing which helped connect us in personally significant ways.

Simply, we set up a heuristic for deconstructing word-structures and, we extended our reality by infusing individual felt-experiences. 

OUTCOME: Innovative Experience

Our heuristic device helped us imagine, create and deliver innovative experiences. It enabled immersive learning, reduced time spent, while increasing engagement and ability to mirror real-life situations. By following the practice of carefully looking at every word, our “writing” became a process of self-interrogation and selecting symbols, motivated by a concern with the personal and cultural implications for the group.

SO WHAT: Augmented Reality and Extended Reality

Immersive learning is still emerging, but it’s clear that, given the broad range of employee-training services, understanding Augmented Reality and Extended Reality technology will be critical to the enterprise of the future. 

Sanjiv

from the fishbowl...

“STRUCTURES OF FEELINGS’ (RAYMOND WILLIAMS):

- refers to the different ways of thinking vying to emerge at any one time in history.

- the term feeling is used rather than thought to signal that what is at stake may not yet be articulated in a fully worked-out form, but has rather to be inferred by reading between the lines.

Re: ABSTRACT DEVELOPMENT

Mon Mar 02, 2020 3:13 pm

#37

"A way of explaining a feeling about someone" and "People living together forming new ideas". This is the path to abstract development. The "Hermeneutic Perspective" of Gadamer is "A way of explaining a feeling about someone". The "Social Imaginary" of Charles Taylor is "People living together forming new ideas". We are approaching the point in time where we must let people know how we feel. We must live together before we can form new ideas. There is no "I" in the Fisbowl there is only "Us". We are learning to develop unity and cohesion among those who live with in the "Fishbowl". There is too much silence among us and why is that? We must interact amongst each other. The fishbowl has no hierarchy we are all equal, there is no barriers between us. We are all in the fishbowl together and once we begin to feel for one another we will create a social sharing of knowledge and information. Alone one can not form new ideas, it is the people living and interacting together that will form new transformational ideas. For example the day that I walked into my first shift of my first job I was terrified. I was hired at Domino's Pizza in Riverside, Rhode Island to be a pizza delivery boy. Like most high school students we didn't know a whole lot about what it really meant to work a long shift all we really knew was that we wanted money to buy things. I was surrounded by an unfamiliar atmosphere one that I had not previously known. I was thankfully guided by the Store Manager at the time he was young and quite friendly and we could relate pretty well. As I began to familiarize myself with the routine over the first weeks I began to realize that I really didn't like the work I was doing but I knew I needed cash for a new car. I wasn't to familiar with my co-workers and I honestly didn't know much about them and they didn't know much more about me other than my name. I began to feel a sense of loneliness. I simply felt I was only there to do my job as the mechanistic organization would want. I knew I wanted to change the way I felt and as I began to make myself familiar and safe within my surroundings I eventually became more and more curious. I had reached the moment in which I wanted to create understanding amongst those I would be interacting with in the "Fishbowl" so I began asking questions and opening up to those who where around me. I began to gain a sense of understanding while at the same time learning some valuable tips that would help me succeed. The more we began to explain to each other how we felt the more we had bonded and unionized. Eventually we where so familiar with ourselves after two months everything became so effortless. We had changed the way we worked after the time we spent living together. We had become such a close group of people from different backgrounds and different ways of life. We were all brought together by a common goal. Like the great President Abraham Lincoln once said "A house divided can not stand". The "house" in other words the "fishbowl" cannot be divided. The responsibility amongst us now is create this sense of unity, secureness, and familiarity so we can begin constructing new ideas together with the digital benefits that surround us in today's business world.

"Many interconnecting parts or elements and a quality of being organized". This deconstruction of complex structures is what we face to move into a quality of being organized. Figuring out the interconnecting parts or elements of the fishbowl is what we have faced it is a method of transitioning quality of organization. The more interdependence and the more adjustments we must make the more we will be interconnecting. We are learning to create value and add value with this play on words. From where I first started to this current point I feel in a position of pivotal change and I'm coming to realize the importance of adapting to a new complex structures such as the fishbowl. It has been a slow progression and a late start but non the less the complexity has awakened me to develop the understanding of these interconnection parts.

#42

"The element of a person that enables them to be aware of the world and their experiences to do something well". This can represent the conceptual human skills that will present themselves as the solution to lasting change in the office. The concept of utilizing an office or space of gathering to complete daily jobs is at the core of the financial times article and Professor Rowley's letter of conceptual human skills. The issue of office vs remote work is at the forefront of how "soft" skills may play a more vital role in managing and navigating unfamiliarity. Caroline Morganelli 's post fit's perfectly within the "soft" skills we must posses to further advance and grow. She speaks about the adjustments she had to make to familiarize and understand the meaning of the fishbowl. First you must solve to understand complex structures. It is the time we put in that will allow us to retain these invaluable skills. From my own experiences I've always had to learn the hard way to adapt to challenging settings . At times there would be difficulties in navigating how to better improve and grow my own "soft" skills when I first began my education here at URI. At times I was probably the least prepared and there would be times where I was the most prepared. The challenges I encounter and to this day encounter on occasion are those we spend the longest time contemplating and thinking about after realizing the impact of certain decisions. It starts with the attitude and approach one conceptualizes that will provide the understanding of complexity and its function in understanding the organizational design skills that will lead to the change.

UNCOVERING STRUCTURES

Fri Mar 06, 2020 12:31 pm

#44

"People acting together with a common interest and clear and definite actions of sharing something". The social worlds that we revolve around exist twice for a reason. The "physical" world which involves people acting together with a common interest, and second the "mental" world which is intangible. The mental uncovering is the activities that arrive around our clear and definite actions of sharing something which involves the conduct, thoughts, feelings, and judgements we make. Our role of uncovering structures derives from our dual lives. Its the classification of decisions that cause us to reevaluate and create meaning. I'm in the process of formulating and creating a template of knowledge and social facts to fundamentally understand what is happening. We uncover new structures daily and each comes with a new challenge and a new approach and the values we carry will be the most crucial force. Understanding the causation and effect is all metaphorically representing the "uncovering of structures".

HUMAN SPECIES

Sat Mar 07, 2020 9:58 pm

#45

What really stood out to me from Bruce Aylward's concept is the idea of "Absolutely fundamental change". I understood this to be "Emphasizing the central importance of becoming different". Relating this all to the human species we may all come from different or similar backgrounds, share different beliefs, and differ in ways of thinking but at the end of the day we are all part of the human race. Understanding our differences and our similarities by connecting and sharing through the fishbowl is a way of understanding this methodology. The world is becoming more and more globalized as we keep heading into the future. With the technology and advances in communication that surround us today we can create this "absolute fundamental change". The fishbowl is allowing us to understand one another and how each other feels. We are so used to keeping to ourselves, minding our own business, and not disclosing to much about ourselves but this is contrary to the "emphasizing the central importance of becoming different". The fear is that we are alienating ourselves from one another when it is moments like these where we have to move out of these "small unit mentalities" and start thinking big. Really big. I keep hearing people in public, on tv, and in articles regarding coronavirus saying that 80% of people fair relatively well fighting off the virus and then 20%(usually the elderly) are the ones who represent the more serious cases. Many of us are taking this for granted for the sole reason it may not affect ourselves. This is why we must emphasize becoming different in our mentality. When we only recognize ourselves we forget what is affecting others around the world. We all have to participate in the change. Locally there have been issues among people who are breaking quarantine. When we break quarantine we are exposing others to the risk of sickness as well. These actions are self benefiting. Do these actions of exposing others when knowingly ill benefit the larger community around us or the "human race" absolutely not. Because of a simple fundamental difference in thinking the individual did not realize his actions could evolve into the possible deaths of senior citizens or elderly in our community. Being able to all be connected and in accordance with one another like the World Health Organization has been with their colleagues around the world it allows them to be effective in achieving their common goal of improving health around the world. The challenges we face together must start with understanding where the differences lay. The fishbowl allows us to bring our ideas together and share them amongst a community. This sense of relationship building and understanding will help improve our flaws.

SPECIES- a group subordinate to a genus and containing individuals agreeing in some common attributes and called by a common name

HUMAN- a human being, especially a person as distinguished from an animal

We were all brought together by a common goal. Like the great President Abraham Lincoln once said "A house divided can not stand". The "house" in other words the "fishbowl" cannot be divided. The responsibility amongst us now is create this sense of unity, secureness, and familiarity so we can begin constructing new ideas together with the digital benefits that surround us in today's business world.

Our role of uncovering structures derives from our dual lives. Its the classification of decisions that cause us to reevaluate and create meaning. HUMAN SPECIES

Sat Mar 07, 2020 9:58 pm

#45

What really stood out to me from Bruce Aylward's concept is the idea of "Absolutely fundamental change". I understood this to be "Emphasizing the central importance of becoming different". Relating this all to the human species we may all come from different or similar backgrounds, share different beliefs, and differ in ways of thinking but at the end of the day we are all part of the human race. Understanding our differences and our similarities by connecting and sharing through the fishbowl is a way of understanding this methodology. The world is becoming more and more globalized as we keep heading into the future. With the technology and advances in communication that surround us today we can create this "absolute fundamental change". The fishbowl is allowing us to understand one another and how each other feels. We are so used to keeping to ourselves, minding our own business, and not disclosing to much about ourselves but this is contrary to the "emphasizing the central importance of becoming different". The fear is that we are alienating ourselves from one another when it is moments like these where we have to move out of these "small unit mentalities" and start thinking big. Really big. I keep hearing people in public, on tv, and in articles regarding coronavirus saying that 80% of people fair relatively well fighting off the virus and then 20%(usually the elderly) are the ones who represent the more serious cases. Many of us are taking this for granted for the sole reason it may not affect ourselves. This is why we must emphasize becoming different in our mentality. When we only recognize ourselves we forget what is affecting others around the world. We all have to participate in the change. Locally there have been issues among people who are breaking quarantine. When we break quarantine we are exposing others to the risk of sickness as well. These actions are self benefiting. Do these actions of exposing others when knowingly ill benefit the larger community around us or the "human race" absolutely not. Because of a simple fundamental difference in thinking the individual did not realize his actions could evolve into the possible deaths of senior citizens or elderly in our community. Being able to all be connected and in accordance with one another like the World Health Organization has been with their colleagues around the world it allows them to be effective in achieving their common goal of improving health around the world. The challenges we face together must start with understanding where the differences lay. The fishbowl allows us to bring our ideas together and share them amongst a community. This sense of relationship building and understanding will help improve our flaws.

SPECIES- a group subordinate to a genus and containing individuals agreeing in some common attributes and called by a common name

HUMAN- a human being, especially a person as distinguished from an animal

Date: 3/10/2020 14:35:35
Subject: disciplined subjectivity (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Would you say we have created a "surrounding sensory feeling of immersion and humanistic participation” in the fishbowl? I thought of rephrasing that in our Abstract, but I’m not sure.

"What is our structure of feelings? It is only to be evident when shared, developed, and deconstructed and infused. Like baking a cake, the final product is nothing short of a delicious masterpiece, and the evidence of hard work and interconnection is a treasure shared between us all." Lea Janz (Fishbowl, Spr2020)

Our focus in the Abstract, I realize this morning, has to be on 'Learning Through Immersion.' These words feel better. These words are the choices we have to make after sorting, sifting and selecting. Creating word pools is key and standard practice, I would think.

The way we write (in your fishbowls) is not the way we speak. There is a gap and this must be kept in mind. The way we write is 'disciplined subjectivity' because of the choices we make. Please see postings by Lea Janz and Michael Degnan below.

Sanjiv

structures of feelings

 Mon Mar 09, 2020 2:14 pm

structure-composition, system, many part put together

feelings-emotions, not always evident unless physically expressed

the composition of emotions

used as a methodology- rules, methods

to identify certain characteristics of the affective experiences they are trying to analyze

the composition of emotions is used to recognize features of moods, feelings, and emotions in experiences that are being analyzed

"It was a structure in the sense that you could perceive it operating in one work after another which weren't otherwise connected" It is a structure because it operates in every waking moment of our lives, under our nose, through repeated practice in the fishbowl. This in turn infers that feeling is patterned and subject to analysis. (Change and Theory in Raymond William's Structure of Feeling, Sean Matthews).

What is our structure of feelings? It is only to be evident when shared, developed, and deconstructed and infused. Like baking a cake, the final product is nothing short of a delicious masterpiece, and the evidence of hard work and interconnection is a treasure shared between us all.

Re: Degnan: Letters

 Sun Mar 08, 2020 8:48 pm

Abstract Development

Thinking of the fishbowl as a virtual community is an accurate comparison because of how similar the fishbowl is to any other community that we are in. In other communities, people share their ideas and opinion on matters and people learn from what others say. That is similar in the fishbowl with our and others' interpretation of the letters that we receive. In addition, our real-life communities have smaller separate groups that we share more of our ideas with than others, and that is similar to what happens in the fishbowl. Lastly, I believe as time goes on in a community, you become more comfortable and share more of your opinions, which is something I believe has happened of the course of the semester in the fishbowl.

Re: Degnan: Letters

Tue Mar 10, 2020 12:18 am

Abstract Development

The whole idea behind our abstract and why we are interested in sharing this at the national conference is because our style of learning is different than any other style, but that does not mean it cannot be just as effective. This style of learning is based on the interpretation of different lessons and seeing what types of new information we can grasp from this new information. I believe that if we show others our ways of learning, they can adapt to our practices and possibly even build on these and incorporate them into their own lessons.

Date: 3/9/2020 12:35:41
Subject: abstract development-4 (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Everything has been stripped away and this morning the opening paragraph of the Abstract reads as follows below. This opening statement, the opening structure, the opening sentence, the opening syntax have to be thought through trial and error which takes focus and meditation and contemplation. After that, Method and methodology and then finally the Outcome, what happened? Something like that...reviewers like to see some clear things: what is the purpose, how are you doing it, what happened, and lastly, the question: so what?

Land is in sight on the horizon, as we ‘gaze' at each other. We have learnt that fear isolates us, imagination connects us. Please see Nick Colicci’s postings below.

Draft Para for Abstract:

Our paper presents a new kind of sharing between author/reader and writer/viewer that transmits a social imaginary and puts into play active humanistic participation. We present a heuristic for ‘reading’ and ‘writing’ in the context of online sharing that is egalitarian, horizontal and non-hierarchical. We are 120 participants (students mostly, at the University of Rhode Island) presenting the ‘way’ in which we make possible the formulation of our text (that is, raise questions) and its subsequent transformation into knowledge (that is, innovative felt-experiences). In other words, we’re presenting the ‘manner’ in which we produced categories and concepts for ordering, organizing, and transmitting knowledge among ourselves. In so doing, it came as a revelation that the more we “immersed” ourselves in something, the more we “connected” to universal processes. The deeper we went, the farther we could see all around. Our simulated world, we call The Fishbowl, created a surrounding sensory feeling of immersion and humanistic participation. 

Sanjiv

GAZE, FOCUS, MEDITATE, CONTEMPLATE

Developing Models

Sun Mar 01, 2020 8:36 pm

The simple line "We need to be receptive to change" from Dawson was very powerful. In seven words, Dawson drove home the solution to what seems to be our biggest issue in society today. We are cemented in our ways and often unwilling to bend even if it is in the best interest of our organization. This how culture needs to be fostered in the organizations we structure. Our emphasis should be placed on making the organizational flexible and conducive to hearing a wide variety of recommendations and opinions. If we pursue a goal with little desire to deviate from our trajected course, how are we to handle adversity? Keeping our eyes and options open is how we will add value to the organization.

In reading this letter, I compared the Fishbowl to the baseball teams I coach. I reference baseball quite often, but I believe it is because of the similarities in the two organizations. Regardless, Sanjiv is "committed to fostering creative and critical thinkers who innovate with ease, who are not rattled by uncertainty, who move agilely from one form of output to another, and who can communicate in multiple ways with acuity and clarity". I am seeking to do the same for the players on my team. Game scenarios are random and cannot be predicted, so each player must be prepared to effectively handle anything that is thrown their way. Further, these skills can be translated as they move through levels and seek to compete with more advanced players.

The phrase "'crumbling systems and structures" caught my eyes. I interpreted this phrase to mean that the makeup and design of organizations are collapsing and are becoming ineffective. In business, we are often introduced to organizations who have a collapsing structure. It is our job to analyze, dissect, and develop solutions to these challenges. For example, if our baseball team is struggling, it is my responsibility to identify the problem and come up with a solution.

Crumbling- to fall into small pieces; break or part into small fragments.

Systems- an assemblage or combination of things or parts forming a complex or unitary whole.

Structures- mode of building, construction, or organization; arrangement of parts, elements, or constituents.

Abstract Development

 Sun Mar 01, 2020 9:12 pm

"forming a cohesive culture among ourselves". This line can be reconstructed to mean that in the Fishbowl, we are constructing interpretations and posts as a means to develop a sense of unity. This unity will grow our culture and enhance our abilities to interact with one another in a way that yields productive results. I believe being a member of a family encompasses the responsibility of forming a cohesive culture among ourselves. In order to have a tight-knit family, we are responsible for connecting on a deeper level. My family traveled as a means to create a cohesive culture and share experiences. It was a fun and different way of spending time together and creating memories.

Forming- bring together parts or combine to create (something).

Cohesive- the act or state of cohering, uniting, or sticking together.

Culture- the quality in a person or society that arises from a concern for what is regarded as excellent in arts, letters, manners, scholarly pursuits, etc.

Among- in, into, or through the midst of; in association or connection with; surrounded by.

Ourselves- a reflexive form of we (used as the direct or indirect object of a verb or the direct object of a preposition).

With technology growing, I expect to be doing business and working with others through computers or at least online. Due to this, we must get comfortable communicating by typing words. We can practice this in the Fishbowl to gain familiarity. We must learn the most efficient methods and processes because we will be able to implement them into the organizational design we seek to enact as we become organizational leaders. In the Fishbowl, we are being exposed to a variety of ideas and mental structures. In doing this, we are able to open our minds to new perspectives and ultimately enhance our ability to add value. We must embrace the change and pursue to combine our differences to build strengths.

Staying Connected Through Reflections

Sat Mar 07, 2020 10:50 am

The opportunity to travel for spring break is exciting for me; I am anxious to take a break from the cold of Rhode Island and explore the warm area of St. Petersburg. While I may not be able to post my responses each day, I certainly will be thinking about them every chance that I get as a means to understand the structure of others and apply my own experiences. I can explore with a sense of abstraction and break down the interactions I have with those that I encounter. It will be an opportunity for me to take a step back from my hectic life and reflect on what I have accomplished this semester thus far.

I went to Florida in November of 2019 to visit my friends in Gainesville, Florida. It was a short trip, I left on a Friday and came back on a Monday. Even the four days I was gone I was happy to eat at different restaurants, meet new people, and see a Florida Gators football game. It helped me to understand how each culture and group of people have their own traditions that make their experiences unique. I am hoping for this same satisfaction this upcoming week. I always encourage my friends to attend a southern college football game. I recommend this not for the football, but the unique traditions each college and its students have on game day. It is a great insight into a culture.

As Andrea said, I hope spring break is an "Opportunity to do nothing." I work best when my brain can take a break, relax, and process the events in my life. It is hard to do this in a time of high stress and school work. To be successful, we need to value the time we have with little to no responsibility and learn to make that time our own.

Personal Empowerment

Sat Mar 07, 2020 11:13 am

I have always worked to assume my own personal power. To me, personal power is the ability to face any challenge head-on and beat it. I believe the act of assuming personal power leads to personal empowerment, which provides me the opportunity to walk into any organization and make my mark. What is the fun of sitting behind the scenes? The pursuit of personal empower is not an easy one, as Sanjiv explained that we need to rethink and reshape the world around us. This takes trial and error because we have to be active participants in the process of deconstruction, looking at the world and other interactions at a more abstract and conceptual level, as we attempt to apply our meaning to these events.

Everyone in the Fishbowl is practicing and building these skills so when we enter the professional world, we can add value and bring the contract home. Each word and sentence we break down is preparing us for unique interactions and events for us to remember. Amiel's post was very powerful. He took the time to write a genuine response to the idea of abstract development. This is why I value the Fishbowl: the commitment of people to their intellectual growth is moving and powerful. I learn from my peers in a way I never have in the past. It is refreshing to not be lectured about how I should feel about events and instead explore my feelings and perspectives about the world.

"change is an individual affair". In other words, to adjust our thought processes, we cannot rely on others and instead focus on the personal steps we can take to grow. Practicing for the LSAT is not an event that we can rely on other people to help us with. We are the only ones responsible and capable of shifting our way of thinking to match that of the test.

Change- to make the form, nature, content, future course, etc., of (something) different from what it is or from what it would be if left alone.

Individual- a single human being, as distinguished from a group.

Affair- anything done or to be done; anything requiring action or effort; business; concern.

Immersive Technology

Sat Mar 07, 2020 11:43 am

The line "It can be intimidating sometimes to share experiences personal to you with classmates that are going to read it, but it also gives you a sense of achievement that you are infusing your own experiences to create knowledge in the world" by Olivia encapsulated the feelings I have each time I make a post in the Fishbowl. I am nervous to share my life with such a large group of people I do not know well. But, it is a way for others to grow as well, and thus I overcome the feelings of intimidation. If I did not infuse my own experiences into the world, or the events I encountered in my daily life, what kind of meaning would my life have? Would it be banaler? Would I be less motivated to see various perspectives and the take time to learn from others? Those are some questions I ask myself in the Fishbowl. They help me to hone in on the purpose of the Fishbowl and why I dedicate a large amount of time to it.

The Fishbowl, which Sanjiv describes as immersive technology, is the key to understanding each other. The same way I can use the Fishbowl to read letters and vocabulary from my peers, I can use the Fishbowl to help Sanjiv overcome some of the roadblocks he is having with the abstract. The process he is following for creating the letter is the process we should follow not only in the Fishbowl but in our organizations and work lives. If we pose a question, it needs to be of meaning and worth. We have to make someone understand why we posed a question, the meaning behind it, and ensure they have the ability to relate their own personal experiences.

Re: Conceptual and human skills will come to the fore

Sun Mar 08, 2020 6:04 pm

The shift to more remote office work has been evident in recent years; people seem to be more productive and at ease when they are not restricted to working inside of an office. While I have not had many office jobs in the past, I can see why the atmosphere is less than ideal for some who prefer to work in comfort. It is interesting to consider whether or not at home work will or will not be more productive and profitable for organizations. With the coronavirus circulating, and more people choosing isolation, will organizational success stymie? Or, will the increase in productivity from a more comfortable work environment actually be beneficial for the company? No one is isolated; there is always a means to communicate and discuss ideas through text, calls, and Skype.

I believe that each college course that we take should focus on us developing our soft skills. After all, soft skills are the foundation for the overarching skills and knowledge that we need to complete a task presented to us. We must place a large emphasis on developing these soft skills because if not, we will be replaced by those who have such skills. Further reflecting on the aforementioned paragraph, when Caroline states "The key, in my opinion, is to make sure that you do not fall behind" raises an important question to organizations that allow their employees to work from home. I feel as if I have fallen behind in the Fishbowl now. It was a busy week and I was not able to lock into the Fishbowl and produce my reflections. However, I am catching up, albeit at a slow pace. I am hoping to capitalize on my free time to gain some lost ground.

Everything has been stripped away and this morning the opening paragraph of the Abstract reads as follows below. This opening statement, the opening structure, the opening sentence, the opening syntax have to be thought through trial and error which takes focus and meditation and contemplation. After that, Method and methodology and then finally the Outcome, what happened? Something like that...reviewers like to see some clear things: what is the purpose, how are you doing it, what happened, and lastly, the question: so what?

Land is in sight on the horizon, as we ‘gaze' at each other. We have learnt that fear isolates us, imagination connects us. Please see Nick Colicci’s postings below.

Draft Para for Abstract:

Our paper presents a new kind of sharing between author/reader and writer/viewer that transmits a social imaginary and puts into play active humanistic participation. We present a heuristic for ‘reading’ and ‘writing’ in the context of online sharing that is egalitarian, horizontal and non-hierarchical. We are 120 participants (students mostly, at the University of Rhode Island) presenting the ‘way’ in which we make possible the formulation of our text (that is, raise questions) and its subsequent transformation into knowledge (that is, innovative felt-experiences). In other words, we’re presenting the ‘manner’ in which we produced categories and concepts for ordering, organizing, and transmitting knowledge among ourselves. In so doing, it came as a revelation that the more we “immersed” ourselves in something, the more we “connected” to universal processes. The deeper we went, the farther we could see all around. Our simulated world, we call The Fishbowl, created a surrounding sensory feeling of immersion and humanistic participation. 

Sanjiv

GAZE, FOCUS, MEDITATE, CONTEMPLATE

from the fishbowl...

Developing Models

Sun Mar 01, 2020 8:36 pm

The simple line "We need to be receptive to change" from Dawson was very powerful. In seven words, Dawson drove home the solution to what seems to be our biggest issue in society today. We are cemented in our ways and often unwilling to bend even if it is in the best interest of our organization. This how culture needs to be fostered in the organizations we structure. Our emphasis should be placed on making the organizational flexible and conducive to hearing a wide variety of recommendations and opinions. If we pursue a goal with little desire to deviate from our trajected course, how are we to handle adversity? Keeping our eyes and options open is how we will add value to the organization.

In reading this letter, I compared the Fishbowl to the baseball teams I coach. I reference baseball quite often, but I believe it is because of the similarities in the two organizations. Regardless, Sanjiv is "committed to fostering creative and critical thinkers who innovate with ease, who are not rattled by uncertainty, who move agilely from one form of output to another, and who can communicate in multiple ways with acuity and clarity". I am seeking to do the same for the players on my team. Game scenarios are random and cannot be predicted, so each player must be prepared to effectively handle anything that is thrown their way. Further, these skills can be translated as they move through levels and seek to compete with more advanced players.

The phrase "'crumbling systems and structures" caught my eyes. I interpreted this phrase to mean that the makeup and design of organizations are collapsing and are becoming ineffective. In business, we are often introduced to organizations who have a collapsing structure. It is our job to analyze, dissect, and develop solutions to these challenges. For example, if our baseball team is struggling, it is my responsibility to identify the problem and come up with a solution.

Crumbling- to fall into small pieces; break or part into small fragments.

Systems- an assemblage or combination of things or parts forming a complex or unitary whole.

Structures- mode of building, construction, or organization; arrangement of parts, elements, or constituents.

Abstract Development

 Sun Mar 01, 2020 9:12 pm

"forming a cohesive culture among ourselves". This line can be reconstructed to mean that in the Fishbowl, we are constructing interpretations and posts as a means to develop a sense of unity. This unity will grow our culture and enhance our abilities to interact with one another in a way that yields productive results. I believe being a member of a family encompasses the responsibility of forming a cohesive culture among ourselves. In order to have a tight-knit family, we are responsible for connecting on a deeper level. My family traveled as a means to create a cohesive culture and share experiences. It was a fun and different way of spending time together and creating memories.

Forming- bring together parts or combine to create (something).

Cohesive- the act or state of cohering, uniting, or sticking together.

Culture- the quality in a person or society that arises from a concern for what is regarded as excellent in arts, letters, manners, scholarly pursuits, etc.

Among- in, into, or through the midst of; in association or connection with; surrounded by.

Ourselves- a reflexive form of we (used as the direct or indirect object of a verb or the direct object of a preposition).

With technology growing, I expect to be doing business and working with others through computers or at least online. Due to this, we must get comfortable communicating by typing words. We can practice this in the Fishbowl to gain familiarity. We must learn the most efficient methods and processes because we will be able to implement them into the organizational design we seek to enact as we become organizational leaders. In the Fishbowl, we are being exposed to a variety of ideas and mental structures. In doing this, we are able to open our minds to new perspectives and ultimately enhance our ability to add value. We must embrace the change and pursue to combine our differences to build strengths.

Staying Connected Through Reflections

Sat Mar 07, 2020 10:50 am

The opportunity to travel for spring break is exciting for me; I am anxious to take a break from the cold of Rhode Island and explore the warm area of St. Petersburg. While I may not be able to post my responses each day, I certainly will be thinking about them every chance that I get as a means to understand the structure of others and apply my own experiences. I can explore with a sense of abstraction and break down the interactions I have with those that I encounter. It will be an opportunity for me to take a step back from my hectic life and reflect on what I have accomplished this semester thus far.

I went to Florida in November of 2019 to visit my friends in Gainesville, Florida. It was a short trip, I left on a Friday and came back on a Monday. Even the four days I was gone I was happy to eat at different restaurants, meet new people, and see a Florida Gators football game. It helped me to understand how each culture and group of people have their own traditions that make their experiences unique. I am hoping for this same satisfaction this upcoming week. I always encourage my friends to attend a southern college football game. I recommend this not for the football, but the unique traditions each college and its students have on game day. It is a great insight into a culture.

As Andrea said, I hope spring break is an "Opportunity to do nothing." I work best when my brain can take a break, relax, and process the events in my life. It is hard to do this in a time of high stress and school work. To be successful, we need to value the time we have with little to no responsibility and learn to make that time our own.

Personal Empowerment

Sat Mar 07, 2020 11:13 am

I have always worked to assume my own personal power. To me, personal power is the ability to face any challenge head-on and beat it. I believe the act of assuming personal power leads to personal empowerment, which provides me the opportunity to walk into any organization and make my mark. What is the fun of sitting behind the scenes? The pursuit of personal empower is not an easy one, as Sanjiv explained that we need to rethink and reshape the world around us. This takes trial and error because we have to be active participants in the process of deconstruction, looking at the world and other interactions at a more abstract and conceptual level, as we attempt to apply our meaning to these events.

Everyone in the Fishbowl is practicing and building these skills so when we enter the professional world, we can add value and bring the contract home. Each word and sentence we break down is preparing us for unique interactions and events for us to remember. Amiel's post was very powerful. He took the time to write a genuine response to the idea of abstract development. This is why I value the Fishbowl: the commitment of people to their intellectual growth is moving and powerful. I learn from my peers in a way I never have in the past. It is refreshing to not be lectured about how I should feel about events and instead explore my feelings and perspectives about the world.

"change is an individual affair". In other words, to adjust our thought processes, we cannot rely on others and instead focus on the personal steps we can take to grow. Practicing for the LSAT is not an event that we can rely on other people to help us with. We are the only ones responsible and capable of shifting our way of thinking to match that of the test.

Change- to make the form, nature, content, future course, etc., of (something) different from what it is or from what it would be if left alone.

Individual- a single human being, as distinguished from a group.

Affair- anything done or to be done; anything requiring action or effort; business; concern.

Immersive Technology

Sat Mar 07, 2020 11:43 am

The line "It can be intimidating sometimes to share experiences personal to you with classmates that are going to read it, but it also gives you a sense of achievement that you are infusing your own experiences to create knowledge in the world" by Olivia encapsulated the feelings I have each time I make a post in the Fishbowl. I am nervous to share my life with such a large group of people I do not know well. But, it is a way for others to grow as well, and thus I overcome the feelings of intimidation. If I did not infuse my own experiences into the world, or the events I encountered in my daily life, what kind of meaning would my life have? Would it be banaler? Would I be less motivated to see various perspectives and the take time to learn from others? Those are some questions I ask myself in the Fishbowl. They help me to hone in on the purpose of the Fishbowl and why I dedicate a large amount of time to it.

The Fishbowl, which Sanjiv describes as immersive technology, is the key to understanding each other. The same way I can use the Fishbowl to read letters and vocabulary from my peers, I can use the Fishbowl to help Sanjiv overcome some of the roadblocks he is having with the abstract. The process he is following for creating the letter is the process we should follow not only in the Fishbowl but in our organizations and work lives. If we pose a question, it needs to be of meaning and worth. We have to make someone understand why we posed a question, the meaning behind it, and ensure they have the ability to relate their own personal experiences.

Re: Conceptual and human skills will come to the fore

Sun Mar 08, 2020 6:04 pm

The shift to more remote office work has been evident in recent years; people seem to be more productive and at ease when they are not restricted to working inside of an office. While I have not had many office jobs in the past, I can see why the atmosphere is less than ideal for some who prefer to work in comfort. It is interesting to consider whether or not at home work will or will not be more productive and profitable for organizations. With the coronavirus circulating, and more people choosing isolation, will organizational success stymie? Or, will the increase in productivity from a more comfortable work environment actually be beneficial for the company? No one is isolated; there is always a means to communicate and discuss ideas through text, calls, and Skype.

I believe that each college course that we take should focus on us developing our soft skills. After all, soft skills are the foundation for the overarching skills and knowledge that we need to complete a task presented to us. We must place a large emphasis on developing these soft skills because if not, we will be replaced by those who have such skills. Further reflecting on the aforementioned paragraph, when Caroline states "The key, in my opinion, is to make sure that you do not fall behind" raises an important question to organizations that allow their employees to work from home. I feel as if I have fallen behind in the Fishbowl now. It was a busy week and I was not able to lock into the Fishbowl and produce my reflections. However, I am catching up, albeit at a slow pace. I am hoping to capitalize on my free time to gain some lost ground.

Hi Everyone,

I better get down to writing (drafting on the draft board) today. This morning I'm thinking and feeling that the Abstract could begin with the notion of virtual community. That’s what we are, you’d agree. 

Got to make thoughts flow (water metaphor) by writing it out.

and/or

Got to make words flow (electricity metaphor) by thinking it out.

In other words, we are searching for meaning by sorting, sifting, and selecting words. 

Fleeting moments, ephemeral images, transient feelings. Flying by the seat of our pants (metaphor).

Our Abstract must talk about HOW we have begun “sharing" in our virtual community called the fishbowl. Next we show our process, that is, how we are doing it (let’s call it: deconstruct and infuse, only for the time-being), and finally reveal ourselves to ourselves in "structures of feelings” (please google Raymond Williams) in the final paper.

Sanjiv

Re: ABSTRACT DEVELOPMENT

Mon Mar 02, 2020 3:13 pm

#37

"A way of explaining a feeling about someone" and "People living together forming new ideas". This is the path to abstract development. The "Hermeneutic Perspective" of Gadamer is "A way of explaining a feeling about someone". The "Social Imaginary" of Charles Taylor is "People living together forming new ideas". We are approaching the point in time where we must let people know how we feel. We must live together before we can form new ideas. There is no "I" in the Fisbowl there is only "Us". We are learning to develop unity and cohesion among those who live with in the "Fishbowl". There is too much silence among us and why is that? We must interact amongst each other. The fishbowl has no hierarchy we are all equal, there is no barriers between us. We are all in the fishbowl together and once we begin to feel for one another we will create a social sharing of knowledge and information. Alone one can not form new ideas, it is the people living and interacting together that will form new transformational ideas. For example the day that I walked into my first shift of my first job I was terrified. I was hired at Domino's Pizza in Riverside, Rhode Island to be a pizza delivery boy. Like most high school students we didn't know a whole lot about what it really meant to work a long shift all we really knew was that we wanted money to buy things. I was surrounded by an unfamiliar atmosphere one that I had not previously known. I was thankfully guided by the Store Manager at the time he was young and quite friendly and we could relate pretty well. As I began to familiarize myself with the routine over the first weeks I began to realize that I really didn't like the work I was doing but I knew I needed cash for a new car. I wasn't to familiar with my co-workers and I honestly didn't know much about them and they didn't know much more about me other than my name. I began to feel a sense of loneliness. I simply felt I was only there to do my job as the mechanistic organization would want. I knew I wanted to change the way I felt and as I began to make myself familiar and safe within my surroundings I eventually became more and more curious. I had reached the moment in which I wanted to create understanding amongst those I would be interacting with in the "Fishbowl" so I began asking questions and opening up to those who where around me. I began to gain a sense of understanding while at the same time learning some valuable tips that would help me succeed. The more we began to explain to each other how we felt the more we had bonded and unionized. Eventually we where so familiar with ourselves after two months everything became so effortless. We had changed the way we worked after the time we spent living together. We had become such a close group of people from different backgrounds and different ways of life. We were all brought together by a common goal. Like the great President Abraham Lincoln once said "A house divided can not stand". The "house" in other words the "fishbowl" cannot be divided. The responsibility amongst us now is create this sense of unity, secureness, and familiarity so we can begin constructing new ideas together with the digital benefits that surround us in today's business world.

UNCOVERING STRUCTURES

Fri Mar 06, 2020 12:31 pm

#44

"People acting together with a common interest and clear and definite actions of sharing something". The social worlds that we revolve around exist twice for a reason. The "physical" world which involves people acting together with a common interest, and second the "mental" world which is intangible. The mental uncovering is the activities that arrive around our clear and definite actions of sharing something which involves the conduct, thoughts, feelings, and judgements we make. Our role of uncovering structures derives from our dual lives. Its the classification of decisions that cause us to reevaluate and create meaning. I'm in the process of formulating and creating a template of knowledge and social facts to fundamentally understand what is happening. We uncover new structures daily and each comes with a new challenge and a new approach and the values we carry will be the most crucial force. Understanding the causation and effect is all metaphorically representing the "uncovering of structures".

HUMAN SPECIES

Sat Mar 07, 2020 9:58 pm

#45

What really stood out to me from Bruce Aylward's concept is the idea of "Absolutely fundamental change". I understood this to be "Emphasizing the central importance of becoming different". Relating this all to the human species we may all come from different or similar backgrounds, share different beliefs, and differ in ways of thinking but at the end of the day we are all part of the human race. Understanding our differences and our similarities by connecting and sharing through the fishbowl is a way of understanding this methodology. The world is becoming more and more globalized as we keep heading into the future. With the technology and advances in communication that surround us today we can create this "absolute fundamental change". The fishbowl is allowing us to understand one another and how each other feels. We are so used to keeping to ourselves, minding our own business, and not disclosing to much about ourselves but this is contrary to the "emphasizing the central importance of becoming different". The fear is that we are alienating ourselves from one another when it is moments like these where we have to move out of these "small unit mentalities" and start thinking big. Really big. I keep hearing people in public, on tv, and in articles regarding coronavirus saying that 80% of people fair relatively well fighting off the virus and then 20%(usually the elderly) are the ones who represent the more serious cases. Many of us are taking this for granted for the sole reason it may not affect ourselves. This is why we must emphasize becoming different in our mentality. When we only recognize ourselves we forget what is affecting others around the world. We all have to participate in the change. Locally there have been issues among people who are breaking quarantine. When we break quarantine we are exposing others to the risk of sickness as well. These actions are self benefiting. Do these actions of exposing others when knowingly ill benefit the larger community around us or the "human race" absolutely not. Because of a simple fundamental difference in thinking the individual did not realize his actions could evolve into the possible deaths of senior citizens or elderly in our community. Being able to all be connected and in accordance with one another like the World Health Organization has been with their colleagues around the world it allows them to be effective in achieving their common goal of improving health around the world. The challenges we face together must start with understanding where the differences lay. The fishbowl allows us to bring our ideas together and share them amongst a community. This sense of relationship building and understanding will help improve our flaws.

SPECIES- a group subordinate to a genus and containing individuals agreeing in some common attributes and called by a common name

HUMAN- a human being, especially a person as distinguished from an animal

The mental uncovering is the activities that arrive around our clear and definite actions of sharing something which involves the conduct, thoughts, feelings, and judgements we make. Our role of uncovering structures derives from our dual lives. Its the classification of decisions that cause us to reevaluate and create meaning. I'm in the process of formulating and creating a template of knowledge and social facts to fundamentally understand what is happening. We uncover new structures daily and each comes with a new challenge and a new approach and the values we carry will be the most crucial force. Understanding the causation and effect is all metaphorically representing the "uncovering of structures".

HUMAN SPECIES

Sat Mar 07, 2020 9:58 pm

#45

What really stood out to me from Bruce Aylward's concept is the idea of "Absolutely fundamental change". I understood this to be "Emphasizing the central importance of becoming different". Relating this all to the human species we may all come from different or similar backgrounds, share different beliefs, and differ in ways of thinking but at the end of the day we are all part of the human race. Understanding our differences and our similarities by connecting and sharing through the fishbowl is a way of understanding this methodology. The world is becoming more and more globalized as we keep heading into the future. With the technology and advances in communication that surround us today we can create this "absolute fundamental change". The fishbowl is allowing us to understand one another and how each other feels. We are so used to keeping to ourselves, minding our own business, and not disclosing to much about ourselves but this is contrary to the "emphasizing the central importance of becoming different". The fear is that we are alienating ourselves from one another when it is moments like these where we have to move out of these "small unit mentalities" and start thinking big. Really big. I keep hearing people in public, on tv, and in articles regarding coronavirus saying that 80% of people fair relatively well fighting off the virus and then 20%(usually the elderly) are the ones who represent the more serious cases. Many of us are taking this for granted for the sole reason it may not affect ourselves. This is why we must emphasize becoming different in our mentality. When we only recognize ourselves we forget what is affecting others around the world. We all have to participate in the change. Locally there have been issues among people who are breaking quarantine. When we break quarantine we are exposing others to the risk of sickness as well. These actions are self benefiting. Do these actions of exposing others when knowingly ill benefit the larger community around us or the "human race" absolutely not. Because of a simple fundamental difference in thinking the individual did not realize his actions could evolve into the possible deaths of senior citizens or elderly in our community. Being able to all be connected and in accordance with one another like the World Health Organization has been with their colleagues around the world it allows them to be effective in achieving their common goal of improving health around the world. The challenges we face together must start with understanding where the differences lay. The fishbowl allows us to bring our ideas together and share them amongst a community. This sense of relationship building and understanding will help improve our flaws.

SPECIES- a group subordinate to a genus and containing individuals agreeing in some common attributes and called by a common name

HUMAN- a human being, especially a person as distinguished from an animal

Hi Everyone,

Any of your postings in your fishbowls can be The Abstract. An important question confronting us today is: How to be in touch with our humanity and not give-in to dogma in the face of a viral global attack. We are watching a historic human melodrama of the most tragic kind occurring in front of our eyes. We don’t know the outcome as we watch the trajectory of its storyline. The last time I watched anything close was the image of Twin Towers coming down in NYC. Life is never the same afterwards.

What our paper might address is: How To Stay in Touch with Humanity and not give-in to Dogma in a Digital world. Tiana Martinez says it most eloquently.

Sanjiv

TianaMartinez

Posts: 113

Joined: Fri Jan 24, 2020 2:07 pm

Re: Letter Interpretations

Wed Feb 26, 2020 2:46 pm

CREATING VISUAL SPACES AND SPECTACLES

As we create abstractions in our fishbowls, we are connecting across cultures in the way that we are writing our personal felt experiences and allowing our readers to think further about their personal life as it relates to our experience. As we write personal expressions, we are giving our class members a way to connect on a deeper level with us and the experiences that we go through. As we write about what we go through and what it means to us, we are creating a culture because our readers are also explaining what it means to them and a similar or dissimilar past experience that they have had. I personally find myself doing this more and more as I read each post that people have been posting. As I read about their experiences, I feel as though a connection is growing there because it makes me more aware of the fact that we all have similarities in what we go through. Even if I do not experience the same things as some people, it still forces me to place myself in their shoes and try to understand the experience that they went through, thus allowing me to understand why they think and express themselves in the way that they do. This is something that makes the fishbowl more powerful because it shows that we create value based on both our differences as well as our similarities. When I push myself to step out of my own thoughts and try to understand another person's, I feel my intellectual mind growing because I am able to experience the true reason for working in a virtual world amongst other people. The fishbowl is also allowing me to get into the habit of expressing the way that I feel and the way that my mind thinks freely. I have not been someone who expresses themselves, instead I tend to keep everything in and to myself, but as I write my abstractions, it allows me to become more comfortable doing this.

Society of the Spectacle by Guy Debord is a book which focuses on examining society's image based culture. He explains how to him, the spectacle is the reign of the market economy and it is brought about by mass media. Although this may sound confusing to some, it is not as incomprehensible as it may sound. We see the spectacle everywhere we look whether it is in the ads we see posted all over the place or even the ads that pop up from our computers. For Debord, the spectacle is unacceptable and it degrades our lives. Some may agree while some may possibly disagree, but everyone is entitled to their own opinions because not everyone has the same culture. The difference is, although a disagreement is brought about, an understanding can be found.

Date: 3/7/2020 23:48:29
Subject: human species (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Your fishbowl reflections are a category of learning that holds up a mirror to us as human beings as to who we really are. That is to say, they obviously have everything to do with our relationship to our lives. They also reflect our relationships with the environment—the built environment that we create (our abstractions in the fishbowl) and the natural environment that responds. Your fishbowls show the moral relationships that we have toward each other as people, and we’re seeing that in your postings.

The main part of preparedness to face global challenges is that we need as human beings to realize that we’re all in this together, that what affects one person anywhere affects everyone everywhere, that we are therefore inevitably part of a species, and we need to think in that way rather than about divisions of race and ethnicity, economic status, and all the rest of it. The way we respond to things like cross-dressers (Kinky Boots), is often a function of our racial or ethnic or religious views rather than our general humanity, and our responses have shown the flaws of human beings in some way. 

But it’s also true that the way that we respond very much depends on our values, our commitments, and our sense of being part of the human race and not smaller units. Bruce Aylward, who led the W.H.O. mission to China said upon his return: "the major thing that needs to happen, if we are to be prepared now and in the future, there has to be an absolutely fundamental change in our mind-set. We have to think that we have to work together as a human species to be organized to care for one another, to realize that the health of the most vulnerable people among us is a determining factor for the health of all of us, and, if we aren’t prepared to do that, we’ll never, ever be prepared to confront these devastating challenges to our humanity.”

Every posting you make in your fishbowls and, the abstraction you create, is testimony to your shared humanity. We connect at abstract levels where we transcend our differences.

Sanjiv

SPECIES, HUMAN

from the fishbowl...

nickcolicci

Posts: 245

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 9:40 am

Contact: Contact nickcolicci

Immersive Technology

Sat Mar 07, 2020 11:43 am

The line "It can be intimidating sometimes to share experiences personal to you with classmates that are going to read it, but it also gives you a sense of achievement that you are infusing your own experiences to create knowledge in the world" by Olivia encapsulated the feelings I have each time I make a post in the Fishbowl. I am nervous to share my life with such a large group of people I do not know well. But, it is a way for others to grow as well, and thus I overcome the feelings of intimidation. If I did not infuse my own experiences into the world, or the events I encountered in my daily life, what kind of meaning would my life have? Would it be banaler? Would I be less motivated to see various perspectives and the take time to learn from others? Those are some questions I ask myself in the Fishbowl. They help me to hone in on the purpose of the Fishbowl and why I dedicate a large amount of time to it.

The Fishbowl, which Sanjiv describes as immersive technology, is the key to understanding each other. The same way I can use the Fishbowl to read letters and vocabulary from my peers, I can use the Fishbowl to help Sanjiv overcome some of the roadblocks he is having with the abstract. The process he is following for creating the letter is the process we should follow not only in the Fishbowl but in our organizations and work lives. If we pose a question, it needs to be of meaning and worth. We have to make someone understand why we posed a question, the meaning behind it, and ensure they have the ability to relate their own personal experiences.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 3/6/2020 16:28:07
Subject: uncovering structures (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Our task (in 443 and 448) boils down to uncovering the most profoundly buried structures of the various social worlds that we occupy; the social meeting exercise in 448 and your first project in 443.

Our social worlds are peculiar in that its structures lead, as it were, a “double life.” They exist twice. According to Pierre Bourdieu, first in the physical distribution of resources, and second in the form of systems of classification, i.e., the mental and bodily schemata that function as symbolic templates for the practical activities---conduct, thoughts, feelings, and judgements that we do.

In doing our projects, we are uncovering our systems of classifications. What form do they take? What is their content? The answers to these questions are social facts and we study them because as humans we are constructing meaning and knowledge.

Sanjiv

SYSTEM, CLASSIFICATION, SCHEMATA, TEMPLATE, FORM, CONTENT, SOCIAL

from the fishbowl...

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 9:06 am

Reflection: Complex Structures

Thu Mar 05, 2020 12:10 pm

After looking up the definitions of the words "complex" and "structure," I believe a complex structure is anything constructed or arranged out of many parts. I think this relates back to the invisible structures that we've talked about in class. These are structures that impact every one of our actions and interactions, yet we barely realize they exist. They are the metaphors we operate under, and I would say that they're indeed complex. They're made of numerous parts, from the values our parents imprint onto us, the values society imprints onto us, our own personalities and many other forces. It would be impossible to identify all the places our invisible structures come from.

As you dive into the first project, I wonder whether the opening structure I gave you is unnecessarily complex. You should have a choice. You are free to consider this one below, as your opening structure; if the group agrees upon it. The opening structure is a group decision:

“Our understanding of what we are seeing changes according to the frame or image that shapes our viewpoint.”

I think this opening structure is more malleable. Fewer concepts/words.

You’re doing a lot of things in the 10+1 steps. Above all, you are creating a memory about figuring something out; of entering the unknown; of creating meaning. 

Your memories in your fishbowls are intersubjective and intertextual (please google both terms). 

You’re “creating history as possibility.” Please google, “Pedagogy of the Oppressed” by Paulo Freire.

Re: Vocabulary/Google Searches

Mon Mar 02, 2020 3:45 pm

Performance- the action or process of carrying out or accomplishing an action, task, or function.

Performativity- a language which functions as a form of social action and has the effect of change. The power of language to effect change in the world

Creative Critical Writing- a research method that treats the form of academic writing as constitutive of its conceptual argument.

Constitutive- having the power to establish or give organized existence to something.

Conceptual- relating to or based on mental concepts.

kevinbugbee

Posts: 102

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 10:13 am

Contact: Contact kevinbugbee

Re: Vocabulary/Google Searches

Thu Mar 05, 2020 3:27 pm

DISCOURSE ANALYSIS- a research method for studying written or spoken language in relation to its social context. It studies how language, texts, and structures are seen in real life situations. We are using discourse analysis every time we implement and discuss our own past experiences in the fishbowl.

THE REDUCTIONIST TECHNIQUE- an approach to understanding the nature of complex things by reducing them to the interactions of their parts, or to simpler or more fundamental things. This is also what we are doing in the fishbowl; every time we deconstruct Sanjiv's letters and chose 1 or 2 phrases, we are using the reductionist technique.
