Date: 3/5/2020 15:02:33
Subject: &quot;conceptual and human skills will come to the fore&quot; (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Yesterday on my way home, I stopped at my usual watering hole and was leafing through the day’s FT. I must have been thinking about you in the fishbowl because something caught my eye on page 8 under Letters (Financial Times, March 4, 2020)

The caption read: "Conceptual and human skills will come to the fore.” The letter is from one Prof Chris Rowley at Kellogg College, University of Oxford, UK. 

In his letter he is referring to FT’s March 2 report titled “Coronavirus may mean lasting change in the office.” 

This is something we all have to consider now. It is a report on the issue of office-vs-remote working and thus very timely. 

The Professor, responds to the report.

He notes that managers and leaders are very often promoted on the basis of a particular technical skill (like, marketing, finance, accounting, supply chain, etc.). 

However, it is the human and conceptual skills (the other end of the dimension on skills) that have gained relative importance in an organizational hierarchy. That is to say, at every level in the organizational hierarchy, you have to have ‘soft’ skills to survive. The ability to work with others is not only important, it has also increased.

Hence the Social Meeting exercise in 448.

Conceptual skills have become increasingly critical according to Rowley. “As organizations face a coronavirus contagion, it is exactly these skills---conceptual and human---that will be ever more important for effective leadership and then managing the difficult and tricky changes needed regarding work.” It is exactly what you and I are doing together in our fishbowls...conceptual and human skills. We’ve never felt so closely before! Please see Caroline Morganelli’s post below.

Sanjiv

CONCEPTUAL, HUMAN, SKILL, HIERARCHY, LEVEL

RE: "facing a new complex structure" (443 & 448)

Entering the semester I was very nervous about using the fishbowl. It is a very complex new structure of communication I am unfamiliar with. I would not say that I was scared, I would more so say I was nervous for the adjustment of this "always online" platform of knowledge sharing. As of now I feel as though I am adjusting. The key in my opinion is to make sure that you do not fall behind. Taking the time to understand something takes work, but without time and effort one will not be able to retain information and then later pass it on to others.

Solving or understanding complex structures takes time and an understanding of organization. To fully understand we must understand how this complex structure works, functions and its organizational method. By understanding this we will be use the knowledge gained from here to advance to the other complex structures in our lives.

complex: consisting of many different and connected parts.

structure: the arrangement of and relations between the parts or elements of something complex.

Complex Structure: a multi-faced arrangement of and relations between parts or elements.

Hi Everyone,

Yesterday on my way home, I stopped at my usual watering hole and was leafing through the day’s FT. I must have been thinking about you in the fishbowl because something caught my eye on page 8 under Letters (Financial Times, March 4, 2020)

The caption read: "Conceptual and human skills will come to the fore.” The letter is from one Prof Chris Rowley at Kellogg College, University of Oxford, UK. 

In his letter he is referring to FT’s March 2 report titled “Coronavirus may mean lasting change in the office.” 

This is something we all have to consider now. It is a report on the issue of office-vs-remote working and thus very timely. 

The Professor, responds to the report.

He notes that managers and leaders are very often promoted on the basis of a particular technical skill (like, marketing, finance, accounting, supply chain, etc.). 

However, it is the human and conceptual skills (the other end of the dimension on skills) that have gained relative importance in an organizational hierarchy. That is to say, at every level in the organizational hierarchy, you have to have ‘soft’ skills to survive. The ability to work with others is not only important, it has also increased.

Hence the Social Meeting exercise in 448.

Conceptual skills have become increasingly critical according to Rowley. “As organizations face a coronavirus contagion, it is exactly these skills---conceptual and human---that will be ever more important for effective leadership and then managing the difficult and tricky changes needed regarding work.” It is exactly what you and I are doing together in our fishbowls...conceptual and human skills. We’ve never felt so closely before! Please see Caroline Morganelli’s post below.

Sanjiv

CONCEPTUAL, HUMAN, SKILL, HIERARCHY, LEVEL

from the fishbowl...

carolinemorganelli

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 8:25 am

Contact: Contact carolinemorganelli

Re: Caroline Morganelli: Letters

 Wed Mar 04, 2020 8:38 pm

RE: "facing a new complex structure" (443 & 448)

Entering the semester I was very nervous about using the fishbowl. It is a very complex new structure of communication I am unfamiliar with. I would not say that I was scared, I would more so say I was nervous for the adjustment of this "always online" platform of knowledge sharing. As of now I feel as though I am adjusting. The key in my opinion is to make sure that you do not fall behind. Taking the time to understand something takes work, but without time and effort one will not be able to retain information and then later pass it on to others.

Solving or understanding complex structures takes time and an understanding of organization. To fully understand we must understand how this complex structure works, functions and its organizational method. By understanding this we will be use the knowledge gained from here to advance to the other complex structures in our lives.

complex: consisting of many different and connected parts.

structure: the arrangement of and relations between the parts or elements of something complex.

Complex Structure: a multi-faced arrangement of and relations between parts or elements.

Date: 3/5/2020 0:04:44
Subject: &quot;facing a new complex structure&quot; (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Brady,

Just to let you know, when I read your posting below, my reaction is that it is an honest expression of feelings and experience. It shows your courage, something which the Irish are famous. To take your reflection further and create value is a word-game and you make-up the rules as you proceed and, later talk about them. I would deconstruct “complex structure” and see where it takes your feelings, expression and experience. Give it a shot, and don’t give a thought to the outcome; it’s the play that matters. You are free to show me a hard copy. Google search the term. Research the concept “complex structures” and understand their meaning in a new way.

Best wishes,

Sanjiv

COMPLEX, STRUCTURE

letter responses

Wed Mar 04, 2020 11:39 am

Personal empowerment

At the begging of the course i felt weak and confused as to how i should approach the letters and structure of the class. I felt i had no control and was powerless because i was facing a new complex structure i have never been a part of before. Over the last few weeks i felt i had more personal power because i have been taking more action to reading the letters of others and adapting to the new situation i am a part of. To have personal power i have learned that i must look at every situation multiple ways and reshape how i view it. I learned that interacting with different students and trying to understand there cultures helped me also develop personal empowerment.

Re: Letters -Palumbo

Tue Mar 03, 2020 5:25 pm

Personal Empowerment

The fishbowl gives you power, or the capacity or ability to direct/influence the behavior of others or the course of events. We have power to influence one another with our words and reflections and teach one another new things. How incredible is it that words have so much power, the world revolves around words. It empowers me, or makes me feel stronger and more confident, when I am able to reflect on personal experiences that are near and dear to my heart. It makes me feel motivated to keep going with my posts, and that this will all pay off in the end. It can be intimidating sometimes to share experiences personal to you with classmates that are going to read it, but it also gives you a sense of achievement that you are infusing your own experiences to create knowledge in the world. We are all sharing our experiences together through the fishbowl, we are all being somewhat vulnerable for knowledge. As Sanjiv said, our reflections are reshaping the world around us, making it our own, and paving the way for our generation and the future as well. "We have all probably experienced situations where we have tried to act a new reality only to find the process reversed by deep structures of power over our lives." - reflecting on situations like these equip us for better handling them in the future and propelling ourselves forward. Breaking through these structures starts with the way we think and our ability to recognize how we feel. We will only gain more information and confidence to break through structures through the fishbowl postings, our groups, and Sanjiv.

Hi Amiel,

In the fishbowl, you assume your personal power by rethinking and reshaping the world around you. Your posting is an excellent example of that.

We have all probably experienced situations where we have tried to act a new reality only to find the process reversed by deep structures of power over our lives.

That’s why we have to bring it all back down to the level of the individual and individual capacities for change---for change is an individual affair! Individuals can form groups, and groups can become social movements. But the process begins and ends with the commitments and actions of individuals.

Best,

Sanjiv

Amiel

Posts: 64

Joined: Sat Jan 25, 2020 7:55 pm

Contact: Contact Amiel

Re: ABSTRACT DEVELOPMENT

Mon Mar 02, 2020 3:13 pm

#37

"A way of explaining a feeling about someone" and "People living together forming new ideas". This is the path to abstract development. The "Hermeneutic Perspective" of Gadamer is "A way of explaining a feeling about someone". The "Social Imaginary" of Charles Taylor is "People living together forming new ideas". We are approaching the point in time where we must let people know how we feel. We must live together before we can form new ideas. There is no "I" in the Fisbowl there is only "Us". We are learning to develop unity and cohesion among those who live with in the "Fishbowl". There is too much silence among us and why is that? We must interact amongst each other. The fishbowl has no hierarchy we are all equal, there is no barriers between us. We are all in the fishbowl together and once we begin to feel for one another we will create a social sharing of knowledge and information. Alone one can not form new ideas, it is the people living and interacting together that will form new transformational ideas. For example the day that I walked into my first shift of my first job I was terrified. I was hired at Domino's Pizza in Riverside, Rhode Island to be a pizza delivery boy. Like most high school students we didn't know a whole lot about what it really meant to work a long shift all we really knew was that we wanted money to buy things. I was surrounded by an unfamiliar atmosphere one that I had not previously known. I was thankfully guided by the Store Manager at the time he was young and quite friendly and we could relate pretty well. As I began to familiarize myself with the routine over the first weeks I began to realize that I really didn't like the work I was doing but I knew I needed cash for a new car. I wasn't to familiar with my co-workers and I honestly didn't know much about them and they didn't know much more about me other than my name. I began to feel a sense of loneliness. I simply felt I was only there to do my job as the mechanistic organization would want. I knew I wanted to change the way I felt and as I began to make myself familiar and safe within my surroundings I eventually became more and more curious. I had reached the moment in which I wanted to create understanding amongst those I would be interacting with in the "Fishbowl" so I began asking questions and opening up to those who where around me. I began to gain a sense of understanding while at the same time learning some valuable tips that would help me succeed. The more we began to explain to each other how we felt the more we had bonded and unionized. Eventually we where so familiar with ourselves after two months everything became so effortless. We had changed the way we worked after the time we spent living together. We had become such a close group of people from different backgrounds and different ways of life. We were all brought together by a common goal. Like the great President Abraham Lincoln once said "A house divided can not stand". The "house" in other words the "fishbowl" cannot be divided. The responsibility amongst us now is create this sense of unity, secureness, and familiarity so we can begin constructing new ideas together with the digital benefits that surround us in today's business world.

Re: Reflections:

 Wed Feb 26, 2020 3:38 pm

Participation is power:

"Participation is power." The action of taking part in something is the ability to influence the behavior of events. Involvement is potential. Contributing is ability. Engagement is a capability. Being involved, engaged, participating, or contributing to a group or class is to actively engage and listen. Without engagement and participation, you won't get anything out of it. There is no point in coming to class if you're not going to pay attention and participate. When you add to the conversation you learn more and help your classmates learn more. Your teacher can even learn from what you have to say. In class, I am very quite. It is hard for me to speak out loud and add to the conversation. I am always actively listening during class. I try to remind myself that I will learn more and other students will learn more if more people participate.

Andreasullivan

Posts: 94

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 11:58 am

Contact: Contact Andreasullivan

Re: Reflections:

Wed Feb 26, 2020 10:42 pm

Creating mental spaces:

"Opportunity to do nothing." A set of circumstances that makes it possible to do no single thing. The chance to do not a thing. The possibility of nothing at all. It is rare in today's world that we have a second of nothing. Even when we have downtime there is a constant distraction of social media. We have an expectation to be entertained at all time because of our phones. The opportunity to do nothing is actually in our hands. When I have a busy day, I can't wait to go home, relax, and "do nothing." But I often just end up sitting on my phone or watching tv. I should take advantage of opportunities to do nothing and check-in with myself.

Reading and writing:

"Generating yourself." To cause something to arise or come about on a personal level. To make or produce something for you personally. To create a personal emotion or situation. In the fishbowl, we use reading and writing text to remember memories and experiences that have meaning. We are infusing personal meaning into the text to create a "living text."

Andreasullivan

Posts: 94

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 11:58 am

Contact: Contact Andreasullivan

Re: Reflections:

Thu Feb 27, 2020 12:27 am

Love/Leadership:

"To teach is to learn." To show or explain to something how to do something is to gain or acquire knowledge of or skill in something. To educate is to master something. To instruct is to be competent in something. To prepare someone else is you must first grasp and absorb the information before digesting it back out. You must truly know a topic to be able to teach other people. By explaining the information is also engrained into your mind even more. You can learn from the people that your teaching. By the question they ask and the new ideas they get from learning the subject. I find that when I'm studying, my final test to see if I have mastered the information is if I can teach the information to someone else. If I can comprehend the information enough to clearly explain it to someone else.

Andreasullivan

Posts: 94

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 11:58 am

Contact: Contact Andreasullivan

Re: Reflections:

Thu Feb 27, 2020 12:54 am

Conference Abstract: Creative critical writing:

"Demolishing structure." To comprehensively knockdown, refute, or defeat a construct or arrange according to a plan. To destroy a composition. To put an end to the formation. To bring down a system. Then once it is broken down we can "rebuild them our way." The goal is to build a structure again after it has been damaged or destroyed. Some structures and organizations don't function well to create results or progress. These structures need to be rebuilt. I often reflect on why we are doing all this fishbowl "stuff." What is the big picture? What is the end goal? We are learning to think differently. To think outside the box. To take our brain filled with new knowledge to bring change to companies. We aren't destroying the companies we are rebuilding the organization.

Andreasullivan

Posts: 94

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 11:58 am

Contact: Contact Andreasullivan

Re: Reflections:

Sat Feb 29, 2020 3:05 pm

Dialogues of space:

"Unique understanding." The ability to understand something unlike anything else. Individual interpretation. Distinctive comprehension. Unusual perception. Everyone has a different way of thinking. We all have different opinions. It is important to remember that everyone grew up different from different views and beliefs. With different experiences and views, everything understands things differently. If we all had the same thoughts we would be stuck with nothing new. It is different perceptions, interpretations, and understandings that create new ideas that think out of the box. When I compare my work to other people's work I worry that mine is different. I worry that mine is wrong and theirs is better. I must remember that we all think and understand differently.

Andreasullivan

Posts: 94

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 11:58 am

Contact: Contact Andreasullivan

Re: Reflections:

Mon Mar 02, 2020 5:28 pm

Creating value by sharing felt-experiences:

"Connect with them." To bring together or into contact so that a real or notional link is established with someone or something. To create a link to something. To form a bond with someone. To find a connection is to find meaning. It means nothing unless we make it personal. Find a personal connection, link, or bond to ourselves. Connections drive us. They give us purpose. These connections are what will make us different. I worked at a café during the summer a couple of years ago. It was supposed to be an easy job to make money during the summer. I would go to do what I need to do and leave. Then I got close to my boss. She reminded me of my grandma who also owns a restaurant in Pennsylvania. Then I started to care. I wanted to do my best for her and for her business. What I made the connection and created meaning I cared and worked harder because of it.

Andreasullivan

Posts: 94

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 11:58 am

Contact: Contact Andreasullivan

Re: Reflections:

 Mon Mar 02, 2020 10:41 pm

Intersections and animations:

"Creative expression." The process of making known one's thoughts or feeling relating to or involving the imagination or original ideas. Innovative communication. Experimental articulation. Unconventional demonstration. It's not how you express yourself its that you find a way to express yourself. Whether it's for work or for fun it is important. Growing up I was always very creative. When I got to college and it became work. I shut down my creativity from the pressure. I learned how to express myself creatively in other ways. I learned to separate work and pleasure.

Date: 2/26/2020 0:47:14
Subject: metaphors (443)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

We are leaving the age of organized organizations (rigid structures; rules and regulations and requirements and standards) and moving into an era were the ability to understand, facilitate, and encourage processes of self-organization will become a key competence. 

It is impossible to develop new styles (concepts) of organization and structures, like your fishbowls, while continuing to think in old ways. Your fishbowl, its organization, its design, its image has no presence beyond that of the people who bring it to life. We might not be able to create a "learning organization" (please google Peter Senge, The Fifth Discipline), but you can enhance people’s capacities to learn and align their activities in creative ways. It is what one is seeing you do in your fishbowls. Please fact check.

Ideas about organizations are always based on implicit images or metaphors that persuade us to see, understand, and manage situations in a particular way. Please think of Strictly Ballroom and the machine as a metaphor. Indeed, think of your own situation and its metaphor.

It is an important point that Lea Janz makes below: ...”questions allow us a better understanding of concepts.” (Janz, Lea. Fishbowl Spr2020)

In BUS443: Organizational Design and Change, the challenge facing you is to become accomplished in the art of using metaphor to find new ways of seeing, understanding, and shaping your actions. Your final Design, three pages, double-spaced and submitted jointly as a group, will be testimony of your fishbowl’s metaphor. Design shapes our actions, behaviors and felt-experiences as we clearly saw in Strictly Ballroom. “Stop that shuffling, you stupid man,” she said. "I'm bored with you."

Sanjiv

ORGANIZATION, SHAPE, ACTION, IMAGE, IMPLICIT, DESIGN

from the fishbowl...

leajanz

Posts: 77

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 11:04 am

Contact: Contact leajanz

Re: Reflections-Lea Janz

 Tue Feb 25, 2020 3:47 pm

power in questions

Andrew’s postings awakened my mind. One in particular mentioned his creative process, “let my instincts take over and just let my thoughts flood onto the paper and let my inner self be the passenger in triggering the thoughts and creativity in my head”. I have found this to be the only way to generate text in a structureless scene. To let the mind wander is to discover new pathways. I can relate to Andrew’s method, but am inspired by his use of questions. “I am practicing putting my thoughts into questions. Am I doing this to help trigger an audience or is this a different way of letting my mind roam free and spark thoughts?”. Our “culture” (student-life, college) may have desensitized us to the power of a question, as we are hassled by them on a daily basis. The thought of asking them may seem silly, but questions allow us a better understanding of concepts. Also, asking questions never leaves a conversation boring. Questions keep the mind ticking, or keep the thread. So, at that, why is collaboration the key to deeper creative thinking? I believe I just answered that by the sentences above.

Re: Letter Interpretations

Tue Feb 18, 2020 11:45 am

CONNECTING ACROSS CULTURES WHENEVER WE ALLOW OURSELVES

When we create meaning for ourselves in our fishbowls, we are also creating meaning for other people.

How our attitudes affect those other people is completely up to us. We are the only ones that can allow ourselves to have either a positive attitude that helps other people grow or a negative attitude that strips away other people's experiences. Our attitudes can be very present in the way we write. If we have a positive attitude, it will be evident in the words we use to symbolize other things, and the tone of our expressions will have positive connotations; however, if we have a negative attitude, this will be present in the impact our writings may have on the other members in our groups. Self reflection is especially mirrored in the way we choose to display our expressions. The way we reflect on our interiors sets the tone and feeling in the way we choose to format our writings and the words we choose to use.

How do you go global in a textual world? By learning to be able to scratch under the layer of phrases and be able to create your own interpretations. In doing so, we put our way of thinking out there for other people to see. By writing in abstract ways, we show that there is more to writing than just the fine print letters. One word alone can have endless amounts of invisible connections, it is all about how we ourselves choose to read and interpret them.

Date: 2/25/2020 14:55:02
Subject: cultural awareness: separating observation from interpretation (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

You and I are at the opposite end of the generation spectrum, and we are tied at the waist. You could say we are intertwined, like a knitted sweater. You see that clearly in the films we are watching, but particularly in Strictly Ballroom (443). It is so in Japanese Story (448) as well. Culture is passed down and learnt. Osmosis is a good word to describe it, metaphorically speaking. We see that in the relationship between Sandy and her mother. Indeed, the film opens with their interaction. 

SPECTRUM, DIMENSION, OPPOSITE, GENERATION, INTERTWINE

I find this observation about Sandy and her Mother very interesting. Why did the film Japanese Story (448) open with Sandy’s Mother and her “silly” book of cuttings? What does it have to do with anything? What does it mean? That’s the real question. What does it mean?

Finding by OBSERVATION is the first step in a search for meaning; a journey or foray into the unknown.

The first step is ventured (risked) by you as your ’selected’ word. You must always pause before any selection, because that is where its trajectory will take you. I took two years before I selected the word-image: Jeep Renegade. Bottom line is observe and select.

The second step is INTERPRETATION. Not just What do you see (in the words Jeep Renegade), but also How do you see it; how come? 

All she (Nicola in Kinky Boots) wanted was a Mercedez, Sanjiv, and she couldn't change that. "She could not change what she wants."

Now, that’s an observation, but how would you interpret it? What meaning do you “attribute” to it. What are Nicola’s intentions?

ATTRIBUTE, INTENTION, BEHAVIOR

So there you have it. Observation and Interpretation. The core of "cultural awareness" is learning to separate Observation from Interpretation (Hofstede). The reason you are developing skills in doing so is because you want to suspend any attribution of meaning (interpretation), until you know more about the other person through observation. Where are they coming from? What is their schtick? What is their intention? 

The usual reaction is to forget actual behavior (facts) and attribute intentions to the behavior. Our attributions are culturally biased and constitute barriers to connecting. More on this to come.

Observe the Other’s behavior, but suspend meaning. When we don’t hold-off attributing meaning, we create impediments for ourselves and work-life becomes difficult.

In 448 we are on the subject of culture, and we are developing an awareness of it. We are watching Kinky Boots and observing Charlie Price and Lola at two ends of the spectrum, joined at the hip, and trying to survive.

There is much at stake for all of us.

Sanjiv

Hi Everyone,

There will always be those of us who are 'flying by the seat of our pants’ and, forever running late with daily catastrophes hitting us, like meteors and drones.

These metaphors describe feelings. Felt-experiences in the physical body. 

It follows that if you change your metaphors, you can change your felt-experiences. 

How so?

It is about the art of framing and reframing. Please google Frame Analysis by Erving Goffman.

In your fishbowls, you are to use images, metaphors, readings, and story lines to cast situations in new perspective and open possibilities for "creative action.”

I like the metaphor of a “sniper.” I think I operate like one. Please don’t confuse me with “navel gazing” or solipsism.

Every posting that you are making in your fishbowls, however mundane and banal they might appear to you, is "creative action." People and organizations (in Strictly Ballroom for instance) tend to get trapped by the images that they hold of themselves and genuine change requires an ability to see and challenge these self-images in some way.

The above feelings show how images and metaphors can be used as “mirrors” through which people and groups can see themselves and their situations in fresh light, creating an opportunity for reflection and change. If one can look in the mirror and see oneself in a new way, the mirror can become a “window,” because it allows one to see the rest of the world with a fresh perspective. This is the job of a budding Designer like yourselves. Or, in terms of the imagery introduced earlier, your design will open new “horizons,” creating opportunities for new actions.

Hang in there. You will soon be taking creative actions to form your design. At this stage you are catching up on concepts and vocabulary. These are your building blocks. You are polishing your tools and laying them out for others to see: all images and metaphors!

Sanjiv

Immaterial labor, cybernetics, metaphor and symbolism

Mon Feb 10, 2020 1:54 pm

Immaterial labor describes how value is created from cognitive and affective activities. This means the value that comes from words or thoughts communicated by the members of the company. Immaterial labor is often associated with the technology industry in which software, coding, etc. are not material you can hold and it is not "real", in a sense. As you stated, the world is moving more and more towards the utilization of immaterial labor because most companies are not industrial and most industries are online. Being able to communicate and build an immaterial structure is an essential skill to have.

Cybernetics is the science of communication. Although cybernetics has been around since the beginning of civilization, science is taking on a new course in Artificial Intelligence. It is interesting that AI is building up a system of cybernetics within a machine. Is it even possible to do that when we haven't even fully understood the cybernetics within a living thing such as a human being? Have we fully grasped the consciousness and communication systems within humans? Does cybernetics involve decision-making processes within people? If we are learning how to hone these skills and master language and communication, won't these skills be pointless if Artificial Intelligence has fully developed these skills? Will AI ever be able to fully develop cybernetics?

You- used to refer to the person or people the speaker is referring to

are- addressing someone as something else

on- physically in contact with and supported by something else

your- belonging to or associated with the person the speaker is addressing

way- a method, style, or manner of doing something

to- expressing motion in the direction of something

becoming- grow to be, turn into

a- used to refer to someone or something

phenomenologist- a scientist of phenomena as distinct from that as the nature of being, an approach that concentrates on the study of consciousness and the object of direct experience

and- used to connect words of the same concept

a - used to refer to someone or something

social- relating to its society or organization

constructivist- a practitioner of a style in which mechanical objects are combined into abstract mobile forms

Knowledge work

Thu Feb 13, 2020 12:26 pm

The knowledge economy is an economy in which growth is dependent on the quantity, quality, and accessibility of the information available, rather than the means of production. The fishbowl is a great example of a knowledge economy as everyone in the class is a worker within the economy. The work we put into the fishbowl expands the base of information and knowledge available to the rest of the class. The interesting thing about the fishbowl is that knowledge and information can keep growing and expanding forever. Or can it? Isn't a fishbowl finite and limited to the bowl itself? How can our ecosystem of knowledge and information within the fishbowl keep growing forever? I thought nothing lasts forever? Regardless, everyone has the power to contribute to the knowledge economy. That's a special skill that all humans have! I am starting to realize that Sanjiv is trying to communicate to his students that they all have this skill and should be proud to use it. I admire Sanjiv's appreciation for the knowledge economy and its infinite possibilities. This is the best way to learn because the information is power and the goal of this course is developing information.

The knowledge (facts, information, and skills acquired by a person through experience or education, the theoretical or practical understanding of a subject) economy (the wealth of a country or region, especially in terms of production and consumption of goods and services) requires work from the knowledge workers, in order to grow. This work can be identified as immaterial labor. We are producing something without actually producing something. Immaterial labor is the knowledge we are creating and the information being put into the fishbowl. By just looking at the words, 'relational thinking in sociology' and 'cultural capital', it is clear why the concepts can be juxtaposed. Is the growth of the knowledge economy dependent on the people surrounding us? Does the knowledge we produce depend on where we grew up and what our backgrounds are? Depending on where someone grew up, does everyone have different amount of cultural capital? Or does everyone have the same amount of cultural capital, it just appears differently to the rest of us? Does everyone need a third-party or a teacher to summon the knowledge and information within us to provide the ability to share and contribute to the knowledge economy? Why or how isn't there a way to make everyone comfortable enough to share the knowledge and information they possess? Is it even possible to do that or is time and patience the only answer to that issue? Is the fishbowl our best answer to these problems?

Relational (concerning the way in which two or more people or things are connected) thinking (the process of using one's mind to consider or reason about something) in (expressing the situation of something that is or appears to be enclosed or surrounded by something else) sociology (the study of the development, structure, and function of human society; the study of social problems). I saw a graphic that visually represented the concept of relational thinking in sociology. In the middle, or in the core, it said "Ideational (relating to the formation of ideas or concepts) Core (the central or more important part of something) of (expressing the relationship between a part and a whole) Relational (concerning the way in which two or more things are connected) Thinking (the process of using one's mind to consider or reason about something)" and surrounding the core were the concepts "Rejection (dismissing or refusing an idea, proposal, etc.) of Modern (relating to the present or recent times as opposed to remote past) Dualisms (The division of something conceptually into two opposed or contrasted aspects, or the state of being so divided)", "Principle (a fundamental truth or proposition that serves as the foundation for a system of belief or behavior or for a chain of reasoning) of Processual (Relating to or involving the study of processes rather than discrete events) Thinking", "Rejection of Substances (the quality of being important, valid, or significant)", "Principle of Interdependency (the dependence of two or more things on each other)", and "Principle of Co-Production (the act of creating something with another person)". Does this relate to the constant reflection we should be aspiring to achieve? In order to maximize relational thinking in sociology, do we have to ignore the divisions and differences among us and unite?

My Creative Process

Sun Feb 16, 2020 3:07 pm

Something I have been practicing in this course is asking questions. In the past, especially when writing, I would let my instincts take over and just let my thoughts flood onto the paper and let my inner self be the passenger in triggering the thoughts and creativity in my head. Although I still do that, instead of constructing opinions and putting together statements, I am practicing putting my thoughts into questions. Am I doing this to help trigger an audience or is this a different way of letting my mind roam free and spark thoughts?

I can define my thoughts as being on two different levels. On one level, I will focus on the big picture and focus my decisions on how it may affect me down the road. These thoughts are much more limited to staying inside my head and are unlikely to be communicated to anyone but myself. In this thought process, I let my mind freeflow but I try to control it in a way that I try to follow one message or mission and let my thoughts revolve around whatever that is. For example, when defining vocabulary, I will define the vocabulary and that definition acts as a core for where my brain decides to journey. In this scenario, my brain will typically trigger memories or personal stories that somehow relate to the core. At this point, it is up to me to communicate these thoughts, but in this course, it is apparent that I need to communicate in order to be successful.

On another level, I limit my thoughts and let my instincts take over. This thought process is much more apparent when I am communicating with others whether through voice or text. For example, when I write out one sentence or say something, another thing may pop up inside my head and this process formulates another chain of thoughts inside my head. I think the difference between the two thought processes is that one has a core and the doesn't.

Like I said before, this thought process has been apparent in this course and I am phrasing a lot of it in the form of questions. When writing this post, I was originally putting together vocabulary for the valentine symbol letter but my brain wanted to explore my creative thought process so I trusted my instinct and let my thoughts roll out into the fishbowl. To others, it may look like ranting but it is an interesting feeling to communicate and bring your thoughts into the world rather than just keep them within your head. I sincerely admire the fishbowl for this reason. The fishbowl provides the environment for students to open the floodgates within their brains and just let thoughts roll out, regardless if they are right or wrong. Not only that, this is a much better concept than opening the classroom for discussion because I don't think the results would be the same as many students, including myself, would be more insecure about sharing thoughts vocally with the rest of the class, rather than through text in the fishbowl. Although this is a small sample of my daily thought process but is this how all people or people my age think or does everyone have their own unique creative thought process?

I am inspired by Lea's post in the fishbowl about her creative process and her inspiration of the late Mac Miller. This makes me realize that my creative process is impacted by my surroundings, environment, and culture. By reading about her creative process, it helps me realize some parts of my creative process that I didn't even know about. For example, when she describes a situation when she is having trouble with bringing an image in her head and making it a reality, she gets frustrated and it takes a minute for her to realize nothing is perfect because it's perfect. It's perfect because she made it and it is coming from her own creative, singular thought. This makes me think about how my creative process is impacted by my surroundings and it is important to be open and absorb as much information and knowledge around you as you can because although no one is perfect, as a whole, we are perfect and by being honest in the fishbowl about ourselves plays a part within a larger entity of changing and growing as people. The fishbowl is the way to learn from each other, thus learn more about ourselves, and go from there.

Know, make, discover

Sun Feb 16, 2020 3:40 pm

"Just play around, do not be afraid, and give yourself time." Lea's inclusion of Mac Miller inspired me to learn more about someone who was able to influence so many and the thought process of millions, Albert Einstein.

Einstein changed the way that people look and travel around the world and the universe as a whole. One of the things that Einstein did was take a daily music break and play his violin. This deep dive into a musical endeavor was one of the ways creativity was sparked in Einstein's brain. Does this mean that his best ideas were triggered when we were dedicating time to something that is a true, passionate interest of his? Is this break from professional work essential to excelling intellectual thought? Including play into your routine allows your brain to bridge different realms (such as music, art, reading) and those connections spark new ideas. Finding your deepest desires and spending time with all of them is essential to growing as people. Another concept that caught my eye about Einstein's creative process was that creativity can't be summoned and most of it is random. Although reflection and stepping back is important, but it is even more important to mix processes like that with committed work time. Although thoughts spark randomly, the sequential pattern of life between work and play is vital to creative processes. For Einstein, most of his creative thoughts were triggered when he spent time with his violin. The time spent learning and examining physics would not be nearly as impactful without reflection time. It is that mix that made Einstein one of the most creative and influential people in history.

Group Dynamics

Wed Feb 19, 2020 11:27 am

Group dynamics are used for understanding decision-making behavior and are a system of behaviors and psychological processes within social groups. They also concern how groups are formed, their structure and process, and how they function.

The fishbowl is a great place to study group dynamics. We are able to witness how are class functions as a group and how we respond to each other and ultimately creatively think. It is clear that we are only fooling ourselves if we believe that everyone learns and communicates like everyone else. That is not the case and the fishbowl is a great place to observe the different ways students process information and communicate personal connections to concepts brought forth in the course. By taking a step back and looking at the group as a whole, you are not only able to understand the group as a whole better but you are also able to discover the different bright spots throughout the group where students are thriving and learning quickly but you can also see the darker spots where students may be struggling with the learning process. It is important to study group dynamics to fully understand yourself.

Reading and Writing

Fri Feb 21, 2020 1:08 pm

Social constructionism is a theory of knowledge in sociology and communication theory that examines the development of jointly-constructed understandings of the world that form the basis for shared assumptions about reality.

Throughout my life so far, social constructionism has been a concept that I feel has been suppressed by my education. Classes have always revolved around the concept of "read, lecture, test, repeat", with no room for social constructionism. Not only does this concept limit my learning in which the information I have learned through this message goes in one ear and out the other, but it upsetting to think about why so many educators use this model.

This is why I admire the fishbowl. It is a place that fosters collaboration and learning from one another based on metaphors and designs we all create. Through the fishbowl, we are able to assemble our thoughts and create a bridge between the dictionary and our felt-experiences, as you said. I sense that the dictionary is the most unbiased piece of literature ever created. Doesn't this mean that a dictionary is the only piece of literature every single person has the ability to learn from? Rather than concepts that someone else created and limit the ability of others to intuitively think and deconstruct those concepts.

Love/leadership

Sun Feb 23, 2020 2:56 pm

In Praise of Love is about Alan Badiou's theory that love is under threat. He believes that love is an existential project and a constantly unfolding quest for truth. The quest begins with the chance encounter, an event that forever changes the two individuals, challenging them "to see the world from the point of view of two rather than one." This, Badiou believes is love's most essential transfiguration. The story urges readers to see love as an adventure rather than fear it as well as see it as a magnificent quest that compels us to otherness and difference, ultimately leading us away from an obsession with the self.

What about the morning's headlines made you despair (the complete loss or absence of hope) and groan (a deep inarticulate sound made in pain or despair)? Why should people ever be in despair and groan? As long as you are living and breathing, what is there to be upset about?

"There is nothing your fishbowl can't do together." All members of the fishbowl have the same opportunity to share reflections and love. Why is easier for some people to share the love and felt-experiences? In reality, there is no such thing as a free lunch. However, the one thing that is truly free is a smile. Every person has the ability to share the love and give someone a smile, but why is it that most people don't? It's so easy, personal, and takes no thoughts behind it! Anyone can be a leader if they want, so what is it that drives the people that actually follow through on their aspirations?

Subject: intersections and animations (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

The subject of the Fishbowl is the writing of (two) provocative thinkers and, especially, the diverse ways in which their thought is intertwined and enfolded through their collaboration. Please see Andrew Bikash’s postings below.

The courses (443 & 448) ostensible goal is to provide an initial orientation to such collaboration. Your fishbowls necessarily are a creative expression of your own angle of approach in reading. Your reflection develops in connection with work that other participants and interlocutors are elaborating in the fishbowl, and, indeed, you continue to express daily in ongoing interchange. You derive these intersections and animations predominantly from vocabulary and others' works (through your selections and interpretations), written together in your fishbowls in productive collaboration.

Sanjiv

Immaterial labor, cybernetics, metaphor and symbolism

Mon Feb 10, 2020 1:54 pm

Immaterial labor describes how value is created from cognitive and affective activities. This means the value that comes from words or thoughts communicated by the members of the company. Immaterial labor is often associated with the technology industry in which software, coding, etc. are not material you can hold and it is not "real", in a sense. As you stated, the world is moving more and more towards the utilization of immaterial labor because most companies are not industrial and most industries are online. Being able to communicate and build an immaterial structure is an essential skill to have.

Cybernetics is the science of communication. Although cybernetics has been around since the beginning of civilization, science is taking on a new course in Artificial Intelligence. It is interesting that AI is building up a system of cybernetics within a machine. Is it even possible to do that when we haven't even fully understood the cybernetics within a living thing such as a human being? Have we fully grasped the consciousness and communication systems within humans? Does cybernetics involve decision-making processes within people? If we are learning how to hone these skills and master language and communication, won't these skills be pointless if Artificial Intelligence has fully developed these skills? Will AI ever be able to fully develop cybernetics?

andrewbikash

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 11:03 am

Constructing a knowing

Mon Feb 10, 2020 3:57 pm

Vertiginous change= unstable and quick differentiation

primitive ape-brains= foundation stage of how human beings process things

distorting filter of the internet= the online world is an illusion with infinitely different perspectives, it is almost impossible to figure out what is right and wrong

However, it made me happy to read that he has the same viewpoint on the internet as I do. The internet truly is a mess and it is extremely difficult to find 100% unbiased and accurate information on the world-wide-web.

Abstractions

Wed Feb 12, 2020 1:52 pm

In today's class, we looked at abstracts that put different ideas and concepts into visual form. Although this was an intriguing concept, it would have been cool to spend a little more time on certain images, unless the point of the exercise was to quickly get an idea of what abstracts can look like, how they are all different, and that it is up to us as students and knowledge-gainers to interpret the meanings of such works. One of the pictures that caught my eye was the one with books giving people a height advantage. This gave me an easy-to-understand visual representation of the fact that with books, comes knowledge, and with knowledge, comes power!

This class seemed to loop right into the idea of phenomena and concepts. Although everything takes different forms, everything has its own unique meaning it is essential to give the time to understand the meaning of all things around you, especially specific words and images. I enjoy looking at pieces of abstract and art because it provides a window into what people are thinking and how they think. By understanding these concepts and adapting them as your own, you can only become more intelligent! However, it takes time and patience to master this skill. I am eager to continue developing!

As MSwalsh said, it is important to slow down and interpret the meanings of the little things, especially specific words and ideas. As he swims to slow time down and reflect, I like to sail and rock climb to slow down time and reflect on my life.

You- used to refer to the person or people the speaker is referring to

are- addressing someone as something else

on- physically in contact with and supported by something else

your- belonging to or associated with the person the speaker is addressing

way- a method, style, or manner of doing something

to- expressing motion in the direction of something

becoming- grow to be, turn into

a- used to refer to someone or something

phenomenologist- a scientist of phenomena as distinct from that as the nature of being, an approach that concentrates on the study of consciousness and the object of direct experience

and- used to connect words of the same concept

a - used to refer to someone or something

social- relating to its society or organization

constructivist- a practitioner of a style in which mechanical objects are combined into abstract mobile forms

Knowledge work

Thu Feb 13, 2020 12:26 pm

The knowledge economy is an economy in which growth is dependent on the quantity, quality, and accessibility of the information available, rather than the means of production. The fishbowl is a great example of a knowledge economy as everyone in the class is a worker within the economy. The work we put into the fishbowl expands the base of information and knowledge available to the rest of the class. The interesting thing about the fishbowl is that knowledge and information can keep growing and expanding forever. Or can it? Isn't a fishbowl finite and limited to the bowl itself? How can our ecosystem of knowledge and information within the fishbowl keep growing forever? I thought nothing lasts forever? Regardless, everyone has the power to contribute to the knowledge economy. That's a special skill that all humans have! I am starting to realize that Sanjiv is trying to communicate to his students that they all have this skill and should be proud to use it. I admire Sanjiv's appreciation for the knowledge economy and its infinite possibilities. This is the best way to learn because the information is power and the goal of this course is developing information.

The knowledge (facts, information, and skills acquired by a person through experience or education, the theoretical or practical understanding of a subject) economy (the wealth of a country or region, especially in terms of production and consumption of goods and services) requires work from the knowledge workers, in order to grow. This work can be identified as immaterial labor. We are producing something without actually producing something. Immaterial labor is the knowledge we are creating and the information being put into the fishbowl. By just looking at the words, 'relational thinking in sociology' and 'cultural capital', it is clear why the concepts can be juxtaposed. Is the growth of the knowledge economy dependent on the people surrounding us? Does the knowledge we produce depend on where we grew up and what our backgrounds are? Depending on where someone grew up, does everyone have different amount of cultural capital? Or does everyone have the same amount of cultural capital, it just appears differently to the rest of us? Does everyone need a third-party or a teacher to summon the knowledge and information within us to provide the ability to share and contribute to the knowledge economy? Why or how isn't there a way to make everyone comfortable enough to share the knowledge and information they possess? Is it even possible to do that or is time and patience the only answer to that issue? Is the fishbowl our best answer to these problems?

Relational (concerning the way in which two or more people or things are connected) thinking (the process of using one's mind to consider or reason about something) in (expressing the situation of something that is or appears to be enclosed or surrounded by something else) sociology (the study of the development, structure, and function of human society; the study of social problems). I saw a graphic that visually represented the concept of relational thinking in sociology. In the middle, or in the core, it said "Ideational (relating to the formation of ideas or concepts) Core (the central or more important part of something) of (expressing the relationship between a part and a whole) Relational (concerning the way in which two or more things are connected) Thinking (the process of using one's mind to consider or reason about something)" and surrounding the core were the concepts "Rejection (dismissing or refusing an idea, proposal, etc.) of Modern (relating to the present or recent times as opposed to remote past) Dualisms (The division of something conceptually into two opposed or contrasted aspects, or the state of being so divided)", "Principle (a fundamental truth or proposition that serves as the foundation for a system of belief or behavior or for a chain of reasoning) of Processual (Relating to or involving the study of processes rather than discrete events) Thinking", "Rejection of Substances (the quality of being important, valid, or significant)", "Principle of Interdependency (the dependence of two or more things on each other)", and "Principle of Co-Production (the act of creating something with another person)". Does this relate to the constant reflection we should be aspiring to achieve? In order to maximize relational thinking in sociology, do we have to ignore the divisions and differences among us and unite?

Symbol

Sun Feb 16, 2020 2:15 pm

Looking at the meaning of Andrew, it is hard to believe that the choice of my name relates to any of the meanings, I think it goes deeper than that. Most of the meanings of the word itself are that it means strong man, brave, and manly. Although I can associate with these symbols, knowing my parents, it is hard to believe that they chose Andrew to be my name for the associated qualities and characteristics. I think any name, in general, represents strength and power. This is a symbol that everyone has and everyone should wear well and be proud of it.

I think in reality, Andrew just fit with my last name Bikash well and my parents happened to choose that name but maybe it goes deeper than that. Maybe Andrew represented a symbol of my parents' love or marriage in some way, maybe there was some event that triggered each of them to name me Andrew. At the same time though, I have two younger twin brothers named Adam and Alex so maybe the letter "A" played a role in the name choices but who knows!

However, in the spirit of Valentine's Day, over time love has been the most universal symbol among all humans and cultures. If symbols are a constant requirement of human nature, love is by far the most prevalent symbol. People of different cultures commonly share the love for things in society. Sports are a great example. Sports unify the world because it is the one way to bring together everyone's individual love for their team or country. Everyone's country or team represents something personal for people because it simply represents where you are from, a commonality among all people, and who doesn't love their home? Sports are a great way to show pride and love and share it with others. A championship always brings a parade to their respective cities which shows the unification and common love among millions of people. Love is the easiest way to bring about happiness throughout the human race. Does this mean the meaning of life is to just love one another and simply enjoy the moment? Is this the way to unify everyone under one common symbol?

My Creative Process

Sun Feb 16, 2020 3:07 pm

Something I have been practicing in this course is asking questions. In the past, especially when writing, I would let my instincts take over and just let my thoughts flood onto the paper and let my inner self be the passenger in triggering the thoughts and creativity in my head. Although I still do that, instead of constructing opinions and putting together statements, I am practicing putting my thoughts into questions. Am I doing this to help trigger an audience or is this a different way of letting my mind roam free and spark thoughts?

I can define my thoughts as being on two different levels. On one level, I will focus on the big picture and focus my decisions on how it may affect me down the road. These thoughts are much more limited to staying inside my head and are unlikely to be communicated to anyone but myself. In this thought process, I let my mind freeflow but I try to control it in a way that I try to follow one message or mission and let my thoughts revolve around whatever that is. For example, when defining vocabulary, I will define the vocabulary and that definition acts as a core for where my brain decides to journey. In this scenario, my brain will typically trigger memories or personal stories that somehow relate to the core. At this point, it is up to me to communicate these thoughts, but in this course, it is apparent that I need to communicate in order to be successful.

On another level, I limit my thoughts and let my instincts take over. This thought process is much more apparent when I am communicating with others whether through voice or text. For example, when I write out one sentence or say something, another thing may pop up inside my head and this process formulates another chain of thoughts inside my head. I think the difference between the two thought processes is that one has a core and the doesn't.

Like I said before, this thought process has been apparent in this course and I am phrasing a lot of it in the form of questions. When writing this post, I was originally putting together vocabulary for the valentine symbol letter but my brain wanted to explore my creative thought process so I trusted my instinct and let my thoughts roll out into the fishbowl. To others, it may look like ranting but it is an interesting feeling to communicate and bring your thoughts into the world rather than just keep them within your head. I sincerely admire the fishbowl for this reason. The fishbowl provides the environment for students to open the floodgates within their brains and just let thoughts roll out, regardless if they are right or wrong. Not only that, this is a much better concept than opening the classroom for discussion because I don't think the results would be the same as many students, including myself, would be more insecure about sharing thoughts vocally with the rest of the class, rather than through text in the fishbowl. Although this is a small sample of my daily thought process but is this how all people or people my age think or does everyone have their own unique creative thought process?

I am inspired by Lea's post in the fishbowl about her creative process and her inspiration of the late Mac Miller. This makes me realize that my creative process is impacted by my surroundings, environment, and culture. By reading about her creative process, it helps me realize some parts of my creative process that I didn't even know about. For example, when she describes a situation when she is having trouble with bringing an image in her head and making it a reality, she gets frustrated and it takes a minute for her to realize nothing is perfect because it's perfect. It's perfect because she made it and it is coming from her own creative, singular thought. This makes me think about how my creative process is impacted by my surroundings and it is important to be open and absorb as much information and knowledge around you as you can because although no one is perfect, as a whole, we are perfect and by being honest in the fishbowl about ourselves plays a part within a larger entity of changing and growing as people. The fishbowl is the way to learn from each other, thus learn more about ourselves, and go from there.

Know, make, discover

Sun Feb 16, 2020 3:40 pm

"Just play around, do not be afraid, and give yourself time." I admire this line from Lea not just because it is a universal thought process that anyone can incorporate, but the fact that it is the true way to learn, trial and error. If we only live once, why not do what you are feeling and experiment with different and learn about how you can grow and utilize your surroundings to do so? Lea's inclusion of Mac Miller inspired me to learn more about someone who was able to influence so many and the thought process of millions, Albert Einstein.

Einstein changed the way that people look and travel around the world and the universe as a whole. One of the things that Einstein did was take a daily music break and play his violin. This deep dive into a musical endeavor was one of the ways creativity was sparked in Einstein's brain. Does this mean that his best ideas were triggered when we were dedicating time to something that is a true, passionate interest of his? Is this break from professional work essential to excelling intellectual thought? Including play into your routine allows your brain to bridge different realms (such as music, art, reading) and those connections spark new ideas. Finding your deepest desires and spending time with all of them is essential to growing as people. Another concept that caught my eye about Einstein's creative process was that creativity can't be summoned and most of it is random. Although reflection and stepping back is important, but it is even more important to mix processes like that with committed work time. Although thoughts spark randomly, the sequential pattern of life between work and play is vital to creative processes. For Einstein, most of his creative thoughts were triggered when he spent time with his violin. The time spent learning and examining physics would not be nearly as impactful without reflection time. It is that mix that made Einstein one of the most creative and influential people in history.

Group Dynamics

Wed Feb 19, 2020 11:27 am

Group dynamics are used for understanding decision-making behavior and are a system of behaviors and psychological processes within social groups. They also concern how groups are formed, their structure and process, and how they function.

The fishbowl is a great place to study group dynamics. We are able to witness how are class functions as a group and how we respond to each other and ultimately creatively think. It is clear that we are only fooling ourselves if we believe that everyone learns and communicates like everyone else. That is not the case and the fishbowl is a great place to observe the different ways students process information and communicate personal connections to concepts brought forth in the course. By taking a step back and looking at the group as a whole, you are not only able to understand the group as a whole better but you are also able to discover the different bright spots throughout the group where students are thriving and learning quickly but you can also see the darker spots where students may be struggling with the learning process. It is important to study group dynamics to fully understand yourself.

Participation is Power

 Wed Feb 19, 2020 11:40 am

I am starting to understand why you don’t believe in deadlines. I chose to respond to your letters last night after a long, tiring day and I realized that my work may not meet its potential if I force myself to communicate my thoughts in the exhausted state I was in last night. It is important to reflect and know when rest is needed because growth requires rest and a committed routine. Everyone learns at their own pace. Learning requires patience and a positive attitude. By forcing it, I am only hurting the growth of myself.

Everyone participates and grows at different levels, but I believe we all have the same potential. Some students can dive right into the fishbowl process and contribute while others need something to hit them in a way that in order to succeed in both the course and in life, you must participate. Does participation level determine intelligence? Insecurity? Drive? Laziness? Or none of the above? I truly believe that everyone has something to contribute in any group setting whether its a lot or a little, but maybe for some people, patience is the answer. Everyone grows, develops, and thinks differently, so why force the growth when the best growth comes naturally? As you said, collaborative writing and creating value for each other is an important part of the learning process.

Creating Mental Spaces

Fri Feb 21, 2020 11:26 am

Space is the freedom or opportunity to express oneself, resolve a personal difficulty, be alone, etc.; allowance, understanding, noninterference. Does the more space you have lead to more happiness? Sadness? Is space required for concepts to settle into your brain? Why do people choose to dedicate their lives to living in free space rather than with the rest of society? Is this because they want to be free from the stresses of their cultures? What about their friends and family? Are some people so inclined to free time that they completely isolate themselves from the rest of the world? Why do some people choose this strict meditation/reflection lifestyle and some don't? Do some people connect more with mental spaces than others?

This is the beauty of the fishbowl. It is completely dependent on ourselves as students and determining how much effort and time we want to dedicate to building metaphors. The fishbowl provides its students with true space. With limited class time and in-class work, students can use their own space to break down the fishbowl and communicate on a truly personal basis, with no barriers or fear.

Multitude means a large number of or an abundance. In terms of politics, it seems that multitudes are a way of breaking down formal democracy and old forms of imperialism. Multitudes are an ideal form of governance that harness the singularity and creativity of masses and groups to lead cultures around the world. However, I am unsure about what this specifically means. It seems that Negri and Hardt created the concept as a way of describing an Empire without structure but I am struggling to grasp the roots of the concept. However, in terms of the fishbowl, does the multitude mean that we are all contributing our felt-experiences to create something larger? And this larger entity requires the creativity of the multitude of students?

Reading and Writing

Fri Feb 21, 2020 1:08 pm

Social constructionism is a theory of knowledge in sociology and communication theory that examines the development of jointly-constructed understandings of the world that form the basis for shared assumptions about reality.

Throughout my life so far, social constructionism has been a concept that I feel has been suppressed by my education. Classes have always revolved around the concept of "read, lecture, test, repeat", with no room for social constructionism. Not only does this concept limit my learning in which the information I have learned through this message goes in one ear and out the other, but it upsetting to think about why so many educators use this model.

This is why I admire the fishbowl. It is a place that fosters collaboration and learning from one another based on metaphors and designs we all create. Through the fishbowl, we are able to assemble our thoughts and create a bridge between the dictionary and our felt-experiences, as you said. I sense that the dictionary is the most unbiased piece of literature ever created. Doesn't this mean that a dictionary is the only piece of literature every single person has the ability to learn from? Rather than concepts that someone else created and limit the ability of others to intuitively think and deconstruct those concepts.

Love/leadership

Sun Feb 23, 2020 2:56 pm

In Praise of Love is about Alan Badiou's theory that love is under threat. He believes that love is an existential project and a constantly unfolding quest for truth. The quest begins with the chance encounter, an event that forever changes the two individuals, challenging them "to see the world from the point of view of two rather than one." This, Badiou believes is love's most essential transfiguration. The story urges readers to see love as an adventure rather than fear it as well as see it as a magnificent quest that compels us to otherness and difference, ultimately leading us away from an obsession with the self.

What about the morning's headlines made you despair (the complete loss or absence of hope) and groan (a deep inarticulate sound made in pain or despair)? Why should people ever be in despair and groan? As long as you are living and breathing, what is there to be upset about?

"There is nothing your fishbowl can't do together." All members of the fishbowl have the same opportunity to share reflections and love. Why is easier for some people to share the love and felt-experiences? In reality, there is no such thing as a free lunch. However, the one thing that is truly free is a smile. Every person has the ability to share the love and give someone a smile, but why is it that most people don't? It's so easy, personal, and takes no thoughts behind it! Anyone can be a leader if they want, so what is it that drives the people that actually follow through on their aspirations?

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 2/23/2020 3:46:51
Subject: creating value by sharing felt-experiences (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
"Our felt experiences are the key to our success; we must embody them, embrace them, and connect with them. This is how we are to be successful.” (Nick Collici, Fishbowl Spr20)

Hi Everyone,

That’s a great quote from Nick Collici. Please see his posting below.

Your felt-experiences are thought-images which you retrieve from memory and describe in your postings. Your thought-image is manifest and embodied in your text.

The same principle applies to brands. Brands are thought-images manifest and embodied in things. When you buy a brand, you are buying a thought or a philosophy that makes you feel powerful, which raises your stature in the eyes of those who matter to you. 

Naturally, people are willing to pay a lot of money for such “codes." The cost of making a product is much less than the cost at which brands are sold. Make your fishbowl into a brand and sell it. In order to charge a premium, great effort has to be made to establish your brands’s philosophy in a cultural landscape. It is building your fishbowl's "cultural capital." See Pierre Bourdieu. 

Unless people are able to “decode" what your brand stands for, it will have no value. I felt betrayed when he thought I would drive a Mercedes! My vehicle is a Jeep Renegade! We create value by sharing our felt-experiences with each other. We increase our "cultural capital” as a fishbowl, and become a brand; we charge a lot of money.

Sanjiv

CODE, DECODE, EMBODY, MANIFEST, BRAND, THOUGHT, IMAGE

from the fishbowl...

nickcolicci

Posts: 187

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 9:40 am

Re: Dialogics of Space

 Sat Feb 22, 2020 9:53 pm

As Walter Lippman put it, "Culture is the name for what people are interested in, their thoughts, their models, the books they read and the speeches they hear”. Our Fishbowl groups are being defined in this same manner. As a trio, we are using intersubjectivity and intertextuality to share words, text, phrases, and experiences to develop the culture we envision. We are not following a normal vision of culture, rather we are defining to fit our own desire and experiences. Quite honestly, I enjoy this freedom. I enjoy the ability that I have to use my own experiences, in conjunction with my peers, to create a culture I enjoy and want to immerse myself in. This is preparing me with the skillsets and abilities to enter international business scenarios or negotiations, understand the situation, and act accordingly. It is an invaluable set of skills that will elevate me above my competitors.

Dominik makes a good point when she states "Experience helps to understand which words to choose best for which person". Before I started viewing words and phrases based on my experiences, I was at a loss when I came across convoluted language I did not understand. However, by thinking back into my memory and archives, certain words and phrases have stuck out to me when I think about a sentence in terms of my personal experiences. It has opened me to a new manner of thinking, one that will take time to develop but will yield great benefits and critical thinking skills I can apply in the business world. We are chasing our goals and by using words and personal experiences, approaching our horizon and marks. Our felt experiences are the key to our success; we must embody them, embrace them, and connect with them. This is how we are to be successful.

Although I posted the above paragraph in my 443 group, I wanted to repost it for my peers to read in this course. It was an important, and life-changing, revelation that has shifted my thought processes and mental structure. I hope it does the same for others as well.

Date: 2/22/2020 13:02:43
Subject: &quot;Dialogics of Space&quot; (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

In 443, we are moving into thinking about “space” as metaphor for designing organizations and ourselves in our fishbowls.

What you have learnt thus far is a basic understanding of metaphor; that it is a word-image and, if you gather 30 associated word-images and sort them into 5 boxes and label them, and then, select/image one word to represent the boxes, you got yourself a metaphor. After that, you compare/contrast metaphors with your group members. And so began an understanding of social constructions, participant-observation and social reflexivity. Please be sure to have googled these terms.

In 448, we are moving into “intersubjective” and “intertextual” “space" as Expression. The exercise on defining “Culture" creates this space. Ultimately, the culture of your group is something only the group can define because it is intersubjective and intertextual (please google these terms). We will see both concepts, time and again, in the real-life business stories we are immersing ourselves in. Thus far, we are looking at the interaction between two cultures trying to get along: Japanese Story and Kinky Boots.

Dominik’s postings below are helpful. Great reflections and a felt-text. Writing and speaking and reading from his experience.

What we are looking at in your fishbowls is Mikhail Bakhtin’s philosophy of 'open-endedness' and ‘becoming.' Please google his name along with "dialogics of space.” 

Hang in there, everything will cohere in your minds and a unique understanding will finally develop. You are journeying towards a dialogical theory of space. I have to shift my head into The Abstract this weekend, and I have done my circling and procrastinating, but nothing on the horizon yet, except a mark. In the meantime, the deadline, like a pirate is creeping up, metaphorically speaking.

Sanjiv

DIALOG, COHERE, MARK, HORIZON

from the fishbowl...

Letter Interpretation

Sun Jan 26, 2020 4:04 pm

1_Letter: INTUITION, IMAGINATION, DESIRE, DISCERN, DISCOVER, DETERMINE

Reading the first letter helped me to see the aim and focus of the class. It seems to me that an important part is to understand and accept the diversity of opinions inside the class which are based on the different cultural background, professional backgrounds and many other life-influencing experiences.

The key message I see is that all opinions are highly welcome and valuable to learn from. To understand and learn to appreciate each other’s opinion is a big chance to challenge us in order to improve our personality. This is my understanding of Sanjiv statement, that he will do everything he can to provide us with the best opportunities but we have to use them.

Learning from others means, to understand the reason behind each other’s action. To get to know the personality as a whole will be an important part to do so, because the individual goals, experiences, desires and environments influence our behavior as a whole. It is okay, that everyone of us do things in our individual way and pace. Respect for each other will be the basic to learn from each other.
