Re: Letter Interpretation

Mon Feb 17, 2020 6:01 pm

Developing a process; following a practice

This letter shows me the importancs of words and the power of arranging them in a specific order. The key words: "DOING, PROCESS, PRACTICE, LEARNING, EXPERIENCE" highly reminds me to my physical practice for Triathlon. I see many similarieties.

Doing is the word, that is forcing your mindset not only to think about it, but actually transfer your idea of getting better and faster into reality

Process is the way, you go through in order to become better. Physical practice means to challenge yourself in every single training in order to force your body to transform.

Practice is required over and over again in order to establish the process of getting better.

Learning is one of the most important parts along the process, because in order to get better, one must learn from failures and succes.

Experience is the result of learning and practice.

I see now the similarities to writing. There you have to start at one point with a message you want to deliver. There are many ways how you can set up a process in order to develop structured and powerful sentences, but all have in common that you need to show a structure for the reader, that combine all your words to the message you want to tell. When I have to write an important message, I think about all the information I want to deliver and structure them into categories. Through practice you gets better and faster over time in developing well structered sentences. Experience helps to understand which words to choose best for which person

I start to understand, that the fishbowl do not gives us rules which we have to follow, but it helps us to learn from others in order to develop our individual process that works for each of us.

Dominik

Posts: 32

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 11:24 am

Re: Letter Interpretation

Fri Feb 21, 2020 10:15 pm

SORT, SIFT, SELECT, SHIFT, STUDY

For me to start it is very positive, that even Sanjiv admits that he is constantly in a learning process and constantly doing mistakes. That shows me, that there have to be many factors in a good position in order to generate good texts that generate meaning. Especially for me it often feels difficult to focus, because I am constantly changing between languages in order to stay in contact with family and friends. But I think Sanjiv is right. You have been structured in order to be creative. Focus on a word has actually a deeper meaning, because it represents the progress, that helps especially foreigners to get started. Start with the most important word, then structure a sentence around it. After repeating this process, it is possible to find good connection for the sentence and generate a meaningful, well structured text.

Being present is for me the essential part to bring in new ideas and aspects to a text. Establish a connection based of your knowledge and experience is something completely unique. No one else can see what is in your mind, but writing a meaningful text which describes the whole thought process you go through can help other people to understand you and give them some new ideas. Through interaction in platforms like the fishbowl it is possible, that the exchange of people results in big symbiosis.

Date: 2/21/2020 18:58:57
Subject: conference abstract: creative critical writing (443 &amp; 448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Please see Lea Janz’ posting below. The challenge is to make this text a reality.

Pulling out phrases and words from the text...

online conference with the fishbowl team

introduce various platforms

use for learning

concepts such as:

word-metaphor association,

strengthening vocabulary, and

demolishing structures.

To make this text a reality, we first have to write an Abstract. This morning I was thinking we might abstract about a visual culture, such as ours, where we are observing and interpreting each other’s postings; we are performing in a visual space (the fishbowl) that evolves and expands with our writing. It is known as "creative critical writing.” Please google the term. We show how we are generating text, intertextually and intersubjectively, at a time when the market is no longer about “niche" but about “space." The impetus for our performativity and creativity in the fishbowl is in part, quite clearly a desire to think of writing as a space, a space to be travelled and negotiated.

Stay with it, we are proceeding slow and easy. Giving time to digest. No busy work.

Sanjiv

PERFORMANCE, PERFORMATIVITY, “CREATIVE CRITICAL WRITING”

from the fishbowl...

message from IBM

As announced during the last faculty meeting, an online conference with the fishbowl team is scheduled at 2PM, February 21st. They will introduce various platforms that we can possibly use in our classes teaching modern concepts such as word-metaphor association, strengthening vocabulary, and demolishing structures only to rebuild them our way. We are planning to adopt an inclusive platform for this class, and the fishbowl is one of the organizational platforms that we are considering. All faculty and students are invited to contribute their own personal thoughts and suggestions.

Never leave the search for meaning. Another phrase for, “keep the thread”

At no time in the past or future should you go away from Exploring Intention.

Date: 2/17/2020 16:43:35
Subject: spoken words (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

This afternoon in class, we will watch two different cultures (Lola and Charlie Price) on the brink of disaster, interacting to survive financially, in a world spun out of their control.

Please read the posting by Andrew Bikash before the film. An important question raised by Bikash: why has it taken society so long to develop a solution?

When watching the film, please take down the words spoken; the phrases spoken in the film. 

Spoken Words are windows from which we look outwards and upwards.

We interpret spoken words and, we write down our interpretations.

We’re watching Lola and Charlie Price: two entirely different symbolic systems interacting. Can you identify the configuration of symbols?

Sanjiv

SPOKEN

andrewbikash

Posts: 94

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 11:03 am

Role of culture

Sun Feb 16, 2020 5:05 pm

"In a global marketplace, many leading international business scholars are arguing"

A global marketplace is the exchange of goods, services, and labor around the world. Leading means the front-runners or the best or most notable in an industry. Business is the practice of making one's living by engaging in commerce. A scholar is a specialist in a particular study. Arguing means giving reasons or citing evidence in support of an idea, action, or theory, typically with the aim of persuading others to share one's view.

After breaking down this phrase, I wonder, "what could business scholars possibly be arguing about?" Why isn't it easy for different cultures to share viewpoints? Is it because ways of life differ so much that answers in some cultures simply don't apply to other cultures?

Why has it taken society so long to develop the solution, "working in an international context, building flexibility, sharing information and developing collective know-how"? I sense that this is an obvious solution, but it is still a concept. How do business scholars break down this concept and incorporate into their work?

International meaning concerning multiple cultures. Context means the circumstances that form the setting for an event, statement, or idea, and in terms of which it can be understood and assessed. Building means the process or business of constructing something. Flexibility means the ability to be easily modified. Sharing means giving a portion of something to others. Information means what is conveyed or represented by a particular arrangement or sequence of things. Developing means growing and becoming more mature, advanced, or elaborate. Collective means were done by people acting as a group. Know-how means practical knowledge or skill.

Ideally, this would be there answer to uniting across all cultures, but I sense this has been an unachievable concept over the course of human history. Society lacks a guide or leader is promoting this process among world leaders. How do we put this guide promoting equality and openness together?

"Developing global economies of scale and at the same time being responsive to local environments; nurturing diversity and at the same time needing integration". I suppose these steps are a stepping stone to globalization but they sound so ideal rather than realistic to me. It would be ideal for cultures around the world to revolve around the common goal of globalization rather than being divided and arguing all of the time, but how realistic is it for it to happen? Is the author of this book trying to plant these foundational concepts within our heads, as students, and it is up to us to change the world and unite cultures under the idea of globalization and flexibility?

I look forward to examining the film this week that makes an attempt at this globalization technique.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 2/17/2020 15:08:20
Subject: inter- (443) copy for 448
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I find your postings to be astounding every time.

We interface, interact, interject, interlayer, interconnect, interplay, inter-relate, intercede, interpenetrate, interfuse, interdepend, intercede, inter... everything. 

Everything is reciprocal, is the point.

Through this inter-activity, we progress forward with ideas (words) that we would normally not thought of.

For instance, upon reading the posting below, I thought of a good film to watch in 443 tomorrow regarding “authorship” and “reading” and “writing.” There are several films out there, but it has to be positioned right; one that enhances the labor and ideas put forth by Olivia Palumbo. Just Keeping the thread!

Ultimately, we are developing story-lines and producing narratives in our fishbowls (making postings into events) that will be archived in memory. 

At the same time, we wish to make them accessible in the present.

You will always have the memory of your fishbowl, but is it accessible?

It is accessibility that will make your fishbowl alive, I would think.

Make your stories (memories) accessible, however mundane and banal they might appear to you.

Sanjiv

INTER, MEMORY, ARCHIVE, ACCESSIBLE, STORY, NARRATIVE, MUNDANE, BANAL, ENHANCE, ASTOUND

oliviapalumbo

Re: Letters -Palumbo

 Sun Feb 16, 2020 10:21 pm

"Reading" and "writing" as metaphors (443)

"In 443, you are giving specific attention to ways in which you can "author” or “write” new organizational realities through a range of processes that mobilizes imaginative ways of thinking and acting"

In my own words, this means that in our class, we are looking closely at different ways that we can be our own author and create our own "story" by interpreting our own truths through our own lenses. This includes using our own real life experiences, creative process, and imagination to think and write on a more in depth, spiritual level. Strictly Ballroom gave us an example of organizational structure through a story, a text that is present and alive, we feel like we are in the story, as apposed to reading about it. The goal of my fishbowl by the end of the semester is to be such a good story teller through my words, that the reader feels like they are in my story, the way I felt watching strictly ballroom.

A metaphor is a figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable. Metaphors are ever so presence in our daily lives as well as this class, they are only limited to our imagination.

To me, the interconnection between reading and writing is the ability to transform a text in your head and let your creative mind take off (reading) and putting this process on paper (writing). We can use images as mirrors and windows to see how our life/everyday emotions reflect through metaphors and how we see ourselves. How will we use organizational design to advance ourselves and make ourselves better writers/workers/students/readers and just overall empower our minds? I am excited to find out in class this week.

Date: 2/17/2020 0:10:51
Subject: writing strategies (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Please imagine yourselves in BUS448/Fishbowl2020 as a global business.

Consider every participant to belong to a different national culture. 

Please note, we're imagining ourselves to be in business (collaboration and cooperation) where we’re from different national cultural backgrounds.

I’m clearly Indian. And you could be Italian-American, Chinese-American, African-American, Iranian-American, Japanese-American, Jamaican-American, Mexican-American, Hispanic-American, and every country in the world. There must be an impact of national cultural differences in our fishbowls.

So here we are, and we are interacting with each other, like the U.N. and, our purpose is enshrined in the syllabus.

One thing is clear, in such a situation, we require to communicate and understand each other first at an abstract level. You’re developing these skills in your fishbowls. Please see Andrew Bikash’ posting below. You’re understanding (the situation you find yourself in the fishbowl) by using a 'writing strategy.’ Please google the term.

How so?

1. In her textbook (see overview), Lisa Hoecklin’s research shows that "the impact of national cultural differences is relevant to all areas of a global business” and by analogy, for all your postings in your fishbowls.

2. "Globally operating companies (like your fishbowls) have used different strategies to manage cultural differences." In our fishbowls, we translate this to mean using different 'writing strategies' to manage cultural differences. Different composition of words, metaphors and symbols that you are using are based upon a writing strategy.

3. "There are many more examples of companies articulating their intention to use cultural diversity for competitive advantage at a strategic level than there are successful examples at an operational level" (Hoecklin). We view this as being so because between the virtual/real dichotomy, digital text and image are predominant in companies like our fishbowls.

We will watch a film this week, but no popcorn because you have to take ethnographic notes. We are researchers and voyeurs to a real-life business happening. 

All this should be simple and will clear up this week.

Sanjiv

WRITING, STRATEGY, IMPACT

from the fishbowl...

Date: 2/16/2020 13:31:00
Subject: role of culture (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I’m reproducing the second and third paragraphs from the Overview in your textbook by Lisa Hoecklin, "Managing Cultural Differences: Strategies For Competitive Advantage."

"In a global marketplace, many leading international business scholars are arguing, the more sustainable competitive advantages are increasingly changing from ‘harder’ efficiency sources to ‘softer’ effectiveness sources. For example, moving to a low-cost labor area is replicable, short-term advantage. 

The more sustainable advantages are firm-specific abilities working in an international context, building flexibility, sharing information and developing collective know-how into a worldwide network. Faster and better learning within organizations is a large part of the evolving competitive logic. In order to develop these capabilities, people from different cultures have to be able to communicate, negotiate, compromise and understand each other’s values and world views."

"Furthermore, there are balances to be struck in the continuing process of globalization, such as developing global economies of scale and at the same time being responsive to local environments; nurturing diversity and at the same time needing integration; maintaining flexibility and at the same time being focused. These are issues with which each organization and function struggles on the road to globaliztion. Understanding the role of culture is of utmost relevance in resolving these dilemmas.”

Please ‘work' the above text. What does 'working the text' mean?

Pull out phrases. Take them further. Don’t be afraid, you will not fall.

You are venturing into the unknown and 

you’re constructing a structure, a knowing, 

brick by brick, 

so that you can take a position 

that represents your likeness 

in the digital community of the fishbowl.

You want to be seen, and 

you are working for adulation.

Next week, we will address each of Hoecklin's phrases by watching a film on how a local business in a small town went global by understanding the role of culture in resolving the dilemma of meeting local needs/reaping global economies of scale. 

We’re looking at the role of culture when solving our problems which often become intractable whenever we are caught in paradoxes and dilemmas. Please see the paradoxes and dilemmas in the posting below.

Sanjiv

PROBLEM, DILEMMA, PARADOX, INTRACTABLE, ROLE, CULTURE

Sat Feb 15, 2020 2:51 pm

what is your creative process?

I tried downhill skiing for the first time this week. I was nervous, uncomfortable, and awkward. I fell numerous times, but got back up and pushed through the pain. As a creative person, I always try to find meaning in everything I do. I put myself in unknown territory and came out bruised and sore…but wise. I learned how to switch from left to right, how to slow down, and how to balance. I discovered a new fear, acceleration, as steep drop-offs made my stomach churn. Before that, I thought I had no fears. To do this experience I had to surrender. I had to accept the fact that I am a beginner, I will fall, and I will go down hills. By the end of the night, I felt harmonization as I was travelling down the hills. Lean on the outer left foot, easy on the right, then ease the right foot pressure, easy on the left foot, and so on. But to do it right, I had to surrender.

To write in the fishbowl is to surrender. Like playing Super Mario, we are defeating old barriers while recognizing new ones. One obstacle for me is I am a perfectionist. To combat this, I tell myself that I should not strive for perfection, rather, the truth. Watching Mac Miller play with music is an exact metaphor for my goal in the creative process. Just play around, do not be afraid, and give yourself time. Patience, another barrier for me.

Ineluctably-unable to avoid, inescapable

How is the inside connected to the outside?

You need to ask yourself – why am I feeling this way? For example, why was I frustrated when I was skiing? Answer: because I have never done it before, I am perfectionist, and I was in a great deal of pain and fatigue. My inside was frustrated because my outside gave up. Sometimes the words we express from the inside won’t resonate to the outside unless we acknowledge the outside.

kyrasolomon

Posts: 61

Reflection: Creative Process

Fri Feb 14, 2020 2:33 pm

Since we've talked a bit about creativity and creative processes in both our emails and our classes, I thought I'd try and reflect on my own creative process a bit. When I'm drawing, sewing, crafting or doing any other creative activity for my own enjoyment, I tend to except a certain degree of perfectionism from myself. When I'm unable to bring the image I have in my head into reality perfectly, or when something unexpected causes me difficulty, I tend to get very frustrated. Sometimes I want to scream and cry and give up. For some reason, I tend to be much harder on myself when I'm doing things of my own volition rather than doing something that's being asked of me, such as school work. Over time, I've come to understand a basic principle that helps me center myself when I'm feeling this way: Something I make isn't good because it's perfect. It's good because I made it. It's something I poured effort and creativity into. It's a reflection of my own skills and experiences. This is something that I tend to forget in this moments when I'm frustrated with myself. I'm too worried about how other people will perceive my creative work. I've got a friend who is a fantastic visual artist, and I often find myself comparing myself to her. However, I know that we work differently because we're different people. She has a lot more experience because she enjoys sitting down to draw, whereas I have a very difficult time keeping myself focused or motivated. Besides that, any time I try and draw, she's very encouraging of me and excited to see what I make. How can I be so hard on myself when this fantastic artist is telling me how excited she is just to see what I create? Besides that, at the same time I've expressed admiration for her drawing and wondered at how she creates them, she's expressed admiration for physical things I've created and wondered at how I've created them. Maybe we're both extraordinary people with extraordinary abilities, just in different ways. I guess the conclusion of this is that, in order to improve my creative process, I need to learn how to give myself more credit for what I'm capable of versus what I'm not.

Date: 2/14/2020 23:50:26
Subject: incarnations and symbols on valentine (448)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

It is only appropriate to talk about symbols on this valentine weekend.

A symbol is both material and spiritual: concrete reality conveying an unseen truth. The lion for example symbolizes strength, just as the snake symbolizes cunning or the dove peace. The Greek verb 'sym-ballo' means “to throw, or put together.” The original ‘symbolon' was a token of recognition or, to be more precise, two tokens which fitted together thus showing the blood-relationship or friendship between the two people who possessed them. Your fishbowls are symbols in this sense. The role of the symbolic then is to bring together and unify participants, whereas the “diabolic” separates or divides them.

Symbols are a constant requirement of human nature, which is made up of both soul and a body. They allow us to pass from one to the other by means of an image or a text. As human beings, we are both spirit and flesh, “incarnated” spirits, and we live on both levels. By uniting flesh and spirit, symbols make our personal selves whole and allow us to communicate with others. They act as linchpins or hinges and are essential to us. Signs and symbols refer to a reality which transcends them. The difference between them is that signs are more specific, while symbols are richer.

It’s easy to understand this at its rudimentary level by completing the following exercise: 

What is the meaning of your name? What does it symbolize? 

Why did your parents choose this name? 

Do you think you fit the meaning of your name? Why and to what extent? 

Whose incarnation are you? Who do you personify?

Sanjiv

INCARNATION, SYMBOL, PERSONIFY

Immaterial labor, cybernetics, metaphor and symbolism

Maurizio Lazzarato is an Italian sociologist and philosopher. He is known for his essay on immaterial labor. His essay explains that our affective (feeling & emotions) and cognitive (thinking) abilities provide value in a capitalist system.

The fishbowl environment is providing us with value, yet it may not seem like it because it is not physical.

For example, I have an urge to spend time in the Fishbowl, but why? Sanjiv compared it to exercising. We do it to feel good and look good. The more we practice the more habitual, and the more value, we get out of it.

Re: Reflections-Lea Janz

Tue Feb 11, 2020 3:57 pm

constructing a knowing...building an awareness

Bateson’s Peripheral Visions: Learning Along the Way, reflects on our rapidly changing world and “proposes a new way of learning through participation”. This “participation” confused me, which led me to dig deeper on her book. By narration of her life story, she encourages the reader that our method of learning and thinking goes beyond structural norms like school and work. She says that most of our learning, “takes place outside the settings commonly labeled as educational and include intuitive and empirical dimensions all too often overlooked in our customary approach to learning”(http://scott.london/reviews/bateson.html)

Intuitive- intuition, what feels to be true and right

Empirical-based on observation, not facts or logic, experience

Most of our learning involves the experiences we put ourselves in outside of the classroom, or our peripheral vision.

She also mentions how our society is goal-oriented. Just get the job done. Instead, to live a fuller life one must open their peripheral eye. Quit focusing on the center and look around. Make connections, dialogues, and experiences.

vertiginous change

vertiginous-whirling, spinning, rotating (unstable)

change- differences

I imagine a tilt-a-whirl at a fair. Spinning makes me sick, I stay behind and watch my friends on the ride.

expectations of perpetual progress

expectations- belief that some event will happen

perpetual-never ending/changing

progress-moving onward or forward

A strong belief that we will continuously keep moving forward. Who will be left behind? Where are we going? What is the purpose?

distorting filter of the internet

distorting-pull or twist out of shape, false impression

filter-removing impurities, removing unwanted material

internet-global computer network that provides information and communication facilities

The unnoticed removal of unwanted material caused by a mass network containing all the information ever known provided by communications of groups. Reminds me of the Library of Alexandria in Egypt. Contained a plethora of information, like the Internet today, but was eventually destroyed.

There is this belief of progression, pulling and twisting us, filtering out our impurities, that leaves me sick and dizzy. Are we all moving forward? If so, where are we going? “Onward!” says ‘everyone’. Maybe I will stay off this ride.

Re: Reflections-Lea Janz

Thu Feb 13, 2020 4:08 pm

the domain of phenomenal forms

The title of this email excited me. It sounds like we are on the cusp of a transformation.

Domain-a specified sphere of activity or knowledge (field, area)

Phenomenal-observable fact or event (extraordinary)

Forms-visible shape or configuration (conformations)

The area of extraordinary conformations

To disregard this event is to disregard one's own perspective. Don't we all want to learn how we think?

Phenomenology- the study of structures of consciousness experienced from the first point of view

The study of the appearance of things by the viewer’s experience.

Social Constructivism-collaborated learning. Developed by post-revolutionary Soviet psychologist Lev Vygotsky, this theory states that all learning begins by interaction within people or groups. Vygotsky says, “Every function in the child’s cultural development appears twice: first, on the social level and, later on, on the individual level; first, between people (interpsychological) and then inside the child (intrapsychological).” (https://gsi.berkeley.edu/gsi-guide-contents/learning-theory-research/social-constructivism/) More notably, Vygotsky highlights the importance of language and cultural in individual intellectual development and how they view the world. “Knowledge is not simply constructed, it is co-constructed.”

So far we have learned that the words we generate have meaning. We know that words are metaphors. We are also learning by comparing our dictionaries to others. We influence each other, and cannot learn without each other.

Subject: knowledge workers in a knowledge economy
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I think by now you’ve all got the hang of what the approach in this course is about. For one thing, the approach appears different every night when you think about it. 

How you make value in a situation that is multi-faceted, multifarious, multidimensional, multidisciplinary is a recurring question. Multi is a good word! 

This evening, as I was reading your postings (it seems it’s all I do these days), I was convinced anew, that your fishbowls are a microcosm of the 'knowledge economy.’ Please google that term. 

You are 'knowledge workers' in a knowledge economy and you have documentary evidence to back it up. You're talking legal and you're talking money, and you’re putting it on your resumes. This is human resources and human rights that you are managing. It is not mumbo-jumbo. Our resources and our rights go together. It’s like Sandy saying to Hiromitsu in Japanese Story: ”Don’t you understand anything? I’m sorry I’m not being polite!” HIromitsu couldn’t believe she said that. The look on his face is priceless. Try reproducing it!

I am thinking about juxtaposing the notion of 'knowledge economy' and 'immaterial labor,' along with, 'relational thinking in sociology' and Bourdieu’s notion of 'cultural capital' (please google Bourdieu’s term). To put this all together as a description of your textual forays into the unknown... and submit it together as co-authors to the conference EDULEARN20 for blind review by the experts in the field, world-wide

. Eighty countries, covering all continents, I believe.

There’s a lot at stake, and it can get hot in the kitchen. Your task is to labor the text. That is to say, to read and read and read, plus eat and sleep, using the dictionary to understand. Your task is to create understanding, that is, to invent your truth, very much like your pasta sauce. It is best to stay focused on the pasta sauce, because everything else is outside our control. No worries and no stress. Just leading a life of reflection and building castles in the air, watching trains go by.

Sanjiv

KNOWLEDGE ECONOMY, KNOWLEDGE WORKER, IMMATERIAL LABOR (MARX), RELATIONAL THINKING IN SOCIOLOGY, CULTURAL CAPITAL(BOURDIEU).

nickcolicci

Posts: 113

The Symbolic Act of Selecting

 Tue Feb 04, 2020 8:38 pm

At first glance, I attempted to break down and create meaning for the quote "What gives humans access to the symbolic domain of value and meaning is the fact that we die.” (Debray). I interpreted this to mean that when people are exposed to the concept of death, they seem to pursue and grasp the underlying meaning of the information they encounter. As Andrew stated, it is interesting that some people do not understand the inevitably of death and continue to build cultural barriers. I believe it is our responsibility as future leaders in business and America to acknowledge the issues with cultural barriers and seek to knock them down.

Studying the Other as well as the dynamic between the characters in the Japanese Story demonstrates the complexities with cross-culture relationships and how it can inhibit progress. Reflection is necessary to overcome these challenges and doing so only once or at the moment we view it is not sufficient. Thus, by engaging in constant reflection, we can overcome cultural barriers and create productive relationships. This is not an easy concept, nor is constant reflection something we as young adults and students are comfortable with. However, if we want to succeed in business and want to ensure that international business and cultural structures are not an impediment, this type of reflection is critical.

Expression and the selection of words will be common during this course and over the semester. However, when we are doing this, we must make an effort to do it genuinely. By this I mean we cannot try to reach "an arbitrary standard", "be intellectual", or "earn a grade". This type of ingenuine reflection will not help us progress or knock down the cultural walls that are built. Also, it will not allow our classmates to know each other as our posts will not be reflective of our true feelings and opinions. Therefore, we must use words that accurately represent our feelings and self-experiences. We cannot be exceptional or stand out if we are not selecting words that are unique to our own experiences.

Technology and social media often perpetuate ingenuine interactions and rude messages that people send behind screens. However, in these Fishbowls, we have to be authentic and transparent. Our posts and reflections must also be honest and representative of our perceptions and perspectives. Once all members of our class are comfortable sharing their ideas, we will achieve progress.

Date: 2/12/2020 13:42:00
Subject: domain of phenomenal forms
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

'Ways of Seeing' is the title of a nifty book by John Berger. "When you discover the way you see anything, a word, an image, you also discover something about yourself and the world you live in."

How do you “see" anything? "How do you think, Sanjiv?” she wanted to know.

For the answer, you have to peel layers (make selections) of text and get to the core. It is the process of abstraction.

Abstractions, Concepts, Phenomenas, Categories: these are words and they each have a history, culture, and context; and, you get to select them. You are on your way to becoming a phenomenologist and a social constructivist. In my world, that is a big deal. At this point, it is good to know what phenomenology and social constructivism means. What have you got yourself into?

To turn away from this activity is to turn away from the world. Definitionally, this turning away is a visual event. It entails the reorientation (or, more precisely, the disorientation) of vision. To abandon the domain of phenomenal forms is, quite simply, to lose one’s sight.

Please think about it.

Sanjiv

PEEL, LAYER, CORE, ABSTRACT, CONCEPT, PHENOMENA, CATEGORY, FORM

from the fishbowl...

Words have unlimited ways of interpretation and meaning that create structure in our own way. The arrangement and relations of words hold great value within influence and meaning. After reading about the assembly lines, it's clear that production efficiency is increased but the opportunity of growth and innovation disappears. At the moment things are great for production, but nothing will ever change. Slowing things down makes 

anything more understandable. For words, taking time to depict its meaning to gain a better understanding is extremely important. In my life, I enjoy swimming because it puts me in a relaxed state of mind allowing me to reflect on many things.

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 2/12/2020 13:39:48
Subject: domain of phenomenal forms
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

'Ways of Seeing' is the title of a nifty book by John Berger. "When you discover the way you see anything, a word, an image, you also discover something about yourself and the world you live in."

How do you “see" anything? "How do you think, Sanjiv?” she wanted to know.

For the answer, you have to peel layers (make selections) of text and get to the core. It is the process of abstraction.

Abstractions, Concepts, Phenomenas, Categories: these are words and they each have a history, culture, and context; and, you get to select them. You are on your way to becoming a phenomenologist and a social constructivist. In my world, that is a big deal. At this point, it is good to know what phenomenology and social constructivism means. What have you got yourself into?

To turn away from this activity is to turn away from the world. Definitionally, this turning away is a visual event. It entails the reorientation (or, more precisely, the disorientation) of vision. To abandon the domain of phenomenal forms is, quite simply, to lose one’s sight.

Please think about it.

Sanjiv

PEEL, LAYER, CORE, ABSTRACT, CONCEPT, PHENOMENA, CATEGORY, FORM

from the fishbowl...

Hi Everyone,

Juxtapose to create meaning.

Sanjiv

JUXTAPOSE

Where The Mind Is Without Fear

Where the mind is without fear and the head is held high

Where knowledge is free

Where the world has not been broken up into fragments

By narrow domestic walls

Where words come out from the depth of truth

Where tireless striving stretches its arms towards perfection

Where the clear stream of reason has not lost its way

Into the dreary desert sand of dead habit

Where the mind is led forward by thee

Into ever-widening thought and action

Into that heaven of freedom, my Father, let my country awake.

nickcolicci

Posts: 81

Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2020 9:40 

The Symbolic Act of Selecting

Tue Feb 04, 2020 8:38 pm

At first glance, I attempted to break down and create meaning for the quote "What gives humans access to the symbolic domain of value and meaning is the fact that we die.” (Debray). I interpreted this to mean that when people are exposed to the concept of death, they seem to pursue and grasp the underlying meaning of the information they encounter. As Andrew stated, it is interesting that some people do not understand the inevitably of death and continue to build cultural barriers. I believe it is our responsibility as future leaders in business and America to acknowledge the issues with cultural barriers and seek to knock them down.

Studying the Other as well as the dynamic between the characters in the Japanese Story demonstrates the complexities with cross-culture relationships and how it can inhibit progress. Reflection is necessary to overcome these challenges and doing so only once or at the moment we view it is not sufficient. Thus, by engaging in constant reflection, we can overcome cultural barriers and create productive relationships. This is not an easy concept, nor is constant reflection something we as young adults and students are comfortable with. However, if we want to succeed in business and want to ensure that international business and cultural structures are not an impediment, this type of reflection is critical.

Expression and the selection of words will be common during this course and over the semester. However, when we are doing this, we must make an effort to do it genuinely. By this I mean we cannot try to reach "an arbitrary standard", "be intellectual", or "earn a grade". This type of ingenuine reflection will not help us progress or knock down the cultural walls that are built. Also, it will not allow our classmates to know each other as our posts will not be reflective of our true feelings and opinions. Therefore, we must use words that accurately represent our feelings and self-experiences. We cannot be exceptional or stand out if we are not selecting words that are unique to our own experiences.

Technology and social media often perpetuate ingenuine interactions and rude messages that people send behind screens. However, in these Fishbowls, we have to be authentic and transparent. Our posts and reflections must also be honest and representative of our perceptions and perspectives. Once all members of our class are comfortable sharing their ideas, we will achieve progress.

Date: 2/5/2020 0:58:43
Subject: attending to meaning
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Howard Rheingold in his best seller Net Smart: How to Thrive Online (please google) tells us: "the first thing we all need to know about information online is how to detect crap, by which I mean information tainted by ignorance, inept communication, or deliberate deception.” (p.16). 

Rheingold says that “learning to be a critical consumer of Web info (like you are generating in your fishbowls) is not rocket science. Becoming acquainted with the fundamentals of Web credibility testing (in your fishbowls) is easier than learning the multiplication tables. The hard part, as always, is the exercise of flabby think-for-yourself muscles.” 

You are exercising your "flabby think-for-yourself muscles!” You’re learning (myself included) how to make use of huge, unsorted, continually changing flows of information without becoming overwhelmed. 

Most of you have understood the skill that you are developing in your fishbowls. Please see Caroline Morganelli’s posting below. Understanding comes and goes like the sea on the shore. Let me state it in terms of Howard Rheingold, who in his book looked at everyday behaviors where communication technology use affected “attention": 

* there are large scale shifts in attentional practices and norms

* we have to take into account the attentional behaviors of others

* you begin to think in new ways about how people deploy their attention when you start looking at the way your own thinking processes have changed

When you’re on your way to gaining control of your online attention and 

have begun to practice crap-detection skills, 

you turn from “this is your brain on the internet” to 

“this is what the Internet enables people to do together.” 

From the cognitive to the social, that is,

you will have shifted your attention to the technology and sociality of participation and collaboration.

We're focusing on the skills digital citizens need to master in order to take part in or instigate mass collaboration. (Rheingold)

In a nutshell, in our fishbowls, we’re focusing on the skills needed to participate in mass collaboration. 

You are doing great. You inspire me. I exist in response to you. A "participatory culture" is developing in your fishbowls. Participation is Power!

Sanjiv

ATTENTION, ATTEND, PARTICIPATE, COLLABORATE, DEPLOY, DETECT, INSTIGATE, COGNITIVE, SOCIAL

from the fishbowl...

Re: Caroline Morganelli: Letters

Tue Feb 04, 2020 2:01 pm

RE: learning to express, one word at a time

The title of this particular letter struck me quite instantly, as I feel this is a reoccurring topic. Everyone has a different style o writing and expresses their voice uniquely. If this was not true, we would live in a very monotonic society, which would be very boring. Expression and style keep things interesting and without it communication would be almost impossible. By following the steps of developing, copying the meaning, and sharing a personal experience of the given word we are able to not only understand the definition, but advance our knowledge on what a word actually means. Understanding a dictionary definition is simply the base or foundation in understanding a given word. Once we are able to accurately find and understand the words we are trying to use and completely understand the words that we are saying, expressing your thoughts becomes much easier.

Hi Everyone,

I’ve been taking a long time understanding Regis Debray’s quote in this book I have: Mind Grenades, Manifestos From The Future.

“What gives humans access to the symbolic domain of value and meaning is the fact that we die.” (Debray)

After the excellent intellectual exchange among us about the notion of Other in cultural studies, and after watching Japanese Story again last evening, I woke up this morning to read where Calder had turned-in and left-off last night. And, thanks to Calder, Debray’s perplexing quote became clear. 

How so? 

The fact that the previous “intellectual exchange" is over, that is to say that moment has past, the Now has become Then, 

what is of value and meaning (that is, what is compelling) is right before me on my laptop, shining with a glow: Calder’s text!

Calder, succinctly draws out the relation between us and among us in the digital environment, like the fishbowl.

How did he do that? Did he do that consciously?

All he did was express himself (sharing his selection of words), without trying to reach some arbitrary standard, like, being intellectual or earning a grade

You’re ultimately, selecting words and saying something about them from your felt-experience. Selection in itself portrays a feeling. Your act of selecting makes you singular.

Our common goal is To Be ourselves by expressing ourselves, in the knowledge that everything is visible in perceptual space. This is how I understand the internet, where transparency and authenticity go hand-in-hand. That is, my selection is visible!

Sanjiv

Date: 2/3/2020 14:57:45
Subject: learning to express, one word at a time
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

When you scroll through the fishbowl and look at participants in their groups, you see differences in the learning styles and expressions in every fishbowl.

We’re all working on our EXPRESSION. Without expression, communication is difficult. We work on expression one word at a time. It is not a difficult PROCESS. But you do have to set up a PRACTICE for it.

DEVELOP your vocabulary is the first step.

COPY the MEANING of the word from a dictionary. Get as many words as you can. 

Then share your PERSONAL EXPERIENCE of the meaning of the words.

Whenever you do that, you are taking RESPONSIBILITY for your text.

Such postings are of interest in the digital market place, and they fetch a price.

Once you get this underway, you can start building from there. It’s easy street after that.

Sanjiv

DEVELOP, EXPRESSION, PROCESS, PRACTICE, COPY, PERSONAL, EXPERIENCE, RESPONSIBILITY

Subject: keeping the thread (443)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

At this stage, you are learning to keep the thread (staying connected) with regard to your work in your fishbowls.

Keep-the-Thread (please google) is a multi-faceted approach that maximizes flexibility, where participants create a mutually agreeable plan appropriate for their situation. 

You’ve begun to discern the boundaries and limits of your learning, and the necessity for collaboration and cooperation among yourselves.

You’re creating this thread. 

There is no underlying, pre-determined thread that exists in your fishbowls, except the one you are creating.

When you think about it, no business is going to pay someone, plus tell them what to do, because they’d do it themselves instead and pocket the money. You must bring your singularity to the table. You must express what is it that you do, and how you do it. I am talking about developing thoughts (words) and ideas (words) and scenarios (words). How do you work? What is your process and your practice?

Please see Andrew Bikash’s postings below.

How do three participants in a fishbowl create a thread; create an idea? Create a tapestry, a painting, an orchestra, a business, a workshop, a presentation, a fishbowl. A design?

How should one go about creating a design that has economic value in a digital environment?

How might the three of you, in a fishbowl, create a design that has value?

When am I being creative?

How am I doing it?

Why am I doing it?

What is the outcome?

Does it have merit and value?

Would it interest someone?

Sanjiv

Sort, sift, select, shift, study

Thu Jan 30, 2020 11:33 am

I watched a video on the meaning of deep learning and it gave the example of 3 children who wrote the number 9. Rather than analyzing the number itself, deep learning methods look into how each child physically drew the number and analyzes how they wrote the number describes the way they think. From my perspective, deep learning means going beyond the surface and diving into the design of concept, symbol, or idea and exactly how it is communicated. This seems to relate well with the course because I am learning how to think deeper into the design of communication rather than the communication itself and maximizing the utilization of this skill. This letter makes me think about how each singular word and its position have such a strong meaning but the power often goes unnoticed. I sense that this is a concept that you want your students to grasp so that they realize the power of syntax and language if used well. This process comes from thinking differently than others and thinking about how your words transverse a community and the head, heart, thoughts, and feelings of others. This is a skill that can be used at any time.

Side-note, after reading Nick's letter, the main thing that caught my eye was his analysis of the sentence, "What is the difference in your perceptions?" and his definitions for every word in the sentence. I must not have realized or taken seriously your message of analyzing every single word in a syntax. I now see that breaking down words and diving into their definitions gives me a completely new perspective on communication. In this most recent letter, a sentence that caught my attention:

To-expressing motion in a direction

open-allowing access or view of something

your-belonging to or association

eyes-pair organs in the head which people use to see

is-to be

challenge-to take part in a competition, go beyond what you believe

your-belonging to or association

perception-the ability to see, hear or feel your surroundings

of-exploring the relationship between a part and a whole

reality-the world or state of things that actually exist

Textual Happening

Sun Feb 02, 2020 5:15 pm

Deleuze: Gilles Deleuze was a French philosopher from the 20th century. He had a philosophy about the production of concepts and discussed the central concepts of empiricism. Immanence, the theory that the divine encompasses or is manifested in the material world, is often referenced throughout his work. Deleuze believed that for philosophy or thought to have real substance, they must create movement and consequences rather than setting up transcendentals, which means communicating something completely theoretical or a strictly reflective subject.

Movement of images: developing concepts with substance and resituating them based on prior images or concepts

Henri Bergson: French-Jewish philosopher who's most enduring contribution to philosophical thinking is his concept of multiplicity which means unifying in a consistent way heterogeneity (state of being diverse as a character or content) and continuity (unbroken and consistent existence or operation of something over a period of time)

Date: 2/3/2020 11:52:07
Subject: looking at layers some more (448)

Dear Dipankar,

Thank you for your email and helpful knowledge content. That is indeed a gem from the Upanishads... “Source of all sorrow is to consider one’s Self distinct from the Self of Others.” 

It is helpful in realizing the enormity of the task ahead when considering ‘pandemics' like the coronavirus.

In the film Japanese Story, it is indeed Sandy and Hiromitsu, the protagonists’ 'source of trouble and sorrow' because they considered themselves ‘distinct' from each other. They started on the wrong foot and arrived with pre-determined structures; a Japanese man/Australian woman. They set the situation right quickly though: they read the printed word (instructions on being stuck in the desert) and saw the light. When we’re together as equal human beings, we can accomplish anything is the message in the film. We have to re-learn how to get along. Or, we are dead in the desert! That would be a C in the course.

We are on this quest of learning how to engage with each Other’s text. Word by word. We don’t find the journey easy and the going can be rough, emotionally speaking. But we are beginning to see that we are also in a fishbowl and not just in the desert....”We all look into our separate mirrors now, and mostly see ourselves looking back.” (Jon Katz) 

Looking at our layers,

Sanjiv

C; BUS448 (International DImensions of Business)

On Feb 2, 2020, at 10:14 PM, dipankar gupta <dipankargupta@hotmail.com> wrote:

Dear Sanjiv,

Your mail about the “other” got me going in an idiosyncratic way which I hope you will temper as you read.

The appreciation of the “other” as a live and corrective counterpart of the “self” is really a very recent introduction that is coeval with the arrival of fraternity in democracy’s consciousness. In my limited understanding, Hegel was the first to position the “other” in this form where the self required needed it for its own advancement and realisation. 

The “other” has long featured in philosophical speculations but there it is all about charity, philanthropy or kindness (true, even in Kant), but as a requirement for self realisation it is as recent as the introduction of fraternity. This is why any consideration of the concept of the “other” ought to accept the novelty of democracy, as well as its contrived and self conscious character. It is not a “mother’s milk” phenomenon.

Without presuming what other religious traditions may have said about the “other”, I have come across a very empathy laden and modern rendition of this concept in the Isha Upanishad. In this text we find the gem: “ Source of all sorrow is to consider one’s Self distinct from the Self of Others.” I think this was so unusual for its times that it has rarely been commented upon by religious exegetes of the past or by trained scholars in religious studies today.

Best,

Dipankar 

Sent from my iPhone

Hi Everyone,

After I distilled my reflections of the Japanese Story, 

accumulated over the years, 

I took a fresh look at the Western idea of the Other (please google). 

In our globalized but increasingly polarized world, Japanese Story shows how the Other remains one of the most compelling ideas of our times.

We continue to treat the Other as hostile aliens, objects of study rather than full partners sharing responsibility for the fate of humankind. It took dramatic circumstances for Sandy and Hiromitsu to realize this and come to terms with it. They were quick learners. That’s what it took: speed in open mindedness, flexible mental structures, focusing on words and symbols, willingness to reflect and adapt, admitting mistakes and taking responsibility.

Every cross-cultural interaction is a journey. It is the intersection of different word (symbolic) structures that makes the outcome singular. “No more map!" This uniqueness is unpredictable and unknown. Consider Meghan Markle and Prince Harry in this light.

Sanjiv

OTHER (please google), INTERACTION, INTERSECTION, SINGULAR, RESPONSIBILITY

from the fishbowl...

Reflection: Being Present

EditDeleteReportWarnInformationQuote

Post by kyrasolomon » Thu Jan 30, 2020 9:06 am

According to the dictionary, the word "being" means existence, or having the capacity to exist. It describes "present" as occurring at the current time or now. When I look at the phrase "being present," I can surmise that it means existing in a particular moment. While this might sound simple to do, I feel there is more to allowing yourself to exist in a moment than simply showing up to it. In order to fully exist in that moment, you should really be experiencing it. How much you allow yourself to experience it depends on things like focus and engagement. I think knowing this is going to be important for this class. In order to derive anything of value from it, we will have to be as present as we possibly can. This will involve practicing skills such as focusing and engaging.

Hi Everyone,

Our work-life, your fishbowls for instance, are constantly in ‘movement.’ Please think about that for a second; it is the 'movement of images' in your fishbowls that have become relevant. Please google Deleuze and Movement of Images. I’m what you’d call a Deleuzian.

Think in terms of moving images? How do you do that? What are you being asked to do? Why doesn’t Sanjiv spell it out in simple language? Why the big mystery? PLease google Henri Bergson as well. Thank you. 

Your fishbowl is a 'textual happening' where the random juxtaposition between seemingly unrelated areas gives rise to arbitrary connections. Please fact-check from your fishbowls.

In class we are watching the textual happening of the organization, Strictly Ballroom. This textual happening is a visual product, made by participants playing traditional ‘roles’ regarding the process of creativity.That it is a textual happening is brought to light by the spoken lines of the two kids. 

We the viewers, do not know what is going to happen next! Is he going to ‘kiss’ her or not?

 

This organization’s product or outcome is arbitrarily created by juxtaposing philosophy (“a life half-lived”) and dance (movement of steps). Please think about that.

So whenever I view these moving images in Strictly Ballroom, I resonate with them, even after a thousand views. I relate to Scott and now more to his father, Doug. I don’t relate to the others. I do relate to the Grandmother as well. Powerful thinker. Watch her lines.

We are watching our lines in the course. We are actors, writing the script and developing our roles. You are designing an organization, your fishbowl.

Riding slow, waiting for the moon to show...

Sanjiv

SORT, SIFT, SELECT, SHIFT, STUDY

Deep learning: a subset of machine learning in artificial intelligence (AI) that has networks capable of learning unsupervised from data that is unstructured or unlabeled. Also known as deep neural learning or deep neural network.

Deep thinking: The power of deep thinking is the essence of creativity. By learning how to think differently and deep, you will find that it is not only your creative thinking, but your critical thinking skills that vastly improve.

Alienation (Marx): Karl Marx's theory of alienation describes the estrangement of people from aspects of their Gattungswesen as a consequence of living in a society of stratified social classes.

From:

http://dnaanthology.com/anvc/dna/deleuze-and-the-movement-image

Deleuze and the Movement Image

In Deleuze’s Bergsonian conceptual universe the world is constituted by images where “everything reacts on everything else”. In this world there is no centre, no particular image that grounds all others. This is a Heraclitean vision of a world defined by the movement of action and reaction, where the stuff of the world always consists of multiple facets of action and reaction. For example, consider water and rock. The water erodes the rock while the rock interrupts the course and flow of the water. The compounds of the rock and their action and reaction with water become (the water and the rock) sediment, erosion, an alluvial plain, a stone to be skipped by a child over the surface of the river. These actions and reactions happen automatically. The rock doesn’t think its reaction with water, and in the language of Cinema One, these are ‘determined’ in the sense that they are subject to the laws of nature.

Managing Innovation and Change (443)

Many classes I've taken at URI seem to be very interesting at the beginning of the semester. I am learning new things from a new face with new people. After a few months however, the class just seems to become stale; we do take notes the same way, we say the same things, and everything is just the same. That is what this letter is all about. Sanjiv is questioning us on how we can spice up our posts and our learning. He is asking us how we can innovate (introduce new changes) our work and keep things fresh. Sanjiv the fours things we will need to change in our dialogue, our process, social construction, and our design. We already starting to change our dialogue with all of the new vocabulary words we our searching. The next step in change is process. Process is defined as a series of actions or steps taken in order to achieve a particular end. I think one way I have already started to change my process is with the work I am doing in this class. I tend to be a last-minute homework doer but I cannot do that in this class. I have already begun to innovate and change the way I do work.

Date: 1/22/2020 15:24:53
Subject: Syllabus2020Spring
------------------------------------------------------------
UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION

SPRING, 2020

Sanjiv Singh Dugal, Ph.D.

Human Resource Management

314 Ballentine Hall

Office Hours: 

WF 11-12 Noon, 1-2pm

By Appointment

BUS 448

International Dimensions of Business

I. Introduction

How do you navigate and negotiate a situation that is foreign and strange? A situation where the Other's language, customs and culture are unknown and, you have no predetermined script nor map on the ground. Under these circumstances, what skills are necessary to successfully conclude a contract? What is the art of the deal?

“As we globalize, we increasingly have to interact, manage, negotiate and compromise with people from different cultures. Working with people whose values and beliefs, not to mention languages and customs are different from your own can make for costly misunderstandings. Experience tells us, often painfully, that one’s behavior, actions and decisions are not separate from one’s values and beliefs. All social behavior is embedded in a particular context and is connected to other deeply held values and beliefs. This means that the stakes are high for mismanaging cultural differences.” (Lisa Hoecklin, 'Managing Cultural Differences: Strategies for Competitive Advantage,' The Economist Intelligence Unit Series, Addison-Wesley, 1995)

II. Concept of the Course: Probing Differences

The course focuses on learning ‘how to probe’ for differences among ourselves (in groups of three, aka The Fishbowl), in the belief that our differences give us a comparative perspective that provides a reflective lens for understanding why we do things the way we do them.

"In a global marketplace, many leading international business scholars are arguing that sustainable competitive advantages are increasingly changing from ‘harder ’ efficiency sources to ‘softer ’ effectiveness sources, such as, managing differences in values and beliefs. Our differences provide a reflective lens to see where we're positioned with regards to each other." (Hoecklin).

Managing differences among yourselves gives your group its competitive advantage. The following skills (Hoecklin, p.ix) makes your group in the Fishbowl competitive:

a. an ability to express;

b. flexibility in thought and action;

c. sharing and disclosing one’s position in a situation; and,

d. abstracting from the particulars of an interaction.

In order to develop these capabilities, you are being asked to communicate, collaborate and connect in the social space of your fishbowl.

III. Method: Participant Observation, Interpretivism and Symbolic Interaction

The course fulfills the logical sequence of awareness (of differences among your group members), knowledge (of differences in your group) and communication (of differences in your group). These three traits (viz., awareness, knowledge and communication) underlie the development of all cross-cultural skills (Geert Hofstede).

The course utilizes Participant Observation, Interpretivism and Symbolic Interactionism as methods for addressing cross-cultural questions such as:

How do you experience the ‘other’ culture?

That is, how do you experience the other’s deeply held values and beliefs?

What do you see?

How did you feel?

What did you do?

IV. Text

1. Managing Cultural Differences: Strategies for Competitive Advantage, by Lisa Hoecklin. The Economist Intelligence Unit Series, Addison-Wesley, 1995.

This text will help you translate abstract cultural issues into concrete business considerations across national borders.

2. Exploring Culture, Exercises, Stories and Synthetic Cultures, by Gert van Hofstede, Paul B. Pedersen, Geert Hofstede. Intercultural Press, Boston, London, 2002.

Real-life exercises and stories, all with debriefings, make much of this book ideally suited for self-study. Specific activities and exercises are steps towards awareness and knowledge of differences. We will practice intercultural communication skills, and experience what it feels and means to be a ‘foreigner.’

V. Creating a Global Experience: The Fishbowl

Your Fishbowl is a social network of writing/viewing/experiencing. The Fishbowl is something knowable, only in specific Fishbowl practices and contingencies during the course of the semester. Understanding globalization is recognizing 'networks of meaning' such as those experienced in your Fishbowl on a vast scale. In other words, you are constructing and creating meaningful interaction among yourselves that is made up of:

subjectivity in its nascent state;

the social in its mutant state; and,

the environment, at the point it can be reinvented.

VI. Grade Distribution

1. Regularity and Quality of Posting in the Fishbowl: 50%

There will be five interactive homework assignments that will account for fifty per cent of your grade. Your grade is based on your efforts in developing a network of symbolic interaction in your fishbowls.

2. Attending to Meaning in Social Space: 30%

We 'attend to meaning' by sharing, responding and listening to each other. Your process will be assessed on the importance you place on 'attending to meaning.' Your fishbowl is an interactive practice of shared words, symbols, images and felt-experiences. Faster and better learning about yourselves in this 'social space' is a large part of the assessment logic.

“When operating in a global economy, if you want your philosophies, objectives, products and services to be not only understood but also believed by employees, customers and partners in different cultures, you must attend to what these things mean to the people in each culture.” (Hoecklin, p.3)

3. Final: A Self-Reflexive Process 20%

In the final analysis, you’re exploring differences in meanings that exist between group members working together on a particular idea. Your final paper (three pages, double–spaced and written individually) presents your group-experience as a coherent idea. You're obliged to become self-reflexive, suspend preconceptions, and imagine being an alien researcher, come to study the culture of an American group; your fishbowl.

VII. Assessment in the Fishbowl

Education in the Fishbowl is about actively combining challenging and enriching experiences with academic rigor and creative opportunities. Interaction during the semester requires courage to push back boundaries of past experiences and explore the possibilities available to you. In the Fishbowl, you experience the excitement of discovering what you are capable of achieving, far more than you ever felt was possible.

Essential Elements:

* Knowledge

* Concepts

* Skills

* Attitudes

* Action

The student will receive letter grades based upon their activity in the Fishbowl. The composition of these letter grades over the semester will determine your grade for the course.

BEGINNING (B) 

The student has basic knowledge and skills. The student demonstrates responsibility towards learning.

DEVELOPING (D)

The student is acquiring new knowledge and skills and is learning to make conceptual connections in familiar situations.The student is making efforts to demonstrate responsibility towards learning.

ACHIEVING (A)

The student has acquired and applied knowledge and skills and is making conceptual connections in familiar situations, to develop new learning.The student is demonstrating responsibility towards learning and becoming an independent learner.

EXCELLING (E)

The student has begun applying knowledge and skills beyond grade level expectations and has been demonstrating self initiated action in unfamiliar situations.The student has consistently demonstrated self-motivation and independence in learning.

VIII. Fishbowl Learner Profile 

The aim of the Fishbowl is to develop global-minded people who recognize their common humanity and shared guardianship of the planet, helping to create a better and more peaceful world. Fishbowl learners strive to be the following:

1. Inquirers 

We nurture our curiosity, developing skills for inquiry and research.We know how to learn independently and with others. We learn with enthusiasm and sustain our love of learning throughout life.

2. Knowledgeable 

We develop and use conceptual understanding, exploring knowledge across a range of disciplines. We engage with issues and ideas that have local and global significance.

3. Thinkers 

We use critical and creative thinking skills to analyze and take responsible action on complex problems. We exercise initiative in making reasoned, ethical decisions.

4. Communicators 

We express ourselves confidently and creatively in more than one language and in many ways. We collaborate effectively, listening carefully to the perspectives of other individuals and groups.

5. Principled 

We act with integrity and honesty, with a strong sense of fairness and justice, and with respect for the dignity and rights of fishbowl participants.We take responsibility for our actions and their consequences.

6. Open-minded 

We critically appreciate our own cultures and personal histories, as well as the values and traditions of others.We seek and evaluate a range of points of view, and we are willing to grow from the experience.

7. Caring 

We show empathy, compassion and respect. We have a commitment to service, and we act to make a positive difference in the lives of others and in the world around us.

8. Risk-takers 

We approach uncertainty with forethought and determination; we work independently and cooperatively to explore new ideas and innovative strategies. We are resourceful and resilient in the face of challenges and change.

9. Balanced 

We understand the importance of balancing different aspects of our lives, intellectual, physical, and emotional, to achieve well-being for ourselves and others. We recognize our interdependence with other people and with the world in which we live.

10. Reflective 

We thoughtfully consider the world and our own ideas and experience. We work to understand our strengths and weaknesses in order to support our learning and personal development.

Welcome to BUS 448

Addendum

Five Objectives stated by University of Rhode Island:

1. Acquiring skills in working with others as a member of a team.

2. Developing creative capacities (writing, inventing, designing, performing).

3. Developing skill in expressing oneself in writing.

4. Learning how to critically evaluate ideas, arguments, and points of view.

5. Acquiring an interest in learning more by asking questions and seeking answers.

Success requires that you keep pace with the work, understand course concepts, and study effectively. The Academic Enhancement Center (www.uri.edu/aec) is a great place to do this. At the AEC you can work alone or in groups, and tutors and professional learning specialists are available to help you to learn, manage your time and work, and study well. They’re open Monday through Thursday from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. and Fridays until 1 p.m. All services are free (the coffee is free as well!), and no appointment is needed. You can call them for complete information at 874-2367, or just stop by the center on the fourth floor of Roosevelt Hall.

THANK YOU

Subject: SyllabusSpring2020
------------------------------------------------------------
UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION

SPRING, 2020

Instructor: Sanjiv S. Dugal, Ph.D.

Human Resource Management

314 Ballentine Hall

Office hours: WF by Appointment

BUS443: Organizational Design and Change

“Imagination is more important than knowledge. To raise new questions, new possibilities, to regard old

problems from a new angle, requires creative imagination and marks real advance in science.”

Albert Einstein

I. Introduction: Design Thinking

BUS443 is a step-by-step guide for deploying ‘design thinking’ in order to create innovative solutions in your workspace. We define innovation as a viable offering that is new to a specific context and time, creating value for user and provider. 'Design thinking' is a mindset and a method that can be applied to create a new challenge or endeavor among a group of people. Using structured methods for observation, interpretation, reframing, prototyping, and visualizing, you will create a group design that best depicts your imagination.

 

II. Online Interactive Design for Change: The Fishbowl

In groups of three, you will create an online network (known as the Fishbowl). You will be three interacting "knowledge-workers" whose range of learning experience will be determined by the level of engagement with the other's text. In your Fishbowl, you will learn to design an interactive system that produces knowledge and knowing from felt-experiences. The purpose of your design is to create value for users.

III. Reference Textbooks

a. Action Trumps Everything: Creating What You Want in an Uncertain World by Charles F. Kiefer and Leonard A. Schlesinger

with Paul B. Brown. Black Ink Press, 2010.

b. 'Living Text: Letters from the Fishbowl,' College of Business, University of Rhode Island, Spring 2020.

IV. Method in the Fishbowl

Facilitating processes for self-organization is an important part of what you do in the course. The following methodologies are covered: Social Constructivism, Design Thinking, Critical Engagement, Dialog, Reflexivity,

Digital Literacy and Active Learning.

V. Performance: Practice and Commitment

The following four relational practices will directly impact your performance in the course:

1. Communication, i.e., a dialogical exchange of views

2. Collaboration, i.e., interactively creating something

3. Cooperation, i.e., working towards a common goal

4. Contribution, i.e., committing to sharing process

Most of your work is done online and in your own time. However, you'll soon discover that in order to survive, you must show-up,

turn-on and tune-in every time. It is your focused presence that will develop conversation and dialogue in the group, and so you begin

the process of formulating a design. Furthermore, since there are few deadlines in the course, you have an increased responsibility

to each other. You're making a commitment to your group members that you'll be there every time. What is expected of you is to

read and respond to each other in a timely manner.

VI. Assessment: Learning Process and Innovative Outcomes

The basis for evaluating your work is based on your group's Design for bringing about ‘innovative learning outcomes.’ WHAT are

you learning and, HOW are you doing it? It is your learning process, along with learning outcomes that are of interest.

Your Final Design is a Critical Thinking Model whose evaluation is based upon three over-lapping activities during the semester:

a. group dynamics;

b. levels of engagement; and,

c. creating meaning and significance from group interaction.

The cornerstone for evaluating your Design is twofold:

a. Authentic, I.e., is your Design real and true?

b. Transparent, I.e., is your Design visible and self-evident?

In other words, your evaluation and assessment are based upon the following questions:

(a) How do you create a group dynamic that is visible and true?

Answer: By generating and sharing subjectivities, i.e., generating things dependent upon your mind and upon your

perceptions for their existence.

(b) How do you determine levels of engagement in your group that are visible and true?

Answer: By producing new ideas, thoughts and suggestions as to possible courses of action.

© How do you create meaning and significance from your group interaction?

Answer: By expanding your range of experiences, i.e., the range of events and occurrences that leave an

impression on others’ minds.

VII. Grade Distribution

1. 20% Taking and Making Notes

You're setting up a process for taking and making notes. This process is an important one because it involves making decisions and

engaging in thought processes, both inside and outside the classroom. It is Active Learning as note-taking and note-making, i.e.,

you're doing something with the information you're receiving. Active listening and active reading means active learning.

'Summaries, recollections, revisions and focusing are four elements which together constitute Active Learning.'

2. 10% Developing Vocabulary

Your vocabulary is the set of words within 'the language of the course' that becomes familiar to you over the semester. Your

vocabulary will serve as a useful and fundamental tool for communicating and acquiring knowledge during the semester.

Developing an extensive vocabulary is one of the largest challenges in learning anything new.

3. 30% Interpreting Letters

You will receive close to 100 letters from the Instructor during the semester. Whenever a letter points to a certain topic, pay close

attention to it. You are constantly assessing what you're listening and reading and, you're deciding whether it is important enough to

take further and probe deeper.

4. 40% Four Exercises and Final Design

There will be four exercises that you will develop interactively in groups of three, during the period of the course. Your purpose in

completing these exercises is to develop a Critical Thinking Model that encapsulates your "way of doing knowledge."

Your Design (Critical Thinking Model) is then applied to a business situation, selected from the Financial Times on the day of the

exam. This application of your model is your final posting in your fishbowl. It is a group effort, submitted in three pages, typed

double-space.

VIII. Concluding Remarks: Attitude and Motivation

Your attitude and motivation is calibrated by how important you consider the material that you're receiving. When something

resonates, it motivates one to go deeper by discovering the essence of it. However, it is your attitude that holds the key. Active

learning involves sitting in a good posture: slouching makes your brain slouch!

Work is assigned on a daily and a weekly basis and operates like a nested Russian Doll where each doll contains another smaller

doll. Your final document is a group effort and is the smallest doll; 3 pages and typed double-space.

Welcome to BUS443

In Business & Society (345) you were concerning yourselves with individual, concrete felt-experiences. You were whatever you chose to make of yourself at every moment during the course. You were free and therefore responsible for everything you did and every felt-experience you had.

Hi Julia,

Thank you for raising the question. The matter is not entirely settled as yet. Next week Troiano will come to class, and we will discuss it then. 

There should be something due, but not be in the nature of an exam. It will be online, short, nothing you can’t do, will not require preparation as such, but allow time to reflect, and it will not conflict with individual travel, so please confirm your plans.

In other words, there will be a closure, a good bye of some sort. A self reflexive exercise. It might have to do with friendship, I don’t know. I haven’t thought that far. Considered opinions are always welcome. I might ask you to write a letter to each other about each other.

Those who get the drift of the fishbowl will have no difficulty, and others too will be able to handle it. We are only to create value together.

I hope that helps. Go with the flow is the metaphor these days. And a reminder: to read slow is to move fast.

Sanjiv
