Date: 11/26/2019 14:42:54
Subject: Self-Referential Design and Action Research (443)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Wishing you all a wonderful break for Thanksgiving. 

Stay close to text in your fishbowls during this time, because you're creating meaning. 

You're using the standard tools of Active Learning and Action Research. Please google.

As we hurtle towards the horizon, you are doing splendidly, for the most part. 

The ending is an exercise on Self-Referencing. It is known as Referential Thinking as well.

You are making a Self-Referential Design. Please google.

I understand it as turning around and looking and re-arranging what I see.

You are giving me hard copies on the last day of class, which I believe is Dec.4.

It is a “reflexive" exercise, and you must have its process under your belt. 

Google and construct your understanding of “reflexivity.” Base it upon your fishbowl experience.

Please post this over the break.

Having done the 10+1 four times, you are giving me the following on 12/4.

1. A list of 16 sentences that you constructed, along with your group. Identify names. (1page for the group)

2. Individually, you are to select 15 words from the 16 sentences above, and sort them into 5 categories.

In other words, every individual is giving me 5 boxes, with 2+1 words in each box. Plus, a sentence for each box: Five structures. 

(That will be 3 pages, one for each individual)

Finally,

A collaborative Design through interaction and dialog, consisting the same: 5 boxes, each with 2+1 words, and 5 sentence structures. (1 page)

And

A metaphorical Title for your Group’s Design. (1page)

It will be 6 pages all together, given by the group, stapled and due on 12/4.

Once again, the following 6 pages are due:

1. 16 sentences (Group's page)

2. 15 selected words, sorted in 5 boxes and 5 sentence constructions (individual's page)

3. Final model done through interaction and dialog: 5 boxes and 5 sentences (group's page)

4. Metaphorical title (group's page).

It is pretty straightforward, I would think. The challenge and struggle is to construct and create structures that are meaningful space for interpretation.

And you will receive the title: Designer & Catalyst. 

But did you create value? That is to be determined on the day of the final exam.

Sanjiv

Date: 11/26/2019 0:39:06
Subject: Relationships, not just parts
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I am going to shift my attention to your design process in 443, and ask you to reflect upon my letters keeping your postings in your fishbowls in mind.

Each part in a symbiotic system is made stronger by its relationship to other parts. Think of your selected words. To connect symbiotically is to link parts to parts, make parts into systems, and join systems to other systems.

Your fishbowls are part of a symbiotic system! Please be sure to understand this. It is about relationships not just parts.

Sanjiv

SYMBIOTIC, SYSTEM, PART, CONNECT, RELATIONSHIP

C: 345

From the fishbowl...

Letter Reflections: Emily Orr

9/10/19

"Emotions are evoked by Text and Images." - Dugal

Humans can have a emotional connection to the text they read or images they see especially if it reminds them of something in their personal lives.

Last edited by emilyorr on Wed Sep 18, 2019 7:57 am, edited 1 time in total.

sharing what we 'see' when we read

Post by emilyorr »

"connecting across differences is the way forward into the future."

We must learn to accept others' points of view if we are to collaborate with them even if the shared experiences or understandings differ.

Last edited by emilyorr on Wed Sep 18, 2019 7:57 am, edited 1 time in total.

a designer's notes

"Designers love questions, but what they really love is ‘reframing' questions"

Viewing what already exists in a different light can bring someone on an entirely new journey and open their mind to other possibilities.

Last edited by emilyorr on Wed Sep 18, 2019 7:57 am, edited 1 time in total.

logistics

"Socially Reflexive"

It is important to reflect upon what has been done especially in relationships with others to learn from shared experience.

Last edited by emilyorr on Wed Sep 18, 2019 7:57 am, edited 1 time in total.

Re-structuring again

"Courage must always be applauded."

Courage is a core value that is good for everyone to posses and therefore should be acknowledged and applauded when demonstrated to inspire those witnessing it.

Reading the other's posting

"It’s an addiction of chasing something else..."

In this fast-paced world, many cannot help but look to what is next when instead they should be savoring the current moment in time.

Thinking about metaphor

"The film depicts a mechanistic organization"

The film showed that those with this mechanical way of thought were too afraid to push boundaries and attempt or accept something new.

New forms of intimacy and friendship

"the development of some form of friendship is inherent in success."

Connections are the bridge from where someone currently stands to a path that leads to a successful future.

Being in a state of Becoming

"Scott was moving out of the machine metaphor (way of thinking and doing) and picking up new symbols (word-images) from Grandma’s metaphor, where the rhythm, she explains, is in the heartbeat ("listen to the rhythm") and not in perfectly rendered steps."

Scott realized that being a person that followed the machine metaphor was no longer in line with what he wished to be so with the help of important people he interacted with, he learned how to change his ways and no longer "follow the crowd". It was helpful for him to see others with an understanding that there is no "right" way of thinking or doing.

Learning is an Act of Courage

"In a digital environment, we create structures. "

In our fishbowls, we are expressing our thoughts and symbols (words) that we possess. In doing so, when we read each others work, our body of knowledge grows and thus builds upon itself forming this structure. Together, we are all key components in this digital space. The more that information is shared, the more we can learn from each other.

creating and constructing knowledge content

"Your text in the fishbowl is nascent and in a state of formation"

The beginning of the fishbowl postings still show potential for improvement and as time goes on and as more is contributed, they will blossom into what they should be. I am still learning how to make my postings, but I feel that with each class and learning from my groups work, I am grasping a better understanding.

Sharing the World: Reading your social meeting reflections

“We cannot share the world as it already is, with the exception of the natural world. The world that we can share is always and still to be elaborated by us and between us starting from the perception and affirmation of what and who we are as humans here and now." -Luce Irigaray

The structure of our world is constantly forming and changing. It is not black and white and is based on each individual and how they go through life.

Date: 11/24/2019 13:31:05
Subject: looking at ourselves again
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Sandra Chu,

Thank you for your well-considered suggestions regarding the abstracts. I am keeping a distance before I return, and will do so then.

I wanted to make the following points after swimming in the labyrinth that is your fishbowls... 

1. You are "developing technologies of lived abstraction." (Simondon) 

Concepts must be experienced. They are to be lived. How so? You do so by looking at processes of subjective and social emergence. Like you are doing in your fishbowls.

2. Your aim is to catch new thought and action, forming at a creative crossing. For instance, you have formed thought and experienced the following crossings: universal/particular; general/specific; abstract/concrete; global/local; collective/individual; mental/physical; feminine/masculine.

3. You understood things like: structures, felt-experiences, form and content, perceptual categories and word-images, dichotomies and social relations.

You explored how these facets come together---how they form, how they reverberate, and how they move by their difference.

Congratulations! You are in preparation for taking on anything and everything.

Sanjiv

Post by sandrachu » Fri Nov 22, 2019 5:39 pm

"Workplace Friendship: A Social Reflexive Exercise" letter

"Our paper presents an interactive method of ‘reading’ and ‘writing’ which we found useful for learning about each other." I like this phrase. It may also be beneficial in the future to encourage replying to other students' posts. This would then feel more like a blog where interaction between all users in the Fishbowl is possible, not just within our respective groups.

"2nd Abstract: In the beginning" letter

"This has two complementary components: we used the world outside the group as a resource for learning and, we used this information to make a positive impact inside the group." In later parts of the paper, it would be nice to add examples of exactly how a positive impact has occurred within the groups.

"Framing the second abstract" letter

"The goal is to understand what we are writing, and to construct meaning from it. Does it have value? To whom and for how much?" To me, the value is in how our words have changed each other. While it is hard to quantify, the change exists.

"How it looks" letter

"In a public and expressive space called the Fishbowl, we showed ourselves to our selves." I think this sentence may need to be reworded. It sounds a bit off.

"Take a break, then The Return of the Jedi" letter

The paper looks good so far. The ideas have been elaborated upon in more depth than in the last letter's version. I particularly liked this sentence: "Clearly, functioning effectively as a team is far more valuable than any individual achievement. Our paper makes a difference by restructuring the experience away from individual fact acquisition towards team-building experiences." The focus on group work in this course has been nice. We may also want to talk about the negative effects - how groups with team members that are not cooperative are doing.

"Finally, the second submission" letter

Under the "Methodology" section, #4 is listed as #3 (there are two #3s). Otherwise, the rest looks good with the new edits to sourcing and the addition of the "Outcome" section.

"Abstracts and authorship" letter

I am happy to have been chosen as one of the co-authors! I look forward to seeing the final version of the paper, along with the results of our work in the Fishbowl.

Date: 11/23/2019 15:51:41
Subject: selection, substitution, satisfaction
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I have often said this, but it is good to remind myself as a daily ritual. Whenever you change the way you think, you change your life.

To change the way you think requires words and images: vocabulary, selection, substitution.

To use new words is to interpret the old anew.

Our selection of words is often the problem, and it is words alone that will solve it; whether you do it yourself or pay someone else.

I’ve begun reading your fishbowls in-depth. If I missed some one entirely for the authorship, please email me. Please note, I stopped looking at my uri address (I was being harassed by admin.) and only open my gmail account, in order to devote my mind entirely to the fishbowl. I changed my metaphor: You’re not students but an audience and it is my performance in the moment and your satisfaction that is at stake. 

Sanjiv

SUBSTITUTION, ANEW, SATISFACTION, PERFORMANCE, AUDIENCE

Good morning Everyone,

The two Abstracts and the authors are copied below. The names are not in any order, and they are equally divided between the two abstracts.

Several things.

1. The Abstracts will undergo Blind Review, and we will know our fate on 12/17. If accepted, the full length Final paper will be due on 1/7.

2. There are about 35 students whose names have not been included at this stage.

And, there are another 20 students who barely made the cut.

I will closely be watching your performance in your fishbowls until 12/17. 

I will have an opportunity to include or exclude your names at that time.

There is time, and you have a window of opportunity.

3. I am anxious, and most interested in including all names. Why so? It’s just that when your work “touches” me, I am compelled to “touch” you back. We don’t have to do this, if we don’t reach out and touch each other!

Sanjiv

WORKPLACE FRIENDSHIP: A SOCIAL REFLEXIVE EXERCISE 

Abstract details | Authors details | Abstract Preview | Printer Friendly Preview

WORKPLACE FRIENDSHIP: A SOCIAL REFLEXIVE EXERCISE

S. Dugal1, S. Singh2, M. Troiano3, R. Singh4, Z. Fontes1, Z. Buckley1, B. Bolofsky1, S. Schultheiss1, E. Orr1, H. Nathanson1, J. Milder1, B. Higgins1, C. Ciccone1, N. Faiss1, N. McGowan1, K. Naranjo1, C. Xiao1, C. Pihery1, J. Young1, L. Sneyd1, M. Oppliger1, C. Machado1, J. Downing1, C. Crawford1, D. Chagnon1, K. Bergantine1, V. Baez1, I. Moak1, J. Day1, B. Hoang1, J. Watson1, E. Tan1, M. Osmanski1, N. McGowan1, C. Holmes1, S. Wynne1, S. Dwyer1, S. Dolan1, A. DeGiacomo1, M. Cole1, V. Cheslo1, A. Capasso1, L. Benco1, K. Blake1, J. Asselin1, M. Beck1, C. Allen1

1 University of Rhode Island (UNITED STATES)

2 Savvymatters (UNITED STATES)

3 Verizon (UNITED STATES)

4 RLStudios (INDIA)

sanjivdugal@uri.edu, shivsingh@gmail.com, michael.troiano1@verizon.net, rahousingh@gmail.com, zachary_fontes@my.uri.edu, zachary_buckley@my.uri.edu, brooke_bolofsky@my.uri.edu, sschultheiss22@my.uri.edu, emilyorr6@my.uri.edu, hmnathanson@my.uri.edu, juell_milder@my.uri.edu, bhiggins98@my.uri.edu, crciccone@my.uri.edu, nicole_faiss@my.uri.edu, nathan_mcgowan@my.uri.edu, kylenaranjo@my.uri.edu, chengna_xiao@my.uri.edu, charlene_pihery@my.uri.edu, jaeyoung627@my.uri.edu, lindsay_sneyd@my.uri.edu, moppliger@my.uri.edu, colbymachado7@my.uri.edu, joedowning@my.uri.edu, clara_crawford@my.uri.edu, daniel_chagnon@my.uri.edu, kbergantine@my.uri.edu, itsavibe@my.uri.edu, isaiahmoak@gmail.com, dayj2102@gmail.com, hoangngocgb12@gmail.com, jessica.watson1011@gmail.com, liztan01@yahoo.com, mattosmanski8@gmail.com, natem12345@gmail.com, coryjayh@gmail.com, samanthamwynne@gmail.com, samanthadwyer03@gmail.com, shannondolan16@aol.com, adegiacomo@my.uri.ed, mcmooka97@gmail.com, vchrischeslo@gmail.com, aecapasso@yahoo.com, ludvik_benco@hotmail.com, blakekelly17@gmail.com, josh.asselin@yahoo.com, beckhockey022@gmail.com, cleo101198@my.uri.edu

Introduction: what we did:

Friendship in the workplace is an important social phenomenon. Our paper presents a social reflexive exercise for initiating and developing ‘workplace friendship.’ Studies on ‘friendship’ show it is diverse and complex, even ambiguous in nature. Among the many issues friendship raises, we believe it existed among us whenever enough threads of intellectual exchange and reciprocated sentiment were present. In our opinion, this entitled our relationship to be termed "workplace friendship." We are business students at the University of Rhode Island. In groups of three, 135 participants formed 45 groups. Each group held a Social Meeting outside the workplace to have an open-ended conversation. Workplace issues were taboo. The social meeting experience was made of feelings and images, and we began to notice and give them form with our words. We crafted word structures, aphorisms, imagery, comparisons, awareness of detail, and playful juxtaposition. Our raison d’etre as a group was the dictum: ‘looking at you looking at me looking at you.’ This amounted to turning around to ‘look’ at our postings; the proverbial Return. We entered the invisible world where light and dark, inside and outside meet; where language became magical and our sentences expressed more than words could say. Our underlying goal was to shift group-dynamics from a competitive to a collaborative mode of thinking during this ‘friendship.'

Methodology: how we did it:

We used self-reflection to explore anecdotal and personal experience of a social meeting and connected our ‘autoethnographic’ content to wider cultural and social meanings and understandings. Our paper presents an interactive method of ‘reading’ and ‘writing’ which we found useful for learning about each other. Specifically, our method elicited textual material regarding attitudes and motivations towards the event that are not adequately elicited by other methods. After the Social Meeting, in seven choreographed steps, every individual generated text and word-images of their conversation and experience and posted on an electronic bill-board called, The Fishbowl. The methodologies underlying our process were the following: participant-observation, symbolic interactionism and social reflexivity. 

Conclusion: what did we learn:

1. By sharing experiences and vignettes from our lives, we saw some of the possibilities that text and images can create.

2. A sympathy and understanding developed and a definite personal relationship was formed and acknowledged. 

3. The tolerance, trust, and sharing of private thoughts we offered each other were of great value in getting a sense of identity for oneself in the group. 

4. Our interactions were interior maps. When we apprehended these maps, these stories, these patterns—-we awoke a new perspective and new possibilities.

5. Friendship is a choice, something you can try on and wear. When we put on the hat and coat of friendship, we incline towards success. 

6. Unless we learn to revise our inner storytelling and let ourselves be seen, we will continue to keep ourselves from friendship with the stories we tell ourselves. 

7. We learnt that in a safe, free setting, surrounded by words, any one can write ‘friendship’ into their working lives—-often very good ones. 

Keywords: REFLEXIVITY, WORKPLACE FRIENDSHIP

ENGAGEMENT AND EXPRESSION: CONSTRUCTING MEANINGFUL KNOWLEDGE-CONTENT 

Abstract details | Authors details | Abstract Preview | Printer Friendly Preview

ENGAGEMENT AND EXPRESSION: CONSTRUCTING MEANINGFUL KNOWLEDGE-CONTENT

S. Dugal1, S. Singh2, M. Troiano3, R. Singh4, S. Chu1, J. Pusateri1, A. Lopes1, B. Rexter1, M. Falaye1, A. Melby1, E. Milich1, A. Coristine1, A. Audate1, M. Barry1, M. Thibodeau1, N. Katchen1, N. Gustafson1, J. Hausherr1, P. Costanzo1, A. Symons1, Q. Logan1, B. Schiffer1, C. Sousa1, C. Rigoliosi1, M. Hernandez1, K. Kertanis1, O. Salvucci1, R. Reynolds1, J. Repoza1, M. Restrepo1, C. Regalbuto1, J. Trovato1, D. Garcia1, N. Farrales1, J. St.Onge1, E. Flynn1, R. Stone1, M. Howe1, J. Underwood1, N. Stephenson1, M. Volpe1, N. Mollicone1, Z. Katzen1, F. Bahre1, M. Waleyko1, S. Rosa1, I. Olczak1, N. Middrup1, M. Halloran1, J. Gibbons1, O. Costello1, P. Capece1

1 University of Rhode Island (UNITED STATES)

2 Savvymatters (UNITED STATES)

3 Verizon (UNITED STATES)

4 RLStudios (INDIA)

sanjivdugal@uri.edu, shivsingh@gmail.com, michael.troiano1@verizon.net, rahoulsingh@gmail.com, sandrac@my.uri.edu, jpusateri@my.uri.edu, alopes98@my.uri.edu, brett_rexter@my.uri.edu, michael_falaye@my.uri.edu, anna_melby@my.uri.edu, emily_milich@my.uri.edu, akcoristine@my.uri.edu, alain_audate@my.uri.edu, meghan_barry@my.uri.edu, marie_thibodeau@my.uri.edu, natalie_katchen@my.uri.edu, ngustafson28@my.uri.edu, julia_hausherr@my.uri.edu, paige_costanzo@my.uri.edu, annie_symons@my.uri.edu, lahquasialogan@my.uri.edu, bschiffer@my.uri.edu, csousa4@my.uri.edu, craig_rigoliosi@my.uri.edu, hernandezma@my.uri.edu, kkertanis@my.uri.edu, oliviasalvucci@my.uri.edu, raivon_reynolds@my.uri.du, jacob_repoza@my.uri.edu, mrestrepo2@my.uri.edu, cregalbuto@my.uri.edu, juliaatrovato@my.uri.edu, darlingg1998@my.uri.edu, nicole_farrales@my.uri.edu, john_stonge@my.uri.edu, eric_flynn@my.uri.edu, ryan_stone1@my.uri.edu, maxwell_howe@my.uri.edu, junderwood93@my.uri.edu, noah_stephenson@my.uri.edu, mcvolpe95@gmail.com, nickmollicone@gmail.com, zackk23@comcast.net, fraser_bahre@my.uri.edu, matthew_waleyko@my.uri.edu, srosa1997@hotmail.com, isabellaolczak@gmail.com, nikmidd@web.de, mhallojr2@gmail.com, jgibbons@my.uri.edu, oliviacostello5@gmail.com, pcapece33@gmail.com

Introduction:

We are 120 undergraduates in the College of Business at the University of Rhode Island. In groups of three, we set out to understand the meaning of Complex Adaptive Systems (1) over a period of two weeks in digital space, we called The Fishbowl (2). We found that when constructing meaningful knowledge-content, our effectiveness increased whenever we “engaged” with text and, “expressed” our reflections to each other. As knowledge-workers constructing meaning, our underlying purpose was to add value to the group’s knowing of the subject matter. In sequential steps, our paper presents one group’s journey into their understanding of Complex Adaptive Systems and, constructing meaning for themselves about it. 

1. We define ‘engagement’ as “conveying interaction with text outside the group to each other inside the group” (3).This has two complementary components: we used the world outside the group as a resource for learning and, we used this information to make a positive impact inside the group. 

2. We define ‘expressiveness’ as “the public display of symbols or enactment of symbolic action for performative effect” (4). 

Methodology:

1. We present 10+1 steps as a way of linking theory and practice so that knowledge can be action based and derived from practice in the real world as opposed to being generated through abstract survey methods. 

2. Our method is best described as sorting, sifting and selecting from word-pools to create and construct understandings about the subject matter.

3. Our method is one of abstracting, framing and interpreting text in a social situation; the Fishbowl. 

3. Our approach to understanding the subject matter belongs to the social-constructionist school of thought. The idea under-pinning this approach is understanding how knowledge has an unfolding transformative potential and, how the images and ideas we hold of ourselves as knowledge-workers has fundamental impact on how our knowing unfolds in the group. The underlying assumption is the belief that we do make and shape our understanding of the world and have the ability to do so anew. 

Outcome:

1. We are 40 groups, three individuals each. In digital space, called the Fishbowl, “we showed ourselves to ourselves” (5). Every individual played an active role when interpreting the subject matter. As active agents (6), we selected symbols and framed interpretations in 10+1 steps from our own standpoint. Both engagement and expression became performances, that is, “interpretive events.” 

2. Organizations have learnt that chasing numbers does not translate into productivity and that linear thinking is archaic. Clearly, functioning effectively as a team is far more valuable than any individual achievement. Our paper makes a difference by restructuring the experience away from individual fact acquisition towards team-building experiences.

3. We see our understanding of the subject matter not as radically new but as recognizing kinship within the group, as well as differences between groups.

References:

[1] Bartlett and Ghoshal, “Managing Across Borders,” (1989).

[2] Howard Rheingold, “Net Smart,” (2014)

[3] Mark Allen Peterson, “Anthropology and Mass Communication,” (2005).

[4] William O. Beeman, “Culture, Performance and Communication in Iran,” (1982).

[5] Clifford Geertz, “The Interpretation of Cultures,” (1973).

[6] John Dewey, “How We Think,” (1933).

Keywords: Action Research, Knowledge-Content, Creativity, Social Constructivism

Subject: finally, the second submission

Hi Everyone,

Engagement and Expression: Constructing Meaningful Knowledge-Content

Introduction

We are 120 undergraduates in the College of Business at the University of Rhode Island. In groups of three, we set out to understand the meaning of Complex Adaptive Systems (1) over a period of two weeks in digital space, we called The Fishbowl (2). We found that when constructing meaningful knowledge-content, our effectiveness increased whenever we “engaged” with text and, “expressed” our reflections to each other. As knowledge-workers constructing meaning, our underlying purpose was to add value to the group’s knowing of the subject matter. In sequential steps, our paper presents one group’s journey into their understanding of Complex Adaptive Systems and, constructing meaning for themselves about it. 

1. We define ‘engagement’ as “conveying interaction with text outside the group to each other inside the group” (3).This has two complementary components: we used the world outside the group as a resource for learning and, we used this information to make a positive impact inside the group. 

2. We define ‘expressiveness’ as “the public display of symbols or enactment of symbolic action for performative effect” (4). 

Methodology

1. We present 10+1 steps as a way of linking theory and practice so that knowledge can be action based and derived from practice in the real world as opposed to being generated through abstract survey methods. 

2. Our method is best described as sorting, sifting and selecting from word-pools to create and construct understandings about the subject matter.

3. Our method is one of abstracting, framing and interpreting text in a social situation; the Fishbowl. 

3. Our approach to understanding the subject matter belongs to the social-constructionist school of thought. The idea under-pinning this approach is understanding how knowledge has an unfolding transformative potential and, how the images and ideas we hold of ourselves as knowledge-workers has fundamental impact on how our knowing unfolds in the group. The underlying assumption is the belief that we do make and shape our understanding of the world and have the ability to do so anew. 

Outcome

1. We are 40 groups, three individuals each. In digital space, called the Fishbowl, “we showed ourselves to ourselves” (5). Every individual played an active role when interpreting the subject matter. As active agents (6), we selected symbols and framed interpretations in 10+1 steps from our own standpoint. Both engagement and expression became performances, that is, “interpretive events.” 

2. Organizations have learnt that chasing numbers does not translate into productivity and that linear thinking is archaic. Clearly, functioning effectively as a team is far more valuable than any individual achievement. Our paper makes a difference by restructuring the experience away from individual fact acquisition towards team-building experiences.

3. We see our understanding of the subject matter not as radically new but as recognizing kinship within the group, as well as differences between groups.

References

1. Bartlett and Ghoshal, “Managing Across Borders,” (1989).

2. Howard Rheingold, “Net Smart,” (2014)

3. Mark Allen Peterson, “Anthropology and Mass Communication,” (2005).

4. William O. Beeman, “Culture, Performance and Communication in Iran,” (1982).

5. Clifford Geertz, “The Interpretation of Cultures,” (1973).

6. John Dewey, “How We Think,” (1933).

Engagement and Expressiveness: Constructing Meaningful Knowledge-Content

Introduction

We are 120 undergraduates in the College of Business at the University of Rhode Island. In groups of three, we set out to understand the meaning of Complex Adaptive Systems over a period of two weeks in digital space, we called The Fishbowl. We found that when constructing meaningful knowledge-content, our effectiveness increased whenever we “engaged” with text and “expressed” our reflections to each other. As knowledge-workers constructing meaning, our underlying purpose was to add value to the group’s knowing of the subject matter. In sequential steps, our paper presents one group’s journey into their understanding of Complex Adaptive Systems and, constructing meaning for themselves around it. 

1. We define ‘engagement’ as “conveying interaction with text outside the group to each other inside the group.” This has two complementary components: we used the world outside the group as a resource for learning and, we used this information to make a positive impact inside the group. 

2. We define ‘expressiveness’ as “the public display of symbols or enactment of symbolic action for performative effect.” (William O. Beeman, 1982: xiii). 

Methodology

1. We present 10+1 steps as a way of linking theory and practice so that knowledge can be action based and derived from practice in the real world as opposed to being generated through abstract survey methods. 

2. Our method is best described as sorting, sifting and selecting from word-pools to create and construct understandings about the subject matter.

3. Our method is one of abstracting, framing and interpreting text in a social situation; the Fishbowl. 

3. Our approach to understanding the subject matter belongs to the social-constructionist school of thought. The idea under-pinning this approach is understanding how knowledge has an unfolding transformative potential and, how the images and ideas we hold of ourselves as knowledge-workers has fundamental impact on how our knowing unfolds in the group. The underlying assumption is the belief that we do make and shape our understanding of the world and have the ability to do so anew. 

Conclusion

1. We are 40 groups, three individuals each. In digital space, called the Fishbowl, “we showed ourselves to ourselves” (Cliff Geertz) when understanding the concept, Complex Adaptive Systems. Every individual played an active role when interpreting the subject matter. As active agents, we selected symbols and framed interpretations in 10+1 steps from our own standpoint. Both engagement and expression became performances, that is, “interpretive events.” 

2. Organizations have learnt that chasing numbers does not translate into productivity and that linear thinking is archaic. Clearly, functioning effectively as a team is far more valuable than any individual achievement. Our paper makes a difference by restructuring the experience away from individual fact acquisition towards team-building experiences.

3. We see our understanding of the subject matter not as radically new but as recognizing kinship within the group, as well as differences between groups.

Subject: final design models due 12/4
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Individually, you are selecting 15 words from 16 sentence structures that you made in your groups.

Your individual model is going to be 3 words in 5 boxes = 15 words.

And, it will have 5 sentence structures, one for each box and made from the three words.

You will make a final group model after consulting each other as a group. This too will be the same: 5 boxes, 3 words in each box, and 5 sentence structures.

It will be a mixture of your individual models.

Your modeling in all its simplicity is an approach to understanding the social reality of your fishbowls and is an approach to change. This approach belongs to the social-constructionist school of thought (please google), please bear that in mind. It is under-pinned by the idea that your awareness and knowledge have an unfolding transformative potential and that the images and ideas you hold of yourselves and your world have a fundamental impact on how your realities unfold.

UNFOLDING TRANSFORMATIVE POTENTIAL...THAT IS HOW I SEE AND EXPERIENCE YOU.

Your final model is due on Dec. 4th. Enjoy the doing of it, as much as I enjoy viewing it, and don’t worry about getting it right because you’d be barking up the wrong tree, metaphorically speaking. I loved your hard copies. Thank you and good luck with it.

Sanjiv

Good morning Everyone,

For class today, please come prepared to work in your groups and in your fishbowls. Please note the following four quotes by Mary Catherine Bateson (please google). You are asked to select two and begin working on them. At the same time, I will be working on our conference abstracts, particularly the second one. The deadline for submission is tomorrow mid-night. So I have until then. This morning I will spend reading your hardcopies and your fishbowls.

Looking at where we have arrived at this point in the semester: I trust the symbiotic relations among us will be apparent and keenly felt in class today. If this is not true for you, then you need to start over. There is time enough. I think what it takes is known as Active Learning among us. Please be sure to google that term.

The four sentences (projects) below are pretty intense. Select two. I think many of you are up for the challenge. I never underestimate you, and I remain conscious of your circumstances all the time.

(1) Sameness and difference are a matter of context and point of view, change and continuity often two sides of the same coin. 

(2) We can only make sense of the relationship between change and constancy by thinking of them in layers one flowing under or over or within the other, at different levels of abstraction: superficial change within profound continuity, and superficial continuity within profound change.

(3) The responsive eye enlivens the vista to which it responds; the play of imagination is one way of enriching and conserving the natural world.

(4) Lessons too complex to grasp in a single occurrence spiral past again and again, small examples gradually revealing greater and greater implications.

See you at 3.

Sanjiv

Text that evokes images?

How so?

Every word evokes an image along with an attitude, a feeling.

How so?

Images that the word evokes are culturally determined.

How so? 

Layers of meaning, accumulated over years. Sanjiv is a Cowboy!

Doesn’t fit.

How so?

Sitting in the midst of our complexity, aware of every individual’s unique perception and potential is the reason it is 'good to see you again.’

It is not just what we are saying in our fishbowls, it is also how we are saying it and, what we are doing: we are creating inter-subjective spaces among us;

creating societies. We're unique, we’re diverse, we're innovative, we're emergent, we're nascent, we're developing, we're growing; and, we’re of value, of potential, of opportunity.

Hi Everyone,

This coming week, I'm going to tune (motivate) myself for writing the Abstracts. This email is the start of the process: where and when I declared my intentions. 

We’re going online next week. No scheduled class. During the week, I will be sharing the evolution, the emergence, the appearance of the Abstracts. Every change, every sentence, every possibility will be sent to you for scrutiny. Right now, I’m fuzzy about the topics. One was on friendship, and the other one? I have to open the files. 

The Abstracts will evolve, morph and become something else. Let me put it another way. Our product is virtual, and it is perceived in a visual culture. The product is self-generated and sustainable. The product is symbolically interactive, where we're looking at each other. The Abstracts are self-reflexive (looking at oneself) and, the product is built upon participation and observation.

Next week, please fact-check the above in your fishbowls. Your A is at stake. 

The way you fact-check is by pointing, by citing, by showing, by admitting where and when it happened. 

Fact-checking is known as "investigative journalism.” Please google the term.

In digital space we produce investigative reports where symbolic interaction, self-reflection, participation and observation are key. 

Any thing outside this, is part of “instrumentality.” Please google the term.

Sanjiv

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 11/8/2019 19:54:36
Subject: cybernetics and your fishbowls
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

"The new is terrifying. Not because it is this way and not another way, but because it is new.” Vilem Flusser, please google.

Your fishbowls are something new. They are your creations and they take on complex forms. “Complex,” in the instance of your fishbowl signifies that there is no substantial reason for differentiating between the 10+1 algorithm and yourself, the user. The 10+1 algorithm functions only in terms of the function of the user, and the user functions only in terms of the function of the 10+1 algorithm. Both exist only through their relationship to each other. Each makes the other’s existence possible, and each defines the other.

That is to say, in your fishbowls, it is not only what you are doing, it is what is happening and, what is becoming you and your fishbowl.

How did you make this happen? By grasping things as structure, multidimensional, pictorial. Please confirm. You are never linear nor reproduce a textbook. Instead, you are reflecting about structures and processes in a phenomenological manner. You are seeing how a structure can be changed, from the outside, from below, from above. Fundamentally, your fishbowl is an attempt to codify the world in such a manner that it can be described cybernetically, in all of its inexplicable complexity and, is thus given meaning.

I hope you can see this about your fishbowls. Your fishbowl is a piece of art and a never ending work-in-process. Until the bell rings. Congratulations!

Sanjiv

Date: 11/8/2019 0:35:21
Subject: constructing social memories (345)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Your learning (10+1) is a synthesis. 

In the light of digital technologies, like your fishbowls, your synthesis (10+1) is a constructed social memory.

Please think about that. 

You have understood synthesis in the Kantian sense of “putting together different representations and grasping what is manifold in one [act of knowledge].”

What Synthesis demands from you is the active unification of parts (10+1) in contrast to an unconscious or mechanical repetition. 

To remember something (like your anecdote) is always a reconstruction in which the fragmented past and the projected future are brought into the present.

Your learning in the fishbowl synthesizes the past, present and future and constructs a social memory among you. 

Paulo Freire (please google) called it “creating history as possibility.”

Congratulations! You are in the nascent stage of ‘becoming’ (Deleuze) something else. Please think of a business, or an organization, or a group like your fishbowl in these terms.

Sanjiv

SYNTHESIS, SOCIAL, MEMORY, FRAGMENT, MANIFOLD, UNIFICATION, CONSTRUCT, NASCENT

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 11/7/2019 22:05:24
Subject: recounting anecdotes and honoring lived experiences
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

You are experimenting with your writing. You recount an anecdote and then attempt to “read” that account for the theoretical insights it affords. You are doing this upside down. You are starting with a theoretical and abstract statement and then “fitting" the anecdote, thereby constructing a meaningful reality; a vignette, an episode, an event. A story line.

Your anecdotes become “interesting” precisely for their ability to intervene in contemporary theoretical debates. “Anecdote” and “theory” carry diametrically opposed connotations: humorous vs. serious, short vs. grand, trivial vs. overarching, specific vs. general. Your fishbowls cut through these oppositions and produces theory which honors the details of your lived experience. The key word here is honors. You honor your lived experiences.

Please think about it.

Sanjiv

ANECDOTE, THEORIZING, RECOUNT, HONOR, EXPERIENCE

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 11/7/2019 15:22:53
Subject: Reorienting One's Vision: The Return
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

By finishing the first exercise of 10+1, the best comment that I can make is “always return to the site.” It is to the look that you are returning. When you don’t do that, you are avoiding deep learning. By this avoidance, you are turning away from the world and this is definitionally a visual event. This is an important point to be aware of. I didn’t cook it up.

It is a visual event whenever we return to look. Why must we return? What if we don’t? What are we gaining-losing by returning and taking a look again?

By returning, you are reorienting, --- or more precisely, the disorientation --- of vision. Let me put it in another way, since you have begun abstracting in your fishbowls: “To abandon the domain of phenomenal forms is quite simply, to lose one’s sight.”

Please fact check in your fishbowls. Particularly as human resource designers. It is a process of looking and reorienting your vision. And every time it is an “event.”

And this is the journey, the trajectory, the narrative, the story of our lives.

Sanjiv

It is a visual event whenever we return to look. Why must we return? What if we don’t? What are we gaining-losing by returning and taking a look again?

By returning, you are reorienting, --- or more precisely, the disorientation --- of vision. Let me put it in another way, since you have begun abstracting in your fishbowls: “To abandon the domain of phenomenal forms is quite simply, to lose one’s sight.”

Please fact check in your fishbowls. Particularly as human resource designers. It is a process of looking and reorienting your vision. And every time it is an “event.”

And this is the journey, the trajectory, the narrative, the story of our lives.

Sanjiv

LOOK, VISION, SIGHT, RETURN, SITE, REORIENT, EVENT, PHENOMENAL, FORM, DOMAIN

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 11/6/2019 16:08:32
Subject: storm as metaphor for your creative process
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

To create means to make, to produce, or cause to grow. In other words, when something is created, it comes into existence. This means it is something new. You are to create a design, and the light is not yet visible at the end of the tunnel. Right now, for the next three weeks you are creating a storm of ideas which are gathering direction, force, and intention from your particular situation. It is dynamic: it starts, stops, rages in one moment and abates the next, ebbs and flows. These are all characteristics of a storm (metaphor). Storms arise out of disturbance, and act to displace and destabilize. Same as you are doing.

Like a storm, your creative process is continuously in motion. Both are shaped by their conditions, just as their conditions shape them. They take in from their situations, producing and depleting again and again. The consequences of a storm and creativity are real, and specific. They are found in the exchange that happens between the world, creator, and those with whom the creation interacts. This may be the viewer of your work, recipient of an idea, patient receiving the novel treatment, dweller in the built house, user of an artifact, and so on. Creation is, in this respect, truly “in the (mind’s) eyes of the beholder,” and principal consequence of the process is transformation.

Sanjiv

DISCLOSE, OWN

https://courses.lumenlearning.com/introliterature/chapter/reader-response-criticism-suggested-replacement/

Reader-Response Criticism In Brief

Reader-response criticism is a school of literary theory that focuses on the reader (or “audience”) and their experience of a literary work, in contrast to other schools and theories that focus attention primarily on the author or the content and form of the work.

Person reading behind a building columnAlthough literary theory has long paid some attention to the reader’s role in creating the meaning and experience of a literary work, modern reader-response criticism began in the 1960s and ’70s, particularly in the US and Germany, in work by Norman Holland, Stanley Fish, Wolfgang Iser, Hans-Robert Jauss, Roland Barthes, and others.

Reader-response theory recognizes the reader as an active agent who imparts “real existence” to the work and completes its meaning through interpretation. Reader-response criticism argues that literature should be viewed as a performing art in which each reader creates their own, possibly unique, text-related performance. It stands in total opposition to the theories of formalism and the New Criticism.

Fishbowl 10+1

Opening: Integrated Networking Structures

Integrated: To make into a whole by bringing all parts together; unify

Networking: An openwork fabric or structure in which cords, threads, or wires cross at regular intervals

Structures: Something made up of a number of parts that are held or put together in a particular way

Word pool:

Isabella:

Integrated: Linked, connected, coordinated, unified, joined, merge, fuse, meshed, blended

Networking: Interconnected, channels, system, arrangement, organization, order, sequence, succession

Structures: Construction, form, formation, establish, start, begin, appear

Brynn:

Integrated: merge, unite, desegregate, join, agreement, embody, assimilate, incorporate

Networking: channels, resources, navigate, circulate, chain, group, system, social

Structures: construct, edifice, formation, arrangement, organize, taxonomy, configuration, binomial, precedence

Matt:

Integrated: unified, combined, interspersed, mingled, mixed, undivided, affiliated, linked, collective, common

Networking: chain, organization, grid, system, interconnection, arrangement, orderliness, coordination, scheme, configuration

Structure: framework, design, build, order, format, institution, assembly, composition, construction, formulation

Re-structuring:

Isabella:

Integrated: CONNECTING with others can lead to friendship (Thought process of what I might use: unified, connecting, or blended)

Networking: The ORDER in which things are accomplished matters (Thought process of what I might use: channels, system, order)

Structures: The START of knowledge building can be a daunting task (Thought process of what I might use: form, start, establish)

Brynn:

Integrated: Joining together as a UNITED front creates peace.

Networking: A group effort is the key to NAVIGATE success.

Structures: To CONSTRUCT a thought requires ideas.

Matt:

Integrated: COMBINED efforts lead to the best results.

Networking: INTERCONNECTION is the key to success in modern society.

Structure: FRAMEWORKS provide the foundation upon which all else is built.

Felt experience:

Isabella: I can remember how I felt when I received my first acceptance letter into college. The ORDER in which I got my acceptance was through a large blue letter in the mail. I was shocked, astounded and proud. I was ready to START my journey as a college student, increasing my knowledge and abilities one step at a time. I was excited to CONNECT with new people and make friends, but I was also scared. I would be going to school in Rhode Island, four hours from home. I would not see my family often and would have to figure things out on my own. I was hope full I would accomplish this, but of course still hesitant.

Brynn: I was 10 years old when my parents told me I was going to be having a new sibling and I was no longer the youngest in the family. I thought I was going to get left out and the new baby would create an imbalance in the family CONSTRUCT. When we found out they were giving birth to a girl I imagined myself being forgotten as the only girl in the family once the new baby came. My Nana called me 4 hours after her arrival and I was taken to the hospital to be UNITED with her for the first time. I'm walking down the hallway nervous with butterflies and underlying excitement. I see my dad and he is pushing my new sister, Rylie, in a little cart. I lean down and look into her big blue eyes and say, "I don't get it, she looks like an alien." He told me to be quiet and to not say that in front of my mom. What I learned is that change is inevitable and we must NAVIGATE through new and different challenges.

Matt: Throughout history, humans have achieved great success by working together. We COMBINE our efforts to achieve more than any of us could alone. On any given day, I might purchase food from a grocery store grown by a faraway farmer, or a new pair of shoes manufactured overseas. Individually, I lack the skills, time and resources to produce these goods, but through our INTERCONNECTED society I have access to them. This FRAMEWORK of INTERCONNECTION is one we continue to live by, and it has become increasingly important with the advent of the Information Age and the knowledge economy.

Date: 10/25/2019 20:57:28
Subject: science of networks
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

"In the quiet corridors of academia, a new science has been emerging---one that speaks directly to the momentous events going on around it. For want of a better term, we call this new science the “science of networks.” And unlike the physics of subatomic particles or the large-scale structure of the universe, the science of networks is the science of the real world---the world of people, friendships, rumors, disease, fads, firms, and financial crises." (Duncan J. Watts). Please google his name.

We are more highly, more globally and more unexpectedly connected than at any time before it. If this connected age is to be understood, we must first understand how to describe it scientifically; that is, we need a "science of networks." According to Watts, your fishbowl is a story about that science. Not THE story, but a fragment: a single group’s journey into a strange and beautiful land of text and images.

Every such story, every such fragment, will have a perspective, a point of view. Same as this email of mine to you. And if this does not read as logical or rational science from textbooks to you, then Watt reminds us in his book The Science of A Connected Age that science doesn’t work that way. Science occurs in the same messy ambiguous world that scientists struggle to clarify, and is done by real people who suffer the same kind of limitations and confusions as anybody else.

Looking forward to your integrated networking structures on Tuesday. I have Isabella Olczak, Matt Osmanski and Brynn Rask’s hard copy, and find it endlessly fascinating in its breadth and depth, as would anybody else.

Sanjiv

Hi Everyone,

You are understanding Integrated Networking Structures in 345 and Metaphor in 443 by using the fishbowl algorithm of 10 steps. You’ll be smart to show me hard copy as a group.

From all accounts, a shift has occurred in our understanding of the meaning of “society” today. 

Understanding and experiencing this shift is essential, particularly, if you want to succeed in the workplace. 

This shift (in our understanding of society) fundamentally changes the way we think. That is, the ‘way' we make decisions has changed. 

This new way is broadly called "Design thinking."

There is a connection between society and design, and then there is culture. Three legs on this stool.

More specifically, you are structuring your learning experience (of integrated networks (345) and of metaphor (443)) by using the following methodologies:

A. You are participating and observing each other. Please google “participant observation."

B. You are socially constructing a (visual) reality among yourselves. Please google Social Construction of Reality. (Later we will get into visual reality) 

C. You are communicating symbolically. Please google Symbolic Interactionism.

In your fishbowls, whenever you select a word, you take action. By this selection, you are taking charge and your are forging your own path. You are the master of your destiny, i.e., master of your own outcome. And, when you do this, and then step back and observe, what word you chose and why, that is Action Research. Please google that term.

In a nutshell, you rock! There are no losers in this game.

Sanjiv

Prologue

Midway, this way of life we’re bound upon

I woke to find myself in a dark wood,

Where the right road was wholly lost and gone.

Aye me, how hard to speak of it,

The rude and rough and stubborn forest,

The mere breath of memory stirs the old fear in the blood.

But when, at last, I stood beneath a steep hillside,

Which closed the valley’s wandering maze,

Whose dread had pierced me to the heart root deep.

Then I looked up and saw the morning rays

Mantle its shoulder from that planet bright

Which guides men’s feet aright

On all their ways.

		(from “Divina Commedia” by Dante Alighieri)

	

		 IN THE FISH-BOWL

Creating this fish-bowl is a performative act. It is a gesture for the continuation of a story... we’re writing as we go along… we do not know where it will lead, nor where it will end…but we know this for sure, it exists in our heads.

		

This is the story of two characters, matt and sanjiv, and the narrative unfolds in new england, at a small university near the ocean…where they’re swimming in a mental fish-bowl, combining Western sensibilities with Eastern ideas…in tryst with purpose, but shunning all direction, except an inner pressure to radicalize. One Viking, the other Sikh, they progress from liberating ego structures, through deeply bled wounds onto downward spirals of hatred and feelings of isolation, and then returning with renewed joy of understanding, forgiveness, and anticipation. Bringing a surging heritage (of bravery in battle) in their bloods, their forays range from existential arguments, to sudden affectionate détentes, and finally onto other arguments. Their relationship mirrors the profound changes in their lifestyles, in their conceptions of work, and of themselves. Determined to move away from conventional categories (of the division between self and other, of the representation of individuality, of established academic standards) in order to reflect a vision of themselves that transcends these boundaries in a new way. The two characters have an odd volatile nature to their wooing…their interactions end suddenly, and generally with puzzled amusement. They improvise, fabricate, and talk about dimensions and chemistry between people… at times their minds almost meet on the same page, until one makes a tiny faux pas that the other sees as shattering…they’re able to maintain this fragility by improvising from moment to moment. That is, they allow themselves to let their personalities and moods influence their performance but not alter the words or circumstances of the scene they enact in their minds…they really have very different ways of thinking, but are able to pass the ball back and forth easily, making for spontaneous fun.

So how do they do this in the fish-bowl? Like their characters, matt and sanjiv can’t agree. “The more I do it,” sanjiv said, “ the more I realize the character is me.” For matt, “it’s a matter of stripping down my defense mechanisms to being that vulnerable again.” Sanjiv countered: “I think for me it’s more building on top of me. I think.”

This interaction ended suddenly, as many interactions between matt and sanjiv, with puzzled bemusement.

Creating a Concept: the Fish-bowl

Instead of the idea of a relationship (like, teacher/student), attached to a real place (like, College of Business at URI), we created the idea of a place, attached to real people, namely, matt-and-sanjiv-in-a-fish-bowl. In this imaginary place, the Fish-bowl, with extraordinary patience and power, through words, we agreed to project awareness and unity of self as the principle theme. 

The Fish-bowl is a meeting place of the mind; it is a metaphysical place. There is no hiding here for matt-sanjiv because they’re simultaneously, observers and observed. 	

It cannot be assumed that the Fish-bowl is a determined, ordered system intelligible to the outsider who can discover the natural laws that govern matt-sanjiv, or that the role of reason is the power guiding matt-sanjiv.

Rationally and empirically, the Fish-bowl has no significance. It can only be seen in terms of the impact that the matt-sanjiv experience will make on its existence.

			

		2.20.99

My Dear Siddharatha,

During our period of estrangement, our inward journey was around doubts as to “who I am” and, “what I stand for,” i.e. who is the authentic self? Am I this, or, am I that? 

Through thought alone, one transcends a situation (of this/that), and thus we transcended our 

situation, comprising of hurt and feelings of insult, by conceiving the fish-bowl. However, to act upon thought, (beginning with the memo allocating matt’s assistantship to sanjiv), is a contingent act… to survive, to live, to be represented. Our contingent act was a gesture demarcating matt-sanjiv representation. Gesture demarcates, and so we conceive of ourselves…

				

The fish-bowl is

 			a contingent act 

a gesture 

 			to exist. 

The betrayal 

of ideas 

is a death 

to being. 

To open one’s mind 

and one’s mental routine 

to the world

is to open one’s heart.

From, 

your very dear friend, Hermann Hesse.

Our Intent: to Play a Unique Role

Our intent is to play a unique role in education: to gain intellect not through verbal discourse per se but through presentation of thought and action; not through involvement with people in an outside world but in a Way Within or an Inward Way that presents world as inner landscape, and so carry out in practice our theme of awareness and unity of self.

Fear of Expressing Feelings

We do not always express Feelings because they’re often Confused, and even Frightening. However, to deny Feelings is to make false, restricted work. To be inauthentic and fake.

In the fish bowl we’re learning to touch Feelings. We touch through expression, i.e. expressing conceptions and perceptions of things, including each other. Particularly, differences like viking/sikh, west/east, physical/ mental, student/teacher,love/hate, and other such dimensions. 

We touch Feelings under public gaze. We have a need to go public with every thing that we say or do.

We’re developing a need to write.

Management Principle 1: Conceiving Ambiguity, Creating Possibility

Ambiguous space is nonhierarchical, horizontal. Its nodes intersect in random, unregulated networks in which any node can interconnect with any other node. We create a new form of rhizomatic knowledge by mixing metaphors. Rhizome is a complex metaphor that contrasts with rooted, 

traditional metaphors, such as, teacher/student. In the fish-bowl, matt-and-sanjiv celebrate their nomadic and schizophrenic qualities. 

We’re motivated to do this because to conceive of ambiguity is to create possibility, and the stronger the ambiguity, the greater is our creativity, and the more powerful our felt-experience.

In the fish-bowl, we’ve created an ambiguious relationship between ourselves: 

we’ve fulfilled all formal requirements (papers, etc.), yet we’re inconclusive about them (grades, etc.); 

we’re not involved in each others research, yet our interaction is research; 

matt is paid fifteen hours/week to assist sanjiv, yet it is sanjiv who assists matt.

The ambiguity in our relationship creates possibility because it allows us to be anything we want. This freedom makes us examine each other in ways we hadn’t been able to see before.

				

Management Principle 2: Creating Myth

The “fish-bowl” is an example of creating a myth. Myth is created inter-subjectively between matt and sanjiv.

“Myth (of matt-sanjiv-in-a-fish-bowl) is a system of communication, it is a message. It is a mode of signification, a form. We assign to this form historical limits, conditions of use, and reintroduce community into it: we must nevertheless first describe it as a form.” (roland barthes)

We use our imagination to describe our form of myth.

The matt-sanjiv form is diasporic ambiguity.

The college of business at URI is percieving and experiencing it.

	Management Principle 3: Create Myth/Intersubjectivity/Intertextuality

Intersubjectivity helps matt-sanjiv to see that most human experience and action goes on between the self and others.

Myth creates Inter-subjectivity; and Inter-subjectivity creates Myth. However, in the fish-bowl the notion of Intertextuality replaces that of Intersubjectivity. “Every text is constructed as a mosaic of other texts, every text is an absorbtion and transformation of other texts” (julia kristeva). Through their intersubjectivity and intertextuality, around the texts of T.E. Lawrence (Lawrence of Arabia), Rainer Rilke (German poet), and Thomas Becket (Archbishop of Canterbury), among others, matt-sanjiv create the myth of the fish-bowl.

When reading our exchange of letters, it is evident that one’s authentic self is indeed problematic in a situation where one can be anything one wants. 

		 			We can be friends forever.

Between ourselves: Mr. Kappus, T.E Lawrence, the English, Rilke, Sartre, Hesse, the German, Eriksen, Viking, Siddharatha, Buddha, the Indian, Eakins, the American, Dugal, Sikh, Baudelaire, the French, the West and the East, we’re creating an inter-textuality, an inter-subjectivity, and a shared memory. Indeed, we’re creating our context. We’re laying the foundation. 

Through this labyrinthe lies the inward journey of the subjective self. 

I find your words,“ Even when overcome by feelings of hate, I still knew that our relationship was a source of great knowledge and understanding” to be most telling of our universal condition, because the central problem is not an abstract one, but one of contingency: what we lack is certainty, confidence, sense of purpose to break paradoxical situations like feelings of hate/ and feelings of great understanding. That is, the more I hate, the more I understand, and the more I understand, the more I hate. 

			

If we had more access to our own past, to memory, to inter-textuality and inter-subjectivity, our sense of purpose would be immensely augmented. Hesse’s Steppenwolf expressed this sense of meaning due to re-possession of the past: 

“For moments together my heart stood still between delight and sorrow to find how rich was the gallery of my life, and how thronged the soul of the wretched steppenwolf with high eternal stars and constellations… the kernel of this life of mine was noble. It came of high descent and turned, not on trifles, but on the stars…”(Steppenwolf, Hesse).

From your friend, Sanjiv

Myth/Intersubjectivity/Intertextuality are Inter-connected. 

Inter-connectedness is the understanding that relations, connecting and opposing, exist. 

			Even lies are part of the truth.	

To be Inter-connected is To-Be-Aware-of-Other-Realities, 

i.e. to be aware of opposing myths, metaphors, dimensions, 

and their on-going interactive inter-subjectivities.

“matt-sanjiv-in-the-fish-bowl” are aware of the what, why, whom, and wherefrom concerning their myth.

					2.21.99

Dear Lief Erikson theViking,

One’s position within a relationship, like,Viking-Sikh, has to do with intersubjective interpretation, in other words, position is determined by our past (shared memory), our present (interpretation), and, our future (imagination). 

The activities representing the past, present, and future, are overlapping in the new millennium to the extent of becoming indistinguishable. We’re experiencing confusion, loss of control, etc. In such a situation, how do I determine my sense of self? 

To do so, I reveal a structure, or deconstruct one, or imaginatively construct one…here’s mine: “I was sent to these Arabs as a stranger, unable to think their thoughts or subscribe their beliefs, but charged by duty to lead them forward and to develop to the highest any movement of theirs profitable to England in her war. If I could not assume their character, I could atleast conceal my own, and pass among them without evident friction, neither a discord nor a critic but an unnoticed influence. Since I was their fellow I will not be their apologist or advocate. Today in my old garments, I could play the bystander, obedient to the sensibilities of our theatre…but it is more honest to record that these ideas and actions then passed naturally. What now looks wanton or sadic seemed in the field inevitable or just unimportant routine.” (T.E. Lawrence, Seven Pillars of Wisdom, 1926)

What is our intersubjective interpretation of the above text with regard to us, as Viking-Sikh? Here is a random list of specifics for us to address in the fish-bowl:locate the fear

build history

zoom in and out

raise the stakes

get specific

explore the underside

Yours truly,

				

Sardar Bahadur Singh the Sikh

Management Principle 4: Experiencing Learning

In the fish-bowl the problem of Being takes precedence over that of Knowing (when acquiring a Ph.D. or anything else). 

“Being cannot be made a subject of objective enquiry; it is revealed to the individual by reflecting on his own unique concrete existence in time and space. Existence is basic: it is the fact of the individual’s presence and participation in a changing and potentially dangerous world. Each self-aware individual understands his own existence in terms of his experience of himself and of his situation. The self of which he is aware is a thinking being which has beliefs, hopes, fears, desires, the need to find a purpose, and a will that can determine his actions.” (sartre)

	Real and Unreal:

We are free to choose between authentic and fake as a form of existence. Freedom distinguishes between “authentic” and “inauthentic” forms of existence. 

In the fish-bowl we distinguish between authentic/fake on the basis of our endeavor to transcend a particular dimension or form. 

This endeavor is the matt-sanjiv form of Authenticity.

We are free to choose our reality.

	

Management Principle 5: Creating Reality as Representational Space

I can represent something (teacher), if you represent the other (student).

You can only represent something (youth), if I represent the other (mid-life).

in this dimension we are bound

Whenever we articulate other dimensions, other myths, other inter-subjectivites, other realities, other representational spaces, we ipso facto create a temporal and spatial disjunction. 

When we articulate the meaning of a new dimension, we experience temporal and spatial disjunction as representational space. 

	Matt & Sanjiv occupy several dimensions, but their spirits are free.

					Viking and Sikh

	

	Reality of Humility/Arrogance

Matt and Sanjiv are inter-connected on the following dimension:

Humility------------------------------------------ Arrogance

Our beings “connect and oppose in relation” to this dimension. 

It is one of several operating realities between us. 

The existence of humility in matt’s being is dependent upon the existence of arrogance in sanjiv’s being; 

and the existence of humility in sanjiv’s being is dependent upon the existence of arrogance in matt’s being.

 We’re hooked.

 		We can be anything we want. It’s all in our heads.

	

Our Method: the Interplay between Verbalized-Thought and Felt-Experience

In the fish-bowl, the interplay between our two distinct identities brought complexity and depth to our respective worlds. We interpreted text (and each-other), as we saw (perceived) and felt (experienced) it. Even as we respect another’s text, we brought our subjectivity to bear upon it. We infused the text with our individual being; not the other way round. The text did not infuse us. 

In other words, we used words as expressions of sensed-thought (felt-experience) rather than as verbalized-thought in promoting the idea of unity above the inner divisions between us. Our interpreted text reveals us and reflects on us.

Example of Verbalized-thought:

“That evening, I found that I had to untangle two different reactions, writing a description of the conversation and, carefully separated, an expression of my feelings as a member of another culture. Each person is calibrated by experience, almost like a measuring instrument for difference, so discomfort is informative and offers a starting point for new understanding. Indeed, what I had seen and heard would not have pushed me to reflection and generalization were it not for the urgency produced by the sense of difference.”

(Mary Catherine Bateson, Peripheral Visions, page 17)

Example of Felt-experience:

In the fish-bowl we found

we had to untangle two processes:

description of the script (between us), 

and carefully separated, 

expression of (our) feelings.

WORDS DESCRIBE, STEP BACK, FEELINGS EXPRESS

We experience difference through the expression of feelings.

Discomfort from difference is Information;

Information is a starting point for new Understanding.

		

EXPERIENCE DIFFERENCE THRU EXPRESSION

	(My) experence, 

Makes (me)

different (from you).

difference (from you)

Makes (me) 

experience (you).

 DIFFERENCE CREATES SOMETHING NEW

The urgency produced by our sense of difference

Forces us to 

Reflect and Transcend the situation.

From the above method, what we learned about ourselves and for the practice of management were the following:

Construct a text/written script

express feelings

expressing feelings makes for difference 

sense of difference produces urgency

 			urgency requires us to reflect, and to transcend

			the written text…

Principle activity: create a sense of difference to achieve unity above inner divisions.

It’ All In Our Heads

						Thank you

								Bye…for 

now.

Epilogue

Our revels now are ended,

These are actors, as I foretold you,

We’re all spirits, and are melted into air.

And like the baseless fabric of this vision,

The cloud capp’d towers, the gorgeous palaces,

The solemn temples, the great globe itself.

Yea all which it inherit shall dissolve,

And like this insubstantial pageant faded,

Leave not a rack behind.

We are such stuff, as dreams are made of,

And our little life is rounded,

With a sleep.

(from “The Tempest” by William Shakespeare)

Hi Everyone,

Something about our process which is common to both courses...something about its methodology (social constructivism, participant-observation, social reflexivity, experiential learning, action research, and first-person auto-ethnography).

 

In your fishbowls, you’re textually doing the following:

Constructing

Collaborating

Cooperating

Creating

Engaging

Watching

Looking

Showing

Sharing

Visualizing

Imagining

You’ve been doing all this through a commitment to sorting, sifting and selecting.

It has to do with creating space: visual, mental, and experientially felt. The context is both digital and physical. It's a melding and molding and morphing, continuously into something else.

Please stop and think about your experience for each of these, whether inside or outside the fishbowl. Indeed, we are all in one big fishbowl, where opposites co-exist.

There’s a concept, which will come up again and worth considering: Recursive. As you do the above things in your fishbowls, you’re ipso facto generating and creating textual information for observation and further comment by you. It’s a recursive process. You are repeatedly looking at yourself looking at yourself. 

Through self-reflexivity and social reflexivity you are generating big-data. But let’s not get beyond ourselves. Understanding comes in steps and stages.

In the Society course, you are looking at Integrated Networking Structures, and we will work your structures and dichotomies in real time in class tomorrow, Tuesday Please come prepared to be helped.

In the Design course, you are looking at Metaphor. On Wednesday we will see metaphor's connection with symbols and design. 

It’s about having awareness. You rarely end-up where you were intending to go, but often you end-up somewhere that you needed to be. Please be aware of that in your fishbowls. Dichotomy: Intending to go/needing to be.

Granted, there’s a lot to think about. Do the basics sincerely. If you’re not used to thinking, the head will hurt, but do not give-in to distraction. NEVER GIVE IN is a worth motto.

Sanjiv

RECURSIVE, REFLEXIVE, IPSO FACTO: MELD, MOLD, MORPH, SORT, SIFT, SELECT

Date: 10/20/2019 22:34:45
Subject: social networks and new forms of sociality
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

One of the key ideas about social networks, like your fishbowl, is that the Whole becomes greater than the Sum of its Parts.

This is because we follow particular algorithms that are in addition to any specific pattern of ties that bind us.

All the ideas you have been learning in your fishbowls have been through your own practice; from infotention to collective intelligence, you are deeply intertwined with your social network and its algorithm. Only recently have we started to understand how our social networks affect us. In the late 1990s scientists began to connect the dots between network structures in physics, biology, sociology, and technical systems, to discover that:

1.Networks, for example, your fishbowls, have structures, and structures influence the way individuals and networks behave.

2. Networks extend and amplify the reach of the social to make new forms of sociality possible.

In your fishbowls, you live on the cusp of great possibilities. 

How so? 

You are Clueing in to Collaboration: Making Virtual Communities, Collective Intelligence, and Knowledge Networks Work for You (and Us). Please check it out for yourselves as to what I am saying. There is much at stake and, you are at the helm of affairs.

Sanjiv

SOCIAL, NETWORK, INTERTWINE, STRUCTURE, AFFECT, CUSP, FORM

C: BUS443: Organizational Design and Change

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/9/2019 12:55:15
Subject: idealizations
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

I wanted to say that the structures you're constructing in your fishbowls are idealizations.

Idealization is a fundamental feature of human thought. We build simplified models in our scientific research and utopias in our political imaginations. Same as you have done in the social meeting exercise. Concepts like belief, desire, reason and fairness are bound up with idealizations and ideals. Life is a constant adjustment between the models we make and realities we encounter. In idealizations (like the one’s you are constructing and creating), we proceed “as if” our representations were ideal, while knowing they are not. This is not a a dangerous or distracting occupation. Our best chance of understanding design, culture and society, and ourselves, is to open our minds to plurality of imperfect depictions that together allow us to manage and interpret our world. I hope you have experienced this among yourselves when completing the social meeting exercise. 

See you in a bit.

Sanjiv

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/8/2019 23:51:55
Subject: Is there a life after the fishbowl?
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Adam,

Thank you for your email below. I was scrolling your reflections in the fishbowl over the last two semesters, and found much depth and breadth of thought. So it is natural for me to raise the question: is there a life after the fishbowl?

Is there a life after theory? The ’thought of’ your fishbowl, seems to have come and gone, but has the moment of ‘high’ theory passed?

Much has been written and debated about this question. There are those who point out, that the word ‘after’ can mean not only ‘following in time’ but also ‘in pursuit of' or even ‘in imitation of.’ Could a life be in pursuit of theory? Could a life ever imitate theory? And, indeed, what is ‘life’? Whatever the answer to that, whatever story we tell of our past experiences, and whatever way(s) you read ‘after’, there is a widespread understanding, explicit or implicit, that ‘fishbowls’ are now experiencing something (social media) we might just call ‘life after theory.’

Whatever life our fishbowls' enact, I personally believe one’s life to be in pursuit and in search of theory. It is one's intellectual journey, and the passion of our minds.

The courses have taken off in full swing, and Students are as marvelous as ever. 

Best wishes,

Sanjiv

C: BUS 345, 443

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/7/2019 23:48:42
Subject: Further reflection on your social meeting papers
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

The presumption that we first think of what we will do forms the basis of most systems of education. The other way around---to have thought informed from or by your action---is given little credence. Yet, as everyone who works with physical material knows, thoughts continuously emerge from action and physical work. These thoughts may be considered lesser, more like hunches than the thoughts of “pure“ thinking, but they are thoughts, nonetheless. Insights, understanding, intuition, grasping---they may all be classified as “soft thoughts” more closely associated with feeling and empathic sensibility.

The words in your paper were informed by your actions during the social meeting. Thank you for your expression and sharing your thoughts.

Sanjiv

Subject: Sharing the World: Reading your social meeting reflections

Hi Everyone,

I've finished reading your social meeting assignment. 

You gave it your best shot and came out ahead. For some, 

it was a new way of developing an idea and a thought. 

The sincerity and integrity in your effort came shining through the cracks.

What you have learnt and experienced thus far are the following research methodologies...

Self-reflection

Participative observation

Symbolic interaction

Auto-ethnography

Dichotomous thinking

Structures and structuring

Interpretation

Sharing thoughts and mental processes

Please google the above terms. Sort and select your understanding of these terms, one sentence for each and share them in your fishbowl.

A favorite quote from Luce Irigaray's (please google her name) book “Sharing the World”:

“We cannot share the world as it already is, with the exception of the natural world. The world that we can share is always and still to be elaborated by us and between us starting from the perception and affirmation of what and who we are as humans here and now."

Sanjiv

Date: 10/5/2019 15:17:26
Subject: creating and constructing knowledge content
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Your text in the fishbowl is nascent and in a state of formation.... I am reminded of two sentences:

“In the 'world of immersion,' authorship is no longer the transmission of experience, but rather the construction of utterly personal experiences.” Brenda Laurel (please google)

"The task of thinking is based upon selection and weeding out: Remembering every thing is weirdly similar to forgetting. Most things that people do shouldn’t be remembered. Maybe forgetting is good.” Gary Wolf 

Your social meeting exercise was a step towards learning to create and construct a knowing (personal experience) and a knowledge content (selecting and weeding).

Sanjiv
