------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 10/4/2019 16:07:43
Subject: assemblages
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

What your viewer sees you doing in the fishbowl, and specifically in the Social Meeting exercise, is reassembling your group.

"Reassembling the Social" is the title of Bruno Latour’s book (please google) which is an introduction fo Actor-Network Theory. Please google.

We’re looking at our fishbowls as assemblages. Our approach is the 'sociology of associations’ where we scrutinize the exact content of what is being assembled.

The society of your group, and the meaning of the word society in the digital environment, considers two distinct things: the process of assembling; and the type of material that is distinct from others. In other words, how are you going about creating and constructing an assembly of words that is materially different from other assemblages.

Please google Actor Network Theory.

Sanjiv

Hi Everyone,

As we come in with our "pre-narrative" and "pre-individual" notions about what to expect (Please see Opening Statement for my Annual Review), I want to point out a sentence from your syllabus:

“The ability to share information --- and to be believed --- becomes an important source of attraction and power.”

So there you have it. You want to construct a Society and do Business in it? 

Then by the end of the semester, you have to demonstrate soft power.

Does this sound like an English writing class? The answer is NO.

Tip: It takes one word, one concept, one element, one step at a time.

See you in the fishbowl.

Hi Everyone,

Re-framing and re-phrasing is re-designing. The re- is the mantra. 

In a digital environment, we create structures. 

You just did so in your fishbowls with the social meeting exercise. 

Thus far you have experienced the following:

Structuring

Re-structuring

Dichotomy

Symbol

Juxtapose

Story telling

Abstracting

Conceptualizing

You gained perspective from different points of view. There is another step for deeper learning yet. You must compare and contrast your differences in the experience of your social meeting. It is our words that create meaning. 

Working in this way, you are constructing meaning in your groups. You have no idea where it will lead... Forget goals in this course. In your group, you have real possibility. The question is do you have courage.

GOAL, POSSIBILITY, COURAGE

Learning is an act of courage.

Sanjiv

Date: 10/2/2019 2:08:11
Subject: meeting once again
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

It was good to see you again. The face and its expression are both important in the management of aesthetics. The field of aesthetics is big, and has been for some time.

Your social meeting exercises are the 'management of aesthetics of story telling.’ Please google the term. It is always good to know what you are doing and why you are doing it. In other words, the theory behind the things we do. 

Aesthetics. Good word.

I’m looking forward to reading your papers. You must have been uncomfortable in the doing of abstracting, but ultimately, I hope, a feeling of satisfaction. It is our abstractions that give us satisfaction. They are aphorisms and axioms. They are the reason why we sing sappy love songs. It keeps us connected. We welcome both the right and wrong of things, because that is who we are as a group.

I have good vibes about our class. We might write a paper on friendship in the workplace and the management of aesthetics of story telling, and present ourselves digitally and in person. We can do anything we want, so long as we do it together and we are open to our differences. Indeed, we seek them and rejoice in them. BUT, we want to make money while we’re at it.

Sanjiv

Date: 9/18/2019 14:42:08
Subject: reading the other's text
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Reading the other’s posting should not be drudgery, and not mere escape either, but a way to live life at a higher pitch. Whenever we read a good posting, it is a pathway to finding ourselves, by getting lost in the words and works of others.

We are overdoing cruising; skimming and skipping. It’s an addiction of chasing something else...

There is another mode of reading --- the kind that requires your full attention and that has as its goal not the mere gathering of information or chasing something else, but the deeper understanding that only good postings can offer.

At a practical level, The Fishbowl is a guide for anyone who yearns for a more meaningful and satisfying reading experience, and who wants to sharpen reading skills and improve concentration.

You want to provide a more immersive, fulfilling experience to your viewers, readers, peers and colleagues. The alternative is hop-skip and jump!

Sanjiv

Subject: Simulating a society
------------------------------------------------------------
Good morning Everyone,

We will address all difficulties in the fishbowl today.

We will discuss the purpose and logic of the fishbowl.

The Fishbowl is a communicative practice. Mostly in your head.

In the ever-changing world (thanks to visual networks), new platforms often lead to momentous formations that dramatically transform our understanding. 

Your fishbowls are growing digital life forms. They are laboratories of the future and they are essential tools of a controversial new scientific method.

This new method is founded not on direct observation and experiment but on the mapping of the universe from real space into cyberspace. The world in a grain of sand! There is a whole new science happening here---the science of simulation.

Sanjiv

Date: 9/16/2019 14:01:26
Subject: re-structuring again
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

Please REVIEW Juell Milder's process below. It is an excellent first attempt and COURAGE must always be applauded. 

Courage is a sign of leadership, as we all know.

Now let us proceed to “critique" it. 

“Criticism,” please google, is a pedagogical tool. Good to have some aspect of it under your belt. Or, at least to know what it means.

An aside: At RISD and Brown, their Adms. invite faculty from along the eastern seaboard to critique students’ work. Makes for interesting interaction with students.

In this instance, you may PRESUME that I REPRESENT UMass, Amherst, Indian Administrative Service, Delhi School of Economics, St.Stephens College and Lawrence School, Sanawar. That’s 5 different points of views and experiences; perspectives. 

We each have a "pre-individual" that affects our PERCEPTION of the world in the present moment. It is good to get at the pre-individual, as early as possible. More on this later.

BTW, talking about perception, many thinkers believe the world to be in a state of perceptual CRISIS.

That’s Huge.

Coming to the text below: 

There is an opening SYNTAX in a. This OPENING, MAKES an ENTRANCE, a STANCE and an ATTITUDE. It sets the stage (theatre metaphor) for what is to follow in EMPTY SPACE. What is to be DEPICTED.

Numbers i to viii are fine-tuning and highlighting NUANCE in the meaning of key words.

The last sentence is the RE-STRUCTURE.

The question that always remains: can you re-structure again and do better?

Sanjiv

From the fishbowl...

a.	Imaginization- “Precise meaning and significance will vary according to the frame of reference through which it is viewed.” 

i.	Precise- exactness 

ii.	Meaning- The significance of something

iii.	Significance- with meaning

iv.	Vary- To show difference 

v.	According – agreeing 

vi.	Frame- to make a border enclosing something

vii.	Reference – the action of mentioning to something 

viii.	View- to have sight of something 

b.	For each word go to dictionary and write the meaning of the words

c.	Coming up with a sentence with that domain of words- don’t need all the words

“Though beliefs vary, they hold much significance according to a person’s viewpoint or frame of reference.”

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/14/2019 1:11:11
Subject: a designer's notes
------------------------------------------------------------
Hi Everyone,

We learn from each other’s notes. I love the way the Notes below range widely. The author’s (sschultheiss22) mind is wonderfully free and her associations interesting and sometimes profound---a marvelous and interesting text.

What exactly is the importance of your Notes? It’s a rich portfolio of experiences, adventures, and failures that teach vital lessons. Your notes raise questions about life that we all ask about one’s meaning and purpose in the world; questions such as: How do I find a job that I like or maybe even love? ... How do I balance my career with my family? ... How can I make a difference in the world?

We all want answers to these questions. We’re just not sure how to go about finding them, or where or how to begin. And we feel the we don’t have the tools to find our way. Designers love questions, but what they really love is ‘reframing' questions. The reframing for the question “What do I want to do when I graduate?” is “What do I want to grow into?”

Sanjiv

The Fishbowl as a pedagogical device, is engagement through exchange of words, not lecturing mass audiences.

Date: 9/13/2019 14:54:29
Subject: sharing what we see when we read
------------------------------------------------------------
Letter: sharing what we see when we read

Hi Everyone,

We are at the beginning of a series of letters (around 100) during the course of the semester. 

The question we’re confronted with, particularly in a digital environment, is always the same one: what do I say? 

What is the opening line? 

Where and when do I enter?

Theatre is a good metaphor to see our selves.

THEATRE, METAPHOR, SEE, IMAGE

So, what is your move?

What is the play?

What is the frame?

What is the structure?

What is the scene? 

MOVE, PLAY, FRAME, STRUCTURE, SCENE

What should I say, when I lean across the aisle?

ACROSS, AISLE

What is the opening sentence? 

Your first thought? 

Your image?

Your feeling?

What is your syntax?

SYNTAX

Difficult questions.

You are interpreting my letter, in the moment of reading, by raising the question: what do my words mean? 

And, you answer this question by becoming a hub (a centre-point) in a “network of information” that technology allows for endless expansion and re-configuration (of your network). We’re becoming this hub through our senses whenever we scroll text and images on our digital screens. We’re in a continual state of “becoming” (please google with Deleuze).

In this way, you CONJURE images in your mind and feelings in your body with regards to my (or anyone else’s) text.

What do you ‘see’ when you read is a relevant question today.

RELEVANT

This relevancy (what we ‘see’ when we read) is born out of our singularity and difference.

In this circumstance, connecting across differences is the way forward into the future. 

Connectivity is our destiny.

Sharing what we see when we read one word at a time.

Sanjiv

READING, INTERPRET, PROCESS, HUB, NETWORK, BECOME (please google Deleuze), SINGULARITY, DIFFERENCE, CONNECT, DESTINY

You are interpreting my letter, in the moment of reading, by raising the question: what do my words mean? 

And, you answer this question by becoming a hub (a centre-point) in a “network of information” that technology allows for endless expansion and re-configuration (of your network). We’re becoming this hub through our senses whenever we scroll text and images on our digital screens. We’re in a continual state of “becoming” (please google with Deleuze).

In this way, you CONJURE images in your mind and feelings in your body with regards to my (or anyone else’s) text.

What do you ‘see’ when you read is a relevant question today.

RELEVANT

This relevancy (what we ‘see’ when we read) is born out of our singularity and difference.

In this circumstance, connecting across differences is the way forward into the future. 

Connectivity is our destiny.

Sharing what we see when we read one word at a time.

Sanjiv

“I am looking at you, looking at me, looking at you” 

The full version comes from the novel "Read Me" Leo Bendictus: "We look into each other´s eyes and suddenly I am looking at you, looking at me, looking at you looking at me looking at you". This was a significant way of symbolizing love in its deepest and truest form. 

Quote Professor Sanjiv Dugal “ Keep your eyes open, do not blink”. Be in the moment, be aware of your surroundings and be curious.

We learn through symbolic interaction, which is a theory that develops from practical considerations and alludes to people's particular utilization of dialect to make images and normal implications, for deduction and correspondence with others based on the work of Charles Horton Cooley and George Herbert Mead. 

We learn through sharing, imagination and experience, which together formed images of how we individually see the world. One must understand how people in society see the world in order to learn and function in a well balanced matter. 

Outcomes from this class discussion: 

1. We are learning one word at a time.

2. We are learning how to create word structure (sentences).

3. We are sharing the images that these words evoke.

As we do all of these things we become a society and "to form a society you have to share your felt experiences". 

"You can have anything you want if you learn how to structure image and text in a manner that makes it impossible to say no to you". 

Vocabulary: 

Sociality: the instance of social intercourse or sociability, the tendency to associate in or form social groups. "This parceling of jobs is the defining feature of the most extreme form of social society, called eusociality or true sociality".

Individuation: Individuation is the process by which an individual becomes distinct. Individuation distinguishes you from everybody else. The word individual is a good clue to the meaning of individuation, which is how a being becomes an independent, separate entity.

Gilbert Simondon - French Philosopher: Gilbert Simondon was a French philosopher best known for his theory of individuation, a major source of inspiration for Gilles Deleuze and Bernard Stiegler.

Reflection -important: serious thought or consideration. 

Flow (Image of things flowing, like water): to move with a continual change of place among the constituent particles

Text, words (linked to images): the original words and form of a written or printed work and an edited or emended copy of an original work.

Jarques Derrida → Deconstruction (this is the steps we will be following for deconstructing words/text): Originated by philosopher Jacques Derrida, deconstruction is an approach to understanding the relationship between text and meaning. Derrida's approach consisted of conducting readings of texts looking for things that run counter to the intended meaning or structural unity of a particular text.

Kaputt: utterly finished, defeated, or destroyed

Anthony Giddens → Social Reflexivity: Giddens introduces reflexivity and in information societies information gathering is considered as a routinised process for the greater protection of the nation. Information gathering is known as the concept of individuation. Individuality comes as a result of individuation as people are given more informed choices. The more information the government has about a person, the more entitlements are given to the citizens. 

Practice and process: A method, procedure, process, or rule used in a particular field or profession; a set of these regarded as standard.

Thank you for the letters and looking forward to the semester!

Hi Everyone,

It takes focus to tune-in with Feelings and Images and Words. Emotions are evoked by Text and Images. Always has been. This trinity drives our actions. Furthermore, it is now on our digital screens and at our finger-tips. The images we see on our screens are determined by the decisions we make on our key boards. Thereby we evoke emotions felt in our bodies.

There is an overlap of the two courses 443 and 345 and the letters will be common. This is because we have to get up to speed with things like metaphor, framework, distance, perspective, imagination, space, experience, learning,.... However, the difference is in the subject matter; the contemplation is different for Society and Design.

In both courses, you are Making Space. Consciously or not, we feel and internalize what the space tells us about how to work. When you enter the third floor of Ballantine, the space tells you that it’s meant for a group of people to work alone.

In BUS345 we are making a social space among ourselves.

In BUS443, we are designing an innovative space.

Sanjiv

------------------------------------------------------------
Date: 9/9/2019 0:16:51
Subject: Syllabus: BUS443: Organizational Design &amp; Change
------------------------------------------------------------
UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND 

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS 

FALL, 2019

Instructor: Sanjiv S. Dugal, Ph.D.

Dept. of Entrepreneurship and Human Resource Management Email: sanjivdugal@uri.edu

Office: 314 Ballentine Hall

Office hours: Tue/Wed by Appointment

BUS443: Organizational Design and Change

“Imagination is more important than knowledge. To raise new questions, new possibilities, to regard old

problems from a new angle, requires creative imagination and marks real advance in science.”

Albert Einstein

I. Introduction

BUS443 is a step-by-step guide on deploying design thinking for creating innovative outcomes for organizing and organizations in digital space. 'Design thinking' is a mindset and method that can be applied to create a new challenge or endeavor within an online organization.

In the course, we define innovation as a viable offering (an idea expressed in text/image) that is new to a specific context and time, creating the provider and/or user-value. Using structured methods for observation, interpretation, reframing, ideation, prototyping, and planning, BUS443 will develop your abilities for deploying 'design thinking' for creating innovative outcomes.

II. Online Interactive Design for Change: The Fishbowl

In groups of three, you will develop a network (aka the Fishbowl) of interacting "knowledge-workers" and “design-thinkers” whose impact and value is determined by the level of engagement with each other's text.

Ultimately, in BUS443, you learn to design an interactive communication system that produces knowledge and knowing from felt-experiences and the outcomes have value to you as designer, and to others as viewers.

III. Reference Textbooks

1. Action Trumps Everything: Creating What You Want in an Uncertain World by Charles F. Kiefer and Leonard A. Schlesinger

with Paul B. Brown. Black Ink Press, 2010.

2. 'Living Text: Letters from the Fishbowl,' by Sanjiv S. Dugal, College of Business, Univ. of Rhode Island, Fall, 2019.

IV. Method in the Fishbowl

Facilitating processes for self-organization (both individually and collectively) is an important part of what you do in the course.

The following methodologies are used to facilitate your process: First Person Action Research, Social Constructivism, Design Thinking, Critical Engagement, Dialogism, Reflexivity,

Digital Literacy and Active Learning.

V. Performance: Practice and Commitment

Your work is done online and in your own time. However, you'll soon discover that in order to survive, you must show-up, turn-on and tune-in, every time. It is your focused presence that will develop conversation and dialogue in the group, and you begin the process of formulating a design. Furthermore, since there are few deadlines in the course, you have an increased responsibility to each other. You're making a commitment to your group members that you'll be there every time. What is expected of you is to read and respond to each other in a timely manner.

The following four relational practices will directly impact your performance in your social group:

1. Communication, i.e., dialogical exchange of views 

2. Collaboration, i.e., interactively creating something 

3. Cooperation, i.e., working towards a common goal 

4. Contribution, i.e., committing to sharing your process

VI. Evaluation and Assessment: Learning Process and Learning Outcome

Your work is evaluated on the basis of your group's final Design. HOW did you do it? It is your learning processes along with their outcomes that are of interest.

The cornerstone for evaluating your learning process and its outcome is twofold:

a. Transparency: is your learning process visible and self-evident? 

b. Authentic: is your learning outcome real and true?

Your final Design is really a Critical Thinking Model whose development is based upon three over-lapping activities during the semester:

1. Online group dynamics;

2. Levels of engagement; and,

3. Creating meaning and significance from group interaction.

In other words, your evaluation and assessment is based upon the following three questions and answers:

(1) How do you create a group dynamic that is visible (transparent) and true (authentic)?

Answer: By generating subjectivities, i.e., generating things dependent upon your mind and upon your

perceptions for their existence.

(2) How do you determine levels of engagement in your group that are visible and true?

Answer: By producing new ideas, thoughts and suggestions as to possible courses of action.

(3) How do you create meaning and significance from your group interaction?

Answer: By expanding your range of experiences, i.e., the range of events and occurrences that left an

impression on your minds.

VII. Grade Distribution

20% Taking and Making Notes

You're setting up a process for taking and making notes. This process is an important one because it involves making decisions and

engaging in thought processes, both inside and outside the classroom. It is Active Learning as note-taking and note-making, i.e.,

you're doing something with the information you're receiving. Active listening and active reading means active learning.

'Summaries, Recollections, Revisions and Focusing are four elements which together constitute Active Learning.'

10% Developing Vocabulary

Your vocabulary is the set of words within 'the language of the course' that becomes familiar to you over the semester. Your

vocabulary will serve as a useful and fundamental tool for communicating and acquiring knowledge during the semester.

Developing an extensive vocabulary is one of the largest challenges in learning anything new.

30% Interpreting Letters

You will receive over 100 letters from the Instructor during the semester. Whenever a letter points to a certain topic, pay close

attention to it. You are constantly assessing what you're listening and reading and, you're deciding whether it is important enough to

take further and probe deeper.

40% Four Exercises and Final Design

There will be four exercises that you will develop interactively in groups of three, during the period of the course. Your purpose in

completing these exercises is to develop a Critical Thinking Model that encapsulates your "way of doing knowledge."

Your Design (Critical Thinking Model) is then applied to a business situation. This application of your model is your final posting in your fishbowl. It is a group effort, submitted in three pages, typed double-space.

VIII. Concluding Remarks: Attitude and Motivation

Your attitude and motivation is calibrated by how important you consider the material that you're receiving. When something resonates, it motivates one to go deeper by discovering the essence of it. However, it is your attitude that holds the key. Active learning involves sitting in a good posture: slouching makes your brain slouch! Work is assigned online on a daily and a weekly basis and operates like a nested Russian Doll where each doll contains another smaller doll. Your final document is a group effort and is the smallest doll; 3 pages and typed double-space.

Welcome to BUS443

Addendum 1: Five Objectives stated by the University of Rhode Island:

1. Acquiring skills in working with others as a member of a team.

2. Developing creative capacities (writing, inventing, designing, performing).

3. Developing skill in expressing oneself in writing.

4. Learning how to critically evaluate ideas, arguments, and points of view. 5. Acquiring an interest in learning more by asking questions and seeking answers.

Success requires that you keep pace with the work, understand course concepts, and study effectively.

The Academic Enhancement Center (www.uri.edu/aec) is a great place to do this. At the AEC you can work alone or in groups, and

tutors and professional learning specialists are available to help you to learn, manage your time and work, and study well. The URI Writing Center, located in Roosevelt Hall 009 (lower level, Memorial Union end), offers one-on-one and small group peer tutoring for student writers in all majors who need help developing ideas or would benefit from advice on any aspect of writing. The WC serve all student writers, not just “beginners.” Writers are encouraged to bring a draft, notes, syllabus, or any relevant information to help facilitate the session. Appointments are 45 minutes in length and can be scheduled online at uri.mywconline.com. It's best to make appointments in advance, especially during midterms and finals, but we often have same-day and drop-in appointments available throughout the day so writers can stop by to see what's open. For more information visit uri.edu/aec/writing.

They’re open Monday through Thursday from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. and Fridays until 1 p.m. All services are free (the coffee is free as well!), and no appointment is needed. You can call them for complete information at 874-2367, or just stop by the center on the fourth floor of Roosevelt Hall.

Date: 9/9/2019 0:14:18
Subject: Syllabus: BUS345: Business in Society
------------------------------------------------------------
UNIVERSITY OF Rhode Island

COLLEGE OF BUSINESS

FALL 2019

BUSINESS IN SOCIETY

BUS 345

INSTRUCTOR: SANJIV S. DUGAL

OFFICE HOURS: TUE/WED BY APPOINTMENT

“Word-work is sublime …. because it is generative; it makes meaning that secures our difference, our human difference—-the way in which we are like no other life. We die. That may be the meaning of life. But we do language. That may be the measure of our lives.”

—Toni Morrison

I. INTRODUCTION: BACKDROP TO THE COURSE

All major social changes are ultimately characterized by a transformation of space and time in the human experience. The most profound social change is taking place in the transformation of communication. New communication technologies are fostering the development of social spaces of visual reality. The Internet is the backbone of this global computer-mediated communication (CMC): it is the network that links up most computer networks. According to sources collected by Vinton Cerf, in 2001 the Internet connected about 63 million computer hosts, 950 million telephone terminations, five million level 2 domains, 3.6 million web sites and was used by 179 million people in more than 200 countries. The International Telecommunications Union reports that in 2010, the number of Internet users will surpass two billion. According to Internet World Stats, of these over 41 percent are in Asia, with North America accounting for 15.7 per cent of total users. Two thirds of global Internet users are non-English speakers enhancing the cross-cultural context of the Internet.

BUS345: Business in Society is placed within the framework of two fundamental transformations in our daily lives: the individualization of work and the fragmentation of societies. 

II. BUILDING A SOCIETY: THE NETWORK AND VISUAL REALITY

Participants develop two interrelated concepts during the course of the semester: The Network Society and Visual Reality. In groups of 3, you will develop a ‘flow’ of information which is a network shaped by algorithms and, continually accessible on your screens. The result is a visual reality, a ‘way of seeing’ and being in the world. 

A ‘way of seeing’ is the key manifestation of “the network society” according to Manuel Castells (The Rise of The Network Society, 2nd ed., 2010, Wiley-Blackwell). The underlying question being: what is your ‘way of seeing’ your world? What is the visual reality of your network society? In the course, you are developing networks and visual realities characterized by the instantaneous flow of word-images. Your networks reflect distinctive realities that are ‘individuations’ outside any academic or state regulation. That is to say, you are developing social relations (forms of relatedness) that are manifestations of your network and flow of information. 

(a) The Network Society: An Assemblage

It is natural to desire for a society of like-minded aesthetes who admire their assemblages of text and images (Bruno Latour). The desire to assemble is as much a metaphor for community as the aesthetic creation. Participating in assembly incarnates an ideal of plurality, of multiplicity and multifariousness. The student’s participation is dialogue and responsiveness; multifarious, accumulative, assemblages. You are artists, learners and writers. 

(b) A Visual Reality: Assembling Your World-View

Visual reality involves the things that we see, the mental model we all have on how to see, and what we can do as a result. That is why we call it visual reality: a reality of the visual. It is not simply the total amount of images that you see, such as YouTube. It is the relation between what is visible (image) and names (words) that you give to what is seen; word-images. This also involves what is invisible or kept out of sight. In short, we don’t simply see what is shown and call it a visual reality. Rather, we “assemble” a worldview that is constant with what we know and have already experienced. Visual reality is the study of how to understand something in a world too enormous to see but vital to imagine. Simply put, the question at stake in a visual world is how to see the world. More precisely, it involves how to see the world in a time of dynamic change and vastly expanded quantities of imagery, implying many different points of view arising from different networks of information. Visual reality regards images as central to the representation of meaning in the world.

III. COURSE METHOD: ETHNOGRAPHIC ACTION RESEARCH

Ethnographic Action Research (EAR) is a form of participatory action research. The ethnographic approach combined with action research means that the course builds upon notions of immersion, long-term engagement and understanding local contexts holistically. A foundational concept of EAR is ‘communicative ecologies.’ This involves paying attention to wider contexts of information and communication flows and channels, formal and informal, technical and social, to understand communication opportunities and barriers.

A communicative ecology is made up of communicative assemblages and refers to the complex systems of communication, media and information flows in a community. Whenever you start to notice HOW your group members communicate around certain themes, or HOW they accomplish certain tasks, you start to appreciate which channels and flows are used and why; and, how this relates to other possible uses, and therefore, where are the opportunities and barriers to a development initiative.

Basically, the course combines three approaches: participatory techniques, ethnography and action learning. Participatory techniques are used to help participants understand complex issues in an inclusive and participatory manner. Ethnography has traditionally been used to understand different cultures in detail, and reject preconceived ideas and categorize in favor of locally emergent ones. Action learning allows you to turn what you learn from re-search into actions, re-search those actions, and adjust and adapt accordingly.

IV. PHENOMENOLOGY

In the course, you work like phenomenologists whose dictum is: Describe phenomena. The things that are described denote any ordinary thing or object or event as it presents itself to your experience, rather than as it may or may not be in reality.To ‘describe’ is to strip away distractions, habits, cliches of thought, presumptions and received ideas, in order to return attention to what is called ‘things in themselves.’ To capture them exactly as they appear, rather than as we think they are supposed to be. Like wine-tasting. In the course, you ‘set aside’ or ‘bracket out’ theorizing and moralizing about what the thing is, so that you are left only with the intense and immediate experience of the phenomenon. The result is a great liberation. It frees you to talk about your experience as a serious topic of investigation. The course gives a formal mode of access to your human experience. 

You’re concerning yourselves with concrete felt-experiences. You talk about your own lives while still being methodical and rigorous. Your rigor has to do with describing phenomenon. Saying the music concert or the homework assignment was great is not enough. You have to stay loyal to describing experience. Traditionally, we began learning with abstract axioms or theories from textbooks. In this course, you’re going straight for life as you experience it, moment to moment. What does it mean to Be in this moment? Anticipation, perhaps? What is it for a thing, like ‘anticipation’ to be? Until you ask this, you will not get anywhere. The method is to disregard intellectual clutter and pay attention to ‘things’ and let them reveal themselves to you.

V. PRACTICE AND PROCESS

The method practiced is both a process and an outcome. It begins with the simple act of paying attention to a word with care and respect. Word practices are found in many traditions around the globe. It is having the awareness that arises by non-judgmentally paying attention on purpose in the present moment. Breathing is a big one! This awareness is a combination of receptivity, like listening, alertness and attentive presence. Letting everything else be in the background or letting it go entirely.

The course requires a different thinking; a thinking that knowing, reminds you, awakens you, brings you to yourself, transforms you. Besides claiming to transform the way you think about doing business in society, the course promises to change how you think about yourselves. In the end, you have no other interest than this: to reconnect with normal lived-experience. There is no traced-out path that will lead you; you must constantly invent your own path. But to invent it, you have to be free, responsible, without excuse, for every hope lies within you. In other words, you are to inhabit your world of ideas (words). You are not following a simplistic set of rules, but you are expected to show how you are living your ideas (words); lived abstraction (Gilbert Simondon). 

By the end of the course, you want to be able to see how you occupy ideas, abstractions and words; how you move about and how you conduct yourself in social space. How you write your narrative!

VI. “IS THERE A TEXT IN THIS CLASS?” 

For an online class, the Viewer takes on greater importance, because the interpretation of text and images are determined, at least in part, by the context in which they are received and viewed. It is you, as the audience, that plays an important role in producing meaning. And, you are together creating “interpretive communities” (Stanley Fish).

References:

1. Manuel Castells, 2010, The Rise Of The Network Society, Vol.1-3, Wiley-Blackwell

2. Margaret Dikovitskaya, 2005, Visual Culture, M.I.T. Press

3. David Harvey, 1990, The Condition of Post Modernity, Blackwell

4. Nicholas Mirzoeff, 2016, How To See The World, Basic Books

5. Mike Chang and Nigel Thrift, Eds, 2000, Thinking Space, Routledge

6. Zygmunt Bauman, 2003, Liquid Love, Polity

7. Anthony Giddens, 1986, The Constitution of Society, California University Press

8. Antonio Negri, 2008, The Porcelain Workshop: For a New Grammar of Politics, Semiotext(e)

9. Bruno Latour, 2007, Reassembling the Social, Oxford

10. Gilbert Simondon, 2012: Being and Technology, Arne De Boever (ed.) Edinburgh University Press 

VII. SKILL SET: DEVELOPING INITIATIVES OF SOFT POWER

Soft power is the ability to attract and co-opt, rather than coerce (hard power). Soft power is the ability to shape the preferences of others through appeal and attraction. The currency of soft power is culture, values and expressiveness. 

You are learning to influence your audience by developing “soft power,” i.e., the multiple and overlapping possibilities of endless writing and endless accumulation encompassing not only collectible objects and experiences but also a more abstract pursuit of the new, the life-changing, and the mind-altering.

Joseph Nye of Harvard University coined the term in a 1990 book, “Bound to Lead: The Changing Nature of American Power.” In this book, he wrote: “when one country gets other countries to want what it wants—might be called co-optive or soft power in contrast with the hard or command power of ordering others to do what it wants.” Nye further developed the concept in his 2004 book, “Soft Power: The Means to Success in World Politics.” 

In the course, you are expected to increase soft power, give a good narrative of your social group, and better communicate your messages to the world. In 2012, Nye explained that with soft power, "the best propaganda is not propaganda", further explaining that during the Information Age, "credibility is the scarcest resource."

In BUS 345, you are developing skills to convince viewers of the advantages of your semantic and action-orienting powers.

VIII. ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATION: FORMING A SOCIETY

In a digital world, we’re creating visual communities and networks that cut across (national) borders. Transnational corporations and nongovernmental actors, like yourselves, are playing larger roles. Many organizations seek to attract others into coalitions that cut across differences. Leadership becomes, in part, a competition for attractiveness, legitimacy, and credibility. The ability to share information—and to be believed—becomes an important source of attraction and power.

It is well documented that the relative role of soft power to hard power will increase in a global world. Your success under these circumstances will have the following two characteristics: multiple channels of communication that helped you frame issues; and, credibility that is enhanced by sustained practices and processes. When undertaking any developmental initiative, it is, ultimately, your sustained practices and processes that will determine success.

IX. GRADE: INDIVIDUATION 

Individuation (Glbert Simondon), or the way you distinguish yourself from others, is always in relationship and it is a process. Individuation makes awareness, action and evaluation possible. 

At the end of the day, after it is all said and done, your grade is determined by two things: level of engagement and creation of value. How often, how much and to what end did you develop and individuate yourself? 

You are expected to open and archive the following Topics:

1. Notes: Taking and Making Notes

2. Vocabulary: Developing concepts

3. Reading: Deconstructing Letters 

4. Interactive Assignments

5. Individual Assignments

X. GRADE: DISTRIBUTION

1. Transnational Organizations 25%

You are interacting online in groups of 3 during the semester. You are experientially learning about characteristics attributed to successful transnational organizations.

Namely, Integrated Networking Structures, Complex Adaptive Systems, Dynamic Decision-Making and Unique Innovative Capabilities.

2. Deep Reading: Concepts, Images, Frames, Perspectives: 25%

You are developing slower and essential cognitive processes such as critical thinking, reflection, and empathy—-all parts of deep reading. What you read, how you read, and why you read changes how you think. The quality of your reading is not only an index of the quality of your thought, it is the best-known path to developing whole new path-ways.

3. Deconstructing Letters: 25%

The act of taking on the perspective and feelings of others is communication effected in solitude and depicts an intimate emotional dimension within the reading experience. Through analogies, drawing inferences, and arriving at independent judgments, you will generate feelings and experiences.

4. Finally: A Selfie 25%

An exercise on visual reality: looking at yourself looking at yourself.

There will be privacy issues to consider if video is used to make recordings for course review. 

EPILOGUE

BUS345 is about becoming who you are. By completing the course, you are not arriving at any fixed destination nor will you find some permanent room with a view. But you will see and experience for yourselves that whenever you search for the highest, you become who you are. 

WELCOME TO BUSINESS IN SOCIETY

Addendum 1: Five Objectives stated by the University of Rhode Island

1. Acquiring skills in working with others as a member of a team.

2. Developing creative capacities (writing, inventing, designing, performing).

3. Developing skill in expressing oneself in writing.

4. Learning how to critically evaluate ideas, arguments, and points of view. 5. Acquiring an interest in learning more by asking questions and seeking answers.

Success requires that you keep pace with the work, understand course concepts, and study effectively.

The Academic Enhancement Center (www.uri.edu/aec) is a great place to do this. At the AEC you can work alone or in groups, and

tutors and professional learning specialists are available to help you to learn, manage your time and work, and study well. The URI Writing Center, located in Roosevelt Hall 009 (lower level, Memorial Union end), offers one-on-one and small group peer tutoring for student writers in all majors who need help developing ideas or would benefit from advice on any aspect of writing. The WC serve all student writers, not just “beginners.” Writers are encouraged to bring a draft, notes, syllabus, or any relevant information to help facilitate the session. Appointments are 45 minutes in length and can be scheduled online at uri.mywconline.com. It's best to make appointments in advance, especially during midterms and finals, but we often have same-day and drop-in appointments available throughout the day so writers can stop by to see what's open. For more information visit uri.edu/aec/writing.

They’re open Monday through Thursday from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. and Fridays until 1 p.m. All services are free (the coffee is free as well!), and no appointment is needed. You can call them for complete information at 874-2367, or just stop by the center on the fourth floor of Roosevelt Hall.
